title: THE REGION ; ;  Chemical Spill Ties Up Traffic
description: A truck carrying toxic chemicals overturned on the New Jersey Turnpike early today, spilling some of its cargo into a creek that feeds the Hackensack River and causing major traffic jams.

title: PATENTS ; Signal Gear Assists Firefighter in Danger
description: New emergency signaling equipment to be worn by firefighters or other workers is designed to inform a central station when anyone is in trouble and where. According to patent 4,468,656, granted this week to Thomas J. Clifford of Massapequa, L.I., and Bernard L. Jansen of Northport, L.I., there are many reports of firefighters being killed in burning buildings because they were unable to alert outside colleagues of their plight.

title: FERRARO SEES NO DANGER OF ECLIPSING MONDAE
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, buoyed after a six- state campaign swing marked by cheering, flag-waving crowds, says her candidacy is in no danger of eclipsing that of Walter F. Mondale.

title: FILLING A CHILD'S NEEDS AS THE SCHOOL BELL RINGS
description: A distinctly back-to-school wool sweater, with a little red schoolhouse against a blue background, is available at Chocolate Soup, 946 Madison Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets. The store also stocks dresses for elementary school children, and there is a large variety of other colorful sweaters.

title: G.M. Missouri Unit Shifting to Indiana
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would close its truck assembly operations in St. Louis and build a new $500 million plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., to build full-size pickup trucks.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $295,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $729,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $529,000 in the quarter and $723,000 for the year. d-After a loss of $295,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,852,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: Your Name, Please

title: PATENTS ; Two Advances In Transmission
description: The National Security Agency, at Fort Meade, Md., which handles communications for Federal agencies, received two patents this week on inventions by staff engineers.

title: Your Money; The Insurance Policy Maze
description: Norton Spiel, a New York City businessman, says that he never reads his insurance policies. ''Immediately, I get a mental block,'' he said. ''The policies are difficult to understand because they are so redundant and circuitous in their language. Considering that insurance policies are submitted to lay people, they ought to be easier to read.''

title: I-95 BRIDGE CLOSED, JAMMING TRAFFIC
description: Connecticut closed the southbound part of a bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Norwalk yesterday after inspectors discovered cracks in two pin-and-hanger assemblies similar to those found when a bridge span over the Mianus River in Greenwich collapsed last year.

title: ADRIAN MURPHY, 79, EX-HEAD OF CBS RADIO DIVISION, DIES
description: Adrian Murphy, a former president of CBS Radio who was instrumental in getting the company involved in television, died of leukemia Wednesday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 79 years old and had lived in Truro, Mass., in recent years.

title: ALTERNATE HIGHWAYS THROUGH CONNECTICUT
description: With the closing yesterday of the southbound lanes of the Yankee Doodle Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Norwalk, Connecticut transportation officials recommended that motorists use alternative routes over the Labor Day weekend.

title: HEAVEN'S NOT FOR TEACHERS
description: President Reagan's proposal to put a schoolteacher in space strikes me as one of his more misguided ideas, in a class with his attempt a couple of years ago to reclassify ketchup as a vegetable.

title: ATLANTANS LABEL IT THE EXPREZWAY
description: Atlantans wonder about Jimmy Carter and a born- again highway.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a $4,390,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-After income of $979,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $2,553,000. d-After a loss of $2,012,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MILLER, H & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $8,792,000 on sale of investment properties in Texas.

description: DriverGetsProbation IntheDeathsofThree

title: Merger Plan Denied
description: The owner of the Jacksonville Bulls, Fred Bullard , said he had discussed the possibility of a merger with the Michigan Panthers and the Pittsburgh Maulers. But a spokesman for the United States Football League, Doug Kelly , countered that there was ''no truth to any merger'' plan involving those teams, as far as the league knew. Both the Panthers and the Maulers may face stadium- lease conflicts with National Football League teams when the U.S.F.L. moves to a fall season in 1986, and the Bulls would be an attractive merger partner because they play in the 80,000-seat Gator Bowl and last season broke a number of U.S.F.L. attendance records.

title: The Workfare Challenge Workfare, the requirement that welfare clients work for their benefits, is under attack from some recipients and union leaders. They consider it a form of second-class citizenship for the poor because the pay and benefits are lower than for civil service workers. While such criticism points out the need for better administration, the workfare concept itself remains worthwhile.
description: The state's ''home relief'' program provides support for 165,000 poor or disabled people who qualify for no other Federal or state benefits. The average monthly grant is $270 a month (excluding Medicaid and food stamps).

title: WITHERSPOON LOSES TITLE
description: He wears pink trunks and is called Pinkie, a nickname the members of Tim Witherspoon's entourage thought was too sweet. But there was nothing sugar-coated about the left jab that Pinklon Thomas used to frustrate Witherspoon and win the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship tonight in a majority decision.

title: Tulsa Soccer Club Folds TULSA, Okla., Aug. 31 (UPI) - The Tulsa Roughnecks, defending
description: champions of the North American Soccer League, announced today

title: JACKSON HOLDS SESSION WITH SOUTHERN CHIEFS TO AID MONDALE DRIVE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and 13 Southern Democratic chairmen held what they called a ''historic meeting'' here today to propose a political agenda for Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign in the South.

title: In Nicaragua, All the Above
description: Here's a multiple-choice question. Since June, American and Nicaraguan negotiators have met four times. Both sides call the results constructive. What does constructive mean?

description: To the Editor:

title: AIRLINES GRANTED TRUST EXEMPTION TO REDUCE DELAYS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave the nation's airlines an antitrust exemption to let them jointly discuss ways to reduce air traffic congestion and delays.

title: SAUDI, JOURNALIST AND DIPLOMAT
description: It was a luncheon in honor of His Royal Highness, Prince Bandar Bin Sultan, the Saudia Arabian Ambassador to the United States. As one woman slipped in to take a seat, her arrival was noted by Prince Bandar.

title: CITY OPERA: 'CARMEN' WITH 4 NEW PRINCIPALS
description: The four principals in Frank Corsaro's new, sometimes stimulating but often willful production of ''Carmen'' at the New York City Opera were taken by different singers Thursday night. The most impressive were the Carmen and the Escamillo.

title: LOOKING AT LIFE
description: TOO LATE AMERICAN BOYHOOD

title: FLOWERS AND SONGS MARK SOLIDARITY'S ANNIVERSARY
description: Lech Walesa walked out of the main gate of the Lenin Shipyard as his shift ended this afternoon, and was cheered by 500 supporters and watched by a ring of 80 policemen. It was the fourth anniversary of the day the Polish Government agreed to the 21 demands of strikers that created Solidarity.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 41.

title: SHARP DROP IN NATURAL GAS SEARCH
description: The American Petroleum Institute yesterday reported a sharp drop in natural gas exploration during the quarter ended June 30.

title: SHUTTLE CREW SENDS 2d SATELLITE IN ORBIT
description: The crew of the space shuttle Discovery launched another communications satellite today and began operation of a drug-processing machine that could open the way to a new space industry.

title: ARMY REPORTS UNAUTHORIZED HOSPITAL TEST
description: A new internal investigative report does not support allegations that an Army anesthesiology chief performed drug tests on unconscious patients without their prior approval on behalf of the A. H. Robins Company,

title: B-1 CRASHED WHILE MANEUVERING TO AVOID 2D PLANE, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The B-1 bomber that crashed Wednesday stalled while maneuvering to avoid an observation plane, according to Government officials.

title: Article 164584 -- No Title
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it would soon complete agreements to exchange residential mortgages for $3 billion in cash or marketable securities.

title: RIVAL GROUPS AT ODDS OVER THE FORMAT AND NUMBER OF MEETINGS
description: A tentative agreement was reached today for at least one televised debate between President Reagan and his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Murder-Suicide In Jersey Town
description: A Massachusetts man, reportedly upset that his girlfriend had left him, doused her with gasoline and set her on fire, then set himself ablaze in a murder-suicide early yesterday, the police said.

title: Transactions BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Acquired Davey Lopes, infielder-outfielder, from the Oakland A's to complete an earlier trade for Chuck Rainey. Announced that Jay Johnstone, outfielder, will be reassigned. CINCINNATI (NL) - Obtained Carl Willis, relief pitcher, from the Detroit Tigers to complete Monday's trade that sent Bill Scherrer, reliever, to Detroit. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Activated Jim Sundberg, catcher, and Tom Candiotti, pitcher, from the disabled list. Called up Doug Loman, outfielder, and Bob Gibson, pitcher, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. NEW YORK (NL) - Sent Gerald Young, outfielder, and Manny Lee, infielder, both from Columbia of the South Atlantic League, to the Houston Astros as players to be named in the deal for Ray Knight, infielder. The third player will be named later. Recalled Calvin Schiraldi, pitcher; John Stearns and John Gibbons, catchers, and Herman Winningham, outfielder, all from Tidewater of the International League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Recalled Cecilio Guante, pitcher, from Nashua of the Eastern League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Traded Tom O'Malley, infielder, to the Chicago White Sox for two minor-league players to be named. COLLEGES GEORGIA - Announced that Andre Holmes, defensive back, has been allowed to rejoin the football team. NOTRE DAME - Named Dennis Grace soccer coach and John Azevedo assistant wrestling coach. FOOTBALL ARIZONA (USFL) - Dismissed Chuck Lane, vice president, and Mark Braccia, administrative aide Signed to two-year contracts Mark Luchy, center from Oklahoma, and Scott McNabb, tight end from Indiana.
description: Activated Frank Minnifield, cornerback. Announced that Dwight Walker, receiver, remained in the coronary care unit of the Cleveland Clinic because of a bruise in the heart area received in an automobile accident Thursday.

title: Enserch Outlook
description: The Enserch Corporation said earnings for the third quarter are expected to be ''somewhat below'' the $21.3 million, or 34 cents a share, that it earned in the period a year earlier.

title: Court Protects U.S. Materials ;
description: Court Backs Secrecy Of Some U.S. Material

title: MUSIC BY MUSAK: ORCHESTRATING THE WORKDAY
description: In the word-processing department of a large midtown Manhattan publishing house, staring at green letters on a black screen, a bored typist is tapping her foot. Two hundred and thirty-nine miles south, a filing clerk in a Washington office taps along in precise unison, 60 times a minute.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: New Status for Black Area
description: South Africa announced today that KaNgwane, which had been designated a so-called black homeland, would become a self-governing territory, effective immediately. The Swazi Council of Chiefs of South Africa, which wants to incorporate KaNgwane into Swaziland, has warned of bloodshed if the territory of 160,000 people is made independent.

title: ; TRIED AND TRUE CRIME AND RESTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL ASSOCIATION TO FILE SUIT AGAINST FREEZE ON DOCTORS' MEDICARE BILLS
description: Officials of the American Medical Association said today that they would soon file a lawsuit challenging the Government's 15-month freeze on payments to physicians under Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.

title: 4 HURT AS A TAXI VEERS ONTO A CURB AT THE ST. MORITZ
description: A taxi swerving to avoid a pedestrian plowed into a crowded sidewalk in front of the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South yesterday evening, injuring four people, one of them critically, the police said.

title: Dialing to Be Simpler
description: The most obvious change that users will notice under equal access is that they will be able to connect with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company or another phone company simply by dialing ''1'' before the telephone number. Until now, customers wanting to use another carrier had to dial as many as 11 extra digits.

title: GEOPHYSICAL FIELD SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company has been operating under Chapter 11 protection since March 1983.

description: Naturally, it rained.

title: Dali Resting at Castle After Injury in Fire
description: Salvador Dali spent a quiet night at his castle after being burned on his right leg in a fire there Thursday, but an attempt may be made to persuade him to enter a hospital, a close friend said today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Vice President Mondale wants substantially more debating than President Reagan.'' - James A. Johnson, Mr. Mondale's campaign chairman.

description: The following article is based on reporting by William J. Broad and Philip Taubman and was written by Mr. Broad.

title: WHEN PHONES GO AWRY, BROKERS GO SCRAMBLING
description: Investors telephoning orders yesterday to four brokerage firms at 560 Fifth Avenue might have thought the Labor Day holiday weekend started early. Although callers heard the phones ring, no one answered.

PROPOSAL TO BURN UNDERGROUND COAL STIRS PROTEST IN PENNSYLVANIA TOWN
description: Entrepreneurs have said they are willing to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in an enterprise that could create thousands of jobs here in the heart of Pennsylvania's depressed hard-coal country. But their project has frightened some residents of the quiet valley along the Schuykill.

description: As anyone who has been in New

title: RALLY BY ANGELS DEFEATS YANKS, 4-3
description: After a fiery start tonight, the Yankees were cooled off by the Angels, losing, 4-3. It was only their second loss in their last seven games.

title: U.S. IS NOT ENCOURAGED BY ISRAELI UNITY PLAN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the government that emerges from the protracted interparty negotiations in Israel will probably be so divided on foreign policy that there will be little opportunity to revive President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative.

title: Colts Change Signals
description: Two retired jersey numbers once worn by famous members of the Baltimore Colts were unretired by the latter-day Indianapolis version of the team yesterday. And then, evidently in response to an outcry, they were quicky retired again.

title: Ticket Sales Starting For Van Gogh Show
description: Tickets will go on sale Tuesday for the exhibition ''Van Gogh in Arles,'' which opens Oct. 18 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street.

title: MANUEL GALICH
description: Manuel Galich, the Foreign Minister of Guatemala in the leftist Government of Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman in the early 1950's, died Thursday in Havana after a short illness, the official Cuban newspaper Granma reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Great Falls, Mont., on Thursday about the smuggling of birds of prey from the United States incorrectly described those arrested. Some of the 39 were members of the North American Falconers Association; none was a top officer of the group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1984 International Israeli foreign policy issues are expected by the Reagan Administration to so seriously divide the government that emerges from the protracted interparty negotiations in Israel that there would be little opportunity to revive President Reagan's Middle East peace inititative. Administration officials said this division would be particularly true of the ''national unity'' government apparently agreed to in principle by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the Likud Party, now in power, and Shimon Peres, whose Labor Party got the most votes in last month's elections. (Page 1, Column 1.) A joint announcement in Jerusalem by Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir confirmed that they had agreed in principle to form a 50- month bipartisan government. But they indicated that a formal agreement still awaited approval by their respective parties. (3:1.) National

title: Tennis Numbers
description: The winners of the men's and the women's singles titles at the United States Open will each take home $160,000, but it is not necessary to win even one match at the National Tennis Center to go home a bit richer.

title: THE REGION ; ;  L.I. Landscaper Held in Strangling
description: A 20-year-old landscaper was charged today with strangling a young Plainview woman in a Long Island motel, then dumping her body in a catch basin, the Nassau County police said.

title: THE FLUORIDE 'HOAX'
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAMIR AND PERES AWAITING APPROVAL OF COALITION PLAN
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Shimon Peres confirmed today that they had agreed in principle to form a 50-month bipartisan Israeli government. But they suggested that a formal agreement still awaited approval by their respective parties, where they indicated there was dissension.

title: James Capel Stake
description: The Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank plans to acquire a 29.9 percent interest in James Capel & Company and its affiliated companies under an agreement announced by the two concerns.

title: BLACK OFFICERS SEEKING ACTION ON DISPUTED TEST
description: A lawyer for an organization of black police officers said yesterday that the group wanted the city either to throw out the results of the latest sergeants examination, which few black and Hispanic candidates passed, or to promote officers based on a racial quota.

title: BIG CHANCE FOR A HOT JOCKEY
description: ''Look, Chris is really wolfing it down,'' one Monmouth Park regular was saying to another as they watched Chris Antley taking very unjockeylike mouthfuls of smoked salmon and cold pasta during a press luncheon at the Meadowlands on Thursday.

title: 1984 CAMPAIGN ORATORY IS YIELDING FEW MEMORABLE TERMS
description: ''Exit poll'' may be on its way in, along with ''Atari Democrat,'' but ''yuppie'' and all its variations are doubtful, according to the editors of the Merriam-Webster dictionaries.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Anderson Supporters To Be Wooed for G.O.P. By The Associated Press
description: Two former leaders of John B. Anderson's 1980 Presidential campaign said yesterday that they would encourage his supporters to vote for the President Reagan for re-election.

title: Kahane Arrives in U.S. On Money-Raising Trip
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, who was recently elected to the Israeli Parliament, arrived in New York yesterday at the start of a visit to the United States in which he said he hoped to raise money for his campaign to remove Arab citizens from Israel. He said he would also urge American Jews to withhold support for Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: APARTHEID'S NEW WRINKLE GETS A TEPID RECEPTION
description: By the Government's account, democracy has been stirring these last few days in this land of racial and ethnic division. The view is not universal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Appraisal Associates Inc., a professionsal valuation services concern based in Milwaukee, said 77.8 percent of its shareholders had approved the company's acquisitionby RLM Investments Inc. for $21 a share.

title: U.S. Limiting Libyans At U.N. to New York
description: The United States told Libya's United Nations diplomats today that they cannot travel outside New York City without special permission.

title: Orde Coombs, Writer, Dies;Former Editor at New York
description: Orde Coombs, a writer and former contributing editor to New York magazine, died Monday in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases after a long illness. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MICHIGAN MAYOR GUILTY OF EXTORTION CHARGE
description: Mayor Donald Bishop of suburban Dearborn Heights was convicted today by a Federal jury of trying to extort up to $250,000 from several companies seeking the city's cable television franchise.

title: World Bodies Assailed By Iran Over Hijacking
description: Iran attacked international organizations today for what it described as their failure to take firm action to gain the return of an Iranian airliner and more than 200 passengers and crew hijacked to Iraq.

Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Malcom Cowley, writer and literary critic, were among the five winners of the 1984-85 Achievement Awards presented by Who's Who in America.''

LIBYA'S CONGRESS APPROVES UNION WITH MOROCCO
description: The General People's Congress of Libya approved a proposed treaty of unity with Morocco today, while Moroccans voted on the pact in a nationwide referendum that was expected to result in an overwhelming endorsement.

title: Man Who Tried to Kill Reagan Petitions Court for Privileges
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., the man who tried to kill President Reagan three years ago, has asked the Federal District Court here for increased privileges at the Federal mental hospital where he is confined.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LIFTS BAN ON PUBLICATION OF NAMIBIA NEWSPAPER
description: South African authorities have lifted their ban on The Windhoek Observer, a weekly newspaper in South-West Africa known for its regular tilting against Government policy in the disputed territory, also known as Namibia.

description: Scott Verplank, a 20-year-old from Dallas, held off Peter Persons today to gain a semifinal berth in the United States Amateur golf championships.

title: Andropov Post Confirmed
description: Igor Y. Andropov, son of the late Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, has been appointed Ambassador to Greece, the official Soviet press agency said today. The appointment was first rumored in June when reports of it appeared in Greece and also in Stockholm, where Mr. Andropov was part of the Soviet delegation to the European disarmament conference. Mr. Andropov is to replace Ambassador Vladimir F. Kaboshkin, who has retired.

title: ON MAKING IT HARDER TO LIVE IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Inches Ahead 1.10 In Very Slow Trading
description: Stock prices ended with minor gains yesterday in the slowest trading this year, as interest waned mainly in reaction to the higher-than-expected money supply figures announced after the market closed Thursday.

title: Mullady Resumes Drills With Giants
description: Tom Mullady, the Giants' only reserve tight end, took part in practice today for the first time this week and is expected to be ready for the season opener against the Philadelphia Eagles here Sunday despite his back problems.

description: The light-flyweight gold medalist of the Olympics, Paul Gonzales , may have boxed all four of his bouts with a broken bone in his right hand. ''Paul appears to have a hairline stress fracture at the base of the third metacarpal, near the wrist,'' said Dr.

title: PHONE BATTLE IN WALL ST. AREA
description: Starting today, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., the investment banking firm, and some 35,000 other business and residential phone users in lower Manhattan can take advantage of the new equal access plan for long- distance dialing.

title: ASBESTOS - USEFUL BUT A HEALTH RISK
description: Asbestos was widely used between World War II and the late 1970's as fireproofing insulation. In recent years, it has been found to pose a threat of several serious diseases, including mesothelioma, a cancer of the lining of the lungs.

description: b-After $57,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-After $2,000 net from discontinued operations. d-Net loss is after $210,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Heinz in Pact On China Venture
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had signed an agreement to join two Chinese companies in building a baby- food factory in Canton, China. The $10 million deal is Heinz's second move in its search for business opportunities in developing nations.

title: LEGAL SERVICES AGENCY TO GET FUNDS FOR 1985;
description: President Reagan has signed into law an $11.57 billion appropriation bill that provides $305 million for the beleaguered Legal Services Corporation, but he warned Congress against tampering with the powers of his nominees to the agency's board.

title: Democrat Chides Laxalt On Letter to Ministers
description: A Democratic Party official chided President Reagan's campaign chairman today for sending out a letter asking fundamentalist ministers across the nation to aid in a Republican voter registration drive.

title: BERENYI HELPS METS GAIN SPLIT
description: Dave Johnson's computer helped Dave Johnson's Mets win two games last night, but only one of the victories helped the Mets in their pursuit of the Chicago Cubs. The other victory, devised by the computer for a between- games promotion, didn't count because it was a 5-4 decision over the 1969 Mets.

title: BEAR'S DEATH IS DEEP LOSS FOR KEEPER
description: The doctors attributed his death to kidney failure, but Joe Smimmo, his keeper at the Central Park Zoo, said he had died of a broken heart.

title: TEXAS CADET DEAD IN HAZING, A PRACTICE OUTLAWED IN 1983
description: A Texas A & M University military cadet was rousted from bed and forced to perform ''motivational exercise'' until he collapsed and died, despite a memorandum ordering a halt to such hazing, the commandant of the Corps of Cadets said today.

title: Western Airlines
description: Western Airlines' 1,200 pilots have approved a new round of salary and benefit concessions that would save the company $107 million by the end of 1986 if the rest of the unions also go along, Western said. Last fall Western's five labor groups voted to accept pay cuts that will save the company about $42 million by the time they expire late this year. In exchange, they got 32 percent of the company's stock, a profit-sharing program and a seat on the board.

description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the United States Open misstated the outcome of a tennis doubles match. The Gullikson brothers defeated Patrick McEnroe and Luke Jensen, 6-4, 7-6.

title: SCHOOLS DELAYED BY ASBESTOS WORK
description: Nearly 100 public schools in New Jersey that have failed to complete the removal of asbestos during the summer will be unable to open next week, the State Education Commissioner said today.

description: Edward T. Riley, a longtime agent for leading commercial artists in New York and Philadelphia, died of cancer Wednesday at the New York Hospital- Cornell Medical Center.

description: The room has the heart of a little girl, with posters and pictures tacked sloppily on the walls and trophies and stuffed dolls sitting on the shelves. But it all seems strange now to the woman who used to sing in front of the mirror and practice her lines on the ruffled bedspread.

title: Harold B. Thomas Dies at 87; Former Sterling Drug Officer
description: Harold B. Thomas, a former senior vice president of Sterling Drug Inc., died Sunday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 87 years old.

description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading that was abbreviated by an early 2 P.M. closing of the government securities market before the Labor Day weekend.

description: A Federal appeals panel, finding that civil rights laws do not protect transsexuals from discrimination, has overturned a ruling that ordered Eastern Airlines to reinstate a pilot who was dismissed after a sex-change operation.

description: Companies

title: SCOTTISH HIGH TECH MATURES
description: During the late 1970's, journalists reaching for a cute phrase began calling a 100- mile-wide region of central Scotland ''Silicon Glen'' because of the number of well-known electronics companies there.

title: POLE-VAULT MARK BROKEN TWICE IN ROME
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke the world record in the pole vault tonight, clearing 19 feet 5 3/4 inches just minutes after Thierry Vigneron of France had broken the record with a vault of 19-4 3/4.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Summer Park Alumni

title: JOB PROGRAMS FOR TEEN-AGERS LAG BEHIND NEED IN MANY CITIES
description: For 18-year-old Stacy Hines of New Haven, Conn., the prized piece of paper in her hand was a source of confusion. It was her first paycheck. She was not sure which part was the check and which was the stub.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $105,000 in the quarter and $556,000 for the year.

title: POLICE LINK BOY, 13, TO FRAUD BY COMPUTER
description: A boy who allegedly bought rare comic books and other goods worth about $4,000 by using a computer to get credit card numbers is helping the authorities trace others doing the same thing around the country, the police said today.

title: G.M. RAISING 1985 MODEL PRICES 2.3%
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was increasing the average price of its 1985 model cars by $292, or 2.3 percent. The increase was similar to the 2.4 percent increase at the beginning of the 1984 model year, although the company later increased prices of some best-selling models.

title: No Headline
description: Soviet Buys More Wheat WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

title: Berlin Players Accept Karajan Peace Gesture
description: The Berlin Philharmonic today said it had accepted an offer from Herbert von Karajan, its chief conductor, to perform Bach's Mass in B minor after a row that has kept the two sides apart for more than three months.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dwight Muhammad Qawi has withdrawn from his Sept. 7 light-heavyweight title fight against Michael Spinks, the champion, after aggravating a chronic shoulder injury, according to the promoter Butch Lewis . . . . The boxer Bobby Czyz pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he burglarized the home of a Bloomingdale, N.J., woman and assaulted her.

title: PITTOCK FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, twilight-night doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, 5:35 P.M. The Mets, with their second doubleheader in two days, get another chance to pick up ground on Chicago. (Television - Channel 9, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 5:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Chicago Cubs, at Atlanta. Dennis Eckersley, another Cub acquisition from the American League, hasn't turned out quite so well as Rick Sutcliffe. Still, at 8-7 he does have a winning record, and he gets the start today against Rick Camp. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.)

title: JAZZ: HANCOCK WITH 'ROCKIT'
description: Herbie Hancock, the venturesome keyboardist who has delved into virtually every jazz idiom over the last 14 years, is the current hero of the dance-music world through his ingenious ''hip hop'' single, ''Rockit.'' The record uses a jazz keyboard motif that recalls ''It Don't Mean a Thing'' as the musical nub around which to swirl the brittle polyrhythms of synthesized drums and the agitated ''scratching'' of the turntable scratch artist, D. St. Mr. Hancock, with the producer Bill Laswell of Material created a model of sophisticated ''hip hop'' music that implied connections between the latest in hard-edged contemporary dance and older jazz-fusion and swing models.

title: FILM: 'C.H.U.D.,' A TALE OF STRANGE CREATURES
description: In this summer when discarded alligators have been discovered maturing in local waterways, is it stretching urban paranoia too far to contemplate the existence of other strange creatures in our midst? Not for makers of horror films.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Includes charges relating to the writedown of certain assets of about $1.4 million for the quarter and about $2 million for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $471,000 for the quarter and $525,000 for the 9 months.

title: Man Makes $1 Million Jump
description: Dan Koko, a stunt man, earned $1 million Thursday by jumping 326 feet from atop the Vegas World Hotel and Casino. He landed in a 20-foot-high air bag and emerged with only a rip in his jump suit. The money, in cash, was given to Mr. Koko by Bob Stupak, owner of the Vegas World. Mr. Stupak said he did it for the publicity.

title: MUCH OF CREUSOT-LOIRE IS TO BE SOLD
description: A number of private and public companies and banks today announced a plan to take over major parts of Creusot-Loire, the industrial giant that went into receivership in June.

title: Norway Exports to U.S.
description: The value of Norway's exports to the United States surged to 5.6 billion kroner, or $676 million, in 1983, an 80 percent jump from 3.1 billion kroner in 1982.

title: Caesar's Husband, Cont. In removing John Zaccaro as the manager of an elderly woman's finances, a Queens judge did all he could have done, but did not say all he might have said.
description: Justice Edwin Kassoff almost applauded Mr. Zaccaro, the husband of the Vice-Presidential candidate, Geraldine Ferraro. The judge ruled that there was no suggestion of dishonesty or malicious intent on Mr. Zaccaro's part when he borrowed $175,000 from the woman's estate. The judge found him to be a forthright witness who thought his handling of the money benefited the estate.

title: Blackout at Howe Caverns
description: A power failure in Howe Caverns left 200 to 300 people in the dark about 150 feet below the surface today, but all were able to get out safely. Rodney Schaeffer, general manager of the tourist attraction, said a tree fell across the power line leading to the caverns and then an emergency generator at the tourist attraction broke down. He said guides using flashlights led the tourists up stairways to the surface of the caverns in Schoharie County southwest of Albany.

title: Ballet-School Auditions
description: An audition for young ballet dancers, 10 to 18 years old, will be held by the School of American Ballet next Tuesday at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. The school, founded by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, is the official school of the New York City Ballet; Mr. Kirstein is the school's director. The audition hours are 9:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. Interested youngsters should call for an appointment: 877-7635.

title: 4 Die in Pakistan Train Crash
description: Four people were killed and 20 were injured today when two trains collided head-on near Bahawalpur, 260 miles south of Islamabad, the Associated Press of Pakistan reported. Both drivers died in the crash.

title: Plane Crashes in the Street
description: A single-engine airplane crashed Thursday night in the middle of a city intersection after its engine apparently failed, injuring both men on board, the authorities said today. The pilot, Jeff Brown, 21 years old, of Nashville, was in guarded condition today at a hospital and his passenger, Lawrence Joyner, 27, also of Nashville, was in satisfactory condition. There were no other reported injuries.

title: BUTTERFIELD EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: On the Avenue

title: NON-SECRETS GUARDED BY THE FOREST SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
 Cancer Treatment
description: Dr. M. David Goldenberg and Dr. Dan Shochat of the Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology at the Newark unit of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey were granted patent 4,468,457 this week. It covers isolation and purification of an antigen from gastrointestinal and ovarian cancers, as well as production of antibodies against the antigen, known as C.S.A.p. The patent has been licensed to Immunomedics Inc., a company on the Newark campus. Dr. Goldenberg has been granted other patents on tumor treatment.

title: A PANEL STUDIES LETTING LAWYERS QUESTION JURORS
description: A panel of trial judges and practicing lawyers has concluded that it may be beneficial for lawyers to take part in the selection of juries in Federal trials.

title: DINING OUT WITH TODDLERS: THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS
description: Patrons of many New York restaurants, particularly those in residential neighborhoods such as the Upper West Side of Manhattan, do not need a census report to document the new baby boom. In some cases it can be heard reverberating through the dining room.

title: Patrick Staying For the Practice
description: James Patrick was back in a Team Canada uniform yesterday, one day after having been cut from the squad, but he was lacking official status. The 21-year-old Ranger defenseman was asked by the coach, Glen Sather, to remain with the team as a practice player for the three-week-long Canada Cup tournament, which, for the Canadian squad, begins tonight in Montreal with a game against West Germany.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS SENDING GUNSHIPS TO EL SALVADOR
description: The United States is considering providing rapid-fire AC-47 gunships to the Salvadoran Air Force, according to the United States Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, and other American officials here.

title: No Headline
description: Pay'N Save To Study Offer The Pay'N Save Corporation

title: EX-OFFICER AT CITY OPERA TAKES POST IN BOSTON
description: Henson Markham, the former director of business and finance of the New York City Opera, has been named managing director of the Opera Company of Boston.

title: A TWISTED TALE IN TWO CITIES
description: The word from Warsaw was that a robot owned by the New York City Police Department had dumped a pile of garbage at the door of the Polish Consulate in Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENTIAL KNOCKS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
AUDIBLE TEACHING MACHINE
description: WASHINGTON A teaching machine that can recognize a student's voice in answers to questions and respond orally was patented this week for the Scott Instruments Corporation of Denton, Tex. The machine, which uses a digital computer, is being manufactured and sold under the trade mark V.B.L.S., for Voice-Based Learning System.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Speier Trade Stands
description: When Chris Speier , a 34-year-old shortstop, was traded from St. Louis to Minnesota and played only one game before injuring his left heel Aug. 21 against Milwaukee, the Twins cried foul.

title: French Wheat Crop
description: France will have a record wheat crop this year and production of other cereals will be sharply higher than in 1983, producers said today. The cereal growers' federation estimated this year's soft wheat production at 26.8 million tons, up 27 percent from 1983 and well above the previous record of 21.6 million tons set in 1982. Production of hard wheat should rise 24 percent, to 474,000 tons, while barley should jump 61 percent, to 673,000 tons.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $440,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the quarter and year. c-After a loss of $324,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a gain of $121,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FOR HUDSONOPHILES, A LONG, LONG TRAIL
description: Two years ago, while I was leading a group through Riverside Park, along the Hudson River, to the Irish bars of Inwood, someone said to me: ''It would be great if people could hike all the way to where the river rises.'' Since then, members of my group and I have been talking to hikers and bikers, walkers and talkers, bureaucrats, state legislators and assorted river rats - Hudsonophiles all - about putting together a 330-mile hiking path along the shores of the Hudson.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: EPIC FASSBINDER Fans of Rainer Werner Fassbinder who missed all or part of ''Berlin Alexanderplatz,'' his 15 1/2-hour epic of post-World War I Berlin, will get another chance. The film is being shown at the Thalia Theater, 95th Street and Broadway, in digestible segments.

title: Young Boxer Finals
description: Boxers 10 to 15 years old will compete in the finals of the Kid Gloves Tournament outdoors tomorrow, beginning at noon, in Grand Army Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Salant Dividend
description: The Salant Corporation, an apparel maker, said its board was expected to suspend the company's quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share.

title: LETTER: ON EVIDENCE
description: SUSPICIONS ABOUT AGENT ORANGE

title: BARRY AIDE CRITICIZES NEWS LEAKS
description: The counsel for Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that Attorney General William French Smith should consider appointing a special prosecutor to investigate disclosures about the Mayor and a grand jury investigation of drug use by city employees.

title: MONDALE TRYING TO GET HIS BID BACK IN GROOVE
description: ''Nobody said running for President was going to be easy,'' Walter F. Mondale mused the other day with a wry smile. ''But someone should have spelled it out a little more clearly.''

title: No Headline
description: Credit Card Voiding Curbed WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

title: FILM: BO DEREK IN 'BOLERO'
description: The fact that ''Bolero,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli, was threatened with an X rating will surprise anyone who sees it, especially those who go for X-rated reasons. Most of Bo Derek's antics look distinctly chaste, and when she appears

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Ferraro Sees No Danger Of Eclipsing Mondale
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, buoyed after a six- state campaign swing marked by cheering, flag-waving crowds, says her candidacy is in no danger of eclipsing that of Walter F. Mondale.

title: Pullman, REDM
description: The Pullman Transportation Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire REDM Industries for $20.375 a share.

title: Slide Hampton Scheduled
description: The trombonist Slide Hampton will lead a six-piece band tonight at the West End Cafe (666-9160), 2911 Broadway, near 114th Street. There is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum; sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight. Information: 666-9160.

title: 3 Rock Bands Performing
description: Three rock-and-roll groups from the 1950's - the Cleftones, Mello- Kings and the Mystics - will appear this weekend at Guild Hall, 158 Main Street, in East Hampton, L. I. Performances are at 7:30 and 10 P.M. tonight and 7:30 tomorrow; a 10 P.M. show tomorrow is sold out. Tickets, $12 and $14. Information: (516) 324- 0806.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Goldwater and Nickles Get Zeros in Vote Study
description: Two Republican Senators, Barry Goldwater of Arizona and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, received the lowest possible rating, zero, from an organization that judges Congress on black and Hispanic issues, a study shows.

title: PATENTS ; Nuclear Fuel Pellets Sorted Automatically
description: An automatic apparatus for sorting nuclear fuel pellets and placing them on trays was patented this week for the General Electric Company, San Jose, Calif.

title: Bavasi Is Retiring
description: Buzzie Bavasi will retire at the end of this season as executive vice president of the California Angels, ending a 35-year career as a baseball executive that began when he became the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1951. ''It's about time,'' the 68-year-old Bavasi told The Long Beach Press-Telegram.

title: Project Is Halted By Forest City
description: Forest City Enterprises Inc. said it had decided not to proceed with the planned $228 million Tower City Center Project.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Inmate at Fishkill Stabbed to Death
description: An inmate at the state prison at Fishkill was stabbed to death by another inmate this morning in the prison's community bathroom, according to the state police.

title: 4 IN EX-FOOTBALL STAR'S FAMILY SHOT DEAD ON COAST
description: Four members of the family of a former National Football League player were shot to death today in a house in central Los Angeles. The police said they were looking for two men whom neighbors saw running from the house.

title: RADIO NEWS SURPASSED BY TV IN SURVEY
description: Radio news, long regarded as offering the most immediacy in coverage, has lost that reputation among the American public to television, a study released today concludes.

title: 'GELATO WAS MY ARMAGEDDON'
description: I had a feeling I wouldn't get past gelati. It began when five gelaterias opened in one night on Columbus Avenue. It got worse when I paid $1.75 for my first two ounces of stracciatelle. But I didn't panic until a friend at work told me about her favorite place to get zabaglione - in Rome. Then I knew it was all over. Gelato was my Waterloo, my Armageddon. And I was just getting used to tofutti.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UNCHANGED A 4TH MONTH
description: Prices farmers get for raw products entering the marketing pipeline were unchanged in August for the fourth consecutive month but still averaged 3.6 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-There were no comparable year- ago results because the company was formed in June 1983. The fiscal year- end results represent operations from Oct. 1, 1983, the date of acquisition.

title: British Unemployment
description: The number of unemployed in Britain rose by about 15,000 in August, but in percentage terms unemployment was unchanged at 12.9 percent of the labor force, the Department of Employment said today.

title: ANDERSN SUPPORTERS TO BE WOOED FOR G.O.P By The Associated Press
description: Two former leaders of John B. Anderson's 1980 Presidential campaign said yesterday that they would encourage his supporters to vote for the President Reagan for re-election.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAYER HALTS ARIAS, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3
description: The progression of top-ranked men came to an abrupt end yesterday at the United States Open when Gene Mayer bumped Jimmy Arias, using his crisp game of touch, angles and variety to upset the sixth-seeded player in straight sets.

title: Marguerite E. Graham Weds Robert Kramer
description: Marguerite Elizabeth Graham and Robert Scott Kramer were married yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Loren Graham, in Cambridge, Mass., by Justice of the Peace John Cratsley of Boston. The bridegroom is the son of Lester Kramer of Framingham, Mass., and Suzanne Kramer of Paxton, Mass.

title: SOLAR CAR COMPLETES CROSS COUNTRY TRIP
description: An automobile powered only by the rays of the sun has completed a trip from California to Florida, becoming the first solar-powered vehicle to cross the country.

title: No Headline
description: Edith Adams a Bride

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We think we've got a good bird here.'' - Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., commander of the space shuttle Discovery. (30:4.)

title:
DINING OUT;
MEXICN FARE IN MOUNT KISCO
description: OVER the summer, Westchester seems to have caught taco fever. Mexican restaurants have sprung up all over the county, even in northern regions usually the last to enjoy the delights of new ethnic cuisines, which tend to establish themselves first down county. Last June Pancho's & Gringo's settled into a block of modern shops behind Mount Kisco's Calico Corners. As in other places serving Mexican food, this restaurant dishes out its share of gloppy combination plates that challenge diners to pick out the enchilada, burrito and tostada hidden in the culinary landscape. But even with its flaws, Pancho's & Gringo's offers fare a substantial notch higher than that served in other such restaurants. One had better have reservations for weekend evenings.

title: No Headline
description: Federals Sale Reported Near

title:
GARDENING;
THE ADVANTAGES OF PLANTING IN THE FALL
description: BY this time, banners in garden centers are proclaiming that ''fall is for planting.'' Experienced gardeners know this is far more than a sales gimmick: It is a statement of fact. New gardeners, however, may need to be convinced. After all, spring, when everything is starting to grow, would seem the best time for planting.

title: Plastic Bag May Fix Balky Shuttle Toilet
description: The solution to the troublesome space shuttle toilet, which has malfunctioned on 10 of the 11 previous flights, may be as simple as a plastic bag.

title: JETS' WALKER STARTS IN COLT TEST TODAY
description: Finally, some good news for the Jets.

title: ;  Short Season
description: Kellen Winslow has decided that if the San Diego Chargers won't play his way, he'll take his ball and go home - or at least that's what he threatens to do.

title: U.S. SAYS A CHINESE WHO ASKED ASYLUM HAS RETURNED HOME
description: State Department officials said tonight that a Chinese businessman who sought political asylum after making a dramatic escape from the Chinese consulate in New York has returned to his homeland.

title: Stray Animal Law Protested
description: A proposed city ordinance to fine people $200 for feeding stray cats and dogs is bringing complaints from animal lovers.

title: A KLAN IMPERIAL WIZARD SAYS HE WILL RESIGN POST THIS YEAR
description: The Imperial Wizard of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, said today that he would resign.

title: PART OF I-95 BRIDGE SECTION COULD REOPEN MONDAY
description: The southbound lanes of the Connecticut Turnpike bridge over the Norwalk River, which were closed for safety reasons Friday, could be partly reopened on Monday in time to handle the heavy holiday traffic, the Connecticut Commissioner of Transportation said today.

title: CHERNENKO STATEMENT URGES TALKS WITH U.S. ON DISARMAMENT ISSUES
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, was quoted today as saying that an agreement with the United States on banning weapons in outer space would ease the way for discussions on other disarmament issues.

title: FAMILY IN NEW MILFORD MAKES A LIFE IN RESTAURANT
description: RUNNING a restaurant is frequently a family affair, but the Mathews family of New Milford carries it one step further at the Ferns, where they live, work and play.

title: A DOCUDRAMA AIMS TO REOPEN A CASE
description: LOS ANGELES Two police officers, played by Morgan Freeman and James Earl Jones, stand in a hospital morgue peering down at the disfigured body of a young black boy. The grisly scene being filmed this summer in an abandoned hospital in Los Angeles recalls one of the most lurid and shocking news stories of our time: ''The Atlanta Child Murders,'' a five-hour mini-series scheduled to be shown early next year on CBS, is about the mysterious murders of 29 black youths in Atlanta during the early 1980's.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM CORROSIVE ROCK TO CABARET
description: Scrambled Feet Starring Madeline Kahn, John Driver, Jeffrey Haddow and Roger Neil; directed by Mr. Driver. RKO Home Video 100 minutes.

title: 16 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 16 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: IN A CITY OF SINGLES, MANY LOOK TO BE COUPLES
description: Boston is home to nearly half a million single men and women. And despite dating services for Jews, Christians, entrepreneurs, advanced degree holders and computer zealots, untold numbers of these single people still yearn for the other half of a couple.

title: Ann B. M. Keith Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Clinton Keith of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Keith's daughter Ann Barrett Milholland Keith to Stoddard Andrew MacPherson Horn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Stoddard Horn of New York and Southampton, L.I. The wedding is to be next month.

description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES last week announced an increase in the cost of Millstone 3, hardly a novelty, since major increases have been announced seven times before in the 13 years since the utility made the project public.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Averack of Jericho, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Debra Michele Averack, to Harry Robert Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan L. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y. A December wedding is planned.

description: For several years Federal agents have been trying to make falcons a little less endangered by making falcon smugglers a little more so. Last week they succeeded in clipping at least one pair of wings.

description: ALTHOUGH more and more children these days are taking active parts in their parents' second marriages - and although the vast majority of parents, children and clergymen feel this is the way it should be, there are those who have misgivings.

description: Ten people whose signs were confiscated when President Reagan appeared at Fountain Square here Aug. 21 have sued White House aides, Republican officials and others.

title: Lisa Ellen Deitsch Planning to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Marian Mimi Deitsch of Livingston, N.J., and Lords Valley, Pa., of the engagement of her daughter, Lisa Ellen Deitsch, to Lindsey Handley Taylor, the son of Roland and Annis Taylor of Durham, N.C. The wedding is to be in December.

description: LONDON ONCE you have changed the face of British industry, it's hard to find an appropriate encore.

title: THE REGION ; Police TestFails to EraseColor Line
description: A test for police sergeant that was designed to be ''color blind'' produced results that puzzled and disturbed officials and minority- group members, it turned out last week. The test, taken by more than 11,500 New York City police officers seeking promotion to sergeant, was devised by a consultant not to discriminate against black, Hispanic or female officers. But the results, released by a black police officers' group and confirmed by the Koch administration, showed a disproportionately small number of black and Hispanic officers earned passing grades. Only 1.6 percent of the black candidates and 4.4 percent of the Hispanic candidates passed, compared with 10.6 percent of the white officers. The exam was given in June 1983.

title: EXERCISING PRUDENCE
description: Exercise can work for or against you. One form of sit-up will strengthen your abdominal muscles; another may strain the back. One level of exercise will benefit the cardiovascular system; another may overtax it. One aerobic exercise will benefit the cardiovascular system but traumatize the joints; another will spare excessive stress on the muscles and joints.

title: ANGELS DEFEAT YANKEES BY 11-6
description: The Yankees, on a hot streak and aiming for a second place finish in the American League East, were set back by the California Angels, 11-6, tonight.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 MUSICAL FINALE
description: Don't look now, but summer has come and gone. At least - and especially - in the outdoor music arena. The season of free bring-your-own- seating concerts unofficially ends tonight at Morgan Park in Glen Cove, but the finale has all the makings of an overture, rather than a swan song. For the Seuffert Band will be on hand and, under the baton of George F. Seuffert, will perform Wagner, Tchaikovsky, Mendelssohn, Rossini, Gershwin, Sarasate (with the violinist Leonid Suchansky as soloist) and, of course, John Philip Sousa's ''Stars and Stripes Forever.'' The concert is at 8:15 P.M. ON THE RUN

description: Bavaria, known for its snowcapped mountains, quaint picturesque towns and dark beer, recently underwent a subtle Americanization. A team from East Rutherford, N.J., not known to be full of European charm, is the talk of Fussen, West Germany.
