title: ;  No Jersey on Jersey
description: A Stanhope, N.J., company evidently thought it could get around the Giants and N.F.L. Properties, the company with exclusive rights to National Football League trademarks, by selling sports merchandise with a ''New Jersey Giants'' logo marked on it. The Giants play in New Jersey, of course, but their official name is still New York Giants.

title: THE NATION ; Fatal TestOf the B-1
description: Tommie Douglas Benefield, chief test pilot for Rockwell International Corporation, was at the controls of an eight-year-old B-1 bomber that had been modified to resemble the more advanced, intensely controversial B1-B that will soon come rolling off Rockwell's assembly lines. The plane had logged 543 hours of flight time, but one morning last week it crashed into the Mojave Desert in Southern California.

title: SOLAR POWER MAST UNFOLDED 73 FEET IN ASTRONAUT TEST
description: In the first test of electricity-generating systems to be erected on future space stations, an experimental solar power array was unfolded today and extended up from the space shuttle Discovery like a glistening stairway to the stars.

title: JACKSON'S ARROGANT PRIDE
description: WASHINGTON

title: PORNOGRAMS AND SUPERCOMPUTERS
description: IMAGINARY MAGNITUDE

title: ENGLISH HAVEN PROSPERS IN BRITTANY
description: Once upon a time, about 130 years ago, some Englishmen set off for the south in search of the sun. They sailed across the Channel and got as far as Dinard, a fishing village on France's Brittany coast. There they found glorious beaches and a climate where palm trees grew, warmed by the Gulf Stream. Here we can be content, they said, and so they stayed.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A SISTER LOST, A DAUGHTER BORN
description: I HAD just turned 16 when my

title: STRUCTURAL DECAY
description: Structural decay forced the demolition five years ago of the Knickerbocker Inn, in Leonia, N.J., a pre- Revolutionary stopover point for the overland stage through northeastern Bergen County.

title: Summer Boom and Bloom
description: A friend with a summer place has been paying particular attention to its sounds as well as its sights lately.

title: TALKING
description: INVESTMENTS

title: SALAD COMPOSITIONS
description: If one approaches cooking as a hobby, as we do, it almost goes without

title: THE REGION ; The ArchbishopPasses Spanish
description: When he was installed as Archbishop of New York in March, John J. O'Connor promised to learn Spanish so he could communicate better with the 800,000 Spanish-speaking Catholics in the archdiocese. He spent four weeks this summer taking private lessons at a seminary in Yonkers and then studied 11 days in Puerto Rico.

title: A. S. Berman Married To Lauren Friedman
description: Lauren Friedman, a daughter of Jacqueline Weintraub Friedman of Tokyo and David Warren Friedman of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Ajayinder Singh Berman, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dilip Singh Berman of Punjab, India. Justice of the Peace Everett P. Arnold of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Weintraub, the bride's great uncle and great aunt, in Lafayette Hill, Pa.

title: Linda Anderson Wed to Henry Rost Jr.
description: The marriage of Linda Seyburn Anderson, the daughter of Edmund Anderson of New York and the late Gwendolyn Seyburn Anderson, to Henry A. Rost Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rost of Wilton, Conn., took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Wilton. The Rev. John Garcia Gensel of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York performed the ceremony.

title: KINDERGARTENS: MORE GO FULL DAY
description: TENAFLY

title: JOURNALISTS PLAN TO CHALLENGE U.S. ON INSIDER TRADING CASE
description: Concerned that Federal charges recently brought against a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal could threaten freedom of the press, several journalistic organizations intend to enter the litigation to challenge the Government's position.

title: IT'S HARVEST TIME ACROSS THE COUNTY
description: THIS summer the corn stands 10 feet tall. Gardeners grumble about the harvest not being exactly a cornucopia. Too much rain, too little sun, and even the zinnias had a rough time.

title: 3 EXHIBITIONS AT THE NOYES MUSEUM
description: OCEANVILLE THE Noyes Museum here is a Surrealist manifestation - a museum of art among woods, marshes and marinas, with the ever-multiplying towers of Atlantic City on the horizon.

title: GREEK CONSERVATIVES CHOOSE EX-FOREIGN MINISTER AS LEADER
description: Greece's conservative opposition group, the New Democracy Party, elected a new leader today, who declared that his main task would be to unseat the Socialist Government and mend Greece's strained relations with the West.

title: Planes Collide in Oregon, Killing All Six Aboard
description: Two small planes collided in flight today near The Dalles, scattering wreckage over a wide area near a mobile home park and killing all six people aboard the planes, officials said.

title: A SHORTAGE OF SHELTERS FOR ABUSED WOMEN
description: OFFICIALS at Connecticut's 11 shelters for battered women say overcrowding has forced them to turn away abused women seeking refuge.

title: Price of Cocaine Has Risen
description: Crackdowns on producers and smugglers of cocaine in Colombia and the United States have caused the wholesale price of the drug to rise sharply, according to officials of the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency. A kilogram, 2.2 pounds, of cocaine that cost a dealer $15,000 six months ago now costs $25,000 to $30,000, Frank Chellino, a spokesman for the agency's Miami office, said.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH OFFER TO RECEIVE HANOI PRISONERS
description: The Reagan Administration is nearing a decision to offer asylum to thousands of Vietnamese prisoners held by Vietnam in ''re-education'' camps, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Transit Cuts in Philadelphia
description: The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority will operate all Broad Street Subway express trains with one person instead of two beginning Tuesday, officials said. The transit workers' union said there would be no conductors to make certain passengers were safely aboard. An arbitrator ruled against the union but agreed to six months' monitoring.

title: TIPS ON INSTALLING ALARM SYSTEMS
description: INSTALLING good locks on all your entrance doors and using timers to make the house look lived in even if no one is at home definitely help to discourage many burglars, as was discussed here last week. But additional protection can often be provided by the installation of an alarm system that will sound a siren or ring a loud bell - and perhaps turn lights on and dial a preselected phone number - when someone tries to break in.

title: MOUNTAIN GUIDE MAKES COMEBACK IN NEW STYLE
description: A species once thought to be nearly extinct is flourishing again in upstate New York's Adirondack Mountains. It is the outdoor guide, the skilled woodsman who can track game, lead anglers to remote ponds and cook a satisfying trail stew.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE ALMOST AWFUL PLAY

title: TENNESSEE OFFICIAL MAKES STRONG RE-ELECTION BID FROM PRISON
description: When Tommy Burnett decided to run again this fall for the State Legislature, some people in East Tennessee saw a chance to beat him. That was because Mr. Burnett is serving time in a Federal prison.

title: MISS MORRISEY, AN EXECUTIVE, WEDS FINANCIER
description: St. Peter's by-the-Lake Episcopal Church in Old Forge, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lucinda Earle Morrisey and Ralph Worthington 4th. The Rev. Arthur Bice performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN a painting of Theodore Roosevelt's charge up San Juan Hill is unveiled at the Sagamore Hill National Historic Site in Oyster Bay on Thursday evening, it will be a special event for Mort K"unstler, an Oyster Bay artist who has done more than 2,000 illustrations and paintings of famous events in American history.

title: HE EATS ICE CREAM AND GETS PAID FOR IT
description: '' WE'RE dealing with the adults of today who were the teen-agers of the 60's,'' said Erhard Sommer of North Babylon. ''These teen-agers, as they grew up, made everybody aware of natural foods, natural environment, natural air. They're the ones who rebelled against pollution. They're the ones who said, like with ice cream: What are all these chemicals doing in there?''

title:
STAMPS;
A PHILATELIC SHOW OF PEDIGREED DOGS
description: A new issue, coming out in New York City this Friday, commemorates the 100th anniversary of the American Kennel Club. For the first time pedigreed dogs appear on American stamps.

title: PERIL TO HEALTH OF JOBLESS SEEN
description: About 70 percent of laid-off workers can expect to lose their health insurance within two years of losing a job, according to a study by researchers at the University of Michigan.

title: MODERNISM OWES A DEBT TO DEGAS
description: ''It is always a windfall to have

title: THE HEARTLESS SOCIETY
description: John Kenneth Galbraith is the Paul M. Warburg Professor Emeritus of Economics at Harvard University. This article is adapted from his introduction to the fourth edition of his 1958 book, ''The Affluent Society,'' to be published next month by Houghton Mifflin.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: OLYMPIC fever may have cooled a bit, but not for the folks in Salem County. On Aug. 25 they paid homage to the Olympic exploits of a longtime resident, George L. Hill Sr. of Salem City, at the Market Street celebration.

title: HIGH POINT PARK BECKONS
description: FROM an observation platform in High Point State Park, an osprey could be seen flying high and strong against the summer winds that whipped across the tall, emerald-green and granite ridge in the distance.

title: AUXILIARY DAM IS BEING BUILT TO CONTAIN MISSISSIPPI RIVER
description: Army engineers, about half finished building a big auxiliary dam near here to keep the Mississippi from changing course, think they will succeed if the river behaves for a few more years when the weather is wet and snow is melting in the North.

title: PHILADELPHIA YOUTHS LINE UP TO SLOP HOGS AND TEND CROPS
description: Far from Mississippi's Delta, Wisconsin's dairylands or the Middle West's grain belt, a high school in the country's fifth-largest city nurtures the largest chapter of Future Farmers of America.

title: INSPIRED BY COLOMBIAN ART
description: Guillermo Cano is the third generation of his family to be a treasure hunter in Colombia. His grandfather, Nemesio Cano, accidentally discovered an Indian tomb while moving a flagstone.

title: LIBERALS GO BACK TO THE FLAG
description: One of the significant political developments of 1984 is the Democratic attempt to take back the traditional American symbols - flag, law, religion, family - that many Democrats abandoned to the Republicans in the 1960's and 1970's.

title: A NEW PLAN SEEKS TO SPUR RESCUE OF 'BOAT PEOPLE'
description: International refugee officials say they have worked out a plan that they hope will encourage ship captains to rescue ''boat people'' in distress rather than abandon them to starvation, drowning and pirates.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLLECTIONS AND TRADITIONS ABOUND
description: IN the autumn of 1958, it was the

title: LANDOWNERS FIGHT SHIFT OF APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: A dispute has broken out in the scenic northwest corner of Connecticut over a proposal to relocate the Appalachian Trail from a dirt road to the ridge of a nearby hill.

title: 650 ACRES REGAINED BY INDIANS
description: A group of eastern Connecticut Indians has taken title to about 650 acres of land, an indication that an eight-year struggle to regain reservation territory is near an end.

title: PAYING HOMAGE TO MOZART
description: At the climax of the play ''Amadeus,'' in a speech unfortunately never uttered on stage for reasons of length, the composer Antonio Salieri informed the audience: ''The God I acknowledge lives, for example, in bars 34 to 44 of Mozart's Masonic funeral music.'' The extremity of this statement - which incidentally is not uttered in the film version either, because of a less verbal and more cinematic script - stirred me profoundly. It permitted my protagonist to cite specific bars of music as evidence of the presence of divinity in the world, rather than just to talk in vague, exalted terms about genius. Surely the specific is always the point in art.

title: ONLY 'TRIAD INSIDERS' WILL SUCCEED
description: IT is a rare businessman who still

title: THIS EARLY-MUSIC MAN LIKES SYMPHONIES, TOO
description: Padding through the lobby of the Mayflower Hotel in his bare feet the other day, Christopher Hogwood seemed very much a modern man in a traditional setting. We usually think of this distinguished British conductor and keyboard player as quite the reverse - a purveyor of 17th- and 18th-century style operating in a world based on progress and change, not tradition.

title: Denise DeConcini To Wed a Student
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini and Mrs. DeConcini of Tucson, Ariz., and McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Denise Marie DeConcini to Robert Anthony Ramin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Ramin of Ithaca, N.Y. The wedding is to be late next year.

title: British Protesters Arrested
description: Policemen arrested more than 100 protesters from the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament on Friday after they sat down in front of entrances to the Alconbury air base near here, which is to become a support base for American cruise missiles, a police spokesman said. The base is now used by United States fighter jets and spy planes.

title:
GARDENING;
THE ADVANTAGES OF PLANTING IN THE FALL
description: BY this time, banners in garden centers are proclaiming that ''fall is for planting.'' Experienced gardeners know this is far more than a sales gimmick: It is a statement of fact. New gardeners, however, may need to be convinced. After all, spring, when everything is starting to grow, would seem the best time for planting.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE STORIES OF F. SCOTT FITZGERALD. (Scribners, $6.95.) Malcolm Cowley selected the 28 stories and composed the introduction and notes for this collection. Alice B. Toklas wrote in The Book Review in 1951 that it was a ''melancholy pleasure'' to read the stories, for F. Scott Fitzgerald, whom she knew, ''has become a legend and the epoch he created is history.'' Miss Toklas added that ''one must gratefully acknowledge the variety of examples chosen from'' the work of Fitzgerald, ''a man who could not easily accept the passing of his own youth.'' BARTLEBY IN MANHATTAN: And Other Essays, by Elizabeth Hardwick. (Vintage, $6.95.) This 1983 collec tion, written by Elizabeth Hardwick between 1962 and 1982, includes essays on Lee Harvey Oswald, Svetlana Alliluyeva, Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights movement, Brazil, plays and authors. Denis Donoghue said in these pages, ''It is not news that Miss Hardwick is a good writer or that she has many ways of making words do her bidding. She can be laconic, but her ordinary style is lyric or meditative; she likes opulent effects and a well-turned syntax.''

title:
LEISURE;
CHOOSING THE BEST SEED FOR LAWNS;
description: Robert Emmons is a professor in the Plant Science Department, SUNY, Cobleskill.

title: Shamocracy in South Africa South Africa wants the world to believe that it is somehow moving to racial justice by establishing separate parliaments for some nonwhites. But even those supposed to benefit are unconvinced.
description: Only 20 percent of eligible voters bothered to take part in a recent election of a chamber meant to represent 600,000 Indians.

title: Procrastinator of Year Waiting to Be Found
description: If there is anyone who would like to nominate someone for 1984 Procrastinator of the Year, Les Waas would be glad to hear from him, whenever he gets a chance to drop Mr. Waas a line.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Uranium CargoOn the Bottom
description: It wasn't the prospect of long-lost treasure that lured divers a dozen miles off the coast of Belgium to the wreck of the Mont Louis last week. It was an environmental threat.

title: SCHOOL FOR ACTORS IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT'S allure as a nurturing place for the arts continues to flourish.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Bomb Sniffing
description: After two terrorist bombings - one in Beirut in October 1983 that killed 241 American servicemen and one the next month that caused damage outside the United States Senate chamber - dogs trained to sniff out explosives were moved into the White House compound in November. Officials said the dogs would screen every entering vehicle, including the limousines of Cabinet members.

title: U.S. Envoy Meets Tunisian
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Gen. Vernon A. Walters, met today with President Habib Bourguiba, the official Tunisian press agency reported. General Walters arrived in Tunisia, where he is to address a conference at the National Defense Institute, after a secret visit to Morocco last week, according to State Department officials in Washington. Morocco and Libya signed a unity accord last month.

title: THE WORLD ; The DroopingGulf War
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week gave a possible reason why Iran's long-standing threat of an all-out offensive against Iraq has not been executed. The military balance has shifted to Iraq in recent months, a staff report said, because of ''massive arms sales'' by France and the Soviet Union and an effective American-led boycott of arms to Iran.

title: DOMESTIC DISCLOSURES
description: FAMILY DANCING

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
AS THE NEST GROWS QUIET
description: HE is gone. Pulled out this morning before 7 o'clock, headed north on I-95. Our son and only child gathered his worldly goods, put his affairs in order, said goodbye to his high school friends, and left to begin his freshman year at a university three hours away from here.

title: Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE FRENCH-CONTINENTAL MANNER
description: THE suggestion to visit Marcel's Locust Valley Inn in Locust Valley came from someone who advised that it was the food, not the decorations, that was worth recommending.

title: SCHOOLS FACING RISING COSTS, NEW STANDARDS
description: C ONTINUING the pattern of the last decade, public schools in Nassau and Suffolk Counties will open this week with decreased enrollments and increased expenditures, reflecting declining birth rates and inflationary costs. However, this year there will be a new state aid formula for school districts, and many districts on the Island are phasing in new graduation requirements as mandated by the New York State Board of Regents.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM CORROSIVE ROCK TO CABARET
description: Great Expectations An animated version of the Dickens novel by Warwick Gilbert and Jean Tych Vestron Video 69 minutes. $39.95

title: DURABLE MACKINAC
description: Outside the Middle West, its reputation rests largely on the Grand Hotel, a white-frame Victorian splendor, and, with the courage of convictions other places should envy, on its absolute ban of the motor vehicle in favor of the bicycle and horse. But Mackinac Island, a six-square-mile dot of Michigan in upper Lake Huron, is much more, one of those unusual resorts whose attractions are more than a match for the words of its brochure writers.

title: VATICAN STUDY EXPECTED TO CAUTION ACTIVIST PRIESTS
description: The Vatican is about to issue its most detailed criticism to date on the doctrine known as the ''theology of liberation,'' which has been used to justify the activism of Roman Catholic priests and nuns in Latin America over the past 15 years.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VIENNA
description: That local rookie police officers will impersonate Chinese court flunkies in an Italian production of Puccini's ''Turandot'' in December seems to interest the Viennese more than whether East-West ''Star Wars'' talks will be held in their city.

title: Victoria B. Smith Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Victoria Belle Smith to William John Chichester has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roger B. Smith of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Chichester of Midland, Mich.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Quest for Energy: Personal Views I am writing to comment on the use of quotes attributed to me in the article ''Grumman's Quest for Energy'' (July 22).

title: Acid Procrastination Throughout the Eastern seaboard, the acid brought by rain, snow, dew and fog is stretching the natural resilience of lakes and soils to their breaking point. The poison is so diffuse and gradual that overt damage is hard to pinpoint. But already the warning signs - dead lakes, damaged crops, forests of stunted trees - presage a massive natural disaster. The Administration's undeviating response to each new danger signal is to call for another study.
description: Last week the Environmental Protection Agency turned down another opportunity for action by rebuffing a petition from New York and other states to curb the sources of acid rain in the Midwest. Lack of definitive proof of harm, the agency says, bars taking steps under the Clean Air Act to control acid pollutants.

title: JAZZ ARTISTS CHAMPION THE CAUSE OF THE CLARINET
description: The clarinet's fall from grace in jazz circles has never been satisfactorily explained. From the first stirrings of jazz, around the turn of the century, through the 1940's, the clarinet ranked with the trumpet, trombone and saxophone as one of the principal jazz horns. In the orchestras of such popular band leaders as Benny Goodman, Artie Shaw and Woody Herman, it was probably the best-known horn of the swing era.

title:
DINING OUT;
PORTUGESE DINING NOT IN NEWARK
description: WHEN Alfonso Pernas opened his restaurant in Hillside about seven years ago, it was welcomed as an outpost of Spanish-Portuguese cuisine and conviviality. Several miles west of Newark's Ironbound enclave (the area that had something of an exclusive on cozy Iberian dining), it was given two stars in this space and built up a loyal clientele.

title: DANCE
description: Dancing as an urban activity is being stressed by several groups this week. Battery Dance Company is opening its third annual Downtown Dance Festival, with free lunch-hour performances in two locations: the Chase Manhattan Plaza at Nassau and Cedar Streets and the World Trade Center Plaza off Church Street. Events get underway at Chase Manhattan on Tuesday with a concert by the Battery Dance Company which, under Jonathan Hollander's direction, seeks to bring dance to Manhattan's Financial District. Other attractions at Chase Manhattan include the Spanish Dance Arts Company on Wednesday, Balletfore in a revival of ''The Firebird'' on Thursday and a tap extravaganza with Jane Goldberg, Andrea Levine, Charles (''Cookie'') Cook and Anita Feldman on Friday. On Friday, the Spanish company will also appear at the World Trade Center. All performances are at 12:15 P.M.

title: REAL SPIES SHOOT DOWN SPY MOVIES
description: WASHINGTON
To the Editor:

title: THE REAGAN TURNOUT
description: Voter turnout is almost certainly

title: NEW LOOKS FOR GIANTS, EAGLES
description: When the Giants open their season against the Philadelphia Eagles today in Giants Stadium, you will need a scorecard and a good part of the game to identify the players on both sides.

title: Illuminating The History Of America
description: With a roll-call of names such as Ethan Allen, Benedict Arnold and Louis Joseph de Montcalm, with a roster of sites from Fort William Henry to Bloody Pond and Fort Ticonderoga, with the rattle of rifle fire and the roar of cannons, there is a new addition to the list of sound and light shows.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: U.F.O. SIGHTINGS

title: THE WORLD ; British UnionsAre Divided
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher returned from an 18-day vacation last week to find Britain's labor unrest wider and more confused than when she left it. She was reported determined to maintain her policy of nonintervention in the long coal strike and in the second dock strike this summer.

title: IT ALL STARTED WITH 'LET'S PUT ON A SHOW'
description: IN search of the secret of the survival and longevity of the Gateway Playhouse on a dying-out

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY DOINGS

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDALIST ENTRIES SOUGHT FOR SHOW IN SWEDEN
description: Works by United States artists are now being sought for possible inclusion in a medallic art exhibition to be held in Stockholm next June. It is to be organized by the prestigious Federation Internationale de la Medaille (FIDEM) in conjunction with FIDEM's 20th World Congress

title: MUCH GROUND TO BE COVERED IN CAMPAIGN'S FINAL PHASE
description: ST.PAUL PRESIDENT Reagan and Walter F. Mondale formally launch their campaigns tomorrow at opposite ends of the country, speaking to different constituencies and, perhaps most important, with their campaigns dominated by sharply contrasting moods.

title: HEADLINERS ; Alvarado's New Job One of doubtless many things
description: Anthony J. Alvarado learned from his experience as New York City Schools Chancellor is that the job market can be tight for public officials who resign under pressure. Last week, after starting his first job since he left the city payroll in May, Mr. Alvarado said the search for a new position had been rough for a while and he was happy the resistance was beginning to fade.

title: LETTERS
description: ISRAEL'S BITTER WEST BANK HARVEST

title: FOR F.E.C., JUSTICE DELAYED IS ROUTINE
description: In a recent effort to prove her good faith in the matter of $109,000 in illegal loans from her family for her first Congressional campaign, Geraldine A. Ferraro noted that the loans were fully disclosed to the Federal Election Commission in 1978.

title: Susan Peng-Yu Lu Is Engaged to James Reichek
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Si-Ming Lu of Whippany, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Peng-Yu Lu to James G. Reichek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Reichek of Parsippany, N.J.

title: Thorpe Legacy Not So Noble
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HEARING ADDRESSES NOISE AT AIRPORT
description: LEGISLATORS from Westchester County in New York sought the views of the public last week on the future of Westchester County Airport, finding that the issue of noise continues to be dominant and that many people, including those from nearby Greenwich, prefer the airport to remain a small general aviation facility.

title: CUBS, ON 3 IN 9TH, BEAT BRAVES
description: Gary Matthews doubled home Ryne Sandberg to lead a three-run ninth inning today that gave the first-place Chicago Cubs a 4-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: WOMAN, 96, FACES EVICTION
description: -year-old Christian Scientist, became ill last December, she insisted she needed only a little ''looking after.''

title: INSIDE CORPORATE TELEVISION STUDIOS
description: large television studios with cameras, teleprompters and a removable overhead lighting grid. Empty sets, used for talk shows, a news program or a cooking demonstration are placed in the corner. Nearby, in the control room, people are working on post-production editing - assembling the narration, music, pictures and special effects.

title: TEMPLE BY FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT IS RENOVATED
description: Seventy-five years ago this fall, Frank Lloyd Wright inspired his contemporaries with Unity Temple, a monolithic concrete structure in Oak Park, Ill. While the wrecking ball has destroyed nearly every other building from Wright's earliest period, this one is being preserved.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Fine Satire On Modern Attitudes Your Aug. 5 issue contained an article by Roger Calip (''Beethoven Belongs to Everyone'') that is certainly a laugh a clause. In it, the author's ability as a satirist of present-day bubble-gum attitudes toward the art of music is firmly established.

title: NEW TERM, NEW RULES BEGINNING
description: WHEN New Jersey's 2,200 public schools open this week, they will, in some respects, reflect trends that have continued for more than a decade: fewer students, fewer schools, greater ethnic diversity, more adults returning to school.

title: CRIME
description: Here we go again - the old story of a pair of police partners who are of different backgrounds and who initially dislike each other but find they can work together after the newcomer proves himself. Read all about them in BLEEDING HEARTS by Teri White (Mysterious Press, $14.95).

title: HOW THE U.S. HAD IT MADE
2 HOMERS FOR STRAWBERRY
description: If anyone wants to believe again, the signs were all over Shea Stadium last night as the Mets swept a doubleheader from the San Diego Padres, 7-4 and 10-6.

title: Dr. Sharon R. Maza Is Engaged to Eric D. Rosen
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Gabriel Maza of Deer Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Sharon R. Maza to Eric D. Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Rosen of New Milford, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Henry Lee Lucas Confesses, So a Murder Verdict Is Voided
description: A judge has overturned the murder conviction of Scotty Scott and ordered a new trial on the ground that Henry Lee Lucas has confessed to the crime.

title: Client Sues Her Hairdresser After Receiving 'Bizarre' Cut
description: A woman who said she suffered mental anguish after receiving ''an extreme and bizarre'' haircut has filed suit against her hairdresser and hair salon.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE CHALLENGE OF AN AFRICAN JOURNEY
description: Africa is at once magnificent and daunting. The prospective traveler is attracted by the countryside, the wide variety of wildlife roaming free and the vitality of tribal ways in many localities. But the thought of the remoteness of many parts of the continent, the widespread primitiveness and poverty, the health hazards and often rudimentary and uncertain communications give the unseasoned traveler pause.

title: President, in Radio Talk, Sees Gains for Workers
description: President Reagan said today that the continuing resurgence of the economy meant ''a hopeful thumbs-up'' for American workers.

title: SUMMER SETS THE CRACKPOT BUBBLING
description: In the summertime, park benches are normally the forum for crackpot theories. This season, more than the usual number of weird notions are also finding their way onto the screen.

title: THE GENTRIFICATION OF THE EAST VILLAGE
description: WHEN Susan Kelley looks out her window she sees a beginning. ''There are so many young professionals sitting on the stoops, ties undone, just talking,'' said the 24-year-old Wall Street real-estate broker as she surveyed East 13th Street, where she has lived for two years. ''There's a feeling of togetherness, of movement. A feeling that things are different every day.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on a dry spell in Portland, Ore., incorrectly described the paths of two rivers. The Columbia runs along the city's northern boundary, and the Willamette runs through the city.

title: ON THE GOLEM AND THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Luggage
description: To the Editor:

title: Space for the Homeless
description: New York State officials were also on the receiving end of a lawsuit last week. The Coalition for the Homeless, a private advocacy group, filed a class-action suit against overcrowding in shelters for the homeless in New York City.

title: DISASTER AT SEA: A SURVIVOR'S TALE
description: WEST PALM BEACH, FLA.SOME people were praying. There were people singing. My mother said the deck was getting hot. There were noises, as if the ship was going to explode.''

title: DATA BANKData Bank, September 2,1984
KEITH CAMERON WED TO CECELIA FITZGIBBON
description: Cecelia Irene Fitzgibbon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vincent Fitzgibbon of Seekonk, Mass., was married yesterday to Keith S. Cameron, the son of Angelyn Stanley Cameron of Middlebury, Conn., and the late Stuart Elliot Cameron. The Rev. Scott A. Kallstrom performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: St. John's Wins
description: Frank Caccavale drove in three runs on a single, a double and a triple to lead St. John's to a 14-6 victory over Seton Hall, the two-time defending champion, in the third round of the Honsberger Memorial Tournament yesterday at Redman Field, Jamaica, Queens. St. John's is the only undefeated team remaining in the eight-school, double-elimination tournament.

title: Louisiana Cutler Is Bride in Alaska
description: Louisiana Winslow Cutler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Cutler of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Hendon Lamar Johnson, a son of Mrs. Amon Thomas Johnson of Thomasville, Ga., and the late Mr. Johnson. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride in Anchorage by the bride's sister, Judge Beverly Cutler of the Alaska Superior Court.

title: BROAD STUDENT SPORTS PHYSICALS REVEALING HEALTH PROBLEMS
description: More than 350 students from high schools in Ansonia and Seymour had to go through more than the usual poking and prodding to pass sports physicals this summer.

title: AUTUMN SALES: UP OR DOWN?
description: Consumer buying has been in the doldrums for three months, convincing economists that the long-awaited shopping letdown had arrived. Indeed, things have been so slow that some stores have extended their summer sales into the fall selling season.

title: MAYBE IT'S TIME FOR SUSHI
description: IF you live near a fish market

title: LITTLE BY LITTLE, CALIFORNIA PREPARES FOR THE BIG ONE
description: After the new term gets under way later this month, teachers in Los Angeles's 430 elementary schools will periodically shout: ''Drop!'' If their pupils do as they are told, they will fall quickly to the floor and dive underneath their desks.

title: Of Vandals And 'Contact'
description: Arlene Levine's letter to the editor and strong ''Ode to a Vandal'' (Aug. 5) addressing my July 1 article, ''Musings on a Lost Lighthouse'' (Opinion Page), advocate ''one-to- one contact'' between the disturbed and the knowledgeably loving as an anodyne for discord in human relations, and I am all for it. But a word of caution is indicated.

title: THE WORLD ; Staying HomeIn South Africa
description: South African whites last week took another step toward giving the country's other minorities a limited say in government. But South Africa's 800,000 Indians, like the 2.8 million people of mixed race who had their own election the week before, showed little interest in the three- house segregated Parliament to be sworn in tomorrow.

title: A NOT-SO-SENTIMENTAL EDUCATION
description: MARIAN SELDES, an actress and writer, is the author of ''Time Together,'' a novel, and ''The Bright Lights: A Theater Life,'' newly issued in paperback by Limelight Editions.

title: PANEL ASSESES INDIAN HISTORY
description: IT has not been easy for Connecticut public schoolchildren to

title: DISMISSAL OF CHARGE AGAINST INDIAN LEADER UPHELD
description: The dismissal of a weapon charge against Dennis Banks, the Indian leader, has been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which said nearly eight years of delays violated his right to a speedy trial.

title: IN THE HEART OF SARDINIA
description: It begins at 5 A.M. First, a lone gull sounds forth, and then slowly up and down the coast the island birds echo the call of first light. Before long, fingers of yellow slip through the shutters, and outside the high, feathery cirrus clouds are watercolored pink. On the far horizon, beyond the two little white fishing boats that have kept their all-night vigil, out on the very rim where the Mediterranean Sea disappears east toward mainland Italy, brilliant blues, yellows, pinks and purples crowd into position.

title: THE NATION ; Ex-Reagan AideIs Indicted
description: The Justice Department brought criminal charges last week against Thomas C. Reed, a former national security adviser to President Reagan, accusing him of improper dealings in the stock market three years ago. It is not the first time one of the President's men has faced charges of financial impropriety, but it may be one of the more inconvenient instances, coming as it did during the campaign season. Mr. Reed's indictment conceivably could give Democrats a chance to criticize Mr. Reagan's appointments and his Administration's ''business ethic.''

title: Clarke C. Wilson Is Married in Ohio To Stanton Pierce
description: Clarke Crandall Wilson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Reading Wilson of Cleveland, and Stanton Ten Broeck Pierce, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Shelton Pierce of Brookline, Mass., and Castine, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Mary Benedict Von Weise performed the ceremony at St. Christopher-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio.

title: New Cabinet Named In Bourkina Fasso
description: The leader of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, has named a new Cabinet that reduces the influence of the Marxist Patriotic Development League, officials said today.

title: Collegians to Play In Amateur Final
description: Scott Verplank of Oklahoma State and Sam Randolph of Southern California ousted their semifinal opponents today and will meet Sunday in the 36-hole championship of the United States Amateur golf tournament.

title: Article 164942 -- No Title
description: As they waited to be cast into the ranks of the Rockefellers, Gettys and Hunts, most ticket buyers had firm plans for the riches they hoped to win in today's $40 million Illinois Lotto drawing, the country's largest jackpot ever.

description: Amphibious Imaginings

title: FREE THE ENTERPRENEUR
description: Q. If a healthy economy is the best tonic for small business, doesn't that suggest it should welcome a second Reagan term?

title: A PRESIDENT UNSUITED FOR POLITICS
description: AN UNCOMMON MAN The Triumph of Herbert Hoover. By Richard Norton Smith. Illustrated. 488 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: JUDGE IS CRITICAL OF DETROIT MAYOR
description: The chief Federal judge in Detroit has removed himself from a case involving Mayor Coleman A. Young after telling a local newspaper, ''One of the things we have to give black people the time to learn to do is to learn how to run city governments.''

title: Toll in Afghan Blast Said to Be at Least 30
description: At least 30 people were killed and 100 wounded in the bomb blast Friday at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, Western diplomats here said today.

title: Brigham Young Upsets Pitt, 20-14
description: Robbie Bosco, who hopes to follow the steps of some famous quarterbacks at Brigham Young University, engineered a 20-14 upset over Pitt today in one of the biggest football triumphs in the Cougars' history.

title: SUTTON IS LEADER ON 68-206
description: Hal Sutton shot a 3-under-par 68 today and took a one-shot lead in the $300,000 B.C. Open.

title: UNEXPECTED RESULTS
description: The form chart for this year's United States Championship in Berkeley, Calif., went as wildly astray as could be imagined. Not one of last year's joint champions, Walter Browne of Berkeley, Larry Christiansen of Los Angeles or Roman Dzindzichashvili of Queens, took any of the top three prizes this time.

title: CLASH ON CONTRIBUTIONS AS PRIMARY NEARS
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: 'GIGI' AND A GALA OPENING THE PALACE
description: THE former Roger Sherman Theater in New Haven, listed in the National Registry of Historic Places, has been restored in the Art Deco tradition and is ready to introduce more than $1 million worth of talent for its inaugural season as the Palace, a multipurpose concert hall and music theater.

title: EAST SIDE AFFORDALES
description: Renovation is now under way on a small residential building at the corner of East 96th Street and Second Avenue that is aimed at apartment-buyers who may have been priced out of the cooperative market in Manhattan. Steven A. Kessner, the developer who is renovating the turn-of-the-century walk-up, says prices for the apartments - all one-bedrooms - will start at $85,000.

title: KEEPING THE SHARKS AT BAY
description: ''Shark repellents'' - antitakeover changes in corporate charters and bylaws - will be used with increasing zeal by companies facing unfriendly suitors, investment bankers say. And, if the recent past is any indicator, stockholders will embrace such moves.

title: OFF TO A GOOD START ON A SCOTTISH MORN
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM, a writer based in New York and a specialist in Japanese textiles, frequently visits Scotland. By AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM

title: Gigi Ghriskey, Cartographer, to Marry Daniel Brewster Jr., Journalist, Oct. 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Ghriskey of Greenwich, Conn., and Seal Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Gwen Ghriskey to Daniel Baugh Brewster Jr., a son of Carol Lieper Brewster and Mr. Brewster, both of Baltimore. The wedding is to be Oct. 27.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; A Blow to Bid forBalanced Budget
description: California, the state that launched the tax revolt six years ago, may not get to vote on one of the most ambitious taxpayer-initiated measures, a referendum on a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.

title: 7 of 11 Workers Seized At a Jersey Town Unit
description: Seven of the 11 employees of Berlin Township's Public Works Department have been arrested on charges of smoking and selling marijuana on the job, the police said today.

title: INDUSTRY COOPERATION IS AN IMMPERATIVE
description: Q. What is so urgent about competing in global markets today that makes large-scale cooperation among companies necessary?

title: FLUTIE PASSES 330 YARDS IN 44-24 VICTORY
description: Doug Flutie tied a Boston College record for career touchdowns as he passed for four tonight in a season- opening 44-24 victory over Western Carolina tonight.

title: WOMEN DEPICTED IN DANCE COME IN MANY GUISES TODAY
description: Helen Dannenberg walked out into the stage space of P.S. 122 recently and did a duet of sorts with an ironing board, using it variously as a ballet barre, a buoying surface for swimming and a perch from which to rise wryly, triumphant as a rooster in the early dawn. An ''ordinary woman'' - a little too short, a little too plump, a little too ravaged by experience to be anything but itself - Miss Dannenberg's stage persona seemed to capture a female sensibility that has become increasingly visible in New York dance over the past decade. There were no irons or rumpled clothes in sight. It did not occur to the woman on stage to go through the motions of ironing, as it once might have. Instead, a stereotypical object readily identifiable with women's work was used as a springboard to release the performer into the ''larger'' and possibly more universal emotion.

title: FERRARO'S FRIEND
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR VINEYARD OWNERS, IT'S TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING
description: In the Finger Lakes region of New York State, Neil Simmons is getting ready to harvest 38 acres of Catawba grapes, one of the main varieties used in making New York wine. But he has been able to sell only half his crop. ''It sure puts me behind the eight ball,'' he said.

title: A SEASON WITH LESS DANCING AND A FEW NEW PARTNERS
description: There will be more running, less dancing. Salaries

title:
PROSPECTS;
BUY MORE, GET MORE
description: Airlines do it. Auto rental agencies do it. And now, one well-known retailer is rewarding faithful customers.

title: Greek and Turkish Cypriots Accept U.N. Move for Talks
description: Greek and Turkish Cypriots both have approved the new United Nations proposals for peace talks the divided Eastern Mediterranean island.

title: Clemson Is Victor By 40-7
description: Clemson, behind two touchdown passes from Mike Eppley, routed Appalachian State, 40-7, in the season opener for both teams today. Clemson broke the game open in the second half when Eppley passed 5 yards to the tight end K. D. Dunn to help make the score 26-0.

title: THE STAR OF EMPIRE RISES
description: THE SPANISH WAR An American Epic 1898. By G. J. A. O'Toole. 447 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: A STANDOUT CASSETTE DECK
description: Superlatives are slippery. One can trip on them as easily as on that proverbial banana peel; and especially among audio components, where excellence can be reached in many different ways, trying to pick a true paragon is tricky. But if one had to single out the best cassette deck, a leading candidate for this distinction would unquestionably be Tandberg's new Model TCD 3014.

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY REVISISTED
description: LOS ANGELES

title: THE NATION ; Ablaze inMontana
description: The big skies glowed red last week as Montana suffered its worst forest fires in a decade. President Reagan declared three of the biggest fires disasters, making Federal funds available to battle them.

title: ; ON MAKING CHILDREN THINK ABOUT DEATH
description: To the Editor:

title: ORGANIZING TO FIGHT A MENACE
description: THREE years ago, after her 16-year-old daughter was in an automobile accident involving a drunken driver, Lorraine Roy decided to take action.

title: NEW YORK POLICEMEN JOIN AN IRISH PARADE HONORING GUERRILLAS
description: Some two dozen members of a New York City police band marched at the head of a parade today commemorating 10 Irish guerrillas who died in 1981 in a hunger strike at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland.

title: Julie Spain Wed To Paul Broches
description: Julie Spain, a clinical psychologist, and Paul Broches, an architect, were married yesterday at their home in East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated.

title: STUDENT AHLETES FACE STRICTER GRADE RULES
description: HIGH SCHOOL athletes in Connecticut who may have been inclined to rest on their athletic laurels in the classroom are going to have to hit the books harder than ever this fall.

title: REACHING OUT; American Neighbor
description: A friend, raised in the small-town America that so often evokes the President's nostalgia, returned to her old home recently. On hearing an elderly aunt speak of ''Steve and his wife, Betsy,'' she assumed they were new neighbors.

title:
LONG ILSAND OPNION;
SEASON OF MAGIC, SEASON OF RENEWAL
description: SOME summers end and we hardly notice, while others wind slowly to a finish, and we mourn their passing as we would the parting of an old and very dear friend. One of those friends once told me that if I were sad in September, it simply meant I'd had a wonderful time all summer long. Not a bleak way of looking at it, but nowadays, I question whether ''summer's lease hath all too short a date,'' or if it's perfect, just as is.

title: WILL TAKING TURNS END ISRAEL'S IMPASSE?
description: FIVE weeks after inconclusive elections, the

title: HOUSTON GRAPPLES WITH AN ERA OF DIMMER HOPES
description: Two years after the energy bust brought its frenzied boom to an abrupt and painful end, a new Houston is emerging: a more sober, modest and mature city with lowered expectations.

title: MODERATE HOUSING FOR GREENWICH
description: FOR the first time since the close of World War II the Town of Greenwich, noted for its stately homes, its million- dollar estates and costly condominiums, has embarked on a program to provide subsidized housing for people of modest means.

title:
GARDENING;
THE ADVANTAGES OF PLANTING IN THE FALL
description: BY this time, banners in garden centers are proclaiming that ''fall is for planting.'' Experienced gardeners know this is far more than a sales gimmick: It is a statement of fact. New gardeners, however, may need to be convinced. After all, spring, when everything is starting to grow, would seem the best time for planting.

title: PHYSICAL-THERAPY RULE CHANGE STIRS DEBATE
description: THE state's Board of Medical Examiners is expected to adopt rules next week allowing physicians, chiropractors and podiatrists to use unlicensed aides to administer some kinds of physical-therapy treatments. Supporters say this is a rational approach to low-risk, mechanical tasks; critics say it will open the way for anyone, including a doctor's file clerk, to use devices that can cause serious harm.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM CORROSIVE ROCK TO CABARET

title: LETTERS
description: WHOSE PARTY IS IT, ANYWAY?

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: The California Angels reactivated Geoff Zahn , Rod Carew , Rick Burleson and Frank LaCorte yesterday, when the major league rosters were permitted to increase from 25 to 40 players. All four had been on the disabled list. . . . The Chicago Cubs took the third baseman Richie Hebner and the catcher Ron Hassey off the disabled list. On Friday, the Cubs acquired Davey Lopes from the Oakland A's.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
HONEST LABOR SPURS A BOY TO MANHOOD
description: ONE recent moonlit night when sleep would not embrace the edge of dreams, memories stirred the boy in me. I gave my mind to times long gone, to boyhood times that helped shape the boy and man.

title: Gold Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TRUSTED MORE ON THE ECONOMY, POLL FINDS
description: President Reagan is viewed by voters as better able than his challenger to keep the country prosperous, while Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, leads in perceived ability to keep the country out of war, according to a Gallup Poll.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; 'Discovery'Is Up andOff to Work
description: NASA's reluctant debutante, the space shuttle Discovery, finally came out last week. After two months of delays, the $1.2 billion craft soared into a cloudless Florida sky on its maiden run. And a busy one it was to be. As the space agency struggled to get the shuttle program back on track, two missions' worth of experiments were crammed onto Discovery's log, and the cargo bay resembled a family stationwagon on a summer vacation.

title: WHAT CUOMO WON IN HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: When the longest and largest hospital and nursing home strike in New York's history ended, the hospitals had given the union a wage increase that was twice as large as they initially offered and half of what the union wanted. It seemed a reasonable compromise, but the only ones smiling when the settlement was announced in the lobby of the Roosevelt Hotel last weekend were union leaders and Governor Cuomo and his aides.

title: MEXICAN PRESIDENT CAUTIONS AGAINST DEFAULT
description: President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado today firmly rejected any plan that would result in Mexico's failing to repay its international debts, saying this would cause ''grave damage to the country.''

title: PANCHO VILLA DEATH MASK CROSSES THE BORDER AGAIN
description: More than 60 years after the assassination of Pancho Villa, his death mask has been returned to Mexico from the United States, with good feelings on both sides after some acrimony.

title: Motorcyclists Injured In San Marino Practice
description: Several riders were seriously injured in a series of accidents today during practice for the Gran Prix of San Marino, the closing event of the world motorcycling championships.

title: Els Collins, an Executive, Weds James Greene, Actor
description: Els Collins, an account executive for Byers, Schwalbe & Associates, a management concern for artists, and James Greene, an actor, were married yesterday.

title: Ex-Head of Baptist Body Set to Endorse Reagan
description: Dr. Joseph Harrison Jackson, pastor of Olivet Baptist Church in Chicago and a former longtime president of the seven million-member National Baptist Convention, said today that he would endorse President Reagan's re-election bid.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ABANDONED grocery carts are the eyesore of Somerville these days. They turn up just about everywhere - on lawns and at curbside, on sidewalks and railroad tracks and in the muddy waters of Peter's Brook.

title: No Headline
description: Linda Ball to Be Married

title: Harry T. Nusbaum, 74; Ex-State Court Justice
description: Harry T. Nusbaum, a former justice of New York Supreme Court, died at Cabrini Medical Center on Friday. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE REGION ; Decision UpheldOn the Disabled
description: The Reagan Administration has not spread its safety net wide enough for the disabled, a Federal appeals court ruled last week in New York. The court ordered the Social Security Administration to restore benefits it had terminated to 4,000 mentally disabled New York State residents and to reconsider its rejection of applications by 50,000 to 60,000 others.

title: N.J. TRANSIT TO OFFER DISCOUNTS TO RIDERS ON MORRISTOWN LINE
description: N.J. Transit officials have announced a campaign to bring riders back to the newly upgraded Morristown Line that will include sharp discounts on some fares.

title: TRAFFIC VEXES RESORT
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, a summer resort community on the western end of the Long Beach island, has been suffering from traffic problems unlike anything her sister barrier island - Fire Island - could ever imagine.

title: GROWING PAINS
description: The news about carbon dioxide is bad. Apparently there is far more of it in the air than there used to be, because everybody burns a lot more coal and oil than we did 100 years ago, and the byproduct of that is carbon dioxide. So what? you ask. So all this excess carbon dioxide just might change the whole earth, that's what. We are talking about a gas that makes plants grow, and scientists are finding that while more of it makes plants grow faster, bigger and fatter, it does not increase the growth rate equally for all plants.
To the Editor:

title: Federal 'Pyramid'
description: ''Pharaoh Wanted. Pyramid for Sale.''

title: NIGERIAN OFFICIAL REPORTED TO FLEE BRITAIN IN CRATE
description: A Nigerian military officer, sought in a foiled attempt in July to kidnap a former Nigerian official and send him home in a crate, was reported today to have fled Britain this week in the same fashion, hidden in a box.

title: NEWARK ARCHBISHOP EVICTING DEFIANT PRIEST
description: A long, oftenbitter dispute between a parish priest and the Archdiocese of Newark has provided an unusual public glimpse into the internal workings of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: CLUE SOUGHT IN DEATHS OF EX-ATHLETE'S FAMILY
description: The police today were hoping to recover rifle slugs that might provide a lead in the fatal shooting Friday of four relatives of Kermit Alexander, a former professional football player.

title: No Headline
description: Stacy Pomeroy to Marry

title: A BRIGHTER JOBLESS OUTLOOK
description: August's national unemployment rate, due out Friday, may remove some of the chill spread by July's unexpected civilian rate of 7.5 percent, the first increase in 20 months. That gain from June's 7.1 percent was seen as a clear signal that the economy was moderating.

title: COUNTY CITES NEED TO FIND FOSTER HOMES
description: THEY are trying to make their 1970 car last one more year. The bills are mounting and they may have to take a second mortgage to pay them. His appliance repairman's salary is barely sufficient for a household with six children. Her nurse's income is decreasing as the birth of the seventh child grows nearer. Soon it will stop altogether. They are involved in some difficult legal battles, which are becoming costly.

title: DEVEOPER BUCKS THE ODDS IN EAST ORANGE
description: WHEN Wilbert Allen first planned to erect and sell factory-built two- and three-bedroom town houses in his home town of East Orange for $65,800 to $69,200, local real-estate people warned him that no conventional house had sold in the city for more than $59,000 in years, and that only a few scattered private houses had been built without direct subsidies in more than a decade.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
OF MICE AND WOMEN
description: My friend Susan rented a house in Southampton for the summer. In the woods.

title: IN A FIT OF INDEPENDENCE, EASTERN EUROPE FLIRTS WITH BONN
description: The kaleidoscope of Eastern Europe has many pieces, bright and dark, and now, all at once, the combinations of light and shadow are quite different. Erich Honecker, president and Communist party chief of East Germany, is ''still possibly'' going to visit West Germany for the first time in his official capacities, at the end of the month. Bulgaria's Todor Zhivkov is also due in Bonn for the first time in September and Rumania's Nicolae Ceausescu in October. A week ago, Mr. Honecker visited Rumania. Erich Honecker in Rumania? A little more than 14 years ago, Mr. Ceausescu became the odd man out in the Warsaw Pact, refusing to go along with five other members of the Soviet bloc in putting pressure on and ultimately invading Czechoslovakia to quash a tentative reform movement. Asked how the Moscow loyalists in the bloc would treat maverick Rumania, an East German propaganda chief, Karl Eduard von Schnitzler, chose a soccer term. ''We'll leave them playing at left wing,'' he said. Thereafter Rumania was scorned as a rather harmless heretic.

title: MONTCLAIR TO OEN FACULTY CONCERTS
description: MONTCLAIR MONTCLAIR State College's ''Music Scholarship Concert Series'' - eight concerts running through May - will enter its third season Friday.

title: THE NATION ; E.P.A. Rejects
description: States' Plea On Acid Rain

title: Dallas's Public Schools Drop Credit for Church Bible Study
description: For the first time in 59 years, public school pupils in Dallas will not be able to get credit for studying the Bible in church, officials of the city school district say.

title:
GARDENING;
THE ADVANTAGES OF PLANTING IN THE FALL
description: BY this time, banners in garden centers are proclaiming that ''fall is for planting.'' Experienced gardeners know this is far more than a sales gimmick: It is a statement of fact. New gardeners, however, may need to be convinced. After all, spring, when everything is starting to grow, would seem the best time for planting.

title: FROM EUROPE WITH EARLY MUSIC
description: Three decades ago, it sometimes seemed as though early music was the exclusive posssession of a handful of scholars and maverick performers. Machaut, Dufay, Palestrina and Monteverdi were represented only in the history books, or perhaps with a token recording or two, while composers such as Robert White and John Sheppard were ignored altogether. Even Bach and Handel were best known through contemporary musical translations, by such men as Leopold Stokowski, Ferruccio Busoni, Thomas Beecham, and Alexander Siloti.

title: MAN FOUND GUILTY IN FLORIDA OF RAPING HIS WIFE
description: A 41-year- old man was found guilty of raping his wife in a case that had been dismissed and then reinstated by an appeals judge who ruled that violence, not sex, was the issue.

title: TELLING IT LIKE IT WAS
description: When the chef leaves a restaurant, the sauce is never quite the same. They might as well change the sign outside the establishment called Monday Night Football; Howard Cosell is hanging up his fluffy white cap and taking Monday nights off.

title: CHANGE COMES OVER PHILADELPHIA'S CITY HALL
description: In recent days, even commuters long inured to the impressive mass and ornate style of City Hall have been stopping in puzzlement as they pass through its four portals.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE next time Raffa's Restaurant in Glastonbury is threatened by a flood, Frank S. Raffa will be prepared with sandbags. ''Did you ever try to buy sandbags in the middle of a flood?'' he asked.

title: AN INCOMPREHENSIBLE 'MARRIAGE'
description: AUDEN IN LOVE

title: Nancy Paulsen Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Paulsen of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Rose Paulsen to David M. Friend, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Friend of Chicago. Miss Paulsen is the managing editor of the children's book department at Viking Penguin. Her fiance is a reporter for Life magazine.

title: HOME DESIGN ; FIREFLY'S ONGOING RURAL GLOW
description: In the late 1940's, the actor Fredric March and his wife, the actress Florence Eldridge, bought a simple 1780 farmhouse in Connecticut that they called Firefly because of the ballet of cascading lights that surrounded the porch every evening at dusk. ''The fireflies are still there,'' reports Joseph Cicio, its most recent occupant. So are the lush grounds that Florence Eldridge lovingly planned herself. According to Cicio, a senior vice president at Macy's, Miss Eldridge was so passionate about landscaping that she hired scores of gardeners to cart shrubs and trees from one end of the property to the other on dollies, like pieces of furniture being moved around a room, until each one was in a suitable place.

title: College Party Turns Violent
description: More than 200 officers used clubs and tear gas to break up a back-to- school party early today at Western Michigan University. At least 40 of the 1,000 people who were present were arrested, the police said. At least one officer was injured by a flying bottle in the four-hour melee, a shed was set on fire, and there were several reports of vandalism, said John Ross, Chief of the Kalamazoo Public Safety Department.

title: TEAMING UP: THE BREWERS AND THE GROCERS
description: For the Milwaukee Brewers, selling sweatshirts was not enough. The best road to a fan's heart, they felt, was through his stomach.

description: MODUS VIVENDI

title: THOSE FILLERS ARE DOING DOUBLE DUTY
description: Steve Schneider frequently reports on developments in cable.

title: IF YOU'RE THINING OF LIVING IN NEW SRINGVILLE
description: LOUIS CHRAMPANIS remembers

title: THE NEW SUPERMARKET TAKES SHAPE
description: AT the Edwards Food Warehouse along Route 1 in Orange, Conn., lines form at the deli, the fresh fish counter and the bakery. Shoppers wander through the aisles, where the merchandise sits in unpacked cartons on the shelves. Others migrate to the bulk-foods section where they scoop up everything from grits to cat litter from wooden cracker barrels. At the check-out counter they bag their own purchases.

title: Swazi Prince Accused Of Attempting a Coup
description: The deputy head of state in this southern African kingdom, Prince Sozisa Dlamini, has been suspended for an attempt to lead the armed forces in a coup, according to a statement issued today by the nation's ruling supreme council.

title: Nicaragua Reports an Attack
description: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan leader, said three small planes and a helicopter from Honduras attacked a Nicaraguan military school today, but the helicopter was shot down. Four men were reported to have been killed in the incident.

title: COLLEGES STEP UP RECRUITMENT
description: LONG ISLAND colleges and universities, faced with a shrinking pool of applicants within their own region and forced to compete against one another and with out- of-state schools for students, have stepped up recruiting efforts, turning increasingly to more businesslike methods.

title: COLLEGE ENROLLMENT LINKED TO VIETNAM WAR
description: Men who came of age in the Vietnam War accumulated more college education than those maturing either before or since, a Government study has found. The researcher who prepared the study said the change was probably caused by a combination of some men's avoiding the draft and others' using the G.I. Bill.

title: Alabama Votes Tuesday In Congressional Races
description: Voters in Alabama will pick Congressional nominees in both parties' primaries Tuesday, setting the stage for a November ballot that could send two Republicans to the Senate from this state.

The initial installment of the 10-part series will be broadcast on cable television for the first time on the Arts & Entertainment Network, beginning Monday at 8 P.M. It will be repeated at midnight and on Tuesday at 7 P.M.

title: ONE MORE, ANDREW STEIN RUNS AGAINST HIS MONEY
description: Andrew Stein is the kind of politician who can spend $500,000 on a primary for the House of Representatives and then call it a ''very low-key campaign.'' Mr. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, is one of four candidates vying for the Democratic nomination in next week's primary in the 15th Congressional District.

Mr. Nakasone, who was speaking to South Korean journalists, referred to what he described as ''ravages'' inflicted by Japan during its colonial occupation of Korea from 1910 to 1945. Japanese, he said, ''should deeply repent our past behavior.''

description: The spectacle of a great nation leaving crucial issues - the control of nuclear weapons and America's relations with the Soviet Union - to media consultants and image manipulators, the modern gladiators of politics, increasingly is generating apprehension among many Americans as well as in the wider world. What's needed instead is serious discussion leading to solid bipartisanship.

He'd say, 'I must have looked at the clock wrong.' A few months later he began to forget the route home. He became disoriented about what month and year it was. You say to yourself, O.K., I can live with this, but then it gets worse.''

title: THE PATH OFL.C.D. KNOW-HOW
description: The phrase ''liquid crystal'' sounds almost like a contradiction in terms, but it is an apt description for the molecules that have given rise to the field of liquid crystal display technology. Liquid crystals are chemicals that flow like liquids while still maintaining the orderly molecular arrangement usually associated with solids.

title: Bail Jumps to $1 Million
description: Judge Mitchell Lipschutz decided Thursday to set bail at $35,000 for Arthur Walker, 27 years old, of Willingboro, N.J., accused of abducting a woman who died in a rescue effort. After callers to a radio talk show complained of the low bail, he decided Friday to raise it to $1 million. Judge Lipschutz blamed ''a failure of communications'' with the District Attorney's office, which disputed that view, noting that its original request was for $200,000 bail.

title: PERUVIAN MILITARY FIGHTS TERRORISTS WITH TERROR
description: In its stepped-up campaign to wipe out Peru's leftist guerrillas, the military has been killing Indian peasants whose ties, if any, to the Maoist Shining Path movement have not been clearly established. Frequent reports of summary executions are officially denied, but the fresh graves are becoming harder to explain in an area where there has been no recent combat. Last week, two mass graves, one with 50 bodies and another with 15, were discovered near the Indian town of Huanta.

title: LIBYA HAS FEW FRIENDS AMONG NEIGHBORS
description: In the 15 years since he overthrew King Idris of Libya to pursue his eccentric vision of Islamic utopia, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has remained faithful to his ideals of Arab nationalism and Arab unity. But his dream of a unified Arab world under his leadership has remained elusive. Yesterday, he marked the anniversary with an appeal to Arabs to unite to ''destroy'' Israel. But he seems as politically isolated as ever. At home ''the Leader,'' as he is known here, faces quiet but growing resistance to his radical economic and social policies. Abroad, he is barely on speaking terms with most of his neighbors.

title: Nancy E. Steiner Will Be Married

title: OUT OF THE ATTIC, INTO THE LIMELIGHT
description: Linens and lace work of the Victorian age through the 1930's are all the vogue again. Highly decorative embroidered sheets and pillowcases, placemats and napkins, hand towels, lacey tablecloths and curtains are winding their way from storage trunks and attics into stylish Manhattan shops, where they are commanding prices that would justify the handwork that went into them. A social historian might explain it as a return to a bit of ostentation and panache after the era of the 1960's and 70's when simplicity, if not to say austerity, were, well, chic.

title: IN SHORT
description: These 15 stories by the West Canadian author W. P. Kinsella include possibly some of the most funny writing of recent times. Silas Ermineskin, 18, a born storyteller and Huck Finnian scamp, narrates tales about his Indian reservation in Alberta. There's his troublemaking buddy, Frank Fence-post, presenting himself as the chief of the Onagatihies (sometimes Onadatchies) to suburban hunters looking for a guide; Mad Etta, a 400-pound medicine woman whose office is a tree-trunk chair; the unanimously despised Chief Tom and his wicked girlfriend, Samantha Yellowknees; and other ne'er-do-wells whose lives we come to cherish. Bound together by a common history of official mistreatment, these people have a finely tuned instinct for silence, mutual help and deadpan trickery. When Silas and his friends cross the borders of the law - to hide a friend escaping from a bogus murder charge by turning him into a law-abiding Pakistani (''He works as a speed bump at a parking lot downtown,'' Silas tells inquiring police) or to prevent the farm of an old dead friend from falling to profiteering ''computer farmers'' by razing its house with a pickup truck - he carries us along with him. Not all the stories are funny, though, and some, like ''Strings,'' ''Green Candles'' and ''Nests,'' seem to challenge the limits of human rage, jealousy and sanity. Unsentimentally poignant, full of the energy and drama of folk tales, these marvelous stories go far in dispelling many lingering myths and misconceptions about the North American Indians - none greater, perhaps, than the one that says they have no sense of humor.

title: WHY THESE POP SINGERS HAVE RISEN TO SUPERSTARDOM
description: ''Who rules the music kingdom - Prince or Michael?'' The question is asked by the September issue of ''Right On!'' magazine, and there, on the cover, are photos of the two singers. Prince, the moody, lubricious star of ''Purple Rain'' stands there, jacket unbuttoned to his waist, a shock of hair rakishly draped over his huge, wet doe-eyes - a raunchy 1980's version of Little Richard, all sultry outrage and sex. And there, next to him, is Michael Jackson, the ''black Sinatra for the 90's,'' ''the Peter Pan of pop,'' immaculate in a tuxedo shirt and sequined military jacket - a dazzling portrait of boyish, all-American show-biz.

title: ;  Auburn Coach Fumes
description: Although Auburn University's football team came within 3 points of beating the defending national champion, Miami, in last Monday's Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium, the Auburn coach, Pat Dye , was far from satisfied. In fact, he described himself as ''nauseated'' by a review of the game films, and instead of resuming practice this week, he sent his players to their various homes, ''I want them to go home, walk the streets and see the difference between chumps and champs.''

title: FANCY FOOTWORK
description: A curious feature of the prestigious Cavendish Invitational Pairs last May was that many world-famous players competed with unexpected partners. Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas, who will attempt to enlarge their collection of world titles in Seattle in November, chose to split up on this occasion.

title: REFLECTING ON A PIONEER CHANNEL'S EARLY DAYS
description: ''Forty Years of Fine Tuning'' is WNEW-TV's celebration of itself, a retrospective by the nation's oldest independent television station. It is rewarding in the way an old scrapbook is rewarding; it's fun to see pictures of old friends, some of whose names we now forget. It is frustrating in almost the same way. Whatever were we doing with those people, anyway? A scrapbook unfolds without explanation, except, perhaps, for notations with names and dates. ''Forty Years of Fine Tuning'' does something like that, too. WNEW, or Channel 5, which is the way most of us think of it, has a long and honorable, even distinguished, history. Its two-hour retrospective, Thursday at 8 P.M., ought to be more interesting than it is.

title: JAZZ VIOLINIST: PONTY LEADS QUINTET
description: Jean-Luc Ponty, the French violinist, keyboardist and composer, is one of a small number of jazz-fusion musicians whose technical virtuosity is matched by a restraint one rarely encounters in an idiom that is practically synonymous with aural flash. Mr. Ponty's lyrical violin style blends the influences of both the classical conservatory and the jazz fiddling of Stephane Grappelli. And many of his mystical compositions have the same air of soaring mysticism that characterized the music of John McLaughlin and the Mahavishnu Orchestra.

title: 130,000 REFUGEES IN THAILAND WAIT TO GO ABROAD
description: More than 130,000 Indochinese refugees are in Thailand awaiting resettlement abroad, nearly 10 years after the Communist takeover of Saigon and five years after the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia.

description: Jennifer Louise Eckrich and James Gordon Gregg plan to be married in November. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Eckrich of Darien, Conn. Mr. Gregg is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Gregg of Bernardsville, N.J.

description: Barbara An-pei Sih and Michael David Klausner, 1981 graduates of the Yale Law School, were married yesterday at the home of Edith Quitman Klausner, mother of the bridegroom, in Philadelphia. Federal Judge Marvin Katz of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony.

description: Civil rights activists seeking laws to forbid discrimination against homosexuals say that a high court's upholding of the Navy's discharge of a homosexual was a setback, but one that would give them added motivation to work harder for their goals.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;
MNEY IS NOT THE SOLUTION TO PROBLEMS IN OUR SCHOOLS
description: PUBLIC education in the United States is in total disarray. It is getting worse. So much so that the Justice Department has even stepped into the picture and urged the Supreme Court of the United States to permit teachers and administrators to stop a student and search him or her for possible possession of drugs.

description: WESTCHESTER landlords, who have often warned that they would convert their buildings to condominiums and cooperatives if rental apartments do not provide sufficient profit, have been doing just that in record numbers for several years, according to a new report released by the County Department of Planning.

A MORRISTOWN TRADITION CONTINUES

description: High winds and a heavy swell today delayed the recovery of highly toxic nuclear cargo from a sunken French freighter.

description: When the French cargo vessel Mont Louis sank a week ago off the Belgian coast with a cargo of uranium, authorities initially announced that the ship was carrying only medical suppplies. The first indication the ship was carrying radioactive material came from the French office of Greenpeace, the environmental group.

title: A BANNER YEAR FOR MARLBORO-MCLAREN
description: The Italian Grand Prix, the penultimate round of the international Formula One season, will be run next Sunday at the Monza Autodrome. But there isn't much suspense left. No matter who wins that event, or the European Grand Prix a month later in West Germany, the Marlboro- McLaren team has already clinched the manufacturers' championship and one of the team's two drivers, either Niki Lauda or Alain Prost, is assured of the world drivers' championship.

title: QADDAFI SAYS HE HAS SENT TROOPS TO HELP NICARAGUA AGAINST U.S.
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that he had sent troops and arms to Nicaragua to help the Sandinista Government fight the United States ''on its own ground.'' He gave no details.

title: INCREASED DEMAND FOR DAY CARE PROMPTS A DEBATE ON REGULATION
description: The explosive growth in the demand for child care and widely publicized reports of the sexual abuse of children at daycare centers in New York and California are raising questions about the quality of such care and the need for increased regulation.

description: Dusty wooden planks were spread like ships lumber on the floor of the late 19th Century building at the entrance to Newport Harbor.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry W. Andersen and the Rev. Daniel McBride, a Roman Catholic priest.

description: ALTHOUGH the drinking rules are changing, the party isn't over in New Jersey. Conviviality is not dead, and friendships are not in jeopardy - unless caring for a friend's safety is the danger.
