title: IF YOU SMOKE, NO ROOM AT THE INN
description: The motel's receptionists are unfailingly cheery when they answer the telephone. ''It's a healthy day here at the Non-Smokers Inn,'' they say.

title:
ART;
COLOR FOR THE EYE, COLOR FOR THE SPIRIT
description: THE second in a series of exhibitions celebrating color in contemporary painting is now on view at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington. In this show, appropriately titled ''Local Color,'' two artists of the area, Stanley Twardowicz of Northport and Maxine Jurow Schnall of Greenlawn, illustrate the subjective use of pigment, one in a semi-abstract context and the other in nonobjective terms.

title: Stephanie Fehr Wed To Douglas W. Brett
description: The marriage of Stephanie Lynn Fehr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Fehr of Weston, Conn., to Douglas Warren Brett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Warren Brett of Westport, Conn. took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. J. Steven Reynolds, a Baptist minister and brother-in-law of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: AIRPORT NOISE IS MAIN ISSUE AT HEARING
description: COUNTY legislators sought the views of the public last week on the future of Westchester County Airport, and found that the issue of noise continues to be a dominant concern and that many people want the airport to remain a small general aviation facility.

title: BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL INCLUDES LETTERS
description: VIVECA LINDFORS does not consider herself an authority on Ludwig von Beethoven. Although one of her early Swedish films was called ''Appassionata'' and used the Beethoven concerto as its theme, her knowledge of his work is limited to a casual fan's appreciation of his music. The actress leaves the expertise to the dozens of musicians who will perform in next weekend's Beethoven Festival at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay.

title: 2D-CENTURY MOSAIC FLOOR UNEARTHED IN GREECE
description: Greek archeologists excavating an ancient Greek city have unearthed a mosaic floor and fragments of about 20 marble statues of Greek gods dating from the time of Roman rule, a Salonika University professor said today.

title:
About Men ;
IN FIGHTING TRIM
description: I'm not a man who picks fights at the ball park or waits in bars for a brawl. But even so, this is the way it goes: I'm on the subway by myself (subways are perfect for this); or walking up a deserted street; or in my car, at a light, late at night. The details aren't important. What matters is that I'm alone, and there's a strange man near me in what might, by a small twist of my urbanized imagination, become a threatening situation. It doesn't matter that this other man is probably thinking about nothing more than the dinner he's late for, or the girlfriend he's just left, or even, a little worriedly, about me. Because the first thing I do, whenever there's even a remote chance of a confrontation, is to start sizing things up. And the conclusion I come to, the footing on which I rest my peace of mind, is a purely physical one: Can I take this guy, or not?

title: A NEW DEVELOPER
description: -year-old Manhattan-based real-estate company, has been exclusively a broker of commercial mortgages and realty equities and a manager of buildings.

description: A Guyanese court confiscated three United States-owned trawlers Friday and fined their South Korean skippers $32,500 each for fishing illegally in Guyanese waters.

title: SONG OF THE SOUTH PACIFIC ISLANDERS: DON'T DUMP IT HERE
description: South Pacific governments took concerted action last week to keep nuclear pollution out of the ocean that surrounds them and provides sustenance for their populations.

description: Nearly 10,000 people packed a sports stadium here today, where Indian opposition leaders pledged to work together to oust the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: 'LA RONDINE' MAY NOW BE COMING INTO ITS OWN
description: Searching through the rubble of the past for neglected masterpieces is work that can be recommeded only to licensed optimists. With few exceptions, the neglect turns out to be all too easily explained. This is especially true of opera, a hybrid form whose appeal depends not only on the music but on a dozen other factors highly susceptible to the ravages of changing fashion, including acting styles, stage and costume design, choreography and lighting effects. Librettos, even high-quality ones such as Metastasio's, also can go stale and strike a following generation as foolishly irrelevant. Or, as happened with the

title: Canadian Polls Show Tories With Wide Lead
description: There were new signs today that Prime Minister John N. Turner may be headed for a landslide defeat Tuesday by his Progressive Conservative Party challenger, Brian Mulroney.

description: The song recital is in decline, moribund, perhaps dead. So at least many observers have claimed or suggested, and the notion is so widespread among those singers, critics and composers who care most about the art-song repertory that it cannot be dismissed.

title: IRAN IS SAID TO CLOSE GULF OIL PORT
description: Iran was reported today to have closed its key oil export terminal at Kharg Island until Sept. 10 to repair ''severe damage'' to jetties caused by Iraqi air attacks. There was no comment on the report from Teheran.

title: THE NEW INTEREST IN INDEX FUNDS
description: WHEN the trustees of the New York State Teachers' Pension Fund withdrew $2 billion from Manufacturers Hanover Investment Management two months ago, they did not hire another money manager to get better performance. Instead, they invested the assets in an index fund, a mechanically invested pool of money designed to match the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index - no more, no less.

description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officer Charged In East Coast Crime Ring
description: A Philadelphia police officer has been charged with playing a leading role in a multistate crime ring whose activities included break-ins by men posing as police officers.

title: ;  Decision Deferred
description: The Detroit Pistons' decision on whether to match the offer sheets tendered to the free agents Kelly Tripucka , by the Cleveland Cavaliers, and Vinnie Johnson , by the Knicks, will not be made until the middle of next week, the club's attorney said. ''I won't have a chance to look at the offer sheets until at least Tuesday, because of the holiday,'' said Oscar Feldman . The Pistons have until next Saturday to match the 7-year, $6.3 million the Cavaliers reportedly offered to Tripucka, and until Friday to match the 3-year, $1.5 million pact the Knicks reportedly offered to Johnson.

title: STORES CATER TO THE OVERWEIGHT
description: ALEX OGRODOWSKI of Trumbull apologizes for being philosophical when he says: ''The streets of America are really paved with gold. The problem is that young people today just don't want to pick it up.''

title: SINATRA DROPS CASINO SHOWS, CITING INSULT BY A JERSEY AIDE
description: Frank Sinatra has canceled his appearances at a casino-hotel here, saying that a state casino commissioner insulted and demeaned him.

title:
CAMERA;
THE SIMPLE BASICS FOR TAKING TIME EXPOSURES
description: Frederic W. Rosen is a freelance writer and photographer. Although most 35mm cameras are equipped with shutters for time exposures, most photographers seem reluctant to use these settings. They believe that special equipment and/or specialized knowledge are necessary. In fact, time exposures enable a photographer to get unusally dramatic and creative effects.

title: GUARDIAN ANGELS HALY BOSTON PATROLS IN A DISPUTE
description: A group of Guardian Angels who began crime patrols in a predominantly black, middle- class area have suspended their activities after clashes with local youths.

title: BELLOW'S TYPEWRITERS AND OTHER TICS OF THE TRADE
description: MY favorite story about writing is really a story about reading. A couple of years ago, when my friend Michael was young (he's now 4 years old and sophisticated about the limits of literature), he tried to climb inside a book. Unwilling to believe that so wonderful a world was unreachable, he simply opened the tale to his favorite page, carefully arranged his choice on the floor and stepped in. He tried again and again, certain he would soon get it right, and each time he was left standing out in the cold he cried in bewilderment. Carol Sternhell teaches journalism at New York University.

title: PODIATRISTS WARN OF FOOT INJURIES
description: EVEN though many people are exercising more and becoming more health conscious, Dr. Jeffrey S. Kahn of Middletown said they are often reluctant to talk about problems with two fundamental parts of their bodies - their feet.

title: KNOW THE LOCAL RULES OF THE GAME
description: AMERICAN companies seem to be comfortable with the idea that they have to modify products and labor practices to operate in other countries. But they are having a rougher time accepting that the success of their overseas ventures can depend on a different set of management and marketing skills.

title: REMOVAL OF ASBESTOS TO DELAY OPENING OF MORE JERSEY SCHOOLS
description: The New Jersey Education Department yesterday revised upward the number of public schools in the state that will be unable to open on schedule this week because they have failed to complete the removal of cancer-causing asbestos insulation during the summer.

title: Sting Withdraws From the N.A.S.L.
description: Saying the move was a new start, Lee Stern, owner of the Chicago Sting, announced that the team will end its membership in the North American Soccer League at the end of the season.

title: MICHIGAN WORKERS SUE FOR EQUAL PAY
description: Michigan's largest union of state workers filed a lawsuit Friday in Federal District Court to force the state to pay women the same as men after a study showed women were paid 21 percent less for comparable jobs.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Salvador Dali Hospitalized
description: Salvador Dali, the Surrealist artist has been hospitalized for burns suffered in a fire, and is being fed intravenously as treatment for chronic malnutrition, doctors said today. The 80-year- old artist was reported to be in stable condition. He was admitted to El Pilar Clinic in Barcelona shortly after midnight for treatment of the second-degree burns he suffered in a fire in his bedroom earlier this week.

title: GERULAITIS TRIUMPHS IN 5 SETS
description: A fruit cocktail saved the day for Vitas Gerulaitis. The snack, delivered at courtside when he was flagging midway through a five-set match against Ken Flach, gave the 12th-seeded New Yorker the lift he needed at the United States Open yesterday and helped turn an imminent defeat into a 6-4, 6-2, 4-6, 6-7, 6-1 victory.

title: Toxic Chemicals Are Spilled
description: Sixteen people were taken to a hospital Friday evening after an accident in which a truck spilled toxic chemicals onto the median of Interstate 35. The highway was closed 45 miles north of Dallas and air traffic was barred from crossing the site as a cleanup crew continued its work today.

title: EAST END SUMMER: NOT THE BRIGHTEST
description: AS the summer season in the Hamptons reaches its Labor Day climax, there are complaints that business is off. Despite crowds that create bumper- to-bumper traffic each weekend, oceanfront properties priced - and selling - at more than $1 million and a building boom that has left few East End fields untouched, the impression gleaned from conversations with real-estate brokers and others active in the resort economy is that the 1984 season has been a disappointment.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ARAKAWA'S ARTS

title: EVENT AIDS CONCERT GROUP
description: KEEPING family budgets in mind, this column is focused as often as possible on low-cost or free events. But even high ticket prices are insufficient to cover operating costs for the majority of arts projects in the county, so support must come from other sources, as well. For those who are in a position to extend a more generous helping hand to the Concert Society of Putnam and Northern Westchester, a most enticing event is scheduled today at 5 P.M. in Carmel's Sedgewood Club Boathouse.

title: LAST-MINUTE RALLY LIFTS MIAMI, 32-20
description: With 41 seconds to play tonight, Miami trailed Florida by 20-19. Then Bernie Kosar passed 12 yards to the wide receiver Ed Brown for a touchdown with 7 seconds left to retake the lead on the way to a 32-20 victory.

title: PUBLIC MEETS ATOM IN REACTOR TOURS
description: Boy Scout Troop 103 of Fleetwood, Pa., checked in with the armed security guards at the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant. They donned hard hats, walked past pipes that had radiation tags and gathered in the control room where the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident unfolded on March 28, 1979.

title: THE WICKED WHICH AND THE COMMA
description: ''G.O.P. Tax Battle Over a Comma'' was the front-page headline of Long Island's Newsday. Over the story on an inside page, the headline writer had a little fun with the verb: ''Comma Punctuates Debate on G.O.P.'s Tax Hike Policy.''

title: TROUBLED THRIFT UNIT GETS NEW CHAIRMAN
description: ''Unrelenting pressures'' finally convinced Charles W. Knapp to step down as chairman, chief executive and director of the struggling Financial Corporation of America, parent company of the American Savings and Loan Association, the nation's largest thrift institution. Named to replace Mr. Knapp was William J. Popejoy, who ran American Savings until Financial Corporation acquired it last year. The bank has suffered a major liquidity crisis and a resultant loss of depositor confidence, and Mr. Popejoy's appointment, which carried the blessing of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is expected to relieve concerns of many large depositors. But depositors seemed to want more. By week's end the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation came under increasing pressure to guarantee all depositors' money. The regulators denied that any full guarantee was planned, however, so Mr. Popejoy has his hands full.

title: 3 OFFICERS ACCUSED OF 'FRAMING' CHIEFZ
description: CAMDEN THREE police officers in Waterford Township have been accused of conspiracy to discredit their chief, who lost his job in 1981 and was replaced by one of the conspiracy suspects.

title: A LAST-MINUTE RUSH FOR HELP
description: Rick Langford was one of many players added to major league rosters yesterday as teams were allowed to expand from 25 players to 40. Most of the players have been promoted from the minor leagues. Rick Langford moved to the Oakland A's roster from the disabled list.

title: THEATER-THE ETERNAL ART OF THE PARTICULAR MOMENT
description: When a passage is uttered on the stage, and a sudden murmur rushes through the auditorium like a wind that raises a wave on a placid lake, old actors say that the play has ''caught hold'' or that there is a ''good house.'' But what does a ''good'' house mean? The living voice is always here and now, hic et nunc. Theatrical time is but one time: the one, two or three hours of a play's duration. Who imposes upon a classic text, who articulates, that one meaning which hits the mark? The director? The actor? Perhaps it really is the spectators. And that is what is meant by a ''good house.''

title: DEBT PLAN FOR SHAKESPEARE THEATER
description: A reorganization plan in which the bankrupt American Shakespeare Theater would repay some of its debts through fund-raising is likely to be approved with few changes, according to a lawyer for the theater's creditors.

description: The first time Paige Covell asked his father for a job in the family company, he was told to finish college. When he came back with a degree, he rejected a job offer because the salary was too low and, instead, sold insurance.

title: Weekend Air Crashes Include Copter Accident By United Press International

description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Jeff Olsen Is Married To Riva Lynn Bennett
description: Riva Lynn Bennett, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Edwin H. Bennett of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday to Jeff Olsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Olsen of Babylon, L.I. A justice of the peace performed the civil ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: LEBANESE DRUSE REMEMBER THE MARTYRS
description: The old men danced proudly in a circle in their baggy Druse mountaineering trousers, fierce moustaches bristling, worn leather bandoliers crisscrossing their chests, brandishing long rifles or old curved swords.

title: CRITICS RAISE QUESTIONS ABOUT HEALTH AND SAFETY OF HIGH-TECHNOLOGY JOBS
description: Sometime in the early hours of June 11, John Zemotel, a 31-year-old technician at a high-technology company on Route 128, either deliberately or accidentally inhaled arsine gas, a toxic vapor used to cook circuits into high- speed microchips.

title: I'M WAY OVERPAID
description: As contract negotiations approach in the auto industry, the prevailing slogan among the more vociferous rank-and-file workers is: ''Restore and More in '84.'' Those who take up this call are the union officers, the union-appointed lackeys, the shirkers and the complainers. I know, because I work alongside them.

title: MARINO PACES MIAMI VICTORY
description: Dan Marino, who missed most of the exhibition season because of a fractured index finger on his throwing hand, today played one of the finest games a Miami Dolphin quarterback has ever had, and easily one of the best in a career that only began a year ago.

title: 3 CHINESE FAMILIES IN MAGIC REVUE
description: The Chinese Magic Revue hasn't changed much since 1979, when it last appeared in New York City. Why tamper with success?

title: Kratochvilova Wins in Italy
description: Jarmila Kratochvilova of Czechoslovakia defeated the Olympic gold medalist Valerie Brisco-Hooks of the United States today in a 400-meter race here.

title: NICARAGUA VICTIMS MAY BE AMERICANS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency believes two of the men killed when Nicaragua shot down a rebel helicopter Saturday were American mercenaries, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Agrico Chemical Co., Tulsa, Okla, has elected Bobby L. Latham to the new position of vice president-manufacturing.

title: JAZZ: QUINTET FEATURES BILL BARRON
description: Harmony fascinates Bill Barron, the saxophonist who came to the Jazz Center of New York last week for a rare local engagement. Leading a quintet that included his younger brother Kenny Barron on piano, Bill Barron played a set of maze-like tunes, full asymmetrical rhythms and quick-change chords.

title: JETS TRIUMPH; EAGLES LOSE BY 28-27
description: For openers, there were standing ovations at Giants Stadium this afternoon. For a change, there was the sight of a healthy Phil Simms, who passed for the second-highest total in the history of the Giants. For old times' sake, there were the standard Giant nervous moments that were overcome in their 28-27 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: No Headline
description: Boy Left in Car Dies; Father Seized on L.I.

title: 4 Primaries May Put Some Seats in Jeopardy United Press International
description: In Florida, one of four states holding primaries Tuesday, three contenders are battling for the right to take on Representative Andy Ireland, a Democrat-turned-Republican in the fall.

title: ART CAPTURES SPIRIT OF MAORI ANCESTORS
description: It is nine feet tall and looks like a cross between the top of a cello and a comb used for Afro haircuts. It has the elegance of a swan's neck and the power of a steelworker's arm. It is 500 years old, yet looks like it was found in a SoHo gallery yesterday. It is quiet as the dead, yet it sometimes speaks.

title: Goulds Pumps Picks President
description: Goulds Pumps Inc. has elected Stephen V. Ardia president and chief operating officer. Mr. Ardia, 43 years old, was formerly vice president of sales.

title: STRATEGIES POINT TO OPPOSITE GOALS AT KICKOFF OF PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGNS
description: On the eve of the traditional Labor Day kickoff of the general election campaign, President Reagan's political advisers say he plans to tone down partisan attacks on Walter F. Mondale and shift to positive, ''future-oriented'' themes in his stump speeches.

title: Reagan on Mortality And Orange County
description: President Reagan returned to his political taproots here in Orange County this evening, waxing mortal about its significance in his history in California and national politics.

title: Teacher Strikes Set In Several States By The Associated Press
description: While teachers in Longview, Wash., reached a tentative settlement Friday, teachers in Michigan threatened to walk out and strikes by educators in six states had the potential to idle 200,000 children this week.

title: Wallace Suffers Reaction
description: Gov. George C. Wallace suffered what his doctor called probable heart palpitations Saturday night from a ''minor'' reaction to medication for blood pressure control. Mr. Wallace's reaction was common, his physician, Dr. William Smith, said today.

title: 49ERS BEAT LIONS ON FIELD GOAL
description: Ray Wersching's 22-yard field goal with four seconds remaining gave the San Francisco 49ers a 30-27 victory over the Detroit Lions today.

title: ADIDAS, THE SPORT SHOE GIANT, IS ADAPTING TO NEW DEMANDS
description: Adidas, the West German sporting shoe giant, has for years been regarded as a kind of corporate dinosaur.

title: B-1 Bomber's Cushion May Not Have Worked
description: A cushioning device in the escape capsule of a B-1 bomber may have failed when it crashed, a source involved in developing the plane said today.

title: OPERA: 'CAV' AND 'PAG' AT THE CITY
description: Although Pietro Mascagni and Ruggero Leoncavallo were both prolific composers, Mascagni has gone down in history simply as the man who wrote ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo as the man who wrote ''I Pagliacci.'' The clever impresario who first conceived teaming these two short works for a single evening's entertainment deserves a special footnote in musical annals, for ''Cav'' and ''Pag'' - as they are customarily abbreviated - have become the Siamese twins of Italian opera, making up a double bill that continues to exude irresistible appeal to audiences all over the world.

title: SOME MONTANANS FIGHT REOPENING OF A GOLD MINE
description: As mining towns throughout the Rocky Mountains struggle with the effects of slumping metal prices or played-out bodies of ore, they are searching for development to prop up their economies.

title: Hope Harris Married To Mark David Lewis
description: Hope Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey H. Harris of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark David Lewis, a son of Mary Jane Lewis of Randolph, N.J., and Richard Lewis of Lake Worth, Fla. State Supreme Court Justice Leo F. McGinity performed the ceremony at the Harris home.

title: LEGISLATOR FAULTS CITY'S DROPOUT-PREVENTION PLANS
description: The chairman of the State Assembly's Education Committee has complained to the city's Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, that the school system's new dropout-prevention programs do not focus on those students most likely to leave school - those in the poorest neighborhoods and the highest grades.

title: TWINS DROP FIFTH STRAIGHT, 6-0
description: Doyle Alexander pitched a two-hitter and Garth Iorg clouted his first home run of the season today as the Blue Jays beat Minnesota, 6-0, and sent the Twins to their fifth straight loss.

title: ZERO-COUPON BONDS: SPEND NOW, LET THE YOUNG PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Personality's Wife Charged in His Death
description: A 20-month hunt for the killers of a Puerto Rican television and radio personality ended today when murder charges were filed against his estranged wife and four other people, according to island officials.

title: Kitty Spence, 79, Dies;Was Model for Parrish
description: Kitty Owen Spence, a model for well- known Maxfield Parrish paintings of the 1920's and granddaughter of three- time Presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan, died Thursday in her home after a heart attack. She lived in Manhattan and was 79 years old.

title: Alone Again
description: Major-league wives are on their own again.

title: HELEN L. LIEBERMAN
description: Helen L. Lieberman, patron of many aspiring young musicians and an accomplished pianist herself, died Thursday of heart disease at her home in Philadelphia. She was 97 years old..

title: OUTDOORS: NIGHT IS TIME FOR BLUES
description: THE nocturnal habits of certain fishes require that a dedicated angler eschew such things as late-afternoon cocktail parties, early suppers and other social and domestic rituals that intrude upon prime fishing hours.

title: CHOOSING PHYSICIANS FOR BABIES
description: Bringing up baby is a task that can force otherwise competent adults to their knees. As new parents quickly discover, babies are mysterious creatures that do quirky, unpredictable things - like breathing erratically at night or producing, and suddenly losing, a rash. That is why there are pediatricians.

title: Nuptials for M. S. Zuckert And Ellen Rosen, Lawyers
description: Ellen Rosen, an associate with Cahill Gordon & Reindel, and Michael Steven Zuckert, an associate with Willkie Farr & Gallagher, both law firms, were married yesterday at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Irving Koslowe officiated.

title: NEW TEXAS SCHOOL: MAKING MAN INTO MANSERVANT
description: ''The reason one should have a butler,'' says Ivor Spencer, ''is that we create happiness.''

title: Dr. Wiesner Wed To a Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Elizabeth Anne Wiesner, a pediatrician, and Dr. Fred Robert Volkmar, a child psychiatrist, both at Yale University, were married yesterday at the summer home in Chilmark, Mass., of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Bert Wiesner of Watertown, Mass. Judge Paul Levy of the Massachusetts Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title: Carole Goldberg, Lawyer, Weds Dr. H. R. Daman
description: Carole Sue Goldberg, a lawyer, and Dr. Harlan Richard Daman, a physician, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Solomon W. Sternstein performed the ceremony.

title: NOT GOOD ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In America, our faith has always been intensely personal. It is between the individual and God, between families and their churches and synagogues, with no room for politicians in between.'' - Walter F. Mondale (1:6.)

title: Rival's Tally in Guam Overshadows Incumbent
description: In a primary in which voters were allowed to cross party lines, Antonio Borja Won Pat, the Democrat who is Guam's Delegate to the House of Representatives, received nearly 2,000 fewer votes than the total received by the Republican he will face in the November election.

title: Coliseum Carpentry
description: The Islanders, who have squeezed four Stanley Cup championships into Nassau County, are continuing their carpentry saga of squeezing seats into one of the National Hockey League's smallest arenas.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Firefighters Leaving As Montana Blazes Die
description: Hundreds of firefighters who put out blazes that charred 230,000 acres of timber and rangeland left today to go home for the holiday.

title: SIKHS, IN RALLY, PRESS THE ARMY TO QUIT TEMPLE
description: Under a steady downpour and the watchful eye of hundreds of armed soldiers and policemen, tens of thousands of Sikhs jammed a shrine here today for an anti-Government rally at which religious leaders called for a mass march to liberate their holiest site from the army occupation.

title: Melissa Smallacombe Married to Sean Egan
description: At St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., yesterday Melissa J. Smallacombe and Sean E. Egan, graduates of the State University of New York College at New Paltz, were married by the Rev. Paul Bryan.

title: CARPENTER NAMED CARTER COMES TO NEW YORK
description: The bus left Georgia early Saturday morning, carrying 40 people headed to New York City to help rehabilitate a building on the Lower East Side. By late afternoon, appetites were growing.

title: LETTER: ON ZONING
description: THE 14TH STREET SOLUTION

title: Remember the Polish 22
description: Poland's Communist regime is backtracking, slyly, testing world opinion to see just how much it can get away with. The West's answer to General Jaruzelski should be clear: If you want to improve your reputation in the world, it will have to be by keeping promises, not by dodging them.

title: Redmen Gain
description: Lou Blanco and Tom Bonura each drove in two runs with singles to lead St. John's to an 8-6 victory over New York Tech in the semifinals of the Honsberger Memorial Tournament yesterday at Redmen Field in Jamaica, Queens. St. John's, the only unbeaten club remaining in the eight- team tourney, will oppose Seton Hall in tomorrow's final. The Pirates advanced with a 6-3 victory over L.I.U. as Tom Grabowski and Tom Biaggo each had two singles.

title: LLOYD UPSETS KRIEK IN 4 SETS
description: The kiss was chaste, a peck on the cheek between a victorious husband and a proud wife, and at the sight of 50 photographers recording the moment John Lloyd and Chris Evert Lloyd broke apart as if embarrassed.

title: BUSH WAR RECORD NOTED ON 'A DAY OF NOSTALGIA'
description: Vice President Bush looked back with emotion and nostalgia today on his experiences as a heroic World War II Navy pilot at a Navy ceremony at Atlantic Fleet headquarters.

title: 'Chinese Diaspora' Series
description: The Asian Cine Vision film and lecture series, ''Chinese Diaspora,'' will begin Thursday at the Seward Park branch of the Public Library, 192 East Broadway, third floor. The series opens with ''How We Got Here,'' by Loni Ding, and ''Hong Kong Dong,'' by Dong Kingman. Films will be Thursdays at 7 P.M. and Saturdays at 2:30 P.M. through November.

title: Remember the Polish 22 Poland's Communist regime is backtracking, slyly, testing world opinion to see just how much it can get away with. The West's answer to General Jaruzelski should be clear: If you want to improve your reputation in the world, it will have to be by keeping promises, not by dodging them.
description: The amnesty Warsaw decreed earlier this summer promised that within 30 days all remaining political prisoners would be liberated. The only exception made was for those facing charges of high treason, espionage or sabotage.

title: THAILAND'S MILITARY IS POISED TO MAKE A POLITICAL CHALLENGE
description: The Government is preparing for what may be a strong political challenge from the military on Monday.

title: No Headline
description: Nuptials for Pearl Bader

title: Arnold Pedowitz Weds Miss Eiseman
description: The marriage of Wendy Susan Eiseman, an account representative for Calvin Klein Classifications in New York, to Arnold Henry Pedowitz, a lawyer in practice in New York, took place yesterday at Congregation Beth Israel in Milwaukee. Rabbi Herbert Panitch performed the ceremony.

title: ; Cubs Win, 4-2, From Braves
description: Leon Durham smashed a two-run homer and Gary Matthews delivered a two- run single today as the Chicago Cubs downed the Atlanta Braves, 4-2.

title: Vivian Lee Stedman Married to Peter J. Heineman
description: The marriage of Vivian Lee Stedman and Peter J. Heineman took place yesterday at the Armonk, N.Y., home of the bride's mother, Gerda C. Stedman. The Rev. Raymond F. Lange, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Reagan and the Russians
description: President Reagan's radio voice-

title: Centralia, Pa., May Lose Insurance Protection
description: The company that provides insurance to this town has decided not to renew its coverage because of ''increased peril'' from a mine fire that has been burning for 22 years, local officials said.

title: CHANGE BRINGS SUCCESS FOR CHRISTIAN NETWORK
description: State-of-the-art technology and one of the country's top cable programs, ''The 700 Club,'' dominate the offerings of the Christian Broadcasting Network Corporation, a rapidly expanding company whose ability to change insured its survival in the 1980's.

title: JERSEY CUTS LIST OF SCHOOLS DELAYED BY ASBESTOS WORK
description: The New Jersey Education Department revised its figures yesterday to say that only 24 public schools in the state would be unable to open on schedule this week because they had failed to finish removing asbestos insulation during the summer.

title: PLACES THAT WOULD BENEFIT FROM GOD'S PRESENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA ELECTION CAMAPIGN WINDING UP WITH TORIES IN LEAD
description: Prime Minister John N. Turner, leader of the Liberal Party, campaigned vigorously in his home district today, telling audiences that he thought there was still time to turn the tide against his conservative challenger.

title: LAWYER SAYS SCIENTOLOGISTS ARE SEEKING TO 'FRAME' HIM
description: Michael J. Flynn, a Boston lawyer, was piloting a light aircraft toward South Bend, Ind., in October 1979 when its engine quit mysteriously at 8,500 feet. After making an emergency landing, he said he found several quarts of water in the fuel tank.

title: UNIONS' SUNSET
description: This Labor Day, like last year, and the year before, it's hard to miss the signs of the decline of American unionism: low public esteem, increasing management resistence, inability to deliver the vote and dwindling membership, concentrated in troubled industries. Many people will spend the day lamenting it. But is it necessarily such a bad thing?

title: THE PENSIONS MILITARY PERSONNEL DESERVE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Thursday from the Israeli village of Um el Fahm about the activities of Rabbi Meir Kahane misstated the political affiliation of a member of the Israeli Parliament. The legislator, Yossi Sarid, is in the left wing of the Labor Party.

title: LONDON'S SUMMER OF MERGERS
description: The tone was set in May, when Thorn EMI P.L.C., a consumer electronics and entertainment group, astonished the City of London by announcing that it was discussing a merger with British Aerospace P.L.C., the partly state-owned missile, satellite and aircraft maker that is Europe's largest private aerospace enterprise.

title: CUBS OF TODAY ZERO IN ON A PENNANT
description: CHICAGO Ryne Sandberg said innocently: ''I never heard that story. Doesn't mean a thing to me.'' Sandberg was being reminded of the pennant race in 1969, of a time early in September after a hard loss. The Chicago Cubs were fading and Manager Leo Durocher had only half-scraped the shaving cream off his face. A reporter entered Durocher's office and asked: ''Leo, are the Cubs tired?'' The fiery manager whipped his head round, pointed his razor blade and shouted: ''You think we're so tired. Why don't we just ask the players.''

title: SCHOLAR CALLED A HERO IN JUDAICA CONTROVERSEY
description: The daughter of a Jewish scholar at the center of a controversy over the sale of rare Hebrew manuscripts said her father should be considered a hero, not a thief, for smuggling the books out of Nazi Germany.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1984
description: The Economy

title: A Welcome Susan Drivers on the Palisades Parkway in New Jersey these days find themselves suddenly blinking at what seems to be a great patch of sunshine thrown down in the middle strip. They realize as they pass that it's a few hundred square feet of those fetching wildflowers, black-eyed Susans. This isn't the work of nature but of landscape architects. It's an experiment, they say, to brighten up endless areas of bland green and to save on mowing - as if it were necessary to have a practical explanation for such a happy idea.
description: There are other wildflower plots on the parkway - blue cornflower, orange and red Indian blanket - and there will be more if the project seems to work out. There is no reason it shouldn't.

title: AFTER HOSPITAL STRIKE, A JOYOUS FAIR
description: Though the hospital strike had ended nearly a week before, it appeared that the celebration was just beginning.

title: Dance Company Plans Shaka Zulu Celebration
description: African singers, dancers and drummers will participate in the IZulu Dance Theater's annual Shaka Zulu celebration.

title: Books of The Times; Jewish Anecdotes
description: THE REST OF US. The Rise of America's

title: SELLER AIDS IN TRANSFER OF AMERICAN MOTOR INNS
description: THE agreement to sell American Motor Inns to Prime Motor Inns does not end the motel career of Joel Krish, American's 60-year-old president. After 27 years in the business, he will stay on to guide the transition. And his brother, Adolph O. Krish, 78, also is remaining chairman of American Motor Inns, based in Roanoke, Va.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS MIXING OF RELIGION AND GOVERNMENT
description: The President's advisers say he intends to tone down his campaign attacks and shift to positive themes. Page 9.

title: JETS TRIUMPH; COLT OPENER SPOILED, 23-14
description: The three ingredients the depleted Jets needed - a defense to keep them in the game, a strong ball-control running attack by Freeman McNeil and kick returns to keep their backs from the goal-line - helped produce a 23-14 opening-game victory over the Indianapolis Colts today.

title: AMERICANS TRYING HARD IN PRO CYCLING
description: Doug Shapiro, of Dix Hills, L.I., wheeled into the pits after some 130 miles of hard racing. The machine was still running fine. It was Shapiro's legs that gave out.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about schools in New Jersey that will not open because of asbestos-removal problems contained an incorrect list of the schools affected. The New Jersey Education Department, which provided the information, said that because of clerical and technical errors it had mistakenly placed some schools on the list, and that a stepped- up program of inspections had found many additional schools safe for use. A corrective article appears on page 28.

title: STATISTICS AND THE ART OF HONESTY
description: Disraeli is usually credited with the remark that there are several different kinds of lies and one of them is ''statistics.''

title: TIPS ON FINDING DAY CARE
description: For parents concerned about how to choose a day-care facility for their children, the United States Department of Health and Human Services publishes ''A Parent's Guide to Day Care.''

title: 19 Arabs Are Seized in Israel After a Protest Over Kahane
description: Nineteen Arabs have been arrested and more are being sought in the aftermath of an attack on the police at a protest against Rabbi Meir Kahane last week, the police said today.

title: Motorcycle Gang Fight Leaves 7 Dead in Sydney
description: Seven people were shot to death and 20 were wounded here today when two rival motorcycle gangs battled outside a tavern with pump-action shotguns, machetes and baseball bats, the police said.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE: STATE'S PROPER RESISTANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW YORKER'S LINK WITH LITERARY FIGURES
description: The letter is dated Dublin, April 8, 1923, and it begins, ''Forgive me for typing this but I have pain in my eyes and so must spare them all I can.'' After reporting that two of his children have recovered from scarlet fever, the author added, ''The only tribulation we suffer from civil war is that we are rather weary of being tied to the house.''

title: AT THE U.S. OPEN, NEW YORK ACCENTS
description: Listen to the voices at the National Tennis Center, a 16-acre asphalt jungle in Queens and home of the United States Open, the only major tournament played in a public park.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
FROM FAR AND WIDE, THEY COME TO PLAY GO
description: Slapping and clicking sounds

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays , at Yankee Stadium, 4:05 P.M. Joe Cowley, one of the Yankees' best pitchers over the last month, goes for his sixth victory. (Television - Channel 11, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals , at St. Louis. The Mets go on the road for four days before returning to Shea for a crucial series against the Cubs on Friday. (Television - Sports Channel, 6:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 6:30 P.M.) Football

title: MIDWAY'S CHIEF PLANS TAKEOVERS
description: Two years ago, when Arthur C. Bass took over as chairman and chief executive officer of Midway Airlines, he promised to review every aspect of the discount carrier ''from the ad agency to the route network.''

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has any team in the major leagues ever had all four regular infielders each drive in 100 or more runs during the same season?

title: CITY OPERA LIGHTING DESIGNER
description: Hans Sondheimer, the lighting designer, technical director and production coordinator for the New York City Opera from its inception in 1944 until his retirement in 1980, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: FORMER U.N. LEADER IS GLOOMY ON FUTURE OF THE ORGANIZATION
description: Former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, assessing the role of the United Nations, says the organization has moved into areas in which ''clashing interests threaten to tear it apart.''

title: Bridge:Greedy Doubler Often FindsHe Has Bitten Off Too Much
description: Gluttony is one of the seven deadly sins, at the bridge table as well as at the dinner table.

title: Artworks by Celebrities Scheduled for Auction
description: Francis Coppola, Olivia de Havilland, Richard Dreyfuss, Christopher Plummer, Richard Chamberlain and Glenn Close - all from the worlds of theater and film - will join the artist Al Hirschfeld in putting their artworks up for auction.

title: MARX'S '84 ISSUE
description: In this mercurial political year, one thing is certain. The debate over the future of the economy will not invoke the name Karl Marx. Yet, the key issue was made famous by Marx: the conflict between labor and capital.

title: PORT JERVIS CELEBRATES ITS CONQUERING HEROES
description: The Banach boys, as everyone knows them here, came back home this weekend, and as the townspeople celebrated their own Olympic gold medalists with a day of marching bands, waving flags and heartfelt speeches, all the hard times and disasters Port Jervis had endured seemed at last forgotten.

title: A Truman Musical
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt has been

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS LOSE COST EDGE
description: For the first time since commercial atomic power came into its own 20 years ago, electricity from new nuclear plants has become much more expensive than electricity from new coal plants, recent studies indicate.

title: U.S. WELCOMES CHERNENKO'S STATEMENT
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it welcomed the latest comments by Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, on the Soviet Union's readiness for arms negotiations. But it dismissed his criticism of American policy as ''wholly familiar and wholly false.''

title: NUTRITION LABELING IS TESTED
description: To the applause of Federal health officials, the largest supermarket chain in the Washington area is expanding a labeling experiment that suggests that consumers will, if given the chance, buy foods lower in salt, cholesterol, fat or calories.

title: East German Sidesteps Comment on Bonn Visit
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, sidestepped comment today on whether he would visit West Germany later this month as he made an unusually short stop at a West German stand at the Leipzig trade fair.

title: Leftist Exiles Barred From Returning to Chile
description: Six left-wing political exiles, including a former Cabinet minister, returned to Chile on Saturday in defiance of a ban by the military regime, but the police forced them to fly back to Argentina early today.

title: DEPARTURE OF A CHINESE RAISES SOME QUESTIONS
description: A lawyer for a Chinese businessman who sought political asylum in the United States last spring has questioned the State Department's contention that his client returned to his homeland voluntarily.

title: CHINA FEARS CHANGE IN U.S. TEXTILE RULES
description: Chen Choi Ling runs a knitting machine. She works six days a week, earns pretty good money and hopes to visit Hong Kong one day. Miss Chen has never heard of protectionism or import regulations, and she does not see how she could figure in any trade dispute.

title: Abortion Warning
description: Opponents of the anti-abortion policy in the 1984 Republican Party platform plan to emphasize in the fall campaign that the re- election of President Reagan would be likely to produce a turnover in the Supreme Court that could reverse the Court's 1973 abortion ruling, whatever the majority view of Congress or the voters might be at the time.

title: TARANTARA TAKES BOOJUM AT BELMONT
description: Tarantara, a former claiming horse who has developed into one of the hardest-hitting sprinters in the East, got a long overdue stakes victory yesterday with a 1 3/4-length triumph over favored Muskoka Wyck in the $70,500 Boojum Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: YANKEES WIN, 5-3, AFTER TWO BRAWLS
description: What had been a cordial, mellow West Coast swing for the Yankees ended today with a brawl and a 5-3 comeback victory over the California Angels.

title: WAYS TO ADD JOBS LISTED IN REPORT
description: A report for two Congressional caucuses today recommended a switch from military to product-oriented research and a special job-preparation certificate for high school graduates to help ease unemployment in the nation's Frost Belt, hit hard by the 1981-82 recession.

title: NIGERIAN RECEIVED WARNINGS
description: Umaru Dikko, the former Nigerian Cabinet minister found drugged in a crate at an airport after being kidnapped two months ago, said in an interview published today that he had been warned he might be in danger.

title: LIBRARIAN RUSHES IN
description: To the Editor:

title: MARK RUSSELL SPECIAL OFFERS POLITICAL HUMOR
description: P olitical humor is not widespread on television. Johnny Carson, in his opening monologues, almost has the field to himself. Rich Little does an impersonation of Ronald Reagan, but it's Mr. Little's body language that's funny, not his jokes. Politics no longer inspires absurdists, and this is a pity because in comedy there is perspective. Be thankful, therefore, for the ''Mark Russell Comedy Special'' on Channel 13 at 1O:30 tonight.

title: REPAIRS ALLOW 2 LANES OF I-95 BRIDGE TO REOPEN
description: Connecticut transportation officials completed emergency repairs yesterday and reopened a part of the Connecticut Turnpike bridge that was closed last week when cracks were found in critical assemblies that secure the roadway to supporting girders.

title: NEW LEADER HEADS RIGHT, BUT WILL ECUADOR FOLLOW?
description: During his inauguration as Ecuador's President three weeks ago, Leon Febres Cordero launched a fierce attack on his predecessor, complaining that he had received ''a country in chaos'' and promising ''no pardon'' for those responsible.

title: PATRIOTS TURN BACK BILLS, 21-17
description: Steve Grogan threw two touchdown passes today and Tony Collins ran for a score as the New England Patriots held off a late Buffalo charge to post a 21-17 victory over the Bills.

title: LEGAL APPOINTMENTS FOR CLUBHOUSES' SAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Trinidad Buys Texaco Assets PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1984 International Talks faltered in Israel on the formation of a bipartisan government to be formed by the Likud bloc and the Labor Alignment. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, and Shimon Peres, the Labor leader, said on leaving a negotiating session that ''serious obstacles'' were blocking formation of a coalition cabinet. They parted without setting a date for a new meeting. (Page 1, Column 4.) Tens of thousands of Sikhs turned out for an anti-Government rally in India's Punjab state at which religious leaders called for a mass march to liberate their Golden Temple, their holiest shrine, from army occupation. They also shouted their approval for a merger of conflicting Sikh political factions into a unified party known as Akali Dal. The demonstration was also intended to ratify a broad anti- Government program that Indians believe could lead to sharper confrontations with supporters of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. (1:5.)

title: PARENTS FIND A WIDE VARIETY OF DAY-CARE QUALITY IN U.S.
description: In one room, a group of 3-year-olds are learning about Mexico; some are inspecting a map and a story book with a young teacher, while others glue orange and yellow crepe paper to a pinata they are making from a brown paper bag.

title: Verplank Wins U.S. Amateur
description: Oklahoma State's Scott Verplank battled back with a flurry of birdies midway through the second 18 holes to win the United States Amateur golf championship over Sam Randolph of Southern California, 4 and 3, today.

title: GOOD START FOR A 400-YARD DAY
description: Ron Jaworski, the quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, knew early in the game today that Phil Simms, his counterpart for the Giants, was going to have a big day.

title: No Headline
description: 4-Year-Old Queens Girl Is Abducted and Raped

title: ADS FOR HISPANIC CONSUMERS
description: Spurred by increasing business interest in reaching Hispanic people, the country's fastest-growing market segment, the number of advertising agencies that specialize in marketing to Hispanic consumers is growing.

title: Group Hopes to Sign Up 1 Million Voters Oct. 4
description: Plans are being made to send 100,000 volunteers into the streets of America in an attempt to register one million new voters on a single day.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR SAY CABINET TALKS HIT SERIOUS SNAGS
description: Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reported tonight that ''serious obstacles'' were blocking the formation of a bipartisan Israeli government.

title: CHILDREN TESTIFY AGAINST PARENTS OVER ABUSE
description: A 6- year-old boy said a cheerful ''Hi!'' to his parents from the witness chair and then, testifying at their trial, accused them of sexually abusing him.

title: TAX CAUTION FOR PENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON Confronted with several proposals for a radical overhaul of the tax system, some groups with lots to lose have started to bang hard on the alarm bells.

title: UNIONISTS SEE LABOR DAY '84 AS A TIME TO WEIGH SETBACKS
description: Union members and leaders are approaching Labor Day 1984 with a growing feeling that the balance of power in the workplace has shifted dramatically in favor of employers.

title: LEGALITIES: THE CASES TO WATCH
description: Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor and civil libertarian, was recently asked his personal, unlawyerly opinion of the roadblocks that have sprung up across Massachusetts as part of a campaign against drunken driving.

title: WHAT HEALTH CLUBS OFFER THE DISABLED
description: It was a regular exercise class: music pulsating, people puffing and perspiring, instructor urging them on.

title: Mamola Triumphs In San Marino
description: Randy Mamola of Santa Clara, Calif., topped Raymond Roche of France and Ron Haslam of Britain today as Honda machines dominated the San Marino Grand Prix, the final 500 c.c. motorcycle Grand Prix race of the season.

title: A KEYNOTE STATEMENT BY CHERNENKO
description: When Konstantin U. Chernenko's answers to questions from Pravda were read on television Saturday night, a certain immutable process was set in motion. Every major Soviet newspaper led its first page today with the interview and television reported broad worldwide enthusiasm for it. In coming days and weeks, references to the interview will become a mandatory element of all major Soviet pronouncements on Soviet-American relations

title: AN AMERICAN OFFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WEST INDIAN CARNIVAL It's carnival time on Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway. Starting at noon, bands, floats and masqueraders will proceed along a three-mile stretch, from Utica Avenue to the Brooklyn Museum, in the 17th annual event sponsored by the West Indian-American Labor Day Carnival Association.

title: Michael Shapiro Wed To Susan Chira in Rye
description: Susan Chira and Michael Shapiro were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chira, in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Julie Gordon performed the ceremony.

title: DOING THE CON CON
description: WASHINGTON Our first constitution, the Articles of Confederation, did not work because it could not be changed. The Founders tinkered with that document in 1785 but left the Annapolis meeting in frustration.

title: Caracas Debt Progress Seen
description: Foreign banks are willing to restructure $19.7 billion of the Venezuelan Government's foreign debt, two Caracas newspapers reported.

title: CONSUMER BANKS' SLOW START
description: The number of financial services companies crowding into the banking business so concerned Federal regulators last year that they imposed a moratorium on the creation of consumer banks, or ''nonbank banks,'' but not before several slipped through the net.

title: Baby Elephant Kills Man
description: A 1,000- pound baby elephant killed a man who had prodded it with an ax handle, the police said today. The dead man, William David Sharp. an employee of a Texas company that was picking up the elephant, was trying to load it into a shipping crate when it gored him. The animal had been in a crate that was dropped 4 or 5 feet earlier in the loading process.

title: No Headline
description: An Unusual Fund

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''That's the way it works every year. The stoplights are turned on, they have time to flash once or twice, and then it's time to turn them off.

title: ;  Solomon Retires
description: Harold Solomon, who won 22 singles titles during his 12-year professional career, announced his retirement yesterday. The 31-year-old from Washington, one of the first players to employ a two-handed backhand, was known for his consistency from the baseline. Solomon, who had played infrequently the last two years, said that, among the interests he will pursue, will be the Hunger Project, an organization dedicated to eliminating world hunger by the end of the century.

title: 'CHESSIE' BACK IN THE SWIM AGAIN
description: Maybe it's just the heat at the end of a long, hot summer, maybe not. But once again there are reports that a sea monster has taken up residence in Washington's watery weekend playground, the Chesapeake Bay.

title: A Bullish View Of Gold Market
description: Commodities prices have been in a long slump, largely a victim of low inflation and continuing high interest rates. But the gold market, because it rose so spectacularly several years ago, has seemed the most depressed, both in price and the spirits of investors.

title: BUSH HAS DECIDED TO DEBATE FERRARO, A SPOKESMAN SAYS
description: Vice President Bush today wooed blue-collar, ethnic voters here with a sharp attack on the Democratic ticket in which he linked Walter F. Mondale to former President Jimmy Carter.

title: Carolina Nuclear Plant In Big Radioactive Leak
description: Radioactive tritium oxide gas leaked from equipment at a Federal nuclear weapons plant here, but officials said this largest leak of the substance from the Savannah River Plant posed no threat to workers or people nearby.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Quiet Baltimore

title: Oil Pricing Is Defended
description: Pressures on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to further reduce oil prices are counterproductive, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Oil Minister, said today.

title: Lobbyists' Spending In theFirst Quarter Was $11.75 Million
description: Lobbyists for business, labor and ideological groups spent $11.75 million trying to influence Congress in the first three months of the year.

title: No Headline
description: Louis Rothschild, 84, Eisenhower Era Figure

title: PEOPLE'S ACTIONS: WHERE THE BUCK STOPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneer Nuclear Plant Closing
description: Commonwealth Edison has announced that it will permanently close its Dresden nuclear plant Unit 1, the first nuclear power plant built by private industry and the blueprint for a generation of modern nuclear reactors.

title: A COSTLY SECRECY IN THE PENTAGON
description: To the Editor:

title: Schedule Is Light for Bond Issues
description: In a holiday-shortened week, the schedule of new bond offerings is relatively light. The Treasury is not expected to borrow in the note or bond market until it sells two-year notes on Sept. 19, followed by a major three- part note and bond financing in the last week of the month.

title: THE RESIDENT RASCAL OF THE STATE DEPT.
description: Although he was once an Air Force officer and a successful Alaska land developer and remains an ardent Republican, Langhorne A. Motley, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, can be a scamp.

title: Immigration Unit Sued On Custody of Children
description: A class action lawsuit was filed Friday accusing the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service of trying to lure undocumented workers out of hiding by holding their children.

title: NEW YORK ; RAPPAPORT SOUNDS THE ALARM
description: My friend Rappaport, whose views and experiences I write about from time to time, came running into my office the other day with his eyes popping and his voice in a state of alarm. This was uncharacteristic of the laconic Rappaport.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Designated Ross Jones, infielder, for reassignment.

title: British Aerospace Plans
description: British Aerospace said it would launch a stretched 120-seat version of its BAE 146 airliner in 1988.

title: SABATINI MAKING A NAME
description: She has been told in the last few

title: Vienna Cabinet Shuffled; Infighting Is Denied
description: Chancellor Fred Sinowatz said today that he had replaced four Cabinet members after a day of talks with leaders of the Austrian Socialist Party.

title: Chicago's Mayor Cites Lack Of Smoke Devices in Deaths
description: A city housing project where four people died in a fire Saturday did not have smoke detectors, and broken elevators and a lack of fire hose hookups hampered firefighters battling the blaze, Mayor Harold Washington said Sunday.

title: STATEWIDE DEBIT CARD SYSTEM INTRODUCED
description: Since Saturday, several Crown Liquor Stores have been allowing customers to pay for their purchases without cash, credit cards or checks. And countless other retailers are expected to soon follow Crown's example - bringing the cashless society a little closer.

title: Lightning Hits Jet at Airport
description: A Piedmont Airlines Boeing 737 unloading passengers at National Airport was struck by lightning tonight, jolting six workers standing near the jetliner, airport officials said.

title: YANKEES BEAT BLUE JAYS BY 2-0
description: Joe Cowley, the other pitcher that the pitching-poor Atlanta Braves let get away, gave the Yankees another good reason yesterday to make sure that he doesn't get away from them.

title: Citicorp Offering
description: Citicorp is raising $250 million through an offering of 12-year capital notes priced at par with interest at a margin of 1/8 percent above the mean between the bid and the offered London interbank rate, said lead manager Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The issue, offered in the name of the company's Citicorp Overseas Finance Corporation N.V. subsidiary, will carry a minimum coupon of 5 1/4 percent and be callable after two years at par. The notes will be available in denominations of $50,000.

title: Hill Wins First L.P.G.A. Title
description: Cindy Hill earned her first victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today by carding a 1-under-par 71 in the final round to claim the Rail Charity Classic by two strokes over three players.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Crown Central Petroleum Corp., Baltimore, has elected Victor G. Oberschall vice president-supply and transportation.

title: NBC TRYING A DIFFERENT APPROACH
description: There is a conflict inherent in those professional football pre-game shows. It seems the

title: African Leaders to Meet
description: Zimbabwe's Prime Minister, Robert Mugabe, left Harare today for Arusha in northern Tanzania to attend a two-day meeting of southern Africa's so-called front-line countries. He will join leaders from Angola, Botswana, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zambia, the countries of the region that are mainly concerned with independence for South-West Africa, known also as Namibia.

title: Brooke Rejects Bid From Unilever
description: Brooke Bond Group P.L.C., the British tea giant, today gave a brisk ''no deal'' response to a rival $460 million takeover bid from International Food Group, Unilever P.L.C. The tea group, which had already rejected an earlier takeover offer from sugar manufacturers Tate & Lyle P.L.C., also issued a sharp rebuke to Unilever for the way the bid was handled.

title: No Headline
description: Brooke

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Boston Aug. 17 about an agreement by the General Services Administration to donate and sell waterfront land to the town of Nantucket misstated the political affiliation and hometown of State Senator Paul Doane. He is a Republican from Harwich.

title: Gemayel Meets Syrian On Impasse in Beirut
description: President Amin Gemayel met with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, in Damascus today to discuss breaking a deadlock within Lebanon's so-called Government of national unity over a security plan and political changes, sources at the presidential palace said.

title: 2 Killed in Memphis Fire
description: Trash piled up at a the rear door of an apartment house caught fire this morning, resulting in a blaze that took the lives of a 9-year-old girl and a 49-year old man, Fire Department officials said.

title: KOCH DEFENDS SERGEANTS TEST AND ORDERS ITS RESULTS USED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that his administration would stand by the results of the latest police sergeants examination, despite the high failure rate among black and Hispanic officers who took the test.

title: OTHER COUNTRIES: EXTENSIVE FACILITIES AND CONTROLS
description: The borough of Camden, running from leafy Hampstead four miles south through Central London and the far-less-affluent area of St. Pancras, has only 7,500 children younger than 5, but the list of facilities available for them - from day-care centers to toy libraries - is so extensive that it fills 96 pages of a publication titled ''Under Fives Welcome.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1984
description: The Economy

title: 'RED DAWN' CONDEMNED AS RIFE WITH VIOLENCE
description: The National Coalition on Television Violence has condemned the summer hit ''Red Dawn'' as the most violent movie ever made. The fantasy about third-world troops invading a small Colorado town averages 134 acts of violence an hour, according to the organization headed by Thomas Radecki, a University of Illinois psychiatrist.

title: EXPERTS DEBATE IMPACT OF DAY CARE ON CHILDREN AND ON SOCIETY
description: Twenty years after the first studies of day care in America, social scientists are debating its effect on the very young and expressing increasing concern about the impact of low-quality care on children's development.

title: ;  Saints Sign Ward The New Orleans Saints signed the former Jet offensive tackle
description: Chris Ward yesterday, hoping to use him to replace the injured Dave Lafary, who is probably lost for the season, according to Bum Phillips, the Saint coach. Kelvin Clark, a reserve will move into Lafary's spot for Sunday's game against Tampa Bay, Phillips said. Ward, who started 86 of his 87 games at left tackle for the Jets, was waived in the team's final cut.

title: Thais Delay Showdown Over Jobs for Generals
description: A possible constitutional crisis was put off today when the Thai legislature voted to postpone a decision on whether active military officers should be allowed to hold Government posts.

title: SWITCH BY PHILIPPINE BUSINESS
description: On his office bookshelf, Jaime V. Ongpin keeps a copy of ''Managing in Turbulent Times'' by the American management expert Peter Drucker. ''It makes for pretty tame reading around here these days,'' Mr. Ongpin said, grinning.

title: A LOOK AT THE MONEY MOVERS
description: In the late 1960's when stock prices jumped wildly and volume soared, the movers and shakers of the securities world were the portfolio managers of equity mutual funds. These days, with interest-rate gyrations so crucial, their counterparts at money market mutual funds, who control assets of $180 billion, are at center stage.

title: 2 Lebanese Killed in Turkey
description: Two Lebanese were killed when a car exploded in a parking lot today, the authorities said. They said the men entered Turkey from Syria on Aug. 30 and ''they were probably planning to stage some acts in Turkey.''

title: PRANK PUNISHES YOUNG SURGEONS
description: W hen the number of routine urine samples sent to a laboratory at Montefiore Hospital became excessive during the recent strike, senior doctors ordered junior doctors, who are called surgical residents, to stop the abuse.

title: REMOVAL OF PHOTO ARCHIVES FOUGHT IN ROCHESTER
description: Since the board of directors of the George Eastman House decided last month to negotiate the donation of its extensive photographic archives to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, a citizens' group has been formed to try to find ways to block the move.

title: COAST FESTIVAL IS A VEHICLE FOR CARS
description: In Los Angeles even the cars aspire to be movie stars. During the parade that opened the city's ''Carplays'' festival held over the Labor Day weekend, many of the cars on display had played significant parts on the large or small screen. Here were Dustin Hoffman's Alfa Romeo from ''The Graduate,'' the 1964 Chevy Impala used on ''Chico and the Man,'' the Excalibur from ''Matt Houston,'' and the 40-foot limousine - identified as the world's longest car - that will appear on an upcoming episode of ''Glitter.''

title: UNIONS IN BRITAIN BACK MINE STRIKE
description: Britain's striking coal miners won an overwhelming promise of support today from fellow trade unionists at the annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress.

title: NBC MOVING PART OF NEWS OPERATION TO MOSCOW
description: NBC News, which has been trying to take the lead in news innovations, will be moving part of its news operations to Moscow this week for an extensive set of reports on Russian society and what it calls ''the new cold war.''

title: Article 165553 -- No Title
description: A 28-year-old printer claimed a $40 million prize from the Illinois State Lottery today and said he wanted nothing extravagant, thank you. Just an engagement ring for his girlfriend for starters, and, oh yes, Cubs baseball tickets.

title: PERES IS AGAIN COURTING SMALL PARTIES
description: Israel's Labor Alignment, its coalition talks with the Likud bloc apparently deadlocked, turned today to smaller parties to try to end the impasse with a more narrowly based government.

title: BURNS AND MALNUTRITION BRING DALI TO CLINIC
description: Salvador Dali, who was burned in a fire at his castle last Thursday, was being treated Sunday for those burns and for chronic malnutrition as well, physicians said.

title: NICARAGUA LINKS COPTER VICTIMS TO THE C.I.A.
description: The Nicaraguan Defense Minister today dismissed reports that at least two of three men killed in a helicopter over northern Nicaragua Saturday were independent mercenaries.

title: ;  Unsigned Devil
description: The Devils, only a week away from the start of their rookie camp, have yet to sign Kirk Muller, their most highly touted rookie. Muller, the second player chosen in June's amateur draft, is represented by Gus Badali of Toronto. Mario Lemieux, the top pick in the draft, is also a Badali client, and the agent says he thinks Muller's pay should approximate that received by Lemieux from the Pittsburgh Penguins, reportedly about $250,000 per season.

title: Market Place; Best Month Since Late '82
description: The opening days of August served up a sizzling rally for the stock market. Groups that

title: LOCAL STATIONS ARE OFFERING 24-HOUR MUSIC VIDEO
description: Local broadcasters, inspired by the advent of stereo television and the success of music videos on cable television, are latching onto this format themselves, giving it a hometown flavor and transmitting it for free.

title: MODEL FOR U.S. RULES ON AMUSEMENT RIDES
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN SLAIN AS SHE FLEES CAB
description: A 38-year-old Manhattan woman was slain on Fifth Avenue early yesterday after she jumped out of a taxicab and was either hit or pushed to the ground by another passenger.

title: BLACK-FOOTED FERRETS REVIVE
description: -footed ferrets, believed to be the rarest mammal in the United States, has turned up a record 128 animals in a remote section of Wyoming, according to Timothy Clark, a wildlife biologist who heads the ferret conservation program of the Wildlife Preservation Trust in Philadelphia.

title: 2 NICARAGUA DEAD TIED TO RECRUITING
description: Government officials said today that two men killed when Nicaragua shot down a rebel helicopter were American mercenaries apparently recruited by rebel sympathizers to make up for the withdrawal of official American aid.

title: CHELATION: MIRACLE CURE OR FALSE HOPE?
description: GLADSTONE, MO. H UNDREDS of people with a broad range of ailments, including problems they say were caused by Agent Orange, are coming here for a costly therapy that proponents view as a miracle cure. Critics contend it can be extremely dangerous and, in some cases, lethal.

title: PLAYS ; TYPICAL PLAY IS EXPLOSIVE FOR GIANTS
description: On paper, at least, there is nothing extraordinary about the play, one found in almost every pro team's playbook. It does have a little deception and deceit in it and Wes Hopkins, the free safety for the Philadelphia Eagles, was beguiled for a second or two, or long enough for Byron Williams to break open in the fourth minute of the second quarter of Sunday's game at Giants Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:New Book by Briton Offers Excellent Collectionof Deals

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays , at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. John Montefusco, victorious in his last start, pitches against Toronto's Jim Clancy as the Yankees try to gain some ground on the second-place team in the Eastern Division.

title: EXCERPTS FROM VATICAN STATEMENT CRITICIZING THE 'THEOLOGY OF LIBERATION'
description: Following are excerpts from the statement on liberation theology as issued in English by the Vatican today:

title: PERES COULDN'T RETURN THE LAND
description: Now that Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir have agreed to alternate as Prime Minister of Israel in a national unity goverment, Americans can have no illusions about the fate of the West Bank. The hard-line expansionist record of Mr. Shamir's Likud bloc is known to all, and Mr. Peres, who is expected to head the government for the next 25 months, can offer little alternative, for he is sure to find in office that his policy for the return of the occupied territories is bankrupt and impossible to realize.

title: APOLLO IS FULL OF HOPE AFTER A DREAMLIKE START
description: When John W. Poduska was unable to get the research funding he wanted at the company he co-founded, Prime Computer, he stormed out in 1979 and headed for a skiing vacation. But, as computer-industry aficionados tell the story, on the way to ski he took a detour to San Francisco.

title: A DUEL ON ECONOMICS SHAPES UP
description: President Reagan is assured of running on one of the strongest election year economies ever. Interest rates are holding steady. Inflation is 4 percent, far below the levels of the Carter Administration, and unemployment has dropped by 3.2 percentage points from the recession high of 10.6 near the end of 1982.

title: 'NEW YORKERS NEED A TAX BREAK - TODAY!'
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.& T. NET MARGIN NEARS CAP
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, despite service backlogs and increased competition, has moved closer in recent months to its maximum authorized profit margin for interstate long-distance telephone service.

title: 'HIGH TECH,' NARRATED BY WALTER CRONKITE
description: I T is late afternoon at the Fanuc

title: CENSUS SHOWS RISE IN NUMBER OF SMALL FARMS
description: The number of small farms in the United States jumped sharply from 1978 to 1982, surprising agriculture experts with the size of their growth, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: INJURY SLOWS BROOKE'S PLANS
description: Bob Brooke's idea when he reported to the American entry in the Canada Cup, was to get in shape. If he failed to make the team, so what? He would have had his rehearsal, and his conditioning would be that much better when the Rangers started training camp later this month.

title: Many Hurt in Nigeria Crash
description: About 40 people were feared dead and many others injured when a bus and an oil tanker collided at Damagun, near Potiskum, in northern Nigeria, the News Agency of Nigeria said today. Quoting a witness, the agency said that the accident occurred early Saturday.

title: GENIUSES AT WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: A DAY OF CAMERAS AND HAMMERS FOR EX-PRESIDENT
description: On the first day of Habitat for Humanity's renovation of a Lower East Side tenement, Jimmy Carter was the last one out of bed.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Ring Comeback After 3 Years Off

title: THEORY ON MAN'S ORIGINS CHALLENGED
description: N ew examinations of bones and stones nearly two million years old have forced many scientists to abandon a cornerstone theory about the social behavior of man's ancient ancestors. As a result, the early history of human culture is being rewritten.

title: BREVITY AND LAPSES ANGER SINATRA AUDIENCE
description: An audience of 15,000 people, paying up to $75 for a ticket, responded with shouts and boos Sunday when Frank Sinatra performed for only 35 minutes - and forgot some of the words to his songs - while the audience had to sit in the rain.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: The Government's search for a

title: PLATFORMS OF PARTIES OFFER FUNDAMENTALLY DIFFERENT VISIONS OF GOVERNMENT
description: The Democratic and Republican platforms embody two fundamentally different visions of Government's proper role in guiding the economy, fighting poverty, protecting civil rights, controlling nuclear weapons and keeping peace throughout the world.

title: ;  Finance Chief Quits Goodrich
description: William D. Wooldredge has resigned as an executive vice president and chief financial officer at the B. F. Goodrich Company, effective Sept. 30.

title: THE BUMPY ROAD TO TRANQUILLITY
description: T HE water line had broken somewhere along the 600 feet between the spring house and my office. Then I learned that my tax bill, deferred by extension and now definitely due, was going to amount to twice what I had expected. It was enough to send one off the deep end with TENSION!!!

title:
ABOUT EDUCATION;
NO-NEED SCHOLARSHIPS
description: -year-old senior at Smithtown High School West on Long Island, was trying to decide which college to attend when a letter arrived from Adelphi University, where she had applied. It informed her that her 3.8 grade point average in high school made her one of several winners of a $5,990 ''Presidential'' scholarship.

title: PANEL IN AUSTRALIA URGES THAT ORPHANED FROZEN EMBRYOES BE DESTROYED
description: A study committee has recommended that state officials authorize the destruction of two frozen embryos that belonged to a Los Angeles couple who died in a plane crash. A final decision, however, has been put off until December.

title: On Kicking Away 3,400 Jobs
description: All over the country, people have discovered that the power to sue can be the power to delay to death. Two New York City legislators, Councilwoman Ruth Messinger and State Senator Franz Leichter, are trying to use that power now to stop a major New York economic development project, one that would protect 3,400 jobs for lower-income workers, produce $20 million a year in real estate taxes for the city and create half a billion in construction dollars. Why?

title: CANADIANS PREDICT A CONSERVATIVE LANDSLIDE IN THE ELECTION TODAY
description: Overconfidence appeared to be the principal worry of Canada's conservatives today on the eve of what may be the biggest political victory for any Canadian party since 1958, when John Diefenbaker, a Tory, won 208 of 265 seats.

title: No Headline
description: Editor Plans Shift to Diebold Lewis H. Young, who is resigning as editor in chief of

title: FALL BOOKS: CIVIL WAR TO BUSINESS INTRIGUE
description: Are you ready for a journey to a parallel world? Would you like to immerse yourelf in the passions of the Civil War? Or is business intrigue more to your taste?

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; THE DIN OF CHAMPIONS
description: It seems that all that might disqualify a man from being

title: Winds Stall Salvage Of Radioactive Cargo
description: Gales battered the partly submerged wreck of the freighter Mont Louis off the Belgian coast today, hampering the salvage of its radioactive cargo, Belgian officials said.

title: FIRST-TIME STARTERS
description: ARE IMPRESSIVE FOR GIANTS AND JETS

title: AH, WILDERNESS! SAVE IT.
description: Today, and 200 years from now, when Americans want to know what the land looked like when their forebears arrived, they need not resort to pictures in a history book. They can go see the real thing, in no small part because of the passage of the Wilderness Act of 1964.

title: NAVRATILOVA TOPS POTTER BY 6-4, 6-4
description: Since she began dominating women's tennis more than two years ago, Martina Navratilova has been credited with establishing several trends in the game, especially in the area of physical conditioning. But she has also been credited recently with helping to revive a custom from another era: practicing with men.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Clowning at Lincoln Center

title: Sting Wins, 3-1, To Stay in Race
description: The Chicago Sting kept their playoff hopes alive today by defeating the Vancouver Whitecaps, 3-1, at Wrigley Field.

title: Francis V. Madigan, 77, Dies; Ex-Housing Authority Official
description: Francis V. Madigan, a lawyer and a former vice chairman of the New York City Housing Authority in the administrations of Mayors Robert F. Wagner and John V. Lindsay, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Silver Lake, S.I. He was 77 years old.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Bush Bars Journalists From Campaign Plane
description: In a break with other candidates, Vice President Bush excluded reporters from his plane as he set out today on a three-day campaign trip to Illinois, Louisiana and Kentucky.

title: SCOUTING;
