description: A 68-Hour Match

title: Husband of Princess Anne Escapes Injury in Car Crash
description: Capt. Mark Phillips, husband of Princess Anne, escaped injury when the car he was driving collided head-on with a car that was trying to pass a truck, the police said today.

title: John A. Savage Weds Miss Beebe in Maine
description: Schuyler Beebe, a daughter of Mrs. Gordon Gray of Washington and Northeast Harbor, Me., and the late Marcus Beebe Jr. of Boston, was married yesterday to John A. Savage, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Savage of Northeast Harbor. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor.

title: Seven Killed in Crash Of 3 Cars in Chicago
description: At least seven people, four of them children, were killed and two others were injured late tonight in a fiery three-car crash on Lake Shore Drive, the police said.

title: JOYS OF SUMMER ON A JERSEY ISLAND NOW BECOME MEMORIES
description: Just before Memorial Day they turned the traffic lights on in this sandy sliver off the Jersey Shore. Another summer had begun. Just after Labor Day they will turn those lights off again. Another summer will have ended.

title: Jessica Ruth Stulman Wed To Laurence M. Sheinman
description: Jessica Ruth Stulman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Stulman of New York, was married at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday to Laurence Marcus Sheinman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sheinman of Lynbrook, L.I. Rabbi Judah Nadich, assisted by Rabbi Harlan Wechsler, performed the ceremony.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; White House Limits News Services' Access
description: The White House, putting a new rule into effect, barred news service reporters today from the pool covering President Reagan when he greeted welcomers at El Toro Marine Corps Air Station.

title: War Games Open in Europe
description: NATO and Warsaw Pact forces began two months of military exercises today. About 60,000 Soviet-bloc troops took the field in Czechoslovakia as 58,000 British troops started crossing the English Channel to join in NATO's Autumn Forge exercise. The Atlantic alliance exercise is being staged from Norway to the Black Sea will eventually involve 250,000 troops.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1984 International Radical versions of the theology of liberation were assailed in a major 36-page document released by the Vatican. The doctrine of liberation theology, which involves the use of Marxist analysis, has been used to justify the activism of Roman Catholic priests and nuns in Latin America for 15 years. (Page A1, Column 6.) At least three people were killed and 29 were wounded as a bomb went off in Montreal's main rail station. The police said the blast might have been intended as a warning against a scheduled visit next week by Pope John Paul II. (A1:3-5.)

title: Nigerians Say British Papers 'Fabricated' Crate News Item
description: The Nigerian High Commission here said today that the British press had 'fabricated' a news item about a crate to embarrass Nigeria.

title: A PRIORITY CONCERN FOR DIASPORA JEWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: RYAN PLANS TO IMPROVE HIS TIMING
description: Although Pat Ryan has been throwing footballs for the Jets since 1978, he looked at his job differently today. And Sunday night he looked at himself in a new way.

title: IGUANAS SUCCESSFULLY BRED
description: W ITH the help of some concrete blocks and a lot of loving care, a group of researchers at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama have developed a method of artificially incubating iguana eggs and hatching baby iguanas with virtually no losses.

title: SHISEIDO PREPARES CAMPAIGN
description: Andrew Philip, president of Shiseido Cosmetics (America) Ltd., thumbed through this month's 804-page copy of Vogue, a magazine so fat with advertising that the first article begins on page 146 and the second on page 312. ''There's not a lot that's different here,'' the 42- year-old executive said after looking at the cosmetics ads. ''There are faces. But nothing very unusual.''

title: Piston Pacts
description: The Detroit Pistons were expected today to announce the signing of the forward Kelly Tripucka and the guard Vinnie Johnson. The Pistons were in danger of losing the two players to National Basketball Association rivals who had signed them to offer sheets. The Cleveland Cavaliers offered Tripucka a reported 7-year, $6.3 million deal, while the Knicks offered Johnson $1.5 million over three seasons.

title: CUBS WIN ON ERROR IN 12TH, 4-3
description: Ryne Sandberg scored the winning run in the 12th inning today when the shortstop Kiko Garcia booted Gary Matthews's two-out grounder to give the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Egypt Delays Nuclear Plan
description: Mohammed Osman Abaza, Egypt's Minister of Electricity, said today that Egypt's plan to build eight nuclear power plants by the year 2000 would be delayed by financing snags.

title: CULT/CURTIS MASSEY'S WINNERS
description: It was Jack C. Massey's plan to spend a quiet summer. Southampton can be a deliciously drowsy place this time of year, and he and his elegant wife had just the house and devoted staff. The Nashville entrepreneur figured he would exercise a game leg, see friends and enjoy Lake Agawam's misty beauty. Then a couple of thunderstorms shook the house. The lights went out at a party. The fog rolled in so you couldn't recognize the person next to you. For days, the village was a gloomy steam bath. The weekends were socially overloaded. But the Masseys didn't mind.

title: Polish Zloty Is Devalued
description: Poland's central bank today announced a 10.6 percent devaluation of the zloty against the dollar as a way to increase exports.

title: THE FIVE-DAY WEEK: CAN JAPAN LEARN TO LOVE IT?
description: A Government advisory council has recommended that hard-laboring Japan move more rapidly toward a nationwide five-day work week - a goal not likely to be achieved easily in a country where six-day weeks were the firm standard until recently.

title: CANDIDATES DIFFER SHARPLY ON PLANS TO AID SCHOOLS
description: P RESIDENT REAGAN's announcement that a teacher would be the first ''citizen passenger'' to fly into space is widely regarded as the blastoff of education as a major campaign issue. The question raised last week by earthbound educators is whether the gesture would also put support of education in orbit.

title: MUSIC: CATHERINE COMET LEADS VERDI 'DESTINY'
description: A NYONE who thinks Manhattan becomes a ghost town on Labor Day weekend should have been at Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Sunday evening. The American Symphony Orchestra gave a free concert in the Damrosch Park bandshell, and to judge by the crowd you'd have thought Toscanini had been announced to conduct. Every seat was taken; the audience jammed aisles, benches and walls, and spilled over well past the point at which the park area joins the Lincoln Center plaza.

title: BEFORE IT'S TOO LATE
description: PARIS Konstantin Chernenko, the Soviet leader, seems to have moved a step closer to Washington's stance on space weapons talks. He says now a ban could facilitate other disarmament sessions.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MONTANA'S FEELINGS ON FIRES
description: Forest fires burned up a lot of wood and grass in this vast state in recent days. The flames also ignited hard feelings among some local people.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Special Ballots Designed For U.S. Voters Abroad
description: Five states with nearly 400,000 potential voters outside the country have devised special write-in ballots so people in remote spots can get their votes counted even if they have to mail them before some candidates are nominated, the Federal Voting Assistance Program says.

title: BOSTON POLICEMAN ARRESTED
description: A Boston police officer was arrested and two New York policemen and a prison guard were wounded yesterday after the Boston officer exchanged shots with the New York police at the Jamaica Day festivities in Brooklyn, the police said. A civilian was also wounded in the incident.

title: VATICAN CENSURES MARXIST ELEMENTS IN NEW THEOLOGY
description: The Vatican today made public a major document that was sharply critical of the more radical versions of the doctrine known as the theology of liberation.

title: BANNERS AND CHEERS FILL LABOR DAY
description: Thousands of banner- waving, horn-tooting, slogan-shouting union workers marched up Fifth Avenue in yesterday's Labor Day Parade as the Democratic Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates led the way.

title: ARGENTINE LABOR MOVEMENT STAGES ONE-DAY STRIKE
description: Argentina's union movement began a 24-hour strike today, the first such labor action in the nine-month civilian administration of President Raul Alfonsin.

title: BRIEFING ; 'Quiet Heroes'
description: President Reagan expressed

title: Chess: Queens International Master Wins Nassau County Event
description: The Nassau County Chess Club International Tournament in Syosset, L.I., was won by Tim Taylor, a Queens international master. He scored 8 1/2- 1/2 to capture the $800 first prize in the 10-player round-robin event.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TIME OF HER LIFE. By Robb Forman Dew. 259 pages. William Morrow & Company. $12.95.

title: JERSEY REVISES LIST OF SCHOOLS CLOSED FOR ASBESTOS REMOVAL
description: After a weekend of confusion and conflicting reports about which public schools in New Jersey would not open as scheduled because of asbestos removal, the state's Education Department issued a revised list tonight.

title: FALL 6 BEHIND
description: The Mets fell tonight as far from first as they have been this season. They lost to the Cardinals here, 7-3, and with the Cubs having defeated the Phillies earlier in the day, the Mets slipped six games behind Chicago in this race between the improbable contenders of the National League East.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; WHY TRADING LACKS DIRECTION
description: Amid mounting evidence that the economy is slowing, financial market participants are still not convinced that lower interest rates are around the corner.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Erudite Aerobics

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Seligman & Latz Names President
description: Arthur E. Fabricant has been named president and chief operating officer of Seligman & Latz Inc., the specialty retailing company announced.

title: TRADE GAP UPSTAGES EXPORT SURGE
description: Buried in last week's announcement of a record trade deficit in July was the news that United States exports were up sharply that month. Administration officials, economists and corporate executives all predicted that the nation's exports would continue to climb in the year ahead, but they said the increase would hardly reduce the trade deficit because import levels are also rising.

title: Tour, Anyone?
description: No one in Washington is quite sure why, but fewer people have been lining up for the public tours of the White House.

title: PHILHARMONIC VISIT GETS ENTHUSIASTIC THAI EFFORT
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced a few weeks ago that it had struck Malaysia from its Asian tour because of a program dispute, it didn't take long for music lovers in Thailand to descend on the United States Information Service here and ask: Can we bring them to Bangkok?

title: WHY KOCH DIDN'T MARCH WITH MONDALE (MAYBY)
description: Walter F. Mondale, of North Oaks, Minn., marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in New York's Labor Day parade. Edward I. Koch, of Gracie Mansion and City Hall, did not.

title: 3D SHOOTING INCIDENT IS REPORTED ALONG THE CONNECTICUT TURNPIKE
description: A gunman in a passing van shot at a couple stopped on the side of the Connecticut Turnpike in Stratford yesterday, the Connecticut state police said. It was the third shooting incident on the turnpike in the last month.

title: Dublin Mayor Sees an Insult In March by New York Band
description: The Lord Mayor of Dublin today called off a meeting with a New York police band, saying its participation in a parade of the Irish Republican Army was ''an insult.''

title: 380 Die as a Typhoon Rakes the Philippines
description: A typhoon whipped the southern Philippines with winds of 115 miles an hour today, leaving at least 380 people dead in a trail of flattened houses, uprooted trees and darkened cities, officials said.

title: ICE POSES PUZZLE BUT SHUTTLE TRIP IS HELD A SUCCESS
description: Space agency officials, vexed by a large chunk of ice that clung tenaciously to a water vent on the side of the shuttle Discovery, were weighing several options today on how to remove it, including using the ship's robot arm to knock it free.

title: P
description: Ronald M. Nonken has been appointed a senior vice president at Decker Guertin & Cheyne Advertising in Hartford.

title: BOOKSTORES GEAR UP, AND DOWN, FOR COLLEGIANS' TASTE
description: ''Hey, John, what sort of books do the students at UMass have sticking out of their back pockets?''

title: CONFIDENT REAGAN VOWS TO 'MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN'
description: On a crest of personal confidence and organizational strength, President Reagan went to the voters today and pleaded for re-election in order ''to make America great again and let the eagle soar.''

title: COWBOYS DEFEAT RAMS
description: The Dallas Cowboys made a successful 1984 debut here tonight. The revamped and revised Cowboys overcame a 13-7 halftime deficit and defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 20-13.

title: Incense Stick Sets Off a Fire In Trenton Apartment House
description: An unattended stick of incense set an apartment ablaze this afternoon, filling a 12- story apartment building with smoke and forcing 60 elderly residents, some of them handicapped, to flee.

title: Omaha Area Evacuated As Tank Leaks Acid
description: Chemists and firefighters emptied a leaking tank today that had sent a cloud of acidic gas over southwestern Omaha, forcing hundreds of people from their homes for several hours.

title: Tiger Hunting in Sri Lanka
description: A tragedy is developing in Sri Lanka, the Indian Ocean island once known as Ceylon. An aggrieved ethnic minority has turned to separatist terrorism, and the majority community has responded with repression and racial war. This is more than a local misfortune because Sri Lanka has been that rare thing in the third world, a working democracy, reasonably prosperous and traditionally nonviolent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SHAKESPEARE IN BROOKLYN With suppport from Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare Festival, Shakespeare & Company is in town from its home base in Lenox, Mass., to be part of ''Celebrate Brooklyn,'' the arts festival in Prospect Park. The company will give six free performances at 8 P.M. in the Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street.

title: AMERICAN MILITARY PENSIONS - BEYOND HALF-PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Asks Lebanon To Look for Journalist
description: Britain asked the Lebanese Government today to make every effort to find Jonathan Wright, a Reuters correspondent who has been missing for six days, a British Embassy spokesman said.

title: MATH PROBLEM VERIFIED
description: The ''Bieberbach conjecture,'' a mathematical problem that has eluded verification since 1916, apparently has been conquered.

title: FUN FAKES FOR FALL: A COLORFUL LOOK AT 'FURS'
description: Frankly fake ''fun furs,'' as they were called in the 1960's, have made an unexpected comeback for fall. Many of them are so appealing that they may be welcomed by those women who can't make it through the day without sable as well as by that larger group of women who object to fur for all manner of ethical, esthetic or economic reasons.

title: ;  Brotherly Help Brothers are supposed to help each other, and that is exactly what
description: Alexi Grewal, the Olympic gold medalist in cycling, did Sunday with his brother, Ranjeet.

title: Taiwan Says Chinese 'Thugs' Kidnapped a Defector in U.S.
description: Taiwan today accused ''thugs from Peking's consulate in New York'' of having kidnapped a Chinese engineer who defected to the United States in April.

title: Cosmos Triumph
description: The Cosmos, trailing by 3-0 in the first half, came back to beat the Golden Bay Earthquakes, 4-3, tonight on a goal by the forward Chico Borja with .42 remaining in the game. Borja took a pass from Vlado Bogicevic, raced 20 yards and pushed the ball past the the goalkeeper Bill Irwin.

title: 14 DIE IN RIOTS IN BLACK AREAS OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: At least 14 people died today in riots and police counterattacks in five black townships around Johannesburg.

title: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL IN UGANDA FOR TALKS
description: The State Department's principal African expert made an unannounced visit here today for talks with Government and opposition leaders and relief officials.

title: Counting Geese and Ducks
description: People getting ready to hunt migrating geese and ducks this

title: ; Sav-A-Stop Executive Moves From Medi-Mart
description: Philip J. Hiscock has been named president of Sav-A-Stop Inc., a unit of the Consolidated Foods Corporation. The appointment is effective Oct. 1.

title: Chernenko Is Working, Soviet Spokesman Says
description: A spokesman of the Soviet Foreign Ministry said today that Konstantin U. Chernenko was carrying out his official duties but would not say whether the Soviet leader had returned to Moscow.

title: ADVERTISING ; Chrysler and Iacocca Plan One-Month Push
description: Tomorrow the Chrysler Corporation begins a one-month print and television campaign to deliver a message about corporate quality and to advertise the restyled 1985 ''K'' cars - the Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliant.

title: CAUTION IS URGED BY BRAZIL BISHOPS
description: The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Brazil cautioned church members today against being alarmed by the Vatican's criticism of the theology of liberation.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Tuesday

title: I.B.M. Issues Eurobond
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's credit subsidiary is raising $100 million through a three-year Eurobond, priced at 99 3/4 with an 11 3/4 percent coupon, according to Salomon Brothers Inc., the lead manager for the issue. The documentation covering the offering will contain language to safeguard potential investors from any United States tax liability, Salomon Brothers said.

title: 40,000 CROSS MACKINAC BRIDGE IN A LABOR DAY RITUAL
description: Why did 40,000 people cross the bridge?

title: Dollar Hits Highs in Europe
description: The dollar reached record highs against the Italian and British currencies today in thin trading. Gold bullion prices dropped in light trading.

title: DOLPHINS' JENSEN ROLE PLAYER
description: By the 11th round of a National Football League draft, teams are hardly trying to fill a need. By then, most teams take ''the best athlete available,'' which means if he makes the club, the personnel director looks like a genius.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Empire State Building Going Dark for 2 Months

title: British Bid By Citicorp
description: Citicorp said it would acquire a 29.9 percent interest in the company resulting from the merger of Scrimgeour Kemp-Gee and Vickers da Costa, both British brokerages. The move is the latest in a series of links between brokers here and outside institutions, particularly banks.

title: ;  Trottier Concerned
description: Bryan Trottier, the Islander center who is playing with the American team in the Canada Cup series, will return home to Manhasset, L.I., today while his young daughter undergoes neurological testing. Lindsy Ann Trottier, 2 1/2 years old, fell off a backyard swing set 10 days ago and landed on her head.

title: ;  Winslow Warned The San Diego Chargers sent
description: Kellen Winslow a letter yesterday informing the all-pro tight end that if he failed to return to the team within five days, he would be placed on the ''reserve-left squad'' list, which means he would be ineligible to play the rest of the season. Winslow's agent, Jim Steiner, said that because Winslow ''retired,'' the team has no right to put him on such a list.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM: A PREJUDICE THAT TAKES MANY GUISES
description: -Semitism, so much as a variety of anti-Semitisms, recent investigations suggest.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Many of the new women's clothes on the market right now may seem a bit somber because of their mannish tailoring. One way of relieving that is with accessories. If the clothes are dark, the accessories are anything but. At Bloomingdale's there is a wide array of sparkling bracelets, including those by Eric Beamon, made of delicate, iridescent crystals strung on suede, $100, and Roxanne's multicolored rhinestone bangles, $20 each, best worn stacked up the arm.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Rolling Concert

title: MUSIC: SUBLETTE PERFORMS IN 'ART ON THE BEACH' SERIES
description: T HE Battery Park landfill endows Manhattan with a synthetic seashore at the west end of Chambers Street. It was to this incongruous spot that a small group of people came Sunday night to enjoy the placid weather, watch the sun set over New Jersey and - not so incidentally - witness a performance by Ned Sublette, as part of Creative Time's ''Art on the Beach.''

title: NEW TODDLER AT THE ZOO
description: The Daily Plant, a bulletin issued by

title: Plan to Issue Raffle Tickets For Homework Is Withdrawn
description: Barraged by psychologists who complained his idea was crazy, the Interim Superintendent of the Salt Lake City school district has discarded his plan to raffle off an automobile to students who do their homework.

title: A LOOK AT SCHOOLS IN U.S.
description: T HE first thing to say about ''To Save Our Schools, to Save Our Children'' is that it is epic. ABC is presenting the intelligent documentary in the fullness of prime time, 8 to 11 tonight, which suggests both the seriousness of the intention and the importance of the subject. The public schools, Peter Jennings says at the start, are in crisis.

title: TV FILM SET ON TROUBLED LIFE
description: A female physician who spent part of her troubled youth in Oregon reformatories will be the subject of a television movie next year, a CBS producer says.

title: SCOUTING;
description: New Dance Steps

title: Yes, Recovery; Then What?
description: Thanks to

title: Israeli Sees Slow Pullout
description: The Israeli Army's chief engineering officer said in an interview on the Israeli radio today that it would take four to six months to dismantle and remove Israel's military equipment in Lebanon after a decision to withdraw has been made.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Armco and Armco Financial Corp. debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by Standard & Poor's.

title: IS YOUR PLEASURE WINS JEROME
description: Is Your Pleasure, a 25-to-1 shot who had twice finished behind Track Barron this summer, got up in the closing yards to catch his nemesis and win the $181,800 Jerome Handicap for 3-year-olds by three-quarters of a length yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS CHALLENGE
description: Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro opened their fall election campaign together today on sharply contrasting notes. The canyon that is Fifth Avenue in Manhattan was disappointingly spare of spectators when the candidates were there in the morning for a Labor Day parade, but a midday rally in a small town in Wisconsin was ebullient.

title: Stacey Cooper Marries Wade Weiner, Lawyer
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday, Stacey M. Cooper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Cooper of Roslyn Estates, L.I., was married to Wade Weiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Weiner of East Meadow, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein performed the ceremony.

title: EQUAL PAY FOR 'COMPARABLE WORTH' GROWING AS JOB-DESCRIMINATION ISSUE
description: The idea that different jobs can be compared in a way that ''equal pay for equal work'' can become ''equal pay for comparable work'' has become a new ground of battle in the courts, in the legislatures and in the political arena.

title: Business and the Law; Re-Examining Rackets Law
description: WASHINGTON It was a novel legal theory that few guessed

title: 204 From Hijacked Jet Questioned in Baghdad
description: The Red Cross was reported today to have questioned the 204 passengers and crew members of a hijacked Iranian jetliner to determine if they want to return to Iran.

title: PLAN FOR FISH FARM ON WETLANDS IS ASSAILED
description: Environmentalists and some Federal officials have criticized a decision by the state to approve the commercial use of coastal areas to raise shrimp, crayfish and other species.

title: MCENROE AND LLOYD GAIN QUARTERFINALS
description: Robert Green Sr. was as overwhelmed to be in a front row seat at Louis Armstrong Stadium as his son was to be in the fourth round of the United States Open. Mr. Green snapped pictures, saved a tennis ball as a souvenir, prodded Bob Jr. with constant cheering and tentatively introduced himself to John McEnroe Sr., the other proud father at courtside yesterday, although a far more experienced one.

title: BATTLEGROUND IN COLOMBIA: BIRTH CONTROL
description: When Colombia's most outspoken Roman Catholic prelate charged recently that ''global castration'' and ''mutilation'' were taking place here under the guise of ''voluntary sterilizations,'' the country's main family planning association seemed relatively unperturbed.

title: B-1B BOMBER UNVEILED AS PROTOTYPE IS GROUNDED
description: The Rockwell International Corporation rolled out the first production model of its B-1B bomber today while the Air Force announced it was grounding the last B-1A prototype because of a fatal crash last week.

title: WHAT ARCHBISHOP O'CONNOR DIDN'T SAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Protests Rise on Textile Rule
description: Canada, Japan and the Common Market today joined third world textile exporters demanding withdrawal of pending United States regulations they said would cut sales and hurt trade by raising import duties.

title: 'BUT CAN HE HOVER'
description: While he was flying helicopters for the Navy, Phil McConkey was a pro football fan. He and a former Naval Academy teammate, Kit McCulley, would rave about the pro players on the television screen, and then they would ask the crucial question:

title: MEAT COOPERATIVE
description: COMPARED with the Hunts Point produce operation, the nine-year-old Cooperative Market appears to be a paragon of order and cleanliness. Unlike the produce terminal, which is leased from the city by wholesalers, the meat facilities are owned by the cooperative, of which the 36 resident concerns are members. The cooperative itself provides security and maintenance for the 37-acre complex.

title: FORSAKEN VACATION ANIMALS
description: ''THE problem is not so much that people are cruel,'' said Archie Jamgotchian. ''It's just hard to get them to believe that animals have rights too. They're not a commodity you know, to use today and throw away tomorrow.''

title: City Plans to Sell $850 Million Notes
description: New York City said it would sell about $850 million of notes next week through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Investment bankers at Merrill Lynch hope to announce interest rates Monday, they said, but the rates may be adjusted, depending on market conditions.

title: HOMOSEXUAL WEDDINGS STIR DISPUTE
description: For nearly a year, the two dozen parishioners of the Ray of Hope Metropolitan Community Church worshiped in undisturbed tranquillity on Sunday.

title: Sun Savings and Loan In Management Shift
description: After more than a week of bickering, the directors of the Sun Savings and Loan Association avoided a full- scale proxy fight by announcing yesterday that its management had been restructured.

title: Baldwin Doubts Deal's Completion
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said it does not expect to complete the proposed sale of its Empire Savings, Building and Loan Association of Denver to Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. The company said the Federal Home Loan Bank Board did not approve the application filed by Kiewit for the proposed transaction by last Friday, the date specified for termination of the November 1983 agreement.

title: THEATER: 'ELVISMANIA,' PRESLEY YEARS
description: WHEN a singer imitates Elvis Presley, he gambles that nostalgia and the charge of a live performance will make up for rough spots. Johnny Seaton, a Presley imitator based in Washington, is taking that gamble in ''Elvismania,'' at the vest-pocket-sized Off On Broadway theater.

title: ; NOT-SO-BENEFICIENT PENTAGON PORK BARRELS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN COLOMBIA, CONCILIATION
description: As the violence goes on in Central America with no sign of peace in sight, something remarkable is taking place in Colombia, the adjacent country of South America.

title: DODGERS 2, PADRES1;
description: The pinch- hitter Sid Bream lifted a sacrifice fly with the bases loaded and one out in the bottom of the ninth inning to give Los Angeles the victory.

title: TORIES IN CANADA WIN A BIG VICTORY OVER THE LIBERALS
description: The opposition Progressive Conservative Party of Brian Mulroney scored a huge victory over the Liberal Party of Prime Minister John N. Turner today in voting for a new national government.

title: Friends in Adversity TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: The touching article ''Are Friends Still Friends in Adversity?'' (Aug. 29) revealed many searing truths about our affluent society.

title: Fast, Fair Ways to Pick Juries
description: The Federal courts are showing a commendable willingness to experiment with the way juries are selected. That willingness should serve as a model for the state courts of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about plans to donate photographic archives of the George Eastman House in Rochester to the Smithsonian Institution misidentified the director of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. He is Roger G. Kennedy.

title: QADDAFI SAID TO TIGHTEN RULE AS RESISTANCE GROWS
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who on Sunday marked the 15th anniversary of the military coup that brought him to power, appears to have consolidated his hold over the country in the wake of an attempt to topple him last May, according to Western and Arab residents here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This was not a day of Titanic proportions. Maybe just Lusitania.''

title: DELBELLO'S 'SHOTGUN WEDDING' WITH CUOMO IS WORKING OUT
description: When Alfred B. DelBello was the Mayor of Yonkers, he recommended that his job be abolished.

title: American Stores
description: The American Stores Company said its Alpha Beta Company subsidiary had agreed to sell all 33 Alpha Beta grocery stores and one drug store in Arizona to Abco Markets Inc. for about $55 million.

title: Accounts
description: * People for the American Way, a citizens group, to Plapler & Associates.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE subject is onion rings. The narrator is Alan Lapidus. The setting is Mortimer's, the popular Upper East Side restaurant, from where Mr. Lapidus, an architect, filed the following account concerning the establishment's onion-ring policy.

title: FLORIDA GOES TO COURT
description: The biggest news in Florida these days is the investigation of the University of Florida's athletic department by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The inquiry has already led to the resignation of the football coach, Charley Pell , effective at the end of the season.

title: Corporate Debt ;  Preferred Stock
description: Citicorp sold $100 millon of 91-day paper at an average rate of 11.466 percent, up from 11.413 last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 11.413 percent, up from 11.363. Commonwealth Edison Co. 's offering of 400,000 preference shares was won with a bid of $99.039 a share and a dividend rate of 13.25 percent by Prudential-Bache Securities; the shares will be reoffered at par with the 13.25 percent rate.

title: REGAN SAYS MONDALE DEFICIT PLAN WOULD MEAN TAX RISE OF $1,890
description: President Reagan's re-election campaign, speaking through Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, contended today that Walter F. Mondales's goal of cutting the Federal budget deficit by two- thirds would require an average tax rise of $1,890 for every American household.

title: The Gipper or Riggins?
description: The changing of the seasons is

title: Afghan Rebels Say They're Bombing Hotels
description: Afghan rebels said today that they had bombed three hotels and a movie theater in Kabul, in addition to the previously reported blast at the Kabul airport, and they warned of more such attacks in the capital.

title: Rail Agency to Inspect Every Mile of Amtrak
description: The Federal Railroad Administration today began a special safety inspection of the 22,000 miles of railway track used by Amtrak, the Government-owned passenger railroad company that has been involved in several serious accidents recently.

title: THE COSTS OF LIVING LONGER
description: Eliminating diseases such as cancer and heart disease would prolong millions of lives but would also mean burdensome costs to society in caring for the elderly whose lives are extended, a private Washington research group said today.

title: Death Toll in the Philippines Reaches 438 After Typhoon
description: The death toll reached 438 today as relief workers stepped up efforts to reach remote areas where more people may have died in the fiercest storm to hit the Philippines in nearly 15 years.

title: First Choice for New York's Legislature In Tuesday's primary, voters registered in a political party will pick candidates for the New York Legislature to be elected in November. Here we offer our choices in contested New York City races in which primary victory probably means election. All are Democratic contests; there are no serious Republican contests. In making our choices, we give weight to effective incumbents.
description: MANHATTANIn the 28th Senatorial District, Franz Leichter has won our past support, but his opposition to sensible economic development subsidies stops us. We wish he had a better opponent than Harry C. Fotopoulos. In the 30th District, partly in the Bronx, we prefer Olga Mendez to the untested Leroy Ricksy. In the 70th Assembly District, Geraldine Daniels has earned renomination over George Miller, a former Assemblyman.

title: PANEL ASKS ACTION ON ACID RAIN NOW
description: A panel of experts commissioned by President Reagan's Office of Science and Technology today recommended an immediate start on ''cost-effective'' steps to reduce the pollution that causes acid rain.

title: A CONTRAST ON TV
description: By all accounts, fewer than 100,000 people in New York, California and Wisconsin turned out on Labor Day to see the campaign kickoffs of President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale. But an estimated 36 million viewers saw the television coverage of those events on the evening news shows of the three major commercial networks. What they saw, Monday night and in the news shows this morning, was an upbeat portrayal of Mr. Reagan alongside portrayals of Mr. Mondale as a candidate still struggling to recapture his political vitality.

title: TOLL IS 29
description: South African authorities said today that they had briefly called in army units to guard Government offices in one black township after a wave of rioting, looting and arson in black areas around here on Monday.

title: Italy Increases Discount Rate
description: Italy raised its official discount rate today to 16 1/2 percent from 15 1/2 percent in an effort to curb strong domestic demand for loans and to keep inflation in check.

title: FILM: 'PICTURES,' A VIEW OF POVERTY IN AMERICA
description: OUT of 100,000 miles of hitchhiking across the United States, out of 3,000 photographs, out of myriad adventures in a five-year odyssey in the 1970's, a Danish self-styled vagabond named Jacob Holdt has fashioned a visually powerful examination of America's impoverished. Part I of his compilation, titled ''American Pictures'' and based on a slide show, opens today for a two-week run at the Film Forum.

title: HEATING OIL PRICES EXPECTED TO REMAIN LOW
description: As hints of autumn turn attention to fuel bills, energy experts have good news for consumers of heating oil: Prices are far below last winter's peak and are expected to rise little, if at all, in the coming heating season.

title: ROBOT ARM KNOCKS TROUBLESOME ICE OFF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Reaching back with a long robotic arm, the crew of the space shuttle Discovery knocked a troublesome chunk of ice off the side of the orbiting craft today to clear the way for the conclusion of a six-day mission in space.

title: '84 ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS IN CHELSEA
description: The artists of Chelsea are taking time out from their studios this month to let their neighbors and everybody else know what they have been up to.

title: THE PRESENCE AND AIMS OF A STAR, JAMES BROWN
description: UNIFORMED waiters corked wine bottles and emptied ashtrays in the New York Hilton's penthouse suite, emphasizing with their practiced, soundless gestures the stillness that had descended with the departure of most of the afternoon's guests. It was the week of the annual New Music Seminar, and publicity agents from record companies large and small were ensconced in various suites and meeting rooms, entertaining producers, managers, musicians and other professionals involved in the dance-music and new-wave rock fields.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
TAKEOVER TALK AND MOBIL
description: WANT to buy an oil company? In the case of the Mobil Corporation, it would only cost $20 billion or so.

title: Plane Crash in Idaho Kills 4
description: Two couples from northern California were killed in a light plane that crashed and burst into flames Monday in central Idaho's wilderness, the authorities said today. The Valley County coroner, Marvin Heikkila, said all four victims were pilots. They were apparently flying out of the area when the Cessna Centurion 210 crashed in the forest two miles east of Indian Creek.

title: CARNATION: A FAMILY COMPANY'S EVOLUTION
description: With its proposed $3 billion offer for the Carnation Company, Nestle S.A. would be acquiring a strong, though largely mature, company.

title: A VARIETY OF FACTORS AFFECT PRODUCE PRICES
description: -coaster world of produce pricing, as any shopper knows. A lot happens between the time a seed is planted and the consumer purchases a ripe product at the greengrocer's or supermarket.

title: NEW FRENCH PROGRAM: TALE MUCH LIKE 'DALLAS'
description: For nearly a year, a French television crew and several dozen actors have been traveling daily to the rolling countryside of wheat fields and stone villages about 25 miles southwest of Paris. There, they are making an already vaguely familiar program that they expect will be the European television sensation of the coming year.

title: Quota Plan For Steel Criticized
description: A diverse group of manufacturers, farmers, retailers and port workers has called on President Reagan to reject a package of quotas and tariffs intended to protect the steel industry from foreign competition.

title: METS TROUNCED: 17 HITS FOR CARDS
description: This was a sour night for the Mets in their quest for the National League East title. They lost to the Cardinals, 12-2, allowing as many runs as they have in a game all season and as many hits, 17, as they have all season. And when it was all over, they were seven games behind the Cubs, who won again in Philadelphia.

title: A YANK BREAKS TRADITION IN BURGUNDY
description: MEURSAULT,France

title: CITY OPERA 'MIKADO' ASSEMBLES
description: The mighty troops of Titipu, before whom we shouldn't be surprised if nations trembled, will file in serried ranks assembled across the New York State Theater stage tomorrow evening. Opening night nerves notwithstanding, they'll never quail (or they'll conceal it if they do). If any of the foregoing is the least obscure, you aren't a Gilbert and Sullivan addict - but the New York City Opera is about to give you a chance to become one.

title: COMPUTER CONSORTIUM LAGS
description: A collaborative effort by American computer companies, mobilized to head off the Japanese attack on the critical high-technology markets of the 1990's, has gotten off to a rocky start.

title: Man Is Indicted In Slayings of 4
description: A former insurance salesman was indicted today on eight counts of capital felony in New London Superior Court in connection with the slayings of four young women in New London County.

title: Hearst Plans to Add Diversion Magazines
description: The Hearst Corporation is about to acquire Diversion Communications and add its magazines for physicians to its existing business publication titles such as Floor Covering Weekly, Integrated Circuits and Today's Office.

title: RALLY BY BLUE JAYS OVERCOMES YANKS
description: The Yankees, who have hopes of leapfrogging past Toronto into second place, played a game of leapfrog with the Blue Jays at the Stadium last night. The Blue Jays, though, took the last leap and won the game, 6-4.

title: Plane Crashes in England
description: A Canadian cargo plane crash-landed on the runway during an international airshow today, and all three men on board walked away uninjured, show organizers said.

title: Tough General Is Head Of Bangkok Garrison
description: The Thai Government announced its annual military shuffle Monday. Prominent in the announcement was the news that the new commander of the army's Bangkok region is a supporter of Gen. Arthit Kamlang-ek, Thailand's Supreme Commander, who has lately been moving to extend and strengthen his political power.

title: Hospital Concerns In Takeover Accord
description: The Hospital Corporation of America plans to acquire the Health Resources Corporation of America in a deal valued at about $330 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: Nicaraguan Officials Arrive In Rome for Talks at Vatican
description: A Nicaraguan Government delegation arrived in Rome today for meetings with Vatican officials in an an effort to improve strained relations with the Holy See.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Wednesday about support for Walter F. Mondale from the League of Conservation Voters misstated the league's relationship with the Natural Resources Defense Council. The council does not have a political arm and does not engage in electoral politics. Its role is discussed further today in the Briefing column, on page B6.

title: NEW ROCKET PROPOSED FOR MILITARY SATELLITES
description: A panel of experts assembled by the National Research Council said today that the space shuttle could not provide as much ''flexibility and security'' for launching military satellites as could a dual system of re-usable shuttles and expendable rockets.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN discussions about cooking with

title: 7 Die in German Bus Crash
description: Seven West Berliners were killed today and 19 were injured after a collision between their double- decker bus and an oncoming truck. The police said the vehicles had sideswiped each other on a rainswept road near here, east of Bielefeld. The bus skidded into a tree and toppled onto its side.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HUNTS POINT MARKET: A WORLD OF FOOD IN THE BRONX
description: EVERY time someone in the Greater New York area bites into a banana (one of 386 million pounds every year), slices an onion (one of 171 million pounds) or broils a steak (one of about 500 million pounds), he or she represents the final link in a long, bafflingly complex yet amazingly efficient chain of events that brings food from distant farms and ranches to the collective metropolitan table. Chances are the typical consumer is unaware of how the system works. That is how it should be if everything is rolling smoothly, as it almost always is in one of the world's largest food markets and surely the most multifarious.

title: On the Record ; Reagan on Religion
description: From remarks in Salt Lake City yesterday to the American Legion, as distributed by The Associated Press:

title: WASTED WIND POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: PISTONS KEEP PAIR
description: Kelly Tripucka and Vinnie Johnson , the Detroit free agents who last month signed lucrative offer sheets with rival teams, returned happily to the Piston fold.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Jackson, Miss., Voters Back Council of Wards
description: Voters approved a referendum today to replace the city's government of two commissioners and a mayor with a mayor-council form in which council members would be elected from wards instead of at large. It is a change that proponents said could give this city its first black elected officials in 72 years.

title: WITHOUT COSELL, IT'S NO SHOW
description: It wasn't exactly the voice of the turtle being heard in the land, as

title: A CORRECTION: ON JOBS
description: On Labor Day, we contrasted the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s loss of two million members in the past five years with a large rise in total employment. The civilian labor force actually grew eight million in those years, not, as we erroneously reported, 25 million. Organized labor is losing ground, absolutely and relatively, but we overstated the contrast.

title: Required Reading; Setting the Stage
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, writing about political action committees in the summer issue of The Journal of Legislation:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Main Courses to GoA gourmet takeout shop with a different touch is Call Cuisine, at 1032 First Avenue (56th Street). The shop, which has been there for two years, specializes in main courses. On a given day as many as a dozen or more are on an impressive list that includes such wonderful old standbys as boeuf Bourguignonne and blanquette de veau.

title: REBUILDING OFFICES DOWNTOWN
description: SO much office space is becoming available in lower Manhattan through the construction of large buildings and the relocation of large tenants that some operators in the downtown market are taking steps to protect their positions in older buildings. The situation consists of these elements:

title: Long-Distance Dialing
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly described the extent to which long-distance telephone users can connect with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company if they have selected an alternative carrier under equal access. By dialing a special code, long-distance customers will be able to have their calls bypass their selected carrier and be carried on A.T.& T. By selecting other long-distance company codes, they can similarly bypass their selected carrier and gain access to other companies as well.

title: CORRECTION
description: On Labor Day, we contrasted the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s loss of two million members in the past five years with a large rise in total employment. The civilian labor force actually grew eight million in those years, not, as we erroneously reported, 25 million. Organized labor is losing ground, absolutely and relatively, but we overstated the contrast.

title: SPAIN, WORRIED BY MOROCCO PACT, WARMS TO NATO
description: The announcement of a treaty of union between Morocco and Libya, including a mutual defense accord, has raised Spanish concerns about the military balance in the Strait of Gibraltar and intensified Government efforts to stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Atwood Richards Inc. , a corporate barter company, has named Robert E. Levitan vice president of product remarketing.

title: MARCH OF TIME
description: Chris Schenkel, the veteran ABC broadcaster, will work his first Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini fight Saturday, when the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion begins a comeback against Kenny (Bang Bang) Bogner in New Orleans. But Schenkel has known Mancini for 16 years, from the time he was a guest speaker at a tribute in Youngstown, Ohio, to the fighter's father, the original Boom Boom, Lenny Mancini.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Recalled Wes Gardner, relief pitcher, and Kevin Mitchell, third baseman, from Tidewater of the International League. Purchased the contract of John Christensen, outfielder, from Tidewater, and planned to activate him when room can be made on 40-man roster. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Ozzie Smith, shortstop, was suspended for seven days and fined a reported $5,000 by the National League for bumping and knocking down Umpire Steve Rippley in a game last Saturday night, but Smith's appeal will allow him to remain eligible to play. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Retained services of Kelly Tripucka, forward, and Vinnie Johnson, guard, by matching offer sheets. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Joe Pellegrini, free-agent offensive lineman, and two running backs, Rodney Tate and Cliff Austin. Placed Richard Williams, running back, Dave Levenick, linebacker; and Dan Dufour, center, on injured reserve. BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed John Mistler, wide receiver, a former Giant. Waived Joey Smith, wide receiver. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Don Laster, a free-agent offensive tackle. LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Acquired Booker Reese, defensive end, from Tampa Bay, and Put Gordon Jones, wide receiver. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Re-signed Terry Echols, rookie linebacker, and placed Calvin Sweeney, wide receiver, on the injured reserve list. COLLEGES ST. JOSEPH'S - Named Jim Van Blunk assistant cross-country and track coach. MIAMI, Fla. - Bill Diaz, swimming coach, announced retirement as of Dec. 1.

title: Folk Artist Fellows
description: Ford's Theater will be the setting

title: Reader's Digest Closing Subsidiary in Spain
description: The Reader's Digest Association said it would close its subsidiary in Spain with the June 1985 issue.

title: JAMAICA' ECONOMIC STRUGGLE
description: In many small grocery stores here these days, customers cannot buy a pound of flour unless they also buy some canned goods or perhaps some detergent.

title: Preparation for the Dance
description: Leaning on the piano, the two teachers scanned 3-by-5 cards and conversed animatedly.

title: Utility Loan Bid in Indiana
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana today asked the State Public Service Commission to approve an agreement allowing the company to borrow up to $320 million.

title: SYRIANS PUT PRESSURE ON LEBANESE GROUPS TO REACH AN ACCORD
description: Syria seems to be bringing increasing pressure on the divided Lebanese Government to make peace, although no results were evident at today's Cabinet meeting.

title: THE REFUTED FEARS ABOUT OFFSHORE DRILLING
description: To the Editor:

title: HARDING ATTACKS FOES IN LIBERAL PARTY BATTLE
description: Raymond B. Harding, the deposed Liberal Party leader, raised the possibility yesterday that ''incompetence'' by his foes in the party could jeopardize the party's nomination of Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro for President and Vice President.

title: Massey, in Shift, Reports a Profit
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the agricultural equipment company, said today that it earned $7.4 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of $11.3 million a year earlier.

title: American General
description: The American General Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its Guardsman Life Insurance Company unit to Integrated Resources Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: KING'S TURN NOW
description: During the second half of last season, there was much discussion over who was the National Basketball Association's most valuable player - Bernard King of the Knicks or Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics. In the end, the vote was split.

title: GOING HAMMER AND TONGS FOR SMALL BUSINESS
description: Relatively few of his constituents know the job he does for them, and fewer still know his name. Yet Frank S. Swain, a 33-year-old lawyer from Corning, N.Y., may be the best friend the nation's 14 million small businesses ever had in Washington.

title: U.S. FINES DIGITAL $1.5 MILLION
description: The Commerce Department announced today that it had fined the Digital Equipment Corporation, a leading American computer company, $1.5 million for export law violations that may have allowed the Soviet Union to obtain one or two of its computers. It was the largest monetary penalty ever imposed for export violations.

title: Morris Helprin, 79, Is Dead; A Movie Company Executive
description: Morris Helprin, one of the first film executives to sell first-run movies to television, died Monday in Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: U.S. YOUTH GAIN
description: The United States youth national soccer team advanced to the semifinals of the North American-Central American-Caribbean regional youth championships by defeating Trinidad-Tobago, 1-0, Monday night in Port of Spain, Trinidad.

title: Army Reactivates Unit Of the Green Berets
description: A 776-man Green Beret unit was reactivated here today, the first to be called back into service since the Vietnam War, and the Army's Special Operations commander said the unit was needed now more than ever.

title: Moslem Group Asserts It Is Holding Reporter
description: A group calling itself the Moslem Socialist Revolutionary Organization said today that it was holding Jonathan Wright, a Reuters correspondent who disappeared in Lebanon six days ago.

title: Owens-Illinois Diversifying Owens-Illinois Inc. said it
description: had agreed to acquire all the

title: Chinese Textile Modernizing PEKING, Sept. 4 (AP) -
description: China plans to invest $425 million to modernize its textile industry in the 1985-87 period, the

title: FRIENDS IN ADVERSITY
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ONE MORE TIME
description: Team tennis, an idea whose time had not yet come a decade ago, is being tried again, but in league with other sports ownerships. Billie Jean King, whose playing career consists now mostly of doubles, is devoting most of her energies to developing a successor to World Team Tennis, which collapsed in 1978 after five money-losing seasons.

title: 2 Major Cities Avert Strikes by Teachers By The Associated Press
description: The number of teachers on strike rose to about 7,000 in six states outside the New York metropolitan area yesterday, disrupting school for more than 100,000 students, but major walkouts were averted in San Francisco and at least temporarily in Chicago when educators reported for class preparations despite expired contracts.

title: Transamerica
description: The Pacific First Federal Savings Bank said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the mortgage banking unit of the Transamerica Financial Services Group.

title: Police Seek Bullet In I-95 Shooting
description: A dozen state police officers searched the westbound side of Interstate 95 here today for the bullet fired at a Bridgeport couple from a passing van on Monday.

title: FEW USE PHILADELPHIA TUNNEL ON 1ST DAY
description: For months the tracks through a yawning 1.7-mile tunnel waited for today and the first regular trains to run into the new Market Street East Station, a cavern of stainless steel and sparkling red tile.

title: USE OF U.S. MERCENARIES IS TERMED LIMITED
description: In the last few years a number of American civilians have taken part in military activities in Central America, paramilitary experts said today, but the experts said they knew of no concerted effort to recruit American mercenaries or to use them extensively in the region.

title: U.S. EXPECTS TO END MINESWEEPING IN 10 DAYS
description: State Department officials said today that the United States would probably complete its minesweeping operations in the Gulf of Suez and the Red Sea in about 10 days and leave the area.

title: BRIDGE: AFTER A SUIT FIT IS LEARNED, SHOULD ANOTHER SUIT BE BID?
description: Once a fit in a suit has been uncovered, it is not normally necessary to bid another suit. Asked what such a bid means, a simple player will probably give a quick simple answer: ''Cue-bid, showing control and suggesting a slam.''

title: REAGAN REASSERTS VIEWS ON RELIGION
description: President Reagan defended his view of religion and politics today, denying that he favored a state religion or mandatory prayers in public school.

title: On Amniocentesis TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: I am the obstetrician quoted in the first paragraph of the article entitled ''Amniocentesis: On the Increase'' (Aug. 22) as having ''performed amniocentesis quite frequently on women much younger'' than age 34.

title: FEEBLE EXCUSES
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.

title: ELEGANCE OF ONSHORE DINING ABOARD A 19-FOOT MOTORBOAT
description: FOR some reason, the idea of serving food aboard a small boat seems daunting to many otherwise imaginative cooks. At least that is the conclusion I've come to in my limited experience aboard friends' pleasure craft, where often as not the menu consisted of cold cuts and pimento cheese sandwiches.

title: A Matter of Tax Law
description: The League of Conservation

title: NCR OFFERS NEW PERSONAL COMPUTER
description: The NCR Corporation, whose personal computer has not sold well, introduced a second personal computer, which uses the same electronic brain used in the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer. The new machine is thus able to run many of the popular business programs, written for the I.B.M. machine, including 1-2-3 Lotus and dBase II, NCR said.

title: BROOKLYN GRAND JURY FINDS FRAUD IN 8 PRIMARIES
description: A Brooklyn grand jury investigating election fraud has found that eight primary elections in the borough between 1968 and 1982 were marked by repeated fraud, including multiple voting by teams of political workers with fake voter registration cards.

title: COINTREAU TELLING ITS LOVE STORY
description: AFTER an unusually long incubation period, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners is preparing to give birth this month to its first advertising for Cointreau, the orange liqueur from France that is No. 1 worldwide but on the border of Never Never Land in the United States.

title: Belgian Jobless Rate Up
description: Belgium's unemployment in August rose eight-tenths of 1 percent from July to a record rate of 12.5 percent, the Government said today. It said 523,776 people were jobless at the end of August, up by 4,285 from July.

title: Holder Makes Bid for Ameriwest
description: The Ameriwest Financial Corporation said it had received an offer from James E. Sowell, a shareholder, to acquire the company for $19.50 a share, or about $40 million. The company said it had also been informed by Mr. Sowell that he currently owns 9.4 percent of the company.

title: Armco Will Cut 170 Office Jobs
description: Armco Inc. will eliminate 170 jobs at its general offices here as part of a move to make the steelmaker profitable, its chairman, Harry Holiday, said. He said that the jobs, now held by clerical, managerial and engineering employees, would be eliminated between now and December through retirements, transfers, dismissals and some resignations.

title: LACK OF STANDARDS AND CONTROLS IN JERSEY ASBESTOS PROBLEM
description: The opening of public schools in New Jersey this month has been marked by confusion and apprehension as dozens of school districts that have decided to remove or cover asbestos during the summer prepare to reopen their buildings.

title: NESTLE PLANNING TO PAY $3 BILLION TO ACQUIRE CARNATION COMPANY
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss food conglomerate, will buy the Carnation Company, the Los Angeles-based dairy and foods company, for about $3 billion, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: 71 Wounded by Bomb At Ulster Train Station
description: A car containing explosives blew up today near a railroad station in the border town of Newry, wounding 71 people in a spray of splintered glass and debris, the police said.

title: ARTHUR SCHWARTZ, COMPOSER OF BROADWAY SHOWS, IS DEAD
description: Arthur Schwartz, a composer who helped bring a new sophistication to Broadway songwriting in the 1930's, with such tunes as ''Dancing in the Dark,'' and ''You and the Night and the Music,'' died Monday at his home in Kintnersville, Pa., after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old.

title: CHILE PROTESTERS CHASED BY POLICE
description: Riot policemen attacked 300 demonstrators singing the national anthem in Santiago's main square today. The French Embassy said a French priest had been found shot to death during the day of anti-Government protests.

title: Building Activity Rises 0.7%
description: The level of new construction edged up seven-tenths of 1 percent in July as work on apartment and office buildings continued at a strong pace, the Government reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about consumers' need to choose a long-distance telephone company incorrectly described some aspects of the choice. A corrective article appears today on page

title: CONGRESS RETURNS TODAY IN HOPES OF CLEARING WORK
description: The nation's lawmakers will return Wednesday for what they predict will be a bitterly partisan, four-week session that is intended to conclude the work of the 98th Congress.

title: SCIENCE JOBS FOR WOMEN
description: LAURIE ALTMAN is a scientist with

title: CONTICOMMODITY BEING SOLD TO REFCO
description: The Continental Grain Company, apparently tired of mounting losses from Conticommodity Services Inc., its futures brokerage subsidiary, announced yesterday that the unit would be sold to Refco Inc., another Chicago-based brokerage that specializes in futures.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: 'IN A DARK TIME' War, peace and heroism are the subjects of the sentences, paragraphs and poems in the book ''In a Dark Time,'' edited by Robert Jay Lifton, a psychiatrist, and Nicholas Humphrey, a psychologist.

title: AMERICAN HELD AS WITNESS IN MONTREAL BOMBING
description: A 65- year-old American was ordered held without bond today as a material witness in the bombing of a Montreal rail station that killed 3 people and wounded 41.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Canada Products Ltd., a unit of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., said it had signed a conditional agreement to buy the assets of the plastics division of Westroc Industries Ltd. of Ontario. Terms were not disclosed.

title: DISAPPOINTED TRAVEL INDUSTRY CLOSES BOOK ON SUMMER SEASON
description: The American travel industry is closing the books on a sluggish and disappointing summer season that began with expectations that a robust economy and falling gasoline prices would help the vacation business outperform its record in recent recession-wracked years.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE CROWDED EARTH: People and

title: Another Opening, Another No-Show
description: Politicians were quick to note yesterday that Mayor Koch, after failing to march with Walter F. Mondale in the Labor Day parade, failed to attend the opening of Mondale-for- President headquarters at 369 Lexington Avenue.

title: CHIEF DEPARTING WARNER-LAMBERT
description: Ward S. Hagan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Warner-Lambert Company since 1978, said yesterday that he would retire next June, when he reaches 65. He will remain a member of the board after his retirement, Warner-Lambert said.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The Washington Redskins have signed the eight-year veteran running back Rick Kane , who was released by the Detroit Lions last week. . . . The Tampa Bay Bucaneers traded the defensive lineman Booker Reese to the Los Angeles Rams for a draft choice. Reese, a 6-foot-6-inch, 260-pounder, was a second-round pick of the Bucs in 1982. . . . Onix Concepcion, the Kansas City shortstop out since Aug. 10 with a broken hand, has been restored to the Royals' active roster.. . . The St. Louis pitcher Bob Forsch , idled since June by back surgery, has been activated from the 60-day disabled list.

title: I.B.M. AIDS MILACRON IN TOOL MOVE
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc., one of the nation's largest machine-tool manufacturers, said today that it would begin marketing the first machine-tool control system that uses the I.B.M. Personal Computer. The system is expected to make it easier to program machine tools to cut, drill or shape metal.

title: WHIMSICAL NECKTIES
description: 1.*Rhinestone Cravat e Benard, Adrienne Vittadini, Betty Hanson, Pierre Cardin and Ellen Tracy. 4.*Fragrance of Roses

title: A Reunion in Mt. Vernon
description: The children who used to hang

title: Hertz Picks Ogilvy
description: The Hertz Corporation has named Ogilvy & Mather Direct to handle all of its direct-response marketing. The previous agency was Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct Response. Scali remains Hertz's advertising agency.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1984 International The Progressive Conservatives won a huge victory over the governing Liberal Party in voting for a new Canadian Government. With nearly all the results in, the Tories led by Brian Mulroney were elected or leading in 190 of the 282 districts nationwide, the Liberals of Prime Minister John N. Turner in 39, the New Democratic Party in 24 and an independent in one. In terms of vote percentage, the Tories had 49 percent, the Liberals 28 percent, the New Democrats 20 percent and others 2 percent. Mr. Mulroney won in his own district in Quebec. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ties between the two Germanys have warmed at a time of strained relations between Washington and Moscow. But Erich Honecker, the East German leader, put off a visit to West Germany he had been expected to make at the end of this month. The postponement, which West Germany said it regretted, appeared to be the result of Soviet pressure. (A1:2.)

title: CEY DRIVES IN 3 AS CUBS WIN
description: Scott Sanderson scattered 13 hits in posting his first victory since July 29 and Ron Cey drove in three runs with a homer and single tonight to lead the surging Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: BUSH, AT TEXAS A&M, BACKS PRESIDENT ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Vice President Bush today defended President Reagan's record on arms control and assailed Walter F. Mondale, saying the Administration, unlike Mr. Mondale, was ''not going to give up the store'' to achieve an agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: CAPT. H. R. BISHOP, EX-HEAD OF NEW YORK MARITIME OFFICE
description: Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, a shipping expert who was Atlantic Coast director of the Maritime Administration, died of hepatitis Sunday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Oakdale, L.I.

title: MORTALITY RATE CREATES MYSTERY
description: Six years after he had won an Olympic gold medal, a Soviet basketball player, Aleksandr Belov, died at the age of 27. Four years after his gold medal in ice hockey, Viktor Blinov died at the age of 23.

title: 3 Kentucky Guards Injured
description: Three guards were injured today in a disturbance involving dozens of inmates at the Northpoint Training Center, prison officials said. Some prisoners also were hurt, but Cecil Brammer, a prison official, said he could not give a number. About 70 inmates were involved in the melee, but Mr. Brammer could give few details of what started the disturbance.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Monday about a wedding omitted the first name of Mark David Lewis's bride. She is the former Linda Hope Harris.

title: Michigan General Talking to Suitor
description: A unit of General Felt Industries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is involved in negotiations with the Michigan General Corporation aimed at acquiring control of the company. The unit, GFI Nevada Inc., said it already holds 1,648,200 Michigan General common shares, or 14.5 percent of the total outstanding.

title: MONDALE SAYS REAGAN RAISED TAXES OF THE POOR
description: Walter F. Mondale, saying he was ''damned mad'' at President Reagan's tax policies, accused the Administration today of substantially increasing taxes for Americans earning less than $10,000 and providing tax relief for the wealthy.

title: DR. HAROLD A. LYONS, SPECIALIST IN TREATING PULMONARY DISEASE
description: Dr. Harold Aloysius Lyons, who conducted research in pulmonary physiology and developed new diagnostic and therapeutic techniques, died Aug. 26 at Lake Placid Memorial Hospital after suffering a heart attack while on vacation. He was 71 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: New British Coal Talks Are Called Off
description: A new initiative to end Britain's 25- week-old coal strike collapsed today, but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher rejected demands to recall Parliament from its summer recess to help break the deadlock.

title: RUSH-HOUR DRIVERS ARE BACK AND CITY ROADS ARE JAMMED
description: From the desk of the Traffic Commissioner, New York City, the day after Labor Day, 1984:

title: DRUG-COMBAT DOLLARS WAGING OTHER WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Mop to Canvas
description: ''I spent a whole year fantasizing

title: WINE TALK
description: PETER MORRELL, a respected wine merchant of many year's standing in New York, wrote to take issue with some points in a column earlier this month on Windsor Vineyards, which sells wine to consumers through mail order.

title: PLEA DELAYS SMITH'S BAN
description: knocking down Umpire Steve Rippley in a game last Saturday night.

title: 2 NICARAGUANS DEAD IDENTIFIED AS U.S. VETERANS
description: Two Americans killed when their helicopter was shot down in Nicaragua on Saturday were identified by associates today as Vietnam veterans and members of an anti-Communist group formed to assist the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: WEST GERMANS TIE CZECHS
description: Peter Rosol scored on a deflection with 1 minute 36 seconds remaining tonight to allow heavily favored Czechoslovakia to gain a 4-4 tie with West Germany in the second round of the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

title: INSURANCE COSTS FOR SATELLITES IS GOING UP, COMPANIES FIND
description: Companies with satellites to send into orbit are finding that the cost of insuring them is going sky high as well.

title: NEW G.O.P. POLICIES ON NEWS ASSAILED
description: Editors of the country's two major news services said today that rules put into effect over the weekend by the campaigns of President Reagan and Vice President Bush would deprive the public of full coverage of the candidates' statements and activities.

title: Suspect Seized In Rape of Girl, 4
description: A suspect in the rape of a 4-year-old Queens girl was taken into custody late last night, the police reported.

title: POT FOR USE AND BEAUTY
description: COOKWARE generally falls into two categories: utensils that are strictly functional and those that also serve as showpieces, items that are so attractively designed they can be brought to the table for serving. The heavy- gauge copper casserole pictured here, called a bassine a rago^ut in France, falls into the latter category.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Rise Modestly
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday in quiet trading, as major investors remained on the sidelines and traders were cautious in the face of rising short-term rates.

title: Dayton-Hudson Officer Plans to Leave Posts
description: Richard L. Schall, vice chairman and chief administrative officer of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, said yesterday that he intended to retire from those positions on Feb. 1.

title: WHERE JOY SPRINGS VIRTUALLY ETERNAL
description: ''If anybody has moonshine you kin leave it with me, and we don't want no gerrymanderin' or ballyhooin' even if it is an election year. And there'll be no gun fightin' or knife playin' and no gamblin.' ''

title: THE NATIONAL DRINK IN MEXICO: BRANDY
description: IN the courtyard of a hacienda a

title: ISRAELI TALKS SEEM TO REACH ACCORD
description: The Labor Party and the Likud bloc appeared tonight to have agreed on a bipartisan government after a day of talks in the Parliament building.

title: Business Digest; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1984
description: The Companies

title: East Germany Cries Nyet
description: Who knows what Soviet threats and bribes finally made Erich Honecker cancel his trip to West Germany this month. Angling to become the first East German leader to visit Bonn, he absorbed incredible abuse all summer. His persistence must have made the Soviet leaders feel that their imperial writ was on the line. And in a sense, that made it so: The big news is not that Mr. Honecker has buckled but that he was left free so long to think he didn't have to.

title: AOUITA WINNER OF 1,500 AT PARIS
description: Said Aouita, the Olympic 5,000-meter champion from Morocco, won the 1,500-meter run at an international track meet tonight.

title: Celentano's Agency
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss has been named the agency of record for the whole line of Italian frozen foods produced by Celentano Brothers of Verona, N.J. The account, previously at Gianettino & Meredith, is expected to bill almost $1.5 million from Sept. 1, 1984, through Aug. 31, 1985.

title: U.P.I. CHIEFS, PRUDENTIAL IN A PACT WITH COMSAT
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation, moving to bolster its entry into satellite-to-home television broadcasting, said today that it had reached preliminary agreements to take on as partners the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the owners of United Press International.

title: RUSSIANS PLEASED BY ALLY'S DECISION
description: The Soviet press took no notice today of reports that Erich Honecker, the East German leader, had put off a visit to West Germany, just as the Russians had not reported his plans to begin with.

title: Two Men Die of Bee Stings
description: A swarm of bees attacked and killed a 51-year-old man in his yard, Louis Loepker, the Clinton County Coroner, said today.

title: JETS AWAIT THE NEXT CHALLENGE
description: The Colts trailed by only 2 points, 16-14, and had possession of the ball in the closing minutes of the game Sunday in Indianapolis. And yet some of the Jets in the defensive huddle were grinning.

title: HE SAYS HE ATE IT
description: Tim Bennett and his brother Steve say they believe Otis Broom, and so does Thomas Hoffman, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Thomaston, Ga. ''Otis Broom is a trustworthy man, a man of integrity,'' Mr. Hoffman advises. ''If he says he caught the fish, I'm sure he did.''

title: RAMS TAKE GAMBLE ON OPTION AND LOSE
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: CONTINENTAL RESCUE: RISKS THE F.D.I.C. WASN'T MEANT TO INSURE
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIMBABWE FREES A FORMER PREMIER
description: The Government today released a former Prime Minister after 10 months of detention. But it warned that he could be detained again if he involved himself in activities the Government deemed subversive.

title: HIJACKED IRANIANS FLY HOME
description: Two hundred Iranians returned home today after a weeklong stay in Baghdad where they were flown on a hijacked jetliner. Six others, including the hijackers, stayed behind.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Watery Lottery
description: Everyone who's seen or heard the weekend news knows that the Illinois State Lottery just paid $40 million to a Chicago printer. Or did it? Yes, Michael Wittkowski did win the jackpot. But if properly computed, his ''$40 million'' prize is worth only about $8 million.

title: Senator Wins in Alabama As Four States Vote By United Press International
description: Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama won the Democratic nomination today for a second term, while Republican primary voters gave an early lead to former United States Representative Albert Lee Smith over three opponents for the right to face Mr. Heflin in the fall.

title: OFFICIALS WITHDRAW FROM TRIBECA SUIT
description: Two Manhattan officials have withdrawn from a legal challenge to a computer center that Shearson Lehman/American Express plans to build on the western edge of TriBeCa. Three community groups remain in the suit, which is scheduled to be heard on Sept. 17.

title: HONECKER DROPS HIS PLAN TO VISIT WEST GERMANY
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, today put off a visit to West Germany that had been expected at the end of the month. The postponement, which West Germany said it regretted, appeared to be the result of Soviet pressure.

title: THE NONISSUE: PROTECTIONISM
description: WITH the race for the White House in full stride, the candidates are assailing each other on taxes, spending, budget deficits, unemployment and every other economic issue but one - protectionism in trade. There, both candidates are yielding to the pressures of special interest groups in ways extremely costly to consumers and dangerous to the national and world economy.

title:
TV REVIEW;
WNBC LOOKS AT A LUNCHEONETTE IN BENSONHURST
description: EVERY New York neighborhood should have a Chookie's; some of them even do. In the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn it is, or was (the future is unclear) at 7818 New Utrecht Avenue, near the corner of 79th Street, under the el. New Utrecht High School students hang out there, and it is the subject of a small gem in local programming - ''They're Selling Chookie's,'' on Channel 4 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: BURFORD ASSERTS SHE GOT PURGE LIST
description: The White House in 1981 sent the Environmental Protection Agency a list of career officials that a leading business organization wanted purged from the agency, according to a document made public recently by a House investigating subcommittee.

title: PHONY DOCTOR GETS 6-MONTH SENTENCE
description: A Merrick beautician was sentenced today to six months in jail after admitting in Nassau County Court that he had posed as a doctor.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT is common experience, when

title: 18 BISHOPS URGE A PUBLIC DEBATE ON ABORTION
description: Eighteen Roman Catholic bishops from four New England states today entered the debate on religion and politics by calling abortion ''the critical issue of the moment'' and saying that it must be in the forefront of public debate.

title: ART: MAX BECKMANN SHOW OPENING IN ST. LOUIS
description: ST.LOUIS

title: WARD FEARS FALL IN POLICE MORALE BECAUSE OF TEST
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that morale was likely to decline among New York City police officers, regardless of how the city dealt with a sergeants examination in which a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic officers failed.

title: BAT SQUABBLE RESOLVED
description: The National League cleared the Phillies' Al Oliver of accusations that he used a corked bat in Monday's loss to the Chicago Cubs at Philadelphia. The bat had been taken out of the game after Oliver hit a double with it in the seventh inning, and at first the home-plate umpire, Bruce Froemming , gave it to Manager Paul Owens of the Phillies for safekeeping.

title: ROYALS TOP TWINS, TRIM LEAD TO ONE
description: Mark Gubicza scattered seven hits over eight and two-thirds innings and Frank White drove in the go-ahead run as the Kansas City Royals defeated Minnesota, 4-3, tonight to pull within a game of the division-leading Twins in the American West.
