title: Woman Wins Bias Suit Over Honor Society
description: A student who was dismissed from a high school honor society after becoming pregnant was a victim of sex discrimination and should be reinstatdd, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: GOLDEN ARMS, LEADEN READINESS
description: When Congress reconvenes today, it will face major decisions on the largest peacetime defense budget request in recent American history. In doing so, it must address the deeply unsettling question: have taxpayers received the improved defense and improved combat readiness that they have paid for - and been promised - over the past four years?

title: WHY NOT DEBATE THE ISSUES?
description: WASHINGTON President Reagan and Walter Mondale agree on at least one thing. This is, as the President said in Dallas, that ''America is presented (in this election) with the clearest political choice of half a century.''

title: THRIFT UNIT OFFICIAL OUT
description: The second-ranking executive at the troubled Financial Corporation of America, J. Foster Fluetsch, resigned late this afternoon as vice chairman and a director of the company and as chairman and chief executive of its primary unit, the American Savings and Loan Association, the company said.

title: EXPOS PLAN CHANGE
description: Just a week after Bill Virdon was dismissed as field manager of the Montreal Expos, John McHale , who has been running the club's front office as president and chief executive officer since 1978, said he planned to give up his key duties as de facto general manager by naming an actual general manager, something the club has done without. McHale, who owns 10 percent of the team, said he would have preferred to name a new field manager and a general manager at the same time but had let Virdon go immediately after consulting with the club's principal owner, Charles Bronfman , and other directors.

title: FRIENDS IN ADVERSITY
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:I read, and then reread, ''Are Friends Still Friends in Adversity?'' It is all so painfully true! What is this malaise that afflicts people when they learn about an illness of a friend? They become paralyzed for reasons accurately described in this article. My husband's tragic diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease was made two years ago.

title: A NEW LOOK IN NOVELS: DEADLINE EVERY 3 DAYS
description: A standup comedian, a news-service correspondent, a jazz musician, and a part-time actress are among the hundreds of individuals who spent their Labor Day weekend at work on a novel.

title: Wang Laboratories Offers New Campaign
description: Wang Laboratories, one of the first computer companies to use network TV when it started on the medium in 1977, breaks a new campaign there and in the top 20 markets on Sunday.

title: BRUTUS COSTE
description: Brutus Coste, who as secretary general of the Assembly of Captive European Nations worked with the Free Europe Committee to restore freedom to nine Soviet-bloc countries, died Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Housing Bonds' Yields Buoyed by Heavy Flow
description: Underwriters in the tax-exempt bond market announced interest rates yesterday for at least six new issues of single-family housing revenue bonds. All the new financings except one are backed by an insurance policy of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association and are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

title: Ford Plans 1.9% Rise in 85 Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company advised its dealers today that it was tentatively increasing the price of its 1985 model cars by 1.9 percent, or an average of $225 a car.

title: Dow Loses 12.03, Closing at 1,212.35
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in sluggish trading, as investors continued to display growing apprehension over interest rates.

title: U.S. AIDE RAISES RIGHTS ISSUE DURING HIS TALKS IN UGANDA
description: The State Department's top official for Africa, ending a visit here, expressed United States concern today over the human rights situation in Uganda.

title: In Re Rhodes Tavern
description: Time and legal maneuvers are

title: Peugeot Head Resigns
description: Jean-Paul Parayre, a prime architect of the Peugeot auto group's expansion, resigned today as chairman.

title: Aid for Kidney Disease May Be Found in Diet
description: A low-protein, largely vegetarian diet at least temporarily delayed the progression of chronic kidney disease in some patients and could spare other patients years of costly dialysis treatment, according to a new study.

title: FARED ROBOT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $442,000 from the sale of certain assets. c-Net loss.

title: Argentine Debt Accord Called Possible Soon
description: The head of an International Monetary Fund technical mission in Argentina said today that agreement might soon be reached on the terms of long-awaited loan accord needed to refinance the country's $43.6 billion in foreign debt.

title: No Headline
description: Creditor Seizes Air Florida Jet MIAMI, Sept. 5 (AP) - One

title: Hiring at Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said 1,500 more workers would be employed at its Seattle area plants this year than earlier projected because of ''improved business conditions'' in the commercial airplane market. The company said the majority of those joining the payroll between now and the end of the year would be recalled from earlier layoffs. In April, the company said it would hire 8,000 additional workers, with 5,300 of those employed in Washington State.

title: Thrift Unit Figures May Be Released
description: Officials of the Financial Corporation of America will meet in the next two days with the company's new chief, William J. Popejoy, to select data to make public in an effort to rebuild depositor confidence, Gary Fishman, a spokesman for Financial Corporation, said today.

title: U.S. News Sale
description: The sale of U.S. News & World Report was postponed for several days because of a ''minor glitch,'' a company spokesman said. Lawyers for the magazine and its prospective buyer, Boston real estate developer Mortimer Zuckerman, discovered that additional papers needed to be filed in certain states, the spokesman said.

title: F.A.A. SUGGESTS FEWER TAKEOFFS FROM NEWARK
description: Kennedy and La Guardia airports would be allowed to have more landings and takeoffs at peak hours, and Newark far fewer, under Government suggestions outlined today.

title: IN VICTOR HUGO'S HOUSE, ROOMS OF HIS OWN DESIGN
description: Those who like their French poets in garrets by the Seine will be disappointed in Victor Hugo's house at 6 Place des Vosges. Hugo, the lyric poet, novelist, and reformer who raised French social consciousness with his unforgettable story of the poor, ''Les Miserables,'' was the son of a general and a wealthy man who surrounded himself with beautiful things, many of his own creation.

title: DELOREAN DISPUTE PUTS FOCUS ON TOWN IN UTAH
description: You could say that Logan, a town tucked into a mountain valley in northern Utah, was off the beaten track.

title: POLLUTION RESEARCH & CONROL reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $147,000. c-Includes a tax benefit of $20,000. Certain year-ago results have been reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company went public in August 1983.

title: Q&A
description: Our house had six-inch insulation on the attic floor with a vapor barrier underneath. I added six more inches of unfaced insulation on top.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A court has upheld the award of more than $1 million to the family of a man shot to death by the police 26 years ago, and the president of the Milwaukee City Council said today that the city should ''put this tragic episode behind us'' rather than appeal.

title: WHAT TO DO IN SEPTEMBER
description: Lawns

title: ;  Track Intrigue
description: A Soviet track star reportedly refused to submit to a mandatory drug test after winning a race in Paris this week. But international track officials have declined to take immediate action against her, apparently out of fear of offending Soviet sports authorities.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Summer Brawls

title: WORLD ACCORD ON GENOCIDE: AN ISSUE SINCE TRUMAN ERA
description: The Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, drafted 36 years ago as a response to the murder of six million Jews by the Nazis, makes the mass killing of national, racial, ethnic or religious groups an international crime.

title: RENOVATING A HOUSE ONE STEP AT A TIME
description: M OST people's dreams of a second house revolve around having the perfect place without spending much money. They hope to find the cheap ugly-duckling property that can, with some expenditure, be turned into a beautiful swan. Others muse on the possible extra features - enlarged baths, more convenient kitchens - that they feel would make the summer house they already own ideal.

title: JAZZ: JOHN BLAKE AND STEVE COHN
description: T HE Greenwich Village Jazz Festival ended in high spirits Monday with an all-day program of new jazz at Sweet Basil. The bandleaders included the vibraphonist Jay Hoggard, the saxophonists Jimmy Lyons and Dewey Redman, the drummer Paul Motian and two groups not recently reviewed in these pages - the John Blake quintet and the Steve Cohn trio.

title: 3 FRENCH TOWNS GO TO EXTREMES TO BE THE CENTER
description: -ALLICHAMPS, France, Sept. 3 - Three hamlets in this rolling rural district just south of Bourges have become embroiled in an argument over which of them is the geographical center of France.

title: TURNBULL THRIVES IN THE REAL WORLD
description: The airplanes were flying overhead, but they were the least of

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINESE EMIGRATION For generations, some Chinese have left their homeland and headed for practically every corner of the world. This phenomenon of emigration and resettlement is the focus of a film and lecture series, ''Chinese Diaspora.'' Sponsored by Asian Cine Vision, the series begins today and continues through Nov. 17. The programs are presented at 7 P.M. Thursdays and are repeated at 2:30 P.M. Saturdays. Scholars and film makers will lead discussions after the screenings.

title: THEATER: A 'DREAM' OUTDOORS
description: ''A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM'' is a kind of artistic Rorschach test for theater companies. Those drawn to the lyricism of Shakespeare's poetry and captivated by the visual fantasies of an enchanted forest usually try to weave some sort of romantic spell with the play, even though it's a comedy that ridicules romance. But Shakespeare & Company, the highly regarded theatrical ensemble from Lenox, Mass., has resisted any such temptation. Its merry, rough-and-tumble production, which had the first of four free performances at the Prospect Park Bandshell on Tuesday, views the romantic goings-on from the point of view of a smart boy who's not quite mature enough to become involved.

title: RATES SHOW LITTLE CHANGE
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday in the Treasury market, with no significant changes in either direction.

title: GERMAN DETENTE: SOVIET QUANDARY?
description: The scuttling Monday of a planned visit to West Germany by Erich Honecker, the East German Communist leader, capped an extraordinary confrontation between the Soviet Union and its weightiest Warsaw Pact ally. But in the view of officials and Western diplomats here, the strenuous Soviet arm-twisting required to get Mr. Honecker to call off the trip suggests that Moscow will have difficulty halting the development of detente between the two Germanys. East Germany's internal stability and prosperity are seen as bound up in its lucrative links to the Federal Republic.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've got a good bird there.'' - Henry W. Hartsfield Jr., commander of the space shuttle Discovery.

title: GREENE CRITICIZES FILM ADAPTATIONS OF HIS BOOKS
description: The writer Graham Greene says many of his books have been turned into ''very bad films'' - even by great directors.

title: Chandler Endorses Reagan
description: A. B. (Happy) Chandler, former Democratic Governor, Senator and baseball commissioner, appeared with Vice President Bush today to endorse President Reagan, and took a jab at Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic candidate for Vice President. ''He could manage his own finances, but that can't be safely said about that young woman who wants to replace him,'' the 86-year-old Mr. Chandler said, referring to the controversy over Mrs. Ferraro's finances.

title: Toddler Rescued After Slaying
description: An 18-month-old girl, who apparently spent several days alone in a South Bronx apartment after her mother was slain, was rescued yesterday from a fifth-floor window ledge by a neighbor.

title: SHOREHAM PANEL BACKS LOADING OF NUCLEAR FUEL
description: A three-judge panel of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ruled yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company should be allowed to load nuclear fuel at its Shoreham reactor.

title: Bush Sees Recession With Mondale Policies
description: Vice President Bush charged today that Walter F. Mondale's spending and tax policies would set off a new recession, resulting in higher unemployment and ''bringing the curtain down on the period of sustained economic growth that everybody wants.''

title: 3 ATTACKS ON I-95: THE WORK OF A LONE GUNMAN?
description: All three targets have been men. All three attacks have been along a 20-mile stretch of Interstate 95 in Connecticut's Fairfield County. And all three have involved gunshots that the police believe were fired from a passing vehicle.

title: Meeting Set on Copper Curbs
description: President Reagan's Cabinet Council on Commerce and Trade meets Thursday for the first time on the thorny issue of copper imports, Administration officials said today.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Required Reading; On Religion
description: May 7, 1984 Dear Mr. President,

title: LED ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS
description: William P. Arnold, former head of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, the parent company of Lord & Taylor, Caldor Inc., Loehmann's Inc. and other retail companies, died of cancer Tuesday at Deaconness Hospital in Boston. He was 59 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: No to Rabbi Kahane
description: The president of the National

title: Plea of Guilty
description: In the last case stemming from a score-rigging scheme to benefit gamblers during Boston College's 1978-79 basketball season, a Staten Island man pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of having conspired to commit sports bribery. The plea was entered by Richard Perry, 39 years old, in Federal District Court in Uniondale, L.I. According to the prosecutor, Jerry D. Bernstein, and the defense lawyer, Joel Winograd, Mr. Perry pleaded under an agreement that, if approved by Judge Leonard D. Wexler, will bring a sentence of time already served in the case, plus a $5,000 fine and a year's probation. Mr. Perry served 21 days after his arrest last April and is now free on a $100,000 personal recognizance bond. Five other people were also convicted of conspiracy charges in the case.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Tough Diagnosis

title: Boy Learns 'Gold' Has 17/ Glitter
description: Joey Errico got the bad news yesterday.

title: 4 KILLED AND 27 WOUNDED BY CAR BOMB IN BEIRUT
description: Lebanon's Education Minister today narrowly escaped a car bomb explosion that killed four people and wounded 27.

title: AUG. 21-31 CAR SALES UP 11.6%
description: New-car sales rose 11.6 percent, on a daily selling rate basis, in the Aug. 21-31 period, the six major American manufacturers reported here today.

title: 2 AMERICANS ASSERT U.S. ASSISTED PRIVATE EFFORT AGAINST LATIN LEFT
description: Two Americans involved in aiding Nicaraguan rebels said today that they received assistance from United States Embassies in Honduras and El Salvador in their effort to provide military equipment to anti-Communist forces in Central America.

title: U.S. ASKS MOROCCO ABOUT LIBYA PACT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told an aide to King Hassan II of Morocco today that the United States was concerned about the treaty of union between Morocco and Libya and wanted assurances that American goods and military supplies would not find their way to Libya, State Department officials said.

title: VIOLENCE FEARED IN FISHING CONTESTS INQUIRY
description: One witness is dead of a shotgun blast, and another says he fears for his life as the authorities investigate charges of cheating in fishing tournaments where prizes run as high as $50,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages Tuesday about Jim Jensen of the Miami Dolphins misidentified his alma mater. It is Boston University.

title: Yugoslav Prices Climb
description: The rise in Yugoslavia's consumer prices slowed a bit last month. They climbed 3.3 percent from the July figure to a level 59.9 percent above that of August 1983, the Government said today. The rise was less than the 12-month increase of 62.1 percent recorded in July.

title: 8,736 SEE COSMOS WIN IN A SHOOTOUT
description: The Cosmos took firm hold of first place in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League tonight with a 2-1 shootout victory over the Toronto Blizzard before 8,736, the smallest crowd, by about 2,000, to watch the Cosmos since they moved into Giants Stadium in 1977.

title: A MOVE INTO MICROPROCESSORS
description: When the NEC Corporation introduced a new family of microprocessors last spring, it marked a watershed for the Japanese semiconductor industry.

title: German Output Rises
description: West Germany's industrial production rose 13.5 percent in July from the month before and 8 percent from July 1983, the Government said today. Part of the gain came as the auto industry tried to make up losses suffered during a metalworkers' strike.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOTHA IN NEW POST
description: Police officers detonated a bomb planted inside the Supreme Court in Johannesburg today, and a series of explosions west of the city wrecked an electricity substation. Sporadic looting continued in black townships to the south that have been convulsed in recent days by violence and arson.

title: Frank Paris, 70, Puppeteer;Creator of Howdy Doody
description: Frank Paris, a puppeteer who created the original Howdy Doody marionette, has died at the age of 70, according to friends.

title: SCIENCE, AID SAKHAROVS
description: The American scientific community must insure that the issue of freedom for Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, is high on the agenda when Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Secretary of State George P. Schultz meet at the United Nations later this month. The Sakharovs' freedom depends upon our putting pressure on the Soviet Union in public forums and private channels.

title: No Headline
description: Nomination To F.T.C. Seat WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -

title: New Talks Scheduled In British Coal Strike
description: The National Coal Board and union leaders today scheduled a new round of talks, but on terms that held out little hope for a quick end to Britain's six-month-old coal strike.

title: Grand Trunk-Burlington Tie
description: Saying that regional railroads need to cooperate to survive, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Grand Trunk Corporation today announced the signing of a 10-year freight interchange agreement. The two railroads will cooperate in the marketing and shipping of coal, grain, automobiles and other freight in the United States and Canada, officials of the companies said.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $559,000 for the quarter and $630,000 for the year, losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,200,000 for the quarter and $2,200,000 for the year, and an extraordinary gain of $1,900,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $616,000 for the quarter and $1,800,000 for the year, and a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $116,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Fluke and Bluefish Still in Abundance
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Splendid angling for

title: 24-Hour Stay Is Granted In Florida Execution
description: A Federal district judge today put off the execution of Nollie Lee Martin less than 15 hours before he was to have died in Florida's electric chair. Originally, he was scheduled to be put to death with another Florida killer in the nation's first double execution in 19 years.

title: BRANIFF TURNS TO LOW-COST STRATEGY
description: Braniff Inc., in a major strategy shift, announced yesterday that it was transforming itself in the next few weeks into a low-cost airline with unrestricted fares.

title: GAETA TO RETIRE AS STATEN ISLAND BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: Anthony R. Gaeta, the Borough President of Staten Island since 1977, said yesterday that he would retire next November.

title: 3 RUSSIANS EQUAL ENDURANCE RECORD IN SPACE
description: Three Russian astronauts who have been orbiting the earth since Feb. 8 today equaled an endurance record of 211 days in space, demonstrating the Soviet Union's commitment to long-term space flights.

title: WHO WOULD TEST POLITICAL CANDIDATES' MINDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. POSTMASTER AND TWO UNIONS AGREE TO RESUME CONTRACT TALKS
description: The Postal Service and unions representing 500,000 postal workers agreed today to return to the bargaining table in an effort to break their six-week impasse over a new contract.

title: THE FIRST BREAK FROM PARENTS
description: T HIS month children as young as 2 and 3 years will be toddling off to school for the first time - an adventure that will prove traumatic for some and just mildly strange for others. At a number of preschools in the city the mothers will be asked to allay their children's anxieties by remaining in the classroom or down the hall for the first few days.

title: A NEW PATH FOR CANADA
description: Brian Mulroney and his Progressive Conservative Party, which on Tuesday won the biggest political majority in Canadian history, appear to have fundamentally changed the country's political landscape. The result, wrote Richard Gwyn, a columnist for The Toronto Star, Canada's largest newspaper, ''almost certainly made the Conservatives the majority party for the rest of this century.''

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Plane Crash in Idaho Kills 4
description: Two couples from northern California were killed in a light plane that crashed and burst into flame Monday in central Idaho's wilderness, the authorities said Tuesday. The Valley County coroner, Marvin Heikkila, said all four victims were pilots. They were apparently flying out of the area when the Cessna Centurion 210 crashed in the forest two miles east of Indian Creek.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 5.7% IN CITY
description: Sales in August at seven of New York City's biggest retailers rose 5.7 percent over the year before, marking the third consecutive month of sluggish business, a spot-check found yesterday.

description: In the short run, duplicate bridge is not a game of justice, although the scales can be expected to reach an approximate balance in the long haul. An example is the diagramed deal, from the recent regional championships in Secaucus, N.J.

description: An unusual picture of President Reagan wearing sweat pants aboard Air Force One has been made available for publication, despite a White House objection.

title: FRENCH PRIME MINISTER SEES MORE ECONOMIC TROUBLES
description: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, in his first television appearance since taking office in July, warned tonight that what he called the country's economic crisis would end only after a long and painful effort.

description: For the first time, doctors have traced a serious outbreak of human food poisoning to drug-resistant germs that spread from beef cattle routinely fed antibiotics to promote growth.

description: b-Includes a gain of $915,000 from dispositions. c-Includes a gain of $1,120,000 from dispositions.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $121,000 for the quarter and $306,000 for the 6 months. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $199,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $201,000 for the 6 months.

title: ALBANY HONORING A NATIVE LITERARY SON FOR 4 DAYS
description: A four-day celebration in honor of the novelist William Kennedy begins here Thursday in the city that he fondly describes in the title of his new book of essays, ''O Albany! Improbable City of Political Wizards, Fearless Ethnics, Spectacular Aristocrats, Splendid Nobodies and Underrated Scoundrels.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart last Thursday, with an article on Soviet space-shuttle capacity, was incorrectly attributed. It was adapted from the work of C. P. Vick in the magazine Aviation Week & Space Technology.

title: PLIGHT OF THE BLIND WHO LOVE BOOKS
description: ''T HE situation for the blind is terrible, just terrible,'' Lillian Hellman complained once again during what turned out to be the last two days of her life. She herself was legally blind by this time, and as she started in on the subject she trembled with her legendary fury. In her final years, this fury sometimes led her to exaggerate its basis.

title: NASA IS JUBILANT
description: The space shuttle Discovery returned from its successful six-day maiden flight today, swooping out of the clear blue desert sky, turning before the hills as the sun was rising, and gliding to a smooth landing here on a dry lakebed runway.

title: LONG A FIGURE AT U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: Adam Malik, the Indonesian statesman and President of the United Nations General Assembly in 1971, died of cancer of the liver yesterday at his home in Bandung. He was 67 years old.

title: CONABLE SEES TAX RISE IN 1985
description: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that taxes would have to be raised next year as part of any deficit reduction package no matter who was elected President.

title: THE PAC-MAN'S GAME: EATING LEGISLATORS
description: Woman power, black power, ethnic power - the popular buzz words of 1984. But there's another kind of political power that is more important than any of them, attracts little public attention and yet, in the current Congressional campaign, poses an immediate and growing threat to the American representative system. It's money power.

title: CONFUSION IN JERSEY
description: When news stories about the problems with asbestos removal projects in scores of public schools appeared last week, one of those who learned about it for the first time was Governor Kean. In an administration whose hallmark has been crisis management - whether it was the discovery of dioxin in Newark or radioactive soil in suburban towns - the failure to stay on top of an emotion-charged issue like asbestos control seemed uncharacteristic.

title: HOFSTRA LEADS WAY IN LOCAL DIVISION III
description: When the Supreme Court ruled last June that the National Collegiate Athletic Association could no longer control regular-season football telecasts , the smallest of the N.C.A.A. schools - the Division III institutions - were forced to cancel plans to expand their postseason playoffs from 8 to 16 teams. That meant the end of the television income that financed the small- college football championship tournaments.

title: METS WIN AND GAIN ON CUBS
description: With their expectations falling and rising from one night to the next, the Mets considered a victory this evening crucial to their effort to catch the Cubs.

description: ''Hello, Bob,'' said one teacher to the other, ''how was your summer?''

title: Nicholas Vanderbilt Service
description: A memorial service for Nicholas Vanderbilt, who was reported missing last Friday on a climbing expedition in British Columbia and is believed to be dead, will be held Saturday at St. Gertrude's Roman Catholic Church in Bayville, L.I. Mr. Vanderbilt, who was 24 years old and lived in Austin, Tex., was the son of Jean Harvey Vanderbilt and Alfred G. Vanderbilt, the race horse owner and former chairman of the State Racing Association.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1984 International Formal oppositon to genocide was expressed by the Reagan Administration as it announced support for a 36- year-old United Nations convention against the practice. The convention has been opposed by right-wing groups and Southern senators on the ground it might interfere with state laws. (Page A1, Column 4.) Three Soviet astronauts who have been orbiting the earth since Feb. 8 equalled an endurance record of 211 days in space. (B10:4-6.)

title: Herman Shoe
description: The Joseph M. Herman Shoe Company said it would close its factory here in 60 to 90 days, leaving 125 employees without jobs.

title: SHARON ACCUSES TIME OF 'BLOOD LIBEL'
description: Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli Defense Minister, testified yesterday that he filed a libel suit against Time magazine because an article in the newsweekly was ''one of the most terrible things that has been done to the Jewish people.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article Aug. 26 on Congressional election prospects misstated results of Democratic Party polling. The party's late June poll found, among those who had made up their minds about Congressional races, 60 percent support for Democratic candidates and 40 percent support for Republicans.

description: F OR those who are interested in learning how to improve living spaces with maximum expertise and a minimum expenditure, there are many courses being given this fall in Manhattan. Registration is now under way. Here is just a sampling:

title: CUB STREAK ENDED
description: David Palmer pitched six scoreless innings of three-hit relief and singled home a fourth-inning run tonight as the Montreal Expos ended Chicago's four-game winning streak by beating the Cubs, 3-1.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ITALIAN THEATER FESTIVAL OPENING AT LA MAMA
description: Picture Desdemona as Marilyn Monroe, and an Othello who alternates between Renaissance garb and a decidedly 20th-century leather overcoat. Add a time frame that shifts, scene by scene, between the Renaissance and the 1940's, and settings ranging from Venice to a trans-Atlantic ocean liner (complete with French Foreign Legionnaires dancing on the decks) to Cyprus.

title: Debris Complicates Salvage Of Nuclear Cargo Off Belgium
description: Efforts to salvage the nuclear cargo from a sunken freighter off the Belgian coast were complicated when floating debris crashed through its deck, officials said today. Bad weather had already hampered the efforts.

title: MONDALE PLEDGES IMMEDIATE EFFORT FOR ARMS FREEZE
description: Geraldine Ferraro's campaign for Vice President is affecting the image of all women in politics. Page B12.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allegheny Beverage Corp., a soft- drink manufacturer and distributor in Baltimore, said it had acquired the principal assets and operations of the Terminal Vending Co., which distributes food and cigarette products in New Jersey.

title: Mapco Oil Unit
description: Mapco Inc. said it would explore the possible sale of all or part of its Mapco Oil and Gas Company subsidiary, which is involved in oil and gas exploration and the operation of natural gas processing plants. Mapco's 1983 annual report showed oil and gas assets of $224 million. Noting that its operations had an estimated discounted future net cash flow of $206 million, Mapco said it expected to ''realize significantly more than their book value or the standard measure of discounted cash flow'' in a sale.

title: ICL Merger Clears Hurdle
description: The Department of Trade and Industry today removed an obstacle to the takeover of ICL P.L.C. by Standard Telephone and Cable P.L.C. The department said it would not refer the proposed takeover to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission for further review.

title: 8 THEATERS GET $1.3 MILLION IN GRANTS
description: Eight nonprofit theaters, including three in New York, yesterday received the first $1.3 million in a new Federal program to aid ensemble companies. Frank Hodsoll, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, announced the grants at a news conference in Manhattan.

title: A FAMILY MAN SWEEPS FLOORS, AND DREAMS
description: Hours after darkness forces a tenuous calm on his jagged-edged neighborhood in Brooklyn, William Anthony is at some nearly deserted subway station, making a living.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Continental Grain Fills a Top Post

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENGLISH JOURNEY: Or the Road to Milton Keynes. By Beryl Bainbridge. 158 pages. George Braziller. $12.95. ''A LL my childhood,'' Beryl Bainbridge says, ''was spent with people who were disappointed.'' When she grew up, she wrote 10 novels, most of them good, about disappointed people. She made it seem that life itself is a question of how you deal with your disappointment. Her best characters seem to appreciate the picturesqueness of their defeated hopes. They regarded them with a mixture of wistfulness and pride, as one might read over a rejected poem that has just been returned from still another publication.

title: ALCOA, JOINING TREND, CUTS OUTPUT AT 2 PLANTS
description: The Aluminum Company of America, following a move in the domestic industry to reduce overcapacity, yesterday announced production cutbacks at two of its plants.

title: THE POTENTIAL PERILS OF POLITICAL PILLOW TALK
description: Politics can make for strange bedfellows. And this applies no more so than when happily married Washington couples discover that their respective careers and commitments have put them at professional odds, if not in political conflict.

title: Reagan's Jet Loses Pressure In Cabin on Flight to Capital
description: Air Force One, carrying President Reagan and his entourage, lost cabin pressure today because of a failure in an air vent but landed safely in Washington. No injuries were reported.

title: ;  Carr Signs With Hawks
description: Antoine Carr , the star forward from Wichita State who passed up the National Basketball Association to play in Italy last season, signed a multiyear contract with the Atlanta Hawks. ''We are very excited about signing Antoine,'' said the Hawks' general manager, Stan Kasten .

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: THE CHINESE MAGIC REVUE
description: T HE Promenade Theater overflowed Tuesday night with jugglers, acrobats, magicians and practitioners of the martial arts. Swords were swallowed, men leaped through fiery hoops, beautiful women hovered in midair, children threw one another cheerfully about the stage, and what looked like a gigantic Pekingese growled a good-natured warning to the front rows.

title: NEW COSTS TO BANKS IS BACKED
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has endorsed a measure that could cost big banks tens of millions of dollars by requiring them to pay insurance premiums to the agency on their foreign deposits, which have been exempt.

title: If Auto Strike Comes to Pass
description: Contracts between major automobile manufacturers and the United Automobile Workers expire Sept. 14, and the threat of a strike holds implications not only for the car makers but also for the nation's economy.

title: Kurds Say Clash With Iraqis Left 105 Dead, Mostly Foes
description: A total of 105 people, most of them Iraqi soldiers, were killed and 47 soldiers were wounded in six days of fighting between the Iraqi Army and Kurdish rebels, a spokesman for the exiled Kurdish Democratic Party said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPE ; ; Burroughs Names Head Of a New Division
description: The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that it was taking three existing divisions and creating a new office and media products group to market worldwide a broad range of data-processing office supplies.

title: TRIAL MAY FOCUS ON RACE GENETICS
description: A libel trial that opened here today may turn into a wide-ranging examination of the theories of William B. Shockley, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist who has argued that blacks are genetically inferior in intelligence to whites.

title: No Headline

title: GATT BIDS U.S. CANCEL NEW CURBS ON TEXTILES
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade body, urged the United States today to shelve new curbs on textile imports that are scheduled to take effect on Friday. They said the restrictions would damage clothing exporters and be discriminatory.

title: EAST-WEST ARMS BUILDUPS DON'T FIT ACTION-REACTION CYCLES

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association surprised the credit markets yesterday with a $6.75 billion issue of zero-coupon subordinated debentures due in 2019. The debentures, which pay no interest, were offered by Salomon Brothers at a price of about $32 per $1,000 face amount, to yield 10.08 percent to maturity and raised $206 million for Fannie Mae.

title: FUGITIVE IN BIG SENTRY THEFT SEIZED ON LONG ISLAND AS DRUNKEN DRIVER
description: An international search for a fugitive in the theft of $11 million from the Sentry Armored Courier Corporation in the Bronx ended Tuesday when the man was arrested on a drunken-driving charge on Long Island, officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLLE ; ;  Pharmacia of Sweden In Management Shifts
description: A number of top management changes were put into effect yesterday at Pharmacia A.B., the diversified health-care company that was the first Swedish company to issue shares in the United States.

title: A MODERN CENTRIST IN CANADA: MARTIN BRIAN MULRONEY
description: Martin Brian Mulroney, who emerged Tuesday as this country's next Prime Minister, has been called ''the Canadian version of Ronald Reagan.'' The characterization came from Sinclair Stevens, the foreign affairs spokesman for Mr. Mulroney's Progressive Conservative Party, whose right-wing elements helped elect Mr. Mulroney party leader in June 1983.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: PROBLEMS OF RETIREMENT ARE EXAMINED ON FILM
description: ''T HE WORK I'VE DONE'' is an ambitious exploration of the personal crises that accompany retirement. Technically, it is a documentary; actually, it is a celebration of cinematic technique. Sometimes the two are in uneasy coexistence. How the film looks takes precedence over what it means, and it promises more than it can deliver. The one-hour program can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: Kennedy Film for Rent
description: One way the Kennedy Center is trying to raise money is by selling and renting, for the first time, the film ''John F. Kennedy - Years of Lightning, Day of Drums.'' The 88-minute film was produced by the United States Information Agency as a memorial to the late President for showing abroad.

title: THE IDEOLOGICAL SHAPING OF THE FEDERAL JUDICIARY
description: To the Editor:

title: Nominations for the Civil Court In Tuesday's primary, voters will pick their party's nominees for Civil Court judgeship races in the November election. Civil Court judges are elected to 10-year terms by countywide vote or by district. They handle matters involving less than $25,000 but may serve as acting Supreme Court justices and sit anywhere in the city. Here are our choices in contested Democratic races; there are no contests among Republican candidates.
description: MANHATTAN: Two judges will be elected countywide in November. One is Judge Eugene Nardelli, who has only nominal opposition. In the Democratic contest for the other nomination, we endorse Phyllis Gangel Jacob, a lawyer with 18 years of experience in practice, teaching and consulting work, over Judge Antonio Brandveen, who has been on the Housing Court since 1980.

title: Nestle-Carnation Effect on Ratings
description: The Nestle Capital Corporation and the Carnation Company may lose their AAA senior debt ratings as a result of their merger, analysts at S.& P. said yesteday.

description: Schoolchildren and their parents are going to star in a local multimedia advertising campaign aimed at getting New Yorkers to take advantage of a wonderful free offer - a public school education.

description: With an increasing number of Protestant children on their rolls, Roman Catholic schools in New York City opened yesterday for 195,000 pupils in 397 schools.

description: Gray & Company Public Communications International, a powerhouse of a Washington public relations firm that recently went public, is in the process of acquiring the Strayton Corporation of Wellesley, Mass., Santa Clara, Calif., and Dallas, which is a leader in the growing field of high- tech public relations.

Towle Dividend
description: The Towle Manufacturing Company said it had voted to omit payment of the quarterly dividend of 11 cents a common share for the third quarter. The company, a maker of silverware and cutlery giftware and crystal, attributed the omission to a desire to reduce the company's level of borrowings to improve its profitability.

title: DAVID R. MITCHELL
description: David R. Mitchell, a retired textile designer and manufacturer, died Aug. 29 at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Bay Pines, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: REAGAN DECLARES BUDGET DEFICIT IS BEING REDUCED
description: Four years after campaigning here on the promise to have the Federal budget in balance by 1983, President Reagan defended his handling of the record deficit today as he campaigned for re-election.

title: Limits on Vendors Upheld by Judge
description: Acting Justice Elliott Wilk of State Supreme Court in Manhattan lifted an injunction yesterday barring the city from enforcing regulations that ban sidewalk food vendors from most of midtown and portions of Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Harris Signed by Seahawks;  Will Replace Warner
description: Franco Harris, a key player in the Pittsburgh Steelers' glory years, agreed to a one-year contract with Seattle today and will replace Curt Warner, the Seahawks' injured running back.

title: CHEMICAL FUNDS AID CAMPAIGNS
description: The political action committees of the nation's largest chemical producers have given more than $2 million in campaign contributions to members of Congress over the last three years, according to a study released today by a research organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, the consumer activist.

title: ADDABBO FACING CHALLENGE FROM GOLAR IN QUEENS
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo faces a stiff challenge from Simeon Golar in next Tuesday's Democratic primary in Queens, and politicians say that the success of Mr. Golar's bid is likely to be determined by the turnout in the district's predominantly black areas.

title: CHURCH'S ACTIVIST CLERICS: ROME DRAWS LINE
description: The confrontation set for Friday at the Vatican between a powerful cardinal and an influential Brazilian priest signals a hardening of the division within the Roman Catholic Church over the religious-political movement known as liberation theology.

title: ACCORD ON ISRAELI GOVERNMENT IS CONFIRMED
description: Israel's top political leaders confirmed today that they had reached basic agreement on a bipartisan government and moved to another stage of negotiations: who would get which post in the Cabinet.

title: SUCCESS OF SHUTTLE'S MISSION BOLSTERS OPTIMISM AT NASA
description: The space shuttle Discovery's almost flawless flight has bolstered the confidence of the space agency at a time of rapid growth in the number, duration and complexity of missions.

title: HERS
description: O UR town has two streets and three blocks and the town council believes we have a parking problem because on Saturday mornings someone may have to leave his pickup on one block and walk to the hardware store on the next.

description: A group of Americans and Chinese will open a series of scheduled exchanges Thursday on ''matters of international political and strategic importance,'' conference organizers said today.

MAN ARRESTED IN CAR AS QUEENS ATTACKER OF GIRL AND WOMAN
description: A 26-year-old man was arrested and charged yesterday with the abduction of a teen-age girl and the attempted abduction of a woman in Astoria, Queens, on Sunday.

title: DOLLAR'S SHARP RISE CONTINUES
description: The dollar yesterday extended the unexpectedly steep ascent that it began Monday, following a sluggish August.

title: Body Is Found In Search for Boy
description: A six-day search for a missing 13- year-old boy ended near the top of a wooded ravine today when the police found what they believed was the body of the boy, apparently a homicide victim, the authorities said.

title: Leonid Kostandov, 68; Soviet Deputy Premier
description: Leonid A. Kostandov, a Soviet Deputy Prime Minister, died here today of a heart attack after having visited the Leipzig trade fair, the East German press agency said. He was 68 years old.

title: Brazil Sees Drop in Debt
description: The Government revised its economic projections for the year and predicted a lower foreign debt and higher trade surplus, the central bank said today.

title: Tennis Group Sued Over Death
description: The family of Richard Wertheim, the tennis umpire who died after striking his head on the ground when he was struck in the groin by a tennis ball during a match at last year's United States Open, sued the United States Tennis Association yesterday for $2.25 million.

STUYVESANT TOWN: STILL GOING STRONG
description: A T last count in July, there were 7,893 names on the waiting list at Stuyvesant Town, the 35 red-brick buildings containing 8,736 rent-stabilized apartments that lie between 14th and 20th Streets and First Avenue and Avenue C.

title: Independent to Stay In Tennessee Contest
description: Ed McAteer, an independent who had promised to drop his campaign for the Senate if it appeared he would hurt Republican chances, said Tuesday that he had decided to stay in the race.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: POLYNESIAN CRAFTS
description: Polynesian Crafts, the American Museum of Natural History, Central

title: BUTCHER BANKS' COSTLY FALL
description: Eighteen months after the collapse of the Butcher brothers' Tennessee banking empire, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation fears that its losses in the episode may total several hundred million dollars more than it initially expected.

title: Canada Turns Right The impressive victory of Brian Mulroney's Progressive Conservative Party in Canada means that five of the seven largest Western democracies will now be ruled from the political right. But the domestic Canadian and North American implications of the outcome are at least as important as the global trend.
description: Mr. Mulroney himself is no ideologue. He is a practical centrist committed to maintaining Canada's developed welfare state. And the continental dimension of his victory bears promise of a return to healthy two-party politics in a country too long fractured by the language and separatist issues of Quebec.

title: THE REGION;
description: A Federal judge today upheld a record $565,000 housing discrimination award against the owners of an apartment complex in Patchogue, L.I.

title: THE CITY ; 8 ACTING PRINCIPALS TO LOSE POSTS
description: Acting principals at five of the city's 110 high schools and at three junior high schools will lose their jobs as a result of a court-order setting new procedures for filling the posts, Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday.

title: SEOUL, TOKYO: GETTING TOGETHER
description: One of the most difficult things for Americans to understand are historical sensitivities over which they have no control. The relationship between Japan and South Korea is a case in point.

title: 4 CHILEANS ARE SLAIN AS THOUSANDS STRIKE AGAINST ARMY RULE
description: Four more people, including a policeman, were slain during widespread protests against military rule today.

title: Iraq Studies Bonn Bid To Inspect Chemical Site
description: Iraq has informed the West German Government that it is considering a request that Bonn be allowed to inspect the site of a chemical laboratory being built near Baghdad, a a Government official said today.

title: WIDCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-Official to FaceSenator in Alabama By The Associated Press
description: Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, will be opposed for re-election in November by former Representative Albert Lee Smith. Both men won primaries on Tuesday.

title: Two Tests of Affirmative Action ''There is no happy solution,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward says of the dispute over the New York City police sergeants' promotion test. And he's right. High-scoring whites will resent any preferential treatment for low-scoring blacks and Hispanics. Minority officers will harbor resentment over the disproportionate white pass rate. But there's more at issue here even than one city's management dilemma.
description: What should a city do when, after it has worked hard to create a fair selection process, that process still gives disproportionate benefit to whites? New York City has now given two answers and both are right. It will stand by the test results - and it will keep on working to make future tests accessible to minority officers. Affirmative action should require good-faith efforts, not mindless quotas.

title: Some of the Homeless Are Allowed to Vote
description: Homeless adults living in welfare hotels or in public shelters in New York City do have a residence and are thus entitled to register and vote, state and city officials agreed yesterday in papers filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: MCI Staff Cuts
description: The MCI Telecommunications Corporation has dismissed 16 full-time supervisors and terminated 241 temporary employees as part of a reorganization.

title: C.D. Yields Turn Up
description: Reversing three weeks of falling yields, average effective yields for six-month certificates of deposit showed a slight increase nationally, to 11.18 percent, from 11.16 percent, for the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Yields for money market funds also increased slightly, to 9.79 percent, from 9.77 percent.

title: Killers in the House In Brooklyn, a 3-year-old discovered his father's loaded gun, pointed it at his 18-month-old brother and shot him dead. In Dayton, a woman alarmed by scratching at her kitchen door picked up a pistol and pulled the trigger. Her 6-year-old daughter darted into the line of fire and suffered a fatal wound. The stories are by now too familiar: the parents say they bought guns to protect against burglars.
description: That's understandable when urban police admit they can do little to prevent break-ins.

title: 4-NATION LATIN PEACE GROUP IS TO MEET TODAY
description: Under a reported threat by Costa Rica to take the region's problems to another forum, the so-called Contadora Group of Latin American peace negotiators is scheduled to meet on Thursday with Foreign Ministers from five Central American countries.

title: Campbell Soup Profit Up 13%
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that a strong performance by its major food brands helped expand its latest three-month profit by 13 percent on a 10 percent sales rise.

title: A.T.& T.'s Backlog
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told the Government today that it had ''stabilized'' its backlog of orders from business phone customers. The backlog of orders, some of which dated to 1983, had been steadily swelling since the breakup of the Bell System. In August, the backlog dropped for the first time, to 40,000, from 44,300 in July.

title: CHERNENKO MAKES APPEARANCE ON TV
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko appeared on television today for the first time in more than seven weeks to hand awards to three astronauts, calming a spate of rumors that he has been ailing.

title: REPAIRING THE WINDSOR CHAIR
description: The American Windsor chair, although possessing a character of its own, was modeled after an English prototype made near Windsor.

title: THE CARE AND REPAIR OF ASPHALT SURFACES
description: D RIVEWAYS or walks paved with blacktop should last for many years - some say almost indefinitely - if properly maintained. But if blacktop is neglected it can soon develop cracks and holes that not only will look unsightly but also can greatly shorten its life.

Nigeria Jails 2 Ex-Governors
description: Two men who were governors of the state of Kano before the military seized power in December have been jailed for 21 years by a military tribunal that found them guilty of taking $65,000 to facilitate a property deal and using the money to enrich an opposition party that has since been banned, Nigerian newspapers reported today. The two are Abubakar Rimi and his successor, Sabo Bakin Zuwo.

title: James Clark Nance, 91, Dies; Ex-Legislator and Publisher
description: James Clark Nance, who built a newspaper empire in Oklahoma and served 34 years in the State Legislature, including tenure as Speaker of the House, died Monday. He was 91 years old.

title: SHUTTLE PROGRAM: ITS SUCCESSES AND FAILURES

The next eight operational missions, beginning with the Columbia's flight in November 1982, involved scientific, military and commercial payloads and were hailed as thoroughly successful. Jesse Jackson in the Democratic Presidential primaries, said today he could give only qualified support to Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee, in the general election.

title: 5 STATION GROUPS TO PRODUCE PROGRAMS

title: Mancini Unfazed by Cut
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, training with bandages covering a cut under his left eyebrow, said today he was ''not worried at all'' that the injury would affect his performance Saturday in his comeback fight here against Kenny (Bang Bang) Bogner.

description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1984.

title: REAGAN WILL SUBMIT 1948 GENOCIDE PACT FOR SENATE APPROVAL
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had decided to back ratification of a 36- year-old United Nations convention against genocide.

title: Judge Considers Plea Of Refugee Worker
description: Jack Elder, director of a Roman Catholic-sponsored refugee center, believed two Salvadorans were fleeing a war zone and he had no intention of violating immigration laws when he drove them to a Texas border bus station, an attorney argued in court Tuesday.

title: ;  Cook Gets Expos Post
description: Murray Cook , who had been demoted from his general manager's post with the Yankees and then resigned from the team last month, was named general manager of the Montreal Expos.

title: Technology; A REBOUND FOR FUEL CELLS
description: At Racquetball World in Fountain Valley, Calif., the lights are powered by the same type of energy source that has run computers and other equipment on the space shuttle Discovery as it orbited the earth this week. The system can also be found at a Howard Johnson's restaurant near Baltimore, at Rawlinson's Laundry in Portland, Ore., and at the Vista Grande Villa Retirement Community in Jackson, Mich.

title: Philippine Bar Group Sees Plot in Aquino Case
description: The Philippine Bar Association has concluded that a soldier shot the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last year in a conspiracy involving ''high echelons of government'' and the military, the association's president said today.

title: A Matter of Franking
description: One of the most important election-year deadlines for members of Congress passed virtually unnoticed by outsiders on Tuesday. In the basement of the Longworth House Office Building is a subdivision of the office of the Doorkeeper of the House that is officially named the Publications Distribution System.

title: Man Fined in Ferraro Threat
description: A man who threatened the life of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, in a campaign visit here has been freed after paying a fine and court costs totaling $125, officials say. The man, Mark Drayton, 25 years old, of Camden, pleaded guilty shortly after his arrest to a single count of harassment stemming from a telephone threat he made when Mrs. Ferraro appeared here Aug. 28, Sgt. Albert Handy of the Camden police said.

title: Stocks Decline Again; Dow Off 3.32
description: The stock market weakened again yesterday in continued dull trading, with few issues posting price moves of a point or more.

description: Archbishop Bernard F. Law of Boston today described abortion as ''the critical issue in this campaign'' and urged voters to make it their central concern when they cast their ballots.

description: A group of interfaith religious leaders warned yesterday that the principle of church-state separation had undergone ''serious erosion'' recently. title: Italy's Retail Prices Up
description: Italian consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August from the July level and were up 10.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. Saving Dwight Gooden for the opener tomorrow of a three-game series against Chicago, the Mets will go instead with Calvin Schiraldi, who was roughed up by San Diego in his major league debut Saturday.

title: TURNBULL AND BASSETT GAIN SEMIFINALS WITH UPSETS
description: Going into the United States Open, Hana Mandlikova and Pam Shriver had established themselves as the best among the hundreds of female tennis players struggling to keep pace with the standards set by Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd. But their success has been accompanied by new pressures and expectations.

title: Cuts Urged For Utility
description: Michigan's chief utility overseer today recommended $200 million in spending cuts, including elimination of common-stock dividends, to help the Consumers Power Company recover from the failure of its Midland nuclear power project.

title: OIL-CUTOFF STUDY CITES SUBSTITUTES
description: The United States, if faced with a major cutoff of foreign oil, could substitute other energy for about 75 percent of current imports within five years, Congressional analysts said today.

title: $100 Million Bond Sale by California
description: A $100 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1985, to 8.80 percent in 1994, and 9.90 percent in 2004. Underwriters were led by the Bank of America.

description: MONTREAL (NL) - Appointed Murray Cook, former general manager of the Yankees, as general manager.

title: ;  It Doesn't Add Up
description: The United States Football League is looking into a report that the San Antonio Gunslingers announced inflated attendance figures for their 1984 home games while quietly submitting correct figures to the league office. According to papers filed in connection with a lawsuit against the Gunslingers' owner, Clinton Manges , the team publicly reported home- game attendance figures totaling 117,371 while reporting attendance to the league totaling only 66,256.

title: EAST SIDE DOCTOR, 81, INDICTED FOR ILLEGAL DISPENSING OF PILLS

title: Soviet Buys More Grain
description: The Soviet Union, continuing its grain-buying spree, has purchased an additional 100,000 metric tons of United States wheat and a half-million tons of corn, the Agriculture Department said today. The latest orders were for roughly 3.67 million bushels of wheat and 19.7 million bushels of corn. The sales would have an estimated United States farm value of nearly $72 million.

title: DEMOCRATS MISS ON JOBS
description: The Democrats' efforts to campaign on the issues of taxes, deficits and nuclear war are all very well, but the party has hardly touched on what could be one of its most effective selling points - its historic commitment to full employment.

description: Senate consideration of an Administration- backed bill that would give banks authority to expand into new financial services was frustrated today by the sustained opposition of both New York Senators.

title: U.S. REPORTS BREAKING UP 2 DRUG RINGS IN MANHATTAN
description: Federal agents announced yesterday that they had arrested 20 people in breaking up two drug-trafficking rings that worked together in lower Manhattan. They said the rings had sold $200 million in heroin and $30 million in cocaine in the last three months alone.

title: LAFAYETTE PARK: NOT JUST ANOTHER PRETTY POSTCARD

description: In a move reflecting the growing importance of its international operations, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that Ib Thomsen, president of its international subsidiary, the Goodyear International Corporation, had been named vice chairman of the parent corporation.

title: WAVING THE FLAG: WITH DIFFERENT APPROACHES, BOTH PARTIES ARE HARD AT IT
description: Along with their clash over the proper place of religion in American politics, President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale have moved quickly into a contest over the political symbolism of the American flag. On both issues, it was Mr. Reagan who moved boldly to seize political advantage from the emotionalism that surrounds the symbols of church and nation, and Mr. Mondale, stung by the Republican assault, who has hit back in response.

title: The Invisible Hand in the Sky Faced with the tough question of how to reduce the appalling delays at airports, the Reagan Administration offers an easy answer: Let the airlines puzzle it out. To that end, it has given the industry temporary immunity from the antitrust laws to let competing lines carve up scheduled flights at crowded peak hours.
description: The industry committee approach, coupled with threats that the Federal Aviation Administration will intervene directly if it fails, creates the appearance of decisive action. And since the busiest flying season is now ending, the problem may go away until next summer. But the Government's ploy is a political dodge, not a policy. Real leadership will be needed to save the skies from gridlock.

title: For the 99th Congress, Now
description: The general election's not till November but steam is already rising from some hot House races in New York - like the Democratic challenge in Manhattan to Bill Green, one of the city's rare Republicans in Congress. In that race, four candidates are campaigning furiously for the Democratic nomination in next Tuesday's primary. But meanwhile, in some other races, a win on Tuesday will quite likely mean election to the 99th Congress. Here we offer our views about five such decisive primary races.

In fact, they will appear in a Deutsche Grammophon recording of Mr. Bernstein's hit musical, ''West Side Story,'' being recorded in Manhattan this week and due for release next September.

title: TV WEEKEND ;  A Verona 'Turandot' With Bulgarian Star
description: Anyone eager to sample the Turandot of Ghena Dimitrova, the big- voiced Bulgarian soprano who's much talked about these days for the heaviest dramatic roles of Italian opera, has a chance tonight at 9, when a production of Puccini's ''Turandot'' from the Verona Arena will be shown on Channel 13. Voices of Turandot proportions are in perilously short supply today, and Miss Dimitrova has one.

title: Howe Sets Priority
description: Steve Howe , the Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher who is serving a season-long suspension for repeated use of cocaine, said he would report to the Arizona Instructional League next week but might not try for a major league comeback next season because he didn't want to jeopardize his rehabilitation. ''In Arizona, there's no pressure-cooker,'' he told The Los Angeles Herald Examiner.

title: No Headline

The performance is part of the third Downtown Dance Festival, which runs through next Friday.

title: IN QUEENS, SINGLES GET TOGETHER OVER LAUNDRY
description: Laundromats,'' said Irene Herman, ''are one place where you can tell what people are really like before you meet them. It's hard to put on airs when you're washing your underwear.''

title: CITY OPERA: 'MIKADO' IN A NEW STAGING
description: LONG before ''Pacific Overtures,'' before even ''Madama Butterfly,'' Gilbert and Sullivan bequeathed us a piece of neo-Japanese musical theater. It's called ''The Mikado,'' and since its premiere in 1885 - a century ago this season - it has counted as the most popular of all the Savoyard canon.

Atwood, executive vice president. ''We are not engaged simply in a replacement of yesterday's machine tools, but in the creation of a superior manufacturing capability,'' he said in a speech to the National Association of Machine Tool Builders in Chicago.

description: Richard Speck, convicted of murdering eight student nurses 18 years ago, refused to appear for his parole hearing today, but several relatives of the slain nurses argued vigorously against his release from prison.

title: DREAM RACE IS STILL A DREAM
description: A giddy announcement Wednesday by Belmont Park officials that All Along was returning to the United States to run against John Henry in the Turf Classic on Sept. 22 was as puzzling as it was exciting, and it turns out to have been a bit premature. The French mare, North America's horse of the year in 1983, has yet to race this year and will not run in the Turf Classic unless she wows her handlers when she makes her seasonal debut at Longchamps in Paris on Sunday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1984
description: International

title: ROCK: CYNDI LAUPER IN A HOMECOMING OCNCERT
description: Cyndi Lauper's rock concert Wednesday night at Pier 84 had all the ingredients of a celebratory homecoming. The place was packed, with a crowd primed to love her (the number of look-alikes and children was striking, but the audience as a whole was refreshingly mixed). She herself was dressed particularly flamboyantly - variations on the theme of orange - and had brought along her mother, ''Captain'' Lou Albano and others familiar from her videos. She was in really excellent voice, stronger and clearer than on her record. And yet, for all the charm of her personality, the show never really cohered, never managed to transcend individual songs into the sort of exultant experience it might well have been.

The Fire in New Jersey's Schools Parents throughout New Jersey are sending their children back to school this week with apprehension. Governor Kean's administration has mishandled the task of seeing that schools are demonstrably rid of asbestos and its pernicious threat to children's health. But though there's blame enough to go around in Trenton, the crisis was created in Washington.
description: Some three million American children are exposed in their schools to possibly dangerous amounts of asbestos, but the Federal Department of Education has almost completely ignored a 1980 law requiring it to help pay for detection and removal. When it discovered the cost - $1.4 billion, or about $100,000 a school - the Administration decided that the price of preventing children getting cancer while being educated was too high.

title: Soviet Explanation
description: A Soviet sports official with little apparent knowledge of international athletics has been blamed for Tatyana Kazankina 's refusal to submit to a mandatory drug test after winning a 5,000-meter race in Paris this week. Even so, Miss Kazankina, a three-time Olympic champion and the holder of the world records in the women's 1,500 and 3,000 meters, faces a minimum 10-month suspension from international competition and could be suspended for life because of the refusal, according to a member of the council of the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

title: 15 REASONS WHY NEW YORK IS ALWAYS NEW
description: NEW YORK CITY seems to present a new face with each new season, almost with each new day. And now, with cooler weather in the air, New Yorkers returning from vacation or venturing into old neighborhoods again with fresh eyes and a sense of renewal will find the city ready with a few surprises. Turn a corner and find a little plaza with chairs in which the city walker may rest and daydream, a private place that wasn't there the day before. Peer up and see a mural, newly refurbished and insisting on due notice, or a tree pushing its way from a rooftop high over Fifth Avenue, growing wild. The discoveries can have an edge to them, as in the case of street art, often, or can stir a feeling of affection for the spirit of New Yorkers who band together to create a pipe organ for their church or a garden for their block. The city can be a source of continuing surprises. Savor them, for they soon will change or be replaced by other revelations.

The singer, who concludes a three- week engagement at Michael's Pub tomorrow, knows just how far to push her particular brand of musical humor, which is based on her sly little-girl delivery and attitude of fey ingenuousness.

title: ERIC ROHMER'S 'FULL MOON IN PARIS' OPENS
description: Eric Rohmer ROHMER shoots his movies in 35 millimeter. He uses full-size actors, seen in long shots, medium shots and close-ups, mostly away from the studio in recognizable landscapes and interiors. His technology is that used by every other movie maker in the commercial cinema. Yet his films - ''My Night at Maud's,'' ''Clair's Knee,'' ''The Marquise of O,'' ''Pauline at the Beach,'' among others - look and sound like those of no other contemporary writer-director in his native France or, for that matter, anywhere else in the world.
