MODERN 'SLIVER' BUILDING GOING UP IN MURRAY HILL
description: Making a new residential apartment building blend with its surroundings in an old urban neighborhood is seldom easy, and occasionally it is all but impossible. And then there are the radical departures.

title: IN PERU PRISONS, REBELS OFFER SOME CLUES TO 'SHINING PATH'
description: They hurl dynamite, occupy villages, recruit the poor and indoctrinate the young. To some, they are disciplined idealists, full of soaring promises of a better world. To others, they are fanatical executioners.

title: Notes
description: Golden Nugget Finance Corp., a subsidiary of Golden Nugget Inc., a casino-hotel operator, has filed an offering of $200 million of exchangeable, variable-rate, mortgage-backed notes due 1994 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.. The notes are unconditionally guaranteed by Golden's parent, GNAC Corp., another Golden Nugget subsidiary.

title: U.S. News Suit
description: A Federal judge declined a request by retired employees to block the $176.3 million sale of U.S. News & World Report to Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a Boston real estate developer.

title: HIROHITO SOOTHES KOREAN PRESIDENT
description: Text of Hirohito remarks, page A6.

title: ONE COUNTRY AGAIN? WEST GERMANS IN NO HURRY
description: Before he goes to sleep each night, Willi H"oll sets his electric alarm clock forward by five minutes. This prim Hessian border village of half-timbered houses gets its electricity from next- door East Germany, and the fluctuations in current have a tendency to slow down Mr. H"oll's clock.

title: SKY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
DU PONT, CITING PRICES, TO HALT METHANOL SALES
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, said yesterday that it would discontinue its methanol sales on Jan. 1 because of an oversupply and low prices in the commodity chemicals market. The company said it might return to the market if there were a significant improvement in the demand or price of methanol.

title: GOULD'S WOES SPUR STOCK DROP
description: The share price of Gould Inc. dropped sharply yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange after the company announced worsening problems in its semiconductor group.

title: ISSUES DEBATED IN RACE TO OPPOSE REP. GREEN
description: I feel Mrs. Lall is an extremist on these issues,'' Andrew J. Stein said of one of his three opponents for the Democratic nomination in the 15th Congressional District in Manhattan.

title: Free the Archives!
description: The National Archives has been

title: TECK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a gain of $151,000 on the sale of an investment. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,343,000 from the sale of businesses. c-Net loss.

title: SINGAPORE'S LINK TO CHICAGO
description: The opening this morning of a futures-trading link between the Singapore International Monetary Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is considered a historic step in the direction of 24-hour trading.

title: CALYPSO: MIGHTY SPARROW PERFORMS
description: Now that British and American bands have begun to borrow from calypso music, authentic calypsonians are looking for a broader pop audience. The annual Labor Day carnival brought many singers to the West Indian community in Brooklyn, and those performers have started to get Manhattan club bookings.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEW YORKERS jammed into parties as if they had been deprived for months and gawked at celebrities as if they had never seen one, when the fall social season - never mind the calendar - got under way this week.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus narrowed in July to a seasonally adjusted $2.06 billion (Canadian), from a record $2.07 billion in June, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The Canadian dollar is equal to 76 cents in United States currency. Exports in July rose 2.9 percent from June and imports rose 3.9 percent.

title: AT THE MERC, OPTIMISM IS HEDGED WITH CAUTION
description: Like hundreds of other traders, Michael G. Sammon is enthusiastic about the opening of the financial futures trading link between Chicago and Singapore.

title: U.P.I. IS COUNTING ON DEEP CUTBACKS IN A DESPERATE STRUGGLE FOR SURVIVAL
description: The management of United Press International is maintaining a gritty optimism that deep pay cuts, layoffs and other economy measures will lead to solvency and assure survival for the worldwide news service, which has lost money for more than 20 years.

title: GREENWICH YOUTH FOUND BURIED WAS STABBED REPEATEDLY
description: A 13-year- old boy whose body was found in a shallow grave here had been repeatedly stabbed, the police said today, adding that they had no leads to the identity of the attacker.

title: Meese Assails Social Security
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, today criticized Social Security as a ''tax and benefit program'' but would not discuss specific plans President Reagan has for the system.

title: Whitbread Talks
description: Whitbread & Company said it was negotiating to acquire the Buckingham wine and liquor distributing business in the United States from the Beatrice Companies.

title: No Headline
description: Hungarian DancesTomorrow will be a day of Hungarian gypsy dance at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street.

title: OUR SCHOOLS AND JAPAN'S 'TURNADOT' FROM VERONA
description: The public schools have captured television's attention, most recently and most spectacularly in a three-hour ABC documentary this week. Inspired by this perhaps, WABC-TV, the network's local affiliate, is giving us ''School Daze: Japan vs. Johnny,'' a two-part ''Eyewitness News'' special of its own. The first half-hour segment will be seen on Channel 7 at 7:30 tomorrow night; the second will be shown Sept. 15.

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $14,058 from discontinued operations.

title: ROSSCOMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
STRAUSS TO FORM MONDALE ADVISER GROUP
description: Walter F. Mondale, moving to stem a tide of pessimism among Democrats about his Presidential candidacy, has asked Robert S. Strauss to form a council of senior party leaders to advise him on campaign strategy.

title: Required Reading; Writing to Congress?
description: Representative Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, in excerpts from a newsletter to his constituents last month, offering a bit of blunt advice for those seeking a share of the Federal largesse:

title: Realtors Spent $6.7 Million On Congress, Study Reports
description: The political action committee of the National Association of Realtors has given $6.7 million to Congressional candidates since 1974, with almost half the money going to current members of Congress, a group opposed to such committees said Wednesday.

title: U.S. HOCKEY TEAM BEATS CZECHS BY 3-2
description: Ed Olczyk has a diary back in Chicago, tucked away in a bureau drawer, dating to July 4, 1983. That day, in a Colorado Springs hotel, the United States named its candidates for the 1984 Olympic hockey team.

title: ; Office of the Chairman Established by Sperry
description: The Sperry Corporation said it had created a four-man office of the chairman. The company said the move was intended to consolidate operations and streamline reporting, administration and control,

title: NEWARK FLIGHT PROPOSALS PROTESTED
description: New Jersey officials today protested a Federal Government proposal for a limit on the number of daily flights at Newark International Airport.

title: CHEMIST FOR EASTMAN KODAK
description: Dr. Arnold Weissberger, a chemist for the Eastman Kodak Company who played a major role in the development of color photography, died of heart disease last Sunday at Genesee Hospital in Rochester. He was 85 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: A COMPANY THAT GETS THE STIFF UPPER LIP OUT OF SHAKESPEARE
description: Tina Packer, the artistic director of Shakespeare & Company, believes that America and American actors today are closer to the England of Shakespeare's day, and to the actors of that era, than modern-day England and British actors are.

title: N.B.A. Abroad
description: The increasing passion for basketball in places other than the United States, notably Europe, has periodically led to speculation that countries like Italy, Spain, France and West Germany could and would support National Basketball Association franchises.

title: ETHIOPIA IS SETTING UP NEW PARTY IN MOVE TO ENTRENCH COMMUNISM
description: Ethiopia moved formally today toward establishment of the country's first Communist Party, which would be the only legal political party here.

title: Iranian Judge Threatens A Swede at The Hague
description: An Iranian judge threatened to kill a Swedish judge today at the international tribunal that is handling claims arising from the Iranian takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979, diplomats said.

title: An Official Role For a Former Jet
description: One glance at the robust-looking man in the khaki and blue striped uniform of United States Open umpires makes it clear that he is an athlete. But few spectators at the Open know that he is a former pro, and perhaps once a hero to many of them.

title: TROUBLED TIME FOR U.S. COPPER INDUSTRY
description: For the United States copper industry, the recent dark days of closed mines and idled workers have just grown darker with the Reagan Administration's decision to deny protection from foreign imports. Some executives and Wall Street analysts who are familiar with copper have asked whether indeed the curtain might not be coming down on the domestic industry.

title: ; Blue Cross Push Its Biggest Ever
description: Because furious competition in the health insurance field is whittling away at its large subscriber rolls, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association in a week will be turning on its most high-powered national advertising effort. And it will get an unusually large amount of support from its 95 member-plan companies.

title: No Headline
description: Cycling in the Bronx

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $75,000 for the latest quarter and $152,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ART: PRINTS TO AMUSE, PROVOKE AND INSTRUCT
description: The thought of yet another mixed show of 20th-century American prints engenders mixed feelings in those who have seen many exhibitions of the kind. There are prints that one cannot see too often, but there are also prints that look too much like hard work, prints that are frankly undervitalized, prints that recycle ideas that work better in painting and prints that have simply worn out their welcome.

title: JAPAN'S YEARS AS HARSH RULER DEEPLY EMBITTERED KOREANS
description: After Japan formally annexed Korea 74 years ago, it went on to ban the use of the Korean language, force Koreans to adopt Japanese names and compel school children to do obeisance at Shinto shrines.

title: THE THORNS OF WAR
description: They call it the War of the Roses, Part II, and it has already lasted seven long years.

title: LEBANESE SEES 'CHEAP' U.S. VALUES IN U.N. VETO
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that the United States exhibited ''cheap values'' when it vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution demanding improved conditions in Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon.

title: BOND PRICES UP MODERATLEY
description: The credit market maintained its upbeat tone yesterday, as fresh signs that the economy is slackening sent bond prices moderately higher after Thursday's sharp rally.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Results for 1984 include a $3,500,000 charge from the discontinuance of certain Crane product lines.

title: The Day-Care Problem Won't Go Away In the words of Edward Zigler, who teaches psychology at Yale, ''It's too bad it takes a sex scandal to make us recognize our problems.''
description: Before sexual abuse was discovered at day-care centers in California and New York, the fact that millions of children must daily be entrusted to strangers seemed to interest mainly their parents. The few people urging a thoughtful approach to the needs of working parents might as well have been hollering down a rain barrel.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; A South African Judge Bans Weekend Protests
description: A South African magistrate placed a ban today on weekend protest meetings in the Johannesburg area. He said such meetings could seriously threaten public order.

title: FRIAR DEFENDS VIEWS AT VATICAN SESSION
description: A Franciscan friar, summoned from Brazil by the Vatican, defended his advocacy of the doctrine known as liberation theology today in a four-hour session with church authorities.

title: U.S. CHALLENGES AGENT ORANGE SUPPLIERS' DEFENSE
description: The Federal Government, after years on the sidelines of the Agent Orange legal case, has moved to counter a key defense of suppliers of the herbicide used in the Vietnam War.

title: PANEL INCREASES RAIL LINE'S COST TO CONNECTICUT
description: An arbitration panel has raised Connecticut's share of the cost of operating the New Haven Line of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad from 50 percent to 60 percent, state transportation officials said today.

title: JOAN MONDALE SERENE IN SUPPORTING ROLE
description: She is the forgotten member of the Democratic quartet.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mears Hurt in Crash
description: Rick Mears , the winner of this year's Indianapolis 500, was listed in stable condition last night after a two- hour operation to close wounds to his feet suffered in a collision at a track outside Montreal yesterday. His car went out of control and collided with one driven by Carrado Fabi of Brazil during a practice run for an Indy-car race tomorrow. Mears, who regained consciousness shortly after being freed from the car, was treated at Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal.

title: JESSE JACKSON TO BE A GUEST HOST
description: Dick Ebersol, the executive producer of ''Saturday Night Live,'' had just found out that his program had agreed to terms with the Rev. Jesse Jackson under which Mr. Jackson would host the program's Oct. 20 segment, and he was excited. Mr. Ebersol said the upcoming 10th season of the program was his chance ''to light things on fire for one last time,'' and this seemed like just the right way to start.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Pohlad , the Minnesota banker who bought the Twins, signed the title papers to take over the team yesterday and also made his first move: He extended the contract of Manager Billy Gardner . . . . The Cosmos have released the defender Wladyslaw Zmuda from his contract so he can return to Poland and help his national team qualify for the 1986 World Cup.

title: JAZZ: SHAW AND COWINGS
description: -jazz singing duo, suggest a more refined, jazz-oriented Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, minus that couple's schmaltz and horseplay. The pair, who appeared with a trio of bass, drums and guitar at the Jazz Center of New York last Thursday, offered an imaginative repertory that ranged from Jerome Kern to bossa nova.

title: U.S. Envoy to Fiji Named
description: President Reagan has named Carl Dillery to be the United States Ambassador to Fiji, the Kingdom of Tonga, Tuvalu and the Republic of Kiribati, the White House announced today. He will replace Fred J. Eckert. Mr. Dillery, a career Foreign Service officer, has previously served in Brussels, London and Nicosia. Since 1982 he has been director of the State Department's Office of United Nations Political Affairs.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Three Ferraro Children Campaign for Democrats
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro's children, making their public speaking debut for the Democratic Party, said today that young people had the most to lose if President Reagan was re-elected.

title: TAKING THE PULSE OF TRUCKING
description: ''You just can't get on the road and run a truck anymore,'' Kenny Benoit, a driver for 18 years, said as he finished his run at the terminal of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation here.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,350,851 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $710,189 for the quarter and $1,426,389 for the year.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:The Super-Weak No-Trump AControversialOpeningBid

title: Judge Postpones CBS Libel Trial
description: A Federal judge has postponed until Oct. 9 the start of the trial of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit against CBS Inc. without ruling on the network's request that the case be dismissed.

title: Creusot-Loire Plan Unravels
description: Three major participants have pulled out of the French Government's planned rescue operation for Creusot-Loire, the country's largest heavy engineering group, which was placed in receivership last June.

title: The Rose Rule
description: The rules of major league baseball specify that a manager is permitted only one free trip to the mound per inning to consult with his pitcher. If he leaves the dugout for a second conversation, the pitcher must be removed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the first page of Weekend yesterday misidentified the designer of the new Charivari boutique at 16 West 57th Street. He was Shigeru Uchida.

title: WALTON ASSAILS JETS' OFFENSE
description: It is Coach Joe Walton who runs the Jets' offense, who sends in all its plays. And today he said that offense ''stunk'' in the 23-17 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers on Thursday night.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Mondale and Ferraro Invited to White House
description: President Reagan has invited Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, to the White House on Tuesday to attend a ceremony honoring the memory of Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: MORTGAGE RATES DIPPED IN AUGUST
description: Mortgage interest rates, which have been climbing since early this year, slipped slightly in August, the Government said today.

title: Catcher Throws Barbs
description: Since his Braves have been lagging in the standing, Joe Torre , the Atlanta manager, has come in for his share of criticism, and now he has drawn some more, from one of his own catchers, Bruce Benedict .

title: Copper Unit Shut
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company said it is temporarily closing its White Pine Copper division in White Pine, Mich. The company cited continuing adverse conditions in the copper market and an inability to negotiate a lower-cost labor contract at the facility, which has been treating scrap copper since the operation was struck in August 1983.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS HIS STATEMENTS
description: President Reagan, leaving the White House for Camp David, accused reporters and his Democratic opponents today of distorting remarks about religion that he made at a Dallas prayer breakfast.

title: 'DAY-CARING' ANTIDOTE TO ANTISOCIAL TRAITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevada Bank Robbers Get Away in Small Plane
description: Two armed bandits landed at a remote airport today and tied up three witnesses, then drove into town, ''cleaned out'' a bank and made a getaway in their private plane.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NOBODY WRITING OFF CONNORS
description: Brett Connors has the sort of unswerving confidence in his father that is fitting in a 5-year-old.

title: Dow Drops 11.48; Early Gains Fade
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday in less-active trading with the large capitalization and technology issues spearheading the decline.

title: Senate to Have Official Flag
description: The Senate today approved a resolution calling for design proposals for a Senate flag. The layout must use the official seal of the Senate, an eagle surrounded by a circle of stars.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE REMAINED STEADY AT 7.4% IN AUGUST
description: The nation's overall unemployment rate held steady at 7.4 percent last month, the level recorded in May and in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Statement Asserts Solidarity Loses Support
description: A statement signed by a fugitive Solidarity leader, Zbigniew Bujak, today challenged Lech Walesa's assertion that the outlawed union is stronger than ever, saying public support is dwindling. Mr. Walesa called the statement a fabrication.

title: A JURIST ON 3 COURTS ON L.I. SINCE 1964
description: Alexander Vitale, a judge for 20 years and a State Supreme Court Justice since 1982, died Wednesday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I., of complications after a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived in Woodbury, L.I.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,499,000 and a loss of $6,931,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,648,000 for the quarter and $50,511,000 for year. d-After gain from discontinued operations of $48,308,000, a loss of $6,931,000 on the sale of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $22,033,000.

title: Debate Talks Adjourned
description: Aides to President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale failed today to reach agreement on a debate between the two Presidential candidates, but the White House Chief of Staff, James A. Baker 3d, said, ''We feel confident there will be debates.'' The Mondale campaign chairman, James A. Johnson, said the two sides had agreed to meet again Monday and then daily until the debate schedule and format was settled.

title: Mancini Suspended
description: The Louisiana Boxing Commission has suspended Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini and his manager, Dave Wolf , for 60 days for failing to tell it that he might have to pull out of a scheduled fight because of a cut over his eye.

title: CHINA SHARPLY WARNS U.S. ON TEXTILE CURBS
description: China today made its strongest threat yet of retaliation against American farmers if the United States imposes new restrictions on textile imports announced on Aug. 3.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ISRAELI UNITY TALKS REPORTED TO FUEL TURMOIL IN THE RANKS
description: An agreement over a bipartisan government reached by the leaders of Israel's two major political blocs was reported today to be causing deep dismay in the ranks of their respective parties and among traditional coalition partners.

title: CHICAGO ISSUES A BAN ON SELLING LEADED GAS
description: A citywide ban on sales of leaded gasoline, believed to be the first in the nation, was adopted Thursday and was immediately hailed by environmentalists as an ''incredibly important step'' toward cleaning the air. But gasoline dealers said they would go to court to stop it.

title: No Headline
description: Villella, Charging Libel, Sues Eglevsky Ballet

title: A Poll Tax on Textiles
description: If sweaters cost a lot more next year, blame Senator Jesse Helms. Or blame President Reagan, whose election-year favor to the North Carolina Republican arbitrarily changed the Byzantine rules governing apparel imports. The best hope now is that the new policy will be delayed until after the November election, when the White House may be more inclined to look at the economic merits of the issue.

title: ASBESTOS REMOVAL: DRUDGERY AND HIGH TECH
description: As in a crude science-fiction film, the removal of asbestos from buildings involves a combination of the ordinary and the fantastic, of old-fashioned elbow grease and high technology.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $456,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $598,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9 months net loss reflects the reversal, as a result of new tax legislation, of $1.5 million of deferred taxes previously provided on the undistributed earnings of its domestic international sales corporation.

title: GOODEN PITCHES 1-HITTER AND STRIKES OUT 11 CUBS
description: Dwight Gooden was so good last night the entire Chicago Cubs' lineup got fewer hits than he did.

title: 'LEMON LAW' ONE YEAR LATER
description: NEW YORK STATE'S new-car ''lemon law'' - requiring dealers to reimburse customers who are sold defective automobiles - went into effect a year ago this month. Consumer advocates, industry representatives and lawmakers all say it seems to be working.

title: FILM: 'THE LAST WINTER,' WAITING BY WAR WIVES
description: What would happen if - in the midst of war - each of two women identified the same man, seen in grainy news film of prisoners, as her husband?

title: Woman, 44, Slain At Parkway Stop
description: A Toms River woman was shot to death and her husband knocked unconscious early today in a picnic area on the Garden State Parkway, according to the police.

title: NEW U.S. CURBS ON FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: The Treasury, moving to close off opportunities for tax evasion, announced this evening that it would no longer permit United States securities to be repackaged and sold in unregistered form to foreigners.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $24,156 for the quarter and $2,442,236 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $12,543 for the quarter and $260,523 for 9 months.

title: Sentencing on Reagan Home LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (AP) - A man who pleaded guilty to trying to defraud President Reagan in the sale of his suburban Pacific Palisades home was sentenced Thursday to three years' probation and to pay an unspecified amount of restitution.
description: The man's wife was ordered by Judge Everett Ricks of Superior Court to undergo 90 days of psychiatric tests before being sentenced, said Deputy District Attorney Al Botello.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1984
description: International

title: VAN GOGH TREASURES ARRIVE AT MET
description: With the excitement of a christening and with security precautions elaborate enough to satisfy a bank, the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday began unpacking 146 paintings and drawings by Vincent van Gogh.

title: MONDALE EXPLAINS ROLE FOR RELIGION
description: Seeking to calm doubts in the Bible Belt, Walter F. Mondale today said he believed religion and morality were linked with politics and described his political career as an expression of his Christian faith.

title: SOVIET POET DENOUNCES FILM ENTRY
description: The 41st Venice Film Festival closed today in a storm of polemics as the Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko charged that one of the films in competition presented ''a sentimental heroization of Fascism.''

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES TAKE A BELTING
description: The recent decision in New Jersey Supreme Court holding a party host liable for guests who get involved in drunken driving accidents is the culmination of a disturbing national trend. Increasingly, and usually at the expense of civil liberties, well- meaning legislators are enacting laws that relieve individuals of responsibility for their own actions.

title: A Gift in Memory Of an Old Home
description: Evan M. Frankel was touched when

title: BRIEFING;
description: Respect for the West

title: 1 WOUNDED
description: A police officer was shot in the hand yesterday when he and two other officers mistakenly exchanged gunfire during a search for a purse snatcher in an abandoned Bronx apartment building, a police spokesman said.

title: Wake Up Fans, Football Is On
description: -fall weather has kept fans outdoors, maybe American viewers got a sports overdose watching the Olympics, or maybe a genuinely long-term decline is developing in pro football's television ratings. Whatever the reason, a large number of fans stayed away from their sets when the National Football League opened its season this week.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH ON 3 RUNS IN NINTH
description: The Yankees and Red Sox have already played their way out of any pennant fight, but their struggle tonight, with Fenway Park full and the chilly air signaling autumn's approach, was reminiscent of so many bygone Septembers when Boston, New York and baseball meant far more than just another game.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Pacific Lighting Tie Backed by Presley
description: The Presley Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Pacific Lighting Corporation in an exchange of stock. Based on Pacific Lighting's closing price of $33.375 a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the deal has an indicated value of about $98.3 million.

title: SOVIET PRISIONER FOR 18 YEARS
description: Josyf Cardinal Slipyj, the Major Archbishop of the Ukrainians who spent 18 years in Soviet prison camps until the Vatican obtained his release from the Russians, died here today. He was 92 years old.

title: Boston Arsonist to Testify
description: A man who called himself ''Mr. Flare'' to boast of his membership in an arson ring will testify against five men accused of setting 163 fires to spur Fire Department hiring, United States Attorney Mark E. Robinson says. Gregg M. Bemis, 23 years old, pleaded guilty Thursday to 68 conspiracy counts in 46 of the 1982 and 1983 fires.

title: FLUTIE AND KOSAR FACE TOUGH RIVALS
description: The two players who may be the leading quarterback candidates for the 1984 Heisman Trophy - Doug Flutie of Boston College and Bernie Kosar of Miami - will face major tests today on the first big weekend of college football.

title: MEXICO REPORTS ACCORD TO EASE DEBT PAYMENTS
description: Mexico announced today that it had reached agreement with its bank advisory group to stretch out repayment of much of its $66 billion in public debt over 14 years at lower interest rates.

title: FRINGE BENEFITS AND NEW LAW
description: -called cafeteria

title: NEW AMSTERDAM NEWS (OR OLDS)
description: Today marks the 320th anniversary of the Dutch surrender of New Amsterdam. On that morning in 1664, Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch Governor General of New Amsterdam, gave up the city without a fight to the Duke of York, after whom the city was soon renamed.

title: ROYALS WINBY 5-4; BALBONI HITS NO. 22
description: Steve Balboni, making his first start in 10 days, hit a towering three- run homer tonight to lead the Kansas City Royals to a 5-4 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: IRANIAN OFFENSIVE REPORTED ON HOLD
description: A senior Iranian official with close ties to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has suggested that Iran's long-planned ''final offensive'' against Iraq may not take place anytime soon.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1984 International Mexico's foreign debt payments will be extended over 14 years at lower interest rates under an agreement reached by the Government with its bank advisory group. The agreement, would constitute the most flexible restructuring of foreign obligations thus far granted to a Latin American debtor country. (Page 1, Column 5.) Four Cuban military advisers died last Saturday during a Nicaraguan rebel air raid in which two private American citizens were also killed, senior Reagan Administration officials asserted. They said the Cubans were killed in the rebel attack on a military training school in Santa Clara, near the Honduran border, that serves as a center for Cuban advisers in Nicaragua. (1:2.)

title: SURVEY FINDS HISPANIC GROUPS MORE UNIFIED
description: Regional and cultural differences among the various ethnic groups known as Hispanic Americans are becoming less distinct, making them a more solid ethnic group, according to a major new study.

title: TRYING TO SOLVE THE CITIES' LINGERING PROBLEMS
description: In the summer of 1967, as one big city after another erupted in riots, an array of national leaders convened here to develop a prescription to prevent future outbreaks of urban violence.

title: Anna Wintour Is Wed To a Child Psychiatrist
description: Anna Wintour, creative director at Vogue magazine, was married yesterday to Dr. David Shaffer, chief of the child psychiatry department at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and the New York State Psychiatric Institute. Judge Elliott Wilk of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan home.

title: Drug Charges Fought
description: Scott Skiles , now a Michigan State basketball star, was named the most valuable player on the Plymouth, Mich., high school team that won the state championship in 1982, but now Skiles says the townspeople who once cheered him on are shunning him because of drug charges brought against him last week. ''A lot of people I've known my whole life have turned on me,'' said Skiles, 20 years old, who is fighting the charges.

title: THE 49th PARALLEL
description: The 49th Parallel Starring Eric Portman, Anton Walbrook, Raymond Massey, Laurence Olivier, Leslie Howard; co-written by Emeric Pressburger and directed by Michael Powell VidAmerica 121 minutes. $59.95

title: The Soft Touch
description: An artificial surface whose manufacturer says provides enough ''give'' to reduce knee injuries will get its first major test today when Oregon's football team plays host to Long Beach State.

PATENTS;

title: TOWN PAYS LITTLE MIND TO EXECUTIONS
description: In the small public library in Starke, which, with the Women's Club across the street and the Post Office, forms a civic center of sorts, a slim file folder holds all the written history of this northern Florida town.

title: JOE CRONIN, AN EX-EXECUTIVE AND STAR PLAYER IN BASEBALL
description: Joe Cronin, the soft-spoken bank clerk-turned-shortstop who spent 20 sparkling years as a major league player and player-manager and later served two terms as president of the American League, died yesterday at his home in Osterville, Mass.

title: Milacron Unit
description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc. said its semiconductor materials subsidiary plans a $39 million expansion of its plant near Maineville, Ohio.

title: NAVRATILOVA WILL FACE LLOYD
description: This is not the United States Open, or at least it isn't for women. That was clear late yesterday afternoon when, after 11 days, 126 matches and 282 sets, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd proved conclusively what has been apparent for some time: that the pinnacle of women's tennis is very much closed to all but them.

title: Murderer of 8 Nurses Is Denied Parole Again
description: Richard Speck, serving a sentence of up to 1,200 years in prison for murdering eight student nurses in their dormitory townhouse, today was denied parole for the fifth time.

title: New High School RuleProhibits All Drugs
description: Students at a high school where new rules ban all drugs say the policy is ''kind of a pain,'' but administrators say it shows students that ''we care.''

title: POSTAL PANEL RECOMMENDS 22C FOR A FIRST-CLASS STAMP
description: The independent Postal Rate Commission today recommended raising the price of a first-class stamp to 22 cents from 20 cents as part of a $2.2 billion rate increase affecting most classes of mail.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: A.T.& T. Adding To '800' Service
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was preparing to extend its toll-free ''800'' service across the Atlantic Ocean to France.

description: The American Civil Liberties Union went to court today to overturn a new city ban on singers, break dancers, jugglers, mimes and other street performers.

title: Panel Issues Revco Report
description: A special committee of outside directors of Revco D. S. Inc., which investigated possible flaws in the company's purchasing operations, reported that none of the business decisions involved had ''a material financial impact on the company.''

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Settlement in Bias Suit May Be Scrapped
description: A tentative settlement reached last week in the school district's 28-year-old desegregation suit is in trouble and a Federal judge has ordered lawyers to be ready for trial Monday.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $200,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $301,552 from discontinued operations.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Reagan Schedules Visit To Upstate New York
description: President Reagan will campaign in New York State and Tennessee next week, appearing before groups of the elderly, Italian-Americans and Polish-Americans, touring high-technology facilities and paying an 81st birthday tribute to Roy Acuff, the country singer.

title: WINNING PAYOFF
description: Horseplayers, it is widely held, are supposed to live and die either broke or down to their last dollar. Lost souls, wandering through a life they cannot love, they shuffle through dingy race tracks like the undead, their twisted brains clouded with odds and payoffs, always scheming for the big score that is denied them time and again.

title: Fed Intervention Disclosed The foreign exchange markets grew so disorderly in late May in response to worries over the stability of the United States banking system that the Federal Reserve was forced to intervene, spending $135 million in one day to shore up the United States dollar, the Fed said yesterday in its semiannual report to Congress.
description: The intervention, which took place on May 24, came in the wake of the widely publicized funding problems at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and at a time when concern over the health of other major banks was spreading.

title: Roses for Liberty's Torch
description: New Yorkers don't see much of the Statue of Liberty these days. It is surrounded by 300 tons of scaffolding as part of the refurbishing for its centennial in 1986.

description: ''Oh, what do women talk about? She liked my new red dress.

title: FINALLY, A LENIN STATUE TO OUTDO ALL LENIN STATUES
description: Lev Y. Kerbel, a sculptor, drew his first portrait of Lenin at the age of 6, and he has continued ever since.

title: CHANGE IN SOVIET COMMAND: DIPLOMATS CALL IT A DISMISSAL
description: Diplomats studying the announcement of Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov's replacement as Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces leaned increasingly today to the conclusion that he had been dismissed.

title: AbductionSuspect Gave False Name
description: The police said yesterday that they had given out an incorrect name for the man who was arrested Wednesday and charged with abducting a 15- year-old girl and trying to abduct a woman in Astoria, Queens, last Sunday. The man is also a suspect in the rape of a 4-year-old girl that day.

title: Steel Price Rise
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise the price of steel rail by $15 to $20 a ton, or about 3 percent.

SLAYER REFUSES TO SIGN PAROLE PLAN ON COAST
description: Theodore Streleski, who murdered his faculty adviser while he was a graduate student at Stanford University, remained in prison today after refusing to sign papers agreeing to the conditions of his parole.

title: Margaret Leach Bride Of Joseph Paul Scalise
description: In the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday Margaret Leach, a daughter of David E. Leach Jr. of Neptune City, N.J., and the late Mary Sullivan Leach, was married to Joseph Paul Scalise, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Scalise of Valley Stream, L.I. The Rev. Louis Gioia performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: PIKE PLACE MARKET A SEATTLE TREASURE
description: Bushels of Walla Walla onions for $1 a pound, row upon row of neatly tied and stacked fresh Dungeness crabs, each as sweet as a Maine lobster but only $3.89 a pound, bunches of yellow squash blossoms just waiting to be stuffed. What Easterners consider costly luxuries shoppers at the Pike Place Market in Seattle take for granted.

title: ILLINOIS SENATE RIVALS FOCUS ON REAGAN
description: Senator Charles H. Percy and Representative Paul Simon today had the first direct public confrontation of their fall campaign for the Senate, and the results seemed to indicate the contest would largely be a referendum on President Reagan.

title: ;  Letter: On Whaling ; Japan Should Retire Its Harpoon
description: To the Editor:

title: Bolivia Accuses Colonel Of Organizing Coup Plot
description: Bolivian officials accused a retired colonel today of organizing a rightist plot to attempt a coup this weekend.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PET PEEVES Millions of unpopular residents will leave New York City forever.'' That's the promise of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which is having a dog wash and de-flea event today at its facilities at 441 East 92d Street, near York Avenue, from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Home Products Corp . said it had completed the sale of its Ekco Housewares operations to a group led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, an investment banking firm, and its Ekco Products businesses to a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Net income for the year-ago quarter includes an extraordinary credit of 11 cents a share.

title: DISNEY'S CHIEF IS FORCED OUT
description: Ronald W. Miller, a son-in-law of the late Walt Disney, ended his 18-month tenure as president and chief executive of Walt Disney Productions today, resigning under pressure from the company's directors.

title: COURT PERMITS CUOMO TO PROCEED WITH HIS PLAN TO REGISTER VOTERS
description: A state appeals court, rejecting Republican contentions of ''irreparable harm,'' cleared at least a temporary path yesterday for Governor Cuomo's plan to use state offices and employees to help register new voters.

title: Ex-Miss America Sues Over Photos
description: Vanessa Williams, who relinquished her Miss America crown in July after sexually explicit pictures of her appeared in Penthouse magazine, has sued the photographer who took the shots, her attorney said today.

title: WHY ROIL BISTATE WATERS?
description: A New York-New Jersey feud is roiling political waters in Washington, threatening passage of several amendments to the Clean Water Act. Since New York and New Jersey are among the principal beneficiaries of the pending legislation and stand to lose the most if the act is not strengthened this year, the dispute is self-defeating and ought to be resolved immediately.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE PROBLEM OF MAKING RESTITUTION FIT THE CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: DRESSING FOR WORK: NOW A SOFTER LOOK
description: In the 1970's, as women entered business and professional fields in increasing numbers, taking jobs usually held by men, they tended to dress severely. It was the era of the man- tailored suit as women tried to blend into the background of their work places and not be distinctive.

title: JOBLESS RATES DECREASE IN NEW YORK AND JERSEY
description: Unemployment in New York City, New York State and New Jersey declined last month, but their economies showed ''less zip'' than early in the year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: THOUGHTS OF AN INFIDEL
description: One of the leading knights in Ronald Reagan's ''religious'' crusade is the Rev. Wally Amos Criswell, senior pastor of the First Baptist Church of Dallas and a pillar of the New Right.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MIKADO' OPENS IN A NEW STAGING
description: Long before ''Pacific Overtures,'' before even ''Madama Butterfly,'' Gilbert and Sullivan bequeathed us a piece of neo-Japanese musical theater. It's called ''The Mikado,'' and since its premiere in 1885 - a century ago this season - it has counted as the most popular of all the Savoyard canon.

title: No Headline
description: Dali's Condition Weak Despite Skin Grafts

title: THE KEY TO POLICE TESTS: STUDY, STUDY AND STUDY
description: They are disappointed, they are frustrated and they are distressed that, because of controversy and litigation, another half a dozen years may go by before they can try again.

title: COMPANY'S SIX TURBULENT MONTHS
description: -year-old son of Disney's co-founder, resigned as a director, citing personal reasons for his departure.

title: Crime Rate Drops In Connecticut
description: Crimes against persons increased in Connecticut during the second quarter of 1984, compared with the same period in 1983, but the overall crime rate dropped 10 percent because of a large decrease in crimes such as burglary and larceny, according to state police records.

title: SPLIT FEARED IN SALVADOR ON CHURCH'S SOCIAL ROLE
description: The Vatican's criticism of liberation theology, expressed most recently in a major document made public last Monday in Rome, could have an especially sharp impact in El Salvador, according to Roman Catholic Church officials here.

title: JAPAN SEES NEED TO END NORTH KOREAN 'ISOLATION'
description: The Prime Minister of Japan told South Korea's President Friday that efforts must be made to end North Korea's ''isolation'' if there is to be stability on the Korean peninsula.

title: ON RATIONING NEW IDEAS IN HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE KINGDOM'S MAGIC FADES
description: The magic kingdom of Walt Disney Productions, an entertainment empire that enriched generations of children as well as investors, has found itself shaken by corporate raiders and the changing tastes of a maturing audience.

title: BAN ON PARKING TO BE ENFORCED AROUND WALL ST.
description: City officials are counting on the color blue to reduce the struggle between cars and delivery trucks in lower Manhattan for what little parking space exists on the narrow, twisting streets laid out in the days of New Amsterdam.

title: Moore Judgment
description: The Moore Corporation Ltd. said a court judgment that might total about $27 million, plus attorneys' fees, had been awarded against its Moore Business Forms subsidiary in a patent infringement suit brought by the Scott Paper Company.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Cubs come back with their ace, Rick Sutcliffe, whose 13-1 record has made him a prime candidate for the Cy Young Award. Walt Terrell goes for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Rain on Forecasters' Picnic
description: Whitecaps broke on the usually placid Lake Washington beach, rain beat on the tops of empty park shelters and temperatures were in the 50's.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FEW BLACKS IN REAGAN CROWDS
description: The ''shining city'' of America oft envisioned by President Reagan seemed finally to loom up before him this week in the shimmering walls of a mirror-windowed suburban industrial park in Orange County, California.

title: TWO QUIT AT CHICAGO TRADE UNIT
description: The president and executive vice president of the clearing house of the Chicago Board of Trade resigned suddenly Thursday for what were described as ''personal reasons.''

title: Pay'n Save Board Backs Acquisition
description: The Pay'n Save Corporation said its board had approved the company's acquisition for $22.50 a share by a group of investors led by the Trump Group of New York and a number of senior Pay'n Save executives. The company said the total value of the transaction is about $355 million.

title: Watch the Ball, Not the Dome
description: The vague yearnings to build a domed stadium in New York City are to get their first serious analysis next week. Indoor football sounds romantic, but New Yorkers need to keep their feet on the ground.

title: FAIR DISMISSED 165 WORKERS AFTER BUDGET IS CUT BY 35% NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 7 (AP) - Officials of the poorly attended World's Fair dismissed 165 employees today and promised ''major changes'' in response to a 35 percent budget cut ordered by Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana. The fair employs about 2,300 people.
description: The Governor, who has estimated the fair's debt at $130 million, ordered officials Thursday to cut the fair's weekly operating budget to $1.5 million from $2.3 million.

title: Winslow Case
description: The San Diego Chargers may place Kellen Winslow on the ''reserved-left squad'' list at any time starting today, an action that would mean the all-pro tight end could not play again this season. Winslow, in a contract dispute, left the Chargers after their opener last Sunday, saying he had ''retired.''

title: Letter$
description: Tet

title: 4 Nonnuclear Containers Retrieved in North Sea
description: Salvage workers retrieved four empty containers today from a French freighter that sank off Belgium two weeks ago with 450 tons of radioactive cargo, an official said.

title: Ratings Point Revised
description: Until this week, a ratings point counted for - according to the A. C. Nielsen Company - 1 percent of the 83.8 million households in the United States with television sets.

title: MINOR PARTIES PLAN PRESIDENTIAL RACES
description: The Democrats and Republicans ran four-day extravaganzas to pick their Presidential candidates, but three minor parties in New York will nominate theirs at four-hour meetings and with little public notice.

title: TROUBLESOME ABORTION ISSUE: THEOLOGICAL ROOTS ARE SPREAD WIDE AND DEEP
description: The issue of abortion, which has emerged so heatedly in the Presidential campaign, has been arousing disputes for hundreds of years, and the grounds of disagreement have not changed much.

title: Police Link Knife To Boy's Slaying
description: The police said today that they had found a 10 1/2-inch kitchen knife that they believe was the weapon used to kill a 13-year-old boy whose body was uncovered in a shallow grave here this week.

title: THE COMPUTER MAGAZINE GLUT
description: Much as the business it covers, the computer magazine industry is in the midst of a shakeout that has already eliminated several publications and is likely to wipe out all but the strongest within a year, according to publishing experts.

title: No Headline
description: Jazz in the Afternoon

title: COURT BAR TO CALIFORNIA VOTE ON A BUDGET PLAN IS UPHELD
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court today turned down a request to let Californians vote in November on a voter-initiated referendum calling for their state to support a budget-balancing amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: A DEPUTY PREMIER IN MOSCOW IS GIVEN ELABORATE FUNERAL
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and a fellow Politburo member, Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, led mourners for Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Kostandov today at an elaborate Red Square funeral not normally accorded officials of Mr. Kostandov's rank.

title: Bass Family Gets Interfirst Stake
description: The Interfirst Corporation said it had been informed by the Bass family of Fort Worth that they and other entities had acquired 2,674,300 shares of Interfirst common stock and $11.5 million of Interfirst convertible subordinated debentures for investment purposes. Interfirst, based in Dallas, is the largest bank holding company in Texas and has about 66.9 million shares outstanding.

title: STOCK OF ABC DECLINES
description: Shares of the American Broadcasting Companies, which shot up more than $8 during two days of takeover speculation, eased more than $3 yesterday amid doubts that a buyout was imminent.

title: RESDEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY 4 CUBANS DIED IN NICARAGUA AIR RAID LAST WEEK
description: Four senior Cuban military advisers in Nicaragua were killed last Saturday during a Nicaraguan rebel air raid in which two private American citizens died, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: FATHER WHO MURDERED 2 OF HIS CHILDREN EXECUTED
description: Ernest John Dobbert, who said he had been abused by his own father, was executed today for the first-degree torture-murder of his 9-year-old daughter.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION ; STUDENTS WALK OUT AS TEACHERS STRIKE
description: Students at Somerville (N.J.) High School walked out of classes yesterday to protest what a union spokesman called a ''lack of a quality education program'' during a strike by teachers.

title: BRIEFING;
description: Getting the Message

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Quick thinking by a patron of Hershey's restaurant recently saved Herman Aronowitz from an afternoon of embarrassment. Mr. Aronowitz had the misfortune to spill some lunch on his necktie and yelled to a waiter for some seltzer to remove the spot. Hearing the distress call, Alex Weinig, a nearby diner, whipped out a pair of scissors and cut Mr. Aronowitz's tie in half, instantly removing the spot.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-After losses from the closing of the company's Quebec plant of $605,000 for the quarter and $650,000 for the year.

title: NEW STUDENTS GET A TASTE OF THE CITY
description: New York City can be a daunting place, especially for college freshmen from out of town.

title: BIG ROT CANDY LESSON
description: While President Reagan tours the country with his Pious Pete number, all about his passion for prayer and high-collar morality, the moral rot in America's candy stores proceeds at a disgusting pace.

title: MEESE NOMINATION PUT ASIDE FOR '84 BY SENATE PANEL
description: The nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General will not be considered by the Senate this year, an aide to the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today.

title: JACKSON JOINS CAROLNA LEADERS IN A CALL FOR UNITY
description: Joining an array of white and black political figures in South Carolina, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today exhorted a crowd on the lawn iat the State Capitol to unite behind Democratic candidates so that ''the South will rise again - but this time together.''

title: COASTAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public July 11 and therefore no share earnings were reported.

title: Bessie Jones Is Dead at 82; Founded Sea Island Singers
description: Bessie Jones, the folk performer who organized the Sea Island Singers, died Tuesday of complications from leukemia at Glynn-Brunswick Memorial Hospital here. She was 82 years old.

description: Mayor Koch may have missed the

description: DALLAS

description: To the Editor:

title: RAIL AND DOCK UNREST EASES IN BRITAIN AS COAL TALKS REOPEN
description: Rail unions canceled a national campaign of disruptions, and a two-week-old dock strike showed signs of crumbling today. But officials said there appeared to be little hope that weekend negotiations would end Britain's six-month-old coal strike.

title: Data Bank; September 9, 1984
THE NATION ; Tinkering WithDeregulation
description: The airlines may need a little regulation to get deregulation back on a smooth course, the Reagan Administration warned last week. With airport delays surging, the Federal Aviation Administration told the airlines to spread out flights at six busy airports, or face Government control of scheduling.

title: LETTERS
description: Distributors

title: Aggravated Tooth Robbery
description: Aaron Isom has been charged with robbery after ordering a man at gunpoint to remove and hand over a false tooth, the authorities said. Mr. Isom, 19 years old, was freed on $2,500 bond Thursday after his arraignment for aggravated robbery. He allegedly threatened to shoot Todd Montgomery, 20, unless Mr. Montgomery used pliers to remove the tooth and give it to Mr. Isom. Police Chief Bryce Acheson said Mr. Isom may have wanted to punish Mr. Montgomery for an outstanding debt.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: No Headline
description: JEWISH LIFE UNDER ISLAM Jerusalem in the Sixteenth Century. By Amnon Cohen. 267 pp. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. $30.

title: THE NATION ; A 'Hit List'For E.P.A.
description: Critics who complain that the Reagan Administration is overly sensitive to industry pressure got a fresh batch of ammunition last week. In 1981, the White House sent along to the Environmental Protection Agency a list of career officials that the Chamber of Commerce of the United States wanted sacked, according to a Congressional document released last month.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: As part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series, Channel 13 and 49 will telecast an especially interesting event Wednesday from 8 to 10 P.M. This is part of a Bach fesstival, in honor of the 300th anniversary of the composer's birth, presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall.

title: ISRAELI CLASHES WITH AMERICAN JEW ABOUT PERSECUTION PAST AND PRESENT
description: An Israeli official and an American whose parents met in a Nazi concentration camp have clashed in New York City during the last few months over such profoundly sensitive issues as the lessons to be drawn from the Holocaust, the attitudes of Jews in the diaspora toward Israel and the ethical obligations of Jews to non-Jewish victims of injustice.

title: WHERE B MEANS BRUTAL
description: These are the actresses of ''Silent Madness,'' a 3-D horror movie to be released in October. It is a film that features strangling, scalding, stabbing and a slow death by repeated discharges of a carpenter's nail gun.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday about foster families, the telephone number for the county's Department of Social Services was given incorrectly. For information about becoming a foster parent, call the department at 285- 5491.

title: HOW TO MAKE A NAME IN LITERATURE
description: EDMUND GOSSE

title: REAGAN'S THE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON

title: 'WOP-BOP' IS NOISY BUT UNCONVINCING
description: AFTER a series of misbegotten musicals and revues, the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport has shot back to life, if not focus, with ''Wop-Bop a-Loo-Bop a-Loop Bam-Boom!'' A compendium of a couple of decades worth of pop music, the revue is an all-out musical assault that pauses, every now and again, in search of theatrical validity.

title: EUROPE DIVIDED
description: A. W. DePorte is a former director of research on Western Europe in the State Department. His most recent book is ''Europe Between the Superpowers: The Enduring Balance.'' THE MARSHALL PLAN

title: YANKS, ON 15 HITS, SINK RED SOX, 12-6
description: Success comes easily for the Yankees these days, and the hits come by the dozen - or more - especially at Fenway Park.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WE MUST PROTECT OUR WATER NOW
description: FOR the last few months, the Northeast has had record- breaking rainfall. Rivers and streams have overflowed their banks and reservoirs have been at peak levels. The fear of drought, with its water-rationing, job layoffs and manufacturing cutbacks, has been replaced by a cry for Federal flood assistance.

title: SURPLUS AN ISSUE IN RACES
description: HARTFORD THE rising tide of black ink on the state's ledgers began spilling over last week onto the fall campaigns for control of the General Assembly.

title: Photo Licenses: Cons and Cons
description: -identification drivers licenses ''would be more valuable in identification for business transactions and for anyone cashing a check.''

title: ARITIFICIAL SEAWEED VS. EROSION
description: AN experimental program using artificial seaweed to prevent beach erosion is expected to begin soon in ocean waters off Fire Island Pines, a summer resort community of 4,000 on the barrier beach, where storms last winter seriously eroded portions of the sandy coastline.

title: FOREST FIRES: NATURE'S CLEANSING ACT
description: McGINNIS MEADOWS, Mont. - Granny Persian first realized something was wrong when dusk fell far too soon on her isolated log cabin near here. ''The air smelled dirty,'' she recalled, ''and there was a roar, like a jet plane coming closer all the time.''

title: 2 RACES ARE FOCUS OF COLORADO VOTE
description: Lieut. Gov. Nancy Dick and an Alamosa lawyer will compete in Tuesday's primary election for the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator William L. Armstrong, a Republican.

title: PRESIDENTIAL SEASON STARTS ON A HIGH NOTE
description: TRENTON AS vacationers were having their last taste of sun and surf along New Jersey beaches over the Labor Day weekend, planes flew overhead with a reminder that the Presidential campaign season is beginning in earnest.

title: THE NATION ; Senate HearingFor Meese IsOff for '84
description: Even if a special prosecutor should say there is no further reason to investigate Edwin Meese 3d, the Senate apparently won't take up his nomination as Attorney General this year. Last week, amid a flurry of conflicting reports about the status of the prosecutor's inquiry of Mr. Meese's personal finances, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee scratched the nomination from his panel's agenda.

title: THE FALL SCHEDULE FOR COURSES IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: John Durniak is a photographic writer and critic. The New York City area will be offering a greater variety of photographic courses than it has in previous years. Spurred by increased student interest, the number of evening classes, workshops and seminars has increased and the subjects have expanded in scope.

title: Mears Out 6 Months
description: Rick Mears, the two-time Indy driving champion who was injured a practice-run crash outside Montreal Friday, was listed in fair condition yesterday, but doctors said his injuries, including a cerebral contusion and severe fractures of both feet, would keep him out of racing for about six months. The 31-year-old Mears was tuning up at the Sanair Super Speedway in St. Pie, Quebec, for a 300-kilometer race today when he lost control of his car and slammed into the inside guardrail.

title:
ANTIQUES VIEW;
AMERICANA ON PARADE
description: Americana and 20th-century design continue to dominate the antiques scene, judging by the museum and gallery exhibitions and antiques shows scheduled for the months ahead.

title: ON EASY TERMS WITH GHOSTS
description: Clark Blaise's latest book is ''Lusts,'' a novel. He is the author of several collections of short fiction, two novels, and has co-edited four volumes of Canadian short stories. THE OXFORD BOOK OF FRENCH- CANADIAN SHORT STORIES

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HELPING PEOPLE 'HEAR'
description: MOUNT KISCO NICKY and Emily were acting up. Nicky was barking, circling the coffee table, pouncing on a little red, white and blue rubber barbell. Emily was trying to grab the toy from Nicky.

title: NATION'S NO. 1 CONCERN, BUT POLITICS BLURS FACTS
description: No one disputes that drug abuse has a devastating effect on American society. But the politics of drug abuse often make it difficult to know just how severe the problem really is.

title: EX-SECRETARY ON 'CRUSADE'
description: GREENWICH SECRETARIES of the world, take heart. Mary Bridget Carroll is spreading the word. Fed up with bosses who called her ''sweetie,'' disgusted by the managers who took credit for her ideas, the 39-year-old Greenwich secretary-turned-executive has done what any self-respecting person seeking revenge does: She wrote a book and took her campaign onto the talk-show circuit.

title: CROWDS REACH OUT TO TOUCH FERRARO
description: Wherever she has appeared in the last several weeks, in cities as diverse as pristine Eugene, Ore., and bustling St. Louis, Geraldine A. Ferraro has attracted large and effusive crowds that cheer with appreciation and want to reach out and touch her.

title: BEST SELLERS Sept. 9, 1984

title: A MISS AMERICA WHO DEMURRED

title: PARTY OFFICIALS TRY TO COPE WITH AIMLESS SOVIET YOUTH
description: ''I scan my whole past in memory and involuntarily wonder: Why did I live, for what purpose was I born? And yet that purpose must have existed, and my destination must have been a lofty one, for I feel, in my soul, boundless strength. But I did not divine that destination, I became enticed by the lure of hollow and thankless passions.''

title: Contracting Out Discrimination According to a judge in New York's Supreme Court, Mayor Koch may not on his own authority require private agencies subsidized by New York City to pledge nondiscrimination against homosexuals. However desirable, the judge ruled, such a social policy must be created legislatively by the City Council.
description: The ruling accords with other recent court decisions but hardly resolves the issue. The city should not have to tolerate discrimination by its contract agencies.

title: THE WORKING MOTHER AS ROLE MODEL

''That's Mommy's dress,'' he says with total confidence. When asked what jobs mothers can do, 9-year-old Andrew responds that mothers can be lawyers, cops and presidents - and, as an afterthought, that fathers can be lawyers, cops and presidents, too.

title: Oh So Sure They're Right This is what President Reagan said to a prayer breakfast in Dallas last month: People who resist the imposition of prayer in public schools are ''attacking religion'' and frustrating the will ''of the great majority of Americans.''
description: This is what he said to a B'nai B'rith convention in Washington last week: The Constitution ''makes sure that every single American is free to choose and practice his or her religious beliefs or to choose no religion at all. Their rights shall not be questioned or violated by the state.''

This is why most new models make their debut at summer's end.

Men have raised sleeping to an art form, doing it in front of wide-awake women all the time.

title: Ryca Jackson Is Bride Of Ronald C.-M. Shih

title: SHOULD AMERICA FORGIVE SAMUEL JOHNSON?
description: SAMUEL JOHNSON is the only British author, as far as I know, to have been burned in effigy on American soil - in Massachusetts, in 1775, in response to his pamphlet ''Taxation No Tyranny.'' When the 200th anniversary of Johnson's death is commemorated later this year (he died in December 1784) it is unlikely that anyone will want to dwell for very long on his dealings with America. They are generally assumed to represent his Toryism at its most pigheaded and least rewarding; Joseph Wood Krutch, in his biography of Johnson, strikes the appropriate note of embarrassment when he describes ''Taxation No Tyranny'' as ''the most unfortunate of his literary productions.'' Yet mistakes can be instructive, especially the mistakes of a great man - and even when Johnson is wrong, what he writes almost always has a valuable residue of truth in it.

title: Troubled News Service Replaces Its President
description: United Press International announced today that William J. Small has been ''terminated'' as president and chief operating officer of the financially troubled news agency and replaced by Luis G. Nogales, its general manager.

title: THE REGION ; Turnpike TerrorIn Connecticut
description: Those who thought that driving on the Connecticut Turnpike couldn't get any worse thought again last week. The third sniper attack on a 20- mile stretch of Interstate 95 in Fairfield County in less than a month raised fears, while lane closings caused by cracks in the Yankee Doodle Bridge in Norwalk brought frustration.

He collected two Grammy awards for his efforts, and became, if not a household word, a recognized name and face.

title: COMEDIES DWINDLE, DETECTIVES MULTIPLY
description: Television loves a genre and by imitating ad infinitum, usually commits genrecide, killing off whatever it was that was pleasurable about the progenitor. That's why so many viewers though they would find relief in cable television, when it began to surge a few years ago and was looked forward to as an alternaive to the domination of the commercial networks. Nevertheless, despite the fact that the networks' share of the total American viewing audience shrank dramatically, television wasn't exactly transformed. And while the hopes for this season lie in some potentially stimulating high points on the network, cable and public television, the general configuration of each of their schdules seems to be in a familiar holding pattern.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; A Step CloserTo Workaday Shuttle Flights
description: It streaked over the desert in the California dawn, announcing its arrival with a double sonic boom. Then it arched into the familiar 180-degree turn and touched down before a rising sun - a picture-perfect ending to last week's maiden mission of the space shuttle Discovery. There were minor bugs - a chunk of ice that formed around a waste water vent had to be swatted away with the craft's space arm and a small oxygen leak briefly knotted some brows - but they were overshadowed by the six-day flight's triumphs. Three satellites were catapulted into orbit (redemption for two failed launches from the sister ship Challenger in February), a 102-foot solar panel was unfurled and an experimental drug-manufacturing device took advantage of the weightlessness to produce a sample of an ultrapure hormone. Not that there was much time for Discovery to rest on its laurels. The schedule called for it to be piggybacked onto a Boeing 747 for the trip this weekend back to the Cape Canaveral pad and, NASA hopes, a November launch. At long last, the shuttle is starting to live up to its name.

title: A WATCHDOG FOR THE HUDSON

title: A TALE OF THE BIG SPECTACLE AND THE GOOD LITTLE MOVIES
description: Once upon a time, in the not-too-distant future, there was an average American town. Every Friday night the people drove to the movie theater, hoping that there might be something new. But ''Ghostbusters'' had been there all summer. And the hit held its ground, even though all the town's elders had already seen it and the children now wore ''Ghostbusters'' T-shirts and knew all the words to the theme song. So on Friday evenings, the people would turn away from the theater in great sadness. They would go home, watch ''Dallas'' reruns and wait for ''Dune,'' the next hit on the horizon, which was supposed to be coming at Christmastime.

title: SERIOUS DRAMA, OLD AND NEW, WILL TAKE CENTER STAGE

The point is that, as an art form and an industry, theater is spontaneous, serendipitousand difficult to prognosticate. Big-budget spectacles like ''Chaplin'' never open; unexpected arrivals like ''Hurlyburly'' set the city afire. It happens every season.

title: FICTION
description: -year-old named Kate, while populating and furnishing her new doll house, creates fantasies that - unknown to her - are acted out by the real-life occupants of a rooming house miles away in central London. Since dolls, like art, imitate life, the events Kate inflicts upon her miniatures mimic the goings-on of her own real-life household in placid Wimbledon Common. Such a premise for a novel may feel awkward at first, but Miss Waugh's smooth and generous descriptive prose will win you over. Writing in a flat, ironic tone, that oh-so-British trademark of satiric fiction, Miss Waugh creates a world like that of her father, Evelyn, in which anything goes. This includes a virgin birth and the metamorphosis of a poodle into an apocalyptic, baby-eating dragon. And when Rumania, Kate's mother, gets pregnant, so does one of Kate's dolls. Margery MacDonald, an unrelated rooming house occupant in Notting Hill does, too. Margery's is the virgin birth. What makes ''Kate's House'' delightful is partly the fun Miss Waugh pokes at middle-class values - both those particularly British, like doting on the Royal Family, and those more universal, like Roman Catholicism and racial prejudice (Margery thinks that black people are the ''incubators of strange germs''). But the charm of this novel derives also from Kate herself. When Kate shaves the hair off all her stuffed animals, Miss Waugh is re-creating the innocently macabre humor resplendent among 4-year-olds. In case you forgot what that was like, ''Kate's House'' will help you remember.
