title: NEW TRIDENT MISSILE BEARS A PAYLOAD OF APPREHENSION
description: A milestone in what many experts believe to be the nation's most vital nuclear weapons program, strategic submarines, is approaching with the end of the Federal budget year later this month. The Navy will stop buying Trident I missiles for these formidable boats and begin producing Trident II's, an evolutionary step of far-reaching consequence to the composition of American and Soviet forces.

title: REMEMBERING JOHN CHEEVER
description: MY father was always a storyteller. His home-room teacher at Thayer Academy used to promise her class that John would tell a story if they behaved. With luck, and increasing skill, he could spin the story out over two or three class periods so that the teacher and his classmates forgot all about arithmetic and geography and social studies. He told them stories about ship captains and eccentric old ladies and orphan boys, gallant men and dazzling women in a world where the potent forces of evil and darkness were confounded and good triumphed in the end. He peopled his tales with his own family and friends and neighbors from the surrounding Massachusetts South Shore towns: Quincy, Hingham, Hanover, Susan Cheever is a novelist whose most recent work is ''The Cage.'' Braintree, Norwell and Wollaston, where he lived in a big clapboard house on the Winthrop Avenue hill with his mother, an Englishwoman whose family had immigrated to Boston when she was 6, his father, a gentleman sailor who owned a prosperous shoe factory in nearby Lynn, and his older brother, Fred, who was going away to Dartmouth in the fall.

title: Barbara Bassett Wed To William P. Erdman
description: Barbara Jean Bassett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton H. Bassett of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to William Pardee Erdman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. B. Erdman, also of Princeton. The Rev. John D. Schule Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the garden ceremony at the Edgartown, Mass., summer home of the bridegroom's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Erdman of Princeton.

title: ON LANGUAGE ; SECRET PLAN
description: A delicious, sinister phrase has been an early centerpiece of the Democratic campaign against Ronald Reagan: The President is charged with harboring a

title: Kathryn Louise Bergman Marries Gordon A. Naylor
description: Kathryn Louise Bergman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Bergman of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Gordon Albert Naylor, a son of Donald W. Naylor and Elizabeth J. Robertson, both of Toronto.

title: MAKE WAY FOR TWO ROMEOS AND A CREOLE GISELLE
description: There will be a good deal of variety this dance year, with strong representation of established and emerging American modern dance choreographers and a few oddities like the fact that not one but two major ballet companies will have new, full-blown productions of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' This will also be a year of anniversaries, with American Ballet Theater celebrating its 45th year and the Paul Taylor Dance Company its 30th birthday. Twyla Tharp and Meredith Monk each observe 20 years of choreography. It has been 20 years, too, since that fine performer Dudley Williams joined the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which will pay him honor in November. And the Joffrey Ballet will celebrate Sir Frederick Ashton's 80th birthday with two all-Ashton evenings.

title: Sindelar, Tour Rookie, Leads by Shot on 69-204
description: Joey Sindelar, bidding for his first victory as a rookie on the PGA Tour, shot a 2-under-par 69 to take the lead from the veteran George Archer today in the third round of the $350,000 Bank of Boston Classic.

title: DANGEROUS DOUBLES
description: That highly successful gambler, Sky Masterson of ''Guys and Dolls,'' had a good reason for declining an improbable bet: ''My pappy told me that if a man walks up to you and bets you he can make the jack of spades pop out of the deck and squirt cider in your ear, the chances are you'll end up with an earful of cider.'' This precept is illustrated by a series of episodes cited by Lee Hazen, who is equally talented as a lawyer, a bridge-player and a raconteur.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
LEARNING TO LIVE WITHOUT SMOKING
description: THE recent Opinion Page article ''Going It Alone Without a Cigarette'' by Lisa Feldman is a collection of bright one- liners about quitting smoking. But the brave wisecracks sound as if she's only laughing because she's hurting and will soon be back on her habit. As with marriage, travel, a political career and a lot of other things, living as an ex-smoker makes sense only if the benefits outweigh the handicaps. Otherwise it's a pointless exercise in masochism that even the Surgeon General shouldn't endorse.

title: COMPACT DISKS, MAJOR ARTISTIS AND RARITIES SHARE ATTENTION
description: While music be may be the ultimate reason for recordings, the technology for playing the music seems destined in the months ahead to be at least as important in determining what is issued. Starting this fall, the laser- played compact disk will be getting the full promotional treatment from the industry - the manufacturers of players, the producers of records and the stores that sell them. One result will be that the emphasis, even more than usual, will be on standard repertory to attract new buyers, to take advantage of the display possibilities of sonic warhorses and - let us not be entirely cynical - to capture the great works of the past in performances by the great performers of the present in state-of-the-art sound. Nevertheless, an astonishing amount of more out-of-the-ordinary fare will be available on compact disks as well as on LP and cassette.

title: LESBIANS' CUSTODY FIGHT ON COAST RAISES NOVEL ISSUES IN FAMILY LAW
description: In a case presenting novel legal issues in family law, a judge in Oakland has ruled that a lesbian may seek visiting rights to the child born to her former companion while the two women were living together.

title: ANTONIA FRASER: THE LADY IS A WRITER
description: Mel Gussow is a drama critic for The New York Times. By Mel Gussow NTONIA FRASER LIVES ON A QUIET, TREE-SHADED square in the Kensington section of London in a large, airy house that she shares with her second husband, the playwright Harold Pinter. With them live the four youngest of her six children by her first marriage, to the late Sir Hugh Fraser. Sitting in her garden on a recent afternoon, Lady Antonia looked softly feminine, a portrait of gentility. A large white picture hat shielded her face from the sun. A wasp buzzed her ear, and she seemed unperturbed. ''I prefer to believe that nature's on my side,'' she said, ''but Harold gets worried,'' and she indicated, high overhead, his response to nature's sting - an electric bug catcher.

title: TAIWAN SHIP SEIZED ON COAST FOR UNPAID FUEL BILL
description: After six weeks anchored off the California coast with dwindling supplies of food, fresh water and fuel, a Taiwanese freighter that was out of money steamed into San Francisco Bay and Federal marshals seized her.

title: ILIE NASTASE IS MARRIED TO ADELAIDE A. KING
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting in Manhattan yesterday for the marriage of Adelaide Alexandra King, a model, to Ilie Nastase, the tennis player. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin officiated.

ANTIQUES;
COURSES, TOURS, AND WORKSHOPSZ
description: C OURSES, lectures, workshops and excursions related to antiques will be available across the state this fall.

title: MILITARY FAMILIES STRUGGLE FOR BASICS OF LIFE
description: When Darlena Bradshaw learned that her husband, Gene, an Army enlisted man, was being transferred from Germany to California not long ago, she entertained visions of palm trees and an easy life back in the states.

title: Dale E. Sharp Is Dead; An Ex-Bank President
description: Dale E. Sharp, a former president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died Thursday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I.

title: A RETURN TO BATAAN; A DICKENSIAN HOLIDAY
description: Tour to Visit Battlegrounds Of Philippines

title: LEXINGTON DEBATES POLICE POLICIES
description: The city police have equipped some rape victims with radio transmitters and sent them back to confront their attackers, according to court records and a police official.

description: Mother Teresa . Last week, the Albanian-born Nobel laureate accepted it. ''We have been trying to get Mother Teresa to come here for some time and we are overjoyed she agreed,'' said Archbishop Nicholas Marcus Fernando.

title: A NEWSPAPER TO SEEK FEES IN LIBEL CASES
description: The publisher of The Charleston Gazette has announced that the West Virginia newspaper will try to recover its legal expenses from lawyers who bring suit in libel cases that the newspaper considers to be frivolous.

title: ACCESS FOR DISABLED PUZZLES BUILDER
description: LAST December, Richard White decided, almost on an impulse, to add a second story to the commercial building he was putting up in downtown Montauk. He was unaware then that new state requirements for access for the handicapped, effective Jan. 1, 1984, would make the installation of an elevator a prerequisite for a certificate of occupancy.

title: Sandinista Delegation Meets Pope's Top Aide
description: Nicaraguan Government officials, here for talks on the troubled church-state relations in their country, met today with Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican Secretary of State.

title: HOW TO PREVENT OUTSIDE PAINT FROM CRACKING AND PEELING
description: WHEN a freshly applied coat of outside paint starts to crack and peel within a year or less, the indignant homeowner will usually blame the paint, but in most cases it is not the fault of the paint at all. It will be because of faulty preparation of the surface before the paint was applied, or because of structural defects that should have been corrected before the house was painted.

title: TWO ORCHESTRAS TO HOLD AUDITIONS
description: LAST week, we considered some of the many choral opportunities open to amateur singers in the county. Equivalent openings for instrumentalists are much harder to come by, and they usually demand a much higher level of technical expertise, but at least talented teen-agers in the county are in luck: the Westchester Conservatory has sent out an audition call for its fine Symphony Orchestra.

title: HOLLYWOOD TRIES ITS HAND AT FARMING FOR DOLLARS
description: To paraphrase an old song, how're you going to lure them back to the box office after they've seen gremlins, ghostbusters and gyrating rock stars? By keeping them down on the farm.

title: NEGLIGENCE AWARD IS REDUCED
description: A state district judge has reduced a jury's punitive damage award by $80 million in a negligence case against the Ford Motor Company.

title: IN POLITICS, WOMEN RUN BY A DIFFERENT SET OF RULES
description: As the first woman to run on a major party's Presidential ticket, Geraldine A. Ferraro is unique. That does not mean, however, that she is unprecedented.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Film View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misidentified the director of the movie ''Le Dernier Combat.'' He was Luc Besson.

title: THE BARBARA WALTERS PRISM
description: Who is Barbara Walters? What is she? Miss Walters is obviously a celebrity, one of television's most easily recognized people. Her precise role, however, always has been hard to define. She has appeared as network news anchor, as correspondent on the big story and, above all and always along with everything else, as interviewer. For the most part now, she interviews only other celebrities, people as famous, although not always quite so famous, as herself. If she gladdens our lives, it is because she introduces us to people we are interested in meeting. If she confuses us, it is because the faces of all these people now run together. The Shah blurs into Anwar el-Sadat and then turns into Mr. T. It is unlikely, moreover, that we remember much of what any of them said. What we remember most about a Barbara Walters interview is Barbara Walters. She is a constant, the lodestar around which the people gather.

title: HOW FOREIGN POLICY WENT OFF THE RAILS
description: Kenneth N. Waltz, the Ford Professor of Political Science at the University of California, Berkeley, is the author of ''Theory of International Politics.'' OUR OWN WORST ENEMY

title: COUNTY'S MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTIRY IS GROWNG
description: VALHALLA A VISITOR to the 219-acre campus of Westchester Community College, directed to the Science Building and told about the Museum of Natural History, might imagine a reconstructed mastodon skeleton and a meteor the size of a suburban house. So it could come as a surprise when he finds that the museum is not the large Science Building, but the adjacent 11-by-11-foot stone structure.

title: THE NATION ; Applied MathOn Protectionism
description: Bill Brock, President Reagan's trade representative, explained last week's decision to deny protection to American copper producers this way: restrictions on imports, which come mostly from third world debtor countries, would, Mr. Brock said, ''complicate efforts to maintain the stability of the international financial system.''

description: ''Writing That Means Business: A Manager's Guide'' by Ellen Roddick. Macmillan, New York, 120 pages, $10.95.

description: Jeanne Marie Fellows, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Fellows of Stonington, Conn., was married there yesterday to Bart John Ruis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. The bride, a sales executive in New York with A. J. Mitchell and K. Benson, sportswear divisions of Jerell Inc., will retain her name professionally. Mr. Ruis is owner of Millennium Construction Inc. in New York.

description: KONSTANTIN U. Chernenko's television appearance last week in the midst of rumors of illness, helped clear up one uncertainty about the Soviet leadership, but another was almost immediately created by the replacement of Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, Chief of Staff of the armed forces, by his deputy, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev.

description: South Korea's President ended a landmark visit to Japan today with leaders of both countries pledging to reinforce their relationship ''as mutually mature partners.''

title:
ART;
EXUBERANCE THAT JOLTS THE MIND AND THE EYE
description: ANDREW LYGHT warns the spectator to walk into his paintings and experience their grip on the total space within a room. This is exactly what happens in the New York artist's current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art - an installation that serves as an exuberant, colorful introduction to a radical but valid creative premise.

title: Berkeley City Council Agrees To Say Pledge of Allegiance
description: For the first time in 13 years, the entire City Council in this haven of radical politics has recited 31 words that are controversial here: the Pledge of Allegiance. But they do not plan to do it again for another year.

title: THE NEW POLITICS OF WHO WE ARE
description: Americans often assume that their national politics is the result of their politicians. It is the other way around: our Presidents, Senators and Representatives are themselves results, not causes.

Tracy of Sebastian, Fla., and the late Harry W. VanLandingham. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

description: MANY New Jerseyans spent the summer with sun, sand and shore, but others tried waters that, at least for them, were uncharted.

description: For months, leaders of the New York Catholic Archdiocese, the Salvation Army and an orthodox Jewish group have been fighting to overturn Mayor Koch's order banning discrimination against homosexuals, saying it violated their religious principles. Last week, a State Supreme Court judge said the order also conflicted with constitutional procedures.

description: He was in his mid-40's and he had a good job as a clinical psychologist, teaching and conducting a private practice. But he was getting antsy.

description: Sabin could not handle the boys yesterday at Belmont Park, but Majesty's Prince proved he could handle a firm course with a three-quarter- length victory in the $362,000 Man o' War Stakes, and Win proved his mettle with a gallant second-place finish.

description: Gaddis Smith, Larned Professor of History at Yale, specializes in the history of American foreign policy in the 20th century.

title: THE WORLD ; Getting CloseTo a CoalitionFor Israel
description: For a time last week, Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir thought agreement was imminent on a grand coalition to govern Israel. But complaints from partners on both sides forced the two party leaders into further difficult negotiations, suggesting that the coalition, if there is to be one, could face a rocky future. Continuing dissatisfaction within the ranks of both major blocs added to the problems. Mr. Peres, whose 42- day mandate expires next Sunday, hopes to submit a Cabinet for parliamentary endorsement by Wednesday.

title: MILK WAR POINTS UP HAWAIIAN INSULARITY
description: It was a half-gallon container of milk, a small thing, that provided the most recent demonstration that Oahu, its ties to the rest of the United States notwithstanding, is a tight little island where defenders of local interests rise quickly to ward off intruders.

title: CONCERT: A BRITISH YOUTH ORCHESTRA
description: The Royal College of Music is one of several conservatories in London; others include the Royal Academy of Music and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. Like the Juilliard School in New York, the Royal College maintains a Junior Department, in this case open to musicians from the ages of 10 to 18. The college was founded in 1882; the Junior Department in 1926.

title: POSTINGS;
description: Perhaps not since the the 1920's or 1930's have apartments been built in Manhattan that match in size and luxury those planned for the residential building now under construction on East 88th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: El Salvador's Vice President Enters U.S. Military Hospital
description: The Vice President of El Salvador, Rodolfo Castillo Claramount, was admitted Friday to a United States military hospital in Texas for what a Salvadoran official said was emergency treatment of a kidney ailment.

title: FLIRTING AND OTHER COMPETITIVE PLOYS
description: GEORG SIMMEL: ON WOMEN, SEXUALITY, AND LOVE Translated and introduced by Guy Oakes. 194 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $20.

description: Working at a desk in the Executive Mansion, sometimes in the middle of the night, Governor Cuomo has been drafting a speech in which he will attempt to describe a line where theology ends and politics begins.

title: Parasite Killed Elephant
description: A parasitic organism caused the death last month of the baby elephant given to President Reagan and his wife when they made a state visit to Sri Lankan, National Zoo officials said Friday. The two-week illness of the 20-month-old Jayathu, who was given to the Reagansin June by J.R. Jayewardene, Sri Lankan president, was diagnosed as schistosomiasis, a parasitic fluke infection, said Dr. Richard Montali. The organism, which attacked the animal's intestines, apparently was harbored by the elephant before her arrival in the United States, a zoo spokesman said.

title: Lynn Roberts Marries Mark Robert Wolfson
description: Lynn Terry Roberts, the daughter of Dorothy Roberts Cohen of New York and the late Paul M. Roberts, was married yesterday to Mark Robert Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Robert Wolfson of Glencoe, Ill. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at the Washington, Conn., home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Paul M. Cohen.

description: Alice Gibb Abel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert R. Abel of Elizabeth, N.J., and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Allan Raymond Boushie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Boushie of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. The Rev. Fredrick W. Schulz performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of East Hampton, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas F. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Commission Delays Decision On Three Mile Island Reactor
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has postponed until next year a decision on whether to allow the undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to be restarted.

title: Grass Fire Peril Eases In Oklahoma and Kansas By The Associated Press
description: Grass fires that scorched more than 400 square miles of Oklahoma rangeland were reduced to ''a few hot spots'' yesterday, but a 15-day ban on open burning was in effect in Kansas, where fires broke out in 11 counties, destroyed a home and temporarily routed nursing home residents.

title: THE DOLLAR RESUMES ITS BOLD ASCENT
description: The mighty dollar staged a major surge last week after a quiet August, establishing new highs against many of the world's biggest currencies. On Friday, the dollar had one of its biggest single-day gains. Bolstered by expectations of higher U.S. interest rates and an unwillingness by investors to sell dollars, the currency rose to record highs against the British pound, French franc, Italian lira and an 11 1/2- year high against the West German mark. Analysts had expected the dollar to weaken during August. ''The correction that was in all the charts didn't happen,'' one trader said, and many now expect the dollar to maintain its current high level for a long time. Much of the buying that continued to push the dollar higher evidently came from major corporations that will need dollars for their operations later this month. And that buying is expected to continue to keep the currency high.

title: OKLAHOMA'S ANTISALOON LAWS TO FACE VOTERS
description: The wets and the drys are gearing up for another showdown over Oklahoma's antisaloon laws.

title: THE WORLD ; Fabius StaysOn Course
description: When Laurent Fabius was Minister of Industry in Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy's Government, he helped devise a plan to modernize France's industry and reduce the burden of subsidies that had helped to keep such sectors as steel and coal alive. Whether through streamlining or recession, some 400,000 jobs have been lost since the Socialists came to power in 1981.

title: DEATH TOLL RISES TO 24 IN BRITISH OUTBREAK OF FOOD POISONING
description: Twenty-four people have died of food poisoning at a mental hospital here, the authorities said today.

title: PUTTING KAFKA'S LIFE IN PESEPECTIVE
description: THE reviews have been overwhelmingly favorable. Irving Howe, for instance, said that ''The Nightmare of Reason: A Life of Franz Kafka'' is ''especially strong - full of vivid and clear detail - on the daily life of Kafka. He presents the best picture yet drawn of the circumstances in which Kafka worked and out of which he made his fictions.''

title: SYRACUSE TRIUMPS BY 23-7
description: Don McAulay made three field goals and Jamie Covington scored a 1-yard touchdown as Syracuse converted four second-half turnovers for a 23-7 upset victory over Maryland today in the season opener for both teams.

title: Temple Burning
description: Three days after a suspicious fire destroyed a small Buddhist temple in Hawley, Mass., three Vietnam veterans surrendered and were charged with setting the blaze.

title: OF FERRAR, CUOMO AND MORAL ISSUES CONFUSED WITH DOGMA
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME LESSONS ABOUT CHARTERS
description: Another banner summer is ending for American travel to Europe, and much of the success can be credited to charter flights. They have made trans-Atlantic trips possible for vacationers who could not otherwise afford them. But the year was not without major headaches, and much of what went wrong with flights to Europe can be attributed to charters, too. The problems provide some lessons for travelers who are contemplating charter vacations in the Caribbean this winter or in Europe next year. One is that travelers would be wise to check the record of charter operators they contemplate using.

title: NICARAGUA SPURNS DISARMAMENT PLEA
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister, Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, says he will reject a call by a four-nation group for regional disarmament as long as the United States continues its undercover attacks on his country.

title: Miss Gerstenmaier and Carl Ally Wed
description: Jo Ellen Gerstenmaier, a daughter of Lois Rolfing Gerstenmaier of Akron, Ohio, and John H. Gerstenmaier of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to Carl J. Ally, the son of Mary Smith of St. Clair Shores, Mich., and the late Carl Ally. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Data Update
description: *4*NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS *4*(In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates) June June 1983 Change Starts 1,886 1,743 x 8% Completions 1,711 1,368 x 25% Sales 620 655 - 5% *4*Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) New York Conventional 14.42 14.44 13.85 Rollovers 13.65 13.69 13.14 Adjustable Rate 12.28 12.30 11.59 *4*Source: HSH Associates New Jersey Conventional 14.41 14.39 13.86 Rollovers 13.56 13.56 13.14 Adjustable Rate 12.52 12.51 11.59 *4*Source: HSH Associates Connecticut Conventional 14.41 14.45 13.93 Rollovers 13.50 13.50 13.34 Adjustable Rate 11.89 12.00 11.71 *4*Source: The Millard Group Inc. Co-ops (N.Y.C) Conventional 14.89 14.88 14.00 Rollovers 13.75 13.85 13.43 Adjustable Rate 12.42 12.41 12.00 *4*Source: HSH Associates

title:
GARDENING;
THE SUBTILE ART OF READING PLANT LEAVES
description: Although the value of reading tea leaves to tell the future is dubious, reading plant leaves as a means of identifying their problems is not.

title: A CIVILIZED ANGLER RESISTS
description: SHE hauled me quite as far from rivers as you can get: to the shore, for a few restful days in East Hampton, ''looking in the galleries, shopping in the pretty little shops, lying on the beach.'' I went quietly. After all, I'd been hauling her in the opposite direction all summer. But behind my luggage, far back in the trunk of the car, neatly hidden, I hauled along my surf-casting rod.

title: 'TAP DANCE KID' SETTLES INTO ROLE
description: ''I LIKE them to like me because I'm me, not just because I'm the Tap Dance Kid.'' Jimmy Tate was referring to the fans awaiting his autograph - he signs ''when I'm not too tired'' - at the stage door of Manhattan's Minskoff Theater, where the musical, ''The Tap Dance Kid'' is playing.

title: OAKLAND YOUTHS GROWING BOLDER AS DRUG DEALERS
description: Amid tree-lined streets and lush green lawns of this city, children on bicycles, on doorsteps and in the park flag down customers in a violent drug trade that has already caused 20 deaths this year.

title: C. B. Coyle Weds Christina P. Burtt
description: At St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Christina Prescott Burtt, a daughter of Mrs. Iain Paul MacKay of Darien, Conn., and Carleton Davis Burtt of Washington, Conn., was married to Christopher Bruce Coyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Coyle of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Elwood L. Stark performed the ceremony.

title: POP: JULIO IGLESIAS SINGS AT RADIO CITY
description: I've been for the last 16 months trying to speak English better,'' Julio Iglesias, the Spanish pop superstar confided to a subdued, elegantly attired opening-night audience in Radio City Music Hall Thursday. But in order to sing in English, Mr. Iglesias explained, he had studied the language 15 hours a day and still, he lamented, his pronunciation was ''the worst.''

title: A FEW BLUE PERENNIALS;
description: Deci Lowry is a writer who gardens in Westchester County.

title: Reagan Bids Students Turn Off TV and Study
description: President Reagan urged the nation's students today to study harder, stay in school, cut out violence and ''stop watching too much TV.''

title: Sports of the Times; THE MET WHO TAKES HIS TIME
description: WHEN George Foster watches his videotapes of the Met games in his home, he understands why opposing pitchers and umpires get annoyed. He settles back in his chair to watch some action, but instead he sees No. 15 on the Mets wandering around outside the batter's box in an apparent somnolent trance.

title: IRISH ARE UPSET: MICHIGAN TOPS MIAMI
description: Notre Dame had the reputation, the expectations, the experience, the size and the magic name. It also had something it did not want or need - generosity.

title: CARTER'S VOLUNTEER GROUP PLANS NICARAGUA PROJECT
description: Habitat for Humanity, a nonprofit, international Christian organization that builds housing for the poor and numbers former President Jimmy Carter among its directors, plans to build homes for landless peasants next year in Nicaragua.

title: JUST WHAT PRODUCTION DESIGNERS DO
description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Columbia and Yale, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: MUSIC
description: In the Manhattan cabaret world, this has been the year of Julie Wilson. The singer, who had been living in her hometown of Omaha, Neb., since the mid-70's, came out of semi-retirement last January with a triumphant two-and-a-half month stint at Michael's Pub singing a program of Cole Porter songs. After winning rave reviews for the show, she returned to the club the following May with an even more successful tribute to Stephen Sondheim. That program, in which Miss Wilson made Sondheim's lyrics the basis for musical protraiture of breathtaking intensity and precision, was so popular that were it not for prior commitment the show might have run for several months.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
REDIRECT NON-COMMERCIAL FLIGHTS
description: What happened to all those low-priced airline flights we used to enjoy? One day soon we may be asking ourselves that question if certain airlines and the F.A.A. have their way. The airline delays that have received so much recent publicity have left a lot of people in Washington scratching their heads about what to do - and their initial reactions to the problem are not healthy ones.

title: Miss Surette Has Nuptials
description: Sharon Frances Surette, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Federhen Surette of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Mann Johnston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Johnston Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Edward Howley performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: REPORTS OF DISTANT CRIMES FOUND REASSURING
description: Newspaper reports of violent crimes actually appear to reassure readers if the crimes were committed in other cities, according to a study reported in the August issue of The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.

title: ROADSIDE LITTER IS STILL A BURDEN
description: STATE Transportation Department officials say that litter along Connecticut's highways has lessened in recent years, but that removing what remains is still a problem, particularly near urban areas.

title: CABLE TV FACING PROBLEMS
description: TWELVE years after the introduction of cable television in Connecticut, 26 companies serve almost 600,000 customers. But despite its growth, the industry has some nagging problems.

title: A NEW INTEREST IN SMALL COMPANIES
description: Investors who were lured into the stock market last year by the high-flying, thinly capitalized, emerging growth stocks may have lost their stomach for investing in them again. Many of these stocks were among the biggest losers during the market correction - dropping in price by as much as 50 percent.

title: DEFENSE BILL BOGGED DOWN IN SYMBOLS
description: WASHINGTON AS Congress was beginning its short pre- election session last week, the Senate Republican leader wearily emerged from a meeting with the Democratic Speaker of the House. They had intended to discuss conferees who would attend a later ''summit conference,'' where the two-month deadlock over military spending would be resolved. But after his meeting with Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee joked: ''This may have

title: 'A HOST OF GOLDEN DAFFODILS' NEEDS ADVANCE PLANNING
description: James S. Wells is a nurseryman who has retired in recent years.

title: GIRL, 9, GOING TO COLLEGE AMID MAINE DISPUTE
description: The parents of a 9-year-old college student want permission from the local school board to continue her nontraditional education, but Auburn officials insist the child must take an achievement test first to show that she is learning.

title: Alice Early Wed In Massachusetts
description: Alice Collins Early, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Early of West Tisbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Matthew Richard Cosgrove, a son of Mrs. Matthew Cosgrove of Cedarburg, Wis., and the late Mr. Cosgrove. The Rev. John E. Wallace performed the ceremony at the West Tisbury Congregational Church.

title: ENFORCING PRIMARY-RESIDENCE RULES
description: City landlords are intensifying their efforts to restrict rent-stabilized and -controlled apartments to tenants who use them as a primary residence.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: On Dec. 2, 1981, the Long Beach City Council passed a resolution of considerable impact. The city's governing body commissioned the formulation of a comprehensive plan, a document that will serve as a community planning guideline well into the next century.

title: CUTTING THE TAX ON PENSION PAYOUTS
description: The number of people cashing out of corporate

title: Lori Esposito Is Wed to Alan Murray
description: Lori Esposito, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Esposito of Stamford, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Alan Murray, a son of Catherine Murray and John R. Murray, both of Chattanooga, Tenn. The Rev. Benedict Tighe performed the ceremony at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford.

title: MOROCCO-LIBYA PACT: THE AFTERSHOCK
description: A month ago, King Hassan II left a meeting with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, and made a number of telephone calls.

title: THEATER SCHOOL RESUMES DESPITE SEX SCANDEL
description: Fall classes have begun at the Minneapolis Children's Theater and School Company for the first time in 20 years without its founder, John Clark Donahue, who was arrested in April on charges of sexually abusing three students.

title: TO ANNOUNCE OR NOT TO ANNOUNCE, THAT IS THE QUESTION
description: The scene is all too familiar, like a recurring bad dream. Just before the music is scheduled to begin, a functionary steps onstage (groans and cries of 'Oh, no!'') and announces that the star is ''indisposed.'' The ailing artist either has consented to go ahead bravely in hopes of saving the day or has given way to a comparatively unknown substitute or stand-in. Either way, the first reaction will be a smattering of boos, usually turning immediately to applause. After all, the audience has come to enjoy itself and will take half a loaf, if necessary.

title: New Storm Off Florida Threatens East Coast
description: The tropical storm Diana suddenly sprang to life in the Atlantic today with 60-mile-an-hour winds.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE LEATHERMAN TALES

title:
DINING OUT;
CULINARY ARTS IN A COLONIAL SETTING
description: WHEN one has to forgive a restaurant for some incompetence in one of its areas of offered service, it is essential to offset it. The offending element at Pratt's Inn is the waiting staff. Diners who feel that doting, caring, formal service is vital to their enjoying a meal could be disappointed here. For others, however, fine basic ingredients prepared with considerable culinary skill will eclipse most lapses in service, the training inthis restaurant lavished on those who prepare the food rather than on those who serve it.

title: Juantorena's Farewell
description: Alberto Juantorena, the Cuban- born track star known as ''White Lightning,'' was hardly in top form Friday night when he finished last in an eight-man, 800-meter race at London's Crystal Palace. His time, 1 minute 50.54 seconds, was more than five seconds off his best 800 of the year, but the crowd of 17,000 gave him a standing ovation anyway, and for a special reason: It was the former Olympic champion's last race.

title: THE REGION ; City Stands ByExam Results
description: The test of an exam is in its contents and not its results, Mayor Koch decided last week. Mr. Koch said he would stand by the results of a new exam for police sergeant, even though a disproportionately small number of black and Hispanic officers passed the test. The exam, designed to be job-related and unbiased toward women and minority-group members, was part of a 1981 settlement of several civil-rights suits filed against the city.

title: KEAN URGES INDUSTRY TO HELP WITH DAY CARE
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey has called on private companies to help Federal, state and local agencies finance the growing national need for day-care centers.

title: HEADLIN
description: Headliners

title: Ocracoke
description: To the Editor:

title: RIKERS I. GAMES LIFT SPIRITS OF INMATES
description: For Steven Diaz, who is serving 13 months at Rikers Island on a drug violation, it was a small but important triumph.

title: Big U.S. Autos Found Safest
description: An new insurance study says that full-size American automobiles are safer than smaller imports when they are involved in collisions. The study also found that Japanese automobiles generally produced higher claims for injury and property damage.

title: ENGLAND: A FIELD GUIDE
description: England is a foreign country, and when you go there, you need to know more than just what to put in your suitcase. The first thing to remember is that you are a foreigner.

title: Spencer Boyd Is Married to George C. Bradley Jr.
description: The marriage of Lucy Spencer Boyd of New York, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Boyd Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., to George Crawford Bradley Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley of Sagaponack, L.I., took place yesterday in the Presbyterian Church of Sewickley. The Rev. George B. Wirth performed the ceremony.

title: ED GIBBS: A VIEW FROM THE OTHER SIDE
description: EARLIER this month, Edward M. Gibbs, the county's executive officer, revisited the site of his fiercest combat, a place, he said, where friends were made and lost and where he ''learned the spirit of teamwork.''

title: VIETNAMESE INFLUX IN CAMBODIA STIRS CONCERN
description: The head of a United Nations group studying the political situation in Cambodia said today that Vietnam was continuing to settle its nationals in that country at a rate that was of serious international concern.

title: ART
description: It is always a good idea to start the season with something that is indisputably and unforgettably great. An opportunity of that kind is offered by the current show of etchings by Rembrandt at the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: 'POLLSTERS WRONG,' FERRARO ASSERTS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, on a three-city campaign swing through New England today, said in Portland, Me., ''The pollsters and pundits are wrong when they say this election is over before it starts.''

title: Miss Clarke Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Donna Belin Clarke, an appraiser-cataloguer with Sotheby's in New York, to Morris Wistar Stroud 2d, an architect with Eberhart Brothers Inc. in New York, took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Scranton, Pa. The Rev. Everett W. Francis performed the ceremony.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
LEARNING ENGLISH: ESTRANGED IN A STRANGE LAND
description: NORIKO answered unhesitatingly when I asked, ''What do you like most about living in America?'' ''The price of meat,'' she replied. She was equally quick when I asked, ''What do you like least about living in America?''

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Who Gets WhatOn Generic Drugs
description: From this side of the pharmacy counter, it sometimes seems as if generic drugs are more argued about than prescribed. Last week the House set out to remedy the situation, unanimously approving a measure designed to make the low-cost substitutes more available to consumers by making them easier for the industry to swallow.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER TO GET HONOR AT PAGEANT
description: ATLANTIC CITY AS usual since it all began in 1921, a great many young women will win all sorts of trophies in Miss America Pageant categories this week, but this time a man also will be in the act.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE BEACH HOUSE: EXPANDED HORIZONS
description: JAMES CAGNEY, the actor, once said he had a ''thing'' about farms.'' My wife, Mary, and I have had a ''thing'' about the ocean. We had long dreamed of having a house within a stone's throw of the ocean, to be used on weekends and vacations.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
A PART-TIME MARRIAGE
description: Noel Perrin

title: GIVING TILL IT HURTS
description: When I was a tot, there was only Christmas to worry about, but then I aged, and along came Valentine's Day. I couldn't believe it.

title: THE WORLD ; Car Bomb MarsHoliday in Beirut
description: In Beirut, where nearly everyone seems to have enemies, a car bomb last week marred the Moslem feast of Al Adha marking the end of the annual period of pilgrimages to Mecca.

title: AN HBO FILM PROJECT ENCOUNTERS CHALLENGES
description: Dan Yakir frequently reports on the cultural scene.

title: Miss Brown Wed To Charles Read
description: Hilary Michaels Brown, a daughter of Mrs. Gerald Breese of Princeton, N.J., and Newell Brown of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday to Charles Hatch Read, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Read of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Eugene Speckman performed the ceremony at the Six Mile Run Reformed Church in Franklin Park, N.J.

title: Illini Player Acquitted
description: Craig Swoope , outstanding football safety for the University of Illinois, was found not guilty of cocaine-trafficking charges yesterday by a United States District Court jury in Springfield, Ill., after 13 1/2 hours of deliberation. ''This is the biggest victory of my life,'' said the 20-year-old Swoope, of Fort Pierce, Fla., who faced a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison and fines totaling $75,000.

title: 'THAR SHE BLOWS' IS THE LATEST CRY FROM THE TOURIST LOOKOUT
description: There are newspaper and magazine advertisements, radio commericals and even a giant billboard on the Massachusetts Turnpike near Boston that proclaims it's ''tons of fun.''

title: FINE ITALIAN DINING IN MANCHESTER
description: HAVING reviewed Cavey's French restaurant in Manchester some years ago, it seemed natural to return for a sampling of the northern Italian dining that shares the same premises but has a different kitchen and dining area.

title: Car Prices to Rise in Poland
description: The price of most Polish and all imported cars will rise by up to 30 percent on Monday, the official press agency said.

title: No Headline
description: The Final U.S. Word: Mango Mailing Is Out

title: 3 on A's Charged Two Oakland A's pitchers,
description: Bill Caudill and Steve McCatty , and a coach, Clete Boyer , were charged with disorderly conduct early yesterday morning in a bar at a Cleveland hotel, the team said.

title: 2 WITH LEGIONNAIRES' DISEASE DIE AT THE DOWNSTATE MEDICAL CENTER
description: Two patients recently died at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn after contracting Legionnaires' disease, the hospital said yesterday.

title: ALL-SEASON ART
description: Brookdale Community College's Arts for All Seasons series opens Saturday at 8 P.M. with the pianist Claude Frank. The recital is one of 60 in the Americas and in Europe and Israel Mr. Frank is scheduled to play this year.

title: 50-State Walk Under Way
description: Rob Sweetgall, a University of Delaware graduate student, began an 11,600-mile walk Friday through 50 states as part of a one-year medical experiment designed to document the health benefits of walking.

title: Miss Murray Has Nuptials
description: Marcia Brady Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Addison D. Minott Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Minott of Brattleboro, Vt. The Rev. Joseph C. Gengras and the Rev. D. Bradley Murray, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: 4 Die in Philadelphia Fire
description: Four people were killed early today when a fire swept through their West Philadelphia row house, officials said. The house was not equipped with smoke detectors, the authorities said.

title: Tentative Accord Announced In Walkout at Drug Company
description: Negotiators for striking workers and Merck & Company reached a tentative agreement today to end a walkout by 3,200 employees at the pharmaceutical concern's plants in five states, company officials said.

title: William Kessler Weds Christine Marie Brown
description: Christine Marie Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Brown of Bellevue, Wash., was married yesterday to William Samuel Kessler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Kessler of New York. Dr. Bruce A. Taft, a minister of the Universal Life Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Triple Restaurant in Seattle.

title: Lawyer Appointed to Review Zaccaro's Handling of Estate
description: A Queens lawyer has been named to review an elderly woman's $1 million estate that was overseen until last week by John A. Zaccaro, the husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: CANDIDATES URGED TO DROP NO-WIN ISSUES OF RELIGION
description: WASHINGTON BY the end of the first week of the general election campaign, strategists for both Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale were worried about continuing the debate over the role of religion in politics. But the issue wouldn't go away. For the President, it threatened to drive a wedge between key constituency groups. For the Democratic nominee, it threatened to weaken him in important states.

title: MAYORS TOLD TO STRESS CITIES' LIVEABILITY TO GAIN JOBS
description: The lures that cities have traditionally used to attract businesses - lowering normal labor costs, taxes and rents - are no longer appropriate in a high- technology economy, an urban affairs specialist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told a group of the nation's mayors yesterday. In fact, he said, they may hurt more than they help.

title: Jane B. Abrams, a Writer, Engaged to Lloyd Nintzel
description: Jane Brown Abrams and Lloyd Charles Nintzel, both of New York, plan to be married Oct. 21.

title: O'Neill Calls Reagan to Task
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, asked Friday whether President Reagan was renewing his request made in 1981 for cuts in Social Security. In a speech this week, Mr. Reagan said Congress had failed to approve $40 billion to $50 billion in budget cuts that year. Mr. O'Neill said those cuts had been aimed at Social Security.

title: SEASHORE ADDS A 'MISSING LINK'
description: FROM the top of the crumbling Fire Island Lighthouse, looking eastward toward Kismet and the densely populated summer communities beyond, one sees a little swath of dune and bayberry thicket below that seems wild and natural, as though it has been untouched for centuries. Drifting sands and tangled thickets of cat brier and poison ivy have covered over all evidence of the dynamic and turbulent history of this newest addition to Fire Island National Seashore.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
MY GRANDMOTHER: NO COOKIES, BUT SHE WAS VERY SPECIAL
description: THE last time my grandmother asked me to write about her, she had just told me once again the tale of being mistaken for Bette Davis at my parent's wedding. At 84 years old, she still looked like a delicate version of the actress; I admired her beauty, as always, and promised, ''Yes, Nana, I'll do an article on you.'' I also wondered, what, really, will I say?

title: Court to Hear Salmon Case
description: FRUSTRATED by what it regards as an illegal and blatantly unrestricted net fishery for Atlantic salmon by the Mic Mac Indians at Cross Point, Quebec, the Atlantic Salmon Federation initiated a court action a few days ago that it says is intended to force Quebec's department of recreation, game and fish to implement the laws protecting the species from over-exploitation.

title: THE NATION ; G.O.P. ChallengeIn Alabama
description: Can Albert Lee Smith hitch another ride to Washington on Ronald Reagan's coattails? That will be up to Alabama's voters to decide come November, when they have yet another opportunity to vote for Mr. Smith, who last week won the Republican Party's nomination for the Senate seat now occupied by Democrat Howell Heflin.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW ; A SCINTILLATING 'WHOREHOUSE'
Heavy Fighting Reported Throughout Afghanistan
description: The official Afghan radio said that more than 100 anti-Government guerrillas were killed today in fighting with Government forces in 12 Afghan provinces.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Drivers over the age of 60 have the option of getting a two-year license without a picture. As one who is eligible for that option, I opted for it upon seeing a standing-room-only crowd waiting for their pictures to be taken at the Springfield Motor Vehicle Agency.

title: SAMPLING PORTUUGAL'S CITIES
description: The American dollar can sometimes be kind. It certainly is in Portugal where, thanks to nearly 150 escudos to the dollar, prices are about half what they were two years ago. Which means that food, accommodations and entertainment are, by American standards, surpassingly inexpensive. Cabs also. Seldom did a cab ride in Lisbon cost more than $1, tip included.

title: PROFESSOR OF THE LOST ART OF WINNING
description: MINNEAPOLIS HE wore a baggy University of Minnesota sweatshirt that made his slight frame look even smaller and a white baseball cap that fit snugly on his head. Peering at his players during practice last week through wire-rimmed glasses and puffing on a pipe, Lou Holtz looked like Woody Allen making a football movie or a Peanuts character in a stage version of ''You're a Good Coach, Charlie Brown.''

title: Tracy Pearce Weds in Jersey
description: The marriage of Mary Teresa Pearce, an account executive at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc., a New York advertising agency, to James Polk Rutherfurd, an associate at the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, took place yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. Msgr. Francis LoBianco performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. Gerald Greaves.

title: Q&A
description: Breaking a Lease

title: CURRICULUM COMPETITION BLOSSOMS IN HIGH SCHOOL
description: Late last spring, a class of ninth-grade students at the Robert F. Wagner Junior High School in Manhattan was asked what high schools they would be attending this fall. A few had passed the entrance test for two of New York City's most prestigious schools, the Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant High School. Others had been accepted by schools with special themes, such as the Murray Bergtraum High School for Business Careers. A third group had chosen vocational schools.

title: WHEN SUPREME COURT RULES
description: NOTICING that judges could be influenced by the political trends of the day, Peter Finley Dunne's Mr. Dooley once quipped that the Supreme Court followed the election returns. Looking at the judges' decisions in the realm of sports, one might add that the Supreme Court seems to follow the baseball season as well. Whenever the Court has had to rule on the question of organized baseball's alleged violation of the antitrust laws, the judges have revealed that a fan's heart beats beneath the black robes. The strangeness of the situation may have been most obvious in 1971, when the majority referred to the Court's own record as a ''confirmed aberration,'' but the triumph of heart over head actually began in 1922, when Oliver Wendell Holmes spoke for the majority in the Federal League Case.

title: ON LATE CURTAINS, BLABS AND THE BRITISH
description: Once while I was writing a theater review on a computer, the words began to disappear, and, in a matter of seconds, the entire review was replaced by a long scroll of question marks. This was the critic's nightmare - as compared to the actor's nightmare, in which the actor forgets his lines in the middle of a play and wonders what he is doing on stage. The incident left one awestruck. It was as if someone had questioned the review, the point of view, the play being discussed and the critic's very existence. That day the Force was not with me. Since then, I have been on the alert when confronting a computer, so it was without surprise the other day when a terminal began talking back - asking questions instead of creating question marks. The cross-examination dealt with audiences, actors and the audio-visual aspects of being in a theater; in other words, we never got past the letter ''A,'' before I purged the interrogation.

title: WAR OF WORDS RECALLS CRISIS IN GREEK LIFE
description: A personal attack by Greece's Socialist Prime Minister on the new leader of the conservative opposition has generated concern that the political feuding of the mid-1960's will be revived.

title: TALENT HUNT
description: Even as retailers continue to promote and play up established designers, they recognize the need to discover and display more ''new names.'' In just three years, for instance, Michael Kors has established an ever- growing following for the neoclassical clothes that he creates in cashmere and silk.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ALTERNATIVE DEGREES

title: MORE THAN GREETS THE EYE
description: Since brewing the morning coffee is perhaps the most culinary chore that regularly occurs in this Manhattan apartment, why waste precious kitchen space on extravagant appliances or sleek counter tops? Besides, the occupants grimace at the mere mention of cooking. The couple do entertain from time to time, however, so Hariet Eckstein, their interior designer, was asked to create a whimsical room that conceals all the trappings needed to produce the occasional catered meal. ''My inspiration came from the 18th-century painted rooms I saw in Paris,'' the designer says.

title: ILLINOIS OVERCOMES MISSOURI BY 30-24
description: Thomas Rooks scored twice and the Illinois defense stopped a late Missouri threat for a 30-24 victory today, the first time the Illini have beaten the Tigers since 1977.

title: ARAB-AMERCAN'S ERROREditor:
description: -Ed article (''Slighting Arab-Americans''), James Abourezk says I returned five $1,000 checks contributed by Arab-Americans to Walter Mondale's campaign ''with a statement that it was policy to refuse contributions from Arab-Americans for the Mondale campaign.''

title: TERROR WASN'T HIS ONLY TALENT
description: Edited by G. R. Thompson. 1544 pp. New York: The Library of America. $27.50.

title: Enough Is Enough
description: As an increasingly public figure, Michael Jackson has found himself subject to increasingly nasty rumors. Last week he took time out from his national tour to deny a batch of stories and throw down his glove in challenge to anyone who dared to print them in the future.

title: China Plans to Cut Back On Big Construction
description: China will cut back on big construction projects during the five years beginning in 1986 to save money and prepare for an economic boom in the 1990's, the Government's chief economic planner was quoted as saying today.

title: WOMEN BEGIN STUDIES TO BE CONSERVATIVE RABBIS
description: Deborah Cantor said she had felt rooked. Debbie Orenstein began considering other careers. And Marion Shulevitz put aside a desire she had had for 35 years.

title: FARMERS HOPE EXPERIMENTAL POTATO WILL HELP CROP
description: -eyed white clone with a softball shape, and after 11 years of testing it shows signs of good breeding. But N.Y. 63, as it is temporarily named, still has more to prove before it earns a place in the remaining potato fields of the East End.

title: FALL IS COMING, AND APPLE IS KING
description: '' ICAN'T visualize a beautiful fall in Connecticut without thinking about apples,'' said Sal Giudice, owner of Pine Brook Orchard in Colchester. ''The first crisp nights of fall weather give everyone visions of biting into a juicy apple.''

title: JERSEY CITY STATE UPSETS ST. JOHN'S, 23-20
description: Jersey City State, which has not had a winning record since it was 7-3 in 1972, opened the season with a stunning 23-20 upset over St. John's University yesterday at Redmen Stadium in Jamaica, Queens.

title: MONDALE PLANS TO FOCUS ON ISSUES WHERE HE SAYS REAGAN IS WEAK
description: After a halting campaign start, Walter F. Mondale plans in the next few weeks to focus on a series of domestic and foreign policy issues and virtually ignore the area of ''leadership'' on which President Reagan is rated high in the polls.

title: F.B.I. Reports 7% Drop In Serious Crimes
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the number of serious crimes reported to the police fell 7 percent nationwide last year, the biggest drop in 23 years, and experts attributed the decrease to the aging of crime-prone ''baby boom'' teen-agers.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. After this game, the teams meet only three more times - in Chicago next weekend.

title: Patricia Donzelli Plans Wedding in November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Donzelli of Saratoga, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Donzelli to Nicholas Trask Palter, a son of Dr. Robert M. Palter of New Britain, Conn., and Toni Inman Palter of New York. A November wedding is planned.

title: A WOODSY PATH TO PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON IN pursuit of new friendships

title: No Headline
description: Sara Goodman Is Wed

title: CY YOUNG CANDIDATES HAVE MORE THAN ONE WAY TO WIN
description: WHEN Steve Stone signed with the Baltimore Orioles as a free agent in 1978, his contract included a provision that would award him $10,000 if he should win the Cy Young Award as the American League's best pitcher.

title: THE UNEASY PEACE AT OCCIDENTAL
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A PLANNING CLASH: OFFICES VS. HOMES
description: STAMFORD and Greenwich, the communities side by side on Long Island Sound that brought big-city office buildings to Fairfield County in the 1970's, are re-examining their zoning regulations, a periodic exercise.

title: ARCHITECTURE WILL MAINLY BE SEEN IN MUSEUMS
description: For all the important buildings just finished, and for all the construction cranes now looming over New York, this is not going to be a season of buildings. A few striking apartment towers, like the setback-silhouetted Park Belvedere on West 79th Street, will open, but it will be a year or more before most of the major commercial structures now underway reach completion. And the picture is similar in most other cities: the autumn of 1984 is shaping up as a lull between the activity of the last year or two and the completion of the buildings now going up.

title: NOTED WITH PLELASURE
description: A Shade of Blue

title: Tracy Hoopes Becomes Bride of William Parker
description: Tracy Townsend Hoopes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Barclay Hoopes of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to William Challen Parker, the son of Challen Rogers Parker Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Betty Putnam Parker. The Rev. David W. Good, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: LETTERS ; Mortgage Money
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Being Let Go

title: ROTARY CLUB TURNS VICTORIAN HOUSE INTO HOME FOR THE AGED
description: The 63 members of the Madison Rotary Club have invested more than $200,000 to renovate a house for the elderly.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ALTHOUGH ''Maverick: Fifty Years of Investigative Reporting,'' by Fred J. Cook (Putnam, New York, $18.95) includes tender memories of growing up in a rural Point Pleasant, it is not intended for leisurely, nostalgic reading.

title: Beatrice Reed to Marry R. A. Morrison
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Pryor Reed of New York and Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Beatrice Anne Reed to Roger Albert Morrison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Roger Morrison of London and Chiddingfold, England. A December wedding is planned.

title: Traveler Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Odeda Rosenthal wrote movingly of her experience as hostess at the 1984 International Games for the Disabled.

title: 16 Die in Plunge in Turkey
description: Sixteen people died and 19 were injured Friday when a farm tractor-trailer they were riding on plunged off a cliff in Corum, 120 miles northeast of Ankara, the Anatolian News Agency reported.

title: EMPHASIS ON NOVELTIES AT MERCHANDISE SHOW
description: Neon-orange stretchable shoelaces, gold-plated artificial fingernails, hygienic telephone ear- and mouthpiece covers - those products and more than 80,000 others went on display yesterday at the 51st National Merchandise Show, at the New York Coliseum.

title: HAS CATACOSINOS RESCUEDLILCO?
description: WHEN William J. Catacosinos took over last January as chairman of the board of the Long Island Lighting Company, the utility had spent more than $3.2 billion on a reactor that it feared would never open and, as a result, was within seven months of running out of money and being forced into bankruptcy.

title: CHILD ABUSE: COURT RULES TV AT TRIAL PERMISSIBLE
description: MOUNT HOLLY A RULING in Burlington County Superior Court here that a 12-year-old girl can testify over closed-circuit television in a case involving abuse and sexual assault breaks new ground in New Jersey legal history and is only the second of its kind in the nation.

title: TROUPE USES DANCE IN PRAYER
description: ''AVODAH'' means ''service of the heart'' in Hebrew, and the Avodah Dance Ensemble, says Jo Anne Tucker, its founder and director, uses Jewish tradition as a catalyst to create dance ''to express visually what is in the heart.''

title:
GARDENING;
THE SUBTLE ART OF READING PLANT LEAVES
description: Although the value of reading tea leaves to tell the future is dubious, reading plant leaves as a means of identifying their problems is not.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Bank Group Reports Accord on Debt
description: Mexico's bank advisory group announced yesterday that it had formalized the agreement with the Government to restructure the repayment of the country's public debt.

title: Ex-Leader in Zimbabwe Denies Mugabe Charges
description: A former Prime Minister, who was released this week after 10 months of detention, today denied Government allegations that he had been involved in subversive activities before his arrest.

title: Optometrist Wed To Loretta Tofani
description: Loretta Tofani, a reporter for The Washington Post who won a Pulitzer Prize last year for special local reporting about prison conditions, was married yesterday to Dr. John Edward White, an optometrist in private practice in Washington. The Rev. Raymond Schroth performed the ceremony at Annunciation Roman Catholic Church in Crestwood, N.Y.

title: BOSTON U. STOPS GRAMBLING
description: For the last five years Eddie Robinson has hinted that his Grambling Tigers needed tougher competition in the annual Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Football Classic.

title: IKE: HOW GREAT A PRESIDENT?
description: EISENHOWER

title: CREATING ART WITH SILK
description: WHEN Carol Hunt, a Southampton artist, was invited to enter ''Silk Works,'' a national design competition sponsored by the American Silk Mills and the Gayle Willson Gallery, she agreed eagerly because ''it sounded like a fun thing to do.''

title: Miss Coxe Weds John Ballantyne
description: Louise Clarke Coxe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Stafford Coxe of Gladwyne, Pa., was married yesterday to John Ainslie Ballantyne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Heath Ballantyne of Brookhaven, L.I., and Auckland, New Zealand. The Rev. Maurice A. Coombs performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Memorial Church of the Good Shepherd in Philadelphia.

title: L.I. TIES IN TWO BOOKS
description: TWO books with strong Long Island connections are steady sellers among representative area booksellers who report their weekly book sales to The New York Times.

title: REACTOR LICENSE VOTED, BUT COAST FIGHT GOES ON
description: For a decade, Diablo Canyon has been a symbol of the struggle between those who contend that nuclear plants create too great a risk of a devastating accident and those who maintain that America's continued growth depends ont he clean, efficient production of power through fission.

title: THE WORLD ; Mourning a Priest
description: Killed In Chile

title: Canadians Top Czechs To Gain Semifinal Berth
description: Canada, led by Mike Bossy, Brent Sutter and John Tonelli, scored four first-period goals tonight to defeat Czechoslovakia, 7-2, and gain a berth in the Canada Cup semifinal.

title: OFFICIALS PREDICT MORE FLAWS IN BRIDGES
description: THE Yankee Doodle Bridge in Norwalk, partly closed because of two cracks, is not expected to be the last bridge in Connecticut to have such problems, according to the State Transportation Commissioner, J. William Burns.

title: PRINCETON HELPING FRESHMEN ATTACK THE 'PREPARATION GAP'
description: For Milagros Mejias, a freshman from the Bronx, it was the stillness of the first night she spent on campus that kept her awake.

title: ELDERLY TEST COORDINATION WITH VIDEO GAME
description: Residents of a center for the elderly here gather twice a week to play a video game in a study of the game's potential for improving their eye-hand coordination.

title: The Olympics, Firsthand
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: While I'm sure Odeda Rosenthal meant well in her article, one sentence pained me terribly. She asserts that the press should have covered the games more thoroughly and that the participants ''are not mentally retarded, nor repulsive to look at.''

title: Speaking Up For Town Employees
description: I have read the cleverly written commentary on the Aug. 5 Opinion Page (''A Dumping Permit, A Hint of Chekhov'') denouncing the behavior of the Southold Town Clerk's staff.

title: CRIME
description: The sea plays a major part in ASIA RIP by George Foy (Viking, $16.95) - the sea off Cape Cod, where commercial fishermen crisscross the Nantucket area. A Cape Cod boat disappears in good weather with all hands. Lars Larsen, a friend of the missing skipper and himself the captain of a fishing boat, determines to find out what happened. Before he is through, he becomes entangled with organized crime, is framed for murder, goes into hiding and has to take on powerful interests to clear himself.

title: Julie Young And Lawyer Are Married
description: Julie Young, a daughter of Patricia B. Young of New York and Robert F. Young of Hastings-on-Hudson and Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Neal O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal O'Connor of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Lawrence A. A. Larson performed the ceremony at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Brewster, N.Y.

title: Sara H. Deadrick Becomes a Bride
description: Sara Hall Deadrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Deadrick of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Minot Allen Frye, the son of Mrs. Allen F. Frye of Essex, Mass., and the late Mr. Frye. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, assisted by the Rev. William Eddy, performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: RECALLING THE NATION'S GLORY DAYS
description: ''Coimbra sings, Braga prays, Lisbon shows off and Oporto works,'' runs a saying no doubt coined in Oporto, defining the attributes of four of Portugal's chief cities. Lisbon and Oporto, exhilarating and in many ways beautiful as they both are, are full of the noise and jostling confusion of all great commercial centers. Those who prefer to enjoy in tranquillity the historic architecture and lovely countryside of central Portugal may be more attracted to the two smaller cities.

title:
ART;
EMPHASIZING THE PAINT IN PAINTINGS
description: FOR some painters, the act of manipulating their medium, of exploring the qualities and effects of which their chosen materials are capable, seems to take precedence over the creation of specific imagery. It is not that their work lacks subject matter or recognizable motifs, but rather that these are secondary in importance to the act of picture-making itself.

title: East German Official To Confer With Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will confer with Oskar Fischer, his East German counterpart, in about three weeks, State Department officials said tonight.

title: BALLROOM DANCERS TEACH BALLET STUDENTS
description: CLIFTON

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BUENOS AIRES
description: Buenos Aires is a city of high style and great passion, a city so huge, so modern and so resplendent that few first-time visitors fathom that it exists in the deep south of South America. Argentines call it ''mi Buenos Aires querido'' (''my beloved Buenos Aires'') and have devoted countless smoldering tangos and flowery poems to it.

title: Laura Ann Harnett to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Harnett of Massapequa, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Laura Ann Harnett to Robert Regis Hogan, a son of Robert Hogan, also of Massapequa, and the late Jane Hogan.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR TASTES
description: RECENTLY, I read somewhere that wine from the cabernet sauvignon grape should smell like black tea, herbs or olives; that pinot noir should recall mint; zinfandel, briars or berries; gew"urztraminer, spice, and semillon, fresh figs or - get this - freshly washed bed sheets drying in the sun.

title: NOT-SO-WILD FRONTIER
description: William Broyles Jr., former editor of Newsweek, Texas Monthly and California magazines, is working on a novel. GUNFIGHTERS, HIGHWAYMEN & VIGILANTES

title: LOOKING BACK WITH AARON COPLAND
description: Note to copy desk: there is a copyright line with this piece. Check Frank Camp's office. - D.E.

title: Distance Swim A True Feat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNALZ
description: WITH complaints about burglaries and robberies mounting, the Village of Lawrence and the cable telechise company franchised by it have put together plans to use television to monitor public parking lots and, in some cases, apartment building lobbies.

title: GIANTS' PASS RUSH TARGETS HOGEBOOM
description: The Giants, like everyone else, know little about Gary Hogeboom, the Dallas Cowboys' starting quarterback for today's game at Giants Stadium. They do know that Hogeboom's first starting assignment turned out to be a roaring success on Monday night against the Los Angeles Rams, and that the best defense against such a formidable passer is a formidable pass rush.

title: Winslow Returning
description: Kellen Winslow, the all-pro tight end who announced his retirement from professional football last week over contract problems with the San Diego Chargers, said yesterday that he would return to the National Football League team today.

title: Mary Beth Murphy a Bride
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Mary Beth Murphy, the daughter of Rita G. Murphy of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and William A. Murphy of New York, was married to Thomas Edward Lurcott, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Horace V. Lurcott of Beach Haven, N.J. Msgr.

title: HISTORIC PATERSON MILL BECOMING OFFICES
description: WHEN the 74-year-old Franklin Mill in Paterson was sold last year, the buyer found cartons of textile spools stowed away on the ground floor amid tons of industrial debris.

title: Falcon, 7, Dies of Infection
description: A peregrine falcon named Scarlett that lived on the 33d floor of a Baltimore skyscraper died of an infection that began in a wound in her mouth, an ornithologist said Friday. The bird had nested on a ledge at the United States Fidelity and Guaranty building for six of her seven years. It died Thursday at the hospital unit of the Baltimore Zoo.

title: MAKING THE SEASON LAST LONGER
description: IT may seem a trifle late to review a Hamptons restaurant, but this particular candidate, Oliver in Westhampton Beach, did not open until July, and the season, if that is a measure of the viability of an enterprise in the resort area, was nearly half over. Besides, assurances ranging from mid-October until January were given for the continued operation of the place.

title: NEW MEXICO OFFICIALS ENTER UNIVERSITY FEUD
description: The Governor and the State Attorney General have been drawn into a dispute over the search for a new president for the University of New Mexico.

title: ; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: Goodbye Sex, Hello Gender

title: Nancy Sutton Is Bride Of Coast Guard Officer
description: Nancy Helen Sutton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Sutton of Larchmont, N.Y., and Bondville, Vt., and Lieut. (j.g.) William Nelson Finley, U.S.C.G., a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Finley of Beach Haven, N.J., and Gulf Breeze, Fla., were married yesterday. Mayor Suzanne Oppenheimer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: 'ABBY ANDREWS,' ALCOHOLIC
description: BROKEN PROMISES, MENDED DREAMS By Richard Meryman. 351 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: No Headline
description: Jean P. Wynn Is Married

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A MAILB FULL OF FANTASIES
description: OPENING my mail nowadays puts me in the grip of a fatal fascination. Neither rain, nor sleet, nor hail prevents the postman's regular delivery of messages that mesmerize. ''Pie in the sky'' pursues me to my very doorstep in the form of multiple mailings, which insistently make me offers I cannot refuse. After all, what have I got to lose?

title: ADVERTISING BANS VERSUS FREE SPEECH
description: In a television advertisement for

title: SMALL DONORS LESS VITAL IN '82 VOTE THAN IN '78
description: Small contributions to House and Senate candidates were much less important in 1982 than in 1978, according to a study of Federal Election Commission records.

title: Queens Boy Is Killed
description: A 14-year-old Queens boy, Peter Bera of 70-20 Kissena Boulevard, was killed and another, Mohamod Weish of 15-15 72d Road, was seriously injured yesterday evening, apparently while they were standing between two parked cars in Fresh Meadows, Queens, a police spokesman said. The spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said a car driven by Albert Mazaltov, 50, of 102-25 67th Road, Forest Hills, ran into the vehicles when struck by another car.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A NEW AUCTION SEASON OPENS IN NEW YORK
description: Coin collectors tend to regard New York as the auction capital of the world and coming events seem likely to reinforce this perception. After several months of relative inactivity, two important auctions will take place in midtown Manhattan within the next 10 days.

title: A MAINSTAY OF TERRORISM
description: Federal officials say most Americans are not even aware of some of the most serious ramifications of drug abuse.

title: Sports of The Times ; Impertinent Cubs Cause Problems
description: The Cubs have caused a state

title: POP: SUNNY ADE AND BLACK UHURU
description: The American pop market is beckoning to King Sunny Ade and his African Beats, from Nigeria, and Black Uhuru from Jamaica, who are touring the United States together. Their New York show Friday, opening two nights at Pier 84, suggested that both groups are willing to try a few American notions - but not to abandon their own music.

title: Measles in U.S. Rises Sharply
description: The incidence of measles in the United States increased sharply in the first half of this year to 1,759 cases, as against 1,095 for the comparable period of 1983, Federal health officials report.

title: THE REGION ; New York 212,New York 718
description: Calling a friend was more genteel in 1876, when the telephone was patented. Each line was identified by a name, not a number. Enumeration began in 1880, when each phone in a town was assigned two digits. By 1930, the number of digits had grown to seven, and in 1951 the introduction of area codes stretched the number still more.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOCCER STAR'S RESTAURANT IN CLIFTON
description: FOR those unfamiliar with American soccer, Bogie 8 will mean nothing. But for devotees of the game, 8 is the number worn by the Yugoslavian-born captain of the Cosmos, Vladimir Bogicevic (Bogie to his fans).

title: TUESDAY VOTE IS FOCUSING ON 20th C.D.
description: WHITE PLAINS THE focus of Tuesday's primaries in the county will be on the outcome of a hard-fought campaign by four Democrats for the 20th Congressional District seat being vacated by Representative Richard L. Ottinger.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
PUTTING A HEX ON MACHINES
description: COMPUTERS don't like me. At first, I was indifferent to computers, but now I am diametrically opposed to them taking over the world in general and my life in particular.

title: ARMY WOULD MODIFY TROUBLED ANTIAIRCRAFT GUN
description: The Army says it is considering the addition of Stinger missiles to its Sergeant York antiaircraft gun to increase the chances of hitting enemy planes.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; A New ForumFor Shockley
description: Although William B. Shockley won the Nobel Prize in physics for inventing the transistor, he is better known for his theory that blacks are genetically inferior in intelligence to whites. After decades of bitter scientific debate, that idea may be put on trial - literally.

title: DEVELOPER DROPS PLAN TO BUILD OFFICES NEAR A JERSEY CONVENT
description: A developer has abandoned plans to construct an office building next to a convent almost a year after the cloistered nuns broke a vow of silence to fight the project, which they contended would destroy their solitude.

title: POP STARS ARE EVERYWHERE
description: P aul McCartney, Mr. T., David Bowie, Prince, Laurie Anderson, Duran Duran, Julio Iglesias, Talking Heads. What do they have in common? All of them have been successful in pop music, except for the television personality Mr. T. More important, all of them, Mr. T. included, will be attempting to wring more lucre from the public's pockets this fall by launching multimedia campaigns.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION ;
THOSE BACK-TO-SCHOOL LAUNDRY-DAY BLUES
description: SO, the public school system has staked its claim on your first-born, and naturally you are worried. To the novice, the ramifications are terrifying. Questions plague you. Does my child really know the alphabet without Bert and Ernie? Will he fend off playground bullies as well as he does the attacks of his little sister? Will he excel in math the way the computer salesman promised he would?

title: THE EAGLE SOARS AGAIN
description: ONCE again, the annual headcount of bald eagles has brought smiles to ornithologists' lips. According to the National Wildlife Federation, 11,819 eagles were observed in 42 of the 48 contiguous states during this year's midwinter census.
