description: Food was all over the place at the

title: JOE BUSHKIN RETURNING FOR A JAZZ ANNIVERSARY
description: ''I'm back into a great feeling about music,'' the jazz musician Joe Bushkin said enthusiastically the other day as he surveyed a career that goes back to the beginning of the big band era. A jazz pianist and composer, Mr. Bushkin is also a walking encyclopedia of jazz lore who has known and worked with some of the great legends of his time. And he is celebrating two of them - Louis Armstrong and Fats Waller - as part of his 50th anniversary in show business.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, has named Joseph J. Laferty president, venture capital investments and technology, and Ronald J. Burns vice president, finance and administration, and chief financial officer.

title: Renault's New Model
description: The state- owned Renault automobile company has disclosed the first details of its Supercinq, or Superfive, to succeed its best-selling R-5, known as Le Car in the United States.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 10, 1984: MONDAY Bristol-Myers

title: 'IT IS SO SIMPLE'
description: BOSTON It is the practice of tyrannical governments to talk of democracy

title: PHILOSOPHERS WITHOUT ROCK-OF-FAITH SUPPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: WIFE-BEATING: FINDING WAYS TO STOP RECURRENCE
description: The best way to deal with men who batter their wives is to arrest them, and more police are doing just that instead of trying to mediate marital disputes, a panel of experts on domestic violence said recently.

title: SPURRED BY WHITE HOUSE PARLEY, TV EVANGELISTS SPREAD POLITICAL WORD
description: As the White House last week tried to damp charges that it maintained a special relationship with the political forces of Christian fundamentalism, those forces were moving more broadly than four years ago to stimulate their constituents to vote for President Reagan's re-election.

title: 25 Former Hostages Arrive In South Africa From Angola
description: A total fo 25 former hostages, including a Roman Catholic priest and 11 nuns, arrived in South Africa after being released by the anti-Government guerrillas in Angola who had seized them, an official of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.

title: JOHN PAUL BEGINS A TOUR OF CANADA
description: Pope John Paul II today became the first Pope to visit Canada, beginning a 12-day visit with a strong call for a return to traditional values.

title: VAIRO IS HAPPY TO BE OUT OF THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Lou Vairo could be doing other things, he says, something altogether different. ''I'm a helluva cook,'' he said one day last week, sitting in a chilly rink in Montreal, goose bumps picking up where his short sleeves left off. ''In fact, I'm a better cook than I am a coach. The restaurant business. I could do it. Fifteen hours a day, six days a week, I could do it and I'd love it.''

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: 'RITUALS' STARTS TONIGHT WITH 5 SHOWS A WEEK
description: Picture this for an opening sequence: An elderly and obviously very wealthy old lady is found dead in the chair lift attached to her grand staircase. A devoted black maid shrieks in horror. Cut to the funeral on a beautifully manicured hillside.

title: CONCERT: 'BACH: MUSICAL OFFERING' AT TULLY HALL
description: Sound the trumpet and let the celebrations begin. J. S. Bach will be 300 years old next March, so the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center decided to preface its regular season with a brief festival in his honor. The five-concert event, entitled ''J. S. Bach: A Musical Offering,'' began last night at Alice Tully Hall with, most appropriately, a program that climaxed in an enthralling performance of the composer's rarely heard masterpiece, ''The Musical Offering.''

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS SAID TO KIDNAP 2
description: Two local Sandinista leaders were apparently kidnapped by Nicaraguan rebels last week, and Government officials here said today that they feared both had been killed.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS EYE MONDALE WITH ANXIETY FOR THEIR CAMPAIGNS
description: The past week of the Presidential campaign has caused some Congressional Democrats to worry out loud that Walter F. Mondale's showing may hurt their campaigns. It has also given new hope to Republican strategists of restoring the legislative coalition that gave President Reagan his most important victories in 1981.

title: A Mix of Fans
description: The mixed doubles title, with a $17,000 top prize, was won by Manuella Maleeva and Tom Gullikson, who beat Elizabeth Sayers and John Fitzgerald by 2-6, 7-5, 6-4. . . . The boardwalk connecting Shea Stadium with the National Tennis Center was a sporting jamboree, a hectic mix of baseball and tennis fans. Vendors who had limited themselves to Open T-shirts (''Five dollars here! Eleven dollars inside!) added Mets caps to their inventory and did a booming business.

title: G.M. LINK AIDS ITALIAN DESIGNER
description: Pininfarina, the Italian auto design company, sails under two flags these days. On the lawn of its big new design center just outside this Piedmontese smokestack city, the American stars and stripes flutter alongside Italy's red, white and green.

title: NEW ERA, NEW PROBLEMS FOR SOUTH'S SHERIFFS
description: Among the 5,000 residents of rural Dawson County, Sheriff John David Davis was the law. The fact that he had once served time in the Federal penitentiary for moonshining and the gossip that he was the target of a Federal drug investigation did not seem to bother most people.

title: Cruise Missile Passes Test
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile successfully passed a test firing Saturday, the Navy reported. The Navy said the missile ''successfully demonstrated its capability to search for, locate and attack a target at sea during a test conducted at the Atlantic Fleet Weapons Training Facility, Sea Test Range, Western Atlantic and Caribbean waters.''

title: YANKS ARE ROUTED BY RED SOX, 10-1
description: The American League batting title will undoubtedly go to a Yankee this year, either Dave Winfield or Don Mattingly. If this weren't September, though, with the season in its twilight, it might not be such a fait accompli. Wade Boggs appears to be just heating up.

title: Paul M. Masullo Marries Yvette Marina D'Arrigo
description: Our Lady of Pompeii Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Yvette Marina D'Arrigo, the daughter of James D'Arrigo of Jersey City and Berte D'Arrigo of New York, to Paul Mark Masullo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Masullo of New York.

title: TRIAL DUE ON PENN SQUARE
description: William G. Patterson, the freewheeling Penn Square Bank officer who became known for wearing Mickey Mouse ears to the bank and drinking liquor from his shoe, goes on trial here Monday on charges of violating Federal bank laws.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Lauda Captures Italian Grand Prix
description: Niki Lauda of Austria drove his McLaren- Tag-Porsche to victory today in the Italian Grand Prix and strengthened his lead in the Formula One world driver standing.

title: SOME UNITS OF JAYCEES REBEL AGAINST ADMITTING WOMEN
description: In Zilwaukee, Mich., the local Jaycees closed their $200,000 meeting hall and disbanded their chapter rather than admit women as members because, the chapter president said, ''I like a night out with the guys after the work's done.''

title: RAIDERS THWART PACKERS, 28-7
description: The cornerbacks Mike Haynes and Lester Hayes and the rest of the Los Angeles secondary dominated Green Bay's receivers today as the Raiders whipped the Packers, 28-7.

title: CITY'S CANDIDATES MAKE FINAL APPEALS FOR VOTES
description: While scores of candidates in tomorrow's New York State primary elections campaigned at street fairs, corners, parks and anywhere else crowds could be found, behind the scenes, aides instructed workers and prepared literature for the Primary Day effort to get out the vote.

title: Washington Watch; U.S.-Israeli Trade Issue
description: WASHINGTON

title: A COOPERATIVE ON THE BEACH LOVES PRIVACY
description: ''Why should everything be public?'' Rosalie Clifford said as she entertained neighbors on the back deck of her asphalt-sided, five-room house in the oceanside Queens community of Breezy Point the other day. ''Everyone's entitled to privacy. ''We don't want any outsiders coming in.'' If there is one quality that links the residents of Breezy Point, it is their passion for privacy. ''If you want public, you go over the bridge,'' said a neighbor, Betty Glennon, referring to the Gil Hodges Memorial Bridge, which must be crossed to get there.

title: BULGARIAN LEADER CALLS OFF BONN VISIT
description: The leader of Bulgaria has called off a scheduled visit to West Germany, a Bonn Government spokesman disclosed today.

title: OPTIMISM MARKS BRITISH AIR SHOW
description: ''Dassault!'' said John Conry knowingly, before resuming a demonstration of the signal-tracking wares of Britain's Marconi Company. The demonstration had just been interrupted by the ear-splitting roar of a jet fighter screaming past the exhibition halls of the Farnborough international air show.

title: THIRD-WORLD DICTATORS UNWORTHY OF U.S. AID
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Police Fire Tear Gas to Quell Riots
description: The police said today that they fired tear gas and rubber bullets to quell a fresh outbreak of rioting in the township of Sebokeng, one of three black areas south of Johannesburg where 31 people have died in unrest in the last week.

title: ;  Holyfield to Sign With Duva Group
description: Evander Holyfield, the Olympic light-heavyweight boxer who was disqualified for hitting on the break while knocking out his opponent, has elected to sign with Dan Duva and Shelly Finkel.

title: MARYLANDERS THROW A PATRIOTIC PARTY
description: When the green parachutes blossomed in the sky, everyone cheered. The endless game of horseshoes paused, and the players silently watched. When the jumpers glided to earth and their canopies fluttered down to disappear in the green fields of soybeans, the cheers rose again.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ; ;  Schoolboy Star Quits Notre Dame
description: Byron Abraham, the leading career rusher in Central New York scholastic football history, has left the University of Notre Dame and will transfer to another school, possibly Syracuse, according to officials from each school.

title: Mexico Cites Debt Pact Gains
description: The innovative agreement between Mexico and its bank advisory committee gives Mexico 14 years to pay $48.5 billion in debt that it would have had to pay in six years, the Mexican Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, said today.

title: THE GRAPES OF 'INFLATION-FREE RECOVERY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Weil Is Wed To an Illustrator
description: Wendy Weil, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jay Weil of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Trossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Trossman of Chicago. Rabbi David Posner of Temple Emanu-El in New York performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Kiernan in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: An Asian Jazz Festival Scheduled Next Month

title: MCENROE BEATS LENDL TO TAKE 4TH OPEN TITLE
description: John McEnroe used his battery of serves and volleys, alternately overpowering and teasing, and dominated Ivan Lendl yesterday to regain the United States Open tennis title he held from 1979 to 1981. His 6-3, 6-4, 6-1 victory was a testimony to McEnroe's artistry and will, because it came less than 15 hours after his bruising five- set semifinal victory over Jimmy Connors, a match that lasted 3 hours 45 minutes and ended at 11:13 P.M. Saturday.

title: Jailed Basques Fasting In France Said to Fail
description: Eight Spanish Basque exiles on hunger strike for a month at a prison near Paris are no longer able to speak or hear, according to their support committee.

title: IF OLDER PARENTS RELOCATE
description: IN 1980 Charles O'Brien of Brooklyn

title: Alcott Triumphs
description: Amy Alcott shot a 2-under-par 70 today to win the $150,000 Portland PING Championship by three strokes.

title: FISHING GUIDE'S FRUSTRATIONS
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.

title: She Who Fought the Fight
description: There will be more familiar

title: CHANGES IN FRENCH DRINKING
description: One of the newcomers to the French cafe scene has nothing to do with champagne, beer, mineral water or existentialism. It is Brut de pomme, a cider aimed at the cola consumer, and it is part of an alteration in drinking habits that is causing far-reaching changes in the French beverage industry.

title: BUSINESS Digest; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1984
description: Companies

title: FOUR-WARNINGED IS FOREARMED
description: What is the single most preventable cause of death and disease in the United States? What causes the deaths of more than 340,000 Americans annually, will kill 24 million now alive from heart disease alone and costs the economy $40 billion annually in lost productivity and health care costs? Cigarette smoking. Congress can help lessen this carnage.

title: Power in the House
description: The power of conservative Southern Democrats has been steadily declining in the House of Representatives for the last two decades. Where once the Dixie delegation, heavy with seniority, ran many key House committees, there are now only 6 Southern chairmen among the 22 standing committees, and half of those are Floridians who tend to be more moderate than their colleagues from the Deep South.

title: Centex President Quits, But Will Stay on Board
description: Jack L. McDonald, president and chief operating officer of the Centex Corporation, has resigned to pursue personal business interests, the company announced. Mr. McDonald's resignation is effective Nov. 15, but the company said he would remain a member of its board.

title: G.M. and Auto Union Step Up Pace of Talks
description: After a weekend of long hours and heated exchanges at the bargaining table, the United Automobile Workers and General Motors began a stepped-up effort today to reach a new contract by midnight Friday.

title: Christine L. Jue Becomes Bride
description: Christine Lee Jue and Orson Desaix Munn 3d were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC AND ARTS MERGE IN HIGH SCHOOL-FINALLY
description: The students who will spend their days in the new classrooms of the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts were worried about details.

title: Former Delaware Judge Wins in Democratic Race
description: Former Justice William Quillen of the State Supreme Court won Saturday's Democratic gubernatorial primary. He will face Lieut. Gov. Michael N. Castle, a Republican, in the November general election.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; 3 Heritage Festivals: Blarney and Banners . . .
description: As a slight breeze ruffled through

title: STORM LASHES FLORIDA COAT AS WINDS REACH 70 M.P.H.
description: Tropical storm Diana lashed Florida's northeast coast with high tides, wall-like waves and 70 mile- per-hour winds early today, prompting some seaside residents to pack up and flee and thousands more from Florida to North Carolina to prepare for a speedy evacuation.

title: 7 ISRAELI M.P.'S DESERT LABOR OVER MOVE TO OFFER A POST TO SHARON
description: The Labor Alignment's strength in Parliament shrank by seven seats tonight as a result of defections by leftist members of the Alignment unhappy over the decision to work to form a coalition government with the rightist Likud bloc.

title: ;  Vault Record Set
description: Radion Gataulin set a world junior record of 18 feet 6 1/2 inches in the pole vault at a Soviet national track and field meet, Tass, the official press agency, reported today. Thierry Vigneron of France held the previous record at 18-4 3/4.

title: SHULTZ RULES OUT A TESTING FREEZE ON SPACE WEAPONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was ready to discuss a joint moratorium on tests of new space weapons with the Soviet Union, but he ruled out a Soviet proposal for a freeze of such tests in advance of actual negotiations.

title: FEDERAL REGULATIONS PARE REQUIREMENTS FOR BILINGUAL BALLOTS
description: New rules issued by the Federal Government sharply reduce the number of counties that must provide bilingual ballots to Hispanic-Americans and other minority groups in the election this November.

title: 5 Seized in Jersey As Counterfeiters
description: Secret Service agents, aided by Hudson County Sheriff's deputies, raided a big counterfeiting operation here on Saturday and arrested five men, officials said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel unbelievable and terrible at the same time. My body said 'That's enough,' but the fact that I was tired made me concentrate better.'' - John McEnroe. (C1:5)

title: THE U.N.'S VISION IS 'CLOUDED,' ITS CHIEF FUNDS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today in his annual report that the once ''majestic vision'' of the United Nations had been ''clouded by the differences of the major powers.''

title: BOND ISSUERS HOLDING BACK
description: When long-term interest rates fell in July and early August while short- term rates held steady, many investment bankers and economists expected corporations to storm the bond markets for money. All year long they had been building up mountainous amounts of short-term debt because the dramatically lower rates in 90-day commercial paper or from banks were too tempting to pass up.

title: ; ONE DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY TOO MANY
description: To the Editor:

title: Yilmaz Guney Is Dead;Turkish Film Director
description: Yilmaz Guney, a film maker who directed ''Yol'' from his cell in a Turkish prison and then escaped to edit the movie and see it win top honors at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival, died of stomach cancer in a Paris hospital yesterday, his family announced. He was 47 years old.

title: METS CUT CUB LEAD TO 6
description: The Mets knew they had to win the game, they weren't winning it - they weren't losing it, either - and their inability to score was frustrating them.

title: Marion Samsam and Alan Solbert Wed
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday Marion Hines Samsam, a daughter of Margaret B. White of St. Thomas, V.I., and Col. Charles Boes Hines, U.S.A., retired, of Roswell, N.M., was married to Alan Goodrich Kirk Solbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. A. Solbert of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: SCIENTISTS CLONE BIT OF VIRUS LINKED TO AIDS
description: Scientists in California disclosed yesterday that they had successfully grown in the laboratory all of the genetic material from a virus that is a probable cause of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Like last week, the Mets have two games each with the Cardinals and the Pirates as preparation for a weekend series against the first-place Cubs. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: Personnel, Structure Changing at M.C.M.
description: C. Ray Freeman, the former I.B.M. man who has been president of Muir Cornelius Moore, is leaving to join Lord Geller Federico Einstein as a senior vice president.

title: PUBLISHING MANUSCRIPTS POSTHUMOUSLY
description: Although he had been working on ''Answered Prayers'' since 1972, and long ago published several of its projected chapters in Esquire magazine, Truman Capote had not handed in any part of the manuscript to his book editor for five or six years before the author died last month.

title: West Berlin Police Break Up Purported Neo-Nazi Meeting
description: The police raided the apartment of a 21- year-old West Berlin man Friday night and broke up what they said was a meeting to organize a neo-Nazi group, a police statement said Saturday.

title: Scali's Yellow Pages
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a major subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather, has established a Yellow Pages marketing and media division by acquiring Kevin Keary to head it and has named him a senior vice president.

title: ARCHBISHOP CALLS FERRARO MISTAKEN ON ABORTION RULE
description: The Archbishop of New York asserted yesterday that Geraldine A. Ferraro had created the mistaken impression that Roman Catholic teaching on abortion was ''open to interpretation,'' when in fact it was monolithic.

title: BUILDER OF ENERGY COMPLEXES
description: J. Robert Fluor, the industrialist who helped expand the engineering and construction concern his grandfather founded into one of the largest companies in the nation, died today of cancer. He was 62 years old.

title: CANDIDATES CLASH IN CAROLINA RACE
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. and Senator Jesse Helms engaged in a sharp debate tonight over the national holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and the state of race relations in North Carolina.

title: LOUISIANIAN WHO KILLED NEIGHBOR EXECUTED AFTER APPEAL IS REFUSED
description: Timothy Baldwin, a former Cub Scout leader convicted of beating an 85-year-old blind woman to death with a frying pan, was electrocuted early today at the Louisiana State Prison.

title: HORIZON SEEKS TO OPEN BANK IN CITY
description: The Horizon Bancorporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in New Jersey, will apply to the New York State Banking Department within the next month to establish a consumer bank in lower Manhattan, William J. Sheppard, Horizon's president and chief executive officer said in an interview Friday.

title: California Suffers In Long Heat Wave By United Press International
description: High clouds spawned by Hurricane Marie helped bring the mercury slightly below 100 degrees yesterday, but stifling humidity meant little relief from a hot spell that has killed at least four people in four days.

title: FLUTIE'S SCRAMBLING UNRAVELS ALABAMA
description: Doug Flutie went down hard, slammed from behind after throwing a pass midway through the third period when he and his Boston College teammates were trailing Alabama, 31-14, Saturday night. The scrambling quarterback extended his left arm to break the fall on the artificial turf of Legion Field and jammed it so badly that it hurt him considerably for the remainder of the game.

title: No Headline
description: Philharmonia Virtuosi To Open 10th Season

title: . . . A Prize Pickle . . .
description: ''Test your Jewish knowledge and

title: He Who Sailed the Blue
description: Sly Congressional Humor Department: The Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Act was officially recorded as House Resolution 1492.

title: CHESS TITLE MATCH BEGINS TODAY
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the 33-year-old world chess champion, starts his third title defense today in Moscow against his countryman, 21-year-old Gary Kasparov.

title: No Headline
description: Susan Johnson Marries

title: LAFAYETTE RADIO SETS NEW PATH
description: Lafayette Radio Electronics, a pioneer electronics retail chain in the New York area, served a generation of postwar consumers before it filed for bankruptcy in 1980. Now, in much reduced form and under new owners, Lafayette is targeting the children of that generation with a new national- brand approach, several new stores in the metropolitan area and a guaranteed competitive-price policy.

title: ROMAN CATHOLIC SHRINE IS SITE FOR REAGAN RALLY
description: President Reagan today brought his re- election campaign to a Roman Catholic religious shrine revered by Polish- Americans, where a crowd of several thousand people shouted ''Four More Years! Four More Years!'' and John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia praised Mr. Reagan's policies.

title: Sarah Jane Jelin is Married to Edward K. Schwarz
description: Sarah Jane Jelin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Jelin of South Orange, N.J., was married yestertday to Edward Kenneth Schwarz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Schwarz of Union, N.J. Rabbis Jehiel Orenstein and Devora Bartnoff performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in Caldwell, N.J.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BAROQUE AND ROCK It's very bawdy,'' Diane Charlotte Lampert was saying, ''a 'Beggar's Opera' kind of thing. I mean the mood, not the music.'' Miss Lampert was describing a new musical comedy called ''Nell'' that will be presented in concert form tonight at 7:30 by the Chamber Opera Theater of New York at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 East 71st Street.

title: LET GEORGE DUCK IT
description: WASHINGTON In our last installment, Vice President George Bush was needled in

title: Nancy Reagan Issues Abortion Clarification
description: A spokesman for Nancy Reagan denied today that the First Lady was suggesting in a newspaper interview that there were circumstances under which she could support a woman's having an abortion.

title: AIRLINES ACCEPT LA GUARDIA PLAN
description: Airlines serving New York's La Guardia airport agreed today to flight schedule revisions that could begin easing congestion and delays by November.

title: Court Voids Seabrook Plan
description: In a decision that could push the lead owner of the Seabrook nuclear plant into bankruptcy, the New Hampshire Supreme Court Friday voided a $425 million financing plan because of biased statements by the state's top utility regulator.

title: TRAIL OF 2 JETS HAS COURTHOUSE BUZZING
description: There is one lineup that the Jets' defensive end Mark Gastineau and the quarterback Ken O'Brien probably never thought they would face: a courtroom jury.

title: BILLY GRAHAM STARTS SECOND SOVIET TOUR
description: The Rev. Billy Graham arrived here today for a preaching tour of four Soviet cities, declaring that he had been ''woefully misinterpreted'' on his first visit two years ago and evidently determined to avoid the criticism he drew then.

title: THE RACE BY NUMBERS
description: When Jim Frey was the batting coach with the Baltimore Orioles, he and the other coaches and Earl Weaver, the manager, compiled a list of all the baseball cliches they could remember.

title: ARCHER WINS BY 6 SHOTS
description: George Archer pulled away from the pack today to win the $350,000 Bank of Boston Golf Classic by six strokes.

title: Padres 8, Astros 4
description: Steve Garvey and Carmelo Martinez drove in two runs apiece, helping the San Diego Padres build an 8-0 lead after two innings. Mark Thurmond (13-7) went seven innings for the victory.

title: ;  Oh, Those Cubs
description: Any Met fans who haven't had enough of the Chicago Cubs by now might want to stop by the Brooklyn Museum to boo or plan to visit the 1010 Repertory Theater on Park Avenue to jeer.

title: Injured Crane Operator Is Stable After Surgery
description: The crane operator who lost an index finger and part of his right leg in the collapse of the machine in mid-Manhattan Saturday afternoon was in serious but stable condition yesterday after surgery at Bellevue Hospital, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Trucks and Buses Allowed on Bridge
description: Trucks and buses were allowed to go over the Yankee Doodle Bridge today for the first time since officials discovered two cracks in support hangers of the heavily traveled bridge.

title: Cigarettes in Congress
description: A pregnant woman who smokes cigarettes puts her fetus at risk of injury, premature birth and low birth weight. And anyone who smokes cigarettes invites lung cancer, heart disease and emphysema.

title: RED FLAGS FLY OVER ROME (BUT WHERE IS MARX?)
description: Maurizio Tomassoni is an activist in San Marino's Communist Party. But at the Italian Communist Party's Festa de l'Unit a this week, Mr. Tomassoni was selling T-shirts bearing the Stars-and-Bars of the Old Confederacy.

title: Debra Michelle Kenyon Married to Peter T. Hess
description: At the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., yesterday Debra Michelle Kenyon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Kenyon of Eastchester, N.Y., was married to Peter Thomas Hess, a son of Walter W. Hess Jr. of New York and Louise Dann of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony.

title: ALLOWING CIVILIAN AID TO LATIN WAR EFFORTS: IS IT LEGAL?
description: By condoning private efforts to support Nicaraguan rebels and El Salvador's armed forces, the Reagan Administration may have furthered its foreign aims, but also may have undermined Federal laws and the intent of Congress, according to Administration officials and Democratic lawmakers. As information about the private efforts became public in recent days, officials and members of Congress said, it became clear that the Administration has done little to prevent activities of questionable legality, apparently because the activities were consistent with the Government's goals in Central America.

title: COLA'S DON'T BOOST PENSION BUYING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Shakes Central Idaho
description: An earthquake registering 4.9 on the Richter scale and several aftershocks rumbled through mountainous central Idaho Saturday, rattling shelves and windows but apparently doing no damage, the authorities said. The shaken region has been the site of three moderate tremors in the past two weeks.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many players from the undefeated Notre Dame and Michigan State teams in 1966 went on to become pros after the teams played to a 10-10 tie late in the season with the top national ranking at stake?

title: BASEBALL ; ; Royals' Victory Puts Them in First
description: Don Slaught and Darryl Motley each hit sacrifice flies in the ninth inning to give Kansas City to a 6-5 triumph over the Seattle Mariners today and earn the Royals sole possession of first place in the American League West.

title: Epstein, Raboy Gets ADR Promotion Effort
description: Applied Data Research - or ADR - might be well known in the corporate computer room where its software systems for I.B.M. equipment have been in use for a quarter-century, but the name probably does not ring bells upstairs when spending for the systems is approved. Since $500,000 or so is a typical sum spent on such systems, corporate recognition can pay off.

title: DOLPHINS' PASSING ROUTS PATRIOTS, 28-7
description: The Miami Dolphins' imaginative passing game stung another team today. Jim Jensen, the quarterback-turned-wide receiver, threw for one touchdown and Dan Marino, the regular quarterback, threw for two, as the Dolphins defeated the New England Patriots, 28-7.

title: Advertising; NCR Plans National Campaign
description: commercials featuring the comedian Dom DeLuise as Ralph the computer retailer resulted in the NCR Corporation's quadrupling the number of dealerships in California that offer its personal computer.

title: LONGER-TERM U.S. ISSUES EXPECTED
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month bills, but dealers in Government securities are looking ahead to a heavy supply of longer-term issues to be auctioned later this month.

title: THE REAL GAINS IN THE WAR ON UNEMPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FILMS ARE THE STAR OF VENICE FESTIVAL
description: J. DIONNE Jr.

title: Debt Issues
description: Kaufman & Broad has filed an offering of $100 million of senior subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes, due in 1994, through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: REPEATING KINDERGARTEN PUTS FOCUS ON GAOSL IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: When about 300 of this city's children were not promoted from kindergarten this spring, the news prompted a few jokes.

title: CHICAGO TRYING TO RESTRICT STREET PERFORMERS
description: Byron Moore is a supple, 6-foot 2-inch break dancer whose favorite place to perform is North Michigan Avenue, this city's premier shopping area.

title: GIANTS ROUT COWBOYS
description: It was the Giants who made the big plays and the Dallas Cowboys who made the bad plays today at Giants Stadium. The result was an astonishing victory for the Giants, 28-7, over a team that had been so abusive to them over so many years.

title: Rooney Pace Official Adds Top Job at Norlin
description: The Rooney Pace Group Inc., the investment concern that said last January that it intended to ''seek significant influence'' over the Norlin Corporation, has done precisely that.

title: BALLET DIRECTOR ON COAST DENIES HE IS RESIGNING
description: Michael Smuin, formerly co-director of the San Francisco Ballet, which announced his resignation from the post on Aug. 29, has denied that he ever submitted a resignation.

title: Miss Bartram Is Bride Of Harland D. Meltzer
description: Carey Gardner Bartram, curator of the corporate art collection of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Harland David Meltzer, a theatrical director, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maynard C. Bartram Jr., in Bloomfield, Conn. Rabbi Robert Harris officiated.

title: Appeal Asks Both Nominees To Pledge Deficit Reduction
description: The Bipartisan Budget Appeal, a group of more than 600 former public officials, chief executive officers, educators, economists and lawyers, is asking President Reagan, Walter F. Mondale and Congress to commit themselves to a deficit reduction plan before the November election.

title: Slain Priest Back in France
description: The body of a French priest, Andre Jarlan, killed during anti-Government protests in Chile last week, was flown home today for burial in his native village of Rignac in southern France. Airport officials said the priest's family had asked that there be no ceremony at Charles de Gaulle Airport.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 10, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: JAMAICA, CLOSE U.S. ALLY, DOES LITTLE TO HALT DRUGS
description: In the last four years, Jamaica has become one of the United States' closest political allies. At the same time, it has been contributing heavily to the worsening American drug problem.

title: Democrats Computerize Hunt for Volunteers
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign kicked off a recruiting program called ''We're The People For Mondale-Ferraro'' with the establishment of a computerized clearinghouse Friday for campaign volunteers.

title: SEAHAWKS WIN IN HARRIS'S DEBUT
description: Franco Harris, after just two practices with his new team, helped bring the Seattle Seahawks out of a first-quarter tailspin today, and they went on to a 31-17 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; New Peugeot Head Directed Cutbacks
description: Jacques Calvet, the new head of France's troubled Peugeot S.A. automobile group, has the reputation of being an abrasive, quick-tempered executive.

title: Addenda
description: * Photo/Design, a new bimonthly magazine with controlled circulation, from Ziff-Davis Publishing.

title: FOR THE TWINS, THERE ARE NO APOLOGIES FOR BEING IN RACE
description: Pushing a grocery cart filled with baseballs, and with mischief on his mind, Tom Kelly, a coach for the Minnesota Twins, headed for the pitcher's mound during batting practice one day in Kansas City, Mo., last week, attaining a speed that shoppers only dream about in a supermarket. When Kelly reached his destination, he tipped over the cart and fell sprawling, scattering baseballs and evoking laughs from the fans who had arrived early at Royals Stadium.

title: Fire on Ticonderoga Injures 13 in Crew
description: A fire in an exhaust vent aboard the Ticonderoga injured 13 crew members and forced the guided missile cruiser to head for its home port for repairs, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: MORE GOALS ARE IN SIGHT FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: Hey, Martina!''

title: ;  Sullivan Is First
description: Danny Sullivan pulled away from Bobby Rahal at the end to win the first Molson 300-kilometer race for Indianapolis cars today. It was the third victory of the season for the 34-year- old driver from Louisville, Ky.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on page 1 in some copies Saturday describing a picture of the funeral procession for Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Kostandov of the Soviet Union misidentified the man at the left, behind Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. He is Yegor K. Ligachev, a Communist Party secretary.

title: STUDY FINDS COMPUTERS AND FAMILY MIX
description: Is the home computer disrupting family life and inhibiting communication? Are children being mesmerized by their computers to the exclusion of other interests?

title: Miss Oceana Wins Maskette
description: Miss Oceana scored her second Grade I stakes victory in eight days by winning the $117,600 Maskette Stakes by a head at Belmont Park yesterday in her first career start against older fillies and mares. The victory gave the daughter of Alydar a strong claim to leadership of the nation's 3-year-old fillies, a divisional title that had seemed lost only two weeks ago.

title: ;  Mill Neck Winner
description: Harvey Rhein got two goals and led the Mill Neck polo team to a 6-4 victory over Huntington today at Bethpage State Park.

title: BANKING BILLS FACE STERN TESTS
description: The push to pass banking deregulation bills in both houses of Congress is coming under increasing opposition as it faces crucial tests this week.

title: TAYLOR SURPRISES HOGEBOOM
description: Lawrence Taylor was just as surprised as Gary Hogeboom, although maybe not as surprised as 75,921 spectators in Giants Stadium watching the home team move into undisputed possession of first place for the first time in 21 years.

title: All Jersey Schools Are to Reopen
description: As Governor Kean considered whether to sign legislation regulating asbestos contractors, education officials reported that all the schools where asbestos removal work had posed a problem would be open Monday.

title: Lendl Lost In a Meadow
description: Ivan Lendl lost and got lost in the meadow yesterday. In Flushing Meadow, to be precise, where the National Tennis Center is situated, and in the final of the United States Open.

title: TRIUMPH FOR RETARDED TOLD IN WOMAN'S STORY
description: Everyone said it was a ridiculous idea and would never work, and there were times when Diane Dupuy wondered whether they were right. After all, the notion that an untrained 24- year-old who had failed at everything that had ever been important to her could take an unruly group of retarded adolescents and turn them into a top-notch professional theater troupe seemed unlikely in the extreme.

title: Taiwan Raids On Computers TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 9
description: Counterfeit International Business Machines computer equipment has been

title: The Squandering of a Panacea It's hard to read without wonder about the long series of unlikely events that enabled Alexander Fleming to discover penicillin. The folly, greed and neglect with which the priceless gift of antibiotics is now being squandered command almost equal awe.
description: Antibiotics are a uniquely potent defense against bacteria, but they possess a fatal weakness: If used to excess, their power fails. That's what's now happening because of doctors who overprescribe antibiotics and farmers who routinely add them to animal feed.

title: Spending on Olympics Was Under Budget
description: Dozens of Federal, state and local agencies involved in the 1984 Olympics spent less than was budgeted, including the Defense Department, which has about $15 million left over.

title: ;  Shepherd Is Best
description: Ch. Covy Tucker Hill's Manhattan, a German shepherd owned by Shirlee Braunstein and Jane Firestone, and the top-winning dog of the year, won the triple crown of the show world today when he was named best in a field of 2,806 at the 67th Westchester Kennel Club fixture at Lyndhurst. Hatter, as he is called, previously won the International in Chicago and the Santa Barbara on the Coast.

title: ;  Czech's Big Chance
description: Ludek Bukac, who is now coaching Czechoslovakia in the Canada Cup series, may be back in North America next fall as a National Hockey League coach. Bukac has directed his country's national team for 17 years and now, at age 49, he says his government will allow his venture west for full-time employment.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LETTERS OF JEAN RHYS. Edited By Francis Wyndham and Diana Melly. 301 pages. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $22.50.

title: BRITISH COAL STRIKE TALKS HELD
description: Talks between the leaders of striking miners and coal industry officials ended after two hours tonight with both sides refusing to say if they had made progress toward ending the 26-week-old walkout.

title: LETTING CITIZENS GIVE REBELS AID WAS U.S. POLICY
description: The State Department said today that the Reagan Administration decided this year not to discourage private American citizens and foreign governments from supporting Nicaraguan rebels.

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLUMBIAN NORTHLAND EXLORATION LTD reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: POPE MAKES WHISTLE-STOP TOUR OF QUEBEC AND SPEAKS OUT ON HANDICAPPED
description: Tens of thousands gathered in church squares and lined railroad tracks today as Pope John Paul II made a whistle-stop tour of Quebec and issued a strong statement supporting the rights of the handicapped.

title: Margaret Phillips Dies at 61;Veteran Broadway Actress
description: Margaret Phillips, an actress who appeared on Broadway in such plays as ''Another Part of the Forest'' and ''Summer and Smoke,'' died of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital on Sunday. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OUTSIDE CONCERT HALLS IN ASIAN TOUR, 'DOC' IS THE MAESTRO
description: BANGKOK, THAILAND The musicians of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra stared down at their salads: to eat or not to eat? Then along came Leonard Essman who, with a confident wave of his hand, dismissed their apprehensions.

title: Vladimir Selinsky Dies at 74;TV Conductor and Composer
description: Vladimir Selinsky, a composer and conductor for television, died of heart disease last Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Common Stock
description: Air Vac, an airline on the West Coast, has filed an offering of 2.5 million common shares through Hambrecht & Quist.

title: ; REVERSE SIDE OF A CURB ON HOSPITAL COSTS
description: To the Editor:

description: As if Walter F. Mondale did not have enough trouble, the political experts in his own party have pinned him in a crossfire of contradictory advice.

title: SEEING MCENROE ANEW
description: John McEnroe strode onto the National Tennis

title: ARTIFICIAL REEFS HELPING TO REPLENISH FISHING GROUNDS
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I.

title: Citicorp Unit's Mortgage Issues
description: A subsidiary of Citicorp announced yesterday plans to sell $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, a kind of bond backed by a pool of home mortgages. The obligations are expected for sale this week through the Citicorp Homeowners Mortgage Acceptance Corporation 1, a subsidiary of Citicorp Homeowners, which is a mortgage banking subsidiary of Citicorp.

title: MISS AMERICA PAGEANT BACK IN 'FESTIVE MOOD'
description: The Miss America Pageant got under way here today, a booming business whose formula for economic success is a shoestring budget and an army of volunteers.

description: When it comes to protecting people from environmental hazards, the Environmental Protection Agency takes care of its own.

description: Giants' Euphoria A Bit Tempered

title: Merrill-Paribas Stock Accord
description: Merrill Lynch, in announcing the completion of its acquisition of Becker Paribas, disclosed yesterday that it had granted Compagnie Financi ere de Paribas Inc. an option to increase its maximum holdings to 5.1 percent of Merrill Lynch's stock.

title: 12% Rise Is Reported In Convicts on Parole
description: The number of convicts on parole from Federal and state prisons reached a record quarter-million last year, and the number of adults on probation surpassed 1.5 million, the Bureau of Justice Statistics said Sunday.

title: AN EMBATTLED PEOPLE IN TRANSITION
description: The Maoris are the indigenous people of New Zealand, the Polynesian group of islands of 104,000 square miles roughly 1,200 miles east of Australia. The Maoris are descended from several waves of migrants who are thought to have arrived from islands in East Polynesia in canoes, the first of which landed about A. D. 800.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Nutri/System Agrees to Offer
description: Nutri/System Inc. said today that it had agreed to be acquired by an investor group for $9 a share, or about $87.5 million, subject to revisions for the closing of its Gloria Marshall operations.

title: IT'S ROOKIE TIME FOR DEVILS
description: The Devils open their rookie camp tomorrow in Totowa, N.J., a collection of young men with big eyes and big dreams who hope to impress someone enough to make the National Hockey League.

title: CAPOTE LEFT FUNDS FOR PRIZE
description: Truman Capote has given money from his estate, valued at more than $600,000, for the eventual creation of an annual prize in literary criticism, according to a will filed last Friday in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: Senate Candidates Clash On Nuclear Arms Cuts
description: Senator John W. Warner says his Democratic challenger, Edythe Harrison, wants the United States to unilaterally dismantle its nuclear weapons, but Mrs. Harrison says her ''build-down'' plan would simply be a ''public relations gesture.''

title: TALKING BACK TO YOUR COMPUTER
description: The once obedient but silent tools of man are becoming more and more vocal, to hardly anyone's real benefit. More than once, upon being greeted by the chirps of the now pervasive audio chip, I have whispered, ''Shut up,'' forcefully beneath my breath. Do we need such devices as a talking dashboard to remind us to buckle our seat belts or that the car needs oil?

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After charges for a writedown on the sale of Fluor Distribution Cos. of $9,604,000 for the quarter and $24,790,000 for the 9 months.

title: Samuel Revits, 72, Is Dead; ExpertonGovernmentBonds
description: Samuel Revits, retired senior vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $78,051 for the quarter and $107,664 for the year from a minority share of a subsidiary loss. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $407,500. The latest fourth quarter net reflects a $1 million first-time contribution to an Employee Stock Ownership and Capital Accumulation Plan. The share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect 10 percent stock dividend issued December 1983.

title: METS DEFEATED, DROP 7 BEHIND
description: It's like two guys having 10-foot putts,'' Dave Johnson was saying in Shea Stadium last night. ''You shoot first, you've got the advantage. If you make it, the other guy's got something else to worry about.''

title: TEXT OF MONDALE'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the prepared text of Walter F. Mondale's statement today on his deficit reduction program:

description: THE Japanese stock market, brimming with

title: DANGERMOUSE, THE HERO RODENT OF BAKER STREET
description: If British adults have any vices that are still secret, they might include Dangermouse, a cartoon character who combines James Bond and Sherlock Holmes and appears on the air for 10 minutes at 5 P.M.

title: U.S. Monitors Texas Banks
description: The Mercantile Texas Corporation and Southwest Bancshares Inc., two large Texas bank holding companies that plan to merge, have disclosed that some of their banks are being operated under supervisory agreements with the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that the results for the latest quarter are after a charge from the writedown of certain machinery and equipment in its non- fabricated line of business and income from the reversal of deferred income taxes related to the recent favorable tax legislation pertaining to foreign sales corporations. The net effect of these transactions is an increase in net income of 2 cents a share.

title: Deficit Politics Reducing the Federal deficit is central to Walter Mondale's economic program for the next four years - and to his candidacy for the next eight weeks. Perceived as a liberal spender, he merits a badge of political courage for acknowledging that the next President will have to seek more unpopular spending cuts and tax increases. The plan the Democratic candidate outlined yesterday isn't perfect, but that's a small failing compared with President Reagan's failure to propose any plan at all.
description: Mr. Reagan has piled up the largest deficits in history and warrants a medal of his own for daring to say the problem should be addressed by declaring it unconstitutional. With or without a Constitutional amendment, the deficit - currently $170 billion - will grow in the next four years unless reversed by radical action. The alternatives are continued high interest rates and renewal of the inflation that was put down by a cruel recession.

title: LABOR PARTY APPROVES ISRAELI COALITION
description: After more than four hours of frequently angry speeches and occasional scuffles, the central committee of the Labor Party voted overwhelmingly today to approve a proposed coalition government with the Likud bloc.

title: SUNKEN SHIP WITH RADIOACTIVE CARGO BREAKS UP
description: A sunken French freighter with 30 cannisters of radioactive material inside broke up tonight in heavy seas, maritime and salvage officials said.

title: A DAWN RITUAL PREPARES MAORI SCULPURE FOR OPENING AT MET
description: A ritual dance was performed yesterday at dawn by two Maori warriors in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. When it was over, a dozen tribal elders rubbed noses with officials of the museum. The occasion paved the way for the opening at the Met today of an exhibition of sacred sculpture by the Maori, the indigenous people of New Zealand.

title: TRANSPLANTING CELLS INTO BRAIN OFFERS PROMISE AS A THERAPY
description: Remarkable successes in transplantation of cells into the brains of animals have encouraged the belief that the therapy may eventually become practical for the treatment of human illnesses.

title: New York Primary Choices New York votes today in a primary election to choose party nominees for Congress, the State Legislature and Civil Court judgeships. In some strongly Democratic districts in New York City, the vote will decide not only the nominee but the winner in November. We offered recommendations for some of these races last week and recapitulate them below. In certain districts, the ballot includes candidates for party posts, for which we make no endorsements.
description: Our most important recommendation is made without reference to party or district: Vote. Polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.; in Connecticut's scattered primaries from noon to 8 P.M.

title: MUSIC: TRIO PLAYS A 'NEW' SHOSTAKOVICH
description: Like every prolific and long- lived composer, Dmitri Shostakovich left many minor works in a variety of forms for posterity to discover and revive. The latest to surface is an attractive one-movement trio, written in 1923 and assigned an opus number by the composer but not published until last year.

title: GIANTS HAD POISE AND HUSTLE
description: On the one hand, there is Phil Simms, who has taken a more mature approach to his job as quarterback of the team. Then there is the new offensive philosophy of striking upfield for big plays by utilizing faster players like Byron Williams. And there has been more aggressiveness in the defense, especially among the backs.

title: DEFICIT PLAN MARKS TURN TO RIGHT FOR 60'S LIBERAL
description: Walter F. Mondale's announcement today of a ''hard, realistic'' deficit reduction package of higher taxes, spending cuts and a modest increase in social programs climaxes a striking evolution for a liberal Democrat of the 1960's who is now speaking in bluntly conservative terms.

title: No Headline
description: $50,000 Award Set Up For Regional Theaters

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PANEL SAYS A MISUNDERSTANDING LED TO SEIZURE OF SCHOOL RECOREDS
description: The seizure of junior high school students' records by the Summit police as part of a drug investigation last February involved no criminal wrongdoing but raised serious concern about how search warrants had been issued, a Union County grand jury said today.

title: WILAND SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHOOL OVERCROWDING PLAGUES SOME DISTRICTS
description: New York City's elementary and junior high schools opened yesterday and students in some of the poorest neighborhoods found overcrowding and makeshift classrooms.

13 Killed in Sri Lanka In Bombing and Battle
description: Nine soldiers died in a bombing and four Tamil separatists were killed in an ensuing gun battle with Government troops today in the Tamil-dominated northern province, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Man Kills 3 and Himself
description: Juan Guerra, 35 years old, abducted his estranged wife and shot her to death, then killed his two infant children and himself, the authorities said. Mr. Guerra also shot and wounded two men who were with his wife, Denise Rackenbury Guerra, 24, when he abducted her Sunday, the police said.

title: COUPLE ON TRIAL FOR SEX ABUSE OF 5 CHILDREN DENY CHARGES
description: A man and woman accused of sexually abusing their 6-year-old son and four other children denied every charge as they testified this morning at their trial in the Carver County Courthouse.

title: VOTING PLAN FOR HOMELESS IS REPORTED
description: A Federal judge proposed a compromise today that could guarantee homeless people here the right to vote in the November election even though they had no residential addresses.

title: THE JULIO IGLESIAS PHENOMENON AND POP'S FUTURE
description: The instant acceptance of the first English-language album by Julio Iglesias, the Spanish pop singer, is a positive sign of the continuing internationalization of American pop. Just five days after its release, the album, ''1100 Bel Air Place,'' topped the million mark in sales. On Billboard's pop album chart, the record leaped to No. 8 in its third week, and five of the singer's earlier Spanish-language records have also entered Billboard's album chart. Mr. Iglesias's weeklong Radio City Music Hall engagement, which ends tomorrow, sold more than a million dollars worth of tickets in 15 hours.

title: MUST WE IDENTIFY U.F.O.'S?
description: I can't see anything wrong with believing in U.F.O.'s. After all, if it

title: U.S., BOWING TO CRITICISM, EASES RULES ON HIGH-TECH EXPORTS
description: In the face of strong criticism from American companies and foreign governments, the Commerce Department announced today that it had softened rigorous new export licensing rules intended to plug leaks of high technology to the Soviet Union.

title: MONTREAL CITY & DISTRICT SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Headline
description: U.S., Soviet Are Winners CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 10

title: Man Held in Deaths Of 8 on Boat in Alaska
description: Two years after seven bodies were found on a burned fishing boat off Craig, Alaska, a 24-year-old laborer who once worked for the skipper was arrested today and charged with murdering them and an eighth victim.

title: MONTANA AND 49ERS DEFEAT REDSKINS
description: Joe Montana passed for two touchdowns and ran for another tonight as the San Francisco 49ers held off a late rally and handed the Washington Redskins their second straight loss, 37-31.

title: Agreement Reached In Houston School Case
description: Lawyers for two minority groups and Houston's public schools ended a 28-year-old school desegregation lawsuit today by signing a settlement that district officials said would cost $53.2 million over five years.

title: 'SPECIAL PEOPLE' SHOWS THEATER OF HANDICAPPED
description: Television is fond of inspirational stories, a fact that can be deduced easily enough from their continuing glut. Generally, as the heroes or heroines struggle to overcome some formidable handicap, the dramatic range of such projects runs a gamut from A to a totally predictable C. Much depends, therefore, on how the B area is handled, and in ''Special People,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, it is fleshed out quite affectingly.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Heinz Expands Earnings 17.2% PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its latest

title: CUOMO QUESTIONS O'CONNOR'S VIEWS
description: Governor Cuomo said tonight that it was appropriate for Archbishop John J. O'Connor to correct politicians if he felt that they were misstating church teaching. But based on what he had read in newspapers, the Governor said, he could not determine why the Archbishop was criticizing Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee.

title: Reagan Names Two Senators As Delegates to U.N. Session
description: President Reagan announced today that he had named Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, to be representatives to the United Nations General Assembly session that begins later this month.

title: Malta Foreign Minister Criticizes the U.S.
description: Malta's Foreign Minister singled out the United States today in an attack on superpower military interests in the Mediterranean.

title: TWINS TOP ROYALS AND TIE FOR FIRST
description: A double by Tim Teufel of Minnesota that was lost in the lights by Darryl Motley and Willie Wilson in the third inning tonight started the Twins on their way to a 7-3 triumph over the Kansas City Royals. The victory moved the Twins into a tie with Kansas City for first place in the American League West. California, which did not play, trails by a game.

title: Talking Businesswith Niskanen, Economic Adviser ; Seeking Cause Of High Rates
description: WASHINGTONWilliam A. Niskanen Jr. was appointed to the President's Council of Economic Advisers in March 1981 and has presided over it since its chairman, Martin S. Feldstein, returned to Harvard University in July.

description: Sept. 11, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EXILE DENIES HE IS OMEGA 7'S LEADER
description: A Cuban exile accused of heading a terrorist group called Omega 7 testified in his Manhattan trial yesterday that he was not the group's leader and had never taken part in any violence in the United States.

title: ;  Cardinals Sign Duncan The St. Louis Cardinals have finally come to terms with the receiver
description: Clyde Duncan , their top draft choice, who ended a four-month holdout by signing a series of one-year contracts. Duncan caught 35 passes for 640 yards and 6 touchdowns during his senior year at Tennessee. . . . Jim McMahon , the Chicago Bears' quarterback who played the final quarter of Sunday's game against the Denver Broncos with a hairline fracture in his passing hand, says he expects to play Sunday against the Green Bay Packers.

description: A $63.3 million issue of adjustable rate bonds of the Red River Authority of Texas was offered with an initial interest rate of 7 1/2 percent and a price of 100 though underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: ISRAEL AND U.S. ARREST 10 SOVIET EMIGRES AS MEMBERS OF COUNTERFEITING RING
description: Israeli and American agents have broken a major international counterfeiting ring with the arrest of 10 Soviet Georgian emigres and the seizure of $13 million in bogus United States currency, officials in New York said yesterday.

title: Article 167356 -- No Title
description: (Reuters) - The Higbee Company, primarily an operator of

title: The Man Who Saved the Circus No one has ever been able to explain what happens in the hearts of some children when they see their first circus. Whatever it is, it happened to Irvin Feld. But instead of dreams about running away to join the circus, he dreamed of owning it, by which, characteristically, he meant the biggest and the best - the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus. Eventually, he not only bought the circus; he saved it.
description: Irvin Feld was a poor boy who sold snake oil on the carnival circuit at 13 to help his family survive the Depression. Later, he went on to make big money as a rock and roll promoter. It was not until 1967 that he, his brother and Roy Hofheinz of Texas bought The Big One from John Ringling North. Then, for 17 years until his death last week at the age of 66 in Venice, Fla., the winter home of the circus, he ran it with unflagging enthusiasm.

title: AFTER DELAY, BRIDGE REOPENS TO TRUCKS
description: The Yankee Doodle Bridge on Interstate 95 reopened to southbound trucks and buses at midday today for the first time since a cracked hanger was found in its support system two weeks ago.

title: ;  Heavyweight Problems The pending fight between the two undefeated heavyweight champions,
description: Larry Holmes and Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa, hit another snag yesterday when a Federal judge in Philadelphia blocked Holmes from entering into any contract to fight the World Boxing Association champion without granting a Virginia lawyer a 90-day right of first refusal. The injunction threw into doubt the plans of the promoter Don King to stage the long- awaited bout in Las Vegas, Nev., in November.

title: Top Democrats to Miss Humphrey Ceremony
description: The Democratic Presidential nominee, Walter F. Mondale, and his running mate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, have declined an invitation by President Reagan to attend White House ceremonies Tuesday in honor of former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: Mohawk Data Nominations
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation and Asher B. Edelman said yesterday that they had reached an understanding for Mr. Edelman and Burton Lehman to be nominated for election to Mohawk's board at the annual meeting on Oct. 26.

title: MATTINGLY LEADS THE YANKEES
description: The stroke, compact and not pretending of any power, has produced more runs for the Yankees than any other player's this season. And tonight, it made Yogi Berra say of Don Mattingly, ''Take our best expectations and he's passed that.''

title: HIRSCHFIELD TO QUIT AS FOX FILM CHIEF
description: Alan J. Hirschfield is resigning as chairman and chief executive officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, according to an announcement from him and Marvin Davis, the company's owner.

description: b-The were no comparable results for the year-ago quarter due to a change in the company's fiscal year- end to March 31 from Dec. 31. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Speed to Spare

title: THE REGION ; ;  Football Player, 15, Collapses and Dies
description: A 15-year-old Elizabeth High School football player who collapsed during practice a week ago has died at a hospital here where he was being treated, a hospital spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK TO REIMBURSE U.S. FOR GRUMMAN BUSES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has agreed to reimburse the Federal Government for its share of the retired Grumman Flxible bus fleet, officials said yesterday.

title: Dallas Concern Cited In Toxic Waste Case
description: The Environmental Protection Agency asserts that the Diamond Shamrock Corporation illegally dumped 1,228 tons of PCB- contaminated waste, and the Federal agency is seeking a fine of $2.3 million.

description: The stock market finished moderately lower yesterday in slower trading after an afternoon upswing ena bled it to reduce earlier sharp losses.

description: b-Net income. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on the first page of SportsMonday yesterday with a picture of John McEnroe lying on his back during the final match of the U.S. Open inaccurately explained the action. McEnroe was holding up his hands as he started to protest an official's call.

title: THREAT TO QUOTRON DISCOUNTED
description: Disaster seemed to be facing Quotron Systems Inc. last spring, when Merrill Lynch & Company and the International Business Machines Corporation announced plans to form a joint venture - called International Marketnet - to provide computerized services to brokerage firms.

title: Sports Figures at ServicesFor Joe Cronin, Hall of Famer
description: Men who played beside him on the field and negotiated with him in the front office filled St. Francis Xavier Church today at services for Joe Cronin, the baseball Hall of Famer.

title: KENNEDY CHIDES CHURCH LEADERS ON ROLE OF STATE
description: The Archbishop of New York and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro discussed their dispute over abortion yesterday, but apparently failed to resolve the question of whether she had misrepresented the Roman Catholic Church's doctrine on abortion.

title: ACCUSATIONS RAISE TENSIONS IN BEIRUT
description: Political tensions in the Government heightened today after two Cabinet members charged that Lebanon's intelligence service was behind an assassination attempt on the Minister of Education last week.

title: Article 167510 -- No Title
description: Congressional auditors concluded in a study issued today that the Army's shoulder- fired Stinger antiaircraft missile may not be useful in combat and recommended that production be cut to a minimum.

title: HEAD OF BOOK CLUB IS RETIRING
description: The Book of the Month Club, a major influence on the reading habits of more than two million Americans, has announced that Edward E. Fitzgerald will retire as chief executive at the end of this month. He will be succeded by Al Silverman, the current president and chief operating officer.

title: QADDAFI'S UTOPIA: BIG IDEAS COVERED IN NAUGAHYDE
description: A mangy cat scratches herself in one of the hotel's damp, dingy corridors. Nearby, her kittens are scrounging scraps of food from trays abandoned, often for days, in front of guests' rooms.

title: COURT REJECTS JUDGES' SUIT OVER DISABILITY POLICY
description: A Federal District Court today rejected a lawsuit filed against the Government by administrative law judges who complained that they had been placed under improper pressure to deny claims for Social Security disability benefits.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $367,000 for the quarter and $2,532,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,755,000 on the repurchase of debentures.

title: HASBRO BRADLEY STARTS BY NAMING A PRESIDENT
description: James J. Shea Jr., chairman of the Milton Bradley Company since 1972, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Hasbro Bradley Inc. Mr. Shea's new position was announced after shareholders of both Milton Bradley and Hasbro Industries voted last Friday to approve Hasbro's acquisition of Milton Bradley. He will report to Stephen D. Hassenfeld, 42, the new company's chairman and chief executive officer.

description: To the Editor:

NBC News Sets Policy On Reporting Returns
description: NBC News yesterday announced a policy on reporting election returns designed to counter criticism that early broadcasting of East Coast results discourages West Coast voters.

title: CUBS RALLY IN 7TH AND BEAT PHILS, 3-2
description: A seventh-inning throwing error on a potential double-play ball by the second baseman Juan Samuel allowed the tying and winning runs to score today as the Chicago Cubs beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2.

title: IRAQ CLAIMS IT HIT BIG 'NAVAL TARGET'
description: Iraq said its warplanes hit a ''large naval target'' - the usual term for an oil tanker - south of Iran's Kharg Island today. There was no independent confirmation of the attack, the first reported in two weeks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Family Ties

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: More Signs of the Times

title: CITY COUNCIL PANEL APPROVES ANTI-BIAS BILL AFFECTING CLUBS
description: Discrimination would be forbidden at a number of private clubs in New York City under a bill approved yesterday by a City Council panel.

title: COMPUTER PHONE GEAR IS DELAYED
description: A shortage of computerized switching equipment made by AT& T Technologies is restraining the growth of one major regional telephone company and causing another to buy the equipment elsewhere, communications industry experts said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: INSIDE VIEW Pedestrians accustomed to tramping through all those wooden tunnels that snake past construction sites can see what's doing on the other side of the barricades this month and next when the Municipal Art Society conducts six ''Hard Hat Tours.''

title: Pillsbury Proposal
description: The Pillsbury Company said in a proxy for its annual meeting that it would ask shareholders to approve a proposal guaranteeing fair pricing for stockholders in the event of an unsolicited two-tier tender offer.

title: A SENATE FLAG: AN IDEA NOW AWAITING A CONTEST
description: Betsy Ross isn't around to do the stitching, but the United States Senate has decided it wants an official flag all its own.

title: Offer by Volvo
description: A.B. Volvo said its Volvo North America Corporation subsidiary plans to make a cash tender offer for as many as four million shares of the Hamilton Oil Corporation at $19.50 each.

title: NEGOTIATE WITH MOSCOW, NOT OURSELVES
description: There is a Law of Holes that says, when you are in one, stop digging. This is a law Congress finds it almost impossible to observe when it acts on defense and arms control issues.

description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York City Notes Priced to Yield 7.15%
description: An $850 million note financing by New York City was tentatively priced yesterday with a yield of 7.15 percent to maturity on June 28, 1985, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Underwriters said that the notes, which have a coupon of 7.6 percent and carry a price of 100.328, were well received.

title: NEW YORK POLITICIANS SHARE IN COURT FEES TO SUPERVISE ESTATES
description: The following article is based on reporting by Marcia Chambers and Sam Roberts and was written by Mr. Roberts.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Saturday on theological views of abortion misidentified Rabbi David M. Feldman's synagogue. It is the Teaneck (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title: ;  Racism Charged
description: Derrel Thomas , traded last week by the Montreal Expos to the California Angels, told The Toronto Globe and Mail that he was treated shabbily in Montreal because he was black. Dan Driessen, the Expos first baseman, and Felipe Alou, a coach, were quoted in the newspaper as supporting Thomas's allegations, but they later denied the quotes.

title: AIRPORT TRAFFIC TALK AT IMPASSE OVER NEWARK
description: Talks between airlines and the Government about easing congestion and delays in the New York area reached a stalemate late today after carriers serving Newark Airport refused to yield on their plans for significant increases in service in the winter travel season.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FINDING THE CENTER: Two Narratives. By V. S. Naipaul. 176 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DOLLAR TOPS 3-MARK BARRIER
description: After a day of generally steady trading, the United States dollar suddenly burst through the psychologically important barrier of 3 West German marks late yesterday for the first time since January 1973.

title: Lowy Schultz, Employe
description: Peoris, Ill. - Lowy Schultz is a 34-year-old Caterpillar Tractor Company worker. He was laid off in September, 1982 after nine years. Last year, he lost his home. He and his wife sold their furniture, packed up what was left and with their four children went West to look for work in Phoenix. Within two months, the Schultzes had jobs. Last month Caterpillar recalled him.

title: THEATER: MULTIMEDIA 'OTHELLO' OPENS
description: ''Othello,'' a mixed-media collage by the Neapolitan performance art group Falso Movimento, is very much in the mood of the moment. A self-described ''modernization'' of the Verdi opera, compressed to a little more than an hour, ''Otello,'' which opened a limited engagement last week at the La Mama Annex, uses Verdi (and Shakespeare) as the basis of a chic multimedia vaudeville show.

title: Aquino Inquiry Panel Said to Be in Agreement
description: The five members of the commission investigating the assassination in August 1983 of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. have reached agreement on the basic points of their report, which may be issued before the end of the month, the group's chief counsel said today.

title: LOOKING FOR WEAKEST LINK
description: While Colombia's new campaign has proved effective enough for United States officials to discount the need to apply new pressure on the Betancur Government, it has brought a fresh complication to the regional narcotics problem by decentralizing it.

title: THE REGION ; ;  L.I. Couple Died In Copter Crash
description: The identities of the last two victims of a helicopter crash Saturday have been released.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BANKS GET MEXICAN DEBT PACT
description: Using special couriers instead of cables, Citibank yesterday began sending the proposed agreement for restructuring Mexico's foreign debt to about 550 banks around the world.

title: Executive Life Set For First Campaign
description: Next week for the first time in its 20-year history, Executive Life, an insurance company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., will begin to advertise to consumers.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net loss

title: MIAMI GETS MUNCIE
description: Chuck Muncie, the talented and sometimes troubled running back of the San Diego Chargers, was traded today to the Miami Dolphins for a second-round draft choice in 1985.

title: MONDALE'S PLAN: THE MIDDLE CLASS IS NOT EXEMPT
description: Walter F. Mondale, who announced his plan today for reducing the Federal budget deficit, had to reach down into the middle class with his tax increases to come up with the final results he had promised. His fiscal package also includes an assumption that a tighter fiscal policy would not bring on recession because the Federal Reserve Board would agree to give him lower interest rates in exchange for smaller deficits. Whether any President could get such a commitment from the central bank that prizes its independence is in doubt.

title: Woodward Vote
description: Woodward & Lothrop Inc. said the United States District Court for the District of Columbia had denied a motion to block a vote on the proposed acquisition of Woodward & Lothrop for $59 a share by a company controlled by Alfred Taubman. As a result, Woodward & Lothrop, an operator of department stores, said it would hold its special meeting of shareholders Tuesday to vote on the offer.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Jeffrey Banks, the men's wear

title: THE CITY ; ;  Drug Dealer Gets New Prison Term
description: Frank Lucas, an international drug dealer who became an informant in more than 100 narcotics cases and then won release from a 70-year prison term in 1981, was sentenced yesterday to 7 years in Federal prison on a new drug conviction.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company went public in February. Year-ago results are on a pro-forma basis.

title: A REVERSAL FOR GANDHI
description: Just when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's political stock seemed to be rising as a result of her bold action in June against Sikh extremists in Punjab, the furor over the dismissal last month of N. T. Rama Rao as the elected leader of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh appears to have sent it plummeting again.

title: 'SLEEPER' AWAKENS FOR GIANTS
description: Lionel Manuel was told to get ready.

description: The company said that the share earnings are pro-forma to reflect a change in dividend rate and classification of Series B preferred stock.
