BETTY BLUM MARCUS
description: Betty Blum Marcus, civic leader and widow of Edward S. Marcus, former board chairman of Neiman-Marcus, died Sunday of cancer at her home here.

title: WESTWOOD ONE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ruling for Air Florida
description: Debt-ridden Air Florida was given court permission today to end a deal to sell its Miami-London route to Eastern Airlines. But Federal Bankruptcy Judge Sidney Weaver reserved until Friday a decision on whether Air Florida also could end an agreement to sell Eastern some landing slots. Air Florida asked the court to allow it to terminate the $7 million deal after reaching a tentative reorganization agreement with Midway Airlines.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., which runs health care facilities, has named Charles Jordan executive vice president of operations.

title: GROUP SEEKS A REVERSAL IN CRAFT SUIT
description: A women's journalism group is seeking a reversal of a ruling that sex discrimination was not a factor in the demotion of Christine Craft from her job as a television anchorwoman.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DRAW OPENS WORLD CHESS FIGHT IN MOSCOW
description: The two young Soviet contenders for the world chess crown fought fiercely to a draw today in an opening game that, to the grandmasters on hand, was likely to presage a long and thrilling confrontation for the championship.

title: PRESIDENT TALKS TO BLACK LEADERS
description: The Rev. T. J. Jemison, the president of the National Baptist Convention and an influential black leader who criticized President Reagan last week, emerged from a meeting with Mr. Reagan today saying that the President's views about blacks had been distorted and that he did appear to have sympathy for them.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. PROMOTES UNION VIEWS IN TV ADS
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. began a $1 million 24-city campaign of television commercials today to showcase union views on economic and social issues.

title: Still a Challenger, Not the Champ
description: Impressed by the stunning success of the Japanese in automobiles and consumer electronics, American industry has waited warily for Japan to bring its weight to bear in computers and high technology. A detailed look at technology in Japan indicates, however, that the nation is far from being or becoming dominant.

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WARD IDENTIFIES 564 CRIME SITES UNDER NEW LAW
description: More than 500 locations in the city have been identified as targets for a padlock law on ''public nuisances,'' Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: SHAKEN COLOMBIA ACTS AT LAST ON DRUGS
description: After years of disregarding United States pressure to crack down on marijuana and cocaine trafficking, Colombia has been prompted to begin a major antidrug offensive by evidence that narcotics are no longer solely an American problem.

title: PROFIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Your encounter with the Gospel has not only enriched you, it has enriched the church.

description: A Reagan Religious Joke

title: 5 Drown in Auto Accident
description: A speeding automobile carrying seven people home from a bar left the road early today and skidded 300 feet across a bayou before sinking. Five occupants drowned.

title: Student Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced yesterday that the issue of $250 million of floating-rate notes, due March 14, 1985, would be reset on the day following each weekly Treasury bill auction. The floating-rate notes are priced at par to yield a variable rate equal to 35 basis points above the bond equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: PRINTS TO LIGHT UP AN EVENING
description: Fashion these days is often a matter of checks and balances. The woman who wears sharply tailored mannish clothes during the day may switch to seductively draped dresses at night. In the resort collections being shown on Seventh Avenue - clothes destined to be worn in warm climates this winter by women who are vacationing, as well as those who live in the southern tier of the country - there is a dramatic contrast between the styles offered for day and for evening.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Distant Cheers

title: THATCHER NAMES NEW ULSTER AIDE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher appointed a new Northern Ireland Secretary today to replace James Prior, who is leaving the Cabinet after three years to enter private industry.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $255,218 recovered against a claim for adjustment of a 1977 contract.

title: SENATE APPROVES CURB ON BANKING BILL DEBATE
description: Forces supporting an Administration-backed banking deregulation bill won a crucial test of strength in the Senate tonight by approving overwhelmingly a limitation on debate.

title: Pay'n Save Board
description: The Pay'n Save Corporation said two directors, Samuel N. Stroum and Stuart Sloan, said they would explore the possibility of getting ''a better deal'' for Pay'n Save shareholders following last week's decision by the board to accept an offer for the company of $22.50 a share, or about $355 million. The two directors, who said they control 18 percent of Pay'n Save and are its largest shareholders, voted against the proposal to sell the company to investors led by the Trump Group.

title: BUSH SAYS MONDALE PROPOSAL IS ONE OF 'ECONOMIC GLOOM'
description: -SALEM, N.C., Sept. 10 - Vice President Bush today branded Walter F. Mondale's deficit-reduction plan as a ''program for failure'' that would stall the economic recovery spearheaded, Mr. Bush said, by Reagan Administration policies.

title: FEDERAL DEFICITS' HARM TO ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: Smith Reduces Gearhart Offer
description: Smith International Inc., whose bid to take over another oil- services company, Gearhart Industries, has been bogged down in court for four months, said it intended to reduce the price of its tender offer to $23 a share, from $31. Smith is still seeking a minimum of 3.7 million shares, and said 6.9 million had been tendered and not withdrawn.

title: ETHIOPIAN COMMUNIST PARTY IS SET UP, WITH MENGISTU AT THE HELM
description: A Communist party was formally created here today to rule Ethiopia.

title: IF THEORY IS RIGHT, MOST OF UNIVERSE IS STILL 'MISSING'
description: A cosmic mystery of immense proportions, once seemingly on the verge of solution, has deepened and left astronomers and astrophysicists more baffled than ever. The crux of the riddle is that the vast majority of the mass of the universe seems to be missing. Or, more accurately, it is invisible to the most powerful telescopes on earth or in the heavens, which simply cannot detect all the mass that ought to exist in even nearby galaxies.

title: No Headline
description: Voters Going to Polls For Primaries Today

title: ;  U.S.F.L. Dropouts
description: Art Wilkinson , the agent for Mike Rozier of Pittsburgh Maulers, told a Houston radio station that the running back would not return to the United States Football League team and would pursue a contract with the Houston Oilers. In an interview with radio station KIKK, Wilkinson read a statement from Rozier that ended, ''In short, I do not wish to return to the Pittsburgh Maulers in 1985 and I will not.''

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net income

title: G.M. OFFER PLAN ON JOB SECURITY, TOP UNION GOAL
description: The General Motors Corporation made an offer today to the United Automobile Workers that the company said ''supplies job security to a significant portion of our work force.''

title: HURRICANE POISED OFF SOUTHERN COAST
description: Like other communities up and down the Southeastern coast, residents of this wealthy resort island battened down their homes and businesses today as Hurricane Diana hovered menacingly offshore.

description: Following are excerpts from prepared remarks by Senator Edward M. Kennedy last night at a fund-raising meeting in New York City of the Coalition of Conscience:

description: Rhode Island Democrats will vote in a gubernatorial primary Tuesday after the most expensive and one of the most bitter campaigns in the state's history.

description: In 1951 the Miss America Pageant asked the president of the local Chamber of Commerce to escort the grand marshal to the traditional Boardwalk parade.

description: The misdemeanor-assault case against Mark Gastineau and Ken O'Brien of the Jets is scheduled to go to the jury today in Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: MUSIC: A BACH OFFERING
description: Sound the trumpet and let the celebrations begin. J. S. Bach will be 300 years old next March, so the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center decided to preface its regular season with a brief festival in his honor. The five-concert event, entitled ''J. S. Bach: A Musical Offering,'' began Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall with, most appropriately, a program that climaxed in an enthralling performance of the composer's rarely heard masterpiece, ''The Musical Offering.''

title: SOVIET ACCEPTS BID TO HAVE GROMYKO MEET WITH REAGAN
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union has agreed to meet here with President Reagan on Sept. 28, a senior Administration official said today.

title: British Hospital Deaths: Spoiled Beef Is Cause
description: Contaminated roast beef served in a salad at a psychiatric hospital started a food poisoning outbreak that killed 26 patients, a medical expert said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1984 International A Reagan-Gromyko meeting has been scheduled, a senior Administration official said. He said that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had agreed to confer with Mr. Reagan in Washington on Sept. 28, two days after Mr. Gromyko meets with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. This would be the first time the President has met a high-level Soviet official. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Administration acknowledged for the first time that high-level policy makers had made a deliberate decision that Washington would not discourage private American citizens and foreign governments from supporting rebels in Nicaragua. (A1:5.)

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Tourney a Redouble Is Doubled

title: '82 LETTER SIGNED BY FERRARO
description: Following is the text of a cover letter dated Sept. 30, 1982, and sent to Roman Catholic members of Congress by Representatives Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, Leon E. Panetta of California and Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota. It was cited by Archbishop John J. O'Connor today in support of his contention that Representative Ferraro had misstated the Roman Catholic Church's position on abortion.

title: BLACKS WARY OF SKILL TESTS FOR TEACHERS
description: The school reform movement, which began by setting standards for students, is increasingly expanding its focus to include teachers. One result is that a growing number of states are requiring prospective teachers to pass tests before they are hired.

title: EAST GERMANS AFFIRM TIES TO BONN AS A GOAL
description: While belatedly backing some aspects of the Soviet Union's hard-line foreign policy, the East German leadership appears determined to continue to its working relationship with West Germany, according to Western diplomats and East German officials here.

title: HOUSE PASSES CIGARETTE WARNINGS
description: The House passed legislation today to replace the 13-year-old general warning on cigarette packages and advertisements with labels detailing specific health risks from smoking, including cancer and heart disease.

title: I.C.C. Backs Soo's Rail Bid
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted today to recommend approval of the Soo Line Railroad's $570.6 million bid for the financially troubled Milwaukee Road.

title: ROMAN EMPEROR PINOCHET MUST GO
description: For 11 years, each time I have turned on the radio, it has been with the hope that the next bulletin would report that Chile's ruler, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, has been overthrown.

title: Girl Beating Odds on Cancer After Care Ordered by Judge
description: The 13-year-old daughter of a minister who began receiving cancer treatments under a court order last year is healthy and beating overwhelming odds against surviving, officials say.

title: PANEL FINDS NO FRAUD BY ALCOHOL RESEARCHERS
description: Two alcoholism researchers who had been accused of scientific fraud have been given a qualified exoneration by a Federal investigating panel.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Kerry Goode , the Alabama halfback who ran back a kickoff 99 yards, a Southeastern Conference record, against Boston College Saturday night, underwent arthroscopic knee surgery yesterday, and Coach Ray Perkins said there was ''a pretty good chance'' Goode will be sidelined for the remainder of the season. Cory Collier , the Georgia Tech tailback who was last year's Atlantic Coast Conference rookie of the year, will miss a minimum of six weeks with a broken foot suffered during a workout over the weekend. . . . M. L. Carr , the 33-year-old Celtics' forward-guard who was considering retirement after Boston won the NBA title last June, has decided to continue playing. . . . Phil Myre, 35, who spent 13 1/2 seasons as a National Hockey League goalie, has retired because of a back injury sustained at the end of last season while he was the player-coach of the Rochester Americans, the Buffalo Sabres' farm team in the American Hockey League. . . . The Illinois defensive back Craig Swoope , found not guilty of Federal drug charges over the weekend, was given permission by the school to rejoin the team.

description: Read ALL About It

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arvin Industries, a manufacturer of automotive and electrical products based in Columbus, Ind., said its Calspan Corp. subsidiary had acquired the Franklin Research Center from the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: COKE OVEN FUMES JOIN HAZARDS LIST
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today, after years of consideration, that it was listing coke oven emissions as a hazardous air pollutant that could cause cancer.

title: NANKIN EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Negotiators Resuming Talks on Coal Contract
description: Negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association today resumed bargaining on a new contract, hoping to head off the prospect of a strike when the current agreement expires Sept. 30.

title: BLACKS FOUND TO BENEFIT FROM PRESCHOOLING
description: Black children who 16 years ago at the age of 3 benefited from preschool education have grown up with markedly greater success in school and in their personal lives than a comparable group without early childhood education, according to a landmark research project in Michigan.

title: 42 Workers Are Treated After Phosgene Gas Leak
description: Deadly phosgene gas leaked from a chemical plant near here today, and the authorities said 42 people were treated for respiratory problems.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Inquiry on Leases Begins in Albany
description: A State Senate investigation began today to determine whether Democratic officials had awarded millions of dollars in leases based on politics.

title: NEW SCHISGAL COMEDY BEGAN ON TENNIS COURT
description: Murray Schisgal, Adolph Green and Phyllis Newman, three names normally associated with Broadway, are opening a play called ''The New Yorkers'' tomorrow in a private school. The story of how it happened begins with a tennis game.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Just when they needed him most, Bruce Berenyi has been showing the kind of form consistent with the promise that led the Mets to trade for him in June. His opponent tonight is Ricky Horton, a young left-hander from Poughkeepsie.

title: Farewell, Falafel People who work in New York City constitute a diverse group, but they have one thing in common: around noontime they start to feel peckish. When that happens, many of them head for a sidewalk cart-vendor and lunch on the run - hotdogs, souvlaki, steak sandwiches, ice cream and the like. But after Oct. 1, workers in mid-Manhattan and busy sections of Brookyn and Queens will have to forgo falafel alfresco. That's when a ban on sidewalk food stands and carts goes into effect.
description: A law passed last year authorizes a ban wherever vendors pose a threat to foot and auto traffic. The choice was left to the Department of Consumer Affairs, which promptly and sensibly barred vendors from 140 overcrowded streets, including several major avenues and parts of the financial district.

title: CHILDREN'S SAFETY RESTS WITH DAY-CARE BOARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M., APPLE UPGRADE MODLES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. announced major improvements for their personal computers yesterday. Industry analysts said the improvements would heighten the competition between the two companies in the low-cost, desktop computer market.

title: A FLAWED SCIENCE SHOWPLACE
description: On the outskirts of town, Sony is erecting what it calls the world's largest television screen. At 82 feet high by 130 feet wide, or almost 2,000 inches diagonally, the Jumbotron is best viewed from two city blocks away.

Sex Abuse Inquiry Is Begun At Nashville Day-Care Center
description: The authorities have removed about 65 children from a day-care center here after reports that some of the children may have been sexually abused.

description: Donald R. Caldwell has been elected president and chief executive officer of Atlantic Financial Federal, Pennsylvania's largest savings and loan association, it was announced yesterday.

description: The sale of the Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation should provide additional money to the holders of annuities issued by the now bankrupt Baldwin-United Corporation, Peter Martosella, Baldwin's president, and Thomas P. Fox, the Wisconsin Insurance Commissioner, said yesterday.

description: Braniff Inc. officials said yesterday that the company has had a ''phenomenal response'' to its plan to transform itself into a discount carrier, offering low-cost, unrestricted fares on all flights.

title: MEROLA INVESTIGATING A SUBWAY CONTRACTOR

title: REDOING THE MAYFLOWER: A BIT OF SERENDIPITY
description: The 60- year-old Mayflower Hotel, the home- away-from-home to Presidents, members of Congress and other capital movers and shakers, as well as the scene of countless state dinners and inaugural balls, has been somewhat eclipsed in recent years by glittery new hotels put up to handle Washington's growing number of visitors.

title: THE J.F.K.-REAGAN RELIGION IRONY
description: It all sounds distractingly familiar. A spokesman for the religious right declaring that his followers will ''determine who gets elected'' President. The revelation at the Republican National Convention that God is spelled G.O.P. A letter from a Republican Senator to fundamentalist ministers that focused on only one issue - not peace, mercy or justice, but whether a candidate is so beholden to one religious group that he would use his influence as President to exalt that group and its public policy positions above all others. It sounds like 1960 all over again.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES DROP SHARPLY
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday amid signs that the Federal Reserve could be encouraging lower interest rates, or at least discouraging further increases in rates.

title: TAPE DECK STAYING HOME
description: Portable stereo radios combined with cassette- tape players and recorders, which go by any number of names, have gotten a terrible reputation in the last few years because of the number of people who carry them on the street or in the subway with the volume knob turned up to 10.

title: Vatican Reports an Increase In New Priests as Total Falls
description: The number of new Roman Catholic priests has been slowly rising in the last few years but the total number of priests in the world has fallen because of deaths and dispensation from vows, Vatican statistics made public today showed.

title: HOPING FOR ANOTHER SHOT
description: The line in the World Series record book is painfully loud: most games lost, Series: 3 - Frazier, George A., New York A.L., 1981.

title: Begin Enters Hospital With Urinary Ailment
description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin was hospitalized today with an ailment of the urinary tract. A hospital statement said it could not yet be determined whether surgery would be needed.

title: No Headline
description: Ray Fontenot of the Yankees and Juan

title: NEW PRIME-TIME SOAP GETS HOLLYWOOD HYPE
description: Although the producer of a well-publicized, eagerly anticipated new television series would seem to be in an enviable position, Leonard Goldberg points out that there are disadvantages as well as advantages to being the beneficiary of Hollywood hype.

title: Ruling on TV Rights Favors 2 Pac-10 Teams
description: U.C.L.A. and the University of Southern California will retain control of television rights for a pair of home games against Nebraska and Notre Dame, despite the objections of the College Football Association and ABC.

title: Advertising; Pfaff Hires a President
description: WARREN PFAFF, who founded Warren Pfaff Inc. 14 years ago, has brought in a president. And if John N. Carpender were a bit taller and less stocky, Mr. Pfaff might be accused of cloning.

title: JETS ARE WAITING FOR MISSING FOUR
description: They are the four who have not played this season: Johnny (Lam) Jones, from the class of 1980; Bob Crable, 1982; Ken O'Brien, 1983, and Russell Carter, 1984.

title: Bethlehem to Sell Another Plant
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is trying to sell its industrial fastener plant in Lebanon, Pa., which has an active work force of 550, and 250 other employees on layoff, according to a company spokesman, Gary Graham.

title: PUBLIC TV TO HOLD DEBATES
description: ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour,'' public television's nightly report on world events, has expanded its coverage of the Presidential race with a series of debates between members of the two parties through Election Day.

title: Suburban Schools
description: Lists of cooking schools in the suburban areas will be published in the Long Island, New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut regional editions of The New York Times on Sunday.

title: OMEGA 7 FIGURE SAYS F.B.I. TRIED TO COERCE HIM
description: A man accused of heading the Omega 7 terrorist group testified yesterday that Federal agents had kidnapped and drugged him in unsuccessful efforts to obtain his cooperation.

title: CBS'S 'SECRET WORLD,' A PROGRAM ON CHILDREN
description: ''THE SECRET WORLD OF THE VERY YOUNG'' mixes up dramatic vignettes, music, animation, interviews with childhood experts and interviews with, and film of, adorable children. It works here and there, but you have to have small children yourself to be interested. The one-hour CBS program, with John Ritter as host, will be seen on Channel 2 at 8 tonight.

title: Letter: On Commodities ; Getting a Handle on Leverage Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRARO ACTS TO STILL ABORTION DISPUTE
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, in an effort to still her dispute with Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York over her views on abortion, said today that they had ''agreed to disagree'' on statements she had made on the subject.

title: BOLIVIA DRUG CRACKOWN BREWS TROUBLE
description: The soldiers rolling past in troop trucks barely noticed Bacilia Flores, sweeping coca leaves here beside the ''cocaine highway.''

title: AIR FORCE TO RESUME TESTING OF LONG-RANGE B-1 BOMBER
description: The Air Force will resume its B-1 testing program this week, the Pentagon said today, an indication that last month's fatal crash of a B-1 prototype was apparently not caused by a design flaw in the new long-range bomber.

title: S-P DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Trummy Young, 72, Is Dead;Jazz Trombonist and Singer
description: Trummy Young, a Big Band-era trombonist and singer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Monday in Alexian Brothers Hospital here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Friday about Walter F. Mondale's campaign strategy misreported remarks by Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, at a breakfast meeting with reporters. As reported, he said that the Mondale campaign had got off to a ''rocky start'' and that some Mondale aides were isolated from segments of the party. But he did not say his appointment to lead a campaign advisory group of senior Democratic leaders amounted to an acknowledgment of these faults by the Mondale campaign.

title: FILM: 'JOKE OF DESTIN,' DIRECTED BY WERTMULLER
description: THE Italian Minister of Finance is on his way to a press conference, riding in the back of his new, Japanese-manufactured, state-of-the-art, computer- controlled limousine, equipped with every known device designed to thwart Italy's state-of-the-art terrorists.

title: ;  Trevino in Tax Suit
description: Lee Trevino has gone to court to challenge an Internal Revenue Service claim that the golfer and his wife, Claudia, owe $82,000 in back taxes and penalties. According to The Austin American-Statesman newspaper, the I.R.S. levied the charge on the ground that $100,000 in securities losses the couple claimed on their 1980 returns constituted sham transactions to avoid taxes.

title: VERSATILE TOASTER OVEN
description: A TOASTER OVEN is the kind of kitchen appliance you never appreciate until you have one. Toaster ovens became widely popular during the energy-conscious 1970's as consumers looked for ways to minimize the use of major appliances, particularly large ovens. That was my original motivation in buying one, but since then I have found so many uses for it that days go by without my turning the regular oven on.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q&A
description: Q.

title: TEICHER WINS 4-WAY PRIMARY IN WESTCHESTER
description: Oren J. Teicher, a former aide to Representative Richard L. Ottinger, won a four- way Democratic primary race tonight for the seat Mr. Ottinger is vacating.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHAT would a Yoko Ono song sound like sung by Elvis Costello, or Roberta Flack, or Eddie Money or the German minimalist band Trio? ''I never had a clue what my songs would sound like recorded by other people,'' Miss Ono said recently. ''John used to keep telling me, 'If someone would cover your songs, people would start to understand that you're a good songwriter.' But I was always stubborn about wanting to sing them my own way. I told him that if somebody covered one of my songs, people would just think it was really one of his.''

title: Wicker to Get Zenger Award For His Work for Free Press
description: Tom Wicker, columnist and associate editor of The New York Times, will receive 30th annual John Peter Zenger freedom of the press award, the University of Arizona announced today.

title: MORE VIETNAMESE TO GET PERMISSION TO ENTER THE U.S.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced today that the United States was ready to admit the thousands of Vietnamese children fathered by Americans as well as 10,000 former and current Vietnamese political prisoners from ''re-education'' camps.

title: Palau Votes for Compact Of Association With U.S.
description: Voters in the Pacific republic of Palau have approved a compact of free association with the United States.

title: MONDALE'S TAX CHALLENGE
description: In his budget proposals, Walter F. Mondale, the

title: MATCH FOR CHESS TITLE: AN AGGRESSIVE OPENING
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, both of the Soviet Union, chose a very aggressive opening for the first game of their world-title match in Moscow Monday but got a peaceful draw out of it anyway.

title: Postal Chairman Says Rate Won't Rise in '84
description: The chairman of the United States Postal Service said again today that the planned increases in postal rates would not take place until next year.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
SUSPECT HAD WORKED ON BOAT WHERE 8 DIED IN '82
description: A man charged with murdering eight people two years ago on their fishing boat attended a memorial service for some of the victims and was in a picture on their mantel, said a friend of the victims.

title: DISPUTE ARISES IN ISRAEL OVER A RELIGION POST
description: The Likud bloc agreed in principle today to join a coalition government with the opposition Labor Party. But a dispute over who should get the Religious Affairs portfolio in the new government held up a formal contract between the two.

title: THEATRICAL STUDIO HUMS AS NEW SEASON BEGINS
description: Neil Simon emerged from ''The Odd Couple'' rehearsal to eat lunch and think about rewrites. He had revised 40 percent of the comedy to accommodate the change in gender before beginning rehearsals; and since he came to 890 the figure had risen. After the first read-through, he cut seven pages. ''I'm not one,'' he said, ''for waiting until we get out of town.''

title: WAR IN GULF: A STANDOFF, WITH A SLIGHT EDGE TO IRAQ
description: The gulf war between Iraq and Iran is entering its fifth year with little sign that either country has the strength to break the present military stalemate, intelligence analysts say, despite a consensus that Iraq holds a considerable advantage in weapons, training and experienced leadership.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
description: Coastal Corp. Executive Stresses Its Energy Role

title: CITY AND COALITION OF UNIONS BEGIN CONTRACT BARGANING
description: The Koch administration and 200,000 municipal employees began to bargain over a new contract yesterday, with each side immediately rejecting the other's proposals.

title: IMPROPER MICROCHIP TESTING MAY BRING CRIMINAL INQUIRY
description: Defense Department officials said yesterday that they would probably investigate Texas Instruments to determine whether the company violated criminal statutes when it shipped improperly tested microchips to manufacturers of weapons systems.

title: Bio-Response Chief
description: Bio-Response Inc. said today that Farason D. Liebler would assume the duties of president and chief executive officer following the resignation of Robert F. Saydah. Mr. Liebler, one of the founders of the medical-research company, was formerly vice chairman. He served as chief executive from the company's inception in 1972 to February 1983.

title: 'CONSCIENCE OF THE BAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: Year-ago sales results are restated to reflect the acquisitions of Prime Home Improvement Centers Inc. in January and of the Somerville Lumber & Supply Co. in March on pooling- of-interest basis.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Treasury Delays Sales To Explain New Notes

title: NEUTRALITY AND PRIVATE ADVENTURES
description: The neutrality laws, enacted almost two centuries ago to bar the organizing in the United States of private military attacks against other nations, have become something of a headache for American policymakers in the era of covert intelligence operations.

title: CABARET: LARRY KERT SINGS SONDHEIM AND JOLSON SONGS
description: ANY singer who performs Stephen Sondheim's sophisticated ballads and Al Jolson's sentimental vaudeville tunes on the same program has to have a long artistic stretch. And Larry Kert, who has been associated with Mr. Sondheim since ''West Side Story'' and who in recent years has also been working on a tribute to Mr. Jolson, has the theatrical versatility to make this unlikely combination work.

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA
description: The paint is peeling, a few windows sag and the plumbing doesn't work too well, but an old rooming house here is slowly growing into a new Philadelphia institution, a home for the homeless established by a 12-year-old boy.

title: BLACK CHALLENGER DEFEATS 5-TERM BRONX INCUMBENT
description: A five-term Assemblyman was defeated in Democratic party primary voting yesterday by a college instructor who became the first black ever to win nomination to the Assembly from the North Bronx.

title: Coast Explosion Cuts Power
description: An explosion and fire ripped through a Pacific Gas and Electric Company power plant here about 11 A.M. today. There were no injuries. About 35 people were evacuated, but the evacuation order was canceled when the utility assured the authorities that smoke from the fire was not dangerous.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Recalled Rick Steirer and D. W. Smith, pitchers, from Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. Purchased the contract of Stewart Cliburn, pitcher, from Edmonton and added him to the roster.

title: FAITH-HEALING COUPLE GUILTY IN MENINGITIS DEATH OF CHILD
description: A couple who prayed, fasted and quoted Scripture over their dying infant daughter without calling a doctor were convicted today of reckless homicide and child neglect.

title: The Red and the Blue
description: No more a matched set, the overhead trams between Roosevelt and Manhattan Islands now are different colors.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 12, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: O'Neill Twits Reagan As Isolated Campaigner
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that President Reagan was running an isolated campaign, relying on television film and ''acting like he wants that Oscar he never got.''

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said that the latest year results include a writeoff of 73 cents a share in the third quarter.

title: 2 Wounded in Ulster; New British Aide Arrives
description: Three gunmen wounded two traffic policemen in Londonderry today before Britain's new minister for Northern Ireland, Douglas Hurd, arrived in Belfast.

title: NABISCO BUYING 20% of ESPN
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., in the largest move thus far by a leading advertiser into cable television ownership, has agreed to buy a 20 percent interest in ESPN, the cable sports network.

title: GETTING A CLEARER PERSPECTIVE ON THE CLAIMS FOR COSMETICS
description: YOUR tan is beginning to fade and the sun, wind and water seem to have dried out your skin and hair. So your interest in cosmetics as a means of recapturing that summer glow and restoring vitality to the surfaces you show to the world is no surprise. But how do you choose from among the staggering array of products that promise a fresh, new look?

title: No Headline
description: A Coca-Cola Apparel Line Murjani International Ltd.,

title: SCOUTING;
description: Beach Boys Beat Temple U. Drum

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; ;  Chief Named at Fluor; Other Officers Promoted
description: David S. Tappan Jr., the president and chief operating officer of the Fluor Corporation, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the engineering and construction company.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; The New Yorker Ends French Elle Link
description: The New Yorker, which had been selling the advertising for the English-language edition of the French Elle magazine being published here, announced yesterday that it was dropping out of that joint venture and that it expects Hachette, the publisher, to announce a new partner shortly.

title: BORROWERS TURN TO EUROBONDS
description: The rally in the credit markets came to a halt yesterday, but not before a flurry of note and bond financings by high-grade American companies in the Eurobond market.

title: European Arms Talks Resume in Stockholm
description: The 35-nation European disarmament conference began its third session today with the Soviet Union renewing its attacks on American foreign policy and accusing Washington of extending the arms race to outer space.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*Silk Satin Luxury e case with its own portfolio is doubly efficient.

title: CUP OF COCA: NOT SO NICE
description: American visitors arriving at the airport here barely set foot in the terminal before they are greeted by salesmen exhorting them to buy ''mate de coca.''

title: N.A.S.L. TO WEIGH RECOVERY PLANS
description: With indoor soccer out of its plans for the first time in eight years, the North American Soccer League will hold a meeting of executives in New York today to begin charting a strategy for financial recovery.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1984 International Thousands of Vietnamese children fathered by Americans and about 10,000 former and present Vietnamese political prisoners may enter the United States, Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced. He appealed to Hanoi to live up to a promise to let them go. (Page A1, Column 6.) Syria's power struggle grew confused as Defense Minister Mustafa Tlas was quoted as saying that the brother of President Hafez al-Assad was ''persona non grata forever.'' Col. Rifaat al-Assad, the brother of the ailing President, had been viewed as the probable victor in any struggle for succession. (A1:5.)

title: DON'T DEPRIVE ANDEANS OF THEIR COCA PLANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILS TOP CUBS ON 4 IN 9TH, 6-3
description: Ozzie Virgil hit a two-out, bases-loaded single in the ninth inning to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Soviet Bloc Maneuvers On
description: Troops from six Warsaw Pact countries began military exercises in Czechoslovakia today, the Tass press agency reported from Prague.

title: Spying on the Master
description: Is the Anglo-American alliance in

title: Sytek Gets $6 Million I.B.M. Loan
description: Continuing its practice of offering financial support to key suppliers, the International Business Machines Corporation has lent $6 million to Sytek Inc., the tiny Silicon Valley concern chosen by I.B.M. to provide a networking system for I.B.M.'s Personal Computer.

title: UNION STARTS PROTEST
description: Part of a newly retiled ceiling in the north tube of the Holland Tunnel collapsed at 5:11 A.M. yesterday, injuring two tilers and holding up rush-hour traffic for three hours.

title: DEMOCRATS' ERROR IN SHUNNING CARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: The Price of Club Privacy
description: New York's City Council is moving to define what makes a club ''private'' and to ban sex and racial discrimination by any that fails its test. Responding mainly to the protest of women, the General Welfare Committee agrees that members of some clubs often enjoy special business opportunities along with a good meal and good fellowship. While the issues here aren't simple, the Council bill is an intelligent response.

title: Checkmate in the Park
description: His big blue eyes staring stonily at

title: CHICAGO TEAMSTERS, IN POLL, PREFER MONDALE OVER REAGAN
description: One of the largest locals in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has broken ranks with top leaders of the union and voted to support Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Dispute Stays Payment To Jackson Accountant
description: Jermaine Jackson's earnings from the Jacksons' current concert tour will be put in a bank account until a lawsuit over payments to the group's accounting firm is settled, lawyers for both sides said Monday.

title: UNFIT NEW MILLIONAIRES
description: To the Editor:

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JERRY VOORHIS, '46 NIXON FOE
description: Jerry Voorhis, a five-term Democratic Congressman from California whose political career came to an abrupt end when he lost his seat in 1946 to a novice Republican, Richard M. Nixon, died yesterday in Claremont, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: 14.3% CAPITAL OUTLAY GAIN SEEN IN '84
description: American companies plan to invest 14.3 percent more this year in new factories and equipment than they did in 1983, a large gain and in line with increases projected earlier this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Campbell Soup
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it had signed contracts with two biotechnology companies for the development of improved varieties of tomatoes. Campbell officials said they had agreements with Calgene Inc. of Davis, Calif., and the DNA Plant Technology Corporation of Cinnaminson, N.J. The agreement represents a multiyear, multimillion-dollar commitment by the company, Campbell said.

title: ;  Women Back Laws Two female champions from the United States Olympic team said yesterday that, without new Federal civil rights laws to insure equal athletic opportunities, women's college sports programs are likely to face cutbacks.
description: Flo Hyman, a member of the the silver medal-winning United States women's volleyball team, and Cheryl Miller, a star for the gold- medal winning women's basketball team, traveled to Washington to support a Senate bill that would withhold Federal monies from schools that practice sex discrimination in any program.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SETTLEMENT IS REPORTED NEAR IN BANKRUPTCY CASE THAT INVOLVES REP. GREEN
description: A settlement among the creditors is near in a complex bankruptcy case involving Representative Bill Green of Manhattan and his family, according to his lawyer.

title: WINE TALK
description: This little wine- making community 22 miles north of the city of Bordeaux may well be the most famous of its kind in the world. Ch^ateau Margaux, one of the five first-growth wines of Bordeaux, is here, of course. But within 20 miles, one can find the four other first growths: Ch^ateaux Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild and Latour, which are the pride of the bustling town of Pauillac to the north, and Haut-Brion, perhaps the oldest of the five, in Pessac, to the southwest.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: HUBERT HEARS THE METS' CALL

title: Healthdyne Sued
description: Healthdyne Inc. said two class action suits had been filed against the company and three officers in the United States District Court in Philadelphia.

title: ACCORD REPORTED NEAR ON DELAYING MX VOTE
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., were near agreement today on putting off any vote on production of new MX missiles until next year, according to aides.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is on lower Broadway where the woman is

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Flying Tiger Pacts
description: The Flying Tiger unit of Tiger International Inc. said it had reached agreements with its pilots' and machinists' unions that call for wage freezes and other concessions. The agreements are expected to save the cargo carrier about $85 million over the next three years, the company said.

title: HURRICANE RAKES CAROLINA COAST WITH WINDS OF 135 MILES AN HOUR
description: Packing winds of more than 135 miles an hour, Hurricane Diana raked the North Carolina coast around Cape Fear early today, pushing tides up to 12 feet higher than normal and pounding the shoreline with torrential rain.

title: BUSH, IN THE SOUTH, BECOMES EMBROILED IN ABORTION ISSUE
description: Vice President Bush reluctantly became involved in the controversy over abortion today when he said that he would personally support it in the case of rape, although he would oppose using public funds to pay for it.

title: Bay Financial
description: A group led by Bradbury Dyer 3d, a Dallas investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Bay Financial Corporation to 718,400 common shares, or 23.2 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a chart yesterday on Walter F. Mondale's proposals to reduce the Federal budget deficit incorrectly described his plan for an income tax surcharge. His proposals call for a 10 percent surcharge on the taxes owed by single people on income above $70,000 a year and a 10 percent surcharge on the taxes owed by married couples on income above $100,000 a year. The surcharge would not apply to taxes owed on income up to the specified amounts.

title: ASSAD'S BROTHER EXILED 'FOREVER,' SYRIAN DECLARES
description: Defense Minister Mustafa Tlas of Syria has been quoted as saying that the brother of President Hafez al-Assad is ''persona non grata forever'' in Syria.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; ;  $120 Million Issue For Texas Airport
description: The Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport is offering $120 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.50 percent for bonds due in 2012. The underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $416,230 for the quarter and $1,700,000 for the 9 months.

title: G.I.'s in Accident in France
description: A bus carrying World War II veterans of the United States 30th Infantry Division and their families on a tour of Normandy collided with a truck today, and 25 people suffered injuries requiring hospitalization, a spokesman for the group said.

title: MONDALE SHIFT TO RIGHT ON FOREIGN POLICY SEEN
description: To attract moderate and conservative Democrats, Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, will be moving to the right on foreign policy issues, according to his aides and advisers.

title: F.B.I. Investigates SmugglinginSicily
description: Nine men were arrested in New York and Sicily yesterday as the result of an F.B.I. investigation in Italy of heroin smuggling.

title: MEETINGS BANNED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The police banned all meetings critical of the Government in 21 cities and towns today after eight days of riots in which 33 people have been killed and about 300 wounded.

title: WHAT H.R.A. NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Debt
description: * Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 11.269 percent, down from 11.466 last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 11.156 percent, down from 11.413.

title: PARTIAL ARTIFICIAL HEART USED AS 'BRIDGE' FOR A TRANSPLANT
description: The victim of a massive heart attack was in serious but stable condition today after an artificial partial heart kept him alive until a donated human heart was found for transplant, a medical center spokesman said.

title: Sales Tax Set at 7 1/2% BySuffolkLegislatu re
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted 10 to 8 today to increase the county sales tax by a quarter of a percentage point for the next five years.

title: SPLIT SAID TO DELAY PLAN TO END BALDWIN CASES
description: A split within the securities industry has delayed the settlement of class action suits filed against the country's largest brokerages by holders of Baldwin-United annuities, industry officials said yesterday.

title: FOR SOUTH AFRICAN COUPLE, NO NICHE IN APARTHEID
description: Since she married, Sylvia Vollenhoven says, she has lost a lot of her friends. Her husband, Bob, says he does not see too much of his prenuptial buddies, either. When they walk together on the streets of this city, a professed haven of liberalism, people sometimes stop, they say, to insult them.

title: PINOCHET ATTACKS CHILE'S OPPOSITION
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, marking the 11th anniversary of the coup that brought him to power, attacked opposition parties today and signaled a new crackdown against political leaders who take part in protests that result in violence.

title: FLORIDA CITED IN 107 VIOLATIONS
description: The University of Florida received a 75-page official letter of inquiry from the National Collegiate Athletic Association today that charged the school with 107 infractions by the football program.

title: POPE, IN MONTREAL, SPEAKS OUT ON THE ROLE OF WOMEN
description: Pope John Paul II called on women today to give service that ''transcends the opinions of this world'' and presided over the beatification of a nun who founded a religious order dedicated to service to priests.

title: Accord on Debates Is Closer
description: Representatives of President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, say they are closer to reaching agreement on campaign debates this fall.

title: BLUE JAYS ROMP OVER YANKS
description: The Yankees were frustrated tonight by the bunt, the bloop and then the home run, and lost to the Blue Jays, 10-3.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: The company said that the results include approximately 71 percent of Jewel Cos.' operations since American Stores acquired about 71 percent of the outstanding common and preferred shares of Jewel on June 28.

title: Jennifer Kendal, 50, Is Dead; A Stage and Screen Actress
description: Jennifer Kendal, an English stage and screen actress who was seen by American audiences most recently in the 1983 film ''Heat and Dust,'' died in London on Sept. 6 after a long illness. She was 50 years old.

title: FILM CHIEFS IN MOVES Barry Diller
description: Hired to head Paramount Pictures 10 years ago at age 32 . . . described as brilliant, a tough negotiator, hard-working . . . born in San Francisco and entered entertainment business as a youth . . . dropped out of U.C.L.A. after four months . . . joined the William Morris agency briefly and in 1966 moved to the American Broadcasting Companies . . . pioneered, at age 26, ABC's ''Movie of the Week'' . . . introduced the concept of the television mini-series on ABC and obtained the rights to ''Roots'' . . . rose to be vice president for prime time entertainment in eight-year career at ABC . . . attracted to Paramount by Charles G. Bluhdorn, then head of studio's parent, Gulf and Western Industries . . . presided over Paramount's consistent box-office success with blockbusters (''Raiders of the Lost Ark'') and sleepers (''Flashdance'') . . . built studio's reputation for well-managed stability . . . named last year to his current post as head of G.&.W.'s leisure-time group, including such enterprises as Paramount Pictures; Simon & Schuster, the book publisher, and Madison Square Garden.

title: Budging the Budget
description: While the political campaign gets going, work on the Federal budget is slowing. If this was not an election year, David A. Stockman, director of President Reagan's Office of Management and Budget, would now be starting the overall financial review that he normally submits to the President in mid- or late October.

title: LATIN POLICIES FAULTED IN EX-OFFICER'S REPORT
description: United States military policies in Central America are ''not working'' and are unwelcome to nations they are meant to help, according to a retired military officer who often travels in the area.

title: Congress on the Run
description: A hardy band of members of Congress, many of whom are running for political survival this fall, will be running for sport and charity tomorrow morning in the fourth annual Nike Capital Challenge. Shortly after 8 A.M. in East Potomac Park, a field of 500, including 10 Senators and 25 Representatives as well as assorted Government officials and journalists, will step off on the three-mile course.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $500,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $450,000 for the 6 months from the sale of real estate. c-Includes tax credits of $45,000 for the quarter and $165,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $51,000 for the 6 months from the sale of real estate.

title: BELGIANS DON'T KNOW IF URANIUM IS IN SHIPWRECK
description: Heavy seas and gale force winds today prevented salvage crews from determining whether containers of slightly radioactive uranium hexafluoride had been swept out of the torn hull of a freighter that sank off Belgium two weeks ago.

title: RILEY'S DATASHARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ARMY SELECTS FORT DRUMM AS HOME FOR A NEW LIGHT INFANTRY DIVISION
description: The Army announced today that it would station a light infantry division at Fort Drum, here in one of the most economically distressed sections of northern New York.

title: Expos Racism Denied
description: Two members of the Montreal Expos and a former member have denied accusing club management of racism.

title: House Inquiry Sought On Ferraro Finances
description: A conservative law group that is pressing for a House investigation of Geraldine A. Ferraro's family finances accused her today of additional violations of the Ethics in Government Act.

title: Barbara Mandrell, 35, Singer, Injured in Fatal 2-Car Crash
description: Barbara Mandrell, a country music star, suffered multiple injuries tonight in a two-car headon collision that killed the driver of the other car, the authorities said. Two of the singer's children were also injured in the crash.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allied Products Corp., a maker of industrial equipment and products based in Chicago, said it had agreed to sell its Wolverine bolt division to Michigan Rivet Corp. of Warren, Mich. Terms were not disclosed.

title: REAGAN WOULD TELL GROMYKO 'THE U.S. MEANS NO HARM'
description: President Reagan said today that he would meet Sept. 28 at the White House with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, in an attempt to ease ''suspicion and hostility'' and ''maybe convince him that the United States means no harm.''

title: 10.3% Perini Stake
description: Harris Associates Inc., a brokerage firm based in Chicago, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Perini Corporation to 338,200 common shares, or 10.3 percent of the total outstanding.

title: LISTS SHOW PRICE PROBLEMS PERSIST IN MILITARY PARTS
description: Newly obtained documents indicate that the prices of some components of large Air Force transport planes are about four to five times what they were four years ago and that the Government this year is paying $170.98 for a flashlight, $13,905 for a crew chief's chair and $74,165 for an aluminum ladder.

title: Mondale Asked to Follow Up On Vow to Fight Bill on Aliens
description: Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio and other Hispanic leaders said today that they would put all the pressure they could on Walter F. Mondale and Congressional leaders to kill a sweeping immigration bill in a House-Senate conference this week.

title: Ex-Bursar Given Weekends in Jail
description: A former bursar of Barnard College accused of embezzling $360,000 from the college was sentenced yesterday to spend weekends in jail for four months and to make partial restitution.

title: TAXPAYERS' IDEA OF WEALTH MAY NOT BE THE SAME AS MONDALE'S
description: Walter F. Mondale portrayed the tax increases he proposed Monday as a program that would primarily affect the wealthy, while leaving the ''average income family'' alone.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Rebel Indian Group Reported To Form Government in Exile
description: Guerrillas fighting for a separate state in northeastern India have set up a government in exile in neighboring Bangladesh, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: Police Enter Wrong Home In a Drug Raid in Memphis
description: Seven police officers looking for marijuana dealers apparently entered the wrong apartment, creating a disturbance after which a woman and her 73-year-old mother were taken to a hospital, an official said Monday.

title: SCOUTING;
description: No Easy Walks

title: AERONAUTICAL ENGINEERING PIONEER
description: Dr. Jerome C. Hunsaker, an aviation pioneer who founded the first college course in aeronautical engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and later designed the first aircraft to fly the Atlantic Ocean, died Monday at his home in Boston after a brief illness. He was 98 years old.

title: NEW MONDALE ADS IMPRESS A SKEPTIC
description: After weeks of reports about a campaign in sputtering disarray, without coordinated strategy or theme, after countless meetings in search of a plan, the Walter F. Mondale's Presidential effort finally began its $25 million advertising campaign this week and converted one important critic.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MIAMI HEARS ECHO OF ITS '80 RIOTING
description: With two events last week, echoes of the Liberty City riot in May 1980 came back once again to haunt Miami.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOLS FAULTED IN REPORT
description: New York City's public school system is managed so ineffectively that it cannot police itself and does not even know how many teachers are teaching children at any given time, the city's Department of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Sperry Computer
description: The Sperry Corporation said it had introduced the Sperry Portable Computer.

title: Rebels Said to Retake Key Afghan Valley Area
description: Afghan guerrillas have apparently regained command of the upper part of a strategic Soviet-occupied valley that controls key supply routes in Afghanistan, Western diplomats said today.

title: UNION SAYS E.P.A. IS STALLING ON ASBESTOS CLEANUP
description: Calling asbestos in the schools the worst potential health threat to children since polio, the Service Employees International Union sued today to require the Environmental Protection Agency to address the danger.

title: No Headline
description: Name Airline, Win Life Pass DENVER, Sept. 11 (AP) -

title: Judge 'Sick' Over Error In Fatal Accident Case
description: A judge who fined a woman driver $9 for passing a stop sign and killing a teen-ager attributed the action to a clerical error and a busy schedule, and said, ''I'm just sick'' over the matter.

title: U.S. Missile Crashes in Test
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile crashed Monday shortly after it was launched from a submerged submarine at the Navy's test site in Puerto Rico, the Pentagon announced.

title: Art Show Honors 42d St.
description: ''On 42d Street: Artists' Visions,'' 24 paintings, drawings, sculptures and prints inspired by 42d Street, will be exhibited at the Whitney Museum at Philip Morris, at Park Avenue and 42d Street, starting Sept. 26. Artists included are Red Grooms, Richard Haas, Childe Hassam, Alex Katz, Christo, Joyce Kozloff, Claes Oldenburg and Saul Steinberg.

title: Green-Stripe Cabs Faulted atHearing
description: A new category of taxicabs intended to provide additional service to boroughs outside Manhattan was criticized by independent consultants and drivers of medallion cabs yesterday at a public hearing in City Hall.

title: ELEPHANTS GREET ORCHESTRA IN INDIA
description: As their mahouts prodded them with iron spikes, a pair of elephants trumpeted a welcome to a beaming Zubin Mehta and members of the New York Philharmonic as they arrived at their hotel here today, marking the return of the maestro to his homeland and the beginning of the orchestra's eagerly awaited tour of India.

description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 'VOICE' IN A COSTA RICAN PACT
description: The Voice of America has contracted with a private group in Costa Rica for the use of transmitters to broadcast to Costa Rica and Nicaragua, according to a spokesman of the United States Government radio.

title: SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for Year to June 30
Wings
description: An artist named Bridget Taylor was

title: PRESIDENT BLAMES CONGRESS FOR RISE IN BUDGET DEFICIT
description: President Reagan said today that the Federal budget deficit would be much lower if Congress had approved all his budget proposals, and he added that he would propose similar budget ''cuts'' if he was re-elected.

title: DOLLAR'S RISE: EXPERTS BAFFLED
description: The dollar traded at above 3 German marks this week for the first time since floating exchange rates were adopted 11 years ago, continuing a recent pattern of strength against the currencies of the world that has left monetary experts struggling to understand and agree on what forces control how much a nation's money is worth internationally.

title: Woman Held for Incest After Marrying Her Son
description: Mary Ann Garton Bass married her son and hid their kinship from him for six years because ''she did not want any other woman to have him,'' a prosecutor said today.

title: NEW NAIL POLISHING SYSTEM
description: A multitude of Chesebrough- Pond's people converged on the Helmsley Palace Hotel yesterday morning to give moral support to top management's announcement of a major new product development - described variously as an ''outstanding breakthrough'' and ''nothing short of revolutionary.''

title: Senate Panel Skeptical Over New F.C.C. Plan
description: Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee voiced skepticism today about any plan allowing broadcast companies to acquire more television stations if it would benefit the major commercial networks.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE FARMER'S WIFE Anna Mary Robertson died in 1961 when she was 101 years old. Fame had come to her only in the last 21 years of her life when, as Grandma Moses, she was acclaimed for her primitive, or folk, paintings. In the 30's she showed her artwork along with her canned preserves at county fairs. In 1939, the Museum of Modern Art displayed three of her paintings in a show called ''Contemporary Unknown American Painters.'' She lived in Eagle Bridge, N. Y., was married to Thomas Salmon Moses, and was a self-taught artist; her first one-woman show was titled ''What a Farm Wife Painted.''

title: STUDY SAYS SOVIET BROKE ARMS PACTS
description: President Reagan will release within the next week a study charging multiple violations of arms-control agreements by the Soviet Union, the White House said today.

title: Realignment At C-I-L Inc.
description: As part of a management realignment, C-I-L Inc., the diversified Canadian chemicals manufacturer, said yesterday that C. H. Hantho, president and chief executive officer, would add the title of chairman.

title: SAWDON NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
description: chief executive of Sawdon &

title: OLYMPIC GROUP REPORTS A $150 MILLION SURPLUS
description: The Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today that it had realized a surplus of about $150 million from the Games this summer and that most of the money was committed to aiding amateur sport programs.

title: KEY STATE VOTE IN INDIA PUT OFF A DAY
description: The state legislature of Andhra Pradesh, which was to have voted on the reinstatement of its dismissed Chief Minister, was adjourned today in a parliamentary maneuver. The move, which caused pandemonium in the chamber, postponed the vote for at least 24 hours.

title: JOB-SECURITY OFFER BY G.M. FALLS SHORT, UNION CHIEF SAYS
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers said today that the General Motors Corporation's offer on job security did not go far enough but could still lead to a breakthrough in the negotiations in time to prevent a strike.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; ;  Offerings for G.M. Are Tax Exempt
description: The General Motors Corporation is offering various issues of tax-exempt pollution control revenue bonds totaling $134.5 million through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Initial yields are 7 1/4 percent and 7 3/8 percent.

title: RUSH IS ON TO EAT RIGHT AND EAT WELL
description: THE nutrition genie has escaped from the bottle. People are discovering that food does not need to be swimming in butter and cream, doused with salt or encased in sugar to taste wonderful. Nutrition, says Stephen D'Agostino, chairman and chief executive officer of D'Agostino Supermarkets, ''has become a genuine media event, a national preoccupation and downright chic.''

title: DISCO: RAP GROUP AT THE RITZ
description: GRANDMASTER Melle Mel and the Furious Five carry bad news with a beat. His songs are percussive rhymes about hard times, decrying the urban miseries of drug use, unemployment, need and greed.

title: DEMOCRATS OPPOSE PRIVATE LATIN AID
description: House Democratic leaders expressed concern today over contributions to the Nicaraguan rebels made by private United States citizens and corporations and over the military involvement of private citizens in Central America.

title: YARDNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yardney is a majority owned subsidiary of the Whittaker Corporation.

title: FILM CHIEFS IN MOVES Alan J. Hirschfield
description: Allen & Company Inc. investment banker turned Hollywood executive . . . chief executive of Columbia Pictures for four years and credited with returning studio to profitability . . . ousted from Columbia in 1978 in power struggle after he sought to have David Begelman, then head of production, dismissed . . . figured prominently in best-selling book, ''Indecent Exposure,'' by David McClintock, which chronicled events following the defrauding of the studio by Mr. Begelman . . . worked briefly for Warner Communications as a consultant . . . brought in to 20th Century-Fox Film in 1979 as vice chairman and chief operating officer, when studio was publicly owned, replacing Alan Ladd Jr. . . . fell out with Dennis Stanfill, Fox's chairman and the man who hired him . . . replaced Mr. Stanfill as chairman when Mr. Stanfill resigned in dispute with new Fox owner, Marvin Davis, who took company private . . . highly respected, at age 47, for his executive talents in volatile business . . . subject of industry speculation for more than a year that his tenure at Fox would be short-lived.

title: COOKING SCHOOLS: WHEN, WHERE, WHAT, HOW MUCH
description: A la Bonne Cocotte, 23 Eighth Avenue; 212-675-7736. Course: Techniques based on menus.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: -green buds used in cooking for garnishes and for their special piquant flavor, are said to have been eaten since Biblical times. They are cultivated in Mediterranean countries and California. As far as I know the buds are not eaten raw.

title: New Bipartisan Coalition Maps Drive on Deficit
description: Thirty-two groups representing 1.7 million farmers, bankers, retailers, real estate agents and small business executives banded together today as the Bipartisan Budget Coalition to work toward slashing the Federal budget deficit in half over the next three years.

title: COOKING SCHOOLS EXTEND APPEAL AND APPROACHES
description: The cooking-school boom is still going strong in New York. Schools and classes are heavily booked with enthusiastic students, and cooking teachers agree that there is a continuing strong interest in the esthetic and creative challenges of cooking. Learning to cook, and learning new ways of cooking, are as fashionable pastimes as they have ever been.

title: METROPOLITAN OPERA TO TRY OUT SUPERTITLES
description: The Metropolitan Opera will experiment this season with supertitles, Anthony A. Bliss, the general manager of the Met, said yesterday.

description: b-Net loss. The company said that the latest year results include a pret-tax gain of $402,000 from the sale of company- owned real estate in the fourth quarter and a pre-tax reversal of a $350,000 deferred compensation accrual in the first quarter.

description: The list of potential buyers for Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad system, has been narrowed to three, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole said today.

THE NEW MIDWAY AND ITS AIR FLORIDA BID
description: In two years under a new management team, Midway Airlines Inc. has been tranformed from a troubled no-frills operation into an exclusively business-class carrier with lower-than- coach prices.

title: Man Dies as Cliff Collapses
description: A coastal cliff collapsed and buried two sunbathers, killing a man and seriously injuring a woman whose life was saved by bystanders who quickly dug her out, officials said Monday.

title: The Election Infection On election night 1980, NBC News and Jimmy Carter punched themselves and the exit polls in the nose. Now the network is trying to make amends with a new policy for election night coverage. It's not likely to change much but it could be a welcome gesture indeed if it prompts television and the rest of us finally to solve the problem of tainting elections by early projections.
description: Exit polls, those surveys of people who have just finished voting, provide invaluable information about voter behavior. Whom do older women prefer? How important is inflation to the voters? But exit polls also can be remarkably accurate in predicting winners. Relying in part on such polls, NBC in 1980 was quick to project Reagan victories in state after state. Relying in part on NBC, Jimmy Carter went on TV to concede.

title: THE SPEAKER AND HIS SOURCES ON LATIN AMERICA
description: No one in Congress has been more caustically critical of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America than the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: MONDALE TELLS THE PRESIDENT HE 'CAN'T HIDE' ON DEFICIT
description: ''You can run but you can't hide,'' Walter F. Mondale told Ronald Reagan today while he campaigned half a continent away from the President.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Barring a sudden reversal in the fortunes of the Cubs, Met fans will have to be satisfied with memories of a season that turned out far better than anyone expected last spring.

title: Argentine Protesters Force Out U.S. Warship
description: About 2,000 protesters, angry over United States support for Britain in the Falkland war, forced an American warship to withdraw Monday night from a southern Argentine port where it planned to take on supplies, Argentine news agencies reported today.

description: It is one of the most storied names in American film history, but in recent years the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation has perhaps become better known for the instability in its executive suite than for its cinematic and television successes.

title: TRUMAN IS REMEMBERED AT A U.N. SEMINAR
description: Harry S. Truman was fondly recalled here today at a special seminar by a handful of speakers from around the world who knew Mr. Truman during the fledgling days of the United Nations.

description: A $115 million financing by the Ohio Public Facilities Commission was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1985, to 10 percent for bonds due in in 1999. Underwriters were led by Prudential- Bache Securities.

title: TREASURY AND FED BACK BANK DEREGULATION PLAN
description: In an unusual joint effort aimed at untangling a banking deregulation bill in the Senate, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board have endorsed a plan that could lead to nationwide banking chains in five years.

description: Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President, handily defeated three opponents yesterday to win the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in the 15th District on the East Side.

title: Subway Felonies Fell 16.6% in July
description: Felony crimes in the subway system dropped 16.6 percent last July compared with July 1983, the Transit Authority police said yesterday.

title: VAST VIEW OF SPACE BECKONS AS TELESCOPE CLEARS A HURDLE
description: The core of the space telescope, whose destiny is to extend human vision into a region of the universe 350 times larger than is now accessible, is essentially complete after a long series of setbacks.

description: Five members of one family were killed by a flash flood, and another flash flood watch was issued for this desert region today.

title: Five Hungry Children Arrested in Food Theft
description: Five hungry immigrant children, all below the age of 10, who were arrested for stealing food will not be charged, the police said today.

title: U.S. JUDGE SAYS HE WON'T BLOCK MEROLA INQUIRY
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to halt an investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office into the financial affairs of a company in which Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan was a vice president.

title: CAGED 'LEOPARDS' OF THE DRUG WAR
description: Clustered outside their union hall in the tiny Chapare-region village of Villa Tunari, several coca farmers could barely contain their contempt for ''the Leopards.''

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Larry Holmes, the heavyweight champion of the International Boxing Federation, said he would appeal a court decision that apparently blocked plans for a November fight against Gerrie Coetzee, the World Boxing Association's titleholder. A Federal judge yesterday invalidated arrangements Holmes had made with the promoter Don King and ruled that Holmes had to honor a disputed contract giving a Virginia lawyer the right of first refusal. . . .The Chicago Bulls have called a news conference for today to announce the signing of Michael Jordan , the club's No. 1 draft choice from North Carolina, to a multimillion-dollar, four-year contract.

title: MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,950,000 from the sale of nearly all of the assets of the company's Precision Forge subsidiary. c-Net loss.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Adele Wilbur opened her polling place in the basement of Public School 56 in the Norwood section of the Bronx promptly at 6 A.M. yesterday under a full moon, put the American flag up on the wall, even though the custodian had asked her not to because of his new paint job, and had her big black book of registered voters at the ready.

title: SIX FASHION VIEWS AT A BENEFIT
description: WITH floodlights shining on a bright red banner in front of the store and carnival music booming from video screens in the windows, Saks Fifth Avenue gave a party last night honoring six American designers and benefiting six charities. On a hot summer night, women arrived in glittering fall dresses, appropriate for the new fashion season.

title: PARAMOUNT CHIEF GETS FOX JOB
description: Barry Diller, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, announced today that he would resign his position to become chairman and chief executive officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, a rival studio.

description: Franco Harris has found new life in a season he had nearly given up on. The Seattle Seahawks have found new and badly needed help for their running game.

title: SILICON VALLEY DAYS
description: Would you believe when my son the Yumpie was born it never crossed my mind he would grow up to be a Yumpie? Only if you are old or read history would you believe that, because in those days Yumpies had never been heard of. No kidding. Never been heard of . . .

title: NEEDED: A U.S. COMMISSION ON TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: When the bright promise of a teenager's life is sacrificed by suicide, we are haunted by an unequaled sense of loss, tragedy and anger. There is no greater pain that a parent, family and community can suffer.

description: Soon after Robert F. Wagner Jr. became Planning Commission chairman a few years ago, his Inspector General told him the agency had 14 uncontrolled telephone lines from which calls were being made to all sorts of distant points, at great cost.

description: Years ago, Holiday Inns Inc. and other lodging chains had to contend with such problems as a gasoline shortage and President Carter's proposal to place a 50 percent limit on the deductibility of business meals.

description: The overall stock market registered a broad advance yesterday as trading increased substantially. The Dow Jones industrial average, however, closed with a moderate loss after recording sharp gains earlier in the day.

title: PUERTO RICAN STAR IS HELD IN MURDER
description: For years television viewers here watched what appeared to be a close-knit marriage between Luis Vigoreaux and Lydia Echevarria, co-hosts of a popular weekly variety show. But recently, after more than a year of mystery surrounding Mr. Vigoreaux's grisly death, the viewers saw Miss Echevarria being taken into custody, charged with having him murdered.

title: French Gasoline Taxes
description: The French Government plans to increase gasoline taxes to keep its 1985 budget deficit within the limits set by President Francois Mitterrand, it was disclosed today. The higher taxes should add 7 percent to current prices in the next year. Pump prices have already risen 8.9 percent this year because of the rising United States dollar.

title: BATTERED ST. PETER'S ENDS SEASON EARLY
description: St. Peter's College of Jersey City, which has competed in N.C.A.A. Division III varsity football since 1968, dropped the sport yesterday, four days after eight of its players were injured during a 72-0 defeat to Catholic University in its season opener. The Rev. Edward Glynn, St. Peter's president, said he was hopeful that his institution could resume varsity football next year.

description: Companies

title: Here One Day, Gone Monday
description: Employees at a Detroit warehouse were in for a shock when they showed up for work this week. Their company had moved its operation to Indiana over the weekend, throwing them out of work.

title: U.S. Won't Prosecute Officer Who Touched Off Miami Riots
description: A police officer who touched off three days of racial violence when he shot a black man to death will not be charged with a civil rights violation, a Federal prosecutor said today.

description: The Giants have won their first two games of the National Football League season, and New York is excited.

description: Bob Boris, the former University of Arizona player who successfully challenged the United States Football League's occasionally ignored rule against signing undergraduates, has reached an out-of-court settlement of his suit against the league. Lawyers for both parties confirmed the settlement yesterday.

description: McEnroe Defeats Borg SYRACUSE, Sept. 11 - The last time they faced each other on a

title: FORMER CITY LEASING OFFICIAL GETS 12 YEARS IN $1.2 MILLION EXTORTION
description: New York City's former director of lease negotations was sentenced to 12 years in prison yesterday for a racketeering scheme in which he extorted nearly $1.2 million from landlords in the five years he headed the office.

description: b-Net loss. The latest quarter and 6 months results include a gain of $5,116,297 from the restructuring of debt.
