description: For students not lucky enough -

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When our President tells someone, 'Get out of here to Geneva,' he goes to Geneva.

title: METS LOSE TO STAY 7 BACK AS CARDS GET 5 IN EIGHTH
description: On an evening that will haunt them all winter, the Mets were probably blasted right out of September last night when the St. Louis Cardinals scored five runs off Jesse Orosco in the eighth inning and demolished them, 9-5.

title: SHOULD U.S. LET BANKS FAIL?
description: Following the Government's multibillion-dollar rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company this summer, debate has flared over whether such rescues are the right thing to do, or whether banks - even the biggest - should be allowed to fail. The debate will reach a key stage next Tuesday, when the House Banking Committee is scheduled to hold hearings on the rescue of Continental, which was the nation's eighth-largest bank.

title: ACTIVISM IN FAITH: BIG SHIFT SINCE '60
description: When John F. Kennedy was running for President in 1960, the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic church was largely silent on the fact that he, who was to become the nation's first Catholic President, opposed some church policies, including aid to parochial schools and the appointment of an ambassador to the Vatican. Now, Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York and other prelates have been attacking Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, who is Catholic, as opposing the church's teachings on abortion. In doing so, the Catholic leaders are working side by side with Protestant fundamentalists, most of whom sought Mr. Kennedy's defeat because he was a Catholic.

title: AIRLINES BEGIN TRIMMING FLIGHTS AT NEWARK
description: Several major airlines using Newark Airport began reluctantly trimming their heavy winter flight schedules today as the seventh day of talks began on moves to ease flight delays in peak travel hours at six major airports in the country.

description: The Minnesota Twins rode the six-hit pitching of Frank Viola and consecutive seventh-inning homers by Kent Hrbek and Tom Brunansky to take sole possession of first place in the American League West tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

description: Herald Center, the $60 million transformation of the old Korvettes store at Herald Square into a 10-story shopping mall, was to have made its debut this month.

title: Alcan Project
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it would invest $110 million (Canadian) over the next three years to build an anode-baking center at its Jonqui ere, Quebec, facilities. The center will have an annual capacity of 92,000 metric tons, and will replace existing facilities, Alcan said. The company said it expects to complete the project in September 1987.

title: AT NEW PASTRY SCHOOL, A SPECIAL CAKE
description: Albert Kumin, the former White House pastry chef who might be described as the dean of American confectioners, was lamenting recently how the fine arts of sugar spinning and chocolate sculpturing are largely the metier of European-trained chefs. ''We have so many young Americans who are interested in elevating their skills in pastries,'' he said, ''but most have to go to Europe to learn.''

title: ARGENTINE PROBLEMS STRESSED
description: Although bankers and diplomats are optimistic about Argentina's chances of finally signing an agreement with the International Monetary Fund by the end of this month, they remain skeptical about the country's ability to hold to the terms of such an agreement.

title: NOW, HOW WILL UNFETTERED MEDIA COVER COMBAT?
description: The guidelines for coverage of combat operations endorsed last month by the Pentagon represent an important step for press freedom, insuring correspondents full access and freedom from pre- censorship. Because of this, the restrictions imposed on the press during our intervention in Grenada should become an aberration, not a precedent, in the history of American combat coverage.

title: Egypt Dissents on Statement Critical of Camp David Pact
description: Egypt today dissented from a final communique issued by members of the movement of nations professing nonalignment here that criticized the Camp David peace accords between Egypt and Israel and United States ''provocations'' off the Libyan coast.

title: CONCERT: STEWART AT GARDEN
description: THE picture of Rod Stewart as a vagabond jet setter is now so fixed in the public imagination that it's easy to overlook the solid roots of his music in early rock-and-roll and 1960's soul. But the show Mr. Stewart and an eight-man band brought to Madison Square Garden on Monday for two nights offered a reassuring reminder of those roots.

title: Bridge:Separate Teams for Canada A Possibility in World Play
description: For most of the last half-century, Canadian players were a minor appendage of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 12
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1,004,000 for the quarter and $1,857,000 for the 6 months.

title: LANDMARKS HEARING FOR CENTRAL PARK TOWERS
description: The five twin-towered apartment houses whose profiles created the Central Park West skyline were considered for landmark status yesterday by New York City.

title: Don't Export Unapproved Drugs Selling foreigners drugs not yet approved as safe for Americans would create an invidious double standard unhelpful to all American drugs sold abroad. Yet the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee is considering a bill that would permit just that.
description: Present law forbids the export of a drug until it's been approved by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. Because the tests are so stringent, drugs are often approved first abroad, and American companies will start production there.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,082,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the quarter and $1,311,000 for the 9 months.

title: Board Approves Rangers' Lease
description: A long dispute over whether Westchester County should extend arrangements allowing the Rangers to practice at Rye Playland's ice rink ended Monday night when the county's Board of Legislators approved a 15-year lease.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Aerojet General Corp., La Jolla, Calif., a wholly owned subsidiary of Gencorp., has elected Jack L. Heckel chairman and chief executive officer, and George W. Leisz president and chief operating officer.

title: 3d Unit Quits Power System
description: Arguing that rate payers take on all the risks and have little control over the Washington Public Power Supply System, commissioners of the Mason County Public Utility District No. 3 have voted to withdraw from the supply system, the third district in two weeks to do so.

title: POPE CALLS FOR GOVERNMENTS TO FINANCE CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: Pope John Paul II issued a strong call today for public financing of religious schools, arguing that ''we cannot leave God at the schoolhouse door.''

title: SWEDEN ELIMINATES U.S., 9-2
description: Sweden scored four goals in a span of 6 minutes 14 seconds of the first period tonight and went on to eliminate the United States, 9-2, from the Canada Cup international hockey tournament.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Browning-Ferris Indsustries, Houston, a company primarily engaged in solid and liquid waste collection, processing-recovery and disposal services, has elected Robert W. Lary vice president, North American Market Development.

title: WOODWARD TOPS AN IMPORTANT SATURDAY
description: The most important day of racing so far this year comes Saturday, when Slew o' Gold meets Fit to Fight in the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park, Chief's Crown runs in the Futurity Stakes there the same afternoon, and Carr de Naskra goes in the Pegasus Handicap at the Meadowlands that night.

title: FRANK MANCUSO NAMED CHAIRMAN OF PARAMOUNT
description: Frank Mancuso, president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group, was selected today as the movie company's new chairman and chief executive officer. In a related move, Michael Eisner, president of Paramount Pictures Corporation, submitted his resignation.

title: First Penn Retiring Warrants
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said yesterday that it had reacquired virtually all the remaining stock warrants granted to a group of banks in exchange for financing during the company's 1980 financial crisis and that it was seeking those granted to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for its help.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $28,991 for the quarter and $93,076 for the six months. c-Net loss.

title: Senate Clears Bill to Speed Approvals for Generic Drugs
description: The Senate today gave final Congressional passage to legislation speeding up the approval process for getting cheaper generic forms of popular drugs on the market, thereby saving consumers millions of dollars.

title: CHIP MAKERS UNDER PRESSURE
description: In the antiseptic ''clean rooms'' of semiconductor manufacturers, the pressure on employees to work quickly is palpable. With demand booming, an extra step or delay in the enormously complex process of fabricating microchips can cost the company hundreds of thousands of dollars in profits.

title: Heller Notes Set
description: The Walter E. Heller Company is offering $75 million of 13 percent junior subordinated notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.86, to yield 13.04 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes are not callable before maturity and were rated Baa-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Court Intervention Asked in Inquiry
description: In an unusual legal action, a construction company that is under investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office asked a State Supreme Court justice yesterday to intervene before any indictments are handed up by a grand jury.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Stuart Hall Co., a maker of stationery and school supplies, has received a 3-year $25 million revolving line of credit from Mellon Financial Services Corp., a division of Mellon Bank.

title: FRENCH BUDGET CURBS OUTLAYS AND CUTS TAXES
description: Across-the- board income tax cuts and the tightest squeeze on public spending in years are the main features of the first budget announced today by the new Government of Prime Minister Laurent Fabius.

title: Nicaragua-Vatican Talks End
description: Vatican officials and a Nicaraguan Government delegation ended a week of talks today on church-state tensions in Nicaragua. A joint statement said the talks had been conducted with ''frankness.'' Relations have been strained over the expulsion of 10 foreign priests from Nicaragua and the presence of four priests in the Nicaraguan Cabinet.

title: CONGRESSMEN GET ASSURANCE ON PRIVATE LATIN AID
description: Members of the House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that they accepted the assurances given by Administration officials that the Government had not encouraged private United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Air Force said it had awarded $87.8 million in contracts for various programs. It said it had given $30.8 million to Litton Industries' Amecom divison for electronic equipment; $29.6 million to Transamerica Airlines, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, for air transportation services, and $27.4 million to the Martin Marietta Corporation for ground support work for the space shuttle.

title: Kohl Links Calling Off Of 2 Trips to Bloc Strife
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that the East German and Bulgarian leaders called off their scheduled visits to West Germany because of internal strife in the Soviet bloc.

title: QUINONES IS CRITICAL OF REPORT ON GRAFT IN THE CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that a new city report critical of the school system was unfair and exaggerated instances of corruption.

title: Another Reagan Joke
description: President Reagan, holder of the

title: Orchestra Applauded AtConcertinNewDelhi
description: The New York Philharmonic Orchestra under the Indian-born conductor Zubin Mehta drew repeated concert applause in New Delhi tonight, with an incident over some players' dissatisfaction with their hotel accommodations apparently smoothed over.

title: AM International
description: AM International said the Federal Bankruptcy Court had confirmed the company's plan of reorganization, which has been accepted by more than 99 percent of its creditors.

title: EXECUTIVES MOUNT BID FOR ARA
description: ARA Services Inc., the world's largest food service company, announced yesterday that an investor group headed by senior management had offered to acquire it.

title: YEARS OF ENDURING RIGORS, AND HOPING, LEAD TO PAGEANT FOR MISS NEW YORK
description: After five hard years of beauty pageants, Mary-Ann Farrell almost threw in her sash last year.

title: CALIFORNIA WILDERNESS BILL IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to protect 1.8 million acres of national forestland and 1.4 million acres of national parkland in California as wilderness areas. The vote was 368 to 41.

title: American Priest in Sudan Is Reported Kidnapped
description: The State Department said today that it had reliable reports that an American Roman Catholic priest was kidnapped last week by insurgents in the Sudan.

title: THE REGION ; TOP JUDGE LEAVING CONNECTICUT COURT
description: Connecticut's Chief Justice, John A. Speziale, announced today that he would resign Nov. 21 and become a partner in a Stamford law firm.

title: Bid for Reuters Stock Rejected
description: The New Zealand Press Association's directors today rejected an offer to buy its shares in Reuters, the British-based news agency.

title: MORE WIND GENERATORS FORESSEN IN RURAL IOWA
description: Experts have called Iowa one of the best places in the country for turning prairie breezes into electricity, and a handful of business operators may be on the verge of proving it.

title: THE IMPACT OF A G.M. STRIKE
description: The last time the United Automobile Workers shut down the General Motors Corporation, the 67-day strike dealt the economy a body blow. That strike, in 1970, led by the union's newly elected president, Leonard Woodcock, pushed the nation's already feeble economic growth into a decline of 3.3 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: BUSH SAYS HE DOESN'T REMEMBER 1980 SUPPORT OF AID FOR ABORTION
description: Vice President Bush said today that he could not recall that, in his unsuccessful bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, he had favored Federal financing for abortions under certain circumstances.

title: C.D. Rates Up Slightly
description: Average effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose slightly, while yields on money market deposit accounts stayed the same for the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: Suspect in Belushi Case Is Ordered Extradited
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith today was ordered extradited to Los Angeles to stand trial for murder in the 1982 death of John Belushi, the comedian.

title: Can It Be? A Path Out of Poverty? There's startling news from a long, rigorous research project in Michigan. Yes, after all the years of experiment and disappointment American society does know one sure way to lead poor children out of a life of poverty.
description: It has different names - Project Headstart, developmental day care, nursery school - but the idea is the same: high-quality preschool education. And it works.

title: FREDERICK C. THOMSON
description: Frederick C. Thomson, retired president of a meat and poultry processing company in New York City, died Tuesday at St. Andrew's Hospital in Boothbay Harbor, Me.

title: CATHOLICS AND ABORTION: DOGMA AND PUBLIC POLICY
description: The dispute over abortion between Roman Catholic prelates and Catholic politicians illustrates the difficulty the church encounters as it tries to turn its moral principles into public policy. The difficulty results from the church's worldwide increase in political activism. As the Vatican under recent Popes has taken a more aggressive approach to social problems, church leaders have sought to set broad, nonpartisan standards by which to encourage Catholics in various societies to redress injustice.

title: Reagan Re-election Seen As Further Blow to Poor
description: A coalition of religious groups warned today that President Reagan's re-election could mean more cuts in Federal programs for the poor.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Key Positions Filled at Trilogy
description: Trilogy Ltd., which has been experiencing financial difficulties stemming from its unsuccessful attempt to build a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip, has named a financial consultant to head its parent company yesterday and its top engineer to run Trilogy Systems, its operating arm.

title: Transactions
description: Jim Napier resigned as manager of the Iowa affiliate in the American Association. NATIONAL LEAGUE - Reduced the suspension of Ozzie Smith, shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals, from seven to three days, beginning Wednesday, and fined him $2,500 for actions in a game with the Houston Astros on Sept. 1.

title: Psych Systems
description: Psych Systems Inc. said it had received an acquisition offer of $1.50 a share from the Charter Medical Corporation, which terminated an earlier $5-a-share offer.

title: SOVIET DISMISSAL NOW BEING LAID TO A POLICY SPLIT
description: A senior Soviet diplomat has told United States officials that Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov was dismissed as chief of the General Staff because he was showing ''unpartylike tendencies,'' Administration officials said today.

title: Snow Cone Inventor Dies
description: Samuel Bert, the man credited with inventing the snow cone ice machine, died Sunday at Baylor University Medical Center of complications from a fall that broke his hip two weeks ago. He was 88 years old. Mr. Bert worked at the State Fair of Texas for 65 years. His son, Nick, said his father invented a machine to mechanically scrape ice for snow cones in the late 1920's.

title: GOODEN FANS 16 AND SETS ROOKIE MARK OF 251
description: In a dazzling display of virtuoso pitching by a 19-year-old rookie, Dwight Gooden fired the Mets to a 2-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night, struck out 16 batters and hurtled past strikeout records set by Tom Seaver, Nolan Ryan and Herb Score.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT ATTACKED SHIP IN GULF
description: Iraq said today that its air force attacked a ''naval target'' south of Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf Wednesday night. The report came hours after Iraq said its navy attacked an Iranian convoy heading toward the port of Bandar Khomeini in the Persian Gulf, destroying four ''naval targets.''

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1984 International Nikolai V. Ogarkov was demoted as chief of the Soviet General Staff because he was showing ''unpartylike tendencies,'' according to a senior Soviet diplomat. Reagan Administration officials said the diplomat had made the statement to United States officials. They said that Marshal Ogarkov might have been dismissed because of possible disagreements with other policy-makers over military priorities. (Page A1, Column 1.) Public financing of religious schools was strongly urged by Pope John Paul II in an address in St. John's, Newfoundland. Earlier, the Pope assailed economic systems that respond ''only to the forces of the marketplace'' and are governed ''by the profit motive of the few rather than the needs of the many.'' (A1:4-5.)

title: Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it would offer a new hardware package that includes the Apple IIc personal computer, the Monitor IIc and the Monitor IIc stand for $1,295. Apple also said it was lowering the suggested retail price of the Apple IIc alone by $100, to $1,195. The prices of the Monitor IIc, at $109, and the Monitor stand, at $39, will be maintained, Apple said.

title: A RIGHTS LEADER CHARGED IN PLOT AGAINST A BANK
description: A Hispanic civil-rights leader has been charged with putting glue in more than 70 automatic teller machines in a plot against Citibank, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ENDING EXASPERATING DELAYS FOR AIRLINE TRAVELERS
description: Travelers using New York's three major airports may count on more relief soon from this year's exasperating flight delays as a result of peak-hour schedule adjustments for those and three other terminals on which airline negotiators reached tentative agreement yesterday. In addition to the schedule shifts, most of which take effect Oct, 28, the seasonal dropoff in traffic can be expected to contribute to a return to relative normalcy.

title: BETTER OFF, AND WORSE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES O. PECKHAM
description: James O. Peckham, a former executive vice president of the A. C. Neilsen Company, the market research concern, died of cancer Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Bridge:Pollow Right Formula
description: In the old days, life was simple for the partner of the opening leader: He played high if he wanted a continuation and otherwise low. That is still true for nine bridge players out of ten, but at the tournament level there are several variations.

title: Orders for Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said it had received an order it valued at $300 million from USAir Inc. for 10 737-300 planes. Boeing said this brings to 30 the total number of planes USAir has ordered. Boeing said deliveries are scheduled for 1987.

title: 3 KILLED, 1 TRAPPED
description: A huge slab of rock fell from the roof of a coal mine today with four miners inside, and three of the men later were found dead in the rubble, a state official said.

title: A Sunday Supplement For Academy Awards
description: Gerald H. Gogol, president of North South Communications, who has been creating ''advertorial'' newspaper inserts for the last four years, will have a new entry next year. A Sunday supplement in an estimated 19 newspapers with a collective circulation of 9.5 million is scheduled to run on the eve of the Academy Awards.

title: ABANDONED MODERATES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE DRUG WAR, BATTLES WON AND LOST
description: The best efforts of a dozen nations have failed to reduce opium-poppy production in Thailand. And the failure clearly demonstrates the weaknesses of a key strategy behind narcotics-control programs used around the world.

title: PITCH THAT INCITES
description: TORONTO

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss The company went public May 16, 1984.

title: STANDARDIZING COMPUTER TALK
description: DETROIT THE General Motors Corporation, historically

title: Mortgage Rate Bill Advances
description: The Senate today approved a measure that would prevent interest rates on adjustable rate mortgages - home loans whose payments rise or fall with movements in short-term interest rates - from increasing by more than five percentage points during the life of the loan.

title: COMMUNITY CARE FOR MENTALLY ILL TERMED A FAILURE
description: The American Psychiatric Association said today that the practice of discharging mentally ill patients from state hospitals into ill-prepared local communities had been a failure and ''a major societal tragedy.''

title: GRANADA RETURNING TO TV ADS
description: FEELING that it is now big enough, Granada TV Rental is putting television back into its advertising mix, beginning on Monday. And the commercials will be a tongue-in-cheek contribution from TBWA Advertising, which got the account about four years ago.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
LIGHTED MIRRORS
description: A LIGHTED magnifying mirror is a useful addition to the bathroom for putting on makeup and contact lenses. Two such mirrors are available.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Hardly a section of the country, urban or rural, has escaped the ubiquitous presence of ragged, ill and hallucinating human beings, wandering through our city streets, huddled in alleyways, or sleeping over vents.

title: 200 WOMEN TURN OUT FOR PARLEY TO SEEK WAYS TO HALT ARMS RACE
description: More than 200 women, many of them prominent, gathered here today to discuss the prevention of nuclear war and to condemn ''the arms race.''

title: BEATTY IS GIVEN A 4-YEAR TERM IN FEDERAL CASE
description: A Federal judge yesterday sentenced former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn to four years in prison for stealing more than $200,000 from a community redevelopment program he helped establish while in the Legislature.

title: I.B.M. System For Chinese PEKING, Sept. 12 (AP) -
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is starting a

title: MUSIC: BACK FESTIVAL AT TULLY HALL
description: THERE they were, facing one another across an imaginary line like opposing bands of Roundheads and Cavaliers. On one side were ranged the more or less conventionally equipped forces of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and, on the other, Christopher Hogwood's Academy of Ancient Music with its Baroque flutes and oboes and its cellos held between the legs without supporting pins. No genuine battle ensued, however, for the two groups had come together peaceably to honor Bach and to throw some new light on his music.

title: JDCC Bid Rejected By Seibels Bruce
description: JDCC Investments Joint Venture, a Houston-based partnership, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had made an unsuccessful bid to acquire the Seibels Bruce Group Inc. for $32 a share. JDCC said the company had rejected the offer.

title: AIRLINES COMPLETE PLAN TO CUT DELAY AT 6 BIG AIRPORTS
description: Airline industry representatives reached tentative agreement today on a broad package of schedule changes intended to reduce delays at six major airports, and the Federal Aviation Administration accepted the plans.

title: MAJOR MANEUVERS HELD BY PRETORIA
description: To the thump of artillery, and with invocations of the Old Testament, the South African Defense Force threw rockets, warplanes, paratroops and tanks into a simulated battle on these bald plains today in its biggest exercise since World War II.

title: Woodward Backs Higher Bid
description: Woodward & Lothrop Inc.'s directors agreed yesterday to accept a new, higher bid of $60.50 a share for the Washington-based retail department store chain from Taubman Holdings Inc., a major shopping mall developer. The new bid, which topped a previous offer of $59 a share, was also accepted by a dissident shareholder group.

title: CBS Regains Top Spot
description: CBS regained first place in the Nielsen ratings last week for the first time since June, but NBC's ''A- Team'' headed the Top 10.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After $67,000 tax credit. c-After $175,000 tax credit.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Quarter is after income of $23,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $50,000. Year is after income of $684,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $8,986,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $371,000 in the quarter and $824,000 for the year.

title: VOTE ON OUSTED INDIAN STATE PREMIER PUT OF AGAIN
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's forces in the state assembly of Andhra Pradesh today postponed for the second time a vote on the reinstatement of the dismissed Chief Minister.

title: AFTER THE GROMYKO TALK
description: It would be petty to object now to Ronald Reagan's scheduled meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko: any kind of contact with the Soviet Union is welcome, and desperately needed. But we must have no illusions about the outcome of the meeting. If Ronald Reagan is re-elected in November, there will be no change of direction in our relations with the Soviet Union. The President and his key advisers are opposed to serious arms control.

title: Voting Scandal New York City's worst election scandal has nothing to do with stuffed ballot boxes or improperly cast votes. The problem is people not voting. The dismal turnout for Tuesday's primary can't be explained away just because it was a quiet election. The voter-registration rate in the city, which hovers around 50 percent, is among the lowest in America. Of the 10 Congressional districts with the lowest voter turnout in the 1980 election, 6 were in the 5 boroughs of New York.
description: Can anything be done beyond exhortation? Governor Cuomo recently ordered state agencies to recruit new voters, but his failure to gain Republican support in advance prompted a court challenge. A judge recently lifted an injunction barring the registration drive, but the Republicans will continue to press their point that such a use of state agencies requires legislative approval.

title: DEFENSE RESTS CASE IN TRIAL OF A CUBAN EXILE FOR MURDER
description: The defense rested its case yesterday in the Federal murder trial of Eduardo Arocena, a Cuban exile accused of heading the anti-Castro terrorist group Omega 7.

title: A PREVIEW OF NETWORKS' FALL LINEUP
description: In the next four weeks, 20 new programs will be introduced on the three television networks, starting tonight with the debut of, ''Glitter,'' ABC's new series about a personality magazine. But by the end of the fall season, says one television executive, the odds are that only one in five of these shows will still be on the air.

title: DUARTE ISSUES RULES FOR AIR ATTACKS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he had issued new guidelines to the Salvadoran Air Force aimed at reducing civilian casualties from aerial bombardment.

title: FOUNDER OF FOOD CHAIN DIES
description: David B. Shakarian, founder of General Nutrition Centers, a major health food company, died of cancer Tuesday at his home downtown. He was 70 years old.

title: WINDMILLS OR TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Light Bulbs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: SHONGUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
People
description: * Norman Tanen has been named a senior vice president of Benton & Bowles.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: FOREIGN AFFAIRS. By Alison Lurie. 291

title: Stuyvesant Town TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: ''Stuyvesant Town: Still Going Strong'' (Sept. 6) requires a bit of amplification to set the record straight. To suggest that Metropolitan Life changed its discriminatory rental policy ''voluntarily in August 1950'' is like stating that an employer ''voluntarily'' gives his employees a wage increase after a protracted strike.

title: Tavern Pays Parents Of Driver's Victim
description: A tavern that gave away beer and a radio station that advertised the promotion have agreed to pay $92,500 in an out-of- court settlement with a couple whose son was killed by a drunken driver who had been to the bar.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis dispatch from Washington on Tuesday about Walter F. Mondale's budget proposals misstated the sponsorship of an August poll on attitudes toward income taxes. It was conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Play That Tune
description: The popular music played on radio station WNEW is mainly from the past, from Paul Whiteman's big-band tunes of the 1920's to Herb Alpert's brass instrumentals of the 1960's.

title: THE COSMOS' FALL BRINGS DOWN DAVIS
description: Rick Davis played his first season for the Cosmos in 1978, when he was 19 years old and brimming with optimism. Those were the days when the North American Soccer League had 24 teams, and it, too, was filled - many would say overstuffed - with optimism.

title: Utility Preferred
description: The Central Louisiana Electric Company is offering 250,000 shares of adjustable rate preferred stock at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. The stock, which has an initial dividend rate of 11.05 percent, will be adjusted quarterly to 1 1/2 percentage points below the higher of the rate on 91-day Treasury bills, 10-year Treasury notes or 20-year Treasury bonds.

title: Winslow Agrees
description: Kellen Winslow , the all-pro tight end who ''retired'' last week because of a contract dispute, has agreed to a pact that will keep him with the San Diego Chargers another five years.

title: INQUIRY FINDS AN 'ERROR' LED TO FREEING OF 2 DRUG DEALERS
description: A seven-month investigation has concluded that two major drug dealers were released from a Federal jail in Manhattan because of ''an administrative error'' concerning their bail.

title: Hines Lumber
description: The Edward Hines Lumber Company said that it had decided to consider a possible merger with another company, the sale of its assets or other opportunities.

title: Honoring Eleanor
description: In cynical, election-year Washington there is little surprise that

title: WARNING ISSUED BY I.M.F. ON THE DOLLAR
description: The record level to which the dollar has risen is ''unsustainable'' and potentially ''detrimental'' to the United States and the rest of the world, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report.

title: Philadelphia Benches Can Be Home to Voters
description: The city has tentatively agreed to let homeless people claim street corners and benches as places of residence when registering to vote, as long as they list a shelter as a mailing address.

title: Securities Firm Censure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured and limited the operations of the Manhattan securities firm of Verrilli, Altschuler, Schwartz Inc. It also prohibited the firm's principals, M. Richard Verrilli, Stanley Altschuler and Stephen Schwartz, from associating with any broker-dealer for six months.

title: Congressman Loses Posts
description: Representative Andy Ireland of Florida, who switched his political allegiance from the Democratic to the Republican Party in July, was officially dropped from the House Democratic Caucus Tuesday. The action also takes him off the rolls as a Democratic member of the Committees on Foreign Affairs and Small Business. A spokesman for Mr. Ireland said the Congressman was working with the Republican leadership to remain on the two committees as a Republican.

title: WON'T TESTIFY IN SON'S CASE
description: A couple whose son has been charged with killing a mail carrier were jailed for contempt today after repeatedly refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating the slaying.

title: SECULAR GOVERNMENT'S PROMISE TO RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: GASTINEAU IS GUILTY, O'BRIEN ACQUITTED
description: -pro defensive end of the Jets, was convicted yesterday of having committed misdemeanor assault in a brawl at a midtown Manhattan discoth eque. One of his teammates, the quarterback Ken O'Brien, was acquitted.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1984 Companies
description: ARA Services got a buyout offer from an investor group headed by senior management for more than $858 million, or $62 a share. The world's largest food service company rejected an offer of $732 million by a former ARA executive in July. (Page D1.)

title: OPTION/GROWTH FUND'S TACTICS
description: THIS has not been a spectacular year for

title: Paul C. Reilly, 94, ArchitectAnd a Catholic Lay Leader
description: Paul C. Reilly, a retired New York and New Jersey architect whose works included the Sacred Heart Cathedral in Newark and the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour at Park Avenue and 38th Street in Manhattan, died Saturday at his home in Locust, N. J. He was 94 years old.

title: COSMOS' PLAYOFF BID STALLS, 1-0
description: After tonight's 1-0 loss to the Golden Bay Earthquakes at Giants Stadium, the Cosmos are in the unfamiliar position of not yet clinching a playoff berth with one game left in the regular season.

title: UPROOTED NICARAGUAN ISLANDERS LOOK HOMEWARD
description: This lush island, for centuries the home of the Rama Indians, is today in ruins and all but deserted, a ghost town in paradise.

title: NBC NEWS-LIVE FROM MOSCOW
description: ALL week, NBC News has been looking at United States- Soviet relations, moving part of its operation to the Soviet Union to do so. ''Are we being used by Moscow?'' Marvin Kalb of NBC asked Secretary of State George P. Shultz yesterday in a Washington interview on the ''Today'' show. No, Mr. Shultz answered, NBC was doing ''a real service.'' Mr. Kalb may have asked the most provocative question raised on television this year.

title: A Wise Runner
description: Dixon, the New Zealander who won the New York City Marathon last October with a stunning kick that overtook Geoff Smith at the end, will probably not enter this year's race through the five boroughs.

title: THE COMMUNIST CONNECTION
description: The Republican Party's campaign platform takes special note of the international drug traffickers who seem to irritate the Reagan Administration the most.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRIMARY VOTING SEEN AS PARADE TO MAYOR RACE
description: While candidates nominated in Tuesday's primaries began their general- election campaigns yesterday, other politicians looked at the primary returns as a possible prelude to next year's mayoral primary.

title: RABBIS PONDER THE MIX OF POLTICS AND RELIGION
description: At a meeting of 150 rabbis in Manhattan yesterday, one asked another, ''Should I talk about religion and politics in my High Holy Days sermons?'' The second rabbi answered, ''Can you not talk about it?''

title: Vietnam Says It's Open To Cambodia Mediation
description: Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said Tuesday that his country would welcome attempts by a third party to promote peace in Cambodia, the Kyodo news agency reported today.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
KAYPRO PARTS MAY BE MISSING
description: The Kaypro Corporation said yesterday that it is investigating the possibility that millions of dollars in computer parts are missing from a circus tent and big trucks where Kaypro stored them.

title: Jordan Gets Rich Pact
description: Michael Jordan, the former North Carolina star who led the Olympic basketball team to a gold medal in Los Angeles, got an even bigger award in Chicago yesterday: a seven- year contract with the Bulls that will apparently make him the third-highest-paid rookie in the history of the National Basketball Association. No financial details were disclosed, but with estimates of his annual earnings ranging from $650,000 to $850,000, it is believed that Jordan will be paid more than any first-year N.B.A. man has ever received, except for Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets.

title: Of Pornography
description: Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat, noting that Indianapolis recently passed a new anti-pornography law, devoted his August report to his constituents to the subject. The report said Americans spend as much as $7 billion a year on pornography, ''more than the combined revenues of the recording and film industries.''

title: German Price Changes
description: West German wholesale prices fell 1.3 percent last month from the July level but were up 1.6 percent from August 1983, the Government said today.

title: 18TH-CENTURY ECHOES IN A STONE HOUSE
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa.

title: Hurricane Effect Seen As Slight in New York
description: The National Weather Service in New York City said early this morning that it was unlikely that Hurricane Diana would reach the New York metropolitan area.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After income of $223,425 from discontinued operations.

title: Cuomo Speech on Television
description: Governor Cuomo's address tonight on theology and politics, to be delivered at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind., will be televised live at 9 P.M., Eastern daylight time, on Channel 21. Channel 13 in the New York area will carry a taped broadcast of the speech at 11 P.M. The speech will also be carried live by WMCA radio in New York.

title: 2D STATE COURT REVIEWS CUOMO'S VOTING DRIVE
description: New York State's top court was asked today by Republicans to stop Governor Cuomo's use of state agencies in voter registration drives.

title: OUTLOOK FOR EXPORT BILL DIMMING
description: House conferees today rejected a Senate proposal to revamp national security provisions of a hotly contested export control bill amid reports that the Reagan Administration has decided to withdraw its support for a revised version of the Export Administration Act this year.

title: Nynex Planning Foreign Ventures
description: The Nynex Corporation said it planned to enter foreign ventures, including consulting services and the sale of telecommunications and electronics products.

title: Bank Stock Offer
description: The Bank of New England Corporation is offering 300,000 shares of adjustable-rate preferred stock at $100 a share through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. The stock was offered with an initial dividend of 11.55 percent and will be adjusted quarterly at a percentage point below the higher of the bond equivalent yield on 91-day Treasury bills, the yield on 10- year notes or the yield on 20-year bonds.

title: WORKING PROFILE: John F. Lehman Jr.; GIVING NEW MEANING TO THE WORD 'SHIPSHAPE'
description: The Pentagon is a building whose interior resembles a big city hospital far more than a yacht club, but the corridor where the Navy's civilian leadership resides sports quantities of varnished wood and polished brass only dreamed of elsewhere.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-The quarter is after income of $45,000 from discontinued operations and a gain on the sale of Oral-B Laboratories of $79.8 million. The nine months is after income of $4.6 million from discontinued operations and a $79.8 million gain from sale of Oral-B Labs. c-After income from discontinued operations of $7.4 million in the quarter and $17.6 million for the nine months.

title: JAZZ: CHAPMAN PLAYS STICK
description: LIKE Adolph Sax playing saxophone, Emmet Chapman performed on the instrument he invented - the stick - Tuesday at the Jazz Center of New York. The stick is a 10-string, fretted, amplified instrument that looks like a guitar fretboard minus the guitar; it is played by tapping the fingers of both hands on the strings.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
Saratoga Six, $3, Takes Futurity
description: Saratoga Six, a $2.2 million yearling purchase, remained undefeated in four career starts today with a three- length victory in the $249,190 Del Mar Futurity for 2-year-olds at Del Mar.

title: East Baton Rouge Mortgage Bonds
description: East Baton Rouge, La., is raising $30 million with an issue of single-family mortgage revenue bonds offered through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

title: 20 ARE SAID TO BE INDICTED AFTER INQUIRY ON L.I. CARTING
description: Twenty people and 17 corporations have been named in sealed indictments charging them with criminal activity in Long Island's private garbage-collection industry, officials said today.

title: HELMS BLOCKS COMMITTEE VOTE ON GENOCIDE PACT
description: Senator Jesse Helms, in a clash with Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, blocked a committee vote today for at least 24 hours and possibly a week on a United Nations convention against genocide.

title: Rome Bus Crash Kills 5
description: A bus collided with a truck and skidded off an overpass in the southern Rome neighborhood of Magliana today, killing five people and injuring 22, Italian news agencies said.

title: MCENROE SAYS THE GAME MISSES BORG
description: He was just a ball boy, an awkward but eager 14-year-old from Queens dashing about the courts at Forest Hills during the 1973 United States Open. Yet even then, John McEnroe knew the feeling of watching Bjorn Borg.

title: CANADIAN COMMERCIAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2.9 million for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 9 months. The bank said that the results of Westlands Diversified Bancorp Inc. are included from June 27 when the acquisition was completed.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CABARET: KERN AT 100
description: THE legacy of Jerome Kern is so vast that his songwriting career can only be glossed in an hourlong cabaret act. For a ''100th Birthday Celebration'' at Michael's Pub, which opened on Tuesday and plays through Sept. 29, the pianist Arthur Siegel and the singer Sandy Stewart have put together a fast-paced musical biography filled with facts and leavened with lighthearted banter.

title: Fugitive Indian Leader Reported Ready to Yield
description: An attorney for Dennis Banks said the fugitive leader of the American Indian Movement left New York today to return to South Dakota.

title: Italian Deficit Widens
description: Italy's current-account deficit widened to $2.44 billion in the first five months of 1984 from $1.22 billion a year earlier, the Bank of Italy said today. The current account measures international dealings - both goods and services.

title: Mapco Talks End
description: Mapco Inc. said that it had agreed with Texaco Inc. to terminate talks on the purchase of Texaco's Chemplex Company, a producer of ethylene and polyethylene resins. When Mapco announced on July 20 that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Chemplex, it said the purchase would increase its annual revenues about $300 million. Mapco, based in Tulsa, Okla., is involved in oil, natural gas and coal and operates pipelines.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NIEKRO BEATEN IN A DUEL
description: If nothing else for the Yankees, tonight's game, a 2-1 loss to Toronto, was a smooth and restful one in which two veteran pitchers, Phil Niekro for the Yankees and Doyle Alexander for the Blue Jays, had the hitters walking back to the bench wondering why they were unable to hit ''hittable pitches.'' ''These guys throw the ball right out there,'' said Dave Collins of Toronto. ''You think I got it, I got it. But then you don't get it.'' The Blue Jays barely chiseled out their runs and barely held off the Yankees, who did not score until the eighth inning. Compared with Tuesday night's game, when the benches cleared during a brushback incident, this was a calm night for the teams. The Blue Jays scored once in the third inning and once in the fifth and the game whisked along in just more than two hours. It was shaped by Niekro's knuckleballs and Alexander's breaking balls.

title: SECULAR GOVERMENT'S PROMISE TO RELIGION

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

description: Shirley Jones still has bad dreams about the day she was arrested, handcuffed and taken to two different jails, where she spent 18 hours sitting on hard benches, afraid to go to sleep and worrying about her young children.

title: STORM: WHY IT LURKED
description: Hurricane Diana lurked off North Carolina for so long yesterday ''with no sense of direction'' because of a lack of the westerly winds that would normally blow it to sea, according to Dr. Neil Frank, director of the National Hurricane Center in Miami.

title: DEBUT OF ABC'S 'GLITTER'
description: ''GLITTER,'' the weekly series that is getting a special two-hour premiere on ABC tonight at 8, works out of the snazzy offices of ''the hottest magazine on the newsstands,'' a magazine that wouldn't mind being mistaken for People. Each episode will feature the staff juggling an assortment of stories designed as mini- showcases for guest stars, much in the manner of ''Love Boat'' and ''Hotel.'' In short, Aaron Spelling, the veteran producer who has latched on to a profitable formula, is at it again, this time with Douglas Cramer as his partner.

description: Yes, folks, welcome once again to the wild and wacky world of the automobile industry, where anything can happen and usually does. Consider these two bargaining positions:

title: Pennzoil Cutbacks
description: The Pennzoil Company said that it would cut the work force at its Shreveport, La., oil refinery by one-third during the next year as part of cost-reduction measures. It said the hourly and salaried staff would be cut to about 325, from 472, with about 100 jobs to be eliminated in the next several weeks. Pennzoil said it would operate the refinery at levels of about 36,000 barrels daily and maintain full output from its lubricating-oil manufacturing units.

title: DANCE: RIVERSIDE CELEBRATES AILEY
description: THE Riverside Dance Festival, an indisputable mainstay of New York's dance scene, opened its new season Tuesday night with a festive gala celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble.

title: Installment Debt Up $7.11 Billion
description: Americans took on $7.11 billion more in installment debt in July than they paid off, the third-biggest increase on record but still well below the record gain set in May, the Government reported today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ; Dollar's Gain Continues Against Mark; Gold Off
description: The dollar continued to rise against the West German mark yesterday, breaking an 11 1/2-year high set on Tuesday. In early European trading, the dollar retreated slightly against most other currencies only to strengthen again in trading in the United States later in the day.

description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld a New York City ban on sidewalk vendors on certain streets.

description: ''WELCOME to the wonderful world of shoji'' was the greeting extended by Richard Knapple, Bloomingdale's vice president of interior design. ''Japan,'' a storewide promotion, opens to the public today, and apart from the traditional rice-paper screens, the event promises to offer an education in such things Japanese as obis, kimonos, tatami, Kabuki, tansu and furoshiki.

title: AGENCY TO ADD 250 WASTE DUMPS TO CLEANUP LIST
description: The national list of toxic waste dumps given priority under the Government's cleanup program will probably expand by nearly 50 percent within the next month, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

description: Perhaps imagining romantic adventures on the high seas, Wall Street types in dark suits pressed close to the railing beside the East River yesterday, gazing at a 56-foot Norwegian Viking ship moored at the South Street Seaport.

description: For years track and field has had antirabbit rules, and for years no one has paid much attention. Now, starting April 1, it won't make any difference, because the rules against rabbits are hippity-hopping right out of existence.

description: These are not the best of times around Washington. In many sections, the normal cheeriness of late summer has given way to sullenness and suspicions. And why? High interest rates? Trouble in Central America? Traffic in Georgetown?

title: LEAHY HOPES TO CLOSE GAPS IN WIRETAP LAWS
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said today that he would seek legislation to improve protection of privacy by closing gaps in Federal wiretapping laws.

title: HERS
description: MY friend Ruth lives with her family in a house on the next ridge of hills a couple of miles to the south of me. She tells me that she looks for the smoke from my chimney each morning in the winter to make sure that I am up and about. Ruth has lived here all her life, and despite the fact that I've known her for 10 years, her soft Ozark speech is hard for me to understand sometimes. It was that way one night when I had been asleep for half an hour and was wakened by the ringing of the telephone. Struggling to wake up as I answered it, I heard Ruth say in an excited voice: ''Sue! Sue! There's a far on you. We're a-comin'.'' And then she hung up. I stood there, holding the telephone, trying to think what I had been told. There's a far on me. There's a far . . . Far? . . . Fire! There's a fire on my place!

title: Coach Reprimanded
description: Dan Gable, the Iowa wrestling coach, was also the coach of a 10-man Olympic team that won seven gold medals in Los Angeles. Now he has been dealt a formal reprimand by the sport's governing body, USA Wrestling, on the ground that he showed favoritism to an Iowa wrestler who won his place on the Olympic team through arbitration.

description: b-After non-recurring charge of $707,000 from litigation expenses.

description: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, who came to the United States after being released from prison, said today that he had decided to go home in December ''to struggle for the return of democracy.''

description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board voted yesterday to tighten its rules on a technique, known as ''instantaneous defeasance,'' that some corporations have used to book profits and reduce debt.

title: MONDALE DEPICTS PRESIDENT AS CRUEL TO THE NEEDY
description: Showing more vigor and force than he has in days, an energetic Walter F. Mondale today painted President Reagan as cruel to the needy and called on voters to choose instead a man of compassion.

description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina wound up his $2.5 million campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination with a debt of $31,892, the Federal Election Commission said Monday.

title: Mancini a No-Show
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, the former lightweight champion, defied a Louisiana court yesterday, failing to report for a court-ordered medical examination in New Orleans to verify his contention that a slow-healing cut over his eye forced the cancellation of his fight against Kenny Bogner there last Saturday. His lawyer, Ed Flask, said that Mancini had not been properly served with the order, which concerned a lawsuit filed by the fight's local promoter. . . . Muhammad Ali spent five days at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, checking out Tuesday, hospital officials confirmed yesterday.

title: MOOD IS BETTER ON DEBT
description: Ministers from 11 Latin American countries gather here on Thursday to discuss the region's debt crisis in an atmosphere markedly less hostile toward foreign banks than three months ago, when they last met.

title: CONCERT: ACADEMY OF ANCIENT MUSIC
description: -music orchestras - London, with the Academy of Ancient Music and others, Vienna with the Concentus Musicus, Amsterdam with the Orchestra of the 18th Century and so forth. For a variety of reasons, New York has lagged behind: Aston Magna, which seems now in transition and which appeared here with smaller forces, was the closest equivalent.

title: FINDING CALYPSO AND SOCA AT A 'CARNIVAL IN SPACE'
description: OVER the recent Labor Day weekend, this critic found relief from the beguiling insularity of the usual clubs and concert halls at the calypso shows and Caribbean-American carnival festivities in Brooklyn. Calypso singers and their almost entirely West Indian audiences were caught up in an intense give-and-take, colorfully costumed ''Moko Jumbies'' stalked the edges of the crowd balancing on 10-foot stilts, and the parking lot nearby was peopled with celebrants whose interstellar-alien garb illustrated this year's ''Carnival in Space'' parade theme.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a dispatch from Tel Aviv in some editions yesterday on negotiations for a new Israeli government referred incorrectly to Yosef Burg, leader of the National Religious Party. It should have described him as a veteran (not Bedouin) in Israeli politics.

title: OFFICIAL OF UNESCO VOWS AGENCY WILL REFUND $80 MILLION SURPLUS
description: A senior Unesco official said today that the organization would eventually repay member governments about $80 million in unspent funds, but not before the end of this year.

title: BOOK ON MORALITY POSES DILEMMA
description: A book of moral philosophy, originally scheduled for publication next month, has been postponed and may be canceled because the author wrote a bogus letter that gave the book a ringing endorsement. The author, Timothy J. Cooney, said last night that he ''forged the letter out of desperation'' because without it ''no one in the world of publishing would even read the manuscript.''

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRAT DERIDES THATCHER AND LABOR

title: PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Demonstrators stoned police on three occasions today in Johannesburg's densely inhabited satellite of Soweto in continuing unrest in black townships. The violence today coincided with the seventh anniversary of the death in detention of Steve Biko, leader of the black consciousness movement.

A Civil War and three marriages later - at the top of the staircase in their new Atlanta mansion - she attempts to slap him but misses, and tumbles down its long, straight flight, losing the child she is carrying.

The suspension will begin today, and Smith will also have to pay a $2,500 fine.

title: Replacing the Synfuels Bet With oil and gas available in liberal supply, does it still make sense to subsidize development of synthetic fuels? So do many in Congress who are offended by reports of incompetence and scandal in the Government-sponsored Synthetic Fuels Corporation.
description: But there's still a case for subsidizing as yet uneconomical technologies for converting solid fuels to liquid and gas. It would be myopic for Congress to phase out all programs just because this one has been, undeniably, mismanaged.
