title: MONDALE FIGHTS PRESIDENT'S GRIP ON SOUTHERNERS
description: To hear some of his own supporters tell it, Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign in the South at this point resembles a cotton field after a boll weevil attack.

title: Poll Finds Reagan Lead Has More Than Doubled
description: President Reagan led Walter F. Mondale by 16 percentage points in a sampling of 1,507 registered voters Sept. 7-11, more than doubling his lead of two months earlier, the ABC-Washington Post Poll reported today.

title: PRICE AND DELOITTE SEEK TIE
description: Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, two of the Big Eight accounting firms, announced yesterday that they are discussing a possible merger that would create the nation's largest accounting firm.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT TO SELL PARTS OF SCA
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest waste disposal company, yesterday agreed to the Justice Department's demand that it sell off parts of SCA Services, the country's third-largest waste collector, before completing the merger of the two companies.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL BEFORE CONFEREES
description: Seven Senators and 29 Representatives plan to meet Thursday in an effort to begin drafting a comprehensive immigration bill passed in different forms by the two houses of Congress.

title:
GARDENING;
MAIL ORDER BULBS BRIGHTEN A FLOWER FANCIER'S WINTER
description: CERTAIN people have what might best be described as flower-dependent personalities: they cannot get through winter without a weekly bunch of fresh flowers. They acknowledge that it is an expensive habit: in January, for example, on a per stem basis, amaryllis can run $4 to $8, paperwhite narcissus and hyacinths $1 and up. And these cut blooms may have a half-week half-life, more or less.

title: Research Center
description: The United Technologies Research Center said it would build an 85,000- square-foot laboratory and office complex to expand its research in microelectronics. The center, part of the United Technologies Corporation in East Hartford, Conn., said the building is expected to be completed by mid-1986 for about $26 million.

title: DEMOCRATS ACCUSE G.O.P. ON SPENDING CURBS
description: The Democratic Party today accused Republicans of bypassing Federal election laws and spending limitations by improperly channeling more than $1 million to help Republican Senate candidates in the upcoming election.

title: FERRARO SAYS RELIGION WON'T INFLUENCE POLICY
description: At a boisterous rally here today, where a large contingent of anti-abortion protesters tried to shout her down, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro altered her prepared remarks to say that her Catholicism would not influence her public policies.

title: ACCORD REPORTED REACHED ON ISRAELI COALITION
description: After an 11th-hour crisis in their negotiations to form a Cabinet, Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, and Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, early this morning seemed to have cleared the last obstacles to a broad-based coalition.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bid Withdrawn For Pay'n Save
description: The Trump Group, an investment group headed by Edmund and Julius Trump of New York, announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its $22.50- a-share offer for the Pay'n Save Corporation, a Seattle- based retail chain.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CONNECTICUT BRIDGE ILLS
description: For most of the last two weeks along Route 1 here - as far as the eye could see - it was bumper-to-bumper trucks: tanker trucks, tractor-trailer trucks, flatbed trucks.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: The company said that the results are pro forma and it went public in June.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Larry McWilliams, the Mets' opponent, has a record of only 9-10. But his earned-run average is under 3.00, and he is one reason the last-place Pirates have the best club e.r.a. in the Eastern Division. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.)

title: EXCERPTS FROM POPE'S ADDRESS TO EDUCATORS
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Pope John Paul II this evening at a meeting with Roman Catholic educators at the Basilica of St. John the Baptist here:

title: REAGAN ATTACKS MONDALE TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan, campaigning at enthusiastic rallies across upstate New York, charged today that Walter F. Mondale's proposal for tax increases was based on a ''fairy tale'' view of the economy that would place ''a ball and chain around America's neck.''

title: REDESIGNING CLOSETS TO INCREASE STORAGE SPACE
description: WITH the change from summer to fall clothes, you may have found your wardrobe has expanded but your closet space hasn't. But redesigning closets to maximize space and establish order has become the business of a growing cadre of specialists.

title: SILVER STATE MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Voter Registration Curb In Cincinnati Challenged
description: Members of a coalition opposed to a ban on voter registration in certain public offices confronted county officials today, asserting that they had signed up eight voters in the courthouse despite a threat of arrest.

title: RESULTS OF THE CONTESTS IN NEW YORK PRIMARIES
description: Following are the results of contested races in Tuesday's primary elections in New York State. Incumbent candidates are marked with an asterisk. Districts marked with a dagger had results that were incomplete.

title: ANTUOFERMO, A 'BORN FIGHTER,' RETURNS
description: His manager told him, ''What do you need it for?''

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $112,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THEY stood under the huge oils of

title: SEDCO CONDUCTS TALKS WITH A POSSIBLE BUYER
description: Sedco Inc., regarded by many analysts as the world's best offshore drilling company, said yesterday that it was ''engaged in active negotiations'' with another company concerning a takeover.

title: Two Tied at 66
description: Superb putting carried Marta Figueras- Dotti of Spain and Muffin Spencer- Devlin to 6-under-par 66's today and a tie for the first-round lead of the $175,000 Safeco Classic women's golf tournament.

title: Hanover Offering $100 Million Notes
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation is offering $100 million of 13 percent notes due in 1987 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Theater Bazaar Slated
description: Theater memorabilia will be offered along with Americana and folk art this weekend at the annual Ridgefield Antiques Show in Connecticut, held at the Ridgefield Ice Rink in the town's Prospect Ridge section.

title: 2 CHARGED IN CLEARING HOUSE CASE
description: Criminal charges have been filed against the Chicago Board of Trade Clearing Corporation and two former officials for violating Federal campaign contribution laws, United States Attorney Dan K. Webb said today.

title: THE CONTINUING BATTLE OVER COVERING WARS
description: Nearly a year has passed since United States Rangers parachuted on to the island of Grenada and a Marine contingent helicoptered across its beaches, but a dispute about whether American journalists should have been there has not been totally resolved.

title: Dining Out Guide: Starring California Wines
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AN AMERICAN PLACE, 969 Lexington Avenue (517-7660) vv (Dec. 9, 1983). An intimate dining room with subtle desert

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; NEW FIREHOUSE DEDICATED AT AN OLD COLONIAL SITE
description: ''Isuppose Peter Stuyvesant came

title: LIBERATION THEOLOGY, NORTH AMERICAN STYLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet and Guinea Sign Bauxite Pact
description: The Soviet Union has signed a $102 million loan agreement with the new military Government of Guinea, gaining a share in the West African nation's bauxite mines and ending a period of cool relations between the countries, Guinean officials said today.

title: Elderly Press Reagan On Health Care Cuts
description: More than 200 demonstrators, some in wheelchairs, converged on the headquarters of President Reagan's political campaign today to demand a response to their questions on alleviating high health care costs and cuts in health care programs.

title: Fredericks Kullberg In Joint Venture
description: Fredericks Kullberg Amato Pisacane is getting into a joint venture that will do direct marketing as well as classified, recruitment and Yellow Pages advertising. The Fredericks venture with Dale Barlow & Company will be called FKAP/Barlow Direct.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Park Ave. Limousines Move Into a Bus Stop

title: U.S. LAUDS PEACE BID BY HANOI
description: The State Department said today that comments by Vietnam's Foreign Minister seemed to open the door to progress toward a political settlement of the longstanding Cambodian issue.

title: The Odd Couple in Israel
description: Perhaps Israel's tough divorce laws can protect the painfully arranged marriage of the Labor and Likud blocs. Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir propose not only to share the Prime Ministry for successive terms of 25 months but also to share the cabinet and all responsibility for a catastrophic economic condition, a military morass in Lebanon and a hopeless policy deadlock in the West Bank. Even the bizarre union of Morocco and Libya sounds more promising.

title: Business Coalition Opposes a Tax Increase
description: A coalition of five major business organizations, raising the curtain on its 1985 tax strategy, declared today that raising individual or corporate taxes next year would jeopardize continued expansion of the economy.

title: BROOKLYN'S COLUMBIA ST. IN THE CONDOMINIUM ERA
description: To longtime residents and shopkeepers on and near Columbia Street in southern Brooklyn, the coming of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the 1950's was only the first of two neighborhood calamities.

title: CARRIBEAN SCHOOL BLOCKED IN JERSEY
description: The State Board of Medical Examiners has ruled that the Ross University School of Medicine on the Caribbean island of Dominica may no longer send students to New Jersey hospitals for clinical training.

title: UPSET GASTINEAU MAY MISS GAME
description: Mark Gastineau, describing himself as ''sick'' over his conviction of misdemeanor assault Wednesday, did not attend the Jets' practice today and indicated he might not suit up for Friday's workout or Sunday's game against the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: SAYLES'S 'BROTHER'
description: ''The Brother From Another Planet,'' written, directed and edited by John Sayles, is an extremely low-key comedy about the adventures of a black extraterrestrial - the ''Brother'' of the title - come to earth to escape slavery on Planet X.

title: ;  Surgery for Honeycutt
description: Rick Honeycutt, the Dodger left- hander who has a 10-9 record with a 2.87 earned run average, will undergo surgery to correct an arthritic condition in his left shoulder and will not pitch again this season. Honeycutt will have the tip of the clavicle of his shoulder removed in the operation, which will be performed next Tuesday.

title: Publishers' Group Aids G.O.P. Cause on Coast
description: President Reagan's campaign is using a group of friendly publishers, who call themselves ''Newspaper Friends of Reagan-Bush,'' to provide small-town newspapers with campaign position papers.

title: All About Tugboats
description: The history of the tugboat is the subject of a ''tug weekend'' at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street.

title: TAKE MY NAME OFF MAILING LIST
description: Former Mayor Abraham D. Beame has asked that Mayor Koch's re-election committee stop sending him campaign literature because, Mr. Beame says, Mr. Koch is distorting the truth about the city's brush with bankruptcy.

title: REAGAN'S SENATE ALLIES SURPRISED BY MOVE ON GENOCIDE PACT
description: Senate aides said today that President Reagan's recent endorsement of a United Nations convention outlawing genocide had come as a surprise to his allies on Capitol Hill, who now fear a bruising debate on the Senate floor.

title: 'NO EXCUSES,' FRAZIER SAYS
description: The song does not end because of one wrong note. Marvis Frazier is fighting again.

title: BASS ENDS TALKS FOR ALEXANDER'S
description: Alexander's Inc., the 15-store New York retailer, said yesterday that negotiations on a merger with representatives of the Bass family interests and Interstate Properties had been discontinued. Discussions had been under way since July 30 on a proposed price of $27.75 a share, or a total of about $125 million.

title: POLAND'S GERMANS: PINING FOR GOETHE OR BMW'S?
description: The well tended graves in the cemetery of this former East Prussian hamlet testify to the oscillations of nationalism as the Polish-German border has changed through history.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Home Section yesterday about closet redesign misattributed a mail-order service. The service, in which the customer fills out a ''green sheet'' listing closet dimensions, is offered by the Closet Systems Corporation, 1175 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y. 11557.

title: ;  Ringer in the Ring A title bout in Seoul, South Korea, last week between the International Boxing Federation's flyweight champion,
description: Kwon Sun-Chon, and the Colombian and Latin American flyweight champion, Alberto Castro, has been nullified retroactively by the Korean Boxing Commission. The challenger Kwon knocked out in the 12th round, the commission said, was not Castro but an imposter who now admits his name is Armando Torres.

title: ALMOST-LOST ART OF MAORIS AT MET
description: ''The Maori'' at the Metropolitan Museum is an exhibition of Maori art from New Zealand collections. As such, it is the first show of its kind to be sanctioned by the Maoris, for whom the works in question have an importance that far exceeds even the awe and admiration with which Rembrandt is regarded by the Dutch or Velazquez by the Spaniards. Maori art - and in this context, as will be seen, the word ''art'' can be disputed - is of absolutely primordial importance to the Maori. Not only is it what he values most in his inheritance, but also it could almost be said to be all that survives of his inheritance. It is the sacrament, the energizing force and the hope of continuity.

title: CITY OPERA: PREMIERE OF 'RAKE'S PROGRESS'
description: IN the 33 years since its premiere, Stravinsky's only full-

title: U.S. HOLDS UP STUDY ACCUSING SOVIET ON ARMS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the White House had reversed its position and decided against the early release of a report charging the Soviet Union with numerous violations of arms control treaties.

title: Diner's Journal
description: West 14th Street, where the aroma of sizzling garlic mingles with rapid Spanish, is hardly the place where an authentic French bistro might be expected. However, one has taken root there, a convivial new restaurant called Quatorze, near Eighth Avenue, which has brought a dash of Gallic flair to New York's unofficial Latin Quarter.

title: CAUTION IS URGED ON PACEMAKER USE
description: Implanting a permanent cardiac pacemaker is justified only when heart problems cannot be corrected any other way, say doctors who have developed new guidelines to help prevent the devices from being overused.

title: AFTER A DEATH, FAMILY IS A LIFETIME
description: The clothes have been gathered together for donation to the Salvation Army. Cuff links, tie clips and cologne have been given away. The large brown ashtray remains at one end of the coffee table, where it has been for years. But it will soon be put on a shelf, hidden from view.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Two Columbia Students Vie At Epson Tourney in Japan

title: AUCTIONS
description: A year ago, Audrey Bain, an ebullient 83-year-old widow from Vancouver, British Columbia, embarked on a trip around the world. Among other things, she wanted to be present in Monte Carlo last fall for the auctioning by Sotheby's of five rare pieces of furniture she owned - a 1902 cabinet and four 1904 bedroom pieces, all by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the Glasgow architect.

title: CARTING PLOT IS ALLEGED
description: Twenty-one people have been indicted in what the State Attorney General described today as a conspiracy by organized crime to dominate private garbage collection on Long Island.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY CUOMO AT NOTRE DAME
description: Following are excerpts from the text of an address by Governor Cuomo delivered last night at the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, Ind., on ''Religious Belief and Public Morality: A Catholic Governor's Perspective'':

title: PERES IS PREMIER
description: Parliament approved a Government of national unity early today that includes both the Labor Party and the Likud bloc. Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, then took the oath as Israel's eighth Prime Minister.

title: A POLITICAL RACE WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: In the pack at the starting line this morning, the distinctions of rank, party and branch of Government that normally govern relationships in the capital were blurred if not forgotten.

title: STOCK SLEUTH USES REPORTS
description: ROBERT A. OLSTEIN manages client accounts in the White Plains office of Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc. But when he talks about the stock market, Mr. Olstein does not sound like a typical broker.

title: CHARLES MOORE CELEBRATES A DECADE
description: Charles Moore, a dancer-choreographer who has specialized in reviving works inspired by African and Caribbean dance, is delighted, he says, by what he considers to be a resurgence of interest in black folklore.

title: BRIEF TIMES OF FAMINE
description: Twice in this century the supply of illicit opiates has been almost completely eliminated. But both times the hiatus was brief.

title: THIS ODD COUPLE FOCUSES ON HEALTH
description: The capital's Odd Couple are not the fastidious Felix Unger and the slovenly Oscar Madison in the play by Neil Simon, but rather two members of Congress of opposite ideologies who have joined to win passage of several important health measures.

title: AIR TRAFFIC: KEY QUERIES ABOUT PACT
description: After months of rampant airtraffic delays and, ultimately, pressure from the Government to adjust operations, the nation's airlines tentatively agreed Wednesday on a plan for peak-hour schedule changes designed to ease the congestion.

title: STORM OVER NORTH CAROLINA LOSES ITS FORCE AS IT MOVES INLAND
description: After smashing into the coast early this morning with 100-mile-an-hour winds that ripped the roofs from buildings and demolished a 100,000-gallon city water tower, Hurricane Diana continued to spread torrential rain and high winds inland.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Girl Shot to Death; Suicide Suspected
description: A 15-year-old high school sophomore was found shot to death behind her family's Putnam County home and is believed to have taken her own life, the police said.

title: SCOUTING;
description: On the Ground

title: Why So Fussy About Genocide?
description: Is genocide evil? Of course. Is it also a crime? The survivors of Hitler's Holocaust know it is. So do people who escaped Pol Pot's Cambodian torture chambers. So do those Bahais who have survived Iran's bloody assaults. But because there has been a legal vacuum on the subject, more than 90 nations have joined in a United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. The United States is not among them.

title: An autumn of tribal art.
description: Nearly a century since the first blossoming of modern art - not to mention in the very year that a human first floated untethered in space, that scientists studied cancer-causing human genes, and that home computers swept the land - the New York art world has excitedly embraced the ''primitive'' arts of Africa, Oceania and North America.

title: AIDED ROCKEFELLER PROGRAMS
description: Donald H. McLean Jr., an associate of John D. Rockefeller 3d who contributed to the development of cultural and educational programs in the Far East, died of cancer Wednesday at the Leahy Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Andover.

title: AUTO WORKERS SPLIT OVER JOB SECURITY AND RAISES
description: Recessions and gasoline prices have devastated the domestic automobile industry in the 14 years since Kenneth Phipps walked into Cadillac's big Fleetwood plant, thinking he had found himself a lifetime job. In all that time, Cadillacs kept selling, Mr. Phipps kept working and job security was not something he worried about.

title: Caterpillar Sees Loss in Quarter
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter and for the full year.

title: BACH AND AN ENSEMBLE CO-CELEBRATE
description: The concert season has barely begun, and it's already dominated by celebrations of Bach's impending tercentenary. This weekend, as the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center winds down its mini-festival of Bach, the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is starting its own. And more are to follow.

title: Benton & Bowles Gets Big Ericsson Package
description: Benton & Bowles has been hired by Ericsson Inc. for a complete communications program: advertising, public relations, direct mail - the works. And, according to David Kreinik, account director at the agency, B.& B. will be conpensated with a fee based on spending of $16 million.

title: Lord Geoffrey-Lloyd; Ex-Tory Cabinet Aide
description: Lord Geoffrey-Lloyd, a former Conservative Cabinet minister, died Wednesday at his home in London. He was 82 years old.

title: PAGEL TESTS CARDINAL DEFENSE
description: For all their travails in recent years, the Colts had always been a solid running team. Last season, with Curtis Dickey's 1,122 yards and Randy McMillan's 802, they finished as the second-best rushing team in the National Football League, which was more reason than any other why they improved to a 7-9 record.

title: 3 Races Draw Top Horses
description: The top older horse, 3-year-old and 2-year-old in training will compete tomorrow in major races at Belmont Park and Meadowlands Race Track.

title: No Headline
description: City Inspector Guilty O

title: THE PENTAGON'S MESSAGE TO THE CHEATERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis Far From Over, Argentine Chief Warns
description: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina said today that Latin America's debt crisis was far from over. He warned that debt defaults in the region had been avoided only by impoverishing its inhabitants.

title: Aboard the Zoo Plane
description: As Presidential campaigns have been doing for some years now, the Mondale organization charges reporters, technicians and Secret Service agents one and a half times first-class airline fare for their seats on the candidate's plane. Actually, there are two chartered planes: one for the candidate, top staff members and a representative of each major news organization; the second, known as the ''zoo plane'' for its housekeeping standards, carries the overflow of reporters, lesser staff and photographers and television crews.

title: FORMER JACKSON AIDE INDICTED
description: A Cuyahoga County Grand Jury today indicted Arnold R. Pinkney, former manager for the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, on four counts of having an unlawful interest in a public contract.

title: BUSTER POINDEXTER, A FAMILIAR FACE AT TRAMPS
description: The urbane vocalist who was perched on a barstool at Tramps the other day, dressed in the tuxedo and black bow tie that are regulation garb for saloon singers,

title: BRIEFS
description: * Angstrom Technologies Inc. of Cincinnati told the S.E.C. that it had increased its holdings in Sperti Drug Products Inc. common stock to 347,471 shares, or 35.3 percent.

title: ELDERLY CHEER A FERRARO BACKER, 22
description: Donna Zaccaro, the 22-year-old daughter of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and John A. Zaccaro, made her public speaking debut for the Presidential campaign yesterday before an enthusiastic crowd of elderly people in Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan to protest cuts in their health care services.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: JOE MORTON speaks. In real life, that is. What might seem obvious in most instances is worth stating in this one, because Mr. Morton, in the title role in ''The Brother From Another Planet,'' the new John Sayles movie opening today at the Embassy 72d Street, does not utter a single word.

title: URANIUM SALVAGED FROM SHIP
description: Salvage crews retrieved the first of 30 containers of radioactive material today from the torn hull of a French freighter that sank 19 days ago in the North Sea, officials said.

title: ADM. GLENN DAVIS, WAR HERO
description: Glenn B. Davis Sr., a retired Navy vice admiral who won the Navy Cross as a battleship commander in the battle for Guadalcanal in World War II, died Sunday at the Hilton Head Hospital in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 92 years old and lived in Hilton Head.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Montreal Wednesday on the visit of Pope John Paul II gave an incorrect birthdate for Sister Marie-Leonie Paradis, who was beatified in a ceremony presided over by the Pope. She was born in 1840.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday GINSBERG MEETS VIDEO

title: INDIAN LEADER, 9 YEARS A FUGITIVE, SURRENDERS FOR JAIL TERM IN DAKOTA
description: Dennis Banks, a founder of the American Indian Movement, surrendered to state and local law-enforcement officials here this morning, even though he said that he feared for his life if he was sent to a state prison.

title: Pact Reached With U.S. On Michigan Waste
description: The Justice Department has reached an agreement with 87 defendants, including the General Motors Corporation, to pay more than $14 million in cleanup costs at a hazardous waste site in Michigan.

title: Spin the Cabinet
description: At President Reagan's seat in the Cabinet Room of the White House for several weeks has been a handy device given him by an admirer. At first blush it appears to be a decision maker: a small, four- sided wooden sign that rotates and, when spun, comes up ''Yes,'' ''No,'' ''Maybe'' or ''Scram.''

title: HBM/Creamer Client
description: HBM/Creamer is hitting the books. Specifically, those of the New American Library, a new client that it expects to spend about $2 million for advertising. The previous agency was Marsteller, a Young & Rubicam subsidiary, which got the assignment in 1981.

title: C.A.B. Backs Midway Merger
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board granted Midway Airlines a one-year exemption from the C.A.B.'s merger procedures, clearing the way for Midway's acquisition of Air Florida.

title: No Headline
description: G.O.P. Fails to Block Cuomo's Voter Drive

title: RESTAURANTS;
description: From Trastevere to restaurant row.

title: LINCOLN WEST IS GIVEN MORE TIME
description: The deadline for final approval of an agreement between the Koch administration and the developers of Lincoln West on how the street system would be developed in the project was extended last night by the Board of Estimate.

title: METS ARE BOOED DURING BAD LOSS
description: The cheering turned to booing in Shea Stadium yesterday as the Pittsburgh Pirates, struck out and shut out by Dwight Gooden the night before, rose up and devastated the Mets, 14-4.

title: SmithKline Bid For Hydron
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation and the National Patent Development Corporation said they had reached a preliminary agreement for SmithKline to acquire the International Hydron Corporation for about $160 million.

title: THE FOOD IS FAST AND THE SETTINGS ARE SNAPPY
description: Many people walking by can't seem to resist pressing their faces against the glass and peering into the bright open space of Blue Plate, a new restaurant at 150 Eighth Avenue between 17th and 18th Streets. Neat rows of turquoise and black chairs are tucked under long cafeteria-style tables. An eye-catching clock hangs on the wall and people in T-shirts stand behind a stainless-steel counter making sandwiches and salads.

title: Museum Highlights And Weekend Events
description: TSome new exhibitions in the city's museums this weekend:

title: Itzik Manger Songfest
description: A one-man musical tribute to the Yiddish poet and balladeer Itzik Manger will be presented by Avi Hoffman tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Rockland Center for the Arts, 27 South Greenbush Road in West Nyack. Mr. Hoffman will give the narration in English and perform the songs in Yiddish. Tickets are $5.50; $4.50 for students and the elderly. Information: (914) 358-0877.

title: LIFT FOR AIRBUS FROM PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways, which has lost more than $650 million in the last three years, announced yesterday that it would spend more than $1 billion to acquire or lease a total of 28 wide-body and standard-body passenger jetliners from Airbus Industrie between 1987 and 1990.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY Tofu on the Mind
description: Some might say David Mintz, the Brooklyn man who invented the nondairy frozen dessert known as Tofutti, is obsessed with tofu.

title: U.S. PUTS EMBARGO ON FLORIDA CITRUS
description: The Federal Government, reacting to an outbreak of destructive citrus canker, today halted all shipment of citrus from Florida, and experts considered burning thousands of trees in more than 40 nurseries to stop the spread of the highly contagious bacterial plant disease.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, beset with financial problems stemming from the nuclear power plant at Shoreham, is offering $100 million of 17 1/2 percent general and refunding bonds due in 1989 and priced at par. The underwriters are led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1984 International A Government of national unity based on power sharing by the two major political groups, the Labor Party and the Likud bloc, was approved by Israel's Parliament. Shimon Peres then took the oath as Israel's eighth Prime Minister. (Page A1, Col. 6.) A U.S. report accusing Moscow of arms treaty violations will not be released soon, according to Reagan Administration officials. One official said the delay was ordered by the White House at least until after Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko meets with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz at the White House on Sept. 28. (A1:5.)

title: FILM: 'FAMILY GAME,' FROM JAPAN
description: ''The Family Game'' was shown as part of this year's ''New Directors/ New Films'' series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 1. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway, between 62d and 63d Streets.

title: SANDINISTAS AREN'T THE WORST
description: The Reagan Administration has spent more than $1 billion to prop up the Salvadoran Government and $150 million to overthrow the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. A comparison of the human rights records of both countries raises serious questions about this choice of friends and enemies.

title: 2 TOP OFFICERS CHOSEN
description: Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells indicated yesterday that they were close to a tentative merger accord by announcing the top management lineup and the name that would be used in a combination of the two Big Eight accounting firms.

title: A COLONEL'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: EGYPT SAYS EFFORT TO CLEAR MINES IS EXPECTED TO END THIS MONTH
description: Egypt said today that the multinational search for mines that damaged 18 ships this summer in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Suez would end this month. No mines have been found.

title: SALE OF HOWARD JOHNSON CONSIDERED BY IMPERIAL
description: The Imperial Group, a British tobacco and food conglomerate, confirmed yesterday that it was considering selling the Howard Johnson Company. Imperial acquired the American hotel and restaurant chain in 1980 and has been having financial problems with it ever since.

title: CUOMO VS. BISHOPS
description: Governor Cuomo's lecture here tonight, with its insistence that Roman Catholics in public office are bound by the church's moral dogma but are free to decide the applicability of these teachings to civil law, places him squarely at odds with many bishops, especially on the issue of abortion. It set forth a sharp distinction between the authority of the Catholic hierarchy and the duties of a Catholic politician.

title: A Wheelchair Olympics
description: A day of competitive wheelchair sports is scheduled tonight and tomorrow on Main Street on Roosevelt Island, with athletes from the three-state area taking part.

title: PARSONS MAY GO PRIVATE IN A $550 MILLION DEAL
description: The Parsons Corporation, a worldwide construction and engineering company, reported yesterday that it was studying a plan that would in effect take the company private in a transaction with an indicated value of about $550 million.

title: RAISE MINIMUM TAXES TO COMBAT DEFICITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilford Picks Chief Of Finance
description: Daniel O. Anderson has been named chief financial officer at Guilford Transportation Industries, the privately held railroad holding company that earlier this week lost out in the bidding for Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad system.

title: Dancer Executive To Head California Unit
description: James H. Lindsey, 51 years old, executive vice president of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample and management director of the Toyota account, will be going west Oct. 1 to become chairman of DFS/ Southern California in Torrance, previously an unfilled position.

title: ;  Insanity Verdict
description: Bruce Curry, the former champion who had been charged with firing a shot at his trainer in Las Vegas a few days after losing the World Boxing Council superlightweight title last January, was adjudged not guilty by reason of insanity and ordered sent to a state psychiatric hospital. Both the defense and the prosecution agreed to the verdict, which was based on two psychiatric reports and the testimony of Curry's former trainer, Jesse Reid, at a preliminary hearing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;
description: Knowing the Ins and Outs, Or a Lesson in Street Savvy

title: JUDGE PENALIZES BURNING TREE CLUB
description: A county judge declined today to rule that the Burning Tree Club, the "club of the Presidents," must admit women. But she said that because it does not do so, it must lose a $186,000-a-year real estate tax exemption.

title: The Urge to Tell
description: The original Administration plan

title: 2 More Priests Reported Seized in the Sudan
description: An official of a missionary order said today that two Roman Catholic priests - a Briton and a Sudanese - had been kidnapped by anti-Government guerrillas in the southern Sudan, in addition to the abduction of an American priest that was reported earlier.

title: FRIENDS TELL OF TRIAL OF SAKHAROV'S WIFE
description: Friends of Andrei D. Sakharov confirmed today that the physicist's wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had been sentenced to five years of internal exile on a charge of anti-Soviet slander. They said they assumed that she was appealing the sentence.

title: Sept. 1-10 Sales of New Cars Up 29.7%
description: The major American automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars in the first 10 days of September rose 29.7 percent from the same period last year, on a daily rate basis. The average daily selling rate of 21,463 was the highest since 1979. The rate last year was 16,542, when sales were restrained by low inventory.

title: SYRIA TALKS BIG
description: He even scolded the Germans for no longer living up to their military history, praising Hitler's generals and wishing for the nation's full restoration, ''not only East and West, but with Austria, parts of Switzerland, wherever German is spoken.''

title: Accord Reached on Abuse Bill
description: Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation to assist states in treating and preventing child abuse and encouraging adoption of children with special needs.

title: Federal Reserve
description: All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Sept. 3 216,200 R 215,300 n.a. Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Sept. 12 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) 23 (8) n.a. Borrowings at Federal Reserve 0 0 n.a. Net Federal Funds Purchases 12,203 R 9,192 n.a. Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit) (12,180)R (9,200)n.a. Federal Reserve Credit Daily averages, week ended Sept. 12 Gov'ts. and Agencies Held Outright 160,689 157,309 153,472 Gov'ts. and Agencies Under Repurchase 991 4,326 642 Float 694 373 1,603 Other Assets 8,410 8,2197,745 Other Factors Affecting Reserves Daily averages, week ended Sept. 12 Gold Stock 11,098 R 11,098 11,128 Special Drawing Rights 4,618 4,618 4,618 Currency in Circulation 177,512 R 177,057164,422 Treasury Deposits 3,933 4,140 3,438 Other Items Gov't.

title: Western Air Pact
description: Western Airlines said its largest union, the Air Transport Employees Union, had approved a new labor agreement that calls for workers to take a 12 1/2 percent pay cut. That reduction is in addition to a 10 percent decrease already in effect.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON SANCTIONS IN IMMIGRATION BILL
description: House and Senate conferees began negotiations today on a comprehensive immigration bill and promptly agreed to authorize punishment for employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens.

title: SUNDAY ON 5TH AVE. A HALF-MILE CELEBRATION OF BOOKS
description: For people who want to bid on a wooden hanger that once belonged to Ernest Hemingway, dance the hula, learn how to ''crime-proof'' a home, buy a rare book, get advice on how to get a book published, watch a fitness demonstration for children, fill in a giant crossword puzzle, meet Snoopy or Garfield, vote on who's cuter - the Mayor or the Governor - the sixth ''New York Is Book Country'' fair is the place to go.

title: A VISA-MASTERCARD PACT TO REDUCE DUPLICATION
description: The Visa and Mastercard credit organizations, which are owned by the banks that issue their cards, have agreed on some first steps in cooperation to cut down on duplication.

title: Money Fund Assets Climb
description: Assets of the nation's 335 money market mutual funds rose to their highest level in 18 months, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: ST. PETER'S SAYS COACH PADDED ROSTER
description: John Inman, a St. Peter's College offensive tackle who collapsed after the 72-0 opening game loss to Catholic University last Friday night, had apparently withheld information from St. Peter's about a head injury he suffered last season when playing for Hampton Institute in Virginia. Inman was admitted to the intensive care unit at Christ Hospital in Jersey City suffering from seizures, but his conditioned has since improved.

title: 275TH YEAR CELEBRATED BY TRINTIY
description: Trinity School - the oldest continuously operating school in the city - celebrated its 275th anniversary yesterday, busing 750 students and 110 teachers to a special convocation at Trinity Church on Wall Street, the original site of the school.

title: FINDINGS ON MEESE SUBMITTED TO JUDGES BY SPECIAL COUNSEL
description: Jacob A. Stein, the independent counsel who has been investigating allegations of wrongdoing on the part of Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counsel, submitted his final report Wednesday to the three- judge panel that appointed him to conduct the inquiry.

title: FOREIGN FUNDS HELP ON DEFICIT
description: DESPITE the record trade deficit, which this year is likely to exceed $130 billion, the United States dollar continues to climb, as foreign capital floods into this country.

title: Corporate Bonds
description: * Ohio Edison Co. has offered $150 million of first mortgage bonds, due in 1994, at 15 3/4 percent through Morgan Stanley.

title: WEAPONS IN SPACE
description: Walter Mondale is ready to enter a moratorium on the testing of new space weapons but the Reagan Administration still refuses to do so. Secretary of State Shultz now says he'd be willing to talk about it, if arms control negotiations were resumed, but that only suggests that the Administration still is determined to test an anti-satellite (ASAT) weapon this fall.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; 2 Communists on Coast Lose Suit to Be on Ballot
description: The State Supreme Court has refused to order the names of the Communist Party's Presidential candidate, Gus Hall, and its Vice-Presidential candidate, Angela Davis, placed on the California ballot as an independent ticket.

title: Suits Challenge College TV Pacts
description: The Association of Independent Television Stations Inc. filed two suits today aimed at opening the college football television market by allowing local stations greater freedom to broadcast games of local interest.

title: 'DEATH WATCH'
description: Bertrand Tavernier's 1979 ''Death Watch,'' which opens today at the Thalia on a double bill with Jean-Luc Godard's ''Alphaville,'' is a muted science fiction melodrama that doesn't work very well either as science fiction or as melodrama. It may be that it's too intelligent for its own good.

title: CANADIAN POWER WILL LOWER NORTHEAST'S BILLS
description: This morning at the La Grande 2 hydroelectric plant here, enough water was bypassing idle turbines and flowing over the spillway to have produced 1,600 megawatts. Utilities in New York or New England would pay $80,000 or more an hour for that amount of power on a hot summer afternoon.

title: Boycott of Food Chain By N.A.A.C.P. Is Ended By The Associated Press
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ended a nine-week boycott of a supermarket chain after the stores agreed to increase economic opportunities for blacks.

title: Poll Finds G.O.P. Lead Over Democrats Grows
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush hold a lead of 15 percentage points over Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, according to the latest Gallup Poll. The findings are parallel to a poll by ABC News and The Washington Post that were announced Wednesday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE REGION ; ;  Murderer Admits Slaying 2 Others
description: Richard Biegenwald, who was convicted of murder last year and sentenced to death by lethal injection, pleaded guilty today to two murders for which he was to be tried this month.

title: SIGNAL'S SEARCH FOR A BIG DEAL
description: As a conglomerate with $6 billion in sales, the Signal Companies is always on the lookout for acquisitions to complement its bevy of high-technology, engineering and industrial subsidiaries. But these days Signal is scouting for more than just the routine acquisition. It aims to pick up a company nearly as big as it is, if not bigger, and to do it sometime in the next six months.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; USA Today Names A New President
description: Lee J. Guittar, chairman and chief executive of The Dallas Times Herald since 1980, has resigned to become president of USA Today, the Gannett Company's national newspaper. The appointment is effective Oct. 1.

title: PUBLISHING: HELPING AUTHORS OUT OF ROYALITIES FOG
description: Acting on the complaints of authors and authors' agents that they find royalty statements indecipherable, the Independent Literary Agents Association will help subsidize the authors' costs of examining the account books of publishers. ''It is hoped that the program will help authors to receive timely, complete and accurate accountings from publishers,'' the association stated in a recent news release.

title: Mexican Crafts on View
description: Several hundred Mexican artifacts from the early 1930's to the 1970's will be on view through Oct. 21 at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street.

title: 9 DIE AS INDONESIAN POLICE BATTLE MOSLEM RIOTERS
description: At least 9 people have been killed and 53 wounded here in clashes between soldiers and militant Moslems, officials said today.

title: THE MIGHTY MCINTOSH IS READY FOR PICKING
description: Today is the official opening day in New York State for growers and visitors alike to pick McIntosh apples, the state's major variety. McIntoshes are also ripe and ready for eating in New Jersey and Connecticut, with orchards welcoming visitors.

title: HISPANICS, BY THE NUMBERS
description: Who are the nation's 14.6 million Hispanics? Hardly as monolithic a group as many would believe, according to William Diaz of the Ford Foundation in a recent report.

title: FILM: 'SOLDIER'S STORY'
description: Combining mystery, history, sociology and inquiry into the psychopathology of hatred and the poison of accommodation to injustice, Charles Fuller's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Soldier's Play'' has been translated to the screen under the title ''A Soldier's Story.''

title: A SAN GENNARO EAT-OUT AND A FAIR ON UPPER 3D
description: Take 100,000 pounds of sausage, sweet or hot; 133,332 green peppers, cut in eighths, and 133,332 medium onions, sliced. Cook according to Mike Acquavella's recipe, adding oil, salt and pepper to taste, and serve on 66,666 loaves of Italian bread.

title: Graham Tells Estonia Reagan Didn't Mean It
description: The Rev. Billy Graham said today that President Reagan sincerely wants peace, in spite of what Soviet citizens think of Mr. Reagan's quip about bombing the Soviet Union. He called the quip ''unfortunate.''

title: Norcen to Sell Unit
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. said it had agreed to sell its gas utility division, the Northern and Central Gas Corporation, to the Inter-City Gas Corporation for $240 million - $163 million in cash and $77 million of Inter-City first preference shares.

title: 6 SOUTH AFRICAN FUGITIVES ENTER BRITISH CONSULATE
description: Six prominent South African political fugitives who have been in hiding since Saturday took refuge today in the British Consulate here to press demands for their freedom.

title: PHOTOS OF IRVING PENN: SUBLIME TOTHE PERVERSE
description: The distinction we customarily make between what we call art and what we call salesmanship does not apply to the photography of Irving Penn. His is an art that sells - that is, if we consider only those gorgeous still lifes of makeup and fashion accessories that he regularly turns out for the pages of Vogue.

title: ACTOR AS PRESIDENT: HALF-HOUR COMMERCIAL WRAPS HIM IN ADVERTISING'S BEST
description: In the midst of a half-hour of American good feeling and praise for Ronald Reagan that the Republican campaign aired on television this week, there was one woman who looked into the camera with a sun-struck conviction and summed up the impression that is the strength of the Reagan Presidency, and the way the President creates it.

title: Frigitronic Stock Plunges on Sale
description: Frigitronics Inc.'s stock plunged after it disclosed that Cooper Laboratories Inc. had notified it that Cooper had sold its stake in Frigitronics.

title: CITY SAYS IT MAY END CONTRACT TALKS
description: The Koch administration told representatives of 200,000 municipal employees yesterday that it was considering ending negotiations over a new contract and submitting the matter to an arbitrator. A union leader called the idea ''assinine.''

title: LIBERATION THEOLOGY, NORTH AMERICAN STYLE
description: To the Editor: The Vatican's pressure upon cer

title: Photo of Owen Bieber (page A14); AUTO UNION FACES MIDNIGHT DEADLINE IN TALKS WITH G.M.
description: Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers worked tonight against a deadline of midnight Friday to reach agreement on a new labor contract to replace the concessions of 1982.

title: 'SWANN IN LOVE,' A PROUSTIAN VIGNETTE FROM FRANCE
description: ''Swann In Love'' is Volker Schl"ondorff's small, prettily decorated, unrevealing fragment lifted - gently and with all due respect - from Marcel Proust's monumental, seven-volume ''Remembrance of Things Past.''

title: BRINK OF INCOMPETENCE FOR POLICE OFFICERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ;  Devils Sign Muller
description: Kirk Muller, the 18-year-old center who was New Jersey's first selection in the National Hockey League draft last June and the second player chosen over all, was signed by the Devils to a two-year contract after Muller had missed the opening day of the Devils' rookie camp. No financial details were disclosed. Muller, who scored 31 goals and 63 assists in 49 games for his junior team in Canada last season, was a member of the 1984 Canadian Olympic team. . . . Greg Gilbert, an Islander left wing, and Kelly Hrudey, a backup goalie, signed multiyear contracts.

title: ANTUOFERMO A WINNER
description: Vito Antuofermo, who did not forget how to cut in three years of retirement, returned to the ring tonight and scored a five-round split decision over Richard Beranek in a blood-splattered bout scheduled for 10 rounds at Resorts International.

title: U.S.F.L. Cautions Rival on Fall Shift
description: Commissioner Chet Simmons of the United States Football League sent a letter yesterday to Pete Rozelle, his National Football League counterpart, in which he cautioned against interference with the U.S.F.L.'s move to a fall schedule in 1986.

title: HARRIS SEEKING AWARENESS
description: THE hope was that when Joseph

title: House Panel Trade Accord
description: A House trade subcommittee agreed today to a 10-year renewal of preferential trade treatment allowing 3,000 products from 140 developing countries to enter the United States duty free.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Playing the Bear

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAS 2D GAME
description: Gary Kasparov tried to work his attacking magic on the world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, in the second game of their title match in Moscow, but strong defensive play by the champion brought the game to a draw in 47 moves yesterday.

title: AID TO REMOVE SCHOOL ASBESTOS VOTED IN JERSEY
description: The State Senate today gave final legislative approval to a bill that provides $40 million in aid to local school districts for the removal of asbestos in public schools.

title: NICARAGUAN PREDICTS A 'CRISIS' IF SANDINISTAS STAY IN POWER
description: A Nicaraguan opposition leader returned from a five-nation tour of Latin America today and predicted that if the Sandinista Government stayed in power ''our country will have to face a crisis with all Central America.''

title: WEAPON'S QUALITY CONCERNS MILITARY
description: Top Pentagon armament buyers told a special Congressional panel on military procurement today that more attention needed to be paid to workmanship and quality control on weapons.

title: NEW YORK AREA MAY GET RAIN
description: The New York metropolitan area will probably feel a touch of Hurricane Diana today and tomorrow in the form of showers.

title: THE WAR ON NARCOTICS: CAN IT BE WON?
description: Some people doubt that the world can ever solve the problem of illicit drug production. For a century, drug traffickers have outwitted or evaded almost every drug-control strategy tried.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES FOR DEFICIT CURB
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a proposed amendment to the Constitution requiring a balanced Federal budget and sent it to the Senate floor. The vote was 11 to 4.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 14, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Liver Ailment Cited in Capote's Death
description: Truman Capote died from liver disease complicated by phlebitis and multiple drug intoxication, but not from a drug overdose, coroner's officials said today.

title: Murdoch Group Tie To Elle Magazine
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Group Publications will be picking up with Hachette's Elle magazine where The New Yorker left off and will have a greatly expanded role.

title: THE 2-TIERED WAGE SYSTEM IS DAMAGING
description: The two-tiered wage system is becoming a popular item on the agendas of United States corporations in collective-bargaining negotiations. Under this invidious scheme, which should be staunchly resisted by unions, companies typically pay new employees as much as 50 percent less than current employees - even though the new employees will perform the same jobs.

title: THEATER: 'TIME OF NERO AND SENECA' FROM SOVIET
description: WATCHING a drama in English by a popular Russian playwright who is living in the Soviet Union and whose work is regularly produced there, an American theatergoer looks for the parable - either an approved message or a hidden rock in the sock. That is probably unfair to the playwright, but we are so accustomed to dissident writing by exiles that a drama of Soviet origin produced here inevitably comes with a caveat.

title: ;  Standing Tall When it comes to dunk shots, the standard procedure for most basketball players is to jump high before stuffing the ball into the hoop.
description: Manute Bol, the University of Bridgeport's new center, has his own style. He simply stands flatfooted under the basket and reaches up.

title: Iraq Says It Sank Another Vessel in Gulf
description: Iraq reported another attack on shipping in the Persian Gulf today, apparently in a drive to tighten its blockade of Iran's oil terminal at Kharg Island.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Catholic public official lives the political truth most Catholics through most of American history have accepted and insisted on: the truth that to assure our freedom we must allow others the same freedom, even if occasionally it produces conduct by them which we would hold to be sinful.

title: Angels 7, Indians 3
description: Fred Lynn drove in four runs with two homers and scored another run as California moved to within a game and a half of the American League West co-leaders, Minnesota and Kansas City. All three teams have the same number of defeats, 71.

title: Free Jazz in Chelsea
description: Four jazz musicians who live in Chelsea - the pianist Andy Laverne, the guitarist Jack Wilkins, the bassist Rick Laird and the drummer Warren Smith - will play a free concert tomorrow as part of Chelsea Fest '84 (929-5733). The concert will take place at 8 P.M. at Seabury Hall of the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, at 20th Street.

title: REAGAN PLAYS HIS CAMPAIGN SONG AT COUNTRY MUSIC'S CAPITAL
description: The President paid homage to the King today as Ronald Reagan campaigned from the stage of the Grand Ole Opry by praising the life and lyrics of Roy Acuff, the South's venerable country singer.

title: BROADWAY;
description: A 3-act theater tale that's ending with a curtain going up.

title: Hanoi Reports Shelling
description: The Vietnamese radio said today that China fired 3,300 artillery shells into Ha Tuyen Province in the first 10 days of September. The broadcast, monitored here, said there had also been 10 company-size incursions of Chinese troops. There have been intermittent reports of clashes since a Chinese- Vietnamese border war in early 1979.

title: What's in a Name?
description: The gentle pressure of gentrification has persuaded Don't Tear

title: POPE, IN CANADA, MEETS POLISH SAILORS
description: Pope John Paul II, on the fifth day of his pilgrimage to Canada, held an impromptu meeting today with a group of Polish sailors and called attention to the plight of the Roman Catholic Church in his homeland.

title: DOGMA ABOUT THE FETUS
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING;
description: Gooden Basking In Good Wishes

title: CUOMO BIDS CATHOLICS PERSUADE BY EXAMPLE, NOT IMPOSE VIEWS
description: Governor Cuomo of New York, in a broad discussion of his views on religious belief and public morality, said tonight that Roman Catholics should practice their religion by setting an example for other Americans, not by seeking to pass laws that impose their views on the rest of the country.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Joe Cowley, the minor-leaguer who languished in the Braves' system before being rescued by the Yankees, tries to improve his 7-1 record.

title: THE CITY ; ;  28 Are Arrested In Cocaine Raids
description: Police officers raiding two businesses in Brooklyn arrested 28 people on drug charges and confiscated $150,000 worth of cocaine, seven guns and $10,000 cash.

title: Hunting in the Not Quite Wild
description: City dwellers with a yen to go upland bird hunting often don't have the time or the knowledge to ferret out productive locations. The next-best approach might be to visit a reputable commercial shooting preserve.

title: RATES DROP ON MONEY SUPPLY FALL
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, with most of the decline coming late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced a suprisingly large drop in the nation's basic money supply.

title: FONTENOT DEFEATS BLUE JAYS
description: Early tonight, before it could ruin him, Ray Fontenot stopped throwing the best pitch he has - the sinker pointed outside. But he abandoned it only for a time. When he returned to it, the Toronto Blue Jays were unsuspecting and they chased it where they could not possibly make contact, below their knees and beyond the reach of their swings.

title: Nigerian's Band Due
description: Femi Nana Anikulapo Kuti, son of the dissident Nigerian songwriter Fela Anikulapo Kuti, will lead his father's 13-piece band, Egypt '80, tonight at 11 P.M. at Pizza a Go Go (736- 2352), 121 West 31st Street. Tickets are $10.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES ; ; Headen Looks Both Ways
description: In the 60th season of the New York

title: PENN YAN, N.Y. - IT'S KASHA COUNTRY
description: On Delancey Street, 206 miles southeast of here, Wolff's kasha has been served at Ratner's Dairy Restaurant since 1905. Wolff's is also a pretty big item at the Kiev over on Second Avenue. And it's a brisk seller as well in Israel, Germany, France and Sweden.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart yesterday with an article on worldwide efforts to reduce drug cultivation misstated the production of opium gum in Mexico. According the Drug Enforcement Administration, average Mexican production was 16 tons in 1981 and 17 in both 1982 and 1983.

title: Canada Upsets Soviet
description: Paul Coffey let fly a long slap shot that deflected off Mike Bossy's shoulder and into the net at 12 minutes 29 seconds of overtime tonight to give Team Canada a 3-2 upset of the Soviet Union, the defending Olympic champion, in the Canada Cup semifinals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Mall Openers in Brooklyn

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NATURE OF THE CHILD. By Jerome Kagan. 309 pages. Basic Books.

title: Nigeria and Britain Agree to Seek Better Ties
description: Britain and Nigeria agreed today to work toward improving relations, which have been strained since the kidnapping two months ago of Umaru Dikko, an exiled Nigerian politician.

title: COPS-IN-HAWAII SERIES; KIDDIES VS. '60 MINUTES'
description: The new season shifts into high gear this weekend with series premieres and a first- run made-for-television movie.

title: SHIFT SEEN IN MAKEUP OF ECU
description: European Common Market finance ministers are expected to agree to changes in the composition of their currency unit, known as the ECU, at a meeting in Ireland this weekend, according to European monetary officials and bankers.

title: Johnston-G.E. Tie
description: Jim Johnston Advertising has gotten a business-to-business advertising assignment from the General Electric Company in Fairfield, Conn., Bart Snider, a program manager in corporate marketing, confirmed yesterday. He said that the assignment, formerly at Chiat/Day, had already resulted in ads in The Wall Street Journal, and other ads are expected in business publications and daily newspapers.

title: DOW JUMPS BY 27.94, TO 1,228.25
description: Wall Street's mood turned to exhilaration yesterday, as stock prices surged. The Dow Jones industrial average, which is composed of 30 major issues, jumped 27.94 points, to 1,228.25 - its largest gain since advancing the identical amount on Aug. 9.

title: Hey, Big Spender!
description: If what he's willing to pay for military parts is any guide, Uncle Sam must be the kind of guy who lights his cigars with dollar bills. According to the nonprofit Project on Military Procurement, which hears from anonymous Government whistle- blowers, Uncle has been ponying up $170.98 for a $25 flashlight, forking over $74,165 for an aluminum ladder and doesn't even blink at paying $17.69 for a 67- cent bolt.

title: ;  Lendl Called Home
description: Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, has withdrawn from the Transamerica Open in San Francisco next week after being summoned home by Czechoslovak tennis authorities to practice for a Davis Cup match against Sweden. 28. The action, which infuriated Transamerica officials and could lead to a fine against Lendl, came after the cup match was switched from a fast, indoor surface similar to the Transamerica courts to a slower, outdoor surface. Lendl had planned to play in both tournaments.

title: International
description: Post at D.D.B.

title: DEMOCRACY IS SPREADING IN LATIN AMERICA
description: Over the last five years, elected civilian presidents have replaced military rulers in Argentina, Bolivia, Ecuador, El Salvador, Honduras, Panama and Peru. With Brazil, as well as Uruguay, Guatemala and Grenada also moving toward greater democracy, more than 90 per cent of the peoples of Latin America and the Caribbean live in countries with governments that are democratic or heading toward democracy. For a part of the world often identified with dictatorship, this is something to cheer about.

title: TOWNSPEOPLE 10,001 AND SALAMANDERS 0
description: The 300 residents of this small town in central North Dakota have turned back a horde of salamanders.

title: PHOTOGENIC FETE FOR MODERN MASTER
description: On Wednesday night the fashion legends came out, and some of them hugged each other. Richard Avedon hugged Lisa Fonssagrives-Penn. David Hockney hugged Duane Michals. The former Vogue models Jean Patchett and Dorian Leigh strode past each other. And Polly Mellen, the fashion editor of Vogue, wearing an enormous rhinestone choker, walked straight up to Irving Penn and kissed him.

title: Harnett T. Kane, 73, Author Of Books About the South
description: Harnett T. Kane, author of ''Louisiana Hay Ride'' and 25 other books of fiction and nonfiction, died in his native New Orleans on Sept. 4. He was 73 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's Disease for the past 17 years.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Circuit Research Labs Inc. , Tempe, Ariz., has appointed Bernard M. Van Benthem president, succeeding Ron Jones, who continues as chairman.

title: MONDALE DEFENDS HIMSELF ON RELIGION ISSUE IN SOUTH
description: His face damp with sweat, his voice faintly tremulous, Walter F. Mondale today told an audience that included noisy hecklers that politicians should keep their ''nose out of religion.''

title: U.S. AND EUROPE IN STEEL CURB TALKS
description: The United States and the European Economic Community are discussing limits on shipments of steel pipe and tube to the United States as part of a protection plan that President Reagan may announce next week.

title: Transactions
description: Announced that Rick Honeycutt, pitcher, would undergo surgery to correct an arthritic condition in his left shoulder. BASKETBALL SAN ANTONIO (NBA) - Matched the offer sheet tendered by the Houston Rockets for John Lucas, veteran guard.

title: SENATE PASSES MEASURE TO DEREGULATE BANKING
description: The Senate late tonight overwhelmingly approved major banking deregulation legislation that would give banks broad new powers to expand into other financial services. Passage came after six days of debate and protracted attempts by opponents to derail the measure.

title: Crazy Eddie Sells Common to Public
description: Crazy Eddie Inc. began an initial public offering of 2 million common shares at $8 a share through underwriters led by Oppenheimer & Company.

title: Recovering Mine Dead Slowed by New Threat
description: Recovery teams today found the last of four bodies of coal miners killed when a slab of rock fell on them, but the workers had to run for safety when loose rock began falling around them.

title: NEW YORK STATE VS. ITS DISABLED WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dade Thrift Unit Issuing Preferred
description: A subsidiary of the Dade Savings and Loan Association, Miami, is offering 2.2 million shares of adjustable-rate preferred stock at $50 a share through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The size of the issue was reduced from 2.5 million shares.

title: Mehta Shifts Position On Performing in India
description: Zubin Mehta, denied permission to tour his homeland with the Israeli Philharmonic six years ago, said today that he would bring the Israeli orchestra to India if the Government agreed.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RITE: OLD LEADER, NEW POWERS
description: P. W. Botha was sworn into office today as South Africa's first President under a new Constitution that gives him potentially authoritarian powers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: From Rome to Pace

title: ;  Davis Team Named
description: John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors, Peter Fleming and Aaron Krickstein have been named to the United States Davis Cup team for a semifinal match against Australia in Portland, Ore., beginning Sept. 28.

title: SCOUTING;
description: The Road Back

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Elizabeth S. Nicholson Weds in San Francisco
description: Elizabeth Stokes Nicholson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Nicholson 3d of Moorestown, N.J., and Castine, Me., was married in San Francisco yesterday to John Wesley MacMorris 3d, the son of Mr. MacMorris Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Katherine Rourke MacMorris. title: BY THE NUMBERS
description: There has never been a season-ending three-way tie for first place in the history of major league baseball. But the American League will deal next week with the possibility that the California Angels, the Kansas City Royals and the Minnesota Twins will set that precedent in the Western Division.

title: STRAVINSKY WORK HAD DEBUT IN '51
description: ''The Rake's Progress,'' Stravinsky's and Auden's operatic commentary on the famous Hogarth drawings, had its world premiere on Sept. 11, 1951, at Venice's Fenice theater with the composer conducting. The cast included Elisabeth Schwarzkopf as Anne Trulove, Robert Rounseville as Tom Rakewell and Jennie Tourel as Baba the Turk.

title: Sterilizer Outlook
description: The American Sterilizer Company said it expected to report net income for the third quarter below that of a year before, when it earned $3.4 million, or 34 cents a share.

title: NO NEW SESSION SET
description: Negotiations aimed at ending the six-month-old national coal strike collapsed today, increasing the prospects that the stoppage will drag on into the winter.

title: Fortune Systems
description: The Fortune Systems Corporation said it and North Star Computers Inc. had ended merger talks. It said the decision to end the talks had been an amicable one and does not affect the terms of Fortune's loan of $3.8 million in debt financing to North Star. The debt financing is convertible into about 19 percent of North Star's common stock.

title: FERRARO WOULD OPPOSE BUSH IN THE THIRD OF OCTOBER ENCOUNTERS
description: Tentative agreement has been reached for two debates in October between President Reagan and his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, officials in both camps said today.

title: 2 Guilty of Violating Federal Meat Laws
description: A jury today convicted Rudolph Stanko and the Cattle King Packing Company, once a major supplier of beef for the nation's school lunch program, of violating Federal meat laws.

title: New Yorker Is Backed To Head Phone Union
description: The executive board of the Communications Workers of America has selected Morton Bahr, vice president in charge of the union's New York district, to become the new president of the union.

title: INFORMAL ARGENTINE DEBT EXTENSION
description: Exasperation with Argentina's inability to clear up some of its overdue interest payments has led its 11-bank advisory group to balk at formally extending the repayment period on a $750 million bridge loan that matured yesterday. However, the group did not formally call the loan, thereby in effect granting Argentina a day-to- day extension.

title: CHAIRMAN DESCRIBES CHANGES AT PARAMOUNT
description: The chairman and chief executive officer of Gulf and Western Industries, Martin S. Davis, said yesterday that the corporation had been planning a reorganization of its Entertainment and Communications Group, which includes Paramount Pictures, before Barry Diller, Paramount's chairman, submitted his resignation earlier this week. Mr. Davis said he had been discussing the reorganization with Mr. Diller in Los Angeles last week.

description: The next chief Israeli delegate to

title: RETAIL SALES DOWN 0.8%
description: Americans, faced with short supplies in automobile showrooms, reduced their retail spending by eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the second consecutive month that retail sales have dropped, the Government said today.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1984
description: The Economy

title: WORSENING INDIA-PAKISTAN TIES WORRY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration has become concerned that a recent deterioration in relations between India and Pakistan could ultimately lead to renewed hostilities between the two countries, Administration officials said today.

title: CONNECICUT PONDERS NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Like a thousand other people who jammed the auditorium of Conard High School here tonight, Bonnie Beach came because she was a little scared and because she was more than a little confused.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A Question of Age

title: Sohio to Resume Beaufort Drilling
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it planned to resume drilling at a Beaufort Sea site that had been an earlier disappointment. Drilling operations are scheduled for late January through April on the east side of Prudhoe Bay.

title: CHURCH VS. STATE: HISTORICL CONCERN
description: When Alexis de Tocqueville visited the United States in 1831 the first thing that struck him was the ''religious atmosphere'' of the place.

title: ;  The Hawaii Blitz?
description: Eddie Einhorn, the Chicago White Sox owner, who also owns the problem-ridden Chicago Blitz, has been in Honolulu talking with state officials about shifting the football club to that city for the 1985 season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have reached an agreement on the disability bill and we hope to have it formalized by Monday. As a result of this agreement, the Social Security Administration will again be able to run a workable program.'' - Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas. (1:6.)

title: THE POPE'S MESSAGE: MISLED MODERNITY
description: In a matter of a few days this week, Pope John Paul II succeeded in pleasing trade unionists, worrying businessmen and making Indians and Eskimos happy and feminists unhappy. He also comforted religious conservatives while displeasing liberals who think church schools should get no government aid.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ETHIOPIAN JEWS DIE, ISRAEL FIDDLES
description: At least 1,300 black Ethiopian Jews, mostly children, have died in the past five months in refugee camps outside Ethiopia in the Horn of Africa. In Israel, the Action Committee for Ethiopian Jews, representing about 7,000 of them living there, charges that the Government and world Jewish community could have saved them. They are right. The inertia is a scandal.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Dinner at Antolotti's

title: U.S. DROPS A FIGHT ON WORTH OF JOBS
description: The Reagan Adminstration has decided, at least temporarily, not to help the State of Washington fight a wide- reaching sex discrimination ruling, Administration sources said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. .

title: New Deadline for Air Florida
description: A Federal judge yesterday extended until Monday the deadline for Midway Airlines Inc. to complete its takeover agreement with debt-ridden Air Florida.

title: A Faith to Trust
description: Mario Cuomo's lecture at Notre Dame masterly stated a thoughtful politician's analysis of how his private religion guides his public life. He can be devout without imposing religious beliefs on others - not only can but must. Roman Catholics especially know from their history that ''to assure our freedom, we must allow others the same freedom.'' To employ the law to force one's religious conviction on others runs the risk that ''they might someday force theirs on us.''

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (Television - SportsChannel, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 3:15 P.M.)

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT RISES BY ONLY 0.2%
description: The Federal Reserve announced today that the nation's industrial production rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in August.

title: FERRARO AND O'CONNOR JOIN IN A LAUGH
description: The Mayor dropped by, told a few jokes, and then left early to go to an MTV video awards banquet.

title: POPE SPEAKS OUT ON POLISH RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II tonight delivered a strong call for human rights in Poland and an indirect but firm endorsement of the Solidarity labor movement there.

title: American Airways
description: American International Airways canceled all flights this evening for at least three days after receiving a court injunction that grounded half its fleet, an executive of the financially strapped airline said. Mike Boyd, A.I.A.'s vice president of marketing, said the injunction prevented the airline from flying at least two of the carrier's four DC-9s, leading officials to decide to shut down the entire system rather than to try to hastily reschedule flights. ''We have ceased operations until approximately the 18th (of September),'' Mr. Boyd said.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Drowning Upstate At Fishing Contest
description: A man participating in a fishing contest drowned today after water released from a hydroelectric dam surged downstream and swept him off his feet into a deep pool, the state police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press yesterday from Winter Haven, Fla., gave an incorrect effective date for a ban on citrus shipments from Florida. The ban, intended to halt the spread of citrus canker, a highly contagious plant disease, took effect yesterday. Further developments are reported today on page 8.

title: uf825Hispanic Educators Honored by Reagan
description: President Reagan, capping a week of courting traditionally Democratic voters, presented awards to eight Hispanic educators today and said he wanted Hispanic youths to ''soar like eagles.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WHISTLER'S EUROPE James Whistler, the American painter whose name most often conjures up his mother, was born 150 years ago, an anniversary that has prompted not one but two exhibitions of his work that opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 81st Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,320,000.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Federal district judge has awarded $37.9 million in back pay to flight attendants dismissed by United Airlines in the 1960's because they were married.

title: DRASTIC ACTION WEIGHED TO SAVE FLORIDA CITRUS
description: Florida officials are considering drastic steps to eradicate a virulent plant disease that threatens the state's $2.5 billion citrus industry.

title: BUSH PRAISES THE VALUES OF CONSERVATION
description: Vice President Bush declared yesterday, ''Conservatism doesn't stand for the preservation of the status quo; conservatism stands for the preservation of values.'' He spoke before the New York State Conservative Party endorsed him and President Reagan, giving them another line on the ballot in the nation's second-largest state.

title: PALESTINIAN MAYOR IN GAZA IS SHOT DEAD
description: Gunmen in a passing car shot and killed the Palestinian Mayor of a city in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip today, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: DISNEY BID IS POSSIBLE, JACOBS SAYS
description: An investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis businessman, said yesterday that it was considering seeking control of Walt Disney Productions.

description: A week ago, President Reagan urged Americans to set aside time to honor their grandparents, citing Sept. 9 as Grandparents' Day. The White House was asked how Mr. Reagan was doing as a grandfather.

description: Connecticut has divested itself of investments in seven ''socially irresponsible'' companies that do not comply with the state's South African investment law, officials said today.

title: EX-OFFICIAL IN INDIA SEEKS A STATE STRIKE TO GET HIS JOB BACK
description: The former Chief Minister of a southern Indian state, who was ousted by an appointee of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, called today for a statewide strike and transportion blockade after a vote on his political future was put off until next week.

description: The Colonial Penn Group, a Philadelphia insurer, said yesterday that its planned merger into the St. Regis Corporation had been terminated. The move had been widely expected in light of St. Regis's subsequent agreement to be acquired by the Champion International Corporation.

description: The Public Schools Athletic League begins its football season today with nine teams having new head coaches and five teams in new divisions.

description: Morris J. Markowitz, founder of the Markland Advertising Agency and a former vice president of Alexander's Department Stores in New York, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Coconut Creek, Fla.

description: Rob Williams reported to his rookie training camp badly out of shape, and his play since then has been inconsistent. On some nights, according to General Manager Paul Phipps, ''he just couldn't go.''

title: RECAST NEW YORK'S BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: A Federal judge has presented New York City with a historic opportunity to reform the powerful Board of Estimate, an archaic and undemocratic institution that inadequately represents both neighborhood interests and the growing minority community.

description: Private enterprise, which is now encouraged nationwide in China, is being hampered by local authorities who have arbitrarily imposed crippling taxes on many successful small-business men.
