description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court expressed ''grave concern'' today over recent rulings by the Court that he said might leave individuals whose rights were violated with no effective recourse.

title: MASERATI'S STUNNING REBOUND
description: Inside one of Maserati's big reinforced concrete factories here, a yawning space reminiscent of an airplane hangar, engineers were busily installing giant computerized drilling machines.

description: Vito Antuofermo, embarking on a comeback after a retirement of more than three years, figures that his opponents are out for his blood. And the 31-year-old former middleweight champion thinks he found some evidence for that belief Thursday night in Atlantic City.

description: Acting under court order, Liberal Party leaders have scheduled a state committee meeting for Monday to nominate the party's Democratic Presidential ticket and to elect state officers for the next year.

title: SALVADORAN VILLAGERS REPORT ATTACK BY ARMY
description: Salvadoran troops encircled and opened fire on hundreds of unarmed peasants and a small number of armed leftist rebels here during a recent antiguerrilla drive, according to people who said they were witnesses to the incident.

title: CITY REINSTATES WHISTLE BLOWER AFTER AN INQUIRY
description: A city buildings inspector who was dismissed in April for making allegations of corruption has been reinstated, the city's Department of Investigation said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK '04-NO IFS, ANDS OR BUTTS
description: This month is historic for New Yorkers: for the first time in American political history, a major party kicked off its fall campaign with a woman - and from Queens - on its ticket. The significance of this fact is enhanced when it is contrasted with another major event that took place in the Big Apple 80 years ago.

title: Dr. Helen L. Price Is Married in Jersey
description: Dr. Helen Louise Price, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey S. Price of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Christopher Donald Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Mitchell of Holywood, County Down, Ireland. The Rev. Dr. Franklin D. Fry, assisted by the Rev. Lynn Nakamura, performed the ceremony at St. John's Lutheran Church.

title: U.S. PREPARED TO HELP ISRAELIS IF AUSTERITY PALN IS IN PEACE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was ready to help Israel out of its precarious economic situation, but only if the Israelis first produced a drastic austerity program.

title: HOUSE UNIT MOVES TO DELAY MX VOTE
description: The House Appropriations Committee, after narrowly defeating tougher restrictions on the MX missile, today approved the delay of any vote on the production of the new intercontinental weapons until spring.

title: VOLUME IS 137.4 MILLION
description: A strong buying surge, propelled by indications the economy is slowing, swept into the stock market yesterday and sent prices broadly higher.

title: Pay'n Save Offer
description: The Pay'n Save Corporation said its board had approved a new offer to be acquired by the Trump Group for $23.50 a share, up from a previous $22.50 a share. The total offer for the retail chain is about $357 million. On Thursday, the Trump Group said it had raised the ofer as a result of an option it obtained from two Pay'n Save directors, Samuel N. Stroum and Stuart M. Sloan, to acquire their nearly 2.8 million shares at $23.50 each.

title: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL GETS TAKEOVER BID
description: The Southland Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had received a proposal to be acquired for stock and debt by a company to be formed by certain members of the Carpenter family, which holds about 30 percent of Southland's shares.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $403,000 from the sale of real estate investments. c-Includes a gain of $209,000 from the sale of real estate investments. Results for the latest 9 months include contingent interest of $600,000.

title: OIL SERVICE CONCERN TO BUY SEDCO
description: Sedco Inc. and Schlumberger Ltd. reported yesterday that they had agreed to a merger of Sedco into a subsidiary of Schlumberger in a transaction valued at more than $1 billion.

title: ;  Boxer Is Stopped
description: Dave Pearce, the British heavyweight champion, lost his bid to resume his career after being banned from the ring because a brain scan had revealed an abnormality. In rejecting Pearce's immediate appeal, the British Boxing Board of Control ruled that, before being allowed to return, he would have to consult a neurologist and convince the board that he is fit.

title: South Koreans Accept Help To Flood Victims From North
description: South Korea today accepted an offer of flood relief from North Korea, and North Korea accepted an invitation to set up a meeting to help ease tensions.

title: GCA Expansion
description: The GCA Corporation said it is considering a ''major expansion'' of its print works complex here. It said the expansion could create several hundred jobs over the next few years and augment its Massachusetts operations, which produce equipment for the semiconductor industry. The final decision depends mainly on the granting of Federal loans to GCA and to the Yankee Tech Corporation, the developers of the complex, GCA said.

title: (TWO HUNDRED TWO) 202 DATA SYSTEMS (O) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
READERS SEND VARIATIONS ON THEMES
description: Mail from readers to this column is voluminous and unfailingly interesting, often providing additional information, a few brickbats and some cheers. Sometimes the information is worth sharing with everyone else.

title: SHULTZ, IN FIRST MAJOR DRUG SPEECH, SAYS CONTROL HAS 'TOP PRIORITY'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in his first major statement on international narcotics control, said today that ''attacking the worldwide network of narcotics production and trafficking'' was ''a top priority in our foreign policy.''

title: Moroccans Vote
description: Moroccans voted today for their fourth Parliament since independence from France in 1956. The election is expected to produce another center-right majority loyal to King Hassan II.

title: PAGEANT HOPES SOAP-OPERA SPOOF ENLIVENS SHOW
description: Weighed down by tradition and accused of being stuffy, the Miss America Pageant this year is making an effort to lighten the show by spoofing a national addiction - soap operas.

title: WAITING ON TABLES, WAITING FOR THE BIG BREAK
description: Sonia glides gracefully across the restaurant floor, carrying two orders of chicken salad and her dreams of dancing on Broadway.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. House Resolution Angers Turkish Premier
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal warned today that relations with the United States could be harmed by a House of Representatives resolution approved this week calling for a day of remembrance for Armenian massacre victims.

title: TEXAS EXPECTS ANOTHER FINE SEASON
description: The start of the 1983 college football season was still a week away, but Tony Degrate, a star defensive tackle for Texas, was talking about what the Longhorns' defensive unit was going to do against Auburn in the opening game.

title: Sidney Torin, a Disk Jockey On Jazz Radio in the 1940's
description: Sidney Torin, the jazz radio disk jockey often known as ''Symphony Sid'' who helped bring public attention to a long list of jazz luminaries, including Miles Davis and Dizzy Gillespie, died of heart disease yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NURSING HOMES SEEK AFFLUENT
description: Like many other consumer-based businesses, the nursing home industry is going after the upper end of the market.

title: PANEL PROGRESSES ON IMMIGRATION BILL
description: House and Senate conferees made substantial progress in negotiations on a comprehensive immigration bill today, but they could not agree on how to prevent job discrimination against United States citizens and aliens legally in the country.

title: MONDALE SHIFTING STAFF AND TACTICS TO STRESS RALLIES AND SPEECHES
description: After a blunt late-night meeting Wednesday in a motel suite in Tupelo, Miss., at which Walter F. Mondale voiced concern about his troubled campaign, the Democratic Presidential candidate has decided to change his tactics and shake up his staff.

title: Jersey School Forfeits Season
description: The football team at Central High School will not be allowed to play this season because 33 of the 45 players did not achieve an acceptable academic average last semester, according to Board of Education officials.

title: CITY OPERA: 'RAKE' HAS PREMIERE
description: In the 33 years since its premiere, Stravinsky's only full-length opera has made its way slowly. However, little by little ''The Rake's Progress'' has attracted a following and, while it cannot yet be said to be a staple anywhere, the work finds its way onto world stages with some regularity. Thursday night it made its first appearance in the repertory of the New York City Opera, in a well-traveled production designed by David Hockney.

title: THE CITY ; ;  L.I.R.R.Dismisses 2 After Derailment
description: The Long Island Rail Road said today that it had dismissed two employees as a result of an investigation of a derailment in Babylon on Aug. 24 in which two riders were hurt and a coach was destroyed.

title: FORTY MORE APPLES FOR A CLEANUP IN THE BRONX
description: To the Editor:

title: HERBERT D. BROOKS Sr.
description: Herbert D. Brooks Sr., father of Herb Brooks Jr., coach of the New York Rangers, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, while playing golf.

title: HAIL TO (AND WAILS FOR) THE REDSKINS
description: It's not how you play the game but whether you win or lose. And you'd better win.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES ; Reagan Leads by 16% In California, Poll Says
description: The California Poll reported today that President Reagan held a 16-point lead in his home state over Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee.

title: CUBS PUSH LEAD OVER METS TO 8-1/2
description: On a cold, gray and brooding afternoon in Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs probably delivered the coup de grace to the Mets today with a 7-1 whipping that left the Mets eight and a half games behind first-place Chicago with only 14 to play.

title: SHOCKLEY WINS $1 IN LIBEL SUIT
description: A Federal jury returned a verdict today in favor of the physicist William Shockley in a libel suit against The Atlanta Constitution and a former employee, but it awarded the scientist only $1 in actual damages and no punitive damages.

title: No Headline
description: The Rev. Dr. W. Eugene Houston, an official of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) and a prominent minister in Harlem for many years, collapsed and died of a heart attack while playing tennis in Laurelton, Queens, last Saturday. He was 64 years old and lived in Laurelton.

title: SONG BY RICHARD STRAUSS DISCOVERED
description: The manuscript of an unpublished Richard Strauss song known only to a few of his intimate associates and composed in November 1948 - two months later than the piece that was previously believed to have been his last work - will be auctioned on Dec. 12 by Sotheby's in New York.

title: GULF NUCLEAR reports earnings for Year to June 30
GASOLINE AND FOOD OFF
description: Producer prices, falling for the first time in nine months, dropped one- tenth of 1 percent in August as gasoline prices showed their steepest decline since March 1983, the Government said today.

title: Soviet on Reagan Meeting
description: The Soviet Union acknowledged for the first time today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would meet with President Reagan on Sept. 28. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, would not tell Western reporters what would be discussed in Mr. Reagan's first contact with a high-level Soviet official.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday, with an article about action by the New Jersey Legislature, misidentified Carmen A. Orechio. He is President of the New Jersey State Senate.

title: LIFELINE FOR THE BLIND
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Contracts
description: The General Dynamics Corporation received $517.4 million in military contracts, the Defense Department said. The contracts included Army contracts of $250 million for 840 M-1 Abrams tanks and $92.9 million for 2,488 Stinger missiles. In addition, the Air Force gave Pan Am World Services Inc. a $115.8 million contract to operate a test range in Cocoa Beach, Fla., the department said.

title: Two Tests for the Senate; Proud Recruits for the School Wars

Teaching now attracts high school graduates from the bottom half of their classes, and the ablest of them leave the profession within five years. Most of the proposed remedies - dramatically increased salaries, merit pay, tougher standards - are stalled by controversy. One modest proposal in Congress, however, appears to be on the verge of realization.

title: ;  Bossy's Knee Hurting
description: Mike Bossy, the Islander who scored in overtime Thursday night to give Canada a semifinal victory over the Soviet Union in the Canada Cup, has a sore knee again and may have to miss the tournament's two-of- three-game final series. Bossy, who has been bothered by knee problems since he was a child, limped noticeably and did not practice yesterday with his teammates in Calgary, where the final, against Sweden, begins tomorrow night. He spoke with General Manager Bill Torrey of the Islanders and decided to remain with the Canadian squad but was not sure he would be able to play.

title: 55 SCHOLARS SAY CHURCH'S ABORTION STAND IS NOT MONOLITHIC

The board said it disagreed with the views on abortion that Mr. Cuomo expressed in a speech Thursday night at the University of Notre Dame.

title: HOW 'AMADEUS' WASTRANSLATED FROM PLAY TO FILM
description: They were, Peter Shaffer recalls, quite the odd couple. To turn his play ''Amadeus'' into a film script, the English playwright spent four months holed up in a Connecticut farmhouse with Milos Forman, the Czech film director. Isolated from the rest of the world in what they called their ''torture chamber,'' the collaborators suffered from writer's block together, listened to Mozart records together, and improvised scenes from the play together. Much of their afternoon work sessions, however, was devoted to arguing. They argued about scenes and words, and the order of scenes and words. They argued about who would say what in the film. They even argued about which of them would cook dinner. In the end, nothing went into the movie that both did not agree upon; and on Wednesday at the Paramount and Tower East - some two and half years after their first argument - ''Amadeus,'' the motion picture starring Tom Hulce and F. Murray Abraham, is finally opening.

title: A GUIDE TO FALL COOKING SCHOOLS
description: WITH the arrival of autumn, it is school time again, and not just for children. Cooking schools throughout the county are gearing up for their fall semester, and the roster of courses is, to say the least, impressive.

description: NINE developers are competing for one of the most important sites on Lexington Avenue, the Grand Central Post Offfice Building at 45th Street. All are seeking to lease the property from the United States Postal Service and redevelop it.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
PLAYS WITHIN PLAYS THAT COMMENT ON OURSELVES
description: ''Life,'' Oscar Wilde quipped, ''imitates art.'' Yes and no, but Wilde forgot to mention that art also imitates art. A quick glance up and down Broadway makes the point. The stage is stage-struck. In ''The Real Thing,'' ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' ''Noises Off,'' ''42nd Street,'' ''Dream Girls'' and ''Chorus Line,'' theater turns to itself for subject matter. All the world's a stage - there's nothing new about the metaphor. What's new is how obssessed popular theater has become with the comparison, how the conceit functions, and the psychological assumptions that underpin it. The poor players no longer strut and fret their hour upon the stage, they kick up their heels and belt out a song to celebrate a new-found freedom in lifestyle and role choice. But if the surface of these plays is light and bright and sparkling, underneath - at least from the sociological point of view - there's often a darker sub-text.

title:

SHOULD 7th AND 8th GRADERS TAKE THE SAT TESTS?

Mensch, an architect and painter, and his wife, Pamela, looked for a house in Manhattan that had the potential of being integrated with its center, so as to make an inner courtyard of green that would relate to the other rooms of the house. Also, once established, this inside garden had to be relatively maintenance-free, for by the following summer they planned to leave for Paris, where Mensch would spend the next year painting.

Not only is the summer barbecue still appropriate but restaurants everywhere are featuring fish, poultry, meats and vegetables that have been given a haunting, smoky intensity by being cooked on a grill. Although one invariably thinks of food as hot off the grill, grilling is also an excellent method of preparing salad ingredients.

Now, several years later, it is still noisy, but the service is generally professional and less frantic, and the food has improved considerably.

title: HEADLINERS

Mr. Mehta and the New York Philharmonic, which he conducts, packed the houses as they began an eight-day tour that marked the maestro's first appearance in his native country since 1967. Some members of the orchestra carped about their accomodations in New Delhi - they said their rooms were cockroach-infested and generally untidy - but none of it dampened Mr. Mehta's enthusiasm.

title: A COUNTRY LOOK IN WASHINGTON

The urge to head straight for the mauve, slipcovered daybed and sink down among the paisley patterned pillows is irresistible. Lillian and Stephane Groueff's Watergate apartment overlooking the Potomac River in Washington,, is a nest of pine and oak country furniture, rag rugs, Pierre Deux and Thai cotton prints.

The veteran swing pianist, who has worked with everyone from Billie Holiday to Tallulah Bankhead, is leading a 10-man band in an amiably exuberant salute to Louis Armstrong that runs through the middle of October.

title: Union Reshapes Winning Attitude
description: OH, how sweet it is, winning. At Union College, winning at football is still something of a new experience. Wonderful, but new. Last year, in its 97th season of college football, Union made its way into the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl, the championship game for Division III colleges. Union didn't win, losing to Augustana, 21-17, in the closing minutes, but just getting there was a considerable feat given a history of considerably more prosaic attempts at the game. And this season even more success is expected.

With the computer now an accepted part of many people's home and office environments, the problem is how to extend its power to cover all bases, including the supplementary habitat, without exceeding budgetary, as well as space, limits.

All proceeds from the final evening, which will be open to the general public, will benefit a newly-created Birgit Nilsson Scholarship Fund, the purpose of which is to provide, in perpetuity, annual scholarships for talented singers who receive their training at the Manhattan School.

The principals were Evan Johnson, playing the Baroque violin, and Julianne Baird, the soprano, and though this was primarily an evening of fragments, great effort was made to superimpose an order upon them.

title: Young Fails Test The Miami Dolphins need a running back to replace the injured
description: Andra Franklin , but for two straight days they have failed in attempts to find a prospect able to pass a complete physical examination. Yesterday Rickey Young, a 10-year veteran who was cut by the Minnesota Vikings before the season, passed the orthopedic part of the exam, but failed the urine test. Earlier in the week, the Dolphins obtained Chuck Muncie from the San Diego Chargers in a trade, but the deal was canceled Friday when the former all-pro's urine test showed traces of tetrahydrocannavinol, the active ingredient in marijuana.

title: EUROPEAN ARCHIVES YIELD JAZZ RICHES FOR A REISSUE SERIES

Founded in the mid-1930's by two French jazz enthusiasts and scholars, Hugues Panassie and Charles Delaunay, Swing was the first record label to be devoted exclusively to jazz. It was the recording wing of a broad European fascination with jazz that preceded any similar response in the United States.

title: SHIRTS & TIES
description: The classic question has always been how to adhere to the proprieties and yet maintain one's individuality. And when it comes to dress, the classic answer has always been that individuality presents itself in the accessories, the haberdashery aspects of the wardrobe, no matter how traditional the suitings. The Fred Astaires, Dukes of Windsor and Douglas Fairbankses of this world would never think to wear anything but the most proper of gray flannel suits and navy blazers. Nor for the likes of a Cary Grant are the neon-checked boiler suit, Day-Glo sport jacket or deafeningley plaid trousers. But who would disagree that each possesses a singular, stylish aura?

title: IN SHORT
description: * SELDOM SUNG SONGS. By Ray Locke. (Roundtable Publishing, 933 Pico Boulevard, Santa Monica, Calif. 90405, $13.95.) Chapters full of conversation, a rapid unfolding of conflict and a short time span make Ray Locke's second novel seem more a play than a novel. Set in a small Mississippi town in 1954, ''Seldom Sung Songs'' chronicles one day in the life of the Kantwiths, a patriarchal, land-poor, once aristocratic family. It is no ordinary day, however; the catalyst for the novel's development is the return of the body of the eldest son, killed two years before in Korea. The setting provides an effective microcosm of the South prior to the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court decision ending public school segregation. We see the ambiguous and complex interaction of the white and black worlds: how two women, one white, the other black, can privately be best of friends yet occupy different spheres of society; the taboos and hypocrisy of a social class unwilling to regognize that it no longer holds the elevated position it once did; the way a young black man of intelligence and promise can be forever banished from his hometown for insulting a white man. While the novel's controlling force throughout is Tom Kantwith, the father, he exists primarily offstage, and we see him largely through the way he has affected the female characters. It is in their presentation that Mr. Locke paints his most vivid and believable portraits.

title: FROM EXPLICIT SEX TO GRATUITOUS PASSIONS

Scene Two: The handsome, sophisticated stockbroker, having just forced himself sexually on a former lover who is now his best friend's fiancee, turns on his most charming smile and says, ''Hey, it's not the end of the world.'' Scene Three: A prostitute begins sounding out her shy customer with some skimpy satin lingerie. ''Would you like me to put it on?'' she asks. ''Sure,'' he says hesitantly. ''Would you like to watch me put it on?'' she continues. ''Sure,'' he replies more confidently.

title: PANMUNJOM: BETWEEN TWO KOREAS
description: CLYDE HABERMAN is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times. Not many tours require you to sign a form freeing the organizers from responsibility in case you get killed. That may be the least unusual aspect of a trip to Panmunjom. More disconcerting is how hard it can be to tell the real from the illusory. To visit the Korean demilitarized zone is to experience diversion in the form of propaganda. The effect can be intriguing. It can also be disturbing.

It is generally believed that even if the meeting puts things back on track, Soviet-American relations will be different from the detente days of the early 1970's, probably far less extensive and certainly attended this time by more modest expectations.

title: PLAINTIFFS ASK A WIDER GREENSBORO CIVIL TRIAL
description: Lawyers pressing a $48 million civil suit against local, state and Federal police agencies in the deaths of five Communist union organizers killed here in 1979 have asked a Federal district judge to add 10 Federal agents and Greensboro police officers as defendants.

title: W. R. Price Weds Christine Goodman
description: Christine Carpenter Goodman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Goodman 4th of New York, Bay Head, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William Randall Price, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Price of Garden City and Remsenburg, L.I. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan, assisted by the Rev. Judith T. Baumer and the Rev. Timothy A. Curtin.

title: No Headline
description: Elaine Kaufman Is Engaged

title: ART SHOW WITH FAMILY TOUCH
description: IN what they are calling a ''twin homage'' to their father, artists Carol and

title: JAZZ: LEE KONITZ PERFORMS
description: Live jazz has a new outlet in Manhattan. At Spring Street, a restaurant whose entrance is actually on West Broadway, the alto saxophonist Lee Konitz and the pianist Harold Danko are ensconced in a back room where the acoustics permit even sotto-voce, unamplified duets to be heard clearly over dinner conversation.

title: PENN STATE WINS
description: Bo Jackson, Auburn's all-America wishbone halfback, was expected to miss the remainder of the season after he suffered a separated right shoulder tonight as Texas defeated Auburn, 35- 27, in Memorial Stadium.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Unquestionably, cable's drama highlight of the week is the official release - after one timely showing last June - of HBO's ''Sakharov'' (Sunday at 8 P.M., Monday at 4:25 A.M., Friday at 10 A.M.). John J. O'Connor of The New York Times called this piercing story of Russia's repression of the idealistic Nobel Prize-winning dissident and his family ''a giant step forward'' in American cable television.

title: Inmate Given $20,000 For Informing in Crime
description: A Connecticut convict who helped solve a murder has received a $20,000 reward from the state.

title: 2 Dutch Minesweepers Due at Port on Red Sea
description: Two Dutch Navy minesweepers are expected to arrive in Jidda on Sunday to replace United States and French teams that have been looking for mines in Saudi Arabia's territorial waters in the Red Sea, a Dutch Embassy spokesman said today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HAVE YOU SEEN MY DUCKLING?

title: EAST HILLS ZONING ISSUES UNRESOLVED
description: '' THIS ill wind did blow a lot of good - to a lot of villages that felt imperiled that someone would find a technical defect in their zoning codes, and then their codes would be down the drain.''

title: I1 PROGRESSO RENOVATION
description: A former newspaper plant at the edge of Greenwich Village, where both Il Progresso, the Italian language daily, and La Prensa, the Spanish-language newspaper, were once printed, will soon go the way of other industrial buildings in this desirable residential area.

title: TIMING AND ISUES MAKE PROBLEMS FOR MONDALE
description: It was one of those scenes of small humiliation. After a late start from Washington, Walter F. Mondale raced to make the afternoon shift change at the Procter & Gamble Company's Fox River Plant in Green Bay to shake hands with the blue- jeaned men and women who produce Bounty paper towels and Charmin toilet tissue.

title: FELIX ROHATYN: LIFE AT THE TOP
description: The proposal for the formation of an ''Industrial Development Board,'' as outlined in the Rohatyn article, has great merit.

title: NICARAGUAN TOWN WELCOMES CUBANS
description: Just about everyone in town, it seems, has seen Cuban advisers from the military training base here.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CANTON
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is the Times bureau chief in Peking.

title: NICARAGUA IS GETTING A MIX OF SIGNALS
description: One day last week, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American chief delegate to the United Nations, told a group of President Reagan's supporters that Nicaragua was a ''Marxist- Leninist-Communist dictatorship that has offered itself as a base for the projection of Soviet power.'' She said Nicaraguan rebels deserved the support of the American people.

title: Poughkeepsie Man Charged In Slaying of Woman in 1982
description: A Poughkeepsie man has been charged with murdering a woman whose skeleton was discovered last Sunday in a shallow grave in Dutchess County.

title: FOLLOWING IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF SILVA
description: Her feet worked deftly against the floor; her graceful arms and tiny hands wove delicate gestures in the air. Any ballet master would have nodded with pleasure, and remembered the dark-eyed girl with the promising future as a ballerina. But here in Varanasi, the holiest of Hindu cities on the Ganges River in India, 7-year-old Lakshmi (named after the Hindu goddess of fortune and beauty) knew nothing of tutus or toe shoes. Wearing a red and white polka-dot dress and pajama pants, lighted harshly by a single overhead bulb, she danced barefoot on the polished concrete.

title: Bowie Near Contract
description: Sam Bowie , the 7-feet-1-inch Kentucky center and the second player selected behind Akeem Olajuwo n in last June's college draft, is close to reaching a contract agreement with the Portland Trail Blazers. Actually, Alan Rothenberg, who doubles as president of the Los Angeles Clippers and the lawyer for the Trail Blazers, said he had reached agreement with Larry Fleisher, who represents Bowie.

title: STAGE: 'TENDER OFFER,' A CORPORATE COMEDY
description: The world of big business - unfriendly takeovers, corner windows and golden handshakes - has for a long time offered possibilities for drama and satire.

title: AT 80, A PHILANTHROPIST BEGINS TO ACCEPT TRIBUTES
description: To hear him tell it, Jack D. Weiler, the New York realty investor, would rather coax a charitable contribution from a donor than pull off a lucrative property sale.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
PRICES MAY SHOOT UP AGAIN BY LATE'84
description: It may be easy to look at the most

title: FOR FERRARO, TOUGH WEEK ISN'T ALL BAD
description: As Geraldine A. Ferraro's campaign plane headed into Scranton, Pa., the other day for what was supposed to be a routine stop on a three- day swing through through working-class cities, the candidate and her entourage braced for a hostile reception from antiabortion protestors.

title: India to Proceed With Fence On Border With Bangladesh
description: India will soon resume construction of a 1,365-mile barbed-wire fence along its border with Bangladesh in an effort to prevent illegal immigration, the United News of India reported Friday.

title: THE ART COLLECTOR: CLUES TO A CHARACTER PROFILE
description: Why do people collect art? Inquiries into the collector's need to surround himself with beauty have been the traditional domain of the esthetician and art historian. But at a time when art is becoming increasingly a ''good'' investment, and more people, in different income scales, are turning to some form of acquiring art objects, it is curious how little behavioral specialists have had to say about the motives of the art collector.

title: AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF BEIRUT REPLACES ITS SLAIN PRESIDENT
description: The trustees of the American University of Beirut annnounced in New York yesterday that Dr. Calvin H. Plimpton, president of Amherst College from 1960 to 1971, had been elected president of the institution.

title: U.P.I. OFFICIAL IS CONTESTING HIS DISMISSAL
description: Late tomorrow afternoon, the vote will be counted that will decide if United Press International's employees have accepted a deep wage cut and layoffs that both the company and the union leadership indicate are necessary to keep the news agency in business.

title: GROUP TO LOSE ITS FOUNDER
description: IN 1974 a Yale University junior,

title: WORTH REPEATING
description: IT HAS BEEN OUR POLICY TO

title: WHAT'S NEW AT N.Y.U.'S BUSINESS SCHOOL
description: A few weeks ago New York University's Graduate School of Business, an institution of higher learning that is compressed into two buildings-plus-library in the heart of Manhattan's financial district, went through a changing of the guard. Dean William May handed over the reins to Richard R. West, once dean of Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School. Mr. West inherited an institution that he sees as being in a ''major growth stage.'' There is ''a real entrepreneurial spirit here,'' he said. ''It's the nature of the place.''

title: THE DOWNSIDE OF UPSTATE
description: There are few places across New York's vast stretches of forests, fields and orchards where one cannot stumble upon pockets of rural poverty.

title: THE REGION
description: Democrats Give Incumbents a Primary Boost

title: SLEW O' GOLD RALLIES TO WIN WOODWARD
description: With a furlong to go, the unthinkable seemed likely. Shifty Sheik, who was claimed for $35,000 only a month ago and whose presence in the Woodward Stakes had elicited more chuckles than fear, had a 1 1/2-length lead on Slew o' Gold, the top race horse in the country and a $20 million stallion prospect. But in the final yards of the most important race so far this year, Slew o' Gold finally got past Shifty Sheik to win the $291,000 Woodward by half a length yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: THE MORRISTOWN CRAFTMARKET: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: AS SURE a sign of fall as the equinox, the annual Morristown Craft Market will settle in here next weekend at the National Guard Armory.

title: HYDROELECTRIC PLANT IN JERSEY TO BE RETURNED TO OPERATION
description: Public officials and representatives of private industry have announced plans to refurbish a hydroelectric plant here that was closed 15 years ago.

title: EXPANDING THE SCOPE OF CHILDREN'S FARE
description: Leslie Garisto frequently reports on the television scene.

title: Australia-Albania Ties
description: Australia and Albania have agreed to establish diplomatic relations at the level of ambassador, Acting Foreign Affairs Minister Gordon Scholes said today.

title: U.S. STEPS UP SECURITY PLAN FOR WARHEADS
description: The Government has put into effect a sweeping new program to improve the security of Federal facilities where nuclear warheads are designed and made.

title: Strike at Spanish Airline
description: A strike by the maintenance staff of Iberia Airlines grounded about 30 flights today and caused delays in many others, company officials said.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Across Canada With the Pope

title: HIDEAWAY IN THE CITY
description: At the time it was built in 1884, the Dakota, one of New York's first luxury apartment buildings, featured commodious rooms with high ceilings, meticulous architectural detailing and pleasing views. There were also collecitve spaces: On lower floors residents shared a restaurant, a ballroom, and a suite of guest rooms.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
HOW TO SPELL RELIEF: C-O-M-P-L-A-I-N-I-N-G
description: SOME of my friends are joggers; others, golfers. The rest play tennis. Their only common interest is complaining. Complaining is a sport like any other sport. The more you practice, the better you get.

CAMERA;

description: Lou Jacobs Jr. has written several books on photography.

title:
GARDENING;
FALL IS THE TIME TO IMPROVE A LAWN
description: OUR northern turf grasses prefer cool weather, and, as noted previously, the fall season is the best time of the year to do most anything to a lawn that needs to be done.

title: RUTGERS TOPS TEMPLE, 10-9, TO END SLIDE
description: Rutgers University finally met a peer it could beat today when the Scarlet Knights' young defense held on to defeat Temple, 10-9. The victory ended a 13-game losing streak for Rutgers against Division I-A rivals, dating to Army in 1982, and a five-game losing streak over all, including last week's opener to Penn State.

title: On Television's Role In the Tennis Marathon To The Sports Editor:
description: I, too, felt like a participant in last Saturday's United States Open tennis marathon. Unfortunately, I believe that both players

title: CONSUMER RATES
CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page picture caption today in some copies of The Guide, section 2A, misidentifies the network for ''Punky Brewster,'' a half-hour comedy series. It has its premiere tonight at 7:30 on NBC.

title: 200th ANNIVERSARY OF FIRST LAW SCHOOL
description: ONE of Connecticut's historic landmarks, the first law school in the nation, is celebrating its 200th anniversary this year.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: One of the most memorable incidents of the Paris Commune was the pulling down of the Vendome Column, a gigantic monument to Napoleon I in the center of the elegant Place Vendome. It happened in May, 1871, long before photographs began to be used to illustrate newspapers, and before photography was fast enough to capture such a fast- moving occurrence as it actually happened.

title: Kristi Dormann, Designer, And John Pl Kelly to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Dormann of New York of the engagement of their daughter Kristi Joy Dormann to John Patrick Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Kelly of Pittsburgh. The wedding is to be Oct. 13.

title: MAMARONECK LIBRARY DRIVE ADVANCES
description: THE Mamaroneck Library and Theater Center, now more than one-quarter of the way toward raising $852,000 for an ambitious expansion program, plans to break ground for its new facilities later this year, library officials announced last week.

title: Georgia Tech Stuns Alabama
description: Robert Lavette scored on a 1-yard run and David Bell made three field goals as Georgia Tech upset Alabama, 16-6, leaving the Crimson Tide with its worst start in 28 seasons.

title: Miss Mead Weds Dr. M. T. Gorey
description: Martina Mary Mead, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. States M. Mead of Greenwich, Conn., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Thomas Gorey, a son of Mrs. Donald J. Gorey of Bellwood, Ill., and the late Mr. Gorey. Msgr. Martin McDermott performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: U.S. REVIEW OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS ENDS
description: After 22 years, Federal regulators are about to complete testing that has so far led to the withdrawal of more than 1,000 prescription drugs judged to be ineffective.

title: Bruce Crenshaw Tully Marries M. Sandra Sennett
description: M. Sandra Sennett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Sennett of Niskayuna, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Crenshaw Tully, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Tully of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. Stanley W. Hosie, executive director of the Foundation for the Peoples of the South Pacific, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Assumption in Lake George, N.Y.

title: AUDIO'S NEW DIVORCE TREND
description: Audio watchers have noticed a shift. Among current entries in the market, the proportion of separate tuners and amplifiers is on the rise. The shift is slight, and these changes do not yet seriously challenge the predominance of receivers, which combine tuner and amplifier in a single unit. But a trend may be in the making and invites speculation about its causes.

title: CLOUDED HORIZON AT SOUTH AFRICA'S 'NEW DAWN'
description: During his days in South Africa in the early years of this century, Mohandas K. Gandhi led civil disobedience campaigns against apartheid. Last week, his granddaughter, Ela Ramgobin, visited her husband, Mewa, at the British Consulate in Durban, where he and five other political fugitives are holed up trying to avoid arrest.

title: Town That Suffered Rioting Getting Education Program
description: State officials have allocated $260,000 for a college and remedial education program in Lawrence in an effort to alleviate the conditions that led to two nights of rioting there last month.

title: THE NEW LOOK IN SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: TACOS, baked potatoes with toppings, salad bars and fresh fruit have replaced meat loaf, pot pies and casseroles in many school cafeterias across the state. Pressures for either more nutritious or more fast-food meals have prompted changes in what schoolchildren are eating for lunch.

title: 3 YOUNG MONDALES USHER 3 ZACCAROS INTO LIMELIGHT
description: One night this summer, Donna Zaccaro, a 22-year-old financial analyst, went dancing on Fire Island where her family has a summer home, and returned to find her way barred by a Secret Service agent.

title: WORLD BANK PLAN FOR AID TO AFRICA DIVIDES MEMBERS
description: The World Bank has proposed that the Western industrialized nations create an emergency aid fund for the most impoverished black African nations, but a split has developed because of opposition by the United States and West Germany, Western diplomats here said today.

title: MONDALE BETS ON TAX PLAN, BUT ODDS STILL FAVOR RE
description: WASHINGTON

description: Sakharov Case Won't Go Away

title: Cynthia A. Archbold Weds P. Parke Muth
description: Cynthia Anne Archbold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cornell Archbold Jr. of West Chester, Pa., was married yesterday to P. Parke Muth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Muth of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. William Fischler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Archbold home.

title: INDIANS BEGIN TO WEIGH THEIR POLITICAL POTENTIAL
description: For more than a century, American Indians have relied on Congress and the courts to protect their political and economic rights. The strategy has made sense for a people whose unique relationship to the Federal Government is grounded in the original language of the Constitution.

title: 500 PROTESTERS ARRESTED IN INDIAN STRIKE
description: Supporters of the former Chief Minister of a south-central Indian state clashed with the police today during a daylong general strike protesting his ouster, and about 50 people were wounded and 500 arrested, officials said.

title: THE NATION
description: Outlook Less Gloomy for Aliens Bill

title: Manufacturer Assails Criticism of Sweetener WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) - The Food and Drug Administration and the manufacturer of aspartame have discounted a new study by California researchers that questions whether the low-calorie sweetener is safe for use in cooking and hot beverages.
description: The study, conducted by Marcus F. Boehm and Jeffrey L. Bada at the University of California at San Diego, noted changes in the chemical components of aspartame when it was is boiled for a long time.

title: HELPING NOVICE LANDLORDS
description: HUNDREDS of younger people who have purchased small rental buildings in New York City as an alternative to high-priced cooperatives have been forming self-help groups to address problems with rent control and rent stabilization.

title: REHNQUIST ASKS LIMIT TO AUTOMATIC APPEALS
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court today proposed eliminating the absolute right to appeal cases from the Federal trial courts as one way of reducing the cost of ordinary civil lawsuits.

title: Balloonist Leaves Maine On Solo Flight to Europe
description: Joe Kittinger sailed his ''Balloon of Peace'' across Newfoundland today and headed toward Greenland, hoping to become the first person to make a solo balloon flight across the Atlantic.

title: SINKING METS LOSE AGAIN TO CUBS
description: The Chicago Cubs kept rolling relentlessly toward their first championship in 39 years today when they beat the Mets, 5-4, and moved nine and a half games in front with only 13 to play.

title: Jose Cabranes and Kate Pressman Wed
description: Jose A. Cabranes, a Federal judge in Connecticut, and Kate Stith Pressman, who will start in January as an associate professor at the Yale Law School, were married yesterday. Judge Carl McGowan of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at a private home in Bethany, Conn.

description: Among American troupes concentrating on African and Caribbean dance traditions, Charles Moore's company stands out for its courtliness.

description: Saving the MX For Another Day

title: WANTED: LEADERSHIP FOR THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic, which opens its 1984-5 season Sept. 25, has been criticized for decades, as somehow less than what the leading orchestra of the nation's musical capital should be. Most recently, the criticisms, justified or not, have focused on the players' fractious attitude and lack of group pride, the continued acoustical deficiencies of Avery Fisher Hall and the artistic failings of the music director, Zubin Mehta.

title: Susan E. Shepard Weds R. J. Dearie
description: Susan Engelke Shepard, an assistant United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, where she is chief of the major crimes section, was married yesterday to Raymond J. Dearie, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District. The Rev. William Starr, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Dietitians Defend Licensure Plan
description: I am incensed by quotations in the Aug. 19 article on dietitians. These ''nutritionists'' lack bona fide credentials and attack the licensing bill in the guise of protecting others.

title: Richard Ticktin Wed To Frances E. Kumin
description: Frances E. Kumin, the daughter of Mrs. Louis H. Kumin of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. Kumin, was married in New York yesterday to Richard M. Ticktin, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David A. Ticktin of New York. Rabbi Joseph Klein performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

description: OUR northern turf grasses prefer cool weather, and, as noted previously, the fall season is the best time of the year to do most anything to a lawn that needs to be done.

title: LANDMARK HANDBOOK
description: In the past few years, as the public's interest in landmark preservation has increased, organizations like the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation have often served as resource centers for those seeking information on the laws that pertain to landmarks and historic sites.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
RETHINKING THE RULES ON POLITICS AND INCOME
description: THE controversy over Geraldine A. Ferraro's tax returns suggests the need to take a second look at our financial-disclosure laws and the need to separate public policy issues from questions of possible wrongdoing.

title: MANOR UPDATES TOUR-TO 1790
description: TWO centuries ago, a small but dedicated group of people, scattered in many different places, struggled for decades, taking a new land from Colonial status, through a protracted war, into a new nation.

title: Betsy Allen Wed To a Veterinarian
description: year student at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and Dr. John K. Sinnigen, who graduated from the school in May, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Jeffrey Wampler performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Westfield, N.J.

title: JAKARTA VIOLENCE LAID TO MILITANTS
description: Street violence that left at least 9 people dead and 54 hurt this week was caused by political pressure, slum dwellers with local grievances and fiery sermons by militant Moslem preachers, diplomats and officials said today.

title: HUSBAND'S CONFESSION
description: Wallace Fowlie's most recent book is ''Aubade: A Teacher's Notebook.'' He is the author of many books on modern literature. ALEXIS

title: MONDALE STRATEGISTS VIEW DEBATES AS KEY TO GALVANIZING CAMPAIGN
description: The following article is based on reporting by Phil Gailey and Howell Raines and was written by Mr. Raines. .

title: Janet McDonough Is Wed to W. F. Marcellino Jr.
description: Janet Ryan McDonough, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles McDonough of Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to William Ferdinand Marcellino Jr., a son of Mr. Marcellino and the late Mary E. Marcellino of Boston. Msgr. William Maguire performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J.

title: IN MILLWOOD, A SHAGGY COW STORY
description: ''WE had the last great cattle drive in Westchester,'' Lloyd Howard was saying. ''I was out at the ballet and came home late at night and a neighbor had called to say, 'Your Highlands are here, eating our grass.' We brought over a feed pail full of grain to lure them back: if one moves the others follow. A policeman saw us, put on his flasher and brought up the rear.''

title: CATALOGUES PROVIDE A TANTALIZING TOUR OF SHOWS
description: The bothersome thing about living in New York City, where there is forever so much to see, is that we cannot possibly get to see what is happening everywhere else. Right now, I for one have a craving to be simultaneously in New Orleans, in San Francisco, in Detroit, in Boston, in Montreal and in half-a-dozen other cities as well. Nor is this a matter of pathological indecision. It is because there is just too much going on, now and at every other time, not only in this country or on this continent, but in other places as well. It is difficult to pick up a newspaper in any great capital city and not read of something that one would cross the oceans to see.

title: TAPPING EQUITY FOR RETIREMENT INCOME
description: IT is an old-fashioned husbandry that Elsie Hand still abides by, a strict habit of thrift inculcated by a lifetime of spending and saving, of caring for a family and stretching budgets as far as they could go.

title: HARVARD PROFESSOR IS NAMED BY HECKLER FOR FEDERAL POST
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, has named Dr. Shervert Frazier of the Harvard Medicl School to be director of the Naitonal Institute of Mental Health.

title: CAPITAL STYLE
description: One could say we're members of the Amtrak set-not the jet set,'' quipped Arlen Specter, Republican Senator from Pennsylvania, who travels each week between the Senate's nine-room English Tudor family home in Philadelphia and their six-room condominium apartment in the Georgetown section of the nation's capital.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Susan Schultz Is the Bride Of Paul Conroy, Contractor
description: Susan Atherton Schultz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Alan Conroy, a son of Mrs. Joseph L. Conroy of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Conroy.

title: COURSES SPAN THE GLOBE AT L.I. COOKING SCHOOLS
description: WITH the arrival of autumn, the school year begins, but not just for children. Cooking schools in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are gearing up for their fall sessions. And once again, the range of courses from which one can choose spans the culinary globe.

title: Rosemary Gray Weds M. F. Cronin, Lawyer
description: Rosemary Victoria Gray, the daughter of Mrs. John R. Gray and the late Mr. Gray of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Fitzgerald Cronin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Cronin of Bronxville, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I. The Rev. George Rutler performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York City, which was built by the bride's great-grandfather, the late John E. Dordan.

title: Teamsters' Farm Drive Gains
description: Seven years after it promised the United Farm Workers it would stay out of farm fields, the teamsters' union has won the right to represent workers on a California farm. Lettuce and celery workers at the Major Farms voted 56 to 23 Monday to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said Pete Maturino, business agent for Local 890 of the teamsters. The teamsters' organizing effort began after a 1977 pact between them union and the farm workers expired.

title: No Headline
description: Corinne Cariello Married

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE National Park Service is planning a bathing beach and expanded recreational facilities along the New Jersey side of the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, but no one knows when they might materialize.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TELEPHONNG ALOFT, TRACKING FALL'S FOLIAGE
description: A Way to Stay In Touch When Aboard a Plane

title: ANNE C. BECKER FOREST HILLS BRIDE
description: Anne Campbell Becker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Valentine Becker of Forest Hills, Queens, was married there yesterday to Gregory John O'Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph O'Connell of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. M. Joseph Farley performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Paul McKeever, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Cilista Clare Eberle Is the Bride of James Turner
description: The marriage of Cilista Clare Eberle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Denman Eberle of Manchester, Mass., to James Riford Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lazear Turner of Pittsford, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. George I. Hunter performed the ceremony at Emanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Fiction 1 AUGUST, by Judith Rossner. (Warner, $4.50.) The five-year relationship of two women, a teen-age patient and her analyst. 2 THE WICKED DAY, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) King Arthur, fulfilling a prophecy of Merlin, falls into an incestuous relationship. 3 HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $3.95.) The struggle for money and power in Tinseltown. 4 THURSTON HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) Three generations of a San Francisco family. 5 SAVANNAH, by Eugenia Price. (Berkley, $3.95.) The romance and ambitions of a young man in the Old South. 6 THE SEDUCTION OF PETER S., by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $3.95.) The sudden, danger-filled success of a long-out-of-work actor. 7 THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. 8 IDAHO! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.95.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches a territory teeming with gold seekers. 9 WINTER'S TALE, by Mark Helprin. (Pocket, $4.50.) A fantastic yet realistic look at Manhattan between the late 19th century and the year 2000. 10 PARTISANS, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) A doughty band sets out to restore King Peter of Yugoslavia to power during World War II. 11 THE MADNESS OF A SEDUCED WOMAN, by Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. (Bantam, $3.95.) A woman's search for love ends in murder charges and institutionalization. 12 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Warner, $4.95.) Murder in an Italian monastery. 13 SECRET OF THE SIXTH MAGIC, by Lyndon Hardy. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $2.95.) The laws of logic are under attack in a fantasy land called Arcadia. 14 ON A PALE HORSE, by Piers Anthony. (Del Rey/ Ballantine, $2.95.) The first volume in a fantasy about the reincarnation of the deceased. 15 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic romance survives the stresses of World War II. Nonfiction General 1 ON WINGS OF EAGLES, by Ken Follett. (NAL/ Signet, $4.50.) The rescue of two Americans from an Iranian prison. 2 FATAL VISION, by Joe McGinniss. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) The case of an Ivy League graduate, doctor and convicted killer of his wife and daughters. 3 THE PETER PAN SYNDROME, by Dan Kiley. (Avon, $3.95.) The plight of men who have never grown up: a psychologist's analysis. 4 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 5 CHICKENHAWK, by Robert Mason. (Penguin, $3.95.) The life of a helicopter pilot in Vietnam. 6 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 OUT ON A LIMB, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $3.95.) The actress's autobiography. 8 LIVING, LOVING & LEARNING, by Leo F. Buscaglia. (Fawcett Crest, $5.95.) Inspirational talks by a California professor. 9 MEGATRENDS, by John Naisbitt. (Warner, $3.95.) Predictions about America in the next decade. 10 BLUE HIGHWAYS, by William Least Heat Moon. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) The back roads of America. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 2 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1984. 3 IN SEARCH OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $4.95.) A new collection of the syndicated ''Far Side'' cartoons. 4 COLOR ME BEAUTIFUL, by Carole Jackson. (Ballantine, $8.95.) Beauty tips for women. 5 SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Macmillan, $4.95.) Newly minted words that ''deserve to appear in the dictionary.''

title: Marjory S. Johnson to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Johnson of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marjory Stuart Johnson to Joseph Anthony Reagan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reagan of Albany. The wedding is to be in December.

title: Arab Engineer Shot in Spain
description: A 32-year-old Saudi Arabian engineer, Nasser Abdul, died after being shot in the head at a cafe here Friday night and one of two Saudi companions, Karim Ibrahim, was wounded in the face, the police said today.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF LOOKING PROPER
description: If one is inclined to think that most business suits look alike, all it takes is a luncheon at a gathering place for executives to see how varied proper dressing can be. A casual tabulation at one recent lunch at New York's ''21'' Club turned up no fewer than 10 variations of the gray or navy suit, five shirt styles worn with seven types of ties knotted in four ways and an equal number of men in belts as in suspenders. As many men eschewed pocket squares as chose them.

title: MICHIGAN IS UPSET BY WASHINGTON, 20-11
description: A week after ending Miami's 13-game winning streak, Michigan today became the victim of an upset when Washington dominated the Wolverines for a 20-11 triumph before a crowd of 103,072.

title: PISCATAWAY TRIUMPHS, 26-13
description: Eric Wainwright, a senior tailback, ran for 195 yards on 14 carries and scored three touchdowns yesterday to propel Piscataway past Hillsborough, 26-13, in Hillsborough.

title: THE ROYAL BALLET MODIFIES ITS TRADITIONS
description: Like many eminent, well-established ballet companies around the world, Great Britain's Royal Ballet is occasionally accused of growing tradition-bound and stuffily conventional. Yet, under Norman Morrice's direction, the Royal does appear to be trying to refute such charges and in the past few seasons it has given opportunities to several young choreographers, the latest of them being Ashley Page. This summer, it offered the world premiere of Mr. Page's ''A Broken Set of Rules,'' which I saw at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, on a recent trip to London.

title: MINDING THE MONEY
description: Peter Passell writes about economics for the editorial page of The New York Times. BEYOND MONETARISM

title: COCA TEA TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT AGRIBUSINESS IS DOING TO ANTIBIOTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraternities Are Suspended
description: American International College, where a freshman died of acute alcohol poisoning, has suspended all campus fraternities and sororities.

title: BEARS ROAMING SUBDIVISION UPSET RESIDENTS IN COLORADO
description: Black bears roaming an exclusive, remote subdivision 15 miles west of Vail have upset some residents and led them into a dispute with the Colorado Division of Wildlife.

title: DESIRABLE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Strasburger Becomes a Bride
description: Alison Strasburger and Richard Scott Ressler, both magna cum laude graduates of Brown University and Harlan Fiske Stone Scholars at the Columbia University School of Law, were married yesterday at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: ALTERED STATES The Zucchini Disaster For gardeners, 1984 has been a time of trouble and a test of faith. Their tomatoes, peppers and eggplant ripened, sure enough. What's almost inconceivable is that the zucchini let them down.
description: This steadfast squash is usually the most manic of vegetables. Get it past the vine borer and it will produce beyond reason, or need.

title: CALIFORNIA RULING LIMITS JURISDICTION IN PCB CASE
description: A judge's ruling has halted a nine-month investigation by the San Francisco District Attorney's office into allegations of violations of state laws on hazardous waste at the Todd Shipyards Corporation facility here.

title: MAN TO DEFEND HIS UNMOWN LAWN IN COURT
description: A self-described environmentalist is scheduled to appear in court next week to defend his right to grow a ''small meadow'' instead of a lawn in front of the house he rents in the suburb of Kenmore.

title: A 'DEALER' SETTLES INTO ROLE OF INVESTOR AND DEVELOPER
description: PHILIP PILEVSKY wants to obliterate his reputation as a fipper. He has become an investor and he is building a portfolio. This year alone, he said, he has bouth $400 million worth of property, and he may reach abillion dollars before thyear end.s Or, conservatively, $800 million.

title: DANCING SHADOWS AT PENGUIN
description: IN ITS valiant quest for original plays, the Penguin Repertory Company here has been holding regular ''Play/Thing'' readings by emerging playwrights.

title: On Language ; Hide That Agenda
description: Thumbing through The New Yorker this summer, Serena Rattazzi of Port Washington, N.Y., came across the phrase

Apter and Nagayo Sawa.Illustrated. 271 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.BEHIND THE MASKOn Sexual Demons, Sacred Mothers,Transvestites, Gangsters, Drifters andOther Japanese Cultural Heroes.By Ian Buruma.Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Pantheon. $16.95.

title: CABLEVISION PLANS MAJOR NEWS SHOW FOR THE ISLAND
description: SHOULD Long Island have its own nightly television news show? Just about every elected official, business and civic leader on the Island emphatically says yes.

title: REAGAN FOES SAY THEIR RIGHTS WERE VIOLATED
description: Protesters against President Reagan said Friday that their civil rights were violated when sheriff's deputies put them into a roped-off parking lot at a Labor Day rally for the President.

title: Weather Halts Salvage Of Radioactive Cargo
description: A strong wind and five-foot seas halted the salvage today of the radioactive cargo of a French freighter that sank three weeks ago, a Government official said.

title: TALKS IN RECESS
description: The assembly lines at the huge Buick complex in Flint were silent today and pickets waved placards as the United Automobile Workers began selected local strikes at 13 General Motors plants.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Illegal Marriage Love has legal limits, and Mary Ann Garton Bass crossed the threshold when she married Danny James Sullivan in 1978. Unbeknown to Mr. Sullivan, it seems, Mrs. Bass was the mother who had given him up for adoption when he was three years old.

title: Fashion View; THE PARIS COURTURE
description: CASTIGATING THE COUTURE IS EASY. It is, after all, a fashion fantasyland in which a simple made-to-order dress - and most are far from simple - costs about $5,000; a suit, in the environs of $12,000, and something for evening (embroidered, of course), $50,000 and more. Quite obviously, the couture is an enclave that only the very wealthy can enter as full participants. It is not surprising, then, that an outsider is at first stunned, even appalled, at the very thought of the couture in a world filled with pockets of want. But here it is, openly displaying opulence and parading astronomically tagged temptations.

title: No Headline
description: Karen Dalton Is Bride

title: Suffering in the Streets ''Deinstitutionalization'' is a 22-letter mouthful that once referred to a reform of the mental health system. Now it should be read as a euphemism for official cruelty. A forthright new report by the American Psychiatric Association makes that clear - and belatedly underlines the heavy obligation of state officials to do something about it. New York, which led the deinstitutionalization movement, should be among the first to take responsibility for correcting its failure.
description: The idea began in the 1960's with popular revulsion against the huge, cruel institutions that had for years warehoused the mentally ill. Hundreds of thousands of chronically ill patients were discharged from overcrowded state hospitals in the belief that their treatment could continue more humanely in the community.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
SALE OF GARRETT COLLECTION TO RESUME IN ZURICH
description: The sale of foreign and ancient coins from the famous Garrett Collection will resume next month in Zurich, Switzerland. A six-session auction to be held Oct. 16-18 will encompass more than 1,800 lots, including important selections of Celtic, Greek, late Roman, Byzantine and European coins.

title: Jerome Murphy, A Lawyer, Wed To Lisa D'Amato
description: Lisa D'Amato, a daughter of Senator and Mrs. Alfonse M. D'Amato of Island Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Jerome C. Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Murphy of Rockville Centre, L.I. Msgr. Edward L. Melton performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre.

title: HOT-DOG STANDS FIND HOME IN KENT
description: IN Kent, a picturesque Housatonic River community long

title: College Soccer Continues to Progress
description: Soccer at the college level continues to progress as vigorously as at the youth and interscholastic levels even as the North American Soccer League struggles to survive.

title: Q&A
description: What Form of Ownership?

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHERE HAS THE WAVE GONE?
description: WAVING is one of the greatest of the small gestures of mankind, yet people these days seem reluctant to take part.

title: Main Street, R.I.P.
description: Main Street is dead. Dead as the Bijou Theater with double-feature programs that changed three times a week. Dead as the dry-goods store that used to sit at the intersection of Washington Avenue. Dead as the trolley car that used to clang down the middle from the First National Bank all the way out to the Bosky Dale Amusement Park. Dead as Sinclair Lewis. Dead, dead, dead.

title: Diana Robb Wed In Southampton
description: Diana Wagstaff Robb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hampden Robb Jr., of Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony Taylor McDowell, a son of Yolande M. McDowell of Norwalk, Conn., and the late James H. McDowell. The Rev. Ronald G. Abrams performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Dune Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: On the Record ; Treasury Aide on Economy
description: Remarks by Under Secretary of the Treasury Beryl Sprinkel at a news conference at the United States Embassy in Tokyo on Wednesday:

title: International
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1984 Western nations are divided over a confidential World Bank proposal for an emergency aid fund for the poorest African nations, Western diplomats said. The diplomats said the confidential World Bank report gives the gloomiest possible picture of black Africa's current prospects, saying that unlike most other regions of the developing world its economic problems have been growing worse rather than better. (Page 1, Column 2.) Cuban advisers have been seen by almost everyone in the Nicaraguan town of Santa Clara. But the commander of a military training base there, Lieut. Carlos Gonzales, said no Cubans were in the area and insisted in an interview that he had not seen a single foreign military adviser in his five years of service along the Honduran border. The United States has reported that four Cuban instructors were killed in a rebel air attack on the Santa Clara base this month. (1:1.)

title: Vivaldi: The Four Seasons
description: A film directed by Jacques Fournier; musical direction by Lorin Maazel MGM/Home Video 46 minutes. $59.95

title: THAILAND'S TOP GENERAL MAY COVET HIS COUNTRY'S TOP JOB
description: When Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda flew to the United States last week, exhausted, for a medical checkup at Emory University in Atlanta, he left behind an unstable political situation that seems to defy resolution.

title: GRAND HOTEL MEETS GRAHAM GREENE
description: Susan Isaacs' most recent novel is ''Almost Paradise.'' THE MIRACLE

title: RACE BEGINS FOR TEICHER, DIOGUARDI
description: WHITE PLAINS HOURS after winning the Democratic nomination for the 20th Congressional Distict, Oren J. Teicher was at the Metro-North station in New Rochelle, shaking hands and thanking voters in his hometown, where he received his largest margin of victory. There, he bumped into Joseph J. DioGuardi, the Republican-Conservative candidate he will face in November.

title: IN PEEKSKILL, THE FOUNDRY BEHIND THE ART
description: THERE is an 18-foot bronze whale at the Vancouver Zoo in British Columbia, Canada, with an odd marking on it that looks like a T standing on the top of an X.

title: THE WORLD
description: Latin Debtors Seek Dialogue

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Felix Mendelssohn was the most poised and temperate of the early romantic composers - a dignified conservative in an age of revolution. It is perhaps because of Mendelssohn's spiritual detachment from the Zeitgeist of his time that the majority of his compositions are rarely played nowadays.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ''A WOMAN'S workplace is in the home'' might well be the slogan of Marion Behr of Edison. Mrs. Behr, co- author with Wendy Lazar of Norwood, is now distributing their second edition of ''Women Working Home,'' a national directory of women's businesses operated from home.

title: STATE CALLED ILL-PREPARED FOR HURRICANES
description: EVEN before Hurricane Diana began gathering strength and threatening the East Coast last week, Federal and New Jersey officials were expressing serious concern that the state was ill- prepared to protect the lives of its coastal residents if a major hurricane - which many believe is long overdue - struck.

title: THE P.L.O.'S INDLUENTIAL VOICE AT THE U.N.
description: Jane Rosen is the United Nations correspondent for The Guardian of London.

title: ECHOES OF CHINA JUST OFF THE MAINLAND
description: When I first arrived in Taiwan as a graduate student in 1961, a friend suggested a bus trip along the island's precipitous East Coast Highway. For 60 miles the road is cut into the sheer face of marble cliffs 500 to 1,000 feet above the turquoise Pacific Ocean. It is a single lane wide, without protective guard rails. Riding on the outside of the bus, jammed with Taiwanese farmers carrying trussed live chickens and with tattooed aborigines from the mountains above us, I had the sensation of being on the world's most scenic roller coaster. Each turn on the serpentine road seemed to threaten a plunge over the edge. From time to time the track mercifully descended into narrow jungle-covered valleys, where we disembarked for a bowl of fresh pineapple or a drink of guava juice at small roadside stands made of split bamboo and woven straw matting.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: OLD BUILDINGS, NEW USES

title: DESIGNED FOR PRIVACY
description: The discreet adulterer once preferred to maintain a hideaway-a place perhaps like Stanford White's tasteful turn-of-the-century bower above a toy company in New York's left district. The Parisian architect Pierre Rahoult says, however, that this type of pied-a-terre, or garconniere-usually an intimately decorated, small, keenly private apartment-is simply out of date: ''Nobody cares about that anymore. There are too many hotels, motels, cars and jets.''

title: Robert Trig ere, 82, Is Dead; Brother of Fashion Designer
description: Robert Trig ere, who was instrumental in the formation of the fashion house run by his sister, the designer Pauline Trig ere, died Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: NISSAN MAKES A STAND IN DIXIE
description: It is hard to visit the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A.'s vast new $660 million pickup-truck assembly plant in Smyrna, Tenn., without at first being teased by the irony of its being there at all.

title: 'CUKOO' DRAMATIZES A BATTLE FOR CONTROL
description: DALE WASSERMAN'S ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' currently being staged at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, has been a problem-plagued production. It has experienced several cast and director changes, technical problems and a postponed opening.

title: Kennedy and Conspiracy
description: BEST SELLERS

title: CREW LEARS THE WAYS OF VIKINGS AT SEA
description: Leaning over the railing of a passing Governors Island ferry, a traveler shouted to a group of men in a squat, wooden sailing vessel: ''What are you guys doing? Sailing around the world?''

title: Basque Separatist Is Force-Fed by French
description: A Spanish Basque separatist who has been on a hunger strike with seven compatriots for more than four weeks is being force-fed by doctors, a senior official of the French Justice Ministry said today.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SOCIAL workers in the state's Division of Youth and Family Services are under such stress because of caseload size and lack of resources that their own physical and mental health is at risk and they cannot properly serve their clients, according to an independent study by Dr. Janet L. Cahill , associate professor of psychology at Glassboro State College.

title: COSMOS LOSE TO STING AND MISS PLAYOFFS
description: The Cosmos missed the North American Soccer League playoffs for the first time since 1975 as the Chicago Sting defeated the five-time champions, 1-0, tonight in the last game of the regular season.

title: Table Settings
description: Starring Stockard Channing, Mindy Cohn, Eileen Heckart, Robert Klein, James Kushner, Dinah Manoff, Peter Riegert; written and directed for the stage and conceived for video by James Lapine RKO Home Video 90 minutes. $39.95

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL WHEN
description: Susan Stevenson, a British athlete, came to the United States, she came looking for gold, and she succeeded. At the International Games for the Disabled, she won a gold medal in the javelin toss, plus a bundle of lesser medals, but there will be an unanticipated bonus as well - a gold wedding band.

title: PANAMA SAYS IT WILL RUN MILITARY SCHOOL GIVEN UP BY U.S.
description: Panamanian military authorities have announced that an American training school being turned over to Panama will be kept open under Panamanian administration.

title: POPE URGES INDIANS AND 'NEWCOMERS' TO RECONCILE
description: -MARIE AMONG THE HURONS, Ontario, Sept. 15 - Pope John Paul II, visiting this shrine honoring 17th century missionaries slain by Indians, told a crowd of 80,000 people today that it was time for a reconciliation between ''the original peoples and the newcomers to this continent.''

title: A COZY JOURNEY THROUGH NEW ZEALAND
description: Rocking through New Zealand's scenic prodigality by train and then writing about it is something like joining a secret brotherhood and then revealing the handshake. One feels a nagging guilt, a sense of betraying those resourceful travelers who've found a good thing and want to keep it out of the tourist ads.

title: OVERCROWDED STATE PRISONS BURDEN COUNTIES
description: With New York State's prisons at 116 percent of capacity, county and municipal jails throughout the state this summer have housed state-sentenced inmates at record levels, according to the State Department of Correctional Services.

title: A Campaign For New Voters
description: Paul Bass's article, ''Drives for Registering More Voters Intensify'' (Aug. 19), was of special interest to the League of Women Voters of Connecticut and local Leagues around the state that are participating in a national nonpartisan voter registration drive in conjunction with RKO radio stations, its affiliates and other cooperating radio stations.

title: PAWN FORMATION ISN'T EVERYTHING
description: There is a strong tendency in contemporary tournament play to elevate the factor of pawn structure to the point where it entirely dominates strategy, but this can lead to just the same sort of excesses as, for example, the singleminded preoccupation with mating attacks did in long-bygone days.

title: Kemble Lickle Is Bride Of W. T. O'Donnell 3d
description: Kemble Carpenter Lickle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Lickle of Montchanin, Del., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married in Greenville, Del., yesterday to William T. O'Donnell 3d, the son of Patricia Hall of Duxbury, Mass., and the late John B. O'Donnell. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: Miss Meyer Has Nuptials In Watch Hill
description: Elizabeth Taft Meyer, a daughter of Mrs. Henry H. Bard of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late S. Willets Meyer, was married yesterday to James H. Eaton 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eaton 3d of Andover, Mass., and Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Seymour St. John, former headmaster of the Choate School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Watch Hill (R.I.) Chapel.

title: SALVADOR'S 'MASAS' ARE FEEDING THE REVOLUTION
description: They call the Salvadoran Army ''the enemy,'' refer to one other as ''comrade'' and say the leftist guerrilla forces that control a third of the countryside are ''the army of the people.'' No one is certain how many Salvadorans feel this way, but it has been estimated that between 150,000 and 300,000 of the more than five million inhabitants of this small country actively support one of the five leftist factions making up the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

title: Laura E. Bellamy Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, N.Y., Laura Elizabeth Bellamy and Steven Brewster Fitzpatrick, 1983 graduates of Cornell University, were married yesterday by the Rev. Edd Payne.

title: THE WAR OVER 'STAR WARS'
description: Michael R. Gordon covers national security for National Journal. BEAM WEAPONS

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A STUDENT LEARNS TO COPE WITH DYSLEXIA
description: MY first memory of having problems with learning was when I was 6 or 7 years old and in Pixie Brownies. We all got cups with jokes on them to drink juice in. At home, my mother could read the jokes to me. There at Pixies, all the other girls could read, but I couldn't. Letters used to ''wave'' at me. ''Pup'' turned into ''peb,'' ''felt'' into ''left.'' I remember writing the word ''zero'' in school one day. I was so proud of myself because I made the ''Z'' look so much like the teacher's ''Z.'' But then she was angry because I made the ''E'' upside down.

title: No Headline
description: New & Noteworthy

title: Yanks Strand 12 and Lose, 4-3
