description: Like a man dodging falling pianos, Al Nipper slipped past one peril after another yesterday. Then finally, just when it looked as if one of the pianos might hit him, along came Bob Stanley to rescue the day for the Boston Red Sox and Nipper.

title: LETTERS
description: ARE WOMEN NATURALLY DOMINANT?

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: 'Social Tragedy' Of the Homeless Mentally Ill

title: THE MALE DIFFERENCE
description: The parade of skin-care products tailored to men's needs and tastes grows longer every year. While the market for such products (not including shaving products) is still a relatively new one - it dates back no more than about 10 years - sales nationwide have jumped from just over $5 million in 1980 to more than $12.5 million in 1983, Product Marketing magazine reports. Between 1982 and 1983 alone, sales rose over 100 percent.

title: OUT OF THE BULLPEN, AND INTO PENNANT RACE
description: JOHN WOCKENFUSS played for the Detroit Tigers for nine years and never was he as valuable to them as he was this year, when he did not play for them. But that's nothing. Greg Gross never has played for the Tigers; yet they have to credit him as being a most valuable person for them, that is, a person who made the most valuable decision of the year.

title: SOVIET REDUCING SUBSIDIZED OIL EXPORTS TO ALLIES
description: The Soviet Union, faced with rising oil-production costs and stagnating output, has begun to reduce its subsidized exports to its allies, according to a study of Soviet energy prospects published by the Brookings Institution.

title: SEBASTIANI ADOPTS A PREMIUM LOOK
description: SONOMA, Calif.

title: THE CAPITOL AND THE KREMLIN
description: Alan Tonelson is the associate editor of Foreign Policy. THE MAKING OF AMERICA'S SOVIET POLICY

title: FEDERAL LAW ON COASTAL LAND USE, AFTER 12 YEARS, IS HAVING WIDE IMPACT
description: Using the Federal Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972 as one of its weapons, New York State managed earlier this year to block the sale of 278 acres of federally owned woodlands, wetlands, meadows and bluffs at Montauk Point on Long Island to private developers.

title: OLD WORLD CHARM IN BOSTON
description: Today's condominium apartment buildings suposedly carry with them the assurance that everything works. Their spick-and-span kitchens, soundproof windows and crisp white surfaces offer instant comfort and convenience for those in search of the new.

title: JAMAICA WATER UNDER ATTACK
description: THIS summer's heavy rains have not eased the problems facing Jamaica Water Supply Company, arguably the largest well-water system in the country and the only private water utility serving New York City residents.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ENTREPRENEUR TICK?
description: WHAT magic ingredients cause entrepreneurial outbursts in areas like Silicon Valley and Route 128? The answer, according to Zenos Block, who will be associate director of N.Y.U.'s Center for Entrepreneurial Studies, is ''a combination of capital, a university environment and something else - a small number of people pushing their ideas.''

title: Tuition Refund Over Job Pact
description: Myrna Baxter, 21 years old, a business college graduate, has received a tuition refund of $6,210 because she did not find a job within 120 days after graduating, Miss Baxter, who had studied computer programming, was the first student to take Brown Mackie College up on an offer of a tuition refund. She received the money in a check Friday even though she found a job a month after the guarantee expired.

title: NEW CHOICES
description: Decorating pied-a-terre is much like outfitting the first small apartment. Virtually everything has to have at lest one and preferrably two functions.

title: 'CINDERELLA' GRANT
description: Since 1966, Brooklyn Union Gas Company's ''Cinderella'' grants have sparked the restoration of residential properties in decaying areas of Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. Until now the program touched only older houses, but with a $25,000 grant to Springfield Gardens Estates, a modest development of 32 semidetached, two-family homes nearing completion at 160th Street and 137th Avenue in Queens, the utility is lending a helping hand with new construction.

title: WHERE A CLAY ARMY COMES VIVIDLY TO LIFE
description: MICHAEL SPECTER holds a Henry R. Luce Fellowship and is a correspondent for The Far Eastern Economic Review.

title: A Record for Piggott
description: All Lester Piggott needed was a mount for a chance at bettering Frank Buckle's 200-year-old English record of turning in 28 classic thoroughbred racing victories in his country.

title: FROM FASCISM TO FELLINI
description: William Murray writes frequently from Italy for The New Yorker and other magazines. His latest books are ''Italy: The Fatal Gift'' and ''Tip on a Dead Crab.'' PASSION AND DEFIANCE

title: ORCHESTRA'S REBATE PLAN SPARKS CALLS
description: CONCERTGOERS in the New York City area have responded enthusiastically to an unusual invitation by the Westchester-based Philharmonia Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra. The orchestra is offering to pay audience members to attend the group's first New York City concert series.

title: APPARENT 'MARRIAGE' ENDS ALIMONY
description: A woman who was living with a man to whom she was not married can be denied alimony because she gave the ''outward appearance of marriage,'' which was prohibited by her divorce agreement, the Massachusetts Supreme Court has ruled.

title: ENSEMBLE CONTEST AT CONSERVATORY
description: ''A MUSICIAN knows what a good performance is,'' said Wilma Machover of White Plains, director of the Adult Music Center of the Westchester Conservatory of Music and one of the judges in the center's first amateur chamber music ensemble competition. ''You could say things like unity of performance, proper within its style, beautifully performed - but each judge has his own criteria and 'good' is in the ears of each qualified judge.''

title: IOWANS VOICE DISCONTENT ON REAGAN BUT APPEAR RELUCTANT ON SWITCHING
description: Janet Kramer is just the sort of voter Walter F. Mondale must attract in November if he is to defeat President Reagan. A survey taker for a market research concern, Mrs. Kramer voted for Mr. Reagan in 1980, but she expresses rising discontent with his policies, particularly in the area of religion.

title: PRODUCER IS WED TO LISA SCHIFTER
description: The marriage of Lisa Schifter and Leland Joseph Greenberg, 1979 graduates of Sarah Lawrence College, took place yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. The Rev. Eugene Carson Blake, a Presbyterian minister and former general secretary of the World Council of Churches in Geneva, performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy Hoversten Wed To William Battey Jr.
description: Nancy Richardson Hoversten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moris Hoversten of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to William Roy Battey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Battey of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. J. Clark Grew, assisted by the Rev. Alan French, performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: A BANNER YEAR FOR CHAMBER MUSIC
description: -MUSIC programs will be blanketing the state this season, and the northwest corner of Connecticut not only offers the last concert of the summer season (this afternoon's 3 o'clock finale at Music Mountain - call 824-7126 if you'd like to attend), but also boasts the earliest start for its two fall series.

title: Revolutionary Nature Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Canyon Visits Down
description: Attendance at Grand Canyon National Park dropped sharply in August for the second straight month, according to park officials.

title: OUT-OF-WEDLOCK BIRYHS ON INCREASE IN STATE
description: students take their babies to

title: THE GREAT OIL ERA ENDS IN TEXAS
description: ZAISAN INC. produces no oil or gas nor anthing remotely related to either. Yet that young computer company, and dozens of others like it, are the new hope of Texas.

title: MENADERING REVUE
description: SATIRE should have us laughing on the outside, but it must have a distinct target and a serious undercurrent. Maybe it dies on Saturday night, as theater lore goes, but at least it is out to kill first.

title: THE DAY THE TEMPLE OPENS
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is the author of ''Kosode: 16th to 19th Century Textiles from the Nomura Collection'' (Kodansha International).

title: A CAMPAIGNER LIFTS ITALIAN PRIDE
description: HARTFORD WHETHER or not she wins their votes, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, has won the admiration of many fellow Italian-Americans, the largest single ethnic group in the state.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
IRVING PENN'S PEOPLE REIGN ABOVE THE HUMDRUM WORLD
description: For the purpose of understanding the photographs of Irving Penn, the world must be divided into two classes of people. On the one hand, there are ordinary people. On the other, there are people who pose for photographs in Vogue, the fashion magazine for which Penn has worked since 1943.

title: Black Narcissus
description: Starring Deborah Kerr, David Farrar, Sabu, Jean Simmons, Flora Robson; directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, 1946 VidAmerica 100 minutes. $59.95

title: No Headline
description: Fountain House Given A G

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
A 'TRIVIAL PURSUIT' ADDICT CONFESSES
description: I FINALLY got to play Trivial Pursuit. Occasionally

title: SEEKING RESPECT
description: THE TEMP

title: HARTFORD'S GLIMPSE OF ITS EARLY DAYS
description: HARTFORD

title: Drug Tests Questioned In New Air Force Report
description: An Air Force report has concluded that drug testing procedures at a Brooks Air Force Base laboratory are reliable, but some results do not meet scientific standards set by an investigative panel.

title: ATTACK IN GULF SAID TO KILL 11 ON GERMAN SHIP
description: Britain said today that 11 crewmen were killed by an Iraqi missile attack this week on a West German oil-supply vessel in the Persian Gulf.

title: THE NEW AMERICAN PIED-A-TERRE
description: Once a French phrase that called to mind the glamorous life of the rich, the pied-a-terre has been reborn as a modern American phenomenon. No longer a luxurious response to convenience or whim, it has become a necessity for an incerasing number of Americans. Today it is not uncommon for two-career couples to find themselves living in separate locations.

title:
ANTIQUES;
IT'S ABOUT TIME TO COLLECT OLD CLOCKS
description: BECAUSE David Morgan, coproprietor with his wife, Betty, of the Antique Clock Gallery here, believes that antique-clock repair is a dying art and that it is becoming more difficult to find people to carry it on, he spends considerable time giving private and group lessons.

title: MEDICARE DOCTOR'S FEE CONTAINMENT GONE AWRY: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: ALTERED STATES; Dining A La Cart
description: A State Supreme Court justice has upheld the city's right to ban sidewalk vendors from certain areas, but Mayor Koch has decided, wisely, not to push that right to a painful extreme.

title: A SKEPTICAL ISREL TESTS THE ACTUAL VALUE OF TWO HEADS
description: Imagine for a moment a dead heat in the American elections so close that the Republicans and Democrats had to get together to form an administration. Setting aside the Constitution, imagine an administration in which it was agreed that Walter Mondale would serve as President for the first two years, while Ronald Reagan acted as Vice President and Secretary of State. In the second half of the term, the two would reverse roles. Half the Cabinet would be Republican and half Democratic. In Congress, Republicans and Democrats would be asked to support the same legislation. . . .

title: WOMEN IN TAKE-CHARGE ROLES STRIDE INTO TV'S LIMLIGHT
description: When Americans flip on their television sets beginning this week, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, won't be the only woman they see in a role traditionally reserved for men. On new prime-time series this season a surprising number of leading characters will be women, including the head of a national advertising agency, a fashion industry mogul, a psychiatrist, a news reporter, space commanders - both good and evil - in an intergalactic war, and a legion of new recruits to television's already burgeoning army of female crime fighters.

title:
GARDENING;
FALL IS THE TIME TO IMPROVE A LAWN
description: OUR northern turf grasses prefer cool weather, and, as noted previously, the fall season is the best time of the year to do most anything to a lawn that needs to be done.

title: V.S. NAIPAUL: 'IT IS OUT OF THIS VIOLENCE I'VE ALWAYS WRITTEN'
description: Mel Gussow is a drama critic for The New York Times.

title: FICKLE METS' FANS MISS OUT ON GOODEN
description: AFTER years of believing otherwise, George Steinbrenner has come to realize that winning, and not a manager named Billy Martin, lures fans to Yankee Stadium. ''Fans don't care who's managing,'' Steinbrenner said earlier this season. ''They want a winner.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A REMEMBRANCE OF FAIRS PAST
description: TO some, the cool breezes of late September carry a warning that soon the leaves must fall and be raked. To others, they are a sign that it is not long before the snow will fly. But to many who grew up in or near Danbury, the chill in the air brings back memories of childhood and an event second only to Christmas in excitement.

title: THE SAME PLAN FOR PARIS AND NEW YORK
description: He found the midtown apartment in a 1930's building just west of Fifth Avenue a few years ago, when he was coming to New York frequently but still living in Paris. ''At the time I thought it would be less expensive than living in a hotel, but I never thought I would actually move here.'' said Didier Grumbach, president of Saint Laurent Rive Gauche and in charge of Yves Saint Laurent licenses in the United States.

title: THE INTELLECTUAL HISTORY OF JIM CROW
description: THE CRUCIBLE OF RACE

title: WHERE SHARK FIN CROWNS THE MEAL
description: -FEI LO is the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes From the Chinese Teahouse'' and the forthcoming ''The Chinese Banquet Cookbook'' (both Crown). She teaches Chinese cooking and nutrition at the China Institute in America and at her home in Montclair, N. J.

title: PORTABLE SOUND
description: A woman in John Updike's novel, ''Bech: A Book'' observes that ''trans-atlantic men are the best,'' voicing her preference for a jet-age subspecies of male who keeps shutting between continents. Similarly, one now sees frequent references to ''bicoastal'' people who go back and forth between New York and Los Angeles. And finally, there are masses of weekend commuters scurrying to and fro between dual residences and millions of students alternating between school and home.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Honoring Lennon
description: Shortly after John Lennon was slain in December 1980, the New York City Council voted to name a triangle in Central Park in honor of the former Beatle. The name chosen was Straw- berry Fields, after a Lennon song, ''Strawberry Fields Forever.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are starting a new dispensation and I am going to act responsibly. If I find a colored or Indian member capable of handling a portfolio, I will not hesitate to appoint him.'' - President P. W. Botha of South Africa. (3:1.)

title: THE REGION
description: Toxic Spillage In Connecticut

title: Syrian Forces Ordered To Help Find Reporter
description: President Hafez al-Assad has ordered Syrian security forces to help find a Reuters correspondent who disappeared in Lebanon 17 days ago, a Government spokesman said today.

title:
GARDENING;
FALL IS THE TIME TO IMPROVE A LAWN
description: OUR northern turf grasses prefer cool weather, and, as noted previously, the fall season is the best time of the year to do most anything to a lawn that needs to be done.

title: THE REGION
description: Police Scolded In School Search

title:
ART;
FOR LANDSCAPES, 'STUDY PICTURES AND NATURE TOGETHER'
description: ALTHOUGH landscape painting no longer enjoys the pre- eminent position it held in the 19th there are still many rewards to be gained from the study of nature, and we would be wrong to assume that contemporary artists have nothing new or interesting to tell us about the subject.

title: NIXDORF TAKES ON THE AMERICANS
description: PADERBORN, West Germany

title: WHEN THE GIANTS RULE THE WORLD
description: SUPER BOWL. The love that dares not speak its name. For Giants fans. Forevermore. Or so it seemed, when suddenly last Sunday. . .a notion, not quite a dream, no bigger than the inch we never made on third and inches, this notion dropped in as if to say hello. Without warning, at the two-minute warning. Giants 28, Cowboys 7. Hello from Palo Alto.

title: YON CAN GO HOME AGAIN
description: URBANA, Ill.

title: LEMON LAW CASES SEEM TO BE RISING
description: IT looks as though the new

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BECAUSE of a $40,000 donation from General Foods, the new season at the Performing Arts Center on the State University of New York's Purchase campus is being expanded. The gift is the first instance of corporate sponsorship in the center's six-year history.

title: SOVIET UNION SEIZES AN AMERICAN VESSEL WITH 5 MEN ABOARD
description: The Soviet Union has seized five American citizens and their 120-foot motor vessel in Arctic waters and detained them in a remote area of the eastern Soviet Union, the State Department said today.

title: WEEKEND SHUTTLE
description: On Thursday night, it begins. Suitcases, hampers, overflowing cartons and bulgy plastic sacks are piled in a corner of the lobby in my New York apartment house, ready to be stuffed into the car at Friday's first light. The next morning, the rest of the equipage appears; the collapsible boxes, the sullen pet in a wicker carrier, the overflowing ice chest and finally, struggling with loaded shopping bags, the family. Rarely do they get everything into the car trunk without sharp words. Is this the beginning of a cross-continental vacation or a move to a new building?

title: Piniaha Gains 190 Yards as Sparta Wins
description: John Piniaha, a senior halfback, ran for 190 yards on 14 carries and scored 2 touchdowns to lead Sparta to a 35-7 victory over Vernon in Sparta yesterday.

title: DANCE: MANUEL ALUM IN SOLO PERFORMANCE, 'ON THE WAY'
description: In his ''On the Way,'' Manuel Alum seemed to dance his way through evolution. And because there were moments when he appeared to be in several stages of evolution simultaneously, the 55-minute solo that he presented Wednesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio implied that an evolutionary drama is still going on within the psyches of contemporary human beings.

title: Hatchet at Ferraro's Event
description: A man with a hatchet was taken into custody today outside a hotel where Geraldine A. Ferraro was attending a fund-raising event, the police said. The man was arrested when security agents noticed the hatchet a few minutes after the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee passed nearby on her way into the Hotels at Syracuse Square, a police spokesman said. The man was questioned but not charged.

title: SOCIAL WORKER OFFERS SOLACE TO SICK PETS' OWNERS
description: During visits to the Animal Medical Center to see their 12-year-old cat, Carl and Libby Dorfman found it hard to accept their pet's worsening condition.

title: MARGARET R. BROWN AND PAUL SHIVERICK MARRY ON DARTMOUTH COLLEGE CAMPUS
description: Margaret Robinson Brown, a marketing manager at the American Express Travel Related Services Company in New York, was married in Hanover, N.H., yesterday to Paul Coombe Shiverick, a securities analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in New York. The ceremony at the Church of Christ (Congregational) on the Dartmouth College campus was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald M. Mackenzie, assisted by the Rev. Martha Weatherhead Shiverick, sister-in- law of the bridegroom.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: As president of the New Jersey Dietetic Association, I feel the need to clarify several issues.

title: 2 NONWHITES IN SOUTH AFRICAN CABINET
description: The new South African President, P. W. Botha, announced a Cabinet today that, for the first time in his country's history, included nonwhites.

title: WHEN INDIA WAS A COLONY
description: A SUDDEN OUTBREAK OF ANGLO-INDIA HAS OCcurred in the cinema world, involving million-dollar budgets and movement of actors and equipment on a global scale - a minor, modern version of such historic globe-trotters as Hannibal, Alexander, Napoleon and heaven knows who else, who moved their hordes and elaborate engines of destruction across continents. Their Indian-oriented counterpart today carries an elaborate load of equipment of a different type - to set up his camp in a strange land, to create illusions of his own choice.

title: THE VATICAN ERRS ON LIBERATION THEOLOGY
description: The Vatican's longstanding campaign against the use of Marxism in Catholic social thought has come to a head this month - in the threatened censure of four Nicaraguan priests, the interrogation of a prominent Brazilian theologian, Leonardo Boff, and, most troubling of all, an uncompromising document condemning ''certain forms of liberation theology.'' Breathlessly alarmist in tone and ill-conceived, this document was one of the most insidious to emerge from Rome in recent years.

title: MIDWOOD DEFEATS SOUTH SHORE, 17-14
description: Despite the downpour yesterday, Midwood and South Shore opened their Public Schools Athletic League season with a tense, disciplined game that was won in the final seconds by visiting Midwood, 17-14.

title: ARCHBISHOP O'CONNOR'S ERROR ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CARMEN' FILM ROLE SOPRANO'S NEW NICHE
description: '' I'M absolutely not serious about myself, and yet very serious about what I do,'' said Julia Migenes-Johnson, between reviewing a new batch of press photographs of herself and suddenly adjusting her frizzy froth of walnut-colored hair. And it is just this combination of playfulness and purpose, one suspects, that has guided her in a career in the performing arts that has encompassed the highest of high culture along with some of the most populist of pop - from significant successes on Broadway and in grand opera to singing ''light'' fare on European television with such performers as Joel Grey.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago, 2:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 2 P.M.).

title: CRIME FIGURE'S SON SLAIN IN JERSEY
description: A son of the man who was reputed to be Philadelphia's leading organized- crime figure until his murder three years ago was found shot to death late Saturday at the side of a secluded road in Gloucester Township, N.J., the Camden County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Genetic Progress In AIDS Research

title: REAGAN ATTACKS MONDALE TAX PLAN IN RADIO TALK
description: President Reagan today called the tax increase proposed by Walter F. Mondale ''a giant stop sign'' that would bring economic growth ''screeching to a halt.''

title: MUSIC: JARMAN AND TEDE SING AT GOODMAN HOUSE
description: The bass-baritone Maxwell Jarman and the mezzo-soprano Margery Tede joined forces Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House for a concert that provided a model of thoughtful and innovative programming. During one evening, the duo presented Maori songs from New Zealand, selections from Mahler's ''Knaben Wunderhorn,'' a world premiere by Ron McFarland, elegant vignettes by Virgil Thomson (along with an extended aria from his opera ''The Mother of Us All''), a sea chanty and a host of similarly aquatic evocations by John Ireland, Ralph Vaughan-Williams, Frederick Keel and Sidney Homer.

title: WHAT THE DIPLOMAT REALLY THOUGHT
description: Gaddis Smith, who teaches American diplomatic history at Yale University, is the author of ''American Diplomacy During the Second World War.'' WAR DIARIES

title: MORE AND MORE, FEDS ARE POLICING CHICAGO
description: Richard Gimbel, a Midwestern high school teacher, used to open each fall's English classes with a true tale from his Chicago childhood days in the 1930's. It seems that during a car tour of the city some visiting relatives from Nebraska said how much they really wanted to see some of Chicago's famous gangsters. The Gimbels laughed as their auto pulled up behind another car at a stop sign, saying such things happened only in the movies.

title: NEW CENTER PLANNED TO FURTHER CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Plans to establish a nonprofit research and advocacy organization to support the civil-rights movement have been announced by two former officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Escape Artist
description: His hands had been blown off, except for remnants, and he had but one good eye, but William Morales managed to cut open a metal window gate and flee by lowering himself with an elastic bandage from a third-floor, maximum-security cell in the Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan.

title: 42D STREET BUS TERMINAL CHECKED FOR SNIPER CLUES
description: Surma Arzuaga, a 36-year-old clerical worker, was finishing her lunch Aug. 28 when a bullet pierced a third- floor cafeteria window of the building at 310 West 43d Street that is a union headquarters for health-care workers.

title: PUBLIC MORALITY, NOT RELIGION
description: The great tradition of American churchmen, from William Ellery Channing and Ralph Waldo Emerson and Theodore Parker to Washington Gladden, James Cardinal Gibbons and Reinhold Niebuhr, is that of the moral crusader. They preached public morality, not public religion. No one can question the right of, or the duty of, churchmen of all denominations today to preach morality and religion: it is when they connect morality with a particular brand of religious faith and this, in turn, with political policies that they venture into troubled waters.

title: MISS GLOVER, NURSE, WEDS
description: Sara Ann Glover, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harvey Glover Jr. of Locust, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter James Tucker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Duane Tucker Jr. of Pelham, N.Y. Msgr. Michael J. Lease, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Thomas Berry, president of the American Teilhard Association in New York, performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Atlantic Highlands, N.J.

title: Candidates, Image And Hype
description: It has been my long-held belief that one of the surest safeguards against political chicanery is not the legislating of limits on the amount a candidate may spend, but on the ways in which he may spend it (''The Power of Political Consultants,'' by Ron Suskind, Aug. 12).

title: Living With an Ailing Heart
description: Over the past weeks, concern and conjecture about the death of the charismatic author and runner, James Fixx, have occasioned the publication of many articles. James A. Michener's ''Living With an Ailing Heart'' (Aug. 19) is the best I have read, evoking as it does the genius of Dr. Paul Dudley White, and the dailiness of heroism that is requisite for living ''boisterously'' in the high-risk category.

title: Puerto Rico Cuts Power To Fix Toppled Towers
description: Puerto Rico's electric authority rotated power shortages on the island Friday as workers repaired two relay towers officials said were sabotaged the day before.

title: Printers' Convention Favors Merger With Graphics Union
description: The International Typographical Union said today that its leaders had been directed to seek merger with the Graphic Communications International Union.

title: EGLEVSKY FUTURE UNCERTIAN
description: THE suit filed recently by Edward Villella, former artistic director of the Andre Eglevsky State Ballet of New York, against the company and 15 persons he says are on its board of directors once again raises questions about the group's current status, its long-range plans and its staff.

title: IS IT TIME ONCE MORE FOR 'LAKME'
description: ''The most ineffective opening,'' thundered the critic of The New York Times, ''that the writer recalls in 22 Metropolitan seasons.'' This was Olin Downes in 1946, and he made it clear where the blame lay. Not with the performers (''an excellent new conductor and a reasonable amount of good singing''), but with the management's decision to offer an opera of ''inherent bathos'' (that comment from an earlier season), a ''pretty-enough piece in its faded, old-fashioned way,'' but not a work for ''the modern opening of a modern opera house.''

title: Miss Campo Wed To Chester Cobb
description: Mary Katherine Campo and Chester Lee Cobb were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Mark Connolly, assisted by Msgr.

title: DANBURY CELEBRATES ITS 300th YEARZ
description: IN the former Danbury Library building on Main Street, amid piles of red, white and blue bunting, T-shirts, flags and other decorations and souvenirs proclaiming the city's 300th birthday, Mary Ann Frede was trying, for the third or fourth time, to count out 100 tricentennial buttons.

title: PAYING FOR A COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: Parents of college-age children are getting the same kind of sticker shock when they see tuition bills that they get when they browse through new-car showrooms. Indeed, a year at an elite private college these days can cost as much as a luxury car, and tuition at the trusty public university can easily rival a subcompact in price.

title: WELCOME TO COLLEGE - AND MY BOOKS
description: John Barth adapted this article from an essay in ''The Friday Book,'' to be published this fall.

title: THEATER: 'LESLIE SIMS RETIRES TOMORROW'
description: The retirement of kings and wars of succession are the stuff of which great theater is made. But the inner turmoil that wracks the ordinary person faced with the same problem can also be affecting, soul-searching theater as ''Lester Sims Retires Tomorrow'' demonstrates.

title: Fuentes and Spanish Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: RETIREES MOVE OUT AS STUDENTS RERENT APARTMENTS
description: AS in many apartment buildings in college towns across the nation, students have moved into the University Gardens complex in New Paltz, N.Y., unpacked and started classes. But unlike those in most college towns, these apartments will be rerented at the end of the academic year to summer tenants, mostly retirees from Florida.

title: 'PORK BARREL' FROM THE STATE
description: THE Talented and Handicapped Artist Workshop of West Islip, $10,000. The Talking Book Program of the Stephanie Kahn Foundation, $65,000.

title: RESETTLEMENT OF 455,000 IN U.S. VIEWED AS SUCCESS
description: Smiling Vietnamese teen-agers pour out of Valley High School in this prosperous commercial center among the suburbs near Disneyland. In the adjacent town of Westminster, dozens of Vietnamese businesses form a bustling, colorful Little Saigon.

title: IT'S NO GAME, BUT HE'S PLAYING TAG lWITH SHOPLIFTERS
description: '' UNIVERSITIES call it a radical innovation,'' said Arthur J. Minasy. ''Something that is being done that has never been done before - starting a new industry with an entirely new product, a new concept, sort of like a Fulton steamboat, they say.''

title: FELIX ROHATYN: LIFE AT THE TOP
description: Business students decades from now will be studying in depth the wisdom and knowledge that Felix Rohatyn has given to business and society. What sets the man apart is his low-key style, coupled with a fine intellectual mind, his understanding of the rich and his compassion for others. Society and the Fortune 1,000 will be better in the year 2000 for his philosophy of never trusting anyone who says it can't be done. JOHN SCAFIDDI Instructor, Business Administration College of St. Elizabeth Convent Station, N.J. --

title: HOW TO CUT GLASS TO SIZE FOR A WINDOW OR A PICTURE FRAME
description: THERE are many occassions when a do-it-yourselfer will want to cut a piece of glass to a specific size - for example, when cutting a small pane of glass for a window or a picture frame or when trying to cut up some large pieces left over from a previous project. Also, there may be times when you may want to cut curved or odd- shaped pieces to fit a particular project.

title: Crew of Marooned Ship Gets San Francisco Tour
description: The crew of a Taiwanese freighter, marooned at sea aboard their debt-ridden ship since mid-summer, set foot on land today for the first time in nearly three months.

title: A PANORAMIC VIEW OF NEW YORK CITY
description: This apartment is the stuff of which fantasies are made. It's brand new, glamorous, sophisticated and luxurious. It is located right on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan just a few steps or blocks away from some of the best shopping and most fabulous landmarks in the city. Perched upon one of the top floors of the 68-story Trump Tower, one of the city's newer luxury apartment buildings, it is perhaps as much a pied-a-ciel as a pied-a-terre, for it features sweeping views of the New York cityscape. And if all that weren't enough, its interiors were decorated by Donghia Associates, one of the best-known names in interior design.

title: POLICE ROOKIE DIES IN COAST SHOOTOUT
description: A rookie police officer died Friday after she was shot through the heart in a routine traffic stop. Two other officers were wounded in the shootout in an area known for its gang activity.

title: Tina Turner: Queen of Rock 'n' Roll
description: Media Home Entertainment 60 minutes. $29.95

title: Coconuts and Cholesterol
description: In the article ''Putting Coconuts to Tasty Use'' (Aug. 12), Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey warn their readers not to make coconut milk a part of the daily diet because ''it is rather high in cholesterol.'' Their advice is sound and well taken, but I am sure that Messrs. Claiborne and Franey know that plant foods do not contain any cholesterol at all, and what they probably meant to say was that coconut milk is rather high in saturated fat for a plant food. DAVID G. SCHARDT, Division of Nutritional Sciences, Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.

title: MEDICARE DOCTOR'S FEE CONTAINMENT GONE AWRY: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Baugh Bride Of Bruno Necatera Jr.
description: Elizabeth Revere Baugh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Briggs Baugh of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Church there yesterday to Bruno Paul Necatera Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Necatera of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Nathan Adams of the Stanwich Congregational Church of Greenwich performed the ceremony.

title: Topics ; Altered States
description: The Iconoclast

title: COCKEYED AT 'RED DAWN'
description: As Leo McCarey's ''My Son John'' epitomized the anti-Communist paranoia of the 1950's, with sometimes unintentionally funny results, ''Red Dawn,'' John Milius's shoot-'em-up World War III fantasy, provides an unusual glimpse into the mind of a certain kind of contemporary archconservative. It's not, heaven knows, the intellectual kind of archconservative.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN WASHINGTON HEIGHTS
description: FROM the gray of the George Washington Bridge to the green of Fort Tryon Park, Washington Heights is a collection of contrasts - young and old, recent immigrants and third-generation residents - and its steep hills and wide vistas make it the part of Manhattan that feels least like New York.

title: Brian Petrovek Is Married To Sara LeBlond, Banker
description: Sara LeBlond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. LeBlond 2d of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Brian Petrovek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. August Petrovek Jr. of West Hyannis Port, Mass. Msgr.

title: FUNDS TO PROTECT SHORE STILL UNSPENT
description: STATE SENATOR Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch, saidlast week that residents along New Jersey's coast might be prepared to weather a bad storm or hurricane in terms of civil defense, but that beachfront damage could be 'devastatin.'

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHAT COURSE FOR THE PARENTS OF DYSLEXIACS?
description: AT first the signs were amusing, then puzzling and finally painful. It was funny when Laura was 14 months old and a dinner guest first met her. She'd been talking in long, complex sentences for some time and my husband and I understood her perfectly. ''What foreign language is she speaking,'' the guest asked with a smile. There was also the time Laura and I did a collage project at home. Laura mixed gummed stars, glue, glitter and noodles together in one glitting glump. But it was puzzling when Laura was 3 years old and we were playing a drawing game. I drew a circle and a triangle and asked her to copy it. She tried, but couldn't make the shapes at all similar.

title: Marion A. Dillon Is Bride in Maine
description: At St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Portland, Me., yesterday, Marion Alice Dillon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Dillon of Westfield, N.J., and Portland, was married to Thomas Patrick Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Morris of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Francis J. Kane performed the ceremony.

title: A Russian Is Coming. Then What? Walter Mondale thinks it's ''pretty pathetic'' that President Reagan's first encounter with a Soviet leader will be with Deputy Premier Andrei Gromyko and not the top man, Konstantin Chernenko. What's really pathetic is that there's any fuss being made about this meeting. How can a photo with Mr. Gromyko prove the President's desire for arms control? And why would Mr. Mondale let the vast issue of Soviet relations degenerate into the silly symbolism of who meets whom when?
description: The critical question is which man will better manage relations with Moscow, a task that requires neither novel doctrine nor sudden breakthrough but a mastery of history, diplomacy and technology.

title: Catholic Overcome By Fordham Rally
description: Fordham, winner of only two games in each of the last two seasons, raised its record to 2-0 yesterday. The Rams rallied to defeat Catholic University, 27-23, at Brookland Stadium in Washington,

title: INCEST-VICTIM GROUP STARTING
description: THE Human Sexuality Center at Montclair State College is helping to organize an affiliate of a support network for victims of incest that has taken hold in the Middle Western and Western states.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: LIBERALS HAIL PRIMARY RESULTS
description: -term Democratic State Representatives in last week's primary elections has prompted liberal groups to urge the state's Democratic Party to seek more citizen activists to run as candidates than it has in the past.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Frank B. Jewett chapter of the Short Hills-based Telephone Pioneers of America is lining up fall and winter projects to follow last summer's successful repair of six flood-damaged homes in the Morris County community of Lincoln Park.

title: Solidarity Activists Are Told They May Be Returned to Jail
description: A Solidarity activist, Janusz Palubicki, who was released from prison in June for health reasons, has been warned that he may be jailed again for causing social unrest.

title: To Hail Bold King
description: Hail Bold King, who had made a reputation as a top 3-year-old by running close to the best in the division without ever winning a stakes race, burst into prominence tonight with an overpowering 9 1/2-length victory over the favored Carr de Naskra over a sloppy track in the $218,400 Pegasus Handicap for 3-year-olds at the Meadowlands race track.

title: HEADLINERS
description: A Star Is Charged Divorce was out of the question for Lydia Echevarria , but murder was not, according to the scenario drawn by the authorities in Puerto Rico. For years, Miss Echevarria and her husband, Luis Vigoreaux, appeared as the happily married co-hosts of a popular weekly television variety show.

title: LITERATURE AS THE LAW
description: Leo Bersani is the author of ''The Death of Stephane Mallarme'' and ''A Future for Astyanax.'' WHEN WORDS LOSE THEIR MEANING

title:
DINING OUT;
AMERICAN FARE IN HISTORIC SETTING
description: THOSE finding themselves south of Nyack (Perhaps to admire autumn from the Palisades) can both nourish the body and soak up some history at The Old '76 House in Tappan, not too far inland. A flyer just inside the door of this old tavern tells all: read about the superstars of the Revolutionary War; learn of historic intrigues, plots hatched and foiled right in our own backyards. The fine old Colonial stone house lacks the porch on which Major John Andre, British spy, paused on his way to the gibbet, but Paul Dalton, the present owner of this landmark restaurant, has plans for faithful exterior restoration. The interior retains much of 18th-century flavor: Wide-planked floors, low ceilings, cozy rooms - particularly the tap room with its huge fireplace and draft-defying booths set against thick walls.

title: FISHING TRIP BRIDGES YEARS
description: MY granddaughter Lucie, who is 5, recently came up with a sure-fire way to induce me to take her fishing.

title: 2 REPORTS SAY CITY HAS IMPROVED FOSTER CARE
description: New York City's foster-care program has made some essential improvements in the last five years, according to two reports.

title: SERIES SAMPLES INDEPENDENT JAPANESE FILMS
description: One film is a drama about a young agricultural worker coming to terms with urban encroachment; another is a comedy about gender reversal. A third is a love story about a Japanese motorcycle racer and an American mechanic, and yet another is ''an autobiographical rumination on the rigors of medical school.''

title: LETTERS ; Gold Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Shows Big Lead For Reagan in 41 States
description: President Reagan leads Walter F. Mondale, his Democratic challenger, in at least 41 states, according to an Associated Press survey that indicates the Democratic challenger can now count on only the District of Columbia.

title: U.S. ACTION DELAYS VOTING IN FLORIDA COUNTY
description: Voting for five newly created county positions here has been delayed indefinitely because of action by the Justice Department. It was the department's first intervention in a local election in Florida.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: PLANNING YOUR FLIGHT TO THE FAR EAST
description: Never before has it been easier to reach the Far East. For example, on 747's of Japan Air Lines, Northwest Orient and Pan American, you can fly nonstop from New York to Tokyo in 13 1/2 hours (or, because of differences in prevailing winds, return to New York an hour faster). Deciding how to go, however, is not so easy. Never before has there been so much competition among airlines, resulting in a puzzling diversity of fares. Seeking the lowest one or the one most suited to your needs can be difficult and may require the services of a travel agent who knows Asia and the airlines intimately and keeps abreast of changes.

title: 76ers Trade Rautins
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have begun their long-awaited roster moves to make room for the eventual signing of the touted draftees Charles Barkley and Leon Wood . They traded Leo Rautins, their top draft choice last year out of Syracuse, yesterday to the Indiana Pacers for future considerations.

title: Felix Rohatyn: Life At the Top
description: David McClintick's article, ''Life at the Top: The Power and Pleasures of Financier Felix Rohatyn'' (Aug. 5), was provocative, stimulating, fascinating, and, in the end, made me hunger for more days with the man. I look forward to reading more of Mr. McClintick's writing. NANCY LEE CARTER, Pittsburgh

title: POP: PRINCE JOINS SHEILA E.
description: Prince, one of the most imitated figures in current pop, upstaged his protegee and production client, Sheila E., when he joined her onstage Thursday at the Ritz. But before he appeared, the singer-songwriter-percussionist Miss E. and her seven- piece band had already worked the crowd up to laughing, dancing and shouting.

title: No Headline
description: Amy Schimmel Is Wed

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Seasonal Festival In New Rochelle The Fall Festival for shoppers in New Rochelle is set for 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Thursday through Saturday and from noon to 6 P.M. next Sunday at more than 35 stores. Yellow umbrellas will mark the reduced-price sidewalk tables and rides and other amusements - plus a flea market Sunday only from 1 to 7 P.M. - will be added to the merchants' offerings.

title: U.S. POWER AGENCY PAYING TO INSULATE HOMES IN STUDY
description: Some people in this Pacific Northwest valley are looking forward to winter: That is when a $20-million study seeking to document the benefits of heat conservation may pay off for 3,100 households.

title: Mary L. Habgood Marries in Bay State
description: The marriage of Mary Lawrence Habgood, the daughter of Robert P. Habgood 3d of London and the late Julia Fearey Habgood, to William Terhune Carpenter 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Carpenter Jr. of Swampscott, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Unwanted Help
description: When the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque began testing an electronic guidance system for the blind late last year, the state's biggest organization representing the blind objected. The group, the New Mexico affiliate of the National Federation of the Blind, said the system would do more harm than good by discouraging the blind from developing their own senses to get around.

title: CREDIT CARD FRAUDS MOUNT
description: SIX shopping days shy of last Christmas, a woman from Dix Hills braved the long lines and short tempers of the holiday rush to reach the lingerie counter of a Miracle Mile department store.

title: WHY THE DOLLAR STAYS SUPREME
description: Just last February, it was fashionable in financial circles to brood

title:
About Men;
Learning to Slow Down
description: Martin Berger

title: ATOLL-HOPPING IN THE PACIFIC
description: An atoll like Tarawa, in what was once the British colony of the Gilbert Islands and is now the independent Republic of Kiribati, is a likely place to find the Pacific as it was before resort developers began transforming much of it into small imitations of Waikiki.

title: ISSUES REMAIN IN MT. VERNON
description: MOUNT VERNON NORMAL numbers of black and white students walked through the September sun to and from classes last week after a three-day boycott by blacks over minority hiring in the city's public school system came to a peaceful end.

title: HOLLYWOOD SHIFTS ITS CHIEFS AROUND
description: Hollywood produced its own version of musical chairs last week. On Monday evening, Alan H. Hirschfield resigned as chairman of 20th Century Fox. A day later, Barry Diller, chairman of Paramount Pictures and a unit of Gulf and Western, announced his resignation to become new head of Fox. Michael Eisner, Mr. Diller's No. 2, also resigned from Paramount, while Frank Mancuso, president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group was chosen to head the entire studio. Analysts said the shuffle was precipitated by Fox owner Marvin G. Davis' dissatisfaction with the studio's per formance at the box office. Meanwhile the relationship between Mr. Diller and Martin S. Davis, head of G.&W., was reportedly souring. The shuffle may come to involve even more studios, depending on where Mr. Eisner ends up. As it was, three major Hollywood studios have lost their chief executives in the last two weeks. Early this month, Walt Disney Studios' chief executive, Ronald W. Millers, was forced to resign. And if past experience is a guide, the top- level departures should lead to major upheavals in lower management ranks. Stay tuned.

title:
ANTIQUES ;
HOMAGE TO HARTFORD'S COLLECTORS
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum, founded in Hartford in 1842, is the oldest art museum in the country. Today its famous collections of more than 40,000 objects help it to rank among the top 10 museums in the United States.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
...BUT THE ISLAND IS STILL HOME
description: IT'S a Friday evening. In a long, leisurely manner, I stroll the streets of

title: Oklahoma Sends Pitt to 2d Straight Loss
description: For Oklahoma's class of '84, this was the final season to redeem itself in the eyes of the Boomer Sooner fans who don't take kindly to losing even one game. The word around Norman, Okla., was that if Oklahoma had another mediocre season, those seniors might be followed out of town by their coach, Barry Switzer, who once had a popularity rating any politican would envy.

title: TIME OF TRANSITION AT BRONXVILLE'S LOFT
description: IN a transition from its illustrious past as a leader in children's theater in the community, The Loft in Bronxville is now accommodating what its co-director, Susan Ingalls, calls an ''adult esthetic,'' while giving the cause of grown- up professional theater in the county a much-needed hand.

title: Dr. Helen L. Price Is Married in Jersey
description: Dr. Helen Louise Price, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey S. Price of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Christopher Donald Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Mitchell of Holywood, County Down, Ireland. The Rev. Dr. Franklin D. Fry, assisted by the Rev. Lynn Nakamura, performed the ceremony at St. John's Lutheran Church.

title: FROM THE NEVSKY PROSPEKT TO ROTTEN ROW
description: Judith Burnley's latest novel is ''Unrepentant Women.'' A WOMAN'S WAY

title: North Carolina Institute Gets Study of a Vietnam Disorder
description: The Veterans Administration has awarded a $3.6 million contract for the first full- scale study of a psychiatric problem believed to have affected thousands of Vietnam combat veterans.

title: MOROCCO FORESEES VICTORY IN SAHARA
description: Moroccan officials and military commanders, buoyed by a treaty with Libya that has ended Libyan financing of leftist Polisario guerrillas, assert that they have all but defeated the guerrillas in their 8-year war for Western Sahara.

title: Convertible Bonds .;  Preferred Stock .;  Rating .;  Private Placement .;  Financing
description: Pan American World Airways has raised its offering of 10-year, 6 1/2 percent convertible bonds to 100 million Swiss francs through Soditic S.A. Corp. Bank of New England Corp. is offering 300,000 shares of adjustable-rate cumulative preferred stock, series 1984, at par through Goldman, Sachs. Hertz senior debt rating was raised to A-3, from Baa-1, by Moody's.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Technology Development Fund, an Atlanta-based venture capital firm, has appointed Daniel D. Ross a general partner.

title: REPUBLICANS CULTIVATING SWING VOTES
description: Representative Dave McCurdy is a moderately conservative Democrat from Oklahoma who occasionally votes with President Reagan and the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives. He was strolling through the lobby just off the House floor last week when Representative Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip, stopped him for a chat.

title: RESPONSE IS MUTED TO MONDALE PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration reacted with restraint today to the announcement that Walter F. Mondale would meet with Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, in New York this month.

title: The Old Standard
description: History being inherently inflexible, not many institutions in this country beyond Harvard College and Plymouth Rock get to celebrate their 300th anniveraries. Consequently, a tremor of excitement is coursing through the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund because Moncatta & Goldsmid, which proclaims itself the oldest and largest trader in gold and silver bullion, is preparing for such a celebration in Washington later this month, at the joint meeting of the bank and fund.

title: THE OPERA: 'NORMA,' IN STAMFORD
description: The Connecticut Grand Opera, a company short in history but long on ambition, opened its seventh season at Stamford's Palace Theater Friday night with a serviceable and well-attended performance of Bellini's ''Norma.''

title: SINGAPORE'S TOURISM INDUSTRY FALTERS
description: In trying to entice tourists, Singapore uses plenty of imagination. Two years ago, for instance, it was decided that foreign visitors might be amused to have breakfast at the Singapore Zoological Gardens with Ah Meng, an orangutan with a taste for rolls, orange juice and coffee.

title: WESTERN DEFENSE: IS EUROPE DOING ENOUGH?
description: The European members of the Atlantic alliance are strongly disputing complaints in the United States that they have not contributed adequately to the defense of the West. They assert that they are, and that critics in Congress and elsewhere are ignoring the facts. The catalyst for the dispute was a proposed amendment to a defense authorization bill by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, that called for a reduction of American forces in Western Europe by one-third unless the allies did more to build up their conventional forces. Senator Nunn, diplomats at alliance headquarters here point out, was restating a complaint that has been aired periodically since Senator Mike Mansfield's comparable resolution in the 1970's.

title: CHINA CAUTIONS STANFORD ABOUT EXPELLING STUDENT
description: China has cautioned Stanford University that future cultural exchanges with the United States may be impaired if the university reverses the expulsion of a graduate student who angered Peking while doing research in China.

title: PACT IS REACHED AT 1 OF 13 PLANTS
description: Negotiators for General Motors and the United Automobile Workers continued bargaining on national issues early today as about 58,000 workers prepared to prevent 11 plants from resuming production today.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Scots in Dock Accord; Hope Is for Wide Pact
description: Port employers in Scotland said today that they had reached an agreement with local dock workers that could lead to an end of the three-week-old British dock strike.

title: Stop Stalling the Conservation Corps There comes a time in the legislative process when compromising has to stop, and it's come for the bill to create an American Conservation Corps. The House has approved this worthy measure twice, by overwhelming margins. The Senate threatens now to stall it to death.
description: Patterned on the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps, this idea pairs jobs for unemployed youth with help for the environment. The House voted 18 months ago for a six-year, $1.8 billion program to provide year-round work and training for 56,000 young people and summer work for 50,000 more.

title: The View From the Top
description: As befits a former swamp, Washington is relatively flat, with landmarks like Capitol Hill and Foggy Bottom not all that different in elevation. Thus, when the Soviet Union decided to build its new embassy compound well up the slope of Mount St. Alban, the highest point in the city, which is capped by the National Cathedral, diplomat-wa tchers assumed that the site had been selected to give the Russians unobstructed access, visual and electronic, to a good deal of the rest of Washington.

title: 2-YEAR TREASURY NOTES SCHEDULED
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular sale of new three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of $8.5 billion of new two-year notes.

title: METS FINALLY WIN AT WRIGLEY
description: After losing eight straight games in Wrigley Field this season, the Mets finally escaped with the consolation prize today when they rose up and whacked the Chicago Cubs, 9-3.

title: EXPERTS SEEK ANSWERS TO TRAGEDY OF CHILD ABUSE
description: The questions continue to proliferate: What causes the physical abuse of children, the sexual abuse, the emotional neglect? How frequently does maltreatment occur, to what kinds of children and at the hands of what sort of adults? What happens to those children in the period after the abuse and in their adulthood? What can be done to help them?

title: POPE SOOTHES THE FEELINGS OF UKRAINIANS
description: On the eighth day of his 12-day journey through Canada, Pope John Paul II has shown again that he is a master of the symbol, a religious leader aware of how to deal with the crowds that surge forward to touch him, and the millions of invisible watchers he is reaching through television.

title: DECLINE IN DRINKING CHANGES LIQUOR INDUSTRY
description: America is sobering up - and that is a sobering experience for the alcoholic beverage industry.

title: GOODEN'S PROMISE UNLIMITED
description: Dave Johnson remembers the first time he saw Dwight Gooden pitch. It was in the summer of 1982, and Gooden was a tall and lean kid of 17 who had just graduated from Hillsborough High School in Tampa, Fla., a kid reporting for work in the Appalachian Rookie League in Kingsport, Tenn.

title: Futures/Options; London's New Arena
description: LONDON BY Chicago or even New York standards, the London futures markets may seem small indeed. Last year, for example, some seven million futures contracts were traded here, compared with 140 million in the United States markets.

title: A Speech in Praise Of Redeemers' Gleanings
description: Any city where a group of police

title: Pemex Chief Sees Stability
description: Stability is ''extremely important'' in the world oil market, and while prices are unlikely to drop, they probably will not increase until 1986, said an official of Mexico's national oil company. The Mexican company, Pemex, plans to continue the 2.75 million-barrel-a-day output it has maintained for almost two years, said its general director, Mario Ramon Beteta.

title: AGREEMENT IS EXPECTED ON BROADCASTING FUNDS
description: Congressional and Administration negotiators hope to reach an agreement this week, perhaps as early as Monday, on the 1987-89 financing levels for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: 3. DEMOCRACY IS THE WAY
description: In late August, South Africa's colored and Indian peoples went to the polls to elect representatives to an enlarged tri- cameral Parliament, giving them a share of power with the whites. The voter turnout was rather low, prompting some critics of the South African Government to claim that the elections were flawed. This claim is spurious.

title: THERE'S NO U.S. CRACKDOWN ON LEGITIMATE VISITS TO CUBA
description: To the Editor:

title: DELOREAN ULSTER LEGACY: DEBT
description: The picture that sits on the desk of Simon Bellamy, the managing director of Interior Trim Ltd., is not a family snapshot - it is a photo of one of two gold-plated DeLorean sports cars built before ill-fated DeLorean Motor Cars Ltd. went bankrupt in 1982.

title: AT ISRAELI TRIAL, A PICNIC ATMOSPHERE
description: A trial that promises to be among the most politically sensitive in Israel's history opened here today in a courtroom jammed with family members and supporters of 20 settlers who are accused of carrying out acts of terror against Arabs in the occupied West Bank.

title: SELF-IMAGE OF MOTHERS A CONCERN
description: THERE is no office to go to in the

title: Mondale Shifts Seattle Visit
description: Walter F. Mondale's visit to Seattle this week has been rescheduled, and his speech to an aerospace workers' convention is now set for Thursday, a spokesman for the Mondale-Ferraro campaign says.

title: JURY IS TOLD OF PENN SQUARE COVER-UP SCHEME
description: William G. Patterson, an officer of the failed Penn Square Bank, ordered false entries and loan switches in 1982 so that the bank could make $13 million in payments on bad loans it had sold to other banks, witnesses testified at his trial that began last week in Federal District Court here.

title: A Yellow Bow Tie
description: CHICAGO

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:European Junior Play Won By France After Tying Italy

title: BELIEVERS FLOCK TO GRAHAM AS THE K.G.B. WATCHES
description: Blending gospel citations, personal anecdotes and fiery appeals, the Rev. Billy Graham stood before the icons of the Russian Orthodox Church of the Resurrection today and exhorted the congregation to become followers of Christ.

title: SOME FRUIT IS SET FOR HARVEST
description: Fruit from 10 Florida groves will be permitted to be harvested, leading the way for the first out-of-state shipments since citrus canker forced an embargo last week, state agriculture officials said today.

title: LIGHTHOUSE ON THE HUDSON IS BECOMING A MUSEUM
description: The old lighthouse at the confluence of the Hudson River and the Rondout Creek still blinks at night as a navigational aid, but it will soon have an added function - as a museum to tell the story of lighthouses in the river.

title: MUSIC: ORGAN RECITALS AT TULLY HALL
description: The Swiss builders who gave Alice Tully Hall its much-admired tracker organ in 1975 have been back this summer to touch it up. Newly scoured and primped, the instrument was on display throughout the just-concluded Bach festival, not only in support of cantatas at the evening concerts but as a vehicle for three satisfying afternoon recitals of music by the organ's greatest composer.

title: LAWYERS HEADED FOR HAVANA CHARGE INTIMIDATION BY U.S.
description: A group of lawyers who plan to attend a legal conference in Havana charged yesterday that the Reagan Administration was engaged in an unconstitutional effort to to discourage them and other professionals and scholars from visiting Cuba.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Dillon, Read Fills New Research Post
description: John F. Hindelong, formerly managing director and director of research at Becker Paribas, has accepted the new post of director of research at Dillon, Read & Company. The appointment is effective today.

title: Janet Passidomo Wed To Gregory F. Presley
description: Janet Ann Passidomo, a vice president and account supervisor at the Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday to Gregory Francis Presley, a management consultant for Cresap, McCormick & Paget in New York. The Rev. Paul Dinter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the bride and the bridegroom received masters' degrees in business administration.

title: SCIENTISTS DEVELOP HERBICIDE ACTIVATED BY LIGHT
description: Scientists at the University of Illinois have developed a plant-killing substance that enlists sunlight to cause weeds to destroy themselves, university officials and the National Science Foundation report.

title: THERE'S NO U.S. CRACKDOWN ON LEGITIMATE VISITS TO CUBA
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1984 International Israel devalued the shekel by 9 percent and announced a plan to cut this year's $20 billion national budget by $1 billion. These were the first steps taken by the new coalition Government to deal with the country's severe economic problems. (Page A1, Column 3.) Israelis accused of terrorizing Arabs in the West Bank went on trial in Jerusalem. It promises to be among Israel's most politically sensitive trials. The sentiment of the spectators and some of the police guarding the courtroom was clearly for the 20 defendants, despite the prosecution's warning that it was a criminal, not a political trial. (A12:4.)

title: South African Miners Said to Come to Blows
description: Violence broke out among black workers at a South African gold mines tonight after they met to discuss a last-minute offer in a pay dispute, a mining company spokesman said.

title: ISSUES IN THE TALKS
description: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest automobile company, and the United Automobile Workers, which represents 350,000 assembly line and skilled trades workers in 147 G.M. production plants and parts warehouses.

title: OUSTED STATE LEADER REGAINS POST AS GANDHI'S FORCES ADMIT DEFEAT
description: Forces loyal to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conceded defeat today and allowed the reinstatement of the Chief Minister of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, whose removal last month stirred nationwide protests against Mrs. Gandhi's Government.

title: Lingering Questions Of a Lost Age
description: A: Why is Oct. 3 a day of mourning

title: OTHER SIDE OF 'GENDER GAP': REAGAN SEEN AS MAN'S MAN
description: Ask men about Ronald Reagan and they often give two-fisted answers.

title: New Gallery to Display European Paintings
description: A new art gallery specializing in 19th- and 20th-century European paintings will open tomorrow.

title: Man Shot to Death
description: A 25-year-old man was shot to death and three women were wounded early yesterday by a gunman who walked into a Bronx social club, opened fire with a pistol and fled, the police said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 17, 1984: MONDAY Bunker-Hill Inc Sec MONY Mtge Inves Chubb Corp NBD Bancorp Dayco Corp PHH Group Horizon Bancorp Rochester Tel TUESDAY Amerace Corp First Boston Inc Brunswick Corp Joy Mfg CPC Intl Lehman Corp Central Soya Shaklee Corp Fedl Paper Board

title: People
description: * Jonathan M. Goward and James Fitts, principals of Clarke Goward Fitts Advertising, Boston, have been named executive vice presidents.

title: Dr. Franklin Schneier Is Wed to Alison Loeb
description: Alison Joan Loeb, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Loeb of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Franklin Richard Schneier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Oliver Schneier of West Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: Bush Assails Democrats For Remarks on Religion
description: Vice President Bush today charged that Democrats, including Walter F. Mondale, had used ''outrageous demagoguery'' in their attacks on President Reagan's views about religion and politics.

title: BENOIT SETS RECORD FOR HALF-MARATHON
description: Joan Benoit, her wedding two weeks ahead and her gold-medal winning Olympic marathon performance a month behind, said she did not know what to expect of her return today to competitive road running.

title: LINDSAY NAMED BEAUMONT CHAIRMAN
description: John V. Lindsay, the former Mayor of New York City, has been appointed chairman of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. He was offered the position on Sept. 5 and accepted it two days later.

title: TWINS STAY TIED FOR FIRST
description: Frank Viola combined with Ron Davis on a five-hitter today to give the Minnesota Twins their second straight shutout, a 2-0 victory over the Texas Rangers. Mike Smithson had beaten the Rangers Saturday night, 1-0.

title: FLAT COSMOS MISS N.A.S.L. PLAYOFFS
description: Just when the North American Soccer League desperately needed them the most, the Cosmos failed to score a goal in their last three games and missed the playoffs for the first time since 1975.

title: RETAILERS SEE GAINS IN AUTUMN
description: Retail sales across the country, which had slowed during the summer enough to arouse concern, have increased sharply for the fall season, signaling what many merchants now believe will be a strong business pace for the rest of the year.

title: A MANAGED DOLLAR WOULD HELP AMERICAN STEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Fiat Tractor and China
description: Fiat Trattori, the tractor manufacturing unit of Italy's largest private industrial group, Fiat S.p.A., said it had signed a letter of intent to renovate two tractor plants in China. Fiat Trattori said Friday that it would renovate plants at Shanghai and at Luoyang under the agreement with China's Ministry of Machine Manufacture. The plants will produce Fiat tractors under license, it said.

title: STATE OFFICIALS DRAFTING BILL ON WITHHOLDING LIFE SUPPORT
description: New York State's Health Commissioner is drafting legislation that would give hospitals and doctors legal authority to withhold emergency life-saving measures in certain cases from terminally ill and dying patients.

title: BALLOONS AND BLUE SKIES GREET BOOK FANS AT FAIR
description: Bookworms came out of the woodwork by the tens of thousands yesterday, jamming Fifth Avenue between 48th and 57th Streets and making it impossible at times to get from one exhibition to another.

title: Shark Kills Diver, 29, South of San Francisco
description: A 15-foot shark surfaced in shallow water among a group of shellfish divers, grabbed one and dragged him under before surfacing again with the dying man in its jaws, sheriff's deputies said today.

title: Mountain Journal ; Of Water, Bald Eagle And a Dig
description: The Rocky Mountain region is used to having the thirsty Southwest eye its snowy peaks and mountain streams, since that is where most of the lower desert's water originates.

title: Raiders Win in Final Minute
description: The mark of a good team is that it can win on a bad day, and for quite a while this afternoon, the Los Angeles Raiders reminded no one that they had won the Super Bowl game last January.

title: APARTMENT FIRE IN BRONX LEAVES 3 CHILDREN DEAD
description: Three young children were killed yesterday when a fire broke out in their sixth-floor apartment in the High Bridge section of the Bronx while their parents were at a neighborhood laundry, the police said.

title: WOR RADIO ARCHIVES TRACE HISTORY
description: Radio station WOR, which set up housekeeping in Bamberger's department store in Newark in 1922, is cleaning out its attic, which is filled with 60 years of American history on tapes and paper, memorabilia that includes the break-in announcement of the attack on Pearl Harbor and the commercial that a newcomer, Beverly Sills, sang for Rinso White.

title: Belgian Aid Bid Barred
description: The executive commission of the European Economic Community said it had rejected a Belgian Government plan to give about $30 million in aid to its textile industry in 1984. The commission said Friday that Belgium's first two aid proposals - in 1982 and 1983 - had been so successful that more assistance would serve only ''Belgian national interests'' and could harm fair competition in the trade bloc's textile sector.

title: INFIDELITY: HOW WIVES FIGHT BACK
description: There are only two central figures in the eternal triangle, as Shirley Eskapa sees it: the wife and the other woman. The man, she says, is simply the prize in an extramarital affair.

title: SLOW REBOUND IN TROUBLED UGANDA
description: Just a few miles outside this capital lies a suburb known as Kababala, where there is a strip of sidewalk saloons and one- room general stores packed with canned soup and toothpaste, Scotch whisky and white bread, fresh eggs, insect spray, bathroom cleaner and cigarettes.

title: James Terrel Bell 2d Wed To Cynthia Adams Streich
description: Cynthia Adams Streich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wakely Streich of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Terrel Bell 2d, the son of Audrey Kempner of North Arlington, N.J., and the late James T. Bell.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's almost stylish not to have too much to drink. It used to be no big deal if you got blind drunk.

title: The Bottom Line From an Impromptu Critic
description: It was the only coat-and-tie combination to be seen in the Eighth Street Playhouse, that was for sure.

title: SPURNING MACH PAST, ESQUIRE FINDS SUCCESS
description: A generation ago, Esquire was known as a robust men's magazine, famous for muscular Hemingway prose and long-stemmed pinups. But times have changed, and so has Esquire. In June, the magazine celebrated the ''new American woman'' as ''professional, lover, competitor.''

title: USE OF YOUTH AS POLICE DECOY SHOCKS KENTUCKIANS
description: The 16-year-old ''street kid'' had been in court before. He was not in trouble this time, but what he told a jury stunned this conservative community and led to accusations of child abuse by the police.

title: 2. CHANGE THROUGH ARMS?
description: On South Africa, Walter F. Mondale and his party uphold a clear moral stance: they abhor apartheid. Were they to come to power, they would abandon Ronald Reagan's policy of accommodation with Pretoria and exert American influence toward achieving the long-term but imperative goal: the dismantlement of the apartheid system.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The schedule-maker figured the Yankees and Orioles might be battling each other for first place, but instead they are battling for third.

title: CHAMBER: AT FESTIVAL, 3 CANTATAS BY BACH
description: Johann Sebastian Bach's output of more than 200 cantatas has been rightly called the most extraordinary trove of unknown treasure in the annals of musical history. With an all but unimaginable fecundity, Bach churned out one masterpiece after another, meeting his liturgical deadline week after inspired week. Even with an allowance for the occasional infusion of borrowed material (and Bach was not above recycling his own melodies once in a while), the cantatas stand as a proud testament to the human imagination.

title: Balloonist Nears France In Solo Atlantic Flight
description: Joe Kittinger, hoping to make the first solo balloon flight across the Atlantic, was sailing smoothly in a fast- moving weather system toward the French coast early today, a flight spokesman reported.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 17, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Redskins Reward Their Fans
description: ''We're lucky we played here,'' Joe Theismann, the Redskin quarterback, said today after leading his team to a 30-14 victory over the Giants that snapped a two-game losing streak that had the nation's capital in a bit of a funk.

title: Steelers Top Rams
description: David Woodley passed for two touchdowns and the defense scored another and thwarted the running back Eric Dickerson as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 24- 14, today.

title: MUSIC: SUSANNE MENTZER IN CITY OPERA'S 'SEVILLE'
description: There were major cast changes in the New York City Opera production of ''The Barber of Seville" on Saturday afternoon. Susanne Mentzer, a young mezzo-soprano from Philadelphia, sang Rossini's heroine, Rosina; Stephen Dickson was the new Figaro; and Joyce Castle took the role of Berta.

title: PLAYER UNCONSCIOUS AND CRITICAL
description: Ed Reinhardt, a 19-year-old tight end for the University of Colorado, was unconscious and in critical condition today after undergoing surgery Saturday night to remove a blood clot from the left side of his brain.

title: NewA.S.P.C.A.HeadNamed
description: Dr. John Kullberg, executive director of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, has been named president of the society by its board of directors. He succeeds Thomas N. McCarter 3d, who became chairman of the board in June. Dr. Kullberg, who has been the chief operating officer since joining the society in 1978, previously was assistant dean of Columbia University's School of Law and director of the school's admissions office.

title: Hughes Sets Japanese Deal
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company said yesterday that it was entering the international communications business in partnership with two major Japanese trading companies, C. Itoh & Company and Mitsui & Company.

title: John Lindau Berger Weds Elizabeth S. Plapinger
description: Elizabeth S. Plapinger and John Lindau Berger, both lawyers, were married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Jay Heyman performed the ceremony at Woodend, a National Audubon Society mansion.

title: COAST GUARD OBEYS LAW AND BENCHES ITS BEAR
description: Breaking a 57-year Coast Guard Academy tradition, Objee the bear is sitting out this year's football season. While Objee cavorts at a honey farm, a cadet in a bear suit is leading cheers for the Academy team, the Bears.

title: CITY OPERA: CHANGES IN THE CAST OF 'RIGOLETTO'
description: At yesterday's matinee performance of ''Rigoletto,'' the soprano Sheryl Woods sang her first City Opera Gilda with sweet lyrical tone, graceful delivery and many thoughtful touches. She may need another performance or two to settle in fully; nerves seemed to get to her a bit in ''Caro nome,'' and her trills and staccatos in it would not satisfy an exacting standard.

title: ; WHAT'S FEEBLE ABOUT HEARING AIDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FRAGILE BALANCE OF OIL PRICES
description: International oil markets are stabilizing, but not because they are calm. Oil analysts say the recent and expected stability in prices and supplies stems from a fragile balance between strong opposing trends and forces, not unlike two arm wrestlers stalemated on a tabletop.

title: Canada Triumphs In Series Opener
description: Mike Gartner and Rick Middleton scored 39 seconds apart and Michel Goulet scored twice tonight to propel Canada to a 5-2 victory over Sweden in the opener of the Canada Cup final series.

title: Whitworth Wins 86th Tour Title
description: Kathy Whitworth shot a two-under- par 70 in the final round today to win the $175,000 Safeco Classic, her 86th victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -of-town tryout in New York for Dublin, but Smock Alley, a new company of seven based in the Irish capital, is making its debut in our town tonight with the first of two plays it will do here and later carry back home to perform there.

title: PATRIOTS OVERCOME 23-0 DEFICIT
description: Tony Eason passed for two touchdowns and ran for one, and Mosi Tatupu scored twice today as the New England Patriots came back from a 23-0 deficit to beat the Seattle Seahawks, 38-23.

title: Commander, or Censor, in Chief? What did the President have in mind last year when reporters were kept out of the American invasion of Grenada?
description: If he was simply trying to shrug and leave the matter to the military, that would have constituted negligence. The reason the Constitution makes him Commander in Chief, after all, is to insure the supremacy of civilian values, like keeping the citizenry informed when its sons go into battle. If he

title: TWO TANKERS STRUCK BY MISSILES IN GULF
description: Two oil tankers were struck by missiles in the Persian Gulf today. Six seamen were reported wounded.

title: 4-PART SERIES ON CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE
description: The sexual abuse of children is a crime as old as civilization itself, although in a way it seems only recently discovered. Let's say right off, meanwhile, that ''Child Sexual Abuse: What Your Children Should Know'' ought to be seen by all parents and children. The four-part series, beginning on Channel 13 at 8 tonight, shows viewers how to lessen the possibility that a child will be victimized. This is worthwhile and all to the good.

title: Advertising; Needham Is New All Over
description: largest ad agency, last week got a new chief executive, a new name, a new board and a new corporate structure.

title: Newsweek Poll Shows Large Lead for Reagan
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush lead their Democratic opponents, Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, by 18 percentage points, a Newsweek magazine poll released Saturday showed.
