title: MARGARET MEAD FESTIVAL OF FILMS ON CULTURES
description: Alone, the man sets out in a canoe to grapple with a dangerous ritual practiced for centuries by his forebears. The villagers believe that the sharks in the surrounding waters contain the spirits of their own dead ancestors. Out in the lagoon, the man begins to ''call'' the sharks, shaking a hoop strung with coconut shell rattles under the surface of the water. When a shark appears, responding to the vibrations, the man lures it into the hoop and then tightens the slender ring around the shark's jaws. Bare- handed, he drags the shark into the canoe with him and clubs it to death.

title: THE REAGAN-INSPIRED ECONOMIC DOWN AND UP
description: To the Editor:

title: RITTER AND A NEW CAST ON 'THREE'S A CROWD'
description: Last night, the new comedy series called ''E/R'' edged its way onto the CBS schedule disguised as an episode of ''The Jeffersons.'' Tomorrow at 8, ''Three's a Crowd'' is being launched on ABC as a ''special one-hour'' episode of ''Three's Company.'' Scheduling maneuvers are a serious business in television, comedies or not.

title: 2d San Diego Officer Dies After Shootings
description: A police officer died today from wounds sustained in a shooting incident in which a second officer was killed and a third wounded, the authorities said.

title: City Opera to Perform In California in 1986
description: Beginning in December 1986, the New York City Opera company will perform a six-week engagement at the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: Oceans Are Celebrated As Frontier of Future
description: Federal agencies are using the Year of the Ocean to press studies of the new territory created last year when President Reagan proclaimed the 200-mile Exclusive Economic Zone for maritime jurisdiction.

title: SOME CANDIDATES FEAR MONDALE'S VISITS
description: In the camps of Democratic candidates for seats in Congress there is increasing concern about being associated with Walter F. Mondale's troubled campaign.

title:
BRIEFING;
The Y's Chocolate Chippers
description: For decades after World War II,

title: ANALYSTS CAUTIOUS ON RATES
description: Evidence of a weaker economy and signs that the Federal Reserve would tolerate, and perhaps encourage, lower interest rates have helped push rates down since Labor Day.

title: Poll Shows Helms Leads In North Carolina Race
description: A Gallup Poll shows Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican, slightly ahead of his Democratic opponent, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., in their heated race for the North Carolina Senate seat.

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOP SAYS OFFICIALS MUST PUT LAW BEFORE TENETS
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New York said yesterday that officeholders of various faiths had a ''primary duty'' to uphold the Constitution and the nation's laws, even if the laws are contrary to the officials' own religious beliefs.

title: YANKEES OFFICIALLY OUT AFTER 5-3 LOSS
description: Jim Rice allowed himself only small satisfaction yesterday, although he had hit a home run, a triple and driven in four runs. His Boston Red Sox defeated the Yankees, 5-3, at Yankee Stadium, but Rice could only consider the result against the shadow of the season, which he called long and unfruitful.

title: 7,000 Ukrainians Hold March in Washington
description: About 7,000 marchers, most of Ukrainian descent, gathered outside the Soviet Embassy today in protest at what they called ''cultural genocide'' committed by the Soviet Government, which they said was trying to ''Russify'' the Ukraine.

title: Lou Brouillard, 73, Ex-BoxerWho Held World Title in 1931
description: Lou Brouillard, the world welterweight boxing champion in 1931, died in a hospital here Friday at the age of 73.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SOUTH AFRICAN, '4TH CLASS'
description: Khulu Sibiya is a journalist who works for The City Press, a white- owned newspaper here whose readership is predominantly black. His column today seemed to have a poignancy of its own, a black view of a white moment.

title: IN LEBANON, IS DISINTEGRATION NEXT?
description: The warlords and power brokers of Lebanon's ''national unity Government'' - which, as in the old academic saw about the Holy Roman Empire, is neither national, unified, nor much of a government - are to sit down Monday under the watchful eyes of the Syrians in a last-ditch attempt to determine the future of a country drifting toward disintegration.

title: 14th Container Taken From Radioactive Wreck
description: Divers removed the 14th container of uranium hexafluoride from the sunken French ship Mont Louis today, but they said access to the remaining 16 containers was blocked.

title: Murderer of California Model Gets 26-Year Prison Sentence
description: Marvin Pancoast, the convicted killer of the model Vicki Morgan, was sentenced Friday to 26 years to life in prison.

title: Washington Watch; A Tug-of-War Over Exports
description: WASHINGTON COMMERCE and Defense are still fighting a hot turf war over export licensing even though President Reagan appeared to have resolved the dispute in favor of the Pentagon nearly six months ago.

title: ;  NBC's Brainstorm
description: It was getting late in the game and ABC had already scored heavily with the Olympics. Michael Weisman, the executive producer for NBC Sports, took a look at the scoreboard and knew he needed something different as the opening for the network's World Series telecasts this year. He decided to give Bob Giraldi a turn at bat.

title: BUT THE ARTIST LEFT OUT ONE PARTICULAR BUILDING
description: In 1872, an artist named George A. Morrison drew a detailed bird's-eye view of Washington, which is of particular interest now because it shows some long gone, long forgotten features of the capital.

title: Book 'Banned by Bean' Is Selling Out in Maine
description: ''The Uncensored Guide to Maine,'' a paperback, 128- page book that spoofs the state in words and pictures, is selling like, well, boots at L. L. Bean.

title: JACKSON PUSHING DEMOCRATS IN SOUTH
description: Doris Wright, along with most of the 500 people who sat in the muggy auditorium of Voorhees Technical School in Denmark, S.C., 50 miles from here, swatted at the gnats that annually descend on that area.

title: MONDALE REPORTS HE AND GROMYKO ARE TO MEET SOON
description: Walter F. Mondale announced today that he would meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, in New York on Sept. 27, a day before President Reagan is to confer with Mr. Gromyko at the White House.

title: FASTEST WHEELS IN TOWN BACK ON DETROIT STREETS
description: Souped up and ready to burn rubber, more than 1,500 high-revving street rodders roared into Detroit this weekend, dreaming of the days of drive-in theaters and curb-service root beer stands.

title: BIG BROTHER SAYS NO
description: BOSTON When the Supreme Court upholds a restrictive Government regulation, the effect on the ordinary citizen's freedom is not usually manifest at once. But the Reagan Administration, in its zeal, is making quickly and dramatically clear how much liberty was lost when the Court decided the Cuban travel case in June.

title: O'Neill Backs Markey To Retain House Seat
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today endorsed Representative Edward J. Markey in Tuesday's Democratic primary election against former state Senator Samuel Rotondi.

title: E.E.C. SET TO BACK POOR LANDS
description: West European finance ministers agreed today to take a different position from the Reagan Administration on aid to deeply indebted developing countries at this week's annual ministerial meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1984

title: 1. REAGAN'S SOUTH AFRICAN POLICY IS A FAILURE
description: The latest South African violence, coming just as the white rulers were implementing a new Constitution, is an acute embarrassment for Pretoria. It is also evidence that America's policy toward South Africa, known as ''constructive engagement,'' has failed.

title: Girl Dies in Boiler Explosion
description: A gas-fired home boiler exploded, killing 13-year-old Teresa Cerundolo, and injuring four other children as they watched television, and Teresa's parents, who were upstairs, the police said today.

title: FOR RYAN, CONFIDENCE ON A SPECIAL DAY
description: On his 29th birthday today, Pat Ryan, who had been going nowhere for the Jets for six years, was given luggage by his wife.

title: Salvador Prelate Asks Study of Grisly Reports
description: El Salvador's leading prelate called today for a Government investigation into an incident Aug. 30 in which Government soldiers were reported to have opened fire on hundreds of unarmed peasants and a small number of guerrillas in Santa Lucia, in Chalatenango Province.

title: French Ship Recovers Mine In Gulf of Suez
description: French ships in a multinational task force recovered a Soviet-made mine in the Gulf of Suez, Egypt's official press agency reported. But the mine was believed to be older than explosives that have recently damaged ships in the area.

title: The Newest Prince: Plain Harry at Home
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales will name their second son Prince Henry but he will be just plain Harry at home, Buckingham Palace announced today, less than 24 hours after the Prince was born.

title: ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR IS NAMED FOR SOVIET STUDIES INSTITUTE
description: Dr. Robert Legvold, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations since 1977, will become associate director of the W. Averell Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union at Columbia University, the university has announced.

title: LIVING LANDMARK CITES HARASSMENT
description: When he first appeared in a courtroom here in 1960, Danny Escobedo was an unknown 22-year-old high school dropout from the South Side. He had already confessed to shooting his brother-in-law, and after a routine trial, he was convicted of murder and sent to prison.

title: VIOLENCE FORCES HMONG TO LEAVE PHILADELPHIA
description: Among his troubled people, the actions of Lu Vang were not unusual. But it was a sad day for him, the young man said Wednesday, as he packed a van to take his family out of harm's way, far from the grim streets of Powelton Village in West Philadelphia.

title: BEARS WIN, 9-7, WITH DEFENSE
description: Bob Thomas made three field goals and the defense allowed only 154 net total yards - only 32 rushing - as the Chicago Bears dominated the Green Bay Packers for a 9-7 victory today.

title: No Malignancy for Begin
description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin, undergoing tests for a prostate gland ailment, shows no signs of malignant disease, a spokesman for Shaare Zedek Hospital said today. She said that Mr. Begin's doctors had completed most of their tests and that they would decide later this week whether he needs surgery. Mr. Begin is feeling well and has been spending most of his time reading, the spokesman said.

title: CATHOLIC THEOLOGIANS HAVE MIXED REACTIONS TO CUOMO'S NOTRE DAME TALK
description: Governor Cuomo of New York has drawn praise from Roman Catholic theologians for the scope and vitality of his address here Thursday night on religion and public morality. But some of the theologians also dispute some of Mr. Cuomo's central conclusions on abortion.

title: PICKING A CENTERPIECE FOR A NEW TIMES SQ.
description: Can there be a Times Square without a Times Tower? As far as New York City and State, which are jointly planning a major urban renewal project for the area, are concerned, the answer is yes.

title: CHEERS FOR MEHTA, BOMBAY'S FAVORITE SON
description: Zubin Mehta, Bombay's favorite and most famous son of the day, was two hours away from conducting the first concert of the New York Philharmonic ever given in his hometown, and it showed.

title: Deborah E. Kaminow Weds Dr. S. B. Miller
description: The marriage of Deborah Ellen Kaminow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Kaminow of Hewlett, L.I., to Dr. Stanton Bruce Miller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller of Lafayette Hill, Pa., took place yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: STEEL QUOTAS WORRY FARMERS
description: The huge steel mill has long been a hazy presence on the horizon of Richard Bauer's wheat and soybean farm here, but this summer it looms as a menace.

title: SOVIET IS SAID TO HOLD 5 U.S. SEAMEN IN HOTEL
description: Five Americans whose supply ship was reported missing near Soviet territory remained in detention today at a hotel in Siberia, United States authorities said. A Soviet official predicted the incident would be resolved ''very quickly.''

title: SHEKEL DEVALUED AS ISRAELIS PLAN TO REDUCE BUDGET
description: The newly formed Israeli coalition Government took its first steps toward dealing with the country's severe economic problems today, announcing a 9 percent devaluation of the shekel and a plan to cut this year's $20 billion national budget by $1 billion.

title: Thousands of Fish Killed in a Brook
description: Contaminated water killed thousands of fish over the weekend in Stewart Brook, and environmental officials warned local residents not to use the water.

title: Kenneth Alan Mogil Wed To Randi Lynn Solomon
description: At the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center yesterday Randi Lynn Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Solomon of Douglaston, Queens, was married to Kenneth Alan Mogil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Mogil of Hewlett Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert Fine performed the ceremony.

title: The Police Blotter
description: An unidentified man was shot in the back yesterday at about 1:15 P.M. as he stood at East 98th Street and Lenox Road in Brooklyn. The man died in a taxi he hailed to take him to the hospital. . . . The body of an unidentified man was found floating in the Hudson River at about 9:30 A.M. at West and Horatio Streets. . . . The nude body of an unidentified young woman was found in an abandoned building at Grand and Flushing Avenues in Maspeth, Queens. The body had neck lacerations but no bullet or stab wounds.

title: Urban Scrawl
description: Some writings on the wall have a

title: Ayer to Debut Work For J. C. Penney Chain
description: In October, the J. C. Penney retail chain will break the first advertising campaign from N. W. Ayer since that agency won the business in January after Penney completed a five-month review.

title: FLORIDA'S PELL IS DISMISSED
description: The University of Florida relieved Charley Pell of his coaching duties today in the wake of a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into violations by the school's football program.

title: Accounts
description: * Embratur, the Brazilian Tourism Authority, to AC&R Advertising for North America.

title: Nalco Leader Retires At 61 Because of Illness
description: O. T. Collins, who has held every top management post at the Nalco Chemical Company and most recently served as chairman of its executive committee, has taken early retirement for health reasons, the company announced. Mr. Collins, 61, is being treated for ameotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Tracks / Cracks
description: Spruced-Up Sidewalks New York's sidewalks may not need to be paved with gold, but they ought to be smooth enough to skate on. In actuality, however, the New York sidewalk is often a monument to cracks, holes and turned ankles.

title: THE MODERN MUCKRAKE
description: WASHINGTON My problem this time of year is dead leaves in the driveway. The trick is to rake them up before rain turns them into a slippery mass of muck.

title: A Hard Choice on Steel So far so good. Last week President Reagan sensibly refused to grant trade protection to the depressed copper mines, arguing that the gain in jobs and profits would be greatly outweighed by the losses to domestic manufacturers and consumers who use the metal.
description: But copper was only a sideshow to the big steel case the White House must decide this month. And in this case, the Americans lobbying against protection seem no match for the groups lobbying in favor. The steel decision thus becomes a pure test of Mr. Reagan's willingness to bear the election-year wrath of a powerful interest for the sake of the long- term health of the economy.

title: Iberia Airline Strike Goes On
description: A maintenance workers' strike against Iberia Airlines, originally scheduled to last only two days, entered its third day today with more than 200 domestic and foreign flights canceled so far, a company official said. The official said he was not optimistic of a quick resolution of the strike. The workers, who are seeking union recognition and more training, decided to extend the stoppage after management refused to rehire 14 dismissed strikers.

title: New Miss America ToBe'RoleModel'
description: Sharlene Wells of Utah began her reign as Miss America 1985 today by pledging to be a role model for young women. She also speculated that the judges were ''looking for someone like me'' because of the turbulence surrounding the pageant in recent months.

title: Fugitive in Kansas City Dies in Standoff
description: A fugitive described as ''the largest heroin dealer in Colorado'' was found dead tonight by the police who entered a house after a standoff that lasted nearly 21 hours.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Sometime in the 1950's, the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles took part in a large trade. How many players were involved and who were they?

title: Hospital Reports Pact With Strikers
description: A tentative agreement has been reached in the 39-day-old strike of about 400 technicians, dietary and maintenance workers at Mount Vernon Hospital, a hospital official said today.

title: Hints of Change From Philip Morris
description: There were advertising rumblings going on at the house of Philip Morris on Friday.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.10

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS: IMPACT IN CITY IS UNCERTAIN
description: Most of the illegal aliens in New York City have jobs and earn as much as legal aliens, and most pay Social Security taxes and some income taxes, according to many immigration specialists.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOWHERE TO RUN: The Story of Soul Music. By Gerri Hirshey. 384 pages. Illustrated. Times Books. $17.95.

title: ;  Solving a Problem
description: John Cirillo is a methodical sort who believes in planning, and so, for that matter, does his fiancee, Francine Pashelukl. Back in March 1983, when the couple were planning their wedding, they made sure that the date would not conflict with the harness season at Yonkers Raceway. Since Cirillo was the track's director of publicity and Miss Pasheluk its press secretary, such precaution seemed to make sense.

title: 5 DEAD AND ONE HURT IN CRASH AT LINDEN AIRPORT
description: Five people were killed and one was seriously injured late last night when a six-passenger private airplane hit a utility pole and a tree shearing off a wing and crashing at Linden Airport in Linden, N.J., the police said.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC. TO TRY MEN'S WEAR
description: This autumn the bright colors and stylish clothes that distinguish Liz Claiborne apparel are omnipresent in the women's department of any major store. Next year, if the Seventh Avenue company has its way - and so far, it has - there will be Liz Claiborne fashions for men.

title: NOT SO 'IRRATIONAL' STANCE ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUT FISHING WITH COMFORT
description: STOWE, Vt.

title: ;  A Fan-Owned Team?
description: Psst! Like to see a National Football League team in New York City, a team that, win or lose, would be guaranteed to stay here? Would it be worth, say, $100, to you?

title: SLEW O' GOLD SET FOR MARLBORO
description: After Slew o' Gold barely wore down the reconstructed claimer Shifty Sheik to win the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday, race track wags were asking whether the race proved that Slew o' Gold is worth only $36,000 or that Shifty Sheik is now worth $19 million.

title: Futile Gesture
description: There are lots of signals for children

title: Suspects Get Youth Status
description: A judge has denied a motion to have three juveniles tried as adults in connection with the drowning of a 23-year-old man who was a homosexual.

title: COLLEGE IN QUEENS TEACHES THE DEAF
description: The other day, Claudia Gregory received an award from her teachers at La Guardia Community College. They told her she was a very special student who answered voices that told her she had a very special song to sing.

title: Calm Is Urged in Jakarta After Outbreak of Riots
description: Indonesia's council of religious leaders called today for restraint after clashes between Moslems and security forces in Jakarta last Thursday in which 20 people were reported dead.

title: Heckler Denies Impropriety
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, says that as a member of Congress she was not required to reveal information on her financial disclosure forms about a loan her husband secured through an estate for which she was the executor.

title: GASTINEAU A FORCE IN 43-23 VICTORY
description: Mark Gastineau's extraordinary ability to produce clutch performances under pressure suddenly transformed a close game against the Bengals into a 43-23 rout for the Jets today.

title: MODERN DOLPHINS BUILD THEIR OFFENSE ON LONG PASS
description: NORTH MIAMI, Fla.

title: Market Place; Stock Reaction To Bond Trend
description: THE stock market finally took its cue late last

title: Canadian Paper Maker Realigns Management
description: British Columbia Forest Products Ltd., a pulp, lumber and plywood company, has named Kenneth P. Benson chairman. He will remain chief executive officer.

title: Rounding Up Candidates
description: Sometimes a Washington news

title: Ohio River Panel Sets Limits Designed to Control Pollution
description: The Ohio River Valley Sanitation Commission, in its first new pollution control regulations in 14 years, has approved standards limiting the substances that can be discharged into the 981-mile-long river.

title: A. T. CHAUDHRI
description: A. T. Chaudhri, one of Pakistan's most prominent editors and columnists, died Saturday night of a heart attack, the official Associated Press of Pakistan reported today.

title: JETS TROUNCE BENGALS
description: Something unusual happened to the surprising Giants today. They lost a football game. Actually, they gave it away to the Washington Redskins, who scored one fourth-quarter touchdown on a pass interception and another on a fumble recovery and won, 30-14.

title: Dorothy K. Chin Marries Kevin Brandt
description: Dorothy Ku Chin and Kevin Michael Brandt were married yesterday at the home of Mrs. Nicholas M. Schenck, the bridegroom's grandmother, in Sands Point, L.I. Justice Vincent Balletta of New York State Supreme Court officiated.

title: DEPOSED SOVIET CHIEF OF STAFF SAID TO BE NAMED WAR COLLEGE HEAD
description: Soviet officials were quoted today as saying Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, who was removed without explanation 10 days ago as armed forces Chief of Staff, had been named to head a Soviet war college.

title: JACKSON IS OUT
description: Bo Jackson of Auburn finally broke away for his biggest run of the young season in the third quarter against Texas Saturday night. He got by linemen, then linebackers, then cornerbacks and settled into a foot race with the safety Jerry Gray, another 1983 all-American. Gray pulled him down to the artificial turf of Memorial Stadium at the Texas 23-yard line.

title: DON'T PLAY INTO QADDAFI'S HANDS
description: American alarm over the federation agreement between Libya and Morocco is badly misplaced: it not only overestimates the likely importance of the pact but also plays right into the hands of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, who welcomes and indeed thrives on just this sort of international notoriety.

title: GOING AROUND THE HORN
description: Early before a game at Yankee

title: KARPOV DEFEATS KASPAROV
description: Anatoly Karpov won the third game of the world chess championship match today when his challenger, Gary Kasparov, resigned on his 31st move.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JOHN HENRY IN JERSEY TEST
description: The Meadowlands today doubled the purse of the first Ballantine's Scotch Classic to a total of $400,000, and said that the field would include John Henry, the 9-year-old gelding whose $5,482,797 in earnings have made him the leading money- winner in racing history.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Georgia Power Agency Sells $250 Million Issue
description: The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia, comprising 47 municipally owned utilities, is selling $250 million of debt securities through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: AUSTERITY PLAN SET BY CHASE
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has ordered its staff to cut expenses by 6 percent from the amount budgeted at the beginning of the year, according to an internal Chase publication.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:A Scot Keeps Up Standards In Latest Book of Problems

title: CANCER PROGRESS: ARE THE STATISTICS TELLING THE TRUTH?
description: A small but growing band of distinguished analysts is challenging proclamations by Government officials and leading cancer scientists that great advances have been made in ''curing'' cancer patients.

title: AUTOPSY REFUSALS IMPERIL ALZHEIMER STUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO END SEARCH FOR MINES OFF EGYPT
description: United States Navy minesweepers in the Gulf of Suez have begun to pack up their equipment for a withdrawal from the region in the next day or two, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Corporate Debt

title: REAGAN ASSAILED OVER NICARAGUA
description: A leading Senate critic of President Reagan's policy in Central America today renewed charges that the Administration may be trying to circumvent the $24 million funding cap Congress has placed on United States covert aid to right-wing Nicaraguan rebels.

title: A Republican Backyard
description: When the men who run things here came home from World War II, Peoria was a thriving industrial community surrounded by some of the richest farmland in America. Hiram Walker distilled whisky. Pabst brewed beer. Keystone manufactured steel. Caterpillar made tractors. Farmers grew corn and hogs. People made money memorialized in the mansions along the bluffs overlooking the mighty Illinois River. Subdivisions went up. Jobs were plentiful. No wonder the town voted Republican.

title: ISLANDERS RE-SIGN GORING
description: Butch Goring, who joined the Islanders during their first Stanley Cup season, 1979-80, signed a new contract with the club as a free agent yesterday, after rumors this summer that he would leave.

title: REAGAN AND THE RUSSIANS: MOSCOW HAS GOOD REASONS
description: When it became known here that Andrei A. Gromyko would meet with President Reagan on Sept. 28, diplomats presumed that the ruling Politburo must have had a profound rationale for its surprising move in sending a diplomat of Mr. Gromyko's unmatched reputation to Washington. As the date for the meeting approaches, the diplomats increasingly believe that the reasons of the Soviet leadership for reviving contacts with Mr. Reagan are the simplest ones - that a prolonged refusal to deal with the President did not undermine his chances for re-election and that more is to be gained in resuming contacts now than later.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD ;  RECONSIDERING MAJOR SURGERY FOR ELDERLY PATIENTS
description: -year- old artist, was in critical condition in an intensive care unit in a hospital in Barcelona last night after undergoing six hours of surgery earlier this month. Skin grafts were placed on about 20 percent of his body to cover burns suffered in a mysterious accident in his home. The prognosis for Mr. Dali is uncertain because of complications.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Baker Angers Colts The Indianapolis Colts have asked the National Football League to investigate the conduct of
description: Bubba Baker, the St. Louis Cardinals' defensive end who was assessed two personal fouls for hitting two Colts' players in Sunday's game at the Hoosier Dome. Baker, a 6-foot-6-inch, 280- pound veteran, squared off against a Colt offensive tackle, Jim Mills, and a linebacker, Mike Humiston, during a multi-player scuffle late in the second quarter.

title: COLLEGES TEST FOR COMPETENCY
description: MINIMUM competency tests, already endorsed by at least 40 states for high school students, are now making themselves felt at the college level as well.

title: Levine, Huntley Gets Telecom Plus Account
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has picked up the Telecom Plus International account, and the client reports it will bill $3 million.

title: LAWHON, JOHN F. FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Plant Use Unchanged In August
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 82.6 percent of capacity in August, the same level as the previous month, the Government reported today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ray Fontenot, his suspension for the California brush-back duel completed, returns in time to take his place in the rotation.

title: Land Mine in Sri Lanka Kills Two Policemen
description: Two policemen were killed and four others were wounded today when a land mine planted by separatist guerrillas exploded in Sri Lanka's Northern Province, the Information Ministry said.

title: Why Exalt John Hinckley? John Hinckley Jr. said he shot President Reagan because he was trying to impress Jodie Foster, an actress. He appears to have made a much bigger impression on Congress. Still reacting to his insanity acquittal two years ago, an angry Senate recently passed a bill drastically limiting the insanity defense in the Federal courts. The House today will consider following suit, and if wise, will say no.
description: Virtually all the Federal courts have arrived at a definition of insanity that improves upon Britain's so-called M'Naghten test. That rule, dating from 1843, required that an accused could be acquitted if he failed to understand the wrongfulness of his criminal act. Modern courts have expanded on that, ruling that a person might also be acquitted if he were so sick as to lack the capacity to choose lawful conduct.

title: Dun's Business Month
description: Dun's Business Month, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Arlene Hershman editor. Formerly assistant managing editor in charge of coverage of financial markets, she succeeds Clem Morgello, who assumed the new position of editorial director at the publication, which has a circulation of 304,000.

title: LOW APPROACH CITED IN CRASH THAT KILLED 5
description: Investigators said today that a small, private plane that crashed here Sunday night with the loss of five lives had approached the airport too low. They had no immediate explanation for the low approach.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 18, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The TV Demons
description: DePaul University, which will have eight of the top nine scorers returning from last year's basketball team that won 27 of 30 games, will be a familiar squad this season to the nation's basketball fans.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HALF OF CARS TESTED FAIL TO PROTECT OCCUPANTS
description: Nearly half of 38 new cars and trucks tested by the Transportation Department failed to protect front-seat occupants from probable death in crashes at 35 miles an hour, according to Government test results made public today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday about art outside New York misstated the current location of the touring exhibition ''Treasures From the Shanghai Museum.'' It is in the National Museum of Natural History at the Smithsonian in Washington, where it is to remain through Nov. 30.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $140,000 and a gain from debt extinguishments of $550,000.

title: E.E.C. Meeting Still Divided BRUSSELS, Sept. 17 (Reuters) - The European Economic Community was still
description: short of agreement today on

title: SITE, LEASE ON GARDEN BEING SOLD
description: The Penn Central Corporation yesterday said it had agreed to sell the land under Madison Square Garden at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street and the long-term lease between the two organizations to Gulf and Western Industries, which owns the Garden.

title: Military Contracts
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation received a $154.9 million contract from the Navy for AV-8B aircraft and spare parts, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said the Rockwell International Corporation had been given a $25 million contract by the Air Force for code-processing equipment for the MX missile program.

title: CARVING A NICHE IN FASHION
description: They live in Philadelphia, they sell their clothes in New York and most people in the fashion business have recently learned their names. Danny and Annette Noble have been nominated for a Coty Award honoring their contribution to fashion.

title: Radioactive Waste Is Found Upstate
description: A radioactive substance used in making smoke detectors has been found in sludge at the Grand Island sewage treatment plant near here at levels three times higher than Federal safety guidelines, a State Health Department spokesman said today.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BEARS GO 3-0 ON GOOD DEFENSE
description: While Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears chases Jim Brown for the National Football League's career rushing record, the Bears' defense has been chasing a few other people.

title: WRISTON 'VIEW' OF BANKING BILL
description: WASHINGTON WALTER B. WRISTON, the former chairman of Citicorp, would no doubt be surprised to find himself quoted as an influential foe of banking deregulation. But that is how he was portrayed on several occasions during last week's Senate debate on an Administration-backed banking deregulation bill.

title: CALIFORNIA'S SPLIT ON THE UNITARY TAX
description: When Fujitsu Ltd. announced last week that it would build two $170 million computer-parts factories employing 1,000 people in Oregon, no one was more disappointed than California officials. ''It's frustrating,'' said James B. Vaughn, director of the state's Office of Business Development. ''Aside from the unitary issue, California was their choice by many other measurements.''

title: U.P.I. UNION VOTES TO ACCEPT 25% CUT IN PAY
description: Members of the union representing almost half the employees of United Press International voted yesterday to accept a deep wage cut intended to help keep the news agency in business.

title: A Chair for Dobrynin
description: Once again, Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union has figured in an incident that may tell more about the state of Soviet-American relations than all the talk about arms control and summit meetings.

title: GOODEN FANS 16 IN EIGHT BUT LOSES GAME ON BALK
description: In one of the most bizarre games in memory, Dwight Gooden of the Mets struck out 16 batters for the second straight time tonight, tied one record, broke another and still lost to the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-1, on a wild pitch and a balk in the eighth inning.

title: Quincy, Mass., Drops Plan to Escort Blacks
description: City officials announced today that they are abandoning a controversial anti-racism plan to provide escorts for blacks seeking housing and using instead a scaled-down referral program.

title: Sears Signs Deal For Satellite Link
description: The American Satellite Company said it had signed a contract with Sears, Roebuck & Company to construct and operate a private communications system for the retailer.

title: Archbishop to Address Controversy on Abortion
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York is planning a ''major address'' in the next few weeks on abortion and the relationship between religion and politics, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: October Meeting Seen For Peres and Reagan
description: The White House said today that a meeting between President Reagan and the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, was almost certain for the second week of October.

title: CANADA SWEARS IN ITS NEW PREMIER
description: Martin Brian Mulroney was sworn in today as the 18th Prime Minister of Canada.

title: FOR THE ISLANDERS, AN EMPTY SUMMER
description: The Stanley Cup, though heavy, is hollow. Hoisted above the head and shaken in exultation, its 32 pounds of mostly silver alloy can test biceps and triceps. But rap on it with a closed fist, and the sound is more like that of a large, empty tin can.

title: 'DALLAS' IS GOING INTO SYNDICATION
description: ''Dallas,'' the serialized drama of greed and power in Texas that promoted itself around the world as a stereotype of American values, will go into syndication in 112 markets, distributed by Lorimar, the company that also produces it.

title: Dissidents Hold Household Stake
description: Two Los Angeles investors, William Hayden and his son, Stanley Hayden, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they hold about 22 percent of Household International Inc.'s $2.50 cumulative convertible preferred shares outstanding and that they believe certain actions taken by Household's directors are ''contrary to the best interests of shareholders.''

title: THOUSANDS SEEK LOANS IN JERSEY FOR FIRST HOMES
description: Thousands of first-time home buyers, many of whom spent the weekend camped outside lending institutions, sought applications today for mortgage loans of 3 to 6 percentage points below conventional rates.

title: MAGAZINES: RENEWED CREATIVITY
description: THE magazine business gave

title: OKLAHOMANS ARE VOTING ON SALE OF LIQUOR IN BARS
description: Oklahoma voters will decide Tuesday whether to make it legal to sell liquor by the drink in this last of the semi-dry states. But at the elegant Skirvin Plaza Hotel here, and at several thousand other places across the state, the question has long been moot.

title: Hospital Strike EndsinMt.Vernon
description: Almost 400 hospital workers overwhelmingly ratified a two-year contract at Mount Vernon Hospital today, ending the longest strike in the hospital's 92-year history.

title: GANDHI'S OTHERWORLDLY NEMESIS
description: When N. T. Rama Rao speaks to a political rally, many people hear the voice of the Hindu god Krishna or Vishnu or Rama. That's because Mr. Rama Rao, who was returned to power Sunday as Chief Minister of a southern Indian state, used to play deities when he was a film star. Today, a day after forces loyal to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conceded defeat and reinstated him as Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, Mr. Rama Rao's former cinematic persona seemed to figure in the accolades. He has emerged as a political hero as well as a figure around whom the usually fragmented national opposition can rally.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COPLAND: 1900 Through 1942. By Aaron Copland and Vivian Perlis. Illustrated. 402 pages. St. Martin's/Marek. $24.95.

title: TREASURY RATES FALL SLIGHTLY
description: After fluctuating in a narrow range, interest rates on Treasury securities ended yesterday with small declines for short- and long-term issues.

title: A U.S. BALLONIST CROSSES ATLANTIC
description: An American completed the first solo balloon crossing of the Atlantic tonight, according to officials and a reporter at the Biarritz airport control tower.

title: Calorie Battle Fought By Sugar Association
description: The sugar industry feels as if it has been misunderstood by dieting-crazy America, so the Sugar Association later this month will mount a $2 million ad campaign in magazines and on radio to let the world know that there are only 16 calories in a level teaspoon of the real thing. As a matter of fact, that is a bit of a steal from the tagline: ''Use Real Sugar.

title: No Headline
description: Musica Sacra Schedules Basically Bach Festival

title: Jug Field Headed By Colt Fortysix
description: Colt Fortysix, the swiftest harness horse in history, led a field of 21 pacers entered today for the Little Brown Jug.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Trak Auto Corp. owns 50 percent of Trak Auto West. Sales figures for Trak Auto Corp. exclude sales for Trak Auto West.

title: Utility Plans Wage Cuts
description: The Consumers Power Company notified employees today that their pay would be cut by up to 5 percent to help the utility regain its financial health after cancellation of its Midland nuclear power project.

title: Heating Oil Inquiry Closed
description: The Justice Department dropped an antitrust investigation today, saying it had found ''absolutely no evidence of conspiracy'' in last winter's sudden, sharp increases in the price of home heating oil in the Northeast.

title: BRITISH START WAR GAMES ON CONTINENT
description: The operational phase of Britain's largest field-training exercise since 1945 got under way near here today, with nearly 58,000 British soldiers and airmen scheduled to take part.

title: THE MYSTERY OF HANNIBAL'S ELEPHANTS
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS have tried. Students of ancient climate and ecology have tried, too. But no one has yet come up with a satisfactory answer: Where did Hannibal get the elephants for his heroic march across the Alps to attack the homeland of the Romans?

title: THE POPE CONDEMNS 'IMPERIALISTIC MONOPOLY'
description: Pope John Paul II condemned inequalities between rich and poor countries today, criticizing ''imperialistic monopoly'' and declaring that the nations of ''this poor south will judge the rich north.''

title: U.S.-JAPAN ARMS EFFORT IS URGED
description: Warning of a buildup of Soviet forces in Northeast Asia and of Japanese defenses that ''fall short,'' a panel of prominent Japanese and American advisers today urged their Governments to start developing high-technology weapons together.

title: BLACKS DO NOT WANT REAGAN'S SYMPATHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Jones Sees Earnings Decline
description: Dow Jones & Company's stock fell $4.25, to $44, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange following the company's announcement that its third-quarter earnings would be about 10 percent below those of a year earlier despite an 8 percent increase in revenues. Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, attributed the expected drop to the comparison with an ''unusually strong'' 1983 third quarter, when earnings were $28.4 million, or 44 cents a share.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED AFTER CAR CRASHES
description: An Essex County police officer was killed by a shotgun blast this morning after he stopped a car on a highway near here for what was apparently a routine check, the county police said.

title: The Direct Approach: Koch to Constituents
description: ''It isn't every day I get a chance to

title: Rationale for Kennedy's Tax Cut
description: Tax-cutting policies with a supply-side flavor were put forward two decades ago by the Democratic Administration of John F. Kennedy.

title: ; THAT CHINESE 'FREE TRADE' SWEATER IS NO BARGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhoden Wields A Big Stick
description: Throughout his 11-year career with the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates, Rick Rhoden has been known as a pitcher who swings a good bat. He has not been the ''automatic out'' that many pitchers are when they step into the batter's box.

title: EXTORTION TRIAL OF WHITE'S AIDE ON IN BOSTON
description: At the opening of the trial today of Theodore V. Anzalone, long the chief fund raiser for former Mayor Kevin H. White, the Government asserted he had extorted $8,000 from a contractor in meetings in Mr. White's official residence and City Hall office.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Steel Output Up Last Week By The Associated Press Steel production rose to 1.488
description: million tons in the week ended

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of cooking schools in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified the teacher of the Gourmet Kitchen course at Abraham & Straus. He is Leonard Klein.

title: IN ECUADOR'S NO. 2 CITY, NO DOFFING HATS TO QUITO
description: Larger, wealthier and more dynamic than the country's mountain capital, the port of Guayaquil has long resented being ruled from Quito. It has occasionally rebelled, it has frequently grumbled and it has always tried to use its economic power to political advantage. But it has never shaken off its complex about being No. 2.

title: ; Jennifer Lewis Offers One-Woman Revue
description: Jennifer Lewis, a talented, young singer-actress, is someone whose energy and intelligence are so ferocious she can be a little scary. Miss Lewis, who has appeared in the Broadway musicals ''Eubie'' and ''Comin' Uptown,'' used to be a member of Bette Midler's backup group, the Harlettes.

title: NEW HEAD OF SMITHSONIAN INSTALLED
description: With an observation by Warren E. Burger, the Chief Justice of the United States, that the event marked both ''continuity and change,'' Robert McC. Adams was installed today as the ninth chief executive of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Adams succeeds S. Dillon Ripley, who led the Smithsonian for 20 years and who seems destined to be remembered as its great 20th-century builder.

title: Dow Drops 0.44 as Trading Slows
description: The stock market's late upsurge last week halted yesterday as prices fell slightly, with investors cashing in profits. Trading was much slower.

title: Holmes to Fight Smith It will be a year since his last fight, so
description: Larry Holmes will not be coming back against any major contender when he fights either Nov. 9 or Nov. 23 in a fight to be televised by HBO, the subscription television network. The world heavyweight champion will be defending his International Boxing Federation title against James (Bonecrusher) Smith , the Magnolia, N.C., slugger who stopped Frank Bruno of England last May 13 for his 14th victory against one loss. The bout, to be promoted by Don King , seems headed for either Las Vegas, Nev., or Buffalo.

title: Shuttle Launching Is Set for Oct. 5
description: The space agency today set Oct. 5 as the launching date for the next space shuttle mission, an eight- day flight in which Challenger will carry a record seven astronauts.

title: West Virginian Dies at 111
description: Mary Marvich, who gained national attention when she became a citizen at the age of 107, died Sunday in her daughter's home. She was 111 years old. Mrs. Marvich was West Virginia's oldest woman when she died, officials said. Mrs. Marvich's daughter, Betty Nicoletti, said her mother's mind had been ''wonderful, but her various organs began to fail several weeks ago.''

title: GIANTS CONCERNED OVER OUTSIDE GAME
description: The Giants beat the Philadelphia Eagles and the Dallas Cowboys in their first two games mainly with long passes. Their inside running was adequate, their outside running ineffective.

title: 10 Czechoslovaks Defect
description: Ten Czechoslovak tourists defected during a weekend sightseeing trip in Hamburg. A city spokesman said today that the 10 were among 276 Czechoslovaks on the Soviet cruise ship Estonia, which had made previous stops in London and Amsterdam after leaving Leningrad. The Estonia was chartered by the Czechoslovak travel agency Cedok.

title: BEATTY IS GUILTY ON FOUR COUNTS OF TAX EVASION
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn, already serving prison terms for election fraud and racketeering, pleaded guilty yesterday to tax evasion in the last criminal case pending against him.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THRIFT UNIT SEEKS $1 BILLION
description: The troubled American Savings and Loan Association is trying to recruit several Wall Street brokerage firms to raise $1 billion in fresh deposits through the sale of certificates of deposits.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.8% IN JULY
description: Inventories held by United States businesses increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, while sales showed their first decline since February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ANDERSON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COLLEGE PRESIDENCIES IN STATE OF DECLINE
description: THE college presidency is in a state of decline, suffering from lack of power on campus and a self-inflicted silence off-campus, and often caught between hostile faculties and divided trustees.

description: Following are excerpts from an interview Sunday with Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, by The New York Times: Central America

title: REAGAN UNRUFFLED BY MONDALE-GROMYKO CHAT
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''no problem'' with Walter F. Mondale's announcement that he would meet with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union.

title: DALAI LAMA BEGINS 44-DAY TOUR OF CITIES AND COLLEGES IN THE U.S.
description: The Dalai Lama, religious and national leader for millions of Tibetan Buddhists around the world, arrived in New York City yesterday to begin a 44-day visit to the United States.

title: MEXICAN PIANIST WITH NO REASON TO BE 'STATELESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson Plans to Go To Latin America Again
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has announced plans for a second trip to Latin America this year and for providing sanctuary to refugees from Central America through Operation PUSH.

title: Lester Mendell Is Dead;Former Head of Bank
description: Lester Mendell, a philanthropist and former banker, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: Bobbie Brooks
description: The MacGregor Corporation said a letter of intent had been signed for its acquisition of Bobbie Brooks Inc. for $2 a share.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FLORIDA REPORTS DISEASED CITRUS AT 2 MORE SITES
description: Citrus canker has been found in fruit trees at two nurseries that received shipments from a contaminated nursery in central Florida, state scientists said today.

title: DALFORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The comparable year-ago results reflect the operations of Dalfort's predecessor, Braniff Airways Inc., during the course of itsChapter 11 proceeding.

title: Brazil Coffee Forecast
description: The severe frosts that struck Brazil last month will have only a moderate impact on next season's coffee production, the head of Brazil's Coffee Institute said today.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of limited partnership interests in November 1983.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL IS TOLD TO RESTORE HEALTH PLAN
description: A Federal judge ruled here today that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had no right to reduce health insurance benefits for 18,000 retired white-collar workers last spring.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Wheaties Signs Retton For weeks she was a familiar face in millions of living rooms as one of the stars of the Olympic Games in Los Angeles. And now
description: Mary Lou Retton will be a familiar face in the kitchen as well. The 16-year-old gymnast has signed a contract with Wheaties cereal, according to C. W. Gaillard, vice president and general manager of General Mills's Big G Division. Gaillard said Miss Retton would appear in television commercials, be featured on Wheaties cereal packages and make personal appearances for promoting the cereal.

title: Omnicare Stock Off On Loss Forecast
description: Omnicare Inc.'s stock plunged $5, to $12, yesterday in hectic trading on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter.

title: British Air's Fare-Cut Plan LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) -
description: British Airways asked the Government today to approve winter discount fares that would

title: Required Reading Moscow Explains It
description: Probably many of you esteemed TV viewers are asking a question such as that put to us in a letter from Great Fatherland War veteran Issa Albekovich Dudayev. Comrade Dudayev asks: What is the difference between the Democratic and Republican parties, and who supports them?

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 5
description: b-Holly's said that it changed its accounting year from a calendar-month basis ending Oct. 31 to 13 four-week periods ending the last Sunday in October. The company said year-ago results are not comparable to this year's figures.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The poor people and the poor nations, poor in different ways - not only lacking in food, but also deprived of freedom and other human rights - will judge those people who take these goods away from them, amassing to themselves the imperialistic monopoly of economic and political supremacy at the expense of others.'' - Pope John Paul II. (A9:5.)

title: WATCHDOG PATROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHORTCUTS TO ALLERGY DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ROUTINE AT CITY HALL: SECURITY GATE
description: It was a sight to chill the hearts of the less-celebrated: Bess Myerson, among New York City's most recognizable citizens, going through the metal detector at City Hall one recent afternoon to prove she intended no harm to the Mayor.

title: Jackson Gets 500th, But Angels Lose
description: Reggie Jackson became the 13th player in major league history to hit 500 career home runs, but his shot was the only highlight for the Angels tonight in a 10-1 pounding by the Royals.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
New Delay on Midway Pact
description: Judge Sidney Weaver of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Miami delayed ruling yesterday on the agreement for Midway Airlines Inc. to acquire Air Florida until next Tuesday so that Air Florida's creditors could review it.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; McKesson Names A Vice Chairman
description: Raymond R. Herrmann Jr. has been named vice chairman of the McKesson Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

title: 'VIVA VITTORIO!'EXPLORES THE ACTOR'S CONDITION
description: In Italy Vittorio Gassman has been praised as one of the world's most brilliant, versatile stage actors.

title: Man Gets 14-Year Term For Raping His Wife
description: A man convicted of the kidnapping and sexual battery of his wife was sentenced today to 14 years in prison.

title: REAGAN 'ABSENT' ON POLICY FOR MIDEAST, MONDALE SAYS
description: Walter F. Mondale charged today that the Reagan Administration's ''swamp of policy confusion'' had led to the deaths of nearly 300 marines in Lebanon and that Mr. Reagan's re-election would ''take us closer to the brink'' of nuclear war.

title: LIBERAL PARTY MEETS TO PICK LEADERS
description: The Liberal Party met here this evening to try to end 21 months of increasingly bitter skirmishing at news conferences, in the courts and at the polls over the party's leadership.

title: ; Branigan's Top-40 Style At Avery Fisher Hall
description: Laura Branigan, who came out of cabaret, is in the unusual position of having achieved commercial success by imitating European, rather than American pop records. Miss Branigan, who appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, made her breakthrough several years ago with ''Gloria,'' one of the last hits produced in the ''Eurodisco'' style popularized by Donna Summer.

title: Baby Is Born to Woman Given New Heart in '80
description: A 23- year-old woman who received a man's heart in transplant surgery four years ago delivered a healthy baby girl, apparently the first successful birth by a heart recipient, doctors said today.

title: NBC Poll Shows Reagan With Backing of 62% By The Associated Press
description: The Republican ticket of President Reagan and Vice President Bush is ahead of the Democratic Presidential nominees, Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro, 62 percent to 32 percent, according to an NBC News poll.

title: 18TH-CENTURY WRECK YIELDS GOLD RING AND TROVE OF COINS
description: The ocean floor has yielded a historic trove to treasure hunters: the gold ring of James Drew, captain of a British sloop of war that sank in 1798.

title: 'DYNASTY' WASHINGTON STYLE: FISHES, LONGS, PELLS
description: Portraits of their famous forebears beam down from their office walls, which are also festooned with political cartoons, campaign buttons and other memorabilia from another era. Many sit in chairs and work at desks used by the fathers, and, occasionally, the mothers, who preceded them in office.

title: Undergoing Treatment
description: Rob Bennett, West Viriginia's leading receiver, has been suspended and is undergoing treatment following his no-contest plea to public intoxication and resisting-arrest charges.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article yesterday about a new art gallery at 22 East 76th Street misidentified it. It is the Victor Galleries.

title: FRANCE AND LIBYA AGREE TO REMOVE TROOPS FROM CHAD
description: France and Libya have agreed to a ''total and simultaneous'' withdrawal of troops from Chad, the French Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: LEBANESE LEADERS MEET ON DISPUTES
description: Lebanon's divided Government began a series of special meetings today to try to agree on redistributing political power and extending Government control beyond the capital.

title: Louis Reard, Engineer, Dies; Designed the Bikini in 1946
description: Louis Reard, a French automobile engineer who designed the bikini swimsuit, died in a hospital here Sunday, his family said today.

title: Devaluation Set in Chile
description: Chile's Finance Minister, Luis Escobar, said the peso would be devalued to 115 to the dollar, from 93, effective Tuesday.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Egypt 80 Makes Debut, Led by Nigerian's Son

title: CROWN BOOKS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $470,000. c-Net income.

title: High-Jump Upset
description: Gerd Wessig of East Germany cleared 7 feet 6 1/2 inches in the high jump today and upset the holder of the world record, Zhu Jianhua, at the Nanjing international track and field meet.

title: DANCE:DEBUT OF EAST-WEST BALLET
description: ON Saturday night at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Korean Performing Arts Inc. presented what was announced as the debut of a new ballet troupe, the East-West Ballet Company. The participants included dancers of various ages and levels of technical ability from America, Korea, Japan and Russia. They never really seemed to be members of a well-organized company and the evening consisted of itsy-bitsy divertissements uncomfortably similar to the items that might turn up in the annual spring recital of a small-town dancing school.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $22,200,000, or $1.78 a share, from the sale of properties. c-Includes a gain of $1,000,000, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of properties.

title: CITY BEACHES' FINEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio City Refreshments
description: Q: What consumes 166 dozen bagels, 65 gallons of coffee, 62 1/2 pounds of cream cheese, 48 quarts of milk and 15 pounds of sugar?

title: Falcone Wants Out
description: Pete Falcone , whose pitching career took him from Lafayette High School and the Brooklyn sandlots to the major leagues, said he plans to retire after the season. ''I'm just tired of baseball,'' the 30-year Falcone, a 10-year veteran, said in an interview with The Atlanta Journal.

title: Leader Is Resigning At Provident Bancorp
description: Joseph F. Rippe, chairman since 1980 of the Provident Bancorp and its principal subsidiary, the Provident Bank, has resigned from both positions, the bank holding company announced. The resignation is effective Oct. 1.

title: BROKERS MORTGAGE SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Swiss Jobless Rate
description: The Swiss unemployment rate in August remained at 1.1 percent for the third consecutive month, the Government said today. It said 32,886 people were unemployed last month.

title: Reading by Israeli Author
description: Amoz Oz, author of ''In the Land of Israel'' and other works, will read from his writings on Oct. 15 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Oz was born in Israel and is one of the leaders of the Peace Now movement.

title: Chile's Ruler Extends State of Emergency
description: President Augusto Pinochet today renewed the state of emergency in Chile for another 90 days, extending his powers to restrict freedom of speech and assembly.

title: Elvis Anniversary Albums
description: The 50th anniversary of the birth of Elvis Presley, Jan. 8, will be marked with a series of albums released by RCA Records, beginning next month. The albums include previously unreleased live material, re-issues of early records and collections of his ''greatest hits.'' The records will be released through next year.

title: BUSH UNDER SCRUTINY: LAPSES RECALL DIFFERENCES WITH REAGAN
description: After resting quietly for the last three years in the political and ideological shadows of President Reagan, Vice President Bush is coming under increased scrutiny by the press and the public as he campaigns as Mr. Reagan's running mate. The examination, which is expected to intensify as the campaign continues, has raised some old political questions about his positions on issues and has resulted in some foulups by the usually unflappable Vice President.

title: Smiles of a Sunny Day
description: Looking apprehensive, a street character watched a police officer approach at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday.

title: A LONG WAIT FROM BACKUP TO STARTER
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

President Set to Leave Electrosound Group
description: Electrosound Group Inc., a record pressing and audio equipment company based in Hauppauge, L.I., announced that Richard H. Burkett will resign as president and chief executive officer, effective Nov. 1, to pursue other business opportunities.

description: * Beneficial Corp., Peapack, N.J., named Larry K. Morris president and chief operating officer of its commercial and industrial lending unit.

title: Koch Vows Enthusiasm For This Year's Ticket
description: Mayor Koch said today that he would campaign for Walter F. Mondale more enthusiastically than he did for President Carter four years ago.

title: VISICALC LAWSUIT IS SETTLED
description: One of the most bitterly fought lawsuits in the personal computer industry, pitting the company that developed the once-popular Visicalc program against the company that held the rights to market it, was settled out of court yesterday.

title: NEW VIEW OF FEMALE PRIMATES ASSAILS STEREOTYPES
description: AN explosion of knowledge about monkeys and apes is overturning long-held stereotypes about sex roles and social patterns among the closest kin to humans in the animal world.

title: THE DEFENSE ILLUSION
description: AVIGNON, France

title: Fair Weather
description: Motorists in New York City on Sunday found themselves walled in by street fairs. Third Avenue, one-way uptown, was closed for the annual Third Avenue Fair.

title: No Headline
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art will present a survey of films from a formative period in American independent film making with the opening Thursday of a series called ''The American Independent Cinema, 1958-1964.''

title: 6 Afghans Reported To Flee to Pakistan
description: Two former Afghan Army generals and four Government officials have defected to Pakistan, an Afghan refugee press service reported today.

title: KOCH REPORTS FINDS SERVICES IMPROVED
description: Serious crimes are down in New York City and felony arrests are up. The welfare rolls are growing, as are the ranks of homeless people. Streets are cleaner, even if they remain pockmarked. Students' test scores are above the national average, but fewer children are attending school.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 11
description: b-Includes tax credits of $274,000 for the quarter and $635,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $266,000 for the quarter and $462,000 for the 6 months.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1984 International A withdrawal of troops from Chad by France and Libya is scheduled, the French Foreign Ministry announced. It said the withdrawal would be ''total and simultaneous.'' The announcement followed an unannounced two- day trip to Libya by Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson during which he met with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. (Page A1, Column 4.) Ethiopia is suffering the worst drought-related famine in more than a decade, according to private relief workers and Western diplomats in Addis Ababa. Relief workers and Ethiopian officials said that tens of thousands of Ethiopians are probably dying of starvation and related diseases and that six million are in dire need of food. (A1:5.)

title: Time Running Out On a Rehearsal Studio
description: There was the familiar sound of upright piano and dancing feet in the Minskoff Rehearsal Studio as the national touring company of ''Doonesbury'' started learning the routines.

title: No Headline
description: Tony Danza Sentenced To 250 Hours of Service

title: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 4
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: JETS KEEP MCNEIL BUSY
description: Freeman McNeil said today that his right leg was still tired, then added proudly, ''It's hard work that's gotten it where it is.''

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 11
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ford Sets 85 Price Rise of 1.3%
description: The Ford Motor Company today said that it would increase the retail price of its 1985 model cars by an average of $153, or 1.3 percent, somewhat less than the tentative prices announced earlier.

title: GAMBLING RAIDS YIELD 23 ARRESTS AND COMPUTER
description: Eleven illegal bookmaking establishments in New York City and New Jersey were raided last night and 23 people were arrested, the police said. Authorities said they also seized a personal computer that calculated odds.

title: ADVANCED LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
9,706 NEW CITIZENS HEAR BUSH
description: Vice President Bush attended a mass swearing-in of new citizens in the Orange Bowl in Miami today, saying he had come on ''a nonpartisan mission in a fairly partisan time.''

title: The Millionaires
description: Millionaires - more than a hundred of them - crowded a theater at South Street Seaport for a free drink, some free hors d'oeuvres and a free show.

title: REAGAN AND BUSH TO DEBATE TWICE, RUNNING MATES ONCE
description: The League of Women Voters announced today that it had concluded an agreement to sponsor two 90-minute debates next month between President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale and one 90- minute debate between Vice President Bush and Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available since this is the company's initial year of operations. Braniff is a majority-owned subsidiary of Dalfort Corp.

title: Cascade Steel
description: Cascade Steel Rolling Mills Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by a subsidiary of the Schnitzer Steel Products Company.

title: ADVERTISING ; People
description: * Jerry Bonsaing named senior vice president at Backer & Spielvogel.

title: A QUID PRO QUO FOR STEEL
description: Ronald Reagan can become the first President to develop a new concept in Federal assistance called ''conditionality'' to help restructure a major industry - a chance presented by his own appointees on the International Trade Commission.

title: U.S. Set Back In a blow to the United States, the Royal Perth Yacht Club has selected the Costa Smeralda Yacht Club of Porto Cerva, Sardinia, as the ''challenger of record'' for the 1987 America's Cup. This means that the Sardinian club will oversee the organization and running of the challenge races in Australia. The move came despite the dominant role the United States has played in the cup races. Before Australia II's victory off Newport, R.I., last year, Americans had a string of victories dating to 1851, keeping the trophy in the grasp of the New York Yacht Club. ''Although we are looking forward to meeting a large group of capable competitors in 1987,'' said Dr.
description: Stan Reid , chairman of the Royal Perth club's America's Cup Committee, ''we felt that the Costa Smeralda Yacht Club was particularly well qualified to serve as the challenger of record.''

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONFIDING IN OTHERS IMPROVESS HEALTH
description: C ONFESSION, whatever it may do for the soul, appears to be good for the body. New studies show that people who are able to confide in others about their troubled feelings or some traumatic event, rather than bear the turmoil in silence, are less vulnerable to illnesses.

title: Reagan Aide Predicts Edge Among Democrats
description: President Reagan would get the votes of 29 percent of registered Democrats if the election were held now, Edward J. Rollins, the Reagan campaign director, said today.

title: Robert C. Good Dead at 60; First Ambassador to Zambia
description: Robert C. Good, former president of Denison University in Granville, Ohio, and the first United States Ambassador to Zambia, died Sunday of a brain tumor at University Medical Center. He was 60 years old.

title: MOROCCO JUSTIFIES UNION WITH LIBYA
description: Morocco's union with Libya has been justified by Libya's agreement with France to withdraw from Chad, Moroccan officials said today.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
A HIGHER TOLL IS SEEN FOR ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's economic crisis has worsened because President Raul Alfonsin missed earlier opportunities to revamp the country's policies, and Argentina now must pay a higher price in terms of additional austerity, according to Reagan Administration financial officials.

title: WITNESS SAYS SHE FEARS 'CHILD PREDATOR' NETWORK
description: A nationally recognized expert in the treatment of sexually abused children testified today that she suspected that there was a wide network of ''child predators'' and that although evidence was circumstantial, it seemed to indicate a conspiracy to operate day care centers as a cover for child pornography.

title: A-Arms Protests in England
description: Several dozen antinuclear protesters halted a train in central England today and climbed over wire fencing onto a base for United States nuclear bombers. A United States Air Force spokesman said more than 40 people were detained at Upper Heyford Airfield after they went into the base and spray-painted slogans on the runway and a radar building. Rail officials said the demonstrators pulled the emergency cord of a train from London as it passed close to the base.

title: Center Devoted to African Art Opens
description: The man has a bolt in the top of his head. His name is Gbo. He is wearing a dress made of hammered iron and a hat decorated with fishooks, metal spikes and arrowheads. In the Republic of Benin in Africa he is a god of war and the patron saint of taxi drivers, mechanics and bicycle repairmen, who keep small shrines to him in their shops and homes.

title: The Line-Item Veto Is a Fake President Reagan asserts at every opportunity that something called the line-item veto would enable him to conquer the runaway spenders on Capitol Hill. It sounds reasonable, but it's a fake.
description: Every President has chafed at the practical impossibility of rejecting individual programs in otherwise acceptable appropriations bills. To get at one such item requires vetoing an agency's whole budget.

title: The Super Rumor
description: Many, if not most, of Washington's mischievous rumors originate on Capitol Hill with whippersnappers and wiseacres who take a bit of truth and twist it, then watch other people spread it. Such is probably the case with the Super Bowl-Inauguration Rumor.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WAGS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONNECTICUT'S ECONOMY IS NOW ONE OF BEST IN U.S.
description: Fueled by high levels of defense spending and enjoying one of the lowest unemployment rates in the country, the economy of Connecticut in recent months has become one of the nation's strongest.

title: ISOLATE NICARAGUA IF IT WON'T BEND, MONDALE SUGGESTS
description: Walter F. Mondale says that if Nicaragua rejected a good-faith compromise and continued to export revolution in Central America, he would respond with a ''quarantine.''

title: Intruder Shoots at Principal
description: The principal of a Bronx elementary school narrowly escaped injury at 8 A.M. yesterday when a shot fired by an intruder passed through his shirt but did not strike him, the police said.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE PHONE-COMPUTER FUSION
description: One of the next big pushes in office automation, telecommunications experts say, will be voice-data work stations - desktop machines for managers that combine a personal computer and an advanced telephone in a single, compact unit.

description: To the Editor:

description: Mount Fuji, the alluring snow- streaked symbol of Japan, is falling apart.

title: 'HUNTER' AND 'JESSIE' 2 SHOWS ABOUT POLICE
description: -ADVENTURE has come screeching back onto the television schedule this season, and two contrasting examples of the form are making debuts as special two-hour movies tonight at 9: ''Hunter'' on NBC, and ''Jessie'' on ABC.

title: ; Springfield Sold Out At Music Hall Concerts
description: Probably no pop singer today evokes more female hysteria per square yard than Rick Springfield, who sold out three nights at Radio City Music Hall, Saturday through Monday. At 35, Mr. Springfield is far from a moist-behind-the-ears teen idol.

title: 20-HOUR BARGAINING SESSION STALLS IN G.M. STRIKES
description: Strikes continued today at 13 facilities of the General Motors Corporation after negotiations for a new agreement broke down early in the morning.

description: The Air Force's explanations of the latest spare parts scandal shed light on a matter that transcends the overpricing of spare parts.

title: YANKS WIN ON 5-RUN EIGHTH
description: Playing as if the division had not been decided long ago, the Yankees and Orioles shared a mightily charged evening of baseball that took its final turn in the eighth inning last night, when Don Baylor and Ken Griffey emerged as the heroes and the Yankees scored five times to win, 12-7.

title: REGULATOR'S DEFENSE ON CONTINENTAL
description: In an apparent attempt to pre-empt a Congressional hearing, the Comptroller of the Currency has circulated a six- page memorandum defending his staff's supervision of the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and the Reagan Administration's commitment to deregulation.

title: NEW YORK ; KEEPING WOMEN OUT
description: One would have thought that by 1984, after decades of civil rights progress and the lifting of barrier after barrier, the men's clubs in New York City would have done the civilized thing and ended their holy war to keep women out. After all, don't we imagine our city to be the center of civilized thought and discourse, the beacon of liberty for all, the example-setter for the nation?

title: ; Michel Block Performs At Alice Tully Hall
description: One could almost admire Michel Block's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon before the first note was played. What a rich and ambitious collection of music this was - Messiaen's ''Le baiser de l'enfant- Jesus'' from the ''Vingt regards,'' ''El Amor y la Muerte'' from Granados's ''Goyescas,'' a Faure Nocturne, Berio's ''Cinque variazioni,'' with Schumann and Rachmaninoff added thereto.

title: NightFlightLeads To L.I. Summons
description: A private jet was caught landing at Long Island MacArthur Airport at 2:30 A.M., and its owner has become the first to receive a summons for violating this town's ban on late-night flights, Town Supervisor Michael LoGrande said today.

description: slam by Lou Whitaker keyed a six-run sixth inning as Detroit gained at

title: Democratic Gallows
description: Not so long ago, Democratic Party officials were in full smirk telling Ronald Reagan jokes: about letting Reagan be Reagan, about the President snoozing at Cabinet meetings, bombing the Russians in a voice check, needing prompting by his wife at news conferences. But, with the recent eruption of polls showing the President far out in front of his challenger, Walter F. Mondale, much of the Democratic japery has turned to gallows humor.

title: Georgia Education Pact Avoids U.S. Fund Loss
description: Georgia has made ''substantial progress'' in speeding up the desegregation of its 33 colleges and universities and no longer faces losing up to $200 million in Federal education funds, Government officials said today.

title: Japan's Steel Output
description: Japan's production of steel in the fourth quarter will rise six-tenths of 1 percent, to 26.7 million tons, from the current quarter, and 3.7 percent from the period a year earlier, the Government predicted today.

title: A REDSKIN SUBSTITUTE SPOILS THE GIANTS' DAY

title: New Illinois Issue All Zero Coupon
description: The University of Illinois has arranged an unusual tax-exempt financing consisting of $229 million face amount of zero coupon bonds to raise $55 million in current dollars. According to the underwriters, led by John Nuveen & Company, it is the first bond issue in the tax-exempt market consisting entirely of zero coupon bonds, which pay no interest.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE week was, by turn, ridiculous, sublime and, in a few instances, unbelievable. What else could it be when, at David Rockefeller Jr.'s, cocktail party for the American Council for the Arts, Oscar de la Renta announced that he was coming out with a new line of clothes for Barbie dolls?

description: b-Includes profit of $43,000 from sales of investments. c-Includes profit of $3,000 from sales of investments.
