description: The Province of Quebec is offering two bond issues today totaling $250 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: CoralloSurrenders InL.I.CartingPlot
description: Antonio Corallo, described by state authorities as the head of the Lucchese organized-crime group, surrendered today to face charges that he led a conspiracy to get underworld domination of Long Island's private garbage collection industry.

title: JURT DELIBERATIONS START TODAY IN OMEGA 7 TRIAL
description: A prosecutor told the jury in a Manhattan trial yesterday that a Cuban exile, Eduardo Arocena, was ''the leader, founder and chief bomb maker'' of a terrorist group called Omega 7.

title: A TUTOR REFINING ATHLETE-BROADCASTERS
description: For years, Howard Cosell has

title: Microchip Tests Made
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that an investigation of microchips used in Pentagon weapons systems showed that more than 90 percent of those reviewed so far had been properly tested.

title: NEC Expansion
description: The NEC Corporation, the Japanese electronics concern, said that it would invest $95 million at its semiconductor plant in Livingston, Scotland, in the so-called Silicon Glen.

title: Kentucky Bonds To Yield 10.557%
description: A $62.3 million financing by Owensboro, Ky., was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.557 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2004 offered at a price of 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Matthews & Wright.

title: ACCORD IN CONGRESS SETS '81 CUTOFF DATE FOR ALIEN AMNESTY
description: House and Senate negotiators drafting a comprehensive immigration bill agreed today to offer legal status to illegal aliens who entered the United States before Jan. 1, 1981, and have lived here continuously since then.

description: b-The company said that comparable year-ago results are not available as Ambulatory Medical was operated as a proprietorship prior to July 1, 1983.

title: ADVANCED SCANNING INFRARED IS TESTED
description: A N advanced type of laser that makes it possible for the first time to scan across the upper infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum has been developed by physicists at the University of California at Santa Barbara.

title: Internorth Seeks To Buy Chemplex
description: Internorth Inc., which makes plastics and adhesives and is active in oil and natural gas exploration and production, said it had tentatively agreed to buy the Chemplex Company of Rolling Meadows, Ill., from Texaco Inc. The agreement follows an announcement last week from Mapco Inc. that it had agreed with Texaco to terminate talks on the purchase of Chemplex, a producer of ethylene and polyethylene resins.

title: 'SUPPLY-SIDE' CLAIMS DOUBTED
description: Four years after President Reagan extolled its virtues as an antidote for a stagnant economy plagued by a high inflation rate, ''supply-side'' economics is basking in the glow of a vigorous economic expansion with low inflation.

title: Computer Crime Bill Voted
description: The House passed a bill today by voice vote that would make it a Federal crime to gain unauthorized access to or tamper with computerized medical records. The bill, sent to the Senate, would set a maximum punishment of one year in prison and a $5,000 fine for unauthorized access. The maximum penalty for altering records would be $25,000 in fines and five years in prison.

title: 2 Men Are Shot, One Fatally, In Car on Williamsburg Bridge
description: One man was shot to death and another critically wounded on the Williamsburgh Bridge last night as bullets tore into their automobile and brought it to a halt near the bridge's Manhattan entrance, the police said. The wounded man was taken to Bellevue Hospital in serious condition.

title: Hot Mud Runs Down From Philippine Volcano
description: Some 26,000 people were said to have fled to evacuation centers to take shelter today as heavy rainfall brought swift mudflows from the Mount Mayon volcano.

title: MARINO STAR AS DOLPHINS WIN
description: Dan Marino continued his excellent passing, throwing three touchdown strikes, as the Miami Dolphins raced to an 18-point lead and held off a Buffalo rally to beat the Bills, 21-17, tonight.

title: KNAPP SAID TO RECEIVE $2 MILLION
description: The American Savings and Loan Association is trying to raise $1 billion in fresh deposits. Page D8.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: LOTS OF DRAWINGS Drawings are among the most demanding sort of art for the museum visitor to walk through; they are more often than not delicate and, in comparison with other art, less likely to leap out at one. But drawings can also be most rewarding for the museumgoer who takes the time to do more than bestow a mere glance as he rushes by. The art of draftsmanship involves painstaking attention to detail and welding the details into a meaningful and artistic whole.

title: Dr. David E. Sweet, 51, Dies; Head of Rhode Island College
description: Dr. David E. Sweet, president of Rhode Island College for the past seven years, died Sunday night at Roger Williams Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: No Headline
description: * Allnet Communication Services Inc. said it had signed a one-year agreement with Southwestern Bell Telephone, a subsidiary of Southwestern Bell Corp., for selective billing services as equal access becomes available. Terms were not disclosed.

title: OPTIMISM IS NOW RESTRAINED
description: N ATURE, one of the world's foremost scientific weeklies, conceded in an editorial recently that the journal may have been ''over optimistic'' last year in predicting rapid progress in understanding the biology of cancer.

title: GAULTIER'S U.S. DEBUT: A THREE RING AFFAIR
description: The fall fashion season got off to a whirling start last night with Bergdorf Goodman's staging of the Jean- Paul Gaultier fashion show in Battery Park, the first time that designer's clothes have been shown in this country.

title: Toasting the Phillips
description: In the rooms the people come and go, talking of Matisse and Rouault. That is once again an accurate description of the scene at the Phillips Collection, the nation's first modern art museum, which plans to reopen all its rooms in its two mansions in Northwest Washington today for the first time in 15 months.

title: Maloney Is Hoping Brawn Will Help
description: The difference, right now, can only be measured in inches and pounds. Dave Maloney fills out his shirts slightly more through the chest these days and his weight, around 188 pounds for most of his career, is up to 198.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $95,000.

title: LOBBYIST IS NAMED TO HEAD THE H.R.A.
description: A Washington lobbyist was named by Mayor Koch yesterday to head New York City's troubled Human Resources Administration.

title: 'SOME' ARE KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA AS POLICE AND BLACK MINERS CLASH
description: South African authorities said tonight that ''some'' black gold miners were killed today when the police confronted 8,000 rioters at a mine at Westonaria, outside Johannesburg. A police spokesman described the encounter as ''heavy.''

title: E. J. ANDRE
description: E. J. Andre, a character actor who portrayed Uncle Jed in the motion picture ''Little House on the Prairie,'' died of cancer Sept. 6 in his Hollywood home.

title: MODERN PLANS SERIES ON ARCHITECTS
description: The Museum of Modern Art, which in recent years has been criticized for devoting too much of its attention to the work of artists and architects of the past, announced yesterday that it will inaugurate a series of five exhibitions of the work of significant contemporary architects.

title: FOR SMOKED FISH, THE BROOKLYN TOUCH
description: BUZZ BILLIK is a bearded, intense young man whose working attire starts with a blue and white baseball cap and ends with a pair of heavy rubber boots. The baseball cap is a personal whim for a man whose real name is John but who is known throughout his trade as Buzz. The boots, however, are a necessary part of his gear. Mr. Billik, who is a partner in the Marshall Smoked Fish Company on Anthony Street in Brooklyn, spends much of his time stomping through large puddles of watery brine and slogging in and out of dark, gritty smoke ovens.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Drexel Wins Bids for 2 Key Bonds
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., not known as a powerhouse in the tax-exempt bond market, jumped to the foreground yesterday when it was the winning bidder and sole underwriter for two of this week's largest offerings.

title: HOUSE WON'T LIMIT INSANITY DEFENSE
description: A bill to curb the defense of insanity in the Federal courts failed in the House today, with Republicans leading the opposition despite widespread support among Democrats and Republicans alike for narrowing the defense.

title: German Car Output Up
description: Production of cars, trucks and buses in West Germany totaled 300,400 in August, up 10.5 percent from the month before and up 11.2 percent from August 1983, the auto makers' association said today.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 4
description: b-Net income.

title: Kaypro Is Sued
description: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against the Kaypro Corporation, a manufacturer of microcomputers, by a stockholder, George Franklin of New York. The lawsuit names as defendants certain members of the Kay family, who own about 86 percent of the company's stock, according to last year's proxy statement, and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The suit charges that the prospectus for the offer of Kaypro stock contained untrue statements, that the defendants inflated earnings by overstating inventory and that they listed figures that resulted in the stock price being artificially inflated. Kaypro said the corporation ''believes there is no substance'' to the charges.

title: Needham Resignation
description: Joel Baumwoll, 44-year-old former president of the New York office of Needham Harper Worldwide, has resigned from the company in order to become a consultant in advertising and marketing. His move comes less than a week after the board named Keith Reinhard chairman and chief executive of the whole company.

title: Emphasis Is Clear
description: The campaign by the Rutgers athletic department to emphasize the college's identity as the State University of New Jersey became clearly visible to fans attending the football team's home opener against Temple last Saturday.

title: Turkish Union in Strike Vote
description: A trade union has voted to go on strike in two small private shipyards, the first such decision since the military coup of September 1980.

title: Economic Scene; The Dangers If Dollar Falls
description: AS the United States dollar continues to climb to record heights against foreign currencies, the nation's trade deficit continues to worsen.

title: People Express Adds Coast Route
description: People Express Airlines Inc. said it would begin service between Newark and the Oakland International Airport on Sept. 28 with one round-trip flight daily.

title: KENNEDY 'MISSES THE POINT' ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Rangaire Sale
description: The Rangaire Corporation said its board had approved a $10-a-share acquisition from Hicks & Haas, a private investor partnership based in Dallas. Rangair, based in Cleburne, Tex., makes lighting fixtures and other appliances. Based on the company's approximately 3.8 million shares outstanding, the transaction would be valued at about $38 million.

title: Comings and Goings The Los Angeles Dodgers have rehired their entire coaching staff, including Ron Perranoski, Manny Mota and
description: Joe Amalfitano, for next season. . . . A prosecutor in Boulder, Colo., said that third-degree sexual assault charges would not be filed against the former Knick, Glen Gondrezick, because of insufficient evidence. . . . Rick Mears, the two-time Indianapolis 500 champion, is recovering from foot injuries he suffered in a crash in Canada on Sept. 7, and will be ready for a second operation at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis on Monday, according to his doctor.

title: RICHARD BASEHART, STAGE AND SCREEN STAR, DIES
description: Richard Basehart, the sonorous- voiced actor who starred on Broadway in ''The Hasty Heart'' and on the screen in ''La Strada'' and ''Moby Dick,'' died Monday in Los Angeles after suffering a series of strokes. He was 70 years old.

title: Ford Shuts Line
description: The Ford Motor Company temporarily laid off the 2,500 employees on its passenger car assembly line at its plant here, said a Ford spokesman, Robert Pollock, because of a shortage of good quality parts from an outside supplier. The line makes Tempo and Mercury Topaz models.

title: WHAT THE ISRAELI VOTERS GOT
description: There was no feeling of jubilation or even relief in Israel when the Likud-Labor coalition Government was sworn in last week. Two months of political crisis are over, but the deadlock produced by the July elections remains. Indeed, Prime Minister Shimon Peres's Cabinet, with its built-in veto powers and absolute parity for both major parties, is a reflection par excellence of that political deadlock.

title: 2 Auburn Inmates Stabbed in Brawl
description: Two inmates at the Auburn state prison have been stabbed since the weekend in the fourth and fifth stabbings at the prison this month, the State Department of Correctional Services said.

title: Getty and 399 Others On Forbes's Rich List
description: For the second year running, Gordon P. Getty sits atop the Forbes magazine list of America's wealthiest individuals.

title: MOLESTER OF BOYS TALKS TO SENATORS
description: ''How many children have you molested?'' Senator Arlen Specter asked the gray- haired, bespectacled man seated before him.

title: SLIGHT RISE SEEN IN GAS PRICES
description: Homeowners who heat with natural gas can expect to face only slight price increases this winter despite the impending removal of Federal price controls on more than half the nation's production.

title: AUTO PACT TALKS RECESS AS UNION EXTENDS STRIKES
description: Talks between the United Auto Workers union and the General Motors Corporation recessed early this morning with the union increasing the pressure on G.M. by authorizing approximately 30,000 more workers to begin strikes.

title: NATIONWIDE POWER reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring non-operating loss of $4.4 million. c-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated for new accounting procedure.

title: Thanks, but . . .
description: President Reagan, as all the nation is aware, likes nothing better than to weave a sentimental anecdote about a real American into his speeches. It is fairly unusual, however, for the subject of the anecdote to respond by shrugging off the arm that Mr. Reagan has affectionately thrown around his shoulder.

title: Cat Gets a New Life
description: This is the story of a street cat that

title: Danish Unemployment
description: Denmark's unemployment rate was 10.5 percent of the work force in July, down a bit from 10.6 percent a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: KURDISH PEOPLE'S LOSS OF A BRAVE SPOKESMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST GERMANS PAY THEIR CHIEF A SUBDUED RESPECT
description: It was appropriate, and probably not accidental, that the day after he postponed a visit to West Germany, Erich Honecker chose to receive a delegation of West German environmentalists led by a native of the Saar, where the East German leader himself was born in 1912.

title: RICHARDSON LOSES IN SENATE PRIMARY
description: In a major upset tonight with national implications, Raymond Shamie, a conservative businessman who strongly supports President Reagan, defeated Elliot L. Richardson, the former United States Attorney General, in the Massachusetts Republican Senate primary.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: MAESTRI AT THE MAESTRO

title: Anderson Says Key GoalIs Defeat of Reagan
description: John B. Anderson, the 1980 independent Presidential candidate, says it is more important to remove Ronald Reagan from the White House in 1984 than to keep trying to build support for a third party.

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE A BIT IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday, with all of the gains coming during afternoon trading.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GOD KNOWS. By Joseph Heller. 353 pages. Knopf. $16.95.

title: RUSSIAN WHO WON ASYLUM IN BRITAIN IS BACK IN MOSCOW
description: A Soviet journalist who spent the past year in Britain turned up here today and said that he was abducted in 1983 by British agents while attending the Venice Film Festival and had been forced to make anti-Soviet statements.

title: A KASPAROV MISTAKE GAVE KARPOV THE VICTORY
description: An unprovoked error cost Gary Kasparov the third game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in Moscow Monday night. The 21-year-old challenger now trails the 33-year-old champion by 0-1.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates fell slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $100 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 11.158 percent, down from 11.269 percent last week. A $50 million sale of 182-day paper resulted in an average rate of 11.046 percent, down from 11.156 percent a week ago.

title: INDEPENDENT PRODUCERS BUY RIGHTS TO 'WIRED'
description: The film rights to ''Wired,'' Bob Woodward's biography of the life and drug death of the comedian John Belushi, have been purchased by the Feldman- Meeker Company, a small, independent film production company.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Capt. Bob Munoz, a jovial salt with more than 40 years in the New York Harbor, piloted his rusty tugboat across Upper New York Bay yesterday, chugging along during a slow work period and telling old tales of the sea - one of which he touted as ''damned near true.''

title: Owner Can Leave Ice on Sidewalk
description: Municipalities and residential property owners have no duty to remove ice and snow from a public sidewalk and cannot be sued by a person who falls and is injured, the Appellate Division of State Superior Court ruled today.

title: '84 WORLD'S FAIR DEFAULTS ON LOAN OF $40 MILLION BUT WILL CARRY ON
description: The 1984 World's Fair, plagued by lagging attendance, lagging revenues and annoyed creditors, has defaulted on a $40 million corporate-guaranteed bank loan that helped open the exposition May 12.

title: TWO SWELL GALAS BETTER THAN ONE
description: IT was one of those Monday

title: Treating Dry Mouth TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: I should like to add some important, helpful facts on dry mouth and Sjogren's syndrome to the information contained in Jane Brody's Personal Health column (Sept. 5).

title: ARGENTINA CALLS I.M.F. PACT NEAR
description: Argentina completed the technical work today on an agreement with the International Monetary Fund that would enable it to secure a 15-month standby loan of $1.4 billion, according to Bernardo Grinspun, Argentina's Economy Minister.

title: Bereavement Can Spur Illness, Scientists Say
description: The death of a close family member leaves some survivors vulnerable to physical or mental illness, but reactions to bereavement vary widely, a National Academy of Sciences report said today.

title: SEABROOK COST WARNING ISSUED BY LEAD UTILITY
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that its share of the cost of finishing the Seabrook nuclear plant could be twice as high as previously estimated. But a spokesman for the utility said yesterday that this was the high end of the possible range and that Public Service did not regard the cost as certain to go that high.

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE ; New Citicorp Head Shifts Key Aides
description: In his first major management shuffle since taking over as chairman of Citicorp this month, John S. Reed yesterday began moving his key lieutenants into senior positions in the area of the company headed by Thomas O. Theobald, who was Mr. Reed's chief rival for the No. 1 spot. But Mr. Reed also promoted a number of senior officials who report to Mr. Theobald, signaling that his former rival's staff will still have opportunities within the organization.

title: FERRARO SAYS PUBLIC'S ADMIRATION FOR REAGAN AS LEADER UPSETS HER
description: Maybe, as she said late in the day, it was because she had a cold coming on. Or maybe it was just that she was tired of hearing about unfavorable polls and predictions. But Geraldine Ferraro was disgusted.

title: Senate Votes to End Filibuster on TV Bill
description: The Senate voted 73 to 26 today to cut off debate so that it could take up a measure that would allow gavel-to-gavel television and radio coverage of its sessions.

title: Sailing, Sailing
description: Back in the Gold Rush days of 1851,

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You just have to go for it, go for it. That's the American way.''

title: ; WHY POLICE OFFICERS NEED A COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: 'Sister Mary Ignatius' Draws Boston Pickets

title: All Hail Queens!
description: Queens County, relegated to dingy obscurity for most of its 86 years as part of New York City, seems to be blossoming forth. With Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro and Governor Cuomo spreading the fame of their borough around the country, once-shy Queens natives are pridefully proclaiming their roots in Jamaica, Hollis and Long Island City.

title: SHULTZ GIVES VIEW ON GROMYKO TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he and President Reagan plan to deliver ''a very positive message'' to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko next week on the Administration's desire for ''a more constructive relationship'' with the Soviet Union.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a charge of $375,000 relating to costs incurred in preparation of possible overseas public financing and an extraordinary gain of $2,693,000, or $1.42 a share, on the liquidation of long-term debt. c-Includes income of $1,411,000, or 79 cents a share, from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
S.A.S. Orders Jets
description: Scandinavian Airlines System said it is ordering new jetliners valued at $150 million from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis. Jan Carlzon, S.A.S.'s president and chief executive, said the DC-9-80's would service routes in Europe and within Scandinavia.

title: LEBANON APPEALS FOR RELEASE OF ALL HOSTAGES
description: Lebanon's Cabinet ministers decided today to tell their private armies to free everyone they had kidnapped.

title: Blow to Afghan Rebels By Russians Reported
description: Soviet forces trying to capture an Afghan guerrilla leader, Ahmad Shah Masood, killed 200 to 300 of his rebels this month, Western diplomats said here today.

title: Accounts
description: * Wigwam Mills Inc., Skis Dynastar and Stratojac Inc. to Ferber, Janklow, Chimbel, Bender.

title: Cargo Bill Is Defeated WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -
description: The House of Representatives

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIRE FOR THOUGHT
description: I have been thinking all week about

title: THE 'CANARD' ABOUT U.S. NUCLEAR INFERIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Burnup & Sims Inc. said it had been selected by Warner Communications Inc. and Warner Amex Cable Communications Co. to build a 1,250-mile cable television system in Milwaukee in a $12.5 million deal.

title: TIGERS CLINCH EAST
description: The Detroit Tigers won their first American League Eastern Division championship since 1972 tonight as Randy O'Neal, making his first major league start, pitched seven scoreless innings and the Tigers beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-0.

title: A U.N. APPEAL TO MAJOR POWERS
description: The 39th annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly opened here today with a plea that the major powers resolve their political differences quickly, if not for themselves then for the smaller nations.

title: REAGAN SEEKS CUT IN STEEL IMPORTS THROUGH ACCORDS
description: President Reagan today ordered actions that the White House said would reduce steel imports and help the American steel industry.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. While three of their Western Division counterparts continue fighting it out in the last two weeks of the season, all the American League's Eastern Division clubs except Detroit look for consolations large and small.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIDGE: LONG ISLAND COUPLE WINNERS TWO WEEKENDS IN A ROW
description: To finish at the top of a large, strong field on consecutive weekends is a rare feat. It was achieved by Janice and David Wachsman of North Hills, L.I., who followed a Grand National Pairs success 10 days ago with a victory Sunday in the Nassau-Suffolk Swiss Team Championship at Garden City, L.I.

title: Careers; Computer Job Scene Changing
description: ''ALMOST everyone still asks about careers in computer science these days,'' a career counselor remarked recently. But the answer is not so optimistic as it was a few years ago, she said, because what used to be a growth area for jobs has probably reached maturity.

title: 34 Dead in Ecuador As Cargo Plane Explodes
description: An Ecuadorean cargo plane clipped a bus and exploded on a building site while trying to take off from the airport here today, killing 34 people and injuring 50, hospital and airport sources said.

title: BONSAI CAMPAIGN: REAGAN DRIVE LESS THAN MEETS EYE
description: Of all the political arts practiced by Ronald Reagan, the newest may be his skill at what could be termed bonsai campaigning: dwarfing his campaign week, much like the Japanese art of making shrubs resemble tiny trees, into a few events that usually allow everyone, especially the President, to be home for dinner after a telegenic hour or two out on the hustings.

title: STEEL ACTION WINS BACKING
description: Users, foreign exporters and makers of steel and steel products had an initially favorable reaction yesterday to the Reagan Administration's announcement that it will seek new restraints on imports of steel, saying that the Administration avoided a blatantly protectionist move while still guarding against trade abuses.

title: SOVIET EXPECTED TO FREE 5 ALASKANS SOON
description: The captain of an Alaskan coastal fuel-supply ship that was seized last week by the Russians said today that he and his four-man crew had been told by United States diplomats that they would be released soon, ''maybe in a day, maybe two.''

title: Rating the Football Glut
description: Is the college football glut on television a plus or a minus for the networks, the independent stations and the various packagers?

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Put on a Happy Wake
description: In the tradition of the legendary

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 12 through 16 with 1,546 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,135 said they were registered to vote.

title: ANOTHER FLORIDA CITRUS GROVE BURNED IN RACE AGAINST DISEASE
description: The destruction of a 40-acre citrus nursery commenced today as state agriculture agents raced to halt the spread of a disease that threatens Florida's orange and grapefruit industry.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York, in its second financing in three weeks, is offering nearly $212.5 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The bonds were tentatively offered with a maximum yield of 10.10 percent for 7 percent bonds due in 2017 and 10.08 percent for 10 percent bonds due in 2004.

title: ECUMED PROJECT NAMES FORMER MT. SINAI HEAD
description: Samuel Davis, who until last Friday was president of Mount Sinai Hospital, has been named president and chief executive of Ecumed, a new international health-care and exhibition center, it was announced.

title: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Democrats Clarifying Grenada Differences
description: In an interview Sunday with The New York Times, Walter F. Mondale said he believed that he would have used force in Grenada ''to go in there and protect American lives.''

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: GEAC COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STRAWBERRY SHOT TOPS PHILS IN 9TH
description: The Mets didn't have Dwight Gooden out there tonight, firing the heater and striking out all those batters. But they did produce another dramatic form of the art when Darryl Strawberry hit a two-out, three-run home run off Al Holland in the ninth inning to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-5.

title: STATE SAYS ART COUNCIL IS WASTING MONEY
description: The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today that the New York State Council on the Arts spends about $84,000 annually for unnecessary consultants to review grant recommendations made by the council's own staff.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Workers at Disneyland Reject Contract Offer
description: Members of a union representing nearly 1,900 Disneyland employees have voted to reject a new contract, but union and company officials agreed to meet with a Federal mediator Thursday before any strike.

title: TOP WINE MAKERS OF FRANCE RAISE A GLASS TO THE U.S.
description: Bordeaux merchants have been selling wine to foreigners at least since the Norman Conquest and, in nine centuries, they've never lost their touch. The result, after some nine centuries of honing their sales skills, is a blend of pomp and ceremony, shrewd commercialism and pure nonsense that has made Bordeaux the envy of the rest of the wine world.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 19, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Payment Ordered for Bridge
description: Federal District Judge Daniel H. Thomas Monday ordered the owners of the phosphate freighter Summit Venture to pay the state $19 million as compensation for the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, damaged four years ago in a collision in which 35 people were killed. An attorney for Hercules Carriers Inc., which owns the vessel, said no decision had been made on an appeal.

title: TIE TO LATIN REBELS
description: The Pentagon acknowledged today that the Air Force had given three surplus planes to ''another government agency,'' but declined to confirm that the planes had been passed on to insurgent forces in Nicaragua.

title: AT THESE SCHOOLS, 'AVERAGE' STUDENTS DO NOT GET LOST
description: The 20 sophomores in Kathy Barnes's English 112 class at Greenwich High School are average students, the silent wheels of most public high schools. Nonetheless, she believes that they deserve some oil, just like the gifted and the troubled students who normally command the most attention.

title: An Olympic Bonanza For a Job Well Done
description: Lolly Keys had joined the army of volunteers who worked for the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee just for the fun of being part of the Olympics. And because she had already received several letters from the organizing committee in the past few weeks, thanking her for her efforts, she was surprised to see another envelope from the committee in her mailbox last week.

title: AGE OF VIDEO SPAWNS NEED FOR TECHNICIANS
description: Finding enough skilled workers for new trades has always been a problem. Mechanics were at a premium in the age of steam, telegraphers scarce in the years after Morse and today video needs more competent technicians than are readily to be found.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Cub Fans Settle on Roof The owner and tenants of an apartment building across from Wrigley Field have settled their roof squabble.
description: Jon A. Duncan and his roommate, James W. Eakle, residents of the building, had filed suit against the landlord, Steven D. Woodruff , to keep their view of Wrigley Field during playoff and World Series games. Duncan testified in Cook County Circuit Court that Woodruff did not restrict the use of the rooftop to watch games until the playoffs became imminent. The settlement allows five people from the first floor, 15 from the second and 20 from the third, with an additional 20 spots reserved for the owner.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT has always struck me as odd

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
AlvaradoCaseFigure Is Arrested in Assault
description: John Chin, the former Board of Education employee whose arrest last February led to the suspension and resignation of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado, was arrested again yesterday. He was accused this time of imprisoning and assaulting a 22-year-old woman in his apartment at 95 West 95th Street.

title: MONDALE'S ATTACKS TAKE ON A PERSONAL TONE
description: With polls showing him falling further and further behind his opponent, Walter F. Mondale has reached beyond his emphasis on issues and has begun attacking President Reagan fiercely and directly.

title: MAN IS ACCUSED OF AIDING KILLER OF ESSEX OFFICER
description: A Long Island man was arraigned in Superior Court here today on a charge of murdering an Essex County police officer on Monday with a blast from his shotgun.

title: 25-Year Jail Term Given In Detroit Racial Slaying
description: A man once given probation by a state judge for beating a Chinese-American to death was sentenced today to 25 years in prison for violating the victim's Federal civil rights on racial grounds.

title: ; Canadian Singer Makes U.S. Debut at the Ritz
description: Whimsy and complexity are spun together in the songs of Jane Siberry, who made her United States debut Monday at the Ritz. Backed by her Toronto-based five-piece band, Miss Siberry airily sings and talks through lyrics that start in daily life - working as a waitress, fending off a pass - and, sooner or later, follow a tangent into the ether.

title: Zaccaro to End Role As Estate Conservator
description: John A. Zaccaro intends to end his role as a court-appointed conservator by mid-October, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Hospital Company Revises Forecast
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said it had reduced its earnings estimate for 1984. It currently believes earnings will increase by 5 percent to 10 percent, down from the midteens as it announced earlier, as a result of moderating sales growth.

title: Women's Day Plans 17 Issues a Year
description: At the Doral Hotel in Miami Beach yesterday, where they were enjoying hurricane season rates, the advertising sales force of Women's Day magazine got the battle plan from Thomas M. Kenney, their publisher of a year.

title: The Joy of Volunteering
description: Lillie Hellerman taught in the city's

title: Draft Accord Reached On Future of Hong Kong
description: After two years of negotiations on the future of Hong Kong, Britain and China have completed a draft agreement on how Peking will regain sovereignty over the British colony in 1997, the British Embassy announced today.

title: INDOOR POLLUTION AND STRESS CITED AS WORKPLACE HAZARDS
description: Indoor air pollution and psychological stress from poorly designed jobs are among health hazards confronting millions of American office workers, according to a report released today.

title: Transactions
description: Acquired Kevin McKenna, forward, from Indiana Pacers in exchange for future considerations. FOOTBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Re-signed Bryan Clark, quarterback. HOCKEY BUFFALO (NHL) - Named Joe Crozier assistant coach.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS GROUPS AND COORS REACH $325 MILLION BUSINESS ACCORD
description: The Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., reached agreement yesterday with major national civil-rights organizations on expanding opportunities for black employees and increasing the brewery's transactions with black businesses.

title: Debt Accord In Yugoslavia
description: The United States Export-Import Bank has agreed to reschedule Yugoslav debt falling due this year, bank officials said today.

title: NEW ISSUES: MARKET SLUMPS
description: After a record year, the market for public stock offerings by private companies has gone into a slump, forcing many of these companies to bypass the new-issue market and seek capital - often through creative deals - elsewhere.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ; Three Dead in India In Scattered Clashes
description: Three people died in two separate incidents today as violence between Hindu and Moslem factions broke out again in Andhra Pradesh state and the police cracked down on guerrillas in Punjab state.

title: AUBURN'S DYE TAPS FLUTIE FOR HEISMAN
description: Coach Pat Dye of Auburn cannot be included in the public-relations chauvinism that habitually marks the annual Heisman Trophy race.

title: FAIRBANKS VIOLINIST PLAYS AT MERKIN HALL ; Fairbanks Violinist Plays at Merkin Hall
description: Kathleen Butler, a young violinist who is an artist-in-residence at the University of Fairbanks in Alaska, but who has performed frequently in New York, gave a solid, standard recital program Monday evening at the Merkin Concert Hall. Her strengths and weaknesses are easy to describe, and they were consistent throughout the program.

title: Abscam Conviction Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to overturn the 1980 conviction of former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. of South Carolina for bribery and conspiracy. Mr. Jenrette was one of seven members of Congress convicted as a result of a Federal undercover investigation into political corruption. He had appealed his Abscam conviction on the ground that he was trapped into committing a crime.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1984

title: Stress on Nutrition TO THE LIVING EDITOR:
description: Good news indeed that eating establishments are catering to the needs of nutrition-minded diners (''Rush Is On To Eat Right And Eat Well,'' Sept. 12). Many such clients, who seldom ate out in the past, can now value restaurants for even more than socializing and ambiance.

title: ALPINE GEOPHYSICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $101,000. c-Net loss.

title: SOONER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Report Finds No Plot In Drug-Bail Release
description: Members of the United States Marshals Service had ''no complicity'' in the release of two major drug dealers who were supposed to be held on $1 million bail each, according to a report issued yesterday by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: A SCULPTURE BY NOGUCHI DEDICATED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: More than 50 years after it was conceived, a giant sculpture by Isamu Noguchi was dedicated tonight in a ceremony at a plaza near the Benjamin Franklin Bridge in Philadelphia where the work is installed.

title: Corporate Debt
description: Household Finance Corp. is offering $50 million of 12.55 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.92, to yield 12.60 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The interest rate on the notes will be adjusted every two years at 45 basis points above the yield on two-year Treasury notes.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HEAD OF O.E.C.D. SEES STRONG DOLLAR AS HELPFUL
description: The dollar's remarkable strength is proving largely beneficial to the economies of Western Europe, buoying their exports to the United States without reviving inflation, Emile van Lennep, Secretary General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said today.

title: LEVI FALLS
description: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday reported a 4.9 percent gain in its fourth-quarter net income, a relatively small rise compared with its usual double-digit increases, while Levi Strauss & Company said its net income fell 65.3 percent in its third quarter.

title: NO COPY FOR 'MINUTE MAN'
description: Officials in the town where Colonial farmers fired the ''shot heard round the world'' have told the Pentagon it cannot borrow the mold of the famous statue ''The Minute Man'' in order to copy it.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES PRESIDENT OUT
description: In a surprise move, the board of directors of the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had accepted the resignation of Robert J. Carlson, its president. Mr. Carlson was widely believed to be the heir apparent to Harry J. Gray, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Hartford-based company.

title: U.S. IS BOLSTERING SALVADOR COPTERS
description: The United States is planning to double the number of combat helicopters available to the Salvadoran Army by the end of this year, according to a senior United States official. He said 10 of the helicopters had already arrived here.

title: STAR FLASHING 20 TIMES A SECOND IS PHOTGRAPHED BY ASTRONOMERS
description: A star flashing 20 times a second has been photographed in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a small, relatively nearby galaxy of stars lying beyond the Milky Way in the southern sky. The star appears to be embedded in an expanding nebula of hot gas very similar to the one forming the Crab Nebula.

title: Advertising; Beatrice's Identity Program
description: THE Beatrice Companies is well

title: Dow Loses 10.82, Closing at 1,226.26
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in accelerated trading, with some technology and large-capitalization issues registering the biggest declines.

title: Market Place; Technology Stock Slump
description: TECHNOLOGY stocks took a beating yesterday, for two unrelated reasons, and helped to

title: RAIL RATE DEREGULATION ON COAL IS REVERSED
description: A three- judge Federal appeals court today struck down an Interstate Commerce Commission order that allowed railroads hauling coal for export to set rates free of Government regulation.

title: 'HIGHWAY TO HEAVEN' WITH LANDON
description: MICHAEL LANDON is getting somewhat thick around the middle and his outsize helmet of hair is beginning to look a bit odd on a man of his age, but he retains a firm hold on television's goodness market. Mr. Landon became a star 25 years ago on NBC's ''Bonanza.'' When that series ran its course in 1973, he went on to even greater fame and fortune as the perfect father in NBC's ''Little House on the Prairie.'' Now, wasting no time, he can be found in the same network's ''Highway to Heaven,'' which gets under way tonight at 8 with a special two-hour premiere. This time, Mr. Landon is being elevated to the status of angel. No kidding.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition recorded as a pooling-of-interest.

title: TO END THE DEBT CRISIS
description: The leaders of the world financial community will gather here next week for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. They have good reason to congratulate themselves for skillfully managing the third world debt crisis by redesigning the global credit system. But more still needs to be done before the crisis is truly behind us.

title: Utah Wilderness Bill Passes
description: Legislation to designate 750,000 acres of Federal land in Utah for preservation was passed by voice vote in the House Monday and sent to the White House.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Orange Juice PricesThe limited quarantine imposed by the United States Department of Agriculture on Florida citrus should have no immediate effect on the price or availability of frozen and reconstituted orange juice in local markets, according to U.S.D.A. officials, although the long-term effects may cause a rise in prices.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pino Turolla, Andes Explorer, Dies at 62 of a Heart Attack
description: Pino Turolla, an explorer, died of a heart attack Friday. He was 62 years old.

title: Ross Concerts Set Record
description: Diana Ross has become the top grossing concert act in the history of Radio City Music Hall. Miss Ross's sold-out 11-show engagement, which began Wednesday, Sept. 12, and ends Tuesday, Sept. 25, has grossed $1,772,505. This breaks the record set last April by Liberace who grossed $1,655,331 for 14 sold-out performances.

title: JOINING OF TWO CULTURES IS URGED BY DALAI LAMA
description: The Dalai Lama, on his first full day of a United States tour, said yesterday that he hoped his visit would encourage greater study of the human mind and spur efforts to bring the teachings of Eastern philosophy together with the findings of Western science.

title: Massey Unit's New President Massey-Ferguson Ltd. of Toronto said yesterday that Ivan
description: Porter had been named president of its combine and farm

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-After a net charge of $89,000 for the quarter and 6 months reflecting an accounting loss of principal on a marketable security.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY: It was a recent warm evening and I was struggling into a nice-looking dress in a clothing store in the theater district. The dressing room, located on one of the shop's outside walls, is minuscule; I am not. I was in an abbreviated state of dress, when all at once, and competely out of the blue, I was startled to hear myself being serenaded by a lusty baritone voice, which got increasingly louder. This is what he sang:

title: MEN CAN COOK IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Two Jackson women are putting together a cookbook that will take its title from the comment that the state's Agriculture Commissioner made last month to Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro: ''Down here in Mississippi, the men don't cook.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHEN people buy a cosmetic, they may have doubts about how well the product will suit their needs, but they don't expect that it will make them sick. In the vast majority of circumstances, it doesn't. Considering how many thousands of cosmetics are used daily by millions of Americans, reports of ill effects are relatively few.

title: 3 CHILEAN BISHOPS SNUB THE MILITARY
description: Three Roman Catholic bishops, upset over Government repression, canceled traditional church-state Independence Day services in their cities today in an unprecedented snub of the Chilean military Government.

title: People
description: * E. Christensen Woodbury named senior vice president at Klemtner Advertising.

title: Books: Historic Byline
description: IDA TARBELL: Portrait of a Muckraker. By Kathleen Brady. 286 pages. Seaview/Putnam. $17.95.

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COLLEGE STUDENTS HECKLE MONDALE
description: In the most tumultuous rally of his Presidential campaign, Walter F. Mondale denounced President Reagan's arms control policies today before hundreds of booing and jeering students at the University of Southern California.

title: DEFECTIVE CASE AGAINST THE GENOCIDE TREATY
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN OUTLINES AID FOR FARMERS
description: President Reagan today announced a program of Federal loan guarantees, temporary interest subsidies and other steps to ease pressure on debt-ridden farmers.

title: PIRATES' SLUGGING CHECKS CUBS, 6-2
description: Lee Lacy and Johnny Ray cracked consecutive home runs in the fourth inning and Ray later knocked in three runs to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 6-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: REV. WILLIAM BONNIWELL
description: The Rev. William R. Bonniwell, a Dominican priest who was a former director of the Preachers Institute in Washington, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: U.S. JUDGE SAYS LIBYA MUST PAY TAX ON MANSION
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the privilege of diplomatic immunity did not free Libya from paying taxes on a $1 million Bergen County mansion purchased for its delegate to the United Nations.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
POLLS SHOW MANY CHOOSE REAGAN EVEN IF THEY DISAGREE WITH HIM
description: A poll found that religion was not the key to voter decisions, but some candidates expressed concern about lost votes. Page B9.

title: PURSUING CHEATERS AND BOGUS SHELTERS
description: Prosecutions are soaring, more convicted tax evaders are going to jail for longer terms and there are strong new legislative and computer weapons at hand to combat cheaters.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMF Inc. , Princeton, N.J., an industrial technology and leisure products company, appointed John R. Supple president of Head Racquet Sports, Worldwide.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nicaragua Official in Soviet
description: The Nicaraguan Planning Minister, Henry Ruiz Hernandez, met here today with Ivan V. Arkhipov, a First Deputy Prime Minister, for talks on trade and economic relations, the press agency Tass reported.

title: Real Estate; L.I. Office Complex Going Up
description: FROM 1945 until 1951, when it

title: CLEMENCY PLEA WEIGHED IN CAROLINA
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. heard appeals today for clemency for a 51-year-old woman who was convicted in 1978 and sentenced to die for fatally poisoning a friend with arsenic.

title: ; Fran Warren Sings Favorites at Freddy's
description: Fran Warren, like many veteran entertainers, is an interesting vocal personality who needs a musical concept through which to tell her story and show to advantage her blowzy charm. The singer's current act, which plays through Saturday at Freddy's Supper Club, isn't the right vehicle.

title: THE SCREEN: 'AMADEUS,' DIRECTED BY FORMAN
description: FROM the initial production of Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus'' at the National Theater in London in 1979, through all of the refinements that preceded the play's New York premiere in 1980, and now, in the even more extensive rewriting and adjustments made by Mr. Shaffer for Milos Forman's handsome, music-filled screen version, one thing has remained constant and exhilarating.

title: SOLAR SYSTEMS BY SUN DANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

This Guardian System Attracts Flies By breaking the rules for court-appointed guardians of estates, John Zaccaro may have served the cause of justice in New York. His borrowing from the estate of an elderly Queens woman whose assets he was assigned to guard prompted the judge who appointed him to rescind the appointment. Yet because his wife is a candidate for Vice President, his case has attracted the spotlight - perhaps enough light even to spur reform of a rotten judicial practice.
description: Guardians are appointed by judges to handle the financial affairs of children, incapacitated adults and the deceased. Typically, such an appointment means a certain guaranteed income. A guardian gets a percentage of all transactions, as a fee. A recent New York Times survey uncovered dozens of appointments of judges' friends, political associates and relatives to these guardianships.

title: DISCOVERIES ; TROVE OF VINTAGE HATS FROM THREE DECADES
description: 1.*Feathers and Veils

title: POPE SKIPS ONE TOWN, DROPS IN ON ANOTHER
description: Pope John Paul II made an unexpected visit to this sub- Arctic town in northern Canada today when fog forced the cancellation of a trip to Fort Simpson, where he had planned to give an address on the rights of Indians.

title: BOARD, TO LESSEN CROWDING, URGES BUSING MORE STUDENTS
description: Board of Education officials said yesterday that they could alleviate overcrowding in city schools by busing children out of their communities.

title: NATIONAL DOCK STRIKE ENDS IN BRITAIN
description: Britain's three- week-old national dock strike, which sprang from sympathy with the much longer miners' walkout, was called off today.

title: Of Buses and Signs
description: A long bus, sleekly done up as a private coach, was parked on Central Park West near 61st Street. Where the destination usually shows, the electronic sign alternately displayed ''Lost'' and ''Student Driver.''

title: Lloyd Record Cut
description: A revision of the records kept by the Womens' Tennis Association has put Martina Navratilova in a position tonight to break Chris Evert Lloyd 's mark for consecutive victories rather than tie it. Facing 16-year-old Melissa Brown of Scarsdale in the first round of the Lynda Carter-Maybelline Tennis Classic in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Miss Navratilova will be seeking her 56th straight victory in her first match since the United States Open.

title: STUDY REPORTS EXODUS OF AFFLUENT AND EDUCATED NEW YORKERS IN LATE 70'S
description: New York State lost hundreds of thousands of its best-educated and most affluent people to other states during the late 1970's, according to a study released yesterday.

title: BOC-Nowsco
description: BOC Group P.L.C. said it was selling its 49 percent interest in the BOC-Nowsco Group to Nowsco Well Service Ltd. of Canada for $32.5 million (Canadian). Nowsco Well Service owns 51 percent of the BOC-Nowsco, which operates in 12 countries. The sale is expected to be closed on Sept. 26.

title: Spain-Guatemala Ties Set
description: Spain and Guatemala will renew diplomatic relations at a ceremony here on Saturday after a four- year break, the Colombian Government, a mediator, said today.

title: Sperry Network
description: The Sperry Corporation said it is introducing Sperry Usernet System, a baseband personal computer network.

title: DOLLAR HITS HIGH, THEN RETREATS
description: In a day of heavy trading, the dollar surged to record highs yesterday before retreating on a wave of profit taking.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO STRENGTHEN LAW TO PROTECT DRINKING WATER SUPPLY
description: Ignoring the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives, voted overwhelmingly today to reauthorize and strengthen the Safe Drinking Water Act. The vote was 366 to 27.

title: A NEW CHIEF FOR A TROUBLED AGENCY
description: Much of what George Gross knows about the problems he will inherit in New York City's Human Resources Administration he has learned in the halls of the United States Capitol. Those legislative lessons are about to be put to a grueling administrative test. The 50-year-old Hungarian native and resident of Potomac, Md., knows there is a ''great challenge'' in taking over the 24,000- employee agency after supervising a five-member lobbying staff for the National League of Cities.

title: Mississippi Unit's $200 Million Issue
description: A $200 million financing by the Mississippi Housing Finance Corporation was tentatively offered with a maximum yield of 10.50 percent for interest-bearing bonds due in 2007, and 11.50 percent for non-interest-bearing bonds due in 2016. Underwriters for the bonds, rated AA by Standard & Poor's, were led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: More Tests for Ali Muhammad Ali returned to New York last night and later checked
description: into Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for further neurological tests. The former heavyweight boxing champion was interviewed by

title: MACY, R.H. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
FOR CLEANING UP
description: -DESIGNED piece of kitchen equipment is much like a well-designed menu: each component should have a function based on logic, not mere ornamentation, and every part should be of the highest quality. This does not apply merely to intricate kitchen machines or expensive copper pots and pans but also to the simplest kitchen tool, such as a vegetable peeler or can opener.

title: Bob Regehr, Vice PresidentAt Warner Brothers Records
description: Bob Regehr, senior vice president of artist development and publicity at Warner Brothers Records, died of cancer Sunday at his home in New York. He was 52 years old.

title: Connections
description: Sharon Percy Rockefeller, whose

title: South Africa Bans Book By American Journalist
description: A book by an American journalist that offers opinions of South African women on apartheid was banned on Aug. 31 by the Directorate of Publications in Cape Town.

title: NOEL B. MCLEAN, 77, A LEADER IN SEA AND SPACE ELECTRONICS
description: Noel B. McLean, a leader in marine and aerospace electronics and former chairman of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, died of complications from a stroke Monday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in New Hope, Pa.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1984 International An American balloonist ended the first solo flight across the Atlantic when he crash-landed his 10-story-tall balloon in storms near Savona, Italy, breaking an ankle but making history. The journey of the American, Joe W. Kittinger, began Friday in Caribou, Me., and ended 3,535 miles and nearly 84 hours later in the Italian Riviera. (Page A1, Columns 2-4.) A Soviet journalist who disappeared while in Italy in 1983 and then spent a year in Britain turned up in Moscow and said he had been abducted by British agents and forced to make anti-Soviet statements while abroad. The journalist, Oleg G. Bitov, spoke at a news conference called by the Soviet authorities. (A1:1.) National

title: CHAD ACCORD: FRENCH CALL IT A DIPLOMATIC SUCCESS
description: The French- Libyan agreement to withdraw forces from Chad marked a success for France in its goal of limiting the spread of Libyan influence, diplomats and French officials said today.

title: Montana Sues Adidas Like many other professional athletes,
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback, picked up some extra money a while back by agreeing to wear a certain athletic shoe and to make promotional appearances for the manufacturer. Montana, who says he got $25,000 for his deal, maintains there was nothing in the contract allowing the manufacturer - in his case, Adidas - to use his name on its products.

title: ; Ensemble Cellist Makes His Solo Debut
description: The cellist Clay Ruede studied with Bernard Greenhouse at the Manhattan School of Music and with Aldo Parisot at Yale University. He has performed with Speculum Musicae, the Da Capo Chamber Players and the New York New Music Ensemble, and he is a founding member of the Arden Trio.

title: EDUCATION INVESTMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooney Set Back by Scratch
description: A scratch on the cheek of Gerry Cooney has delayed the heavyweight boxer's departure for Anchorage to prepare for his first fight in more than two years.

title: SPACELINK LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $218,000.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Including a gain of $34,950,000 from the sale of a discontinued business. c-Including a tax credit of $594,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 27.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend paid in May 1984.

title: 2 GROUPS VYING FOR CUSTOM HOUSE
description: Two cultural groups are vying for approval from the Federal Government to rent the United States Custom House, a Beaux-Arts landmark in lower Manhattan. The competition has attracted the attentions of local, state and Federal politicians, who have endorsed one plan or the other.

title: MESHING GEARS OF GOVERNMENT WITH A CAMPAIGN
description: In its cliche version, President Reagan's re-election campaign may seem like a styrofoam sculpture of patriotic images and platitudes. In reality, it is a complex machine that meshes every day with the wheels and gears of government.

title: ITT Unit Is Sold
description: The ITT Corporation said it had sold its German household products company, Leifheit A.G., to the Deutsche Bank for about $40 million.

title: THE REGION
description: PanelUpholdsBan On Power Project

title: I.B.M. Starts Making 256K's The International Business
description: Machines Corporation said it

title: WAGS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2d Chance for Youth
description: Charles Washington, a 17-year-old high school all-America defensive back from Dallas, appeared headed for the University of Texas this summer. Then he was convicted of two counts of armed robbery of a convenience store, and his collegiate football career was canceled before it even began.

title: CONTINENTAL EXAMINERS CRITICIZED
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Fernand J. St Germain, charged today that Federal banking examiners failed to act effectively when they learned that the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company had a long list of sour loans that threatened its solvency.

title: YANKEE HOME RUNS OVERPOWER ORIOLES
description: Mike Pagliarulo, who was not around during the first half of the year when the Yankees teetered near last place, continued to brighten their second half when he hit a grand slam last night in a 10-2 rout of the Orioles.

title: MENTAL HEALTH PROPOSALS LEAD TO RESIGNATION
description: The proposals of a state commission to overhaul the system of caring for the mentally ill in New York State prompted the resignation today of a commission member who represented state mental health workers.

title: GETTING BACK TO BASICS, TO LET THE COOK OUT OF THE KITCHEN
description: HAVING company for dinner is an enterprise that all too easily gets out of hand, especially when the company constitutes one or two new- found friends coming over for the first time.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $28,300.

title: Nurses Group Backs 'Ailing' Mondale Ticket
description: The American Nurses Association announced its endorsement today of the ''ailing'' Democratic ticket of Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: COMPUTON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests.

title: CHURCH ISSUES SPREAD TO STATE RACES
description: The elevation of religion as an issue in the Presidential campaign is causing deep concern for many Democratic leaders on the Congressional and state levels, particularly in the South, where some voters are accusing the Democratic Party of abandoning support for the goals of Christian fundamentalists.

title: 4 Indonesians Arrested After Moslem Riot
description: The police have arrested four Moslem youths on charges of distributing anti-Government leaflets around the Indonesian capital after a fierce riot last Wednesday, a Government official said today.

title: DeLorean and Ferrare Begin Trial Separation
description: John Z. DeLorean, a month after he was acquitted of charges that he was a participant in a $24 million cocaine conspiracy, said today that he and his wife, Cristina Ferrare, had separated.

title: Omega 7 Jury StartsDeliberating
description: A Federal jury started deliberating yesterday in the case of a Cuban exile, Eduardo Arocena, 41 years old, accused of being the leader of Omega 7, an anti-Castro terrorist group.

title: G.A.O. AIDE WARNS MANY U.S. MISSILES WOULD BE USELESS
description: Thousands of Sidewinder and Sparrow air- to-air missiles, the mainstay of America's air combat arsenal, are useless because of defects or maintenance problems, a General Accounting Office investigator told Congress today.

title: Sony Reports Profits Triple
description: The Sony Corporation said today that its profits in the third quarter more than tripled from a year earlier, as sales of all product lines rose sharply and interest expenses decreased.

title: JUSTICE BURGER AT 77
description: WASHINGTON The Chief Justice of the United

title: STOCK SEIZED BY THE U.S. PAYS OFF, 40 YEARS LATER
description: The Government realized a profit today on stock that it seized as enemy assets in World War II and that it had regarded as worthless for more than 30 years.

title: VAN PELT IS STILL WONDERING
description: It has been more than two months since Brad Van Pelt's life turned upside down. After 11 seasons as an outside linebacker for the Giants, he had wanted to be traded to the Detroit Lions or a team in Florida or California. Instead, he was sent to the Minnesota Vikings.

title: IT'S HARVEST TIME FOR BAY SCALLOPS
description: -old tradition, an armada of baymen set off in open skiffs into Great Peconic Bay off eastern Long Island before dawn Monday, hoping to mine a rich lode of one of the region's most coveted delicacies: bay scallops. Early indications are that this year's harvest will be relatively plentiful and that the scallops, while perhaps not as large as desired, are bigger than last year's.

title: Manila Protesters Blocked
description: Hundreds of riot policemen and soldiers prevented about 2,000 students from marching on the presidential palace today. Student leaders said the protest marked the start of a series of demonstrations that will end on Sept. 21.

title: POWER OF THE INCUMBENT
description: With a pair of carefully balanced decisions today aimed at helping farmers and the steel industry, President Reagan has demonstrated the capacity of an incumbent to time policy actions for potential political advantage in key states. By ordering his trade negotiator to press for a one-fourth cutback in foreign steel imports, the President has sought to improve his prospects in steel-producing states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Indiana and New York, where the domestic steel industry and its unions have been clamoring for protection.

title: STATE DEPT. AIDE SAYS 'DOOR IS VERY MUCH OPEN' TO AN ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
description: A senior State Department official said today that ''the door is very much open'' to early progress on a package agreement between Angola and South Africa, leading to the independence of South-West Africa and the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: M.T.A. REPORT FAULTS ALL IN PURCHASE OF RAIL CARS
description: The manufacturer, the consultants hired by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the authority itself are at fault for the purchase of more than a hundred defective commuter rail cars, according to a report by the M.T.A. inspector general.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-Aide Indicted In Zoning Case
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted the former director of the Atlantic City Planning and Development Department on charges of extortion in the sale of land zoned for casinos, authorities announced here today.

title: KOREANS DISAGREE ON AID BY NORTH
description: Despite long and mostly cordial bargaining, North and South Korean officials failed to agree today on how North Korea could carry out an offer to send relief supplies to recent flood victims in the South.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. SELECTS 36 INSTITUTIONS TO SHARE AID
description: Thirty-six arts institutions in 13 states and the District of Columbia were selected today to share $2.5 million in Federal funds and technical assistance.

title: QUESTIONS OF QUALITY; Weapons Utility There's so little competition among defense contractors, concludes a report by the management consultant Arthur D. Little, that the Pentagon should concede the fact and quit even trying to secure competitive prices. What then would stop weapons makers from charging sky-high prices for their products? The consultant recommends price regulation by the Pentagon, just as public utility commissions regulate those of telephone and gas companies.
description: That's an interesting thought, but it puts the cart before the horse. The problem isn't so much the exorbitant costs of weapons as their patchy quality.

title: Carson and Gray Are Questionable
description: Harry Carson and Earnest Gray, injured in the Giants' loss at Washington, were listed as ''questionable'' yesterday for the home game Sunday against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, meaning that their chances of playing were considered only 50-50. Carson, the star inside linebacker and defensive captain, has a sprained right ankle, and Gray, the team's chief wide receiver, has a bruised left elbow. Neither is expected to practice today or tomorrow.

title: Gates Learjet
description: The Gates Learjet Corporation of Tucson, Ariz., said it would suspend production of its commercial 30 and 50 series aircraft to reduce inventories.

title: Judge Sets Rerun Of Primary Vote
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn has ordered a rerun of the Democratic primary election in the 51st Assembly District in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn after a count of absentee ballots left the two leading candidates only two votes apart. The rerun is scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Cram Is Victor In 800 at Peking
description: Steve Cram of Britain scored an easy victory today in an 800-meter race today in the windup of the Nanjing International track and field meet.

title: Jim Walsh at Pusan
description: Last Saturday morning Jim Walsh, the football coach of George Washington High School in Manhattan, called his 26 players into a room 90 minutes before they were scheduled to play Lehman High in the Bronx.

title: VOTER FOUND UNEASY OVER RELIGION AS ISSUE
description: Most Americans seem uncomfortable about the way politics and religion have become intertwined in this year's election campaign, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But religious issues do not appear to be an important factor in how they plan to vote in November.

title: LIBERALS CHOOSE HARRINGTON IN 19-HOUR ALBANY MEETING
description: At the longest and one of the most tumultuous meetings in its history, New York's Liberal Party today elected the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington and James F. Notaro as its leaders for the next two years.

title: PIERA MAIOGLIO
description: Piera Maioglio, co-owner of the Barbetta Restaurant, died of leukemia Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: 'BONA' GIVES A GLIMPSE OF LIFE IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: BONA loves Gardo. Gardo loves Gardo. Gardo loves going to bed with almost any woman he can attract. Once - apparently in the absence of anyone better - he even takes Bona to bed, but by the next morning, the matter seems to have slipped his mind.

title: QUESTIONS OF QUALITY; TV NEEDS A FRIEND
description: Only a man who loved television would say of its performers that they ''visit us as if they were a friend or neighbor coming by for the evening.'' Yet President Reagan, the author of this warm sentiment, isn't showing himself to be much of a friend to

title: MARINER IS STRIKEOUT ARTIST
description: Even Mark Langston - no, especially Mark Langston - is impressed with what Dwight Gooden has done this season.

title: Whitfield Leads
description: Rick Whitfield, in his first season as pro at the Country Club of Fairfield, shot a two-under-par 69 today for the first- round lead in the 54-hole, $40,000 Izod Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Black Course of Bethpage State Park.

title: WOMAN CLEARED OF SEX OFFENSE AT CARE CENTER
description: A 62-year-old woman has been cleared of charges that she sexually abused children at the Praca day-care center in the Bronx, Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, said last night.

title: Long Life, More Taxes TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: Your article ''The Costs of Living Longer'' (Sept. 5) omits the corollary that living longer disease-free would mean working longer and contributing longer to the tax rolls, not only income taxes but Social Security, sales, real-estate and gasoline taxes.

title: RESURGENT WATERBURY PREPARES TO GREET CANDIDATE REAGAN
description: It was a magic moment for this city, and just about everyone here over the age of 24 claims to have been a part of it.

title: Gimbels Officer To Retire The Batus Retail Group,
description: which owns Gimbels, said yesterday that Stanley Abelson, 61

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 10
NEW ALBUM BY NEVILLES AT TIPITINA'S
description: TIPITINA'S, the New Orleans club that is known worldwide as home base for many of the city's most celebrated musicians, is not very prepossessing from the outside. Situated on a tree-shaded corner in a neighborhood of one- family cottages and small apartment buildings, Tipitina's looks much like an ordinary neighborhood bar. There is nothing outside to suggest that the place was a kind of vernacular concert hall for Professor Longhair. And Tipitina's remains the New Orleans venue where locals and visitors can hear and see performers like the Neville Brothers, the Meters, Huey (Piano) Smith, Allen Toussaint and the city's other reigning masters of blues, soul music and funk.

title: Telefunken Rebounds
description: West Germany's largest corporate bankruptcy drew to a close today when AEG-Telefunken A.G. made final payments equivalent to about $115.2 million to its creditors.

title: G.E., Ungermann To Make Networks
description: The General Electric Company and Ungermann-Bass Inc. said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to produce a network system to link factory-automation equipment.

title: CANADA BEATS SWEDEN FOR CUP
description: Mark Messier and Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers sparked a five-goal first period tonight and Canada withstood a stunning comeback by Sweden to win, 6-5, and capture the Canada Cup event.

title: The Soaring Dollar Everyone the world over seems to agree that the dollar is overvalued. Everyone, that is, except the governments, banks and corporations that keep investing billions in American securities and push its exchange value ever higher. A dollar today buys nine French francs, or three German marks - roughly 10 percent more than last year and nearly 100 percent more than five years ago.
description: Does this matter? To many Americans a strong dollar is cause for pride. It also lowers the cost of foreign imports, thus working against inflation and supporting the economic policies of the Reagan Administration. But a strong dollar raises the price of American goods abroad and costs Americans jobs. The currency imbalance invites restrictions on trade and sucks scarce capital into America, the nation that least needs it.

title: 'VOLUNTARY' IMPORT RESTRAINT
description: President Reagan's decision Tuesday to ask other countries to limit their steel shipments to the United States was presented by the White House as upholding the principles of free trade. But the recent history of ''voluntary'' export restraint suggests it is potentially the most protectionist action this Administration has yet taken.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A popular method for paving a walk or patio is to lay bricks on a bed of sand with no cement or mortar. Either new or old bricks can be used, but they should be reasonably clean and smooth to insure a relatively level surface. If you are using old bricks, it won't hurt if they have mortar on the bottom, but it will be more difficult to level them.

title: Republican Tax-Rebate Ruse Has Unusual Result in Ohio
description: Intending to mock Democratic tax-rebate policies, Republican fund-raisers mailed out 400,000 reproductions of rebate checks, clearly labeled as ''non- negotiable.''

title: Of Ellis Island And Kosher Hot Dogs
description: The six television sets looked

title: Debt Issues
description: Buttes Gas and Oil Co. has filed a $20 million offering of senior subordinated exchangeable variable rate notes through Prudential-Bache.

title: TWO IN ABUSE CASE FOUND NOT GUILTY
description: The first of 25 people arrested in an investigation into purported sexual abuse in a small Minnesota town near here were acquitted tonight. The defendants, Robert L. Bentz and Lois J. Bentz, had been charged with molesting their 6-year- old son and four other children.

title: ;  Pastorini Sues Raiders
description: Dan Pastorini , the former quarterback, and the National Football League Players Association have filed a $1 million lawsuit against the Los Angeles Raiders seeking payment of an arbitration award he won last May. The suit, filed in Superior Court in San Francisco on Tuesday, maintained that when the Raiders signed Pastorini in March 1980 after a trade with the Houston Oilers, the Raiders assumed contracts that covered through the 1983 season.

title: Disability Benefit Bill Goes to the President
description: The Senate and House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation that would make it more difficult to terminate Social Security disability benefits.

title: FIGHTING CONTINUES IN SOWETO
description: South African police said today that seven black gold miners were killed Tuesday when police officers moved against rioting workers at a mine outside Johannesburg.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION - Approved the relocation of the Evansville, Ind., franchise to Nashville, Tenn. BASKETBALL

title: No Headline
