title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
ELECTRIC SHOW POLISHERS TO AVOID MESSY JOBS
description: Several manufacturers have recently introduced hand-held electric shoe polishers. Convenient for their small size, they will give a quick buff or a full polish without getting hands dirty.

title: An Election Winner Pays Winning Voters
description: A candidate for county supervisor who offered $2,000 to raffle winners to encourage people to vote has narrowly won a special election.

title: AUTO TALKS AT STANDSTILL, WITH 91,000 NOW ON STRIKE
description: Negotiations between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers Union appeared to be at a standstill today as strikes and layoffs left almost one-third of the company's workforce idle.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by Perri Klass, a third-year student at the Harvard Medical School and the author of a novel, ''Recombinations,'' to be published next year by G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: PADRES BEAT GIANTS IN 10TH INNING, 5-4
description: Bob Brenly, the catcher, dropped a throw from the second baseman, Manny Trillo, with the bases loaded, allowing Eddie Miller to score the winning from third base in the bottom of the 10th inning tonight as the San Diego Padres defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-4.

title: CASTING THE COVETED 'AMADEUS' ROLES
description: Two of the most coveted film roles of the decade - the parts of Mozart and Salieri in the screen version of Peter Shaffer's play ''Amadeus'' - have gone to two actors who are barely familiar to most moviegoers.

title: THE ABORTION DEBATE: WHAT 'LEGISLATED MORALITY' CANNOT DO
description: To the Editor: As a Catholic, I am appalled by the shameless partisanship being dis

title: CHEATING PROMPTS AIR FORCE TO HALT CADET HONOR BOARDS
description: The worst cheating scandal in nearly 20 years at the Air Force Academy has prompted the Air Force to suspend the cadet-run system of discipline for honor code violations pending a thorough review of the academy's strict honor system.

title: POPE DENOUNCES ARMS RACE AND RELIGIOUS PERSECUTION
description: Pope John Paul II tonight denounced ''the absence of agreements to reduce and eventually halt the arms race'' and criticized what he called the ''reprehensible'' denial of religious liberty in many nations.

title: SILKY SULLIVAN'S RETURN
description: MINNEAPOLIS Whenever I go to a race track, I bellow at the horse bringing up the rear, ''Come on, Silky!''

title: TOWN IS WORRIED AS U.S. SHIFTS ATOM WASTE OF 40'S
description: From his cornfield, James Lombardi can see just the tip of the silo.

title: Chris-Craft Talks With United TV
description: Chris-Craft Industries Inc. said it was discussing with United Television Inc. a ''corporate combination'' involving their six television stations.

title: A Museum for McDonald's
description: Billions of hamburgers later, the original McDonald's restaurant will become a museum in tribute to the company's history, officials of the McDonald's Corporation say.

title: Reynolds Metals To Close Unit
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would close permanently the chemical products facility at its Hurricane Creek plant in Arkansas.

title: BEYOND SCARS, BROWNSVILLE SHOWS SIGNS OF NEW HOPE
description: The people of Brownsville, like those in other poor neighborhoods, believe that their community lies somewhere beyond America's line of vision. It comes into view only occasionally, when cries over some perceived wrong mount into screams, when riot-sparked fires illuminate rage or when a criminal act makes news.

title: Congress Gives Citizenship To a Russian Who Defected
description: Congress completed action today on a bill granting citizenship to a Soviet employee at the United Nations who defected last year.

title: Vern Haugland Dies; A.P. Aviation Writer
description: Vern Haugland, the chief aviation correspondent for the Associated Press for 21 years, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Sundowner Hotel in Reno. He was 76 years old and lived in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Bid for Keystone By Giant Portland
description: The Giant Portland and Masonry Cement Company said it had agreed to acquire 600,000 common shares, or 51 percent, of the Keystone Portland Cement Company for 600,000 shares of Giant $25 preferred stock.

title: Arsonists Attack Offices Of Ruling Party in Japan
description: Terrorists using truck-mounted flame throwers set fire to the headquarters of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in the center of Tokyo tonight, causing heavy damage to the nine-story building.

title: ATLANTIC NICARGUA: REGGAE YES, REVOLUTION MAYBE
description: Here on the damp and isolated Atlantic coast of Nicaragua, people speak lilting English, wear jewelry made of black coral, catch giant turtles by the boatload and try to adjust to the jarring realities of revolutionary government and civil war.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; ;  Sears Names Officers For Its Trading Unit
description: Sears, Roebuck and Company yesterday announced that Frank C. Carlucci had been nominated to be chairman and chief executive officer of Sears World Trade Inc. Mr. Carlucci, who is currently the subsidiary's president, would replace Richard M. Jones, Sears's vice chairman and chief financial officer who temporarily assumed the company's top position last April when Roderick M. Hills resigned.

title: REQUIRED RELIGIOSITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO FEUD RECESSES FOR FERRARO RALLY
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro accomplished today what no one else had been able to, not even Walter F. Mondale. She made Chicago's top Democrats stop fighting long enough to give the party's Presidential ticket a rousing boost with an old-fashioned, brass-band rally.

title: Trade Tempered by Politics President Reagan's plan to reduce steel imports by forcing other nations to accept negotiated restraints is a masterly solution to his political problem. The reduction sought, from 25 to 20 percent of the American market, should be enough to silence union and industry criticism of the Administration, undercutting Walter Mondale's appeal in the Rust Belt. Yet the choice of flexible, ''voluntary'' curbs on countries accused of unfair competition is likely to diffuse the criticism of U.S. consumers of steel who oppose formal import quotas.
description: No matter how skillfully packaged, however, these import restraints will aggravate the nation's economic problem. They will cost consumers billions and reduce the competitiveness of American manufacturers dependent on steel. And they will do little to halt the decline of America's big, integrated steel makers.

title: FLORIDA BEGINS ALL-OUT BATTLE TO SAVE CITRUS
description: The Florida Agriculture Commissioner approved an emergency measure today empowering state agents to decide on the spot whether to burn citrus trees and destroy crops that they suspect of carrying a virulent disease.

title: No Headline
description: Planned Airline Booking Seats MIAMI, Sept. 19 (AP) -

title: THE REGION ; BRIDGE WORK RESET TO AVERT TIE-UPS
description: The state will suspend repairs on the Interstate 91 bridge crossing the Connecticut River at Windsor Locks next weekend in an effort to avoid a repetition of traffic jams caused by the work last weekend, officials said today.

title: UNANSWERED QUESTIONS ABOUT AGENT ORANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: OKLAHOMA PREPARES TO MAKE A BAR DRINK LEGAL
description: After a quarter century of illegal drinking, what cynics called ''liquor by the wink,'' Oklahoma today prepared to accept what it has been doing all along and set in motion machinery to allow legal sale of liquor by the drink.

title: 'FIGHTING FRITZ': MONDALE SPURRED ON BY ADVERSITY
description: It is one of the paradoxes of Walter F. Mondale's long march to the Presidential election that when the polls show the potential for a brutal defeat, when commentators and reporters brush aside his candidacy, when Democratic leaders groan privately about his faltering campaign, the former Vice President loosens his shirt collar, rolls up his sleeves, drops his stump speech and caution and goes on the attack.

title: Cocaine Is Found In a Speeding Car
description: A state trooper who stopped a car for speeding today found 45 pounds of cocaine with a wholesale value of $1.35 million in a false compartment in the trunk, the police said.

title: Block That Wall!
description: Metaphor of the Month (Congressional Division) by Representative Ron Paul of Texas, speaking of a measure to require Americans to make financial declarations before traveling abroad: ''If this bill passes the Senate, Congress will be building an invisible Berlin Wall around America.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, announced that Jeffrey R. Lapides had been named a senior vice president.

title: Wilder and Radner Wed In Private Rite in France
description: -DE-VENCE, France, Sept. 19 (UPI) - Gene Wilder on Tuesday married Gilda Radner, who plays his lovesick secretary in their latest movie, ''The Woman in Red,'' in a private ceremony attended by eight friends here.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Croquet
description: United States National Championships, at the Central Park Croquet Lawn, West Drive and 69th Street, just north of the Sheep Meadow, 8:30 A.M. This annual double-elimination tournament continues through Sunday, with competition in singles and doubles. Harness Racing Little Brown Jug, at Delaware, Ohio.

description: Leaking tanks that store fuel and chemicals underground are increasingly being viewed as a

title: Buttle Reshapes Tough Image
description: His name sounds tough, and he has a way of talking tough. The problem last year was that Greg Buttle of the Jets, injured and overweight, didn't play tough.

title: Daon Sells Land
description: The Daon Development Corporation said it had sold 2,050 acres of citrus and avocado farmland in Riverside County, Calif., to Foothills Properties for $25 million. Daon said most of the land, acquired in 1981, is within the city limits of Corona. Under the sale agreement, Daon said it would begin proceedings to obtain subdivision approvals and would be compensated for the work.

title: NORTH KOREA GIVES IN ON AID
description: A North Korean official said today that his country had agreed to South Korea's conditions for delivering relief goods intended for South Korean flood victims, according to a report monitored here.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1984 International The sovereignty of Hong Kong would be transferred from Britain to China in 1997 under a draft agreement reached by London and Peking after two years of sometimes contentious negotiations. The accord may be initialed soon. (Page A1, Column 1.) A budget-cutting plan by Israel must be presented before Washington will consider a big increase in economic aid for the new Israeli Government, according to State Department officials. (A12:4-6.)

title: ADVERTISING ; Seminar on Protecting Promotional Efforts
description: With the kind of money pouring into sales promotion capers like sweepstakes, cents-off coupons and celebrity endorsements, no wonder there is concern in marketing circles about protecting such investments.

title: JERSEY CHURCH IS SALVADORAN HAVEN
description: When the young Salvadoran couple fled their homeland a few months ago, they left behind all their possessions, even their names. At St. Michael's Episcopal Chapel on the Bush campus of Rutgers University here, they have found a sanctuary and, they say, much more.

title: MONDALE'S CAMPAIGN PICKS UP STEAM ON HOT CALIFORNIA NIGHT
description: The banner on the wall of the Farmers' Market said ''Fightin' Fritz,'' and the temperature was pushing well past 100 degrees when Walter F. Mondale addressed a crowd of sweat-drenched, stirred-up supporters here Tuesday afternoon.

title: MARROW TRANSPLANT FOUND TO BE A CURE IN SICKLE CELL CASE
description: For the first time doctors have cured a case of sickle cell anemia with a bone marrow transplant, but they caution that this life-saving therapy will be suitable for only a small minority of victims of the disease.

title: $145 Million Bond Sale by Jersey
description: A $145 million issue of New Jersey general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8.5 percent in 1994 and 9.30 percent in 2004 through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan.

title: INMATE IS BACKED ON RIGHT TO TRIAL TO DETERMINE RELIGIOUS SINCERITY
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a prisoner was entitled to a full trial to determine whether he sincerely believed in an unorthodox religious faith that he wanted to practice in prison.

title: Soviet Loan From West
description: The Soviet Union today obtained a loan of $166 million from a consortium of nine Western banks, its third loan this year from the West.

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES 0.5% WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) - Americans' personal income rose five- tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain in three months, as spending rose at an even slower pace, the Government reported today.
description: The Commerce Department said that personal consumption spending rose one-tenth of 1 percent percent in August, matching July's tiny gain.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; ;  Certificate Offer For Power Plants
description: The Modesto Irrigation District in California is offering $150 million of adjustable-rate certificates of participation through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; New Magazine Due On Athletic Fitness
description: Fitness nuts will have another magazine title appealing to them next month - Sports Fitness - and it will be the fourth publication of such bent from Joe Weider of Woodland Hills, Calif.

title: U.S. 'PIRATES' PROSPER ON THE BRITISH AIRWAYS
description: ABOARD THE TRAWLER COMMUNICATOR, in the North Sea - Seventeen miles off the British coast, four American disk jockeys relax on ''Splinter Beach,'' as the upper deck of this rusty trawler is known to their fans.

title: New Democratic TV Ads Focus on Foreign Policy
description: Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro are echoing their recent attacks on President Reagan's arms control policies in two new television commercials.

title: KINETICS AND THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: On the wall of Roger L. Stevens's office at the Kennedy Center for the Peforming Arts is a framed, one-sentence letter that succinctly spells out the role Mr. Stevens has played in the capital for almost a quarter century.

title: 2 Sentenced In Stock Case
description: A taxi driver and his girlfriend have been sentenced after pleading guilty to charges that they made stock market profits by using information provided by a former proofreader at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: Houston Zoo Admits A Snake Was a Fake
description: The telephone caller said he had been worried because he had not seen the Houston Zoo's coral snake move in nine months.

description: New Sounds

title: IMMIGRATION BILL IS AT AN IMPASSE
description: House and Senate conferees who are drafting a comprehensive immigration bill broke up this evening in disagreement over how to prevent job discrimination against legal aliens and United States citizens of Hispanic origin.

title: ENOUGH WAS ENOUGH
description: BOSTON The rule of law still holds its high

title: Alcan to Close Extrusion Unit
description: Alcan Aluminium said it would discontinue aluminum extrusion at its Kingston plant and phase out its two obsolete presses there.

title: TASK FORCE URGES ACTION AGAINST FAMILY VIOLENCE
description: A Justice Department committee that has been studying family violence called today for toughening the actions that could be taken to arrest, bring to trial and imprison offenders.

title: BUSH SAYS DEMOCRATS ARE MAKING 'KAMIKAZE' ATTACKS ON PRESIDENT
description: Vice President Bush asserted tonight that the Democratic Presidential ticket was resorting to ''kamikaze'' and ''low-road personal'' attacks against President Reagan.

title: A Road Advisory
description: Sign on back of tow truck inching

title: 12.8% DROP IN STARTS OF HOUSING
description: Construction of new houses skidded 12.8 percent in August, to an annual rate of 1,537,000 units, the lowest since December 1982, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: National Campaign Set To Urge People to Vote
description: Entertainers, athletes and the head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will join in a national advertising campaign to get more people to the polls, officials of the campaign announced Tuesday.

title: Refining in Indonesia
description: Indonesia will expand its oil refining capacity, turning from an importer to an exporter of refined products by 1985, Subroto, the energy minister, said today. Refining capacity is to rise to 660,000 barrels a day from 242,000 barrels a day.

title: ;  Comings and Goings
description: Martina Navratilova , seeking to break the record 55-match winning streak she shares with Chris Evert Lloyd , was stopped yesterday by rain that forced postponement of her match against Melissa Brown , a 16- year-old from Scarsdale, N.Y., at the Lynda Carter-Maybelline Tennis Classic in Fort Lauderdale. . . . Sydney Maree will run for the first time competitively since the Olympic trials in the Fifth Avenue Mile on Saturday, the New York Road Runners Club announced. He withdrew from the Olympics with a hamstring pull.

title: THE ABORTION DEBATE: WHAT 'LEGISLATED MORALITY' CANNOT DO

title: No Headline
description: Soviet Oil Price Increase Seen By The Associated Press European oil industry

title: Trudeau Will Join Law Firm
description: Former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau will join the Montreal law firm of Heenan, Blaikie, Jolin, Potvin, Trepanier, Cobbett, the firm announced today. The firm said Mr. Trudeau would be able to remain active in public life.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday quoted an incorrect chronology of events in the Korean War. MacArthur's landing at Inchon occurred in September 1950 and was followed, in order, by the Chinese intervention and the retreat of the United Nations forces to Pusan.

title: EIGHT MEN ARE INDICTED IN INSIDER-TRADING CASE
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a former employee of Sullivan & Cromwell and seven other men on charges of stealing confidential information from the prestigious New York law firm and using it to profit in stock trading.

title: Riccardo Lombardi Is Dead; Leader of Italian Resistance
description: Riccardo Lombardi, a leader of the Italian Resistance during World War II and former president of the Socialist Party, died Tuesday at Mater Dei Hospital here, officials said.

title: EL SALVADOR IS EXPANDING CONTACTS WITH REBELS
description: The Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador is moving to expand contacts with leftist guerrilla leaders in the countryside, according to senior Salvadoran officials.

title: PARAMOUNT'S NEW CHIEF BRINGS SALES SKILLS TO JOB
description: When Frank Mancuso was named chairman of Paramount Pictures one week ago, he flew to California the same afternoon so that he could personally reassure executives at Paramount studio here that no one's job was in jeopardy.

title: CHANGE IN DRUG HELPS ALI IMPROVE
description: Muhammad Ali, who has been bothered by slurred speech and sluggish body movements since retiring from the ring in 1981, has shown noticeable improvement since beginning a new medication regimen just over a week ago, his personal physician said yesterday.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; Del Monte Is Switching Some Work to McCann
description: Del Monte, a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, is carting its fresh fruit business from one of its big agencies to another of its big agencies.

title: CALENDAR: COURSE FOR ASPIRING WEAVERS
description: Portable Loom Weaving for Beginners, Parsons School of Design/

title: ABC REFUSED OFFER OF OLYMPIC REBATE
description: The ABC television network rejected an offer from the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee on the eve of the Summer Games that would have saved the network several million dollars, an official of the organizing committee said today.

title: Growth Rate 6.7% in Japan
description: Japan's economy, fueled by robust exports and domestic industrial spending, grew at an annual rate of 6.7 percent in the quarter ended June 30, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: COURT UPHOLDS THE FEES STATIONS PAY FOR MUSIC
description: The method by which local television stations are charged for the right to use copyrighted music has been declared legal by a Federal appeals court.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: $450 Million in Notes Offered by Michigan

title: Competitor Sues MTV
description: A fledgling music video network charged in a lawsuit today that a rival network, MTV, has a monopoly arrangement with five of the country's largest record companies to insure exclusive rights to the choicest video clips. The network, Discovery Music Network, which plans to begin broadcasting Jan. 1, 1985, contended in its Federal suit that during the last 90 days MTV signed ''predatory and anticompetitive'' agreements with RCA, CBS, MCA, Geffen and Elektra-Asylum-Nonesuch records. It said the agreements granted sole access to new videos for up to six months and contended that this violated antitrust laws.

title: TRADING HEAVY
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged yesterday as a late selloff erased its earlier gains. However, the general market finished with only minor losses in heavy trading.

title: No Verdict in Omega 7 Trial
description: A Federal District Court jury in Manhattan broke off deliberations last night without reaching a verdict in the trial of a Cuban exile accused of heading the Omega 7 anti-Castro terrorist group.

title: NASA MAGAZINE TO GET ADS
description: When you start selling advertising for a NASA publication, then you are truly in the space business.

title: Semyon K. Tsarapkin; Soviet Career Diplomat
description: Semyon K. Tsarapkin, a Soviet diplomat whose 47-year career took him to Washington, Bonn and the United Nations, has died, the press agency Tass said today. He was 78 years old.

title: BLACKS AND JEWS GET TOGETHER FOR DIALOGUE IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: Concerned that recent incidents had heightened tensions and promoted misunderstanding across the country and in their own city, blacks and Jews here began meeting last May to discuss ways of healing the breach.

title: ;  Jersey Proposal In a letter to
description: Robert W. Lee , acting athletic commissioner in New Jersey, and Irwin I. Kimmelman , Attorney General, the State Commission of Investigation recommended that the athletic commissioner and his agency be prohibited from consulting with sanctioning bodies on the selection of referees and the licensing of fights. The proposals follow a four-month investigation of boxing in New Jersey and a complaint in which Lee was charged with violating conflict-of-interest laws by soliciting and receiving contributions from boxing promoters regulated by the athletic commission.

title: U.S. LINKS AID TO ISRAELI BUDGET PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration has officially asked the new Israeli Government to present it with a comprehensive budget- cutting plan before requesting a sharp rise in American economic aid, State Department officials said today.

title: TWO AUCTION HOUSES NAME NEW PRESIDENTS
description: The New York branches of two London auction houses - Sotheby's and Phillips Son & Neale - have named new presidents.

title: HIGH CANCER RISK FOUND IN SIBLINGS
description: In a finding adding to the evidence some childhood cancers have an inherited link, scientists said today that siblings of children with a certain kind of brain tumor were up to 30 times more likely to develop cancer as well.

title: U.S. Will Spend $38.6 Million To Refurbish Port in Somalia
description: The United States has signed an agreement with Somalia to spend $38.6 million to refurbish the Indian Ocean port of Kismayu, the state-run Radio Mogadishu said today.

title: CITY U. PLANNING COURSE TO AID IN SARGENT TEST
description: The City University said yesterday that it planned to offer a course to help prepare candidates for the Police Department's sergeants examination.

title: Populists Sue Virginia Over Its Election Laws
description: Virginia election laws make it impossible for third-party candidates to get on the ballot in the state, the Populist Party says in a lawsuit in Federal Court.

title: COSBY IN NBC SERIES ON A NEW YORK FAMILY
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, John Chancellor, then anchoring the ''NBC Nightly News,'' maintained in an interview that the nation's most effective communicator was Bill Cosby. Since then, Mr. Cosby has been displaying some of his communicating skills in television commercials, those vignettes in which he is usually surrounded by delighted children. But he has had a problem, since completing the series ''I, Spy,'' finding a vehicle for his broader performing talents. That may now be solved with ''The Cosby Show,'' which makes its debut on NBC tonight at 8.

title: Candidates to Withhold Election Day Comments
description: President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale have agreed not to make any Election Day comment on the results of the Presidential voting until the polls close on the West Coast, a Congressman from Oregon said today.

title: 10 More Bodies Found After Ecuador Crash
description: Disaster teams uncovered 10 more bodies today from the ruins of a neighborhood where an Ecuadorian DC-8 cargo jet crashed Tuesday. The authorities said that 60 people had died, 56 of them on the ground, and that more bodies might be found.

title: SCORES ON COLLEGE ENTRANCE TESTS RISE 4 POINTS, BEST GAIN SINCE '63
description: High school graduates scored an average of four points higher on the major test that colleges use in making admissions decisions than graduates of a year earlier, the College Board reported yesterday.

title: ADVISERS REJECT POSTAL PAY PLAN
description: A panel of outside fact-finders, called in to examine the two-month-old Postal Service labor impasse, rejected the agency's demand for a wage freeze and said its proposal to hire new workers at lower wages than present employees was not ''necessary or desirable.''

title: Robert Landau Files Chapter 11
description: Robert Landau Associates Inc., a marketing and promotional services company, has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing liabilities of about $10 million.

title: Nicaraguan Aide Says MIG's Are on the Way
description: Nicaragua's Defense Minister said Tuesday that his country would acquire Soviet- built MIG jet fighters to inhibit ''flagrant violations'' of its territorial waters and airspace by United States warplanes and ships.

title: Fannie Mae Sees Loss in Quarter
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said it would make a supplemental addition of $35 million to its allowance on loan losses on conventional mortgages, and that the increase would result in a loss for the third quarter.

title: Army Contracts
description: Sikorsky Support Service Inc., a division of United Technologies Inc., received a $61.2 million contract from the Army for maintenance on rotary and fixed-wing aircraft, the Defense Department said. It also said the Magnavox Government and Industrial Company had been given a $25.3 million Army contract for radio receiver sets and spares, hydraulic generators, and air-conditioners.

title: QUALITY OF ARTIFICIAL HEART VALVES IS ASSAILED
description: The former manager of quality control for the manufacturer of artificial heart valves that have been linked to at least 64 deaths asserted today that the company had rejected his suggestions to improve the quality of the devices.

title: ANGELS WIN IN 11TH, TRAIL ROYALS BY 1-1/2
description: Bobby Grich's bad-hop single with one out in the 11th inning tonight drove in a pinch-runner, Rick Burleson, and gave the California Angels a 4-3 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: A.T.&T. Picks Computer Marketer
description: In a move that may quell criticism that its computer marketing lacks focus, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would strengthen efforts to sell data processing equipment through distributors and other intermediaries.

title: OPERA: SAN FRANCISCO 'SONNAMBULA'
description: The San Francisco Opera's new production of ''La Sonnambula,'' unveiled Tuesday night at the War Memorial Opera House, is of interest to admirers of Frederica von Stade, who sang the part of Amina for the first time, and to those concerned with how we today should perform Romantic operas like those of Bellini.

title: IN THE WEST BANK: A COMMON GROUND
description: -Occupied West Bank, Sept. 18 - The Arab residents of the West Bank and the Jewish settlers who live among them rarely see things the same way, but now they are agree about one thing: neither group has much use for the policies espoused by Israel's new coalition Government.

title: RESTRAINT SERVES PLURALISM
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - In early August, Bishop James M. Malone, president of the United States Catholic Conference of Bishops, stated that it is ''not logically tenable'' for political candidates to draw a dichotomy between their personal morality and public policy. Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York more recently made the same point. In doing so, they expressed a common belief about the moral integrity required of the politician: we don't like hypocrites or those who think that private belief and behavior are irrelevant to public office.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the new positions of two officials at CPC International Inc. David Newstadt and Robert J. Gillespie were named executive vice presidents of CPC's Best Foods North America division.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON SEWAGE LIMITS
description: Lawmakers from New York and New Jersey announced an agreement today to amend the Clean Water Act to restrict New York City's discharge of raw sewage into the Hudson River.

title: DEBERG IS INSECURE AFTER 7 YEARS IN JOB
description: In Steve DeBerg's seven previous seasons as a pro quarterback, he was never comfortable in the job. He will start for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers against the Giants here Sunday, and he is still uncomfortable.

title: RELATIVES OF MURDER VICTIMS URGE NO CLEMENCY FOR CAROLINA KILLER
description: Relatives of two victims killed by a woman now on death row asked Governor James B. Hunt Jr. today to permit her to be executed as scheduled on Nov. 2.

title: LEBANESE QUARRELING OVER A CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY
description: The Moslem-Christian Cabinet wrangled throughout the day over who would be named to a constituent assembly to draw up political changes in hopes of restoring peace to Lebanon.

title: THE REGION ; 4TH AUBURN INMATE IN 3 DAYS STABBED
description: Auburn state prison officials, acting after four inmate stabbings in three days this week, have ordered that every inmate moving through the prison be frisked, officials said today.

title: MATTINGLY'S 3 HITS HELP YANKEES WIN
description: The Yankees were young again on this September night.

title: JAZZ: BOBBY MCFERRIN SINGS AT BLUE NOTE
description: THE temptation for a jazz singer like Bobby McFerrin, who can make practically every vocal and instrumental sound known to pop, is to be virtuosic often at the expense of feeling. The ability to

title: FOR FERRARO, VOTES FROM THE HEART
description: Ernest DeMattei said all that needed to be said about Geraldine A. Ferraro, so far as most of the men gathered at a recreation center in South Philadelphia were concerned.

title: ;  Muncie in Drug Care After being barred by the National Football League until he successfully completes prescribed treatment for use of drugs,
description: Chuck Muncie has checked into a hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. The San Diego Union reported that Muncie was admitted Monday to Scottsdale-Camelback, but neither the San Diego Chargers nor the league would confirm that, saying the matter was confidental.

title: U.S. AIDE SAYS ETHIOPIA IS MISHANDLING EMERGENCY FOOD SHIPMENTS
description: The head of the Agency for International Development said today that the Ethiopian Government's lack of cooperation in handling emergency food supplies from donor nations was hampering the delivery of badly needed food to the country.

title: 4TH GAME OF TITLE MATCH POSTPONED BY KARPOV
description: Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, today postponed the fourth game of his title match with Gary Kasparov until Friday.

title: MIXING PERSONAL MORALITY AND PUBLIC POLICY
description: The debate over the appropriate role of religion in politics is befogged by a crucial misunderstanding about the nature of abortion, which is in essence a matter of public and not merely private morality.

title: DUBLIN MAYOR FAULTS NEW YORKERS ON ULSTER By The Associated Press
description: The Lord Mayor of Dublin met with Mayor Koch in New York yesterday and criticized New York City police officers and a city lawyer for appearing in Northern Ireland at events sponsored by Sinn Fein, the legal political arm of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Award to Playwright
description: Craig Lucas, author of the play ''Blue Window,'' will receive the first George and Elisabeth Marton Award for playwrighting. The award, which consists of $1,000, will be given annually in the fall to a new playwright by the Dramatists Guild. The award was provided by Elisabeth Marton, a theatrical agent, in honor of her late brother, George, who was also a theatrical agent.

title: THE REGION ; 1.3 MILLION IN JERSEY TO GET GAS CREDIT
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company has agreed to give each of its 1.3 million gas customers a $30 credit on the November bill, state officials said today.

title: HIGH ATOP 5TH AVENUE, A CITY SYMBOL SHRINKS
description: The Empire State Building, epitome of the New York skyscraper, has shrunk.

title: ;  Promotions at Bloom
description: Tony to his friends, and 50 years old to everyone - has been promoted from chairman and chief executive of the Bloom Agency/Dallas to president of the Bloom Companies, the parent company. Dennis McClain, who is 36 and has been president/creative director since coming aboard last year, will replace him as chairman of the Dallas agency. Grabbing the president portion of Mr. McClain's title is Paul MacMahon, 39, who will continue as general manager.

title: House Approves a Bill Restricting C.I.A. Files
description: The House approved legislation today to put in the statute books what Federal courts have consistently held: that Central Intelligence Agency operational files are off limits to requests under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: CUOMO PLAN SEEKS TO SPUR INVESTING IN NEEDY SECTIONS
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday announced new regulations for state- chartered banks intended to lure up to $1 billion in investments to depressed neighborhoods.

title: TORRAY LIFTS STAKE IN CASTLE
description: Torray Clark & Company, an investment concern based in Bethesda, Md., has increased its holdings in Castle & Cooke Inc. to a 19.45 percent stake in the Hawaii-based real estate and food company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -VIEW MIRROR

title: CITY CENTER OFFERS NEW DANCE SERIES
description: THE City Center Theater has announced a new dance subscription series for its 1984-85 season. Subscribers will receive tickets to seven events at substantial savings from the regular box office prices. In addition, subscribers will be able to purchase tickets for a controversial Japanese dance company at a discount.

title: The Mayor as Manager
description: If New York were a private corporation, Mayor Koch's 1984 Management Report would have a bottom line. But a city's purpose is the future of its citizens. To forecast that future, the Koch administration has established departmental goals and reports progress toward them. The report just issued suggests that city management has done well in fiscal 1984 but that many goals remain far off.

title: Reagan and World War II
description: President Reagan likes to use

title: PLAYING CRYSTAL BALL, OR PIN THE TAIL ON THE BUDGET
description: In refusing Walter F. Mondale's challenge to outline a deficit-reduction program before the November election, President Reagan says he has already made his overall intentions clear in the four budgets he has submitted to Congress since taking office in 1981.

title: THE QUEBEC POWER TRADER
description: Every company building a large manufacturing facility takes a risk that the market for its product will not justify the cost of construction. But Hydro-Quebec, the provincial utility that has spent $10.7 billion here over the last 14 years to construct the largest energy project on the continent, has developed a price structure that adds new variations to that theme.

title: C.D. Yields Are Down
description: Average yields on most certificates of deposit dropped sharply in the week ended yesterday after five weeks of stability, while average yields on money market accounts rose slightly, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: ; A Fighting Champ In Another Bout
description: Muhammad Ali, now age 42, has changed perceptibly in recent years, and other former fighters may have felt the change more deeply than most.

title: No Headline
description: Bank Money Accounts Money6-monthMarketC.D.'s(%)(%) Bankers Trust 10.7011.40 Chase Manhattan 10.6311.35 Chemical Bank 10.6311.46 Citibank 10.6311.18 Manufacturers Hanover 10.2411.35 Bowery Savings 11.5512.19 Dime Savings (N.Y.) 10.5011.46 Dollar Dry Dock Savings 10.4111.75 Goldome 9.5912.19 Metropolitan Savings 10.6311.91 City Federal (N.J.) 9.7612.00 First Nat. State (N.J.) 9.7311.00 Midlantic Nat. Bank (N.J.) 9.6911.00 United Jersey Banks 9.7611.30 Connecticut Bank & Trust 10.0911.30 Connecticut National 9.9311.20 People's Bank (Conn.) 10.2011.30 Bank Rate Monitor Index* 9.8011.16 **Annual effective yields offered by 50 large institutions in the five largest U.S. markets.

title: Chicago Mayor Vetoes Bond Issue for Airport
description: After vetoing $820 million in public works projects, Mayor Harold Washington said ''the door is still open'' to compromise with the City Council in a longrunning battle over Council review of major contracts.

title: Government to Collect Blood For Test to Diagnose AIDS
description: The government will collect as many as 200,000 blood samples from healthy donors to use for research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome once a diagnostic test for the disease is available, Health and Human Services Secretary Margaret M. Heckler said today.

title: Blast at Grain Elevator Kills One in Tennessee
description: A grain elevator exploded today and sent fiery debris crashing onto a loading dock, killing one man, injuring 10 and leaving two missing.

title: ASBESTOS IN HOME: EXAMINING RISKS
description: Federal officials are beginning to investigate - and express concern over - asbestos in the home, as inquiries continue into the presence and hazards of asbestos in schools and other public buildings.

title: CBS PLANS TO ABANDON KURALT-MOYERS PROGRAM
description: CBS News, which for the last few years has invested a great deal of its documentary-film resources in the production of a weekly program with Bill Moyers and Charles Kuralt, said yesterday it has abandoned the series.

title: Texaco Plans 21% Staff Cut Integrating With Getty
description: Texaco Inc. will reduce its worldwide work force by about 14,500, or 21 percent, by the end of this year, John K. McKinley, Texaco's chairman, said yesterday. The step comes as Texaco integrates its operations with the Getty Oil Company and other interests that it recently acquired.

title: DEBATING DESIGN IN HISTORIC DISTRICTS
description: ON the face of it, there could be nothing better than a debate that has been simmering all summer over the design for the apartment house that will be built on the Avenue of the Americas between Washington Place and Waverly Place. For if nothing else, it reveals that passions for architecture are running high - that in Greenwich Village at least, residents are arguing over lintels and cornices with the earnestness with which they have always debated social issues.

title: High Court Clears Way For Florida Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court cleared the way today for James Henry to die in Florida's electric chair Thursday morning for the 1974 slaying of a civil rights leader.

title: CONTINENTALL SEVERANCE QUESTIONED
description: C. Todd Conover, Comptroller of the Currency, told Congress today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is ''likely to take some action'' against large severance contracts the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company granted to Roger E. Anderson, its former chairman, and two other top officials. Mr. Conover is one of three F.D.I.C. directors.

title: 3 ARE CONVICTED IN TOGO OF KILLING AMERICAN Three residents of the West African country of Togo have been found guilty of killing a 23-year-old Peace Corps worker from Oneonta, N.Y. in June, a spokesman for the Togo mission to the United Nations said yesterday.
description: Jennifer Lynn Rubin, who had been a Peace Corps volunteer for 12 months in the village of Defale in the northern part of the country, was bludgeoned to death in her home June 11 after she had accused one of the defendants of stealing articles of clothing, according to Peace Corps accounts at the time.

title: WITNESS SAYS CRIME FIGURES RULE DISPOSAL OF TOXIC WASTE
description: A former Teamsters Union and carting company official testified at a State Assembly hearing today that organized-crime figures were using their control of trash collection concerns to rule the separate, lucrative business of disposing of toxic wastes.

title: THE 'LIVING WILL' GAINS ACCEPTANCE
description: Luis Kutner's musings about death anticipated the day when medicine would cross the line from prolonging life to prolonging dying. More than 50 years ago he wrote his first ''living will,'' a document that allows a person to specify under what conditions life- support systems should be discontinued.

title: MILITARY PRICE ON COFFEE CITED AS $7,622
description: Senators were told today that the approved price for a 10-cup coffee maker for the C-5 transport plane was $7,622 and that the Air Force was paying $670.06 for aircraft armrests that mechanics believe can be made for $5. The price of the coffee brewer does not include a stainless steel pot.

title: WHEN A HEALTH DAMAGE SUIT ISN'T CLEAR CUT
description: To the Editor:

title: RESIGNATION'S STOCK IMPACT
description: The announcement Tuesday of the sudden

title: CAMBRIDGE PRESS MARKS 400 YEARS OF PUBLISHING
description: PRACTICALLY unnoticed by its New York publishing neighbors, for the last 35 years the American branch of Cambridge University Press has quietly gone about the business of publishing scholarly books for a limited audience.

title: American International
description: American International Group, the largest company traded on the over- the-counter market, has applied for listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 5 ALASKANS RETURNED BY RUSSIANS TO U.S. CUSTODY
description: Five American seamen who had been held in Siberia for a week after their vessel strayed near the Soviet Union, headed home today after being released in a rendezvous on the high seas, officials said.

title: Coming to the Party Of the Aide
description: Fifteen portraits - not a smile in

title: PROTESTANT GROUPS SUE TO BAR U.S. TIES TO VATICAN
description: A broad coalition of Protestant churches filed a federal court lawsuit today asking that the exchange of diplomats between the Reagan Administration and the Roman Catholic Church be nullified as a violation of the First Amendment guarantee of separation of church and state.

title: Britons' Wages Climb
description: British workers' pay rose 1.4 percent in July from June and 5.3 percent from July 1983, the Government said today.

title: BRIDGE: U.S. IS UNUSUAL IN SPURNING SPONSORSHIP OF TOURNAMENT
description: In one important area of bridge organization the American Contract Bridge League has been different from the rest of the world. It has spurned sponsorship, attempting to keep the game a totally amateur recreation divorced from all commercial taint.

title: BRITISH NAVAL FORCES INSPECT A MINE FOUND IN GULF OF SUEZ
description: Egyptian and British officials said today that British mine-hunting forces in the Gulf of Suez were inspecting a mine that might be one of the devices that have damaged at least 18 ships in the Gulf and Red Sea waters since July.

title: INTEREST RATES TURN DOWN
description: Interest rates declined yesterday as new data confirmed a slowdown in economic growth at the same time as the Federal Reserve showed its willingness to help sustain the recent drop in overnight interest rates.

title: Coming to the Aid Of the Party
description: The Liberal Party had to use politicians of other parties to keep some semblance of order at its 19-hour state meeting to elect officers.

title: 'Dear Colleague'
description: Congressional staffs are paid to deal with matters too small to command the personal attention of the eleced member. But sometimes the members produce matters that seem almost too small for their staffs to bother with.

title: SORTING OUT GERANIUM PUZZLE
description: Gardeners hardly need be reminded of their confusion when it comes to plant nomenclature. Yet even experienced nurserymen concede that they are fooled by the blur of the geranium family. It is not surprising, then, that the common use of the word geranium is suspect and that the popular flower of window-box fame should really be called pelargonium.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday of Piera Maiolgio, co-owner of the Barbetta restaurant in Manhattan, misstated her family's relationship to the business. Barbetta describes itself as the oldest restaurant in New York still owned by the family that founded it.

title: No Headline
description: American Sterilizer Studying a Buyout

title: Litton to Sell Unit
description: Litton Industries said it had agreed to sell its Monroe Systems division to a group of private investors.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 20, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SIERRA CLUB BREAKS ITS TRADITION AND BACKS A CANDIDATE: MONDALE
description: The Sierra Club broke a 92-year tradition today and endorsed Walter F. Mondale for President.

title: COACH SUSPENDED FOR REFUSAL TO PLAY
description: Jim Walsh, the football coach at George Washington High School in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, was suspended yesterday for the rest of the season, a move that also ended the school's football program for this year. The suspension came four days after the coach had ordered his players to forfeit a game, saying he feared for their safety.

title: PLANNING NEW LIVING SPACES FOR THE NONTRADITIONAL FAMILIY
description: The nuclear family - a working father, homemaking mother and two or more children - may persist as a dominant image of the American family, but among all households, this unit is a statistical minority, a scant 5.7 percent of the 83,500,000 households in the United State today.

title: LAOTIAN MIGRATION WORRIES THAILAND
description: As many as 10,000 migrants may have crossed the border from Laos in the last six or seven months, according to Thai authorities. This is double the number of border crossings over the previous two years, refugee workers say.

title: Canadian Is Invited to U.S.
description: President Reagan has invited Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to visit Washington next Tuesday to discuss common issues.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SENATE RACE OFFERS A SHARP CHOICE
description: Voters in Massachusetts will face one of the clearest Senate choices in the nation in the election in November after Tuesday's primary victories by Raymond Shamie, a millionaire conservative Republican, and Lieut. Gov. John F. Kerry, a liberal Democrat.

title: Hearst Heir Is Publisher Of San Francisco Paper
description: William Randolph Hearst 3d, 35 years old, was named publisher today of The San Francisco Examiner, which his family has owned since 1887 when it became the first publication in the nationwide chain of newspapers established by his late grandfather.

title: TOP JERSEY COURT UPHOLDS STATE'S FUND FOR CLEANING UP TOXIC WASTE
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 0,today that the state's Spill Compensation Fund law, which taxes chemical companies to pay for cleaning up toxic wastes, is constitutional and not pre- empted by Federal law.

title: LED LITTLE ROCK INTEGRATION
description: Ted Lamb, a lawyer and former advertising executive who fought successfully for public school integration while he was a member of the Little Rock, Ark., school board in the desegregation crisis of the late 1950's, died of pancreatic cancer Sept. 6 at his home in Alexander, Ark. He was 57 years old.

title: DEFENSE AIDE PUTS PROBLEM NAVY MISSILES AT 21%
description: A Pentagon official acknowledged today that a significant share of the Navy's air combat missiles are currently unusable, but said the blame fell in part on Congress's insistence on competitive bidding.

title: ;  People
description: * Walter Bernd, Kenneth Kopas and Gregory Weed promoted to senior vice president in the Consumer Group of Sudler & Hennessey.

title: MANILA INQUIRY PANEL SUPPORTED
description: The chief of the Philippine armed forces has promised that the military will abide by the findings and recommendations of the panel investigating the assassination last year of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: A Show of Hands on Civil Rights Despite overwhelming support for it in Congress, the Civil Rights Act of 1984 is in danger because time is so short before adjournment. The bill's modest purpose is to restore the laws against discrimination by sex, race, age and physical handicap to the vigor they had before the Supreme Court narrowed their scope. The House passed a corrective measure in June by 375 to 32. A comparable majority is ready to approve the Senate's version - if it can be brought to a vote.
description: The Court said that sex bias laws, and by implication the similar laws on race, age and handicap, permitted an institution receiving Federal funds to comply in one department and to discriminate in others. It no longer matters whether the Court misread the laws or whether they were poorly drawn over the last two decades.

title: PRESIDENT HEAPS PRAISE ON VOTERS IN THE NORTHEAST
description: President Reagan bid for re-election today by heaping lavish praise on ethnic voters and condemnation on the Democrats for fashioning an economic ''blueprint for bondage.''

title: Jacor Acquisition
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said it had agreed to acquire two Cleveland radio stations - WBBG-AM and WMJI-FM - from Robinson Broadcasting Inc. and Robinson Communications.

title: PANEL BROADENS TAX-BREAK PLAN ON RENTAL UNITS
description: A City Council panel yesterday expanded the areas in Manhattan where luxury rental apartment buildings would continue to be eligible for tax breaks, changing a Koch administration plan.

title: U.S.-Iran Arbitration Suspended at Hague
description: The president of a tribunal set up to rule on United States claims against Iran suspended arbitration indefinitely on Wednesday because of an accusation that two Iranian judges punched a Swedish judge.

title: FRENCH DOCTORS SAY THEY HELPED PATIENTS DIE
description: A group of French doctors declared today that they had helped some of their patients to die.

title: CHINA AND BRITAIN JOINTLY ANNOUNCE HONG KONG ACCORD
description: China and Britain announced today that they had concluded a long-awaited draft agreement that would transfer Hong Kong from British to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. The accord may be initialed as early as next week.

title: COMMITTEE BACKS GENOCIDE TREATY
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today recommended approval of a United Nations convention outlawing genocide, but it is uncertain whether the measure will reach the Senate floor before Congress adjourns.

title: PROTEST VOICED AT U.S. EXCLUSION OF VISITORS BECAUSE OF THEIR IDEAS
description: Several well-known Latin Americans and Europeans who have encountered difficulties in visiting this country joined today in protesting United States restrictions on foreign visitors for ideological reasons.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Friendly Wager

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1984
description: The Economy

title: OUR TOWNS
description: Although they follow a path that teaches them to subdue the ego and not pursue it, Joshua and Diana Cutler have agreed, for a moment at least, to step into the light, because they are true believers and, in the way of all true believers, there is a little of the missionary in them.

title: AtomicBombProject Wae
description: The Manhattan Project, the Government-sponsored research project that produced the first atomic bomb, cost more than $2 billion, employed 125,000 people and involved several laboratories across the country.

title: A CONRAIL BID SAID TO TOP $1.5 BILION
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation has proposed a cash buyout of the Consolidated Rail Corporation valued at more than $1.5 billion, according to sources familiar with the Government's discussions with the railway's three potential buyers.

title: MUSIC: DEJOHNETTE AT LUSH LIFE
description: JACK DeJOHNETTE, long acclaimed as a masterful drummer and bandleader, is performing on his second instrument - the piano - through Sunday at Lush Life. His trio has a repertory of DeJohnette compositions and, in the second set Tuesday, tunes associated with Miles Davis and John Coltrane.

title: ECONOMISTS OUTLINE A REMEDY FOR ISRAELI WOES
description: The traditional remedy prescribed for countries in desperate economic straits, such as Israel, where the new leadership is trying to devise an economic reform plan, is a painful combination of cutbacks in Government programs, tax increases and slower monetary growth.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Appraisal Associates Inc. , an appraisal holding company based in Milwaukee, said its board had extended the deadline for closing on its acquisition by RLM Investments Inc. until Oct. 3.

title: King Radio Suitor
description: The King Radio Corporation said it was holding talks on being acquired by a major corporation, which it declined to identify.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PHILS ROUT METS ON 15-HIT ATTACK
description: The strikeout pitching, the clutch home run and all the other fantasies fled tonight as the Mets committed five errors, got nowhere against Steve Carlton and took a 13-5 hammering from the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: REPAIRING THE HINGES ON ANTIQUE FURNITURE
description: Often with antique furniture, the restorer must ask, ''How did this damage happen in the first place?'' and then decide what can be done to prevent it from happening again.

title: MUSIC: KUN WOO PAIK
description: THE pianist Kun Woo Paik, who presented an ambitious concert at the Abraham Goodman House Tuesday night, is a master colorist. One seldom hears the piano played with such obvious love and respect for its timbral possibilities. Mr. Paik coaxes a bejewelled, singing tone from his instrument.

title: SPAUDING, 2 OTHER UNITS ARE SOLD BY Q HOLDINGS
description: The A. G. Spalding Company, the 108-year-old producer of sporting goods, has been sold to a group of investors that includes two top officers of its parent company.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; ; Marsh & McLennan Reports Appointments
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's biggest insurance brokerage firm, announced yesterday that Frank J. Borelli, 49, had been named senior vice president and chief financial officer. It also said that Richard H. Blum, 45, had been appointed president of Guy Carpenter & Company, its reinsurance brokerage subsidiary.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR IS INDICTED ON 14 PERJURY COUNTS
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock was indicted by a county grand jury today on one count of conspiracy and 14 counts of perjury, ending a two-month investigation of his personal and campaign finances.

title: ;  Maryland Sewer District Bonds
description: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, in Maryland, is offering $55 million of bonds through underwriters led by Citibank. Underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank submitted a bid that set a lower interest cost to the district, but it was rejected because it arrived a few minutes late.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Dun & Bradstreet Fills 2 Top Posts

title: THE REAGAN TOUCH, THE CARTER TOUCH
description: Robert S. Strauss, who brings a Texas dimension to law, politics and storytelling in Washington, was both marveling at and complaining about President Reagan's success in using his office and his incumbency to political advantage this election season.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DIARY OF VIRGINIA WOLFE: Volume 5, 1936-1941. Edited by Anne Olivier Bell, assisted by Andrew McNeillie. 402 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. THE fifth and last volume of ''The Diary of Virginia Woolf'' may be the best. Beneath its bright energy, there is also a fervent goodbye, for the last entry was written four days before she drowned herself in March of 1941. Opening in 1936, when she is 54, this volume covers the abdication of King Edward VIII, the first years of World War II and the final falling into place of many literary reputations, including her own, T. S. Eliot's, E. M. Forster's and James Joyce's.

title: S. DILLON RIPLEY'S HERITAGE
description: In some ways, S. Dillon Ripley, who

title: Coming to the Parties Of the Aid Group
description: Women, a majority of the population (52 percent), are a tiny minority of elected officials (10 percent).

title: THE ABORTION DEBATE: WHAT 'LEGISLATED MORALITY' CANNOT DO
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Rasmussen Is Suspended Dennis Rasmussen of the Yankees and Willie Upshaw of the Toronto Blue Jays were suspended for three games apiece by the American League president yesterday for their roles in the latest brushback

title: DESIGN IDEAS IN 2 NEW SMALL HOTELS
description: Steve Rubell of Studio 54 and Andree Putman, the Parisian interior designer, were scurrying through the nearly completed renovation of the building that will house Morgans, a 154-room hotel that will open Oct. 1 at 237 Madison Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets.

title: ;  N.F.L. Appeal Citing a problem of ''franchise free agency,''
description: Pete Rozelle , commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that the league has formally petitioned the United States Supreme Court to overturn an appellate court decision that upheld the right of the Raiders to move from Oakland to Los Angeles without the league's approval. In a writ of certiorari filed last Friday, the league asked the high court to hear an appeal of a 2-1 decision last February by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco that held the league had no right to block a franchise from moving from one city to another. That was followed within a month by the move of the Colts from Baltimore to Indianapolis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't live in a world in which there exists a single definition of honor anymore, and it's a fool that hangs on to the traditional standards and hopes that the world will come around to him.'' - Joseph J. Ellis, former instructor at West Point. (A21:1.)

title: UNUSUAL CHAMPION IS RE-EMERGING
description: Next to her stall in barn 9 at Belmont Park, there is no plaque reading, ''All Along - Horse of the Year 1983,'' and even if there were one, many passersby would still not believe it.

title: Grumman Loses Bid To Dismiss City Suit
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday refused to dismiss the New York City Transit Authority's $324 million suit against the Grumman Corporation, makers of the city's Flxible buses.

title: A MILE TO GO FOR WENDY SLY
description: It's been a long, hard Olympic year

title: BROADER EDUCATION FOR MEDICAL STUDENTS PROPOSED
description: A new approach to medical education, intended to cut down on lecture classes, minimize memorization and ease the pressure on undergraduates hoping to get into medical school, was proposed yesterday by a panel sponsored by the Association of American Medical Colleges.

title: IN COLUMBIA COUNTY, RESTORATION IS A WAY OF LIFE
description: When Laurie and Jim Gambee found the 1760 house on a back road near Canaan, N.Y., it was badly in need of attention.And even more in need of a coat of paint: it had been done in a stunning chartreuse.

title: PROTECTING SUSPECTS
description: A 62-year-old woman with no criminal record is charged with the sexual abuse of children. She spends the night in a cockroach-infested jail cell, hectored by prostitutes. She is shown on television handcuffed and in tears as she fends off angry parents. Photographs and articles appear in the local newspapers. It may sound like something out of Kafka or Orwell. But for Herminia Albo, an assistant teacher at the Praca Day-Care Center in the Bronx accused of molesting young children, it was all too real. Then, last Tuesday, a Bronx grand jury declined to indict her.

title: Coffee Price Rise Rejected
description: Nations that import coffee rejected a proposal from producing countries to increase the internationally regulated price range for coffee by about 10 cents a pound, a spokesman for the importers said today.

title: TORREY UNTROUBLED BY 3-GOALIE ISSUE
description: Bill Torrey leaned back in his chair, more than a little cheshire in his grin, and dismissed the issue. The Islanders, lo and behold, no longer have a goaltending problem.

title: 2 Killed in New Clashes In Southern Indian State
description: Two people died and eight were wounded in new violence in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad before an important state assembly session, the police said today.

title: A Korean Export Rise
description: South Korean exports of electrical and electronic products rose 48.4 percent, to $2.9 billion, in the first eight months of 1984 from a year earlier, an industry trade group said today.

title: Utility Pares Michigan Plan
description: The Consumers Power Company has told the State of Michigan it would be willing to discuss a rate increase $267 million a year less than it originally sought to cover costs of the defunct Midland nuclear power project, a state official said today.

title: THEATER: ORWELL'S '1984' VISITS AN ONTARIO TOWN
description: -ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario Sept. 19 - The serenity of this picturesque town was displaced Tuesday by parades, billboards and loudspeakers heralding the repressive regime of Big Brother, as the Shaw Festival Theater turned its attention from sedate Shavian matters to an environmental evocation of George Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four.''

title: RUSSIAN HAD WILLIAM MORROW BOOK CONTRACT
description: A Soviet journalist who received political asylum in Britain last year and turned up in Moscow on Tuesday had signed a contract to write a book on the Soviet press, a New York publisher said yesterday.

title: SHOW OF CERAMICS IN VARIED METHODS
description: Two concurrent exhibitions at the American Craft Museum emphasize mastery of ceramic surface design. A major retrospective devoted to the work of Rudy Autio shares space with a collection of raku and smoke-fired ceramics by 22 craftsmen.

title: SCOUTING ;
description: No More Injuries

title: TIGERS VICTORY AWAKENS WEARY DETROIT
description: Detroit forgot its troubles today and celebrated the Tigers' clinching of the American League's Eastern Division championship.

title: PAPANDREOU PLANS TO VISIT LIBYA NEXT WEEK
description: The Government announced today that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou will make an official two-day visit to Libya starting Sunday.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Lanier Leaving A High Post

title: BIZET'S 'CARMEN' FROM FRANCESCO ROSI
description: THREE months after the frostily received world premiere of ''Carmen'' in Paris in 1875, Georges Bizet, its composer, died. Within 10 years ''Carmen'' had become one of the world's most popular operas - and it still is.

title: NEEDLESS ALARM OVER U.S. JUDICIARY'S IDEOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: REYNOLDS $1.7 BILLION DIVESTITURE
description: In one of the largest corporate divestitures in recent years, R.J. Reynolds Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its energy operations to the Phillips Petroleum Company for $1.7 billion.

title: Salvatore Testa, Buried; Reputed to Be Crime Leader
description: Salvatore Testa, reputed to be a leading figure in Philadelphia organized crime until he was found shot to death last Friday, was given a Mass of Christian Burial today in South Philadelphia.

title: Soviet Says It Accepts Inspection of Reactors
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would allow international inspection of its civilian nuclear reactors, and that the gesture was aimed at strengthening trust between nations.

title: HAVE-NOTS FEAR 'MANHATTANIZATION' AS DEVELOPERS SIZE UP CHINATOWN
description: Toyping Wong, who has lived for 40 years in a tenement at 56 Henry Street, says she is going to fight eviction ''because I've got no place else to go and this is my home.''

title: THRIFT REGULATORS MOVE AGAINST EQUITY C.D.'s
description: Federal officials are trying to stop a new technique by which savings institutions have been issuing certificates of deposit to finance real estate ventures generally considered riskier than usual.

title: HARVEY STEVENSON, 89, ARCHITECT WHO HELPED DESIGN F.D.R. DRIVE
description: Harvey Stevenson, an architect who helped design the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive, died Wednesday at a convalescent home in Waterford, Conn. He was 89 years old and lived in Lyme, Conn.

title: VIRULENT UNKNOWN BACTERIA STRAIN SPREADING CANKER
description: The citrus canker disease that threatens Florida's $2.5 billion orange, grapefruit and tangerine industry is being spread by a previously unknown bacteria strain that scientists say may be one of the most aggressive and virulent microorganisms ever to imperil citrus crops.

title: IRAQ REPORTS ATTACK ON AN IRANIAN OIL DEPOT
description: Iraq asserted today that its forces had attacked Iranian oil installations at Kharg Island. Iran denied the report.

title: Norman Lear Group Opens $1 Million Drive
description: People for the American Way, a lobbying group founded four years ago by the television producer Norman Lear, announced today it was launching a $1 million campaign ''to counter the rhetoric of today's fundamentalist right.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER, 21, 1984 International The U.S. Embassy was attacked by a suicide car bomber, killing at least 23 people and injuring scores in a Beirut suburb. The assailant, who died in the explosion, detonated the vehicle in front of the six-story building, devastating it. Two Americans were known to be among the dead. The embassy had recently been moved to Aukar in Christian East Beirut because it was thought to be safer than West Beirut. (Page A1, Columns 3-6.) Security measures were incomplete when the United States occupied its new embassy in Beirut, according to a senior State Department official. The area around the embassy was guarded by Lebanese Christian militiamen because a contingent of 80 United States marines was withdrawn seven weeks ago when State Department officials decided it was no longer needed. (A1:5.)

title: MONDALE OFFERS HIS 'FULL SUPPORT' TO APPROPRIATE COUNTERMEASURES
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that President Reagan would have his support ''for appropriate countermeasures'' against those responsible for the attack on the United States Embassy in Beirut.

title: THE ELDERLY MAY DUMP REAGAN
description: The way senior- citizens issues like Medicare and Social Security are breaking in the polls, Walter F. Mondale may be one- quarter of the way to the White House, thanks to seniors.

title: 5 Killed by Separatists In Northern Sri Lanka
description: Separatist guerrillas shot and killed five people Wednesday night in the troubled northern district of Jaffna and tied their bodies to lampposts, security sources said today.

title: Jim Craig Quits Hockey $95;BOSTON, Sept. 20
description: Jim Craig, the gold-medal goalie whose bittersweet odyssey took him from Olympic hero to professional hockey journeyman, announced his retirement from the sport today at the age of 27. Having helped the United States team to a first-place finish at the 1980 Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y., Craig went directly to the Atlanta Flames, and for a while his future in the National Hockey League appeared bright.

title: A MORE RESPONSIVE U.N.
description: President Reagan's appearance next Monday before the United Nations General Assembly will probably attract a fair amount of attention. If the last few years are any accurate measure, though, the odds are that when he leaves most Americans will hardly notice that the Assembly is still in session.

title: A U.N. CHARTER REVIEW
description: PARIS There have been about 150 wars in

title: Teamsters' Pact Ballots Are Ordered Impounded
description: A Federal district judge has ordered that teamsters' union ballots on a proposed contract renewal with the United Parcel Service be impounded, saying union leaders gave members little opportunity to consider the offer.

title: ;  Sony Betamax Drive
description: The Sony Corporation of America, once the front-runner in the

title: NEW WELFARE CHIEF FACING CHALLENGES
description: When he begins his new job on the 15th floor of an office building in lower Manhattan next month, George Gross will face many of the same challenges that a new leader must face in any large institution. He can expect to put in long, hard hours merely to learn the jargon, the players, the problems and their possible solutions. But as the new Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, Mr. Gross will face an uphill climb that is steeper than most new executives can imagine. Even the weather will be an adversary because, as winter approaches, the numbers of homeless people seeking shelter increase sharply. The city is already housing 3,000 families in shelters and hotels - about 700 more than it expected to have next January.

title: U.S. MIGHT APPROVE MISSILE PAYMENTS
description: Air Force contract managers are satisfied with the Hughes Aircraft Company's efforts to solve workmanship problems and have recommended that the Pentagon resume millions of dollars in payments frozen since last month, a defense contract official said today.

title: CAR BOMBING HAS BECOME FAVORED TACTIC OF TERRORISTS IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Explosives concealed in cars and trucks have repeatedly been used by terrorists in the Middle East since April 18, 1983, when an unidentified driver gunned an explosives-laden Chevrolet pickup truck into the front driveway of the main United States Embassy compound in West Beirut.

title: A DAY OF KNOGHTS AT THE CLOISTERS
description: It's not easy being the black knight.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction in this space yesterday - referring to the Sports of The Times column on Wednesday - gave a further incorrect chronology of events in the Korean War. The United Nations command's withdrawal to Pusan occurred in the summer of 1950, before either the American landing at Inchon or the Chinese intervention. (A later evacuation by sea to Pusan, by the United States X Army Corps, occurred in December 1950, after all the other events.)

title: INQUIRY ON MEESE DISCERNS NO BASIS FOR CRIMINAL CASE
description: A court-appointed investigator said today that there was ''no basis'' under Federal law for prosecuting Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor and nominee for Attorney General.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN VISIT STIRS A CITY
description: The temporary stage and its huge blue backdrop - ''Waterbury, Connecticut Says America Is Proud Again, Thanks President Reagan'' - were gone by this morning.

title: DEMOCRAT EAGER TO LAND TELLING BLOWS ON REAGAN
description: As rumbling jet engines bore his campaign plane through the inky night, Walter F. Mondale leaned forward in his private compartment and contemplated the well- chewed end of an unlit cigar.

title: Kodak Copiers
description: Canon Inc. will supply the Eastman Kodak Company with medium-volume copying machines bearing the Kodak label and employing new photoconductive materials, the companies announced. Technologies and expertise from each company will be employed in the products, Kodak said. Canon, of Tokyo, is a leading maker of small- and medium-sized copiers, and Kodak makes a line of high-volume copier-duplicators.

title: ANGELS CUT ROYALS' LEAD TO HALF A GAME
description: Mike Witt stopped Kansas City on three hits, and Brian Downing cracked his 21st home run of the season tonight as the California Angels trimmed the Royals' American League West lead to one-half game with a 2-0 victory. Minnesota, which won today, trails by one game.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; EARLY CALL RECONSIDERED
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said yesterday that it is not certain that the next offering of 20-year Treasury bonds will be callable by the Government after five years. Treasury officials said in August that the five-year feature might be introduced with the 20-year bond sale that was to be auctioned next week but that was postponed until Congress increases the debt ceiling.

title: FLORIDA GIRDS FOR IMMEDIATE AND LONG-RANGE FIGHT TO STERN CITRUS DESEASE
description: The pace quickened today in the campaign to close a ring around the spreading mysterious disease that menaces the Florida citrus industry.

title: No Headline
description: Rift Said to Bar Trade Talks PARIS, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -

title: JAZZ: AT 71, VAN EPS PLAYS GUITAR
description: -year-old guitarist George Van Eps has emerged from semiretirement for a rare engagement at Fat Tuesday's, where he is playing duets with the guitarist Tony Rizzi through Sunday.

title: U.S. SAYS IT WON'T RETALIATE NOW
description: The United States today called the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut ''a senseless, brutal attack'' and a reminder that ''civilized norms of behavior are threatened by those who use terrorism as a political weapon.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The ''Amadeus'' premiere ended

title: MONDALE GOADS REAGAN TO SUBMIT ECONOMIC PLANS
description: ''Mr. Reagan, where's the plan?'' Walter F. Mondale challenged today. And thousands of trade unionists added in unison, ''Where's the plan?''

title: BAKER TRIES TO MEDIATE DISPUTE ON SCOPE OF CIVIL RIGHTS BILL
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. sought vainly tonight to work out a compromise on a proposed civil rights measure that would supercede a Supreme Court decision dealing with discrimination.

title: Rose Fines Himself It probably became inevitable as soon as
description: Pete Rose was named player- manager of the Cincinnati Reds last month and now it has happened: The manager has had to fine the player. The $50 penalty was levied after the 4-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday night, in which Pete Rose, the player, failed to heed the third-base coach's warning to stop at the base and was thrown out at home plate by 10 feet. ''That's the first time I've had to do that since I became the manager,'' Rose said later. ''I paid it to me, but it'll really go to charity.''

title: Busy Clinics
description: While the leading athletes of the world were pushing their physical capacities to the limit in quest of medals at the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, a volunteer team of about 500 doctors, nurses, physical therapists and other authorities on health care were on constant duty inside Olympic Village Polyclinics to tend to their medical problems.

title: Talks on Purchase Of Charter Units
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Merrill Lynch & Company and the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. said jointly that they had started ''exploratory negotiations'' to acquire the insurance subsidiaries of the Charter Company.

description: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Sept. 10 214,600 R 216,400 n.a. Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Sept. 12 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) R 37 (8) n.a. Borrowings at Federal Reserve 0 0 n.a.
