title: FERRARO, FACING DEMONSTRATORS COUNTERS WITH A DISPLAY OF WIT
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro faced the most disruptive crowd of her campaign today, and she countered with a blend of quick wit and retorts.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Cafe at Pete's Place, ensconced in the basement of a turn-of-the-century tenement in a jagged-edged neighborhood of the East Village, looks from the outside like little more than a watering hole for the Ninth Precinct station next door. Over the years, this spot has served that function between sporadic restaurant ventures; however, over the last year, new management has turned it into one of the best buys in Italian food in town.

title: Hormone Test Failed
description: Espen Thorsen and Vetle Linge , members of the Norwegian women's quadruple sculls team that finished eighth at the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, have failed hormone tests and were suspended yesterday by the Norwegian Athletic Federation.

title: PERSONAL SAFETY: WHEN GOVERNMENT KNOWS BEST
description: To the Editor:

title: ASHLAND OIL SEES LOSS FROM SALE
description: Ashland Oil Inc. announced yesterday that it would have a one-time, $270 million after-tax loss in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 from the planned sale of non-petroleum businesses it acquired in 1981 and from the closing of an unprofitable methanol venture started in 1979.

title: Deterred by Rain For the second time in 24 hours, rain in Fort Lauderdale has delayed
description: Martina Navratilova's attempt to break a record held by one of the city's favorite sons - or daughters. With 55 consecutive victories in matches, Miss Navratilova has matched an achievement accomplished by Chris Evert Lloyd , who grew up in Fort Lauderdale.

title: BLACK BASS EVENT BY INVITATION ONLY
description: Although well known for its striped

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Electrolux Delays Zanussi Takeover
description: Electrolux A.B. of Sweden has had to put off announcing a takeover of Industrie Zanussi as foreign creditors of the Italian company continue to hold out for improved financial terms, Zanussi's chairman, Gianfranco Zoppas, said.

title: SHOW FROM FRANCE OPENS NEW CENTER FOR AFRICAN ART
description: There's cause for rejoicing this week among those who remember fondly the old Museum of Primitive Art, the small but stellar institution that flourished in New York from 1957 until it became the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Metropolitan Museum. A brand-new facility along the same lines, the Center for African Art, has opened at 54 East

title: Say, 'Arf'
description: The Dog Observed: Photographs 1844-1983,'' an exhibition of more than 100 canine images, is on display through Nov. 30 at the Dog Museum of America, 51 Madison Avenue, at 26th Street (lobby of New York Life Insurance Company.)

title: Ellsworth Bunker in Hospital
description: Ellsworth Bunker, one of America's top diplomatic trouble-shooters for three decades and Ambassador to Saigon at the height of the Vietnam War, was hospitalized in critical condition today. Mr. Bunker, 90 years old, who has a home in Dummerston, Vt., has an undisclosed ailment. He is in Brattleboro Memorial Hospital.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Taking a Seat At the Barricades

title: EQUITABLE LIFE WILL MIX ART AND COMMERCE
description: Public art in the form of an unusually extensive combination of museum shows, sculptures and monumental murals will become the theme of the Equitable Life Assurance Society's new headquarters on Seventh Avenue, company officials said yesterday.

title: AMID THE AGONY OF UGANDA: THE PUZZLE OF OBOTE
description: Recently, President Milton Obote arrived by plane in a small town in the western part of this East African country.

title: U.S. Has Native Aardvark
description: The first aardvark to survive birth at the Philadelphia Zoo, a 3-pound, 15- ounce mammal that zookeepers christened Aarthur, is being cared for by humans because the mother initially ignored her baby, officials said. The Philadelphia Zoo is one of eight in the United States to house aardvarks, the long-nosed pig-like African mammals that eat insects and ants and are known for their digging power.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; Gianettino & Meredith Is Named by Triex
description: Gianettino & Meredith, a favorite among Mountainside, N.J., ad agencies, has become agency for the regional operation of Triex, a company started by the same people who started Century 21. Their aim now is to impart the benefits of national advertising to the used-car business as they did to real estate brokerages.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Algorex Corp., a company engaged in automated design services, announced that Jeffrey J. Waxweiler had resigned as president; Sheldon O. Newman, chairman and chief executive, will assume the office and duties of president.

title: WHAT NEW YORK STANDS TO GAIN FROM A NAVY HOME PORT
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a subheading in a dispatch from Cairo yesterday on Britain's discovery of a mine in the Gulf of Suez misidentified the nations that Egypt suspects may have mined the waterway. They are Iran and Libya. Both have denied the allegations.

title: 2 Chinese Officials Replaced
description: Two Government ministers in key science and economic posts were replaced today in a shake-up requested by Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, the official New China News Agency announced.

title: SPORTS TODAY Baseball
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Sid Fernandez, slumping with a 4-6 record, opens a weekend series by opposing the Expos' young Joe Hesketh. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. The Yankees, who have now surpassed the Mets in winning percentage, meet the American League's Eastern Division champions. Although the Tigers have dominated the league this year, they have managed only a 3-3 split in games with New York. Tonight, they send Milt Wilcox, a 17- game winner, against John Montefusco. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Soccer

title: G.M. AND THE AUTO WORKERS AGREE ON A TENTATIVE NATIONAL CONTRACT
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers union early today tentatively agreed on a new national contract, lifting the threat that local strikes would spread nationwide and affect up to 350,000 G.M. employees, both sides announced.

title: U.N. Chief Calls Beirut Blast 'Criminal and Indiscriminate'
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that the the bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon was a ''criminal and indiscriminate'' act.

title: IMPROPER LOAN BY PORT AUTHORITY CREDIT UNION INVESTIGATED
description: The Manhattan District Attorney is investigating an improper $550,000 loan from the credit union of the Port Authority to John DeLorenzo, a New York real-estate developer, according to authority and credit union officials.

title: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES BUYOUT SET
description: Ben W. Heineman, the energetic entrepreneur who heads Northwest Industries, agreed with the company's directors yesterday to a leveraged buyout offer from an investor group that is valued at more than $1 billion.

title: REAGAN DEPICTS FARM TROUBLES UNDER MONDALE
description: President Reagan defended his farm record today by accusing Walter F. Mondale of preparing a ''one-two punch'' of protectionism and taxation that will mean a ''harvest of hardship'' for farmers.

title: MUSIC TO GO: A GUIDE TO DISK AND TAPE SHOPS
description: AMERICANS bought $3.8 billion worth of recorded music last year - not half bad for a music business that saw itself as barely pulling out of a slump. To judge by the crowds in New York's record stores on weekends, who are looking for anything from Cyndi Lauper or the Nubian oud player Hamza El Din to broadcasts of Maria Callas, Jelly Roll Morton piano-roll transcriptions or dance music by Tabou Combo from Haiti, there's a market for all kinds of music.

title: STATE OFFICIALS IN INDIA WINS A VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: N. T. Rama Rao easily won a vote of confidence in the Andhra Pradesh state assembly today, thereby ratifying his reinstatement this week as Chief Minister of the southern Indian state.

title: A CATHEDRALFUL OF HARP STRINGS
description: IN the past, Wendy Chambers has scored her compositions for such euphonious ensembles as a grouping

title: Australian Leader Cries As He Denies Cover-Up
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke wept in public today as he denied an opponent's charge that he was covering up organized crime.

title: BUSH, IN VERMONT, CONFRONTS ANTINUCLEAR HECKLERS
description: On the Brattleboro Common today, a square of green in the middle of town where people usually come to play chess and listen to music, Vice President Bush learned what an iconoclastic place Brattleboro is in a traditionally Republican state.

title: PUBLISHING: NOVEL'S 2D 'DEBUT' OF '84
description: FRANCESCA STANFILL became a first novelist this week - for the second time this year and with the same book, published by two publishers. It may not be a publishing first, but publishing-industry sources say they cannot recall a similar incident.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from San Francisco Sept. 9 about police reassignments after scandals incorrectly reported the whereabouts of Jeff Brown, the city's public defender, when a bar there named Lord Jim's was raided Aug. 31. Mr. Brown, who later criticized the raid, was in Anaheim, Calif. at the time.

title: Outdated Voting Rules Deplored in U.S. Survey
description: The states ''are still in the dark ages'' in recording data about registered voters, creating obstacles to voting, measuring participation and encouraging people to register, a study published Wednesday said.

title: 'PLACES IN THE HEART,' BENTON'S WAXAHACHIE IN THE DEPRESSION
description: OUT of the memories of his boyhood in Waxahachie, Tex., during the Great Depression, and within the unlikely tradition of the old-fashioned ''mortgage'' melodrama, Robert Benton has made one of the best films in years about growing up American. Its title is ''Places in the Heart,'' which is misleading in its sentimentality, for the film itself, though full of sentiment, demonstrates in every other way the writer-director's built- in junk-detector.

title: GOLDIN CLASHES WITH THE MAYOR ABOUT A LETTER
description: A new dispute over whose signature belongs where - and how much it means to whom - broke out yesterday between the Mayor and the City Comptroller. And the City Council President quickly joined the fray.

title: Continental Illinois Shift
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved a reorganization for the Continental Illinois Corporation that should make it easier for Federal regulators to recover possible losses related to the assistance given the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company.

title: JOHN EWALD, EX-HEAD OF AVON
description: John A. Ewald, former president and chairman of Avon Products, died Monday at a nursing home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 82 years old and had lived in Santa Barbara since his retirement in 1981.

title: 3 DAY-CARE WORKERS INDICTED IN CHILD SEX ABUSE
description: Three employees of a city-financed day-care center in the Bronx have been indicted on charges that they sexually abused children in their care, the Bronx District Attorney said yesterday.

title: INDICTED MAYOR DEMANDS TRIAL BEFORE ELECTION
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, indicted Wednesday on charges of perjury and conspiracy to violate election and financial disclosure laws, said today he would demand a trial before a Nov. 6 runoff election.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KATE QUINTON'S DAYS. By Susan Sheehan. 158 pages. Houghton Mifflin.

title: CONCESSIONS BY SANDINISTAS REPORTED
description: Nicaraguan Government leaders have made substantial concessions in private to their political opponents, according to diplomats and opposition activists.

title: BRITISH LIBERALS WANT MISSILES OUT
description: The annual Liberal Party assembly called today for the removal of American cruise missiles from Britain depite the protests of David Steel, the Liberal leader.

title: No-Contest Plea In Death of Marvin Gaye
description: The father of the singer Marvin Gaye pleaded no contest today to voluntary manslaughter in the shooting death of his son during an argument on April 1.

title: Banks Get Japan Offer
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry said today that it had told three foreign banks they might start dealing in Government bonds under the same conditions as Japanese banks. Citibank, the Bank of America and the Chase Manhattan Bank can start dealing next month if they submit application forms soon, the ministry said.

title: STUDY BY CONGRESS FAULTS UNESCO AND PLACESBLAME ON ITS DIRECTOR
description: A six-month American inquiry into Unesco has drawn a picture of a highly centralized, badly managed organization where power is concentrated in the hands of the Director General, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal.

title: THEATER: 'AVNER THE ECCENTRIC,' A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: Avner Eisenberg, or ''Avner the Eccentric,'' as he bills himself, is every kid's clown. He is a lovable fool with an expressively funny face and a streak of innocent vulgarity - a mischievous child in an adult's body. No wonder he was once arrested in Paris on the charge of buffoonery in public.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY GROUP
description: Following is the text of the statement telephoned to Agence France-Presse today 90 minutes after the explosion at the United States Embassy. The anonymous caller spoke in Arabic and the text was translated by The Associated Press:

title: Dining Out Guide: Town-House Settings
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BOX TREE, 250 East 49th Street (758-8320)

title: A CITY OF SURVIVAL
description: PRAGUE Centuries ago, this achingly beautiful city was at the cultural and political heart of Europe and the Holy Roman Empire. Today it's the sad capital of the most subservient of Soviet satellites, the East bloc country with which the United States has the worst relations - even more acrimonious than with the Soviet Union itself.

title: Longshore Union Chief Endorses Reagan By The Associated Press
description: The president of the International Longshoremen's Association endorsed Ronald Reagan for President yesterday, breaking with the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: PPG Elects Chief, Other Top Officers

title: STATE DEMOCRATS FEAR REAGAN COATTAIL EFFECT
description: As they ring doorbells, stuff mailboxes and shake hands, Democrats in New York State are expressing concern that the strength of President Reagan's re-election drive may translate into help for Republican candidates in close Congressional and legislative races in the state.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Indian Music
description: Two nights of music from southern India will be presented by the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. the veena (long-neck lute) player S. Balanchander will perform with two percussionists; tickets are $10 (Theater Development Fund, plus $5.50). Sunday at 8 P.M., the 14-year-old mandolinist U. Srinivas will perform with a violinist and a percussionist. Tickets are $7 (voucher plus $2.50).

title: CLASSIC SHOWDOWN ON TURF
description: Tomorrow, for the first time, three races worth $500,000 or more will be run on the same day: the $625,250 Turf Classic for older horses on the grass at Belmont Park, the $577,625 Arlington-Washington Futurity for 2-year-olds at Arlington Park near Chicago and the $500,000 Super Derby for 3-year-olds at Louisiana Downs near New Orleans.

title: Chico Freeman to Play
description: The saxophonist Chico Freeman will lead a quintet through Sunday at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: 2D CO-ANCHOR SAYS STATION DISCRIMINATES
description: The television station sued by Christine Craft, its former co-anchor, confirmed today that a second co-anchor had filed a complaint, this one alleging that she was the victim of sexual and racial discrimination.

title: SAM RUBIN'S BIGGEST BET
description: There were these two horseplayers. They became a double

title: 'FLASH' PUTS G.N.P. RISE AT 3.6%
description: The nation's economy seems to be growing at an annual rate of 3.6 percent in the current quarter, barely half its pace of advance during the three months ended June 30, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PANEL REAFFIRMS TV BAN IN COURTS
description: The top policymaking body for the Federal courts today reaffirmed its longstanding prohibition against television and radio coverage of Federal court proceedings.

title: BRIEFS
description: Academy Insurance Group Inc. , an insurance holding company based in Valley Forge, Pa., said its board had decided not to proceed with the proposed sale of the company's 51 percent interest in Pension Insurance Group of America Inc. and other collateral supporting receivables owed by Amason Holding Co. to Academy's former chairman, William M. Allen.

title: LOW-TURNOUT TREND REVERSED IN BUSHWICK
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 EXPELLED FROM SOUTH LEBANON
description: An Israeli Army captain ordered two Associated Press reporters and two correspondents for The Times of London to leave southern Lebanon today under escort by armed militiamen to a crossing point out of occupied territory.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON ARMS BUDGET
description: A compromise was reached today on a military budget that would delay any vote on the production of more MX missiles until next year and would set the 1985 military budget at $292.9 billion. The increase over the current budget would be about 5 percent, after inflation.

title: RIVERDALE ESTATE PROJECT: OBSTACLES ARE OVERCOME
description: At the old Delafield Estate, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, the rock outcroppings that dot the surface of the land are made of nearly fissureless quartz called Manhattan gneiss. It is very difficult to build around, or blast through.

title: ADVERTISING ;
description: Insurer Picks Wells, Rich

title: ARMY OVERPAID MILLIONS TO FORD FOR ANTIAIRCRAFT GUN, AUDIT SAYS
description: The Army paid millions of dollars more than necessary for the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun, partly because the service's contract negotiators had failed to follow Government standards, Pentagon auditors have concluded.

title: BROADEAY;
description: For chess-warfare tale, the pieces are falling into place.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THE most important thing is expressing nuances, and the next thing is finding rhythm.'' Through a translator, the 34-year-old Tokyo-born director Yoshimitsu Morita was discussing the philosophy of film making that has seen him acclaimed as one of the leading lights in a renaissance of Japanese movies.

title: SOVIET GIVES TIMES REPORTER VISA TO COVER CHESS MATCH
description: Harold C. Schonberg, cultural correspondent for The New York Times, has arrived in Moscow after obtaining, on his second application, a visa from the Soviet Embassy in Washington that will enable him to cover the chess tournament in Moscow that began Sept. 10.

title: Murder at the Jefferson
description: Writers of murder mysteries, notably Margaret Truman of late, have often set the scene of their crimes in Washington, more for reasons of reader familiarity than the incidence of local violence. This weekend, however, the plot really thickens as several dozen detective story fans check into the Jefferson Hotel, there to live out an intricate scenario involving at least one murder, a half-dozen local actors and the real intervention of the District of Columbia police.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Refurbished Picnic House For Prospect Park

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF EXHIBITIONS AND EVENTS IN THE MUSEUMS
description: Following are some exhibition and events highlights this weekend at museums in the metropolitan area:

title: No Headline
description: Show on Black Baseball In New Jersey

title: ;  Irvine Names President Of New Planning Unit
description: The Irvine Company, one of the nation's largest land development concerns, said yesterday that it had created a new unit to plan, develop and build industrial, research and high-technology projects. Richard G. Sim was named president and chief operating officer of the unit.

title: G.N.P. ESTIMATE HELPS DOLLAR HIT HIGHS AGAIN
description: The foreign exchange market found yet another excuse to push the dollar to new records yesterday: the Government's ''flash'' estimate for third- quarter economic growth.

title: Hard Bullets, Hard Politics The San Diego police officers who arrived at the McDonald's in which James Huberty slaughtered employees and customers this summer probably felt more secure because of the vests they were wearing. What they didn't know was that most of the bullets the deranged gunman was firing were Czechoslovak imports capable of penetrating police vests.
description: Federal legislation to ban such bullets, which have no legitimate purpose, seems at hand, but snags have developed in both houses of Congress. The case for overcoming them is clear; rarely does Washington get such a practical opportunity to enhance police and public safety.

title: PITFALLS IN MILK MARKETING DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor

title: MUSIC: ROSTAL AND SCHAEFER
description: PETER ROSTAL and Paul Schaefer, who together make up the duo piano team of Rostal and Schaefer, offer a distinctive blend of easy-listening pops and gentle humor. On Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, the duo played through their own arrangements of popular classics by Rossini, Offenbach, Tchaikovsky, Gershwin, Chopin and others, as well as a handful of Beatles hits and selections from such well-known musicals as ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Evita'' and ''West Side Story.''

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Oilers Still Await Turnaround
description: A year ago the Houston Oilers were 0-3, on their way to a 2-14 finish, one of their worst seasons ever.

title: Books Avoirdupois
description: Used books will be selling for 50 cents a pound, magazines for 10 cents each, on Sunday at the central branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, Grand Army Plaza (corner of Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue) in the Park Slope section.

title: Polish Spokesman Rules Out An Improvement in U.S. Ties
description: A Polish Government spokesman today ruled out any improvement in relations with the United States until there was a change in the ''illogical, absurd and unjust'' policies toward Poland.

title: STAGE: 'VIVA VITTORIO!' SHOWS ACTOR'S TRICKS
description: AT 62, Vittorio Gassman has lost none of the charm, intelligence or physical grace that have served his long film career in Italy and Hollywood. The actor's engaging persona is not enough, however, to put over ''Viva Vittorio!'' a thin and amateurishly produced recital that has arrived at Off Broadway's Promenade Theater for a limited run. Although the Promenade is a cozy house well suited to Mr. Gassman's warm, informal style, ''Viva Vittorio!'' would probably play best in a living room filled with the star's nearest and dearest friends.

title: U.S. FORCES IN THE MEDITERRANEAN NOT ALERTED OR ORDERED TO MOVE
description: Defense Department officials said today that United States military forces in the Mediterranean region had not been alerted or ordered to move in response to the bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut.

title: Transactions
description: Purchased the contract of Nate Snell, pitcher, from Charlotte of the Southern League. HOUSTON (NL) - Announced Craig Reynolds, shortstop, signed a three-year contract extension.

title: HECKLERS MAKING THEIR PRESENCE FELT
description: Hecklers have hounded three of the four Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates this week, and the disruptive behavior itself is turning into a campaign issue.

title: No Headline
description: Eleven people, including six state and local public officials, have been indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury investigating the garbage collection industry on Long Island.

title: ; Della Femina, L.G.F.E. Get New Accounts
description: Autumn begins tomorrow, and yesterday, as if on cue, there was a rush of account movement announcements as the advertising community shook off the effects of the lazy days of summer.

title: Hasbro Bradley
description: Hasbro Bradley Inc., the toy manufacturer, said it would close its Chicago plant in December because the facility had not been economical to operate.

title: No Headline
description: Sense of Thirst Found To Diminish With Age

title: The Denny's Buyout Deal
description: Is anything holding up the leveraged buyout of

title: ETHIOPIA CITES REASON FOR DELAY IN AID RELIEF
description: The Ethiopian envoy in Washington said today that the distribution of relief food to avert famine in his country is hampered by congestion at limited dock, warehouse and transport facilities, and not by a lack of cooperation by his government, as United States officials charge.

title: Disneyland Gears for Strike
description: Disneyland officials today trained clerical workers to run the amusement park in the event of a strike as negotiations resumed with five unions representing more than 1,800 employees. The unions' contract expired on Monday but has been extended while negotiations continue.

title: ART: TWO EXHIBITIONS OF WHISTLER PRINTS AT THE MET
description: IF silica were a gas, James Abbott McNeill Whistler might have been a general. At least, that was the view the artist himself took of his failure to identify the mineral correctly in a chemistry oral at West Point and of his summary dismissal from the Military Academy in 1853, at the age of 19.

title: No Headline
description: Seat-Belt Legislation Advances in Trenton

title: NIEKRO WEIGHS FUTURE
description: Phil Niekro, approaching the end of the baseball season homesick and injured, is unsure about whether he will return to the Yankees next season.

title: Pillsbury Net Up by 11.8%
description: The Pillsbury Company today reported an 11.8 percent increase in net income for the first quarter of its 1985 fiscal year.

title: Memorial Tribute Is PlannedFor Capote at Noon Tuesday
description: A memorial tribute to Truman Capote will be held at noon Tuesday at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street.

title: DANCE: HUMAN STEPS FROM CANADA
description: dance choreographer from Montreal, brought his company, La La La Human Steps, to Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater Wednesday night. The 90-minute New York premiere he is presenting through Sunday afternoon is entitled ''Businessman in the Process of Becoming an Angel.''

title: Prices Rise in Denmark
description: Danish wholesale prices rose four- tenths of 1 percent last month from July and were up 6.6 percent from August 1983, the Government said today.

title: POPE, LEAVING CANADA, DEPLORES HEDONISM
description: Pope John Paul II ended his 12-day visit to Canada today with a denunciation of the ''generalized tendency to hedonism.''

title: Biogen Planning Interferon in '85
description: Biogen S.A. expects the first government approvals for its alpha interferon anticancer drug, for which the Schering- Plough Corporation holds a production and marketing license, to be granted early next year. Biogen's chief executive, Walter Gilbert, said the drug was expected to be authorized for use during 1985 in the United States and a number of European countries.

title: TURNING THE SENATE AWAY FROM TRIVIAL PURSUITS
description: When the Senate talks, is anyone listening?

title: THE CITY ; ;  Antenna Removal Lacked Approval
description: The owners of the Empire State Building should have submitted an application for permission before they removed a section of the television antenna atop the building, a spokesman for the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission said yesterday.

title: THE 'FATHEAD' EQUATION IN NON-VOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: RICHARD PRYOR IS BACK IN A SERIES FOR CHILDREN
description: IT'S surprising to find Richard

title: AS LEAVES START TO FALL, STREET FAIRS START TO RISE
description: As the air becomes cooler and the afternoons clear, the thoughts of New Yorkers turn to strolling the streets and avenues. This weekend, four of the city's best street fairs, the Columbus Avenue Festival, the Flatbush Frolic, the 52d Street Fair and the Washington Square Park Arts, Crafts and Antiques Fair, are hoping to be able to take advantage of crisp autumn weather.

title: Continental Group Sale to Kiewit
description: Continental Group Inc. said it expects its $2.75 billion acquisition by the Kiewit-Murdoch Investment Corporation to be completed within 10 days of its stockholders meeting next Wednesday.

title: MARCOS SAYS HE MAY DIFFER WITH MILITARY ACCOUNT OF AQUINO DEATH
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that while the Philippine military says that a lone gunman hired by Communists killed the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., ''I did not say that was my opinion.''

title: Hinkle Posts a 68
description: Lon Hinkle, a nonwinner for five years, compiled the lowest 36-hole score of the year and maintained his lead today through the second round of the Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational, Hinkle, who shot 68 today, completed the first two rounds of the five-day, 90-hole event with a score of 130. That is 11 shots under par and three shots ahead of Corey Pavin. But since the tournament, which offers $1,122,500 in total prizes, is being played on four courses, with three different pars, Hinkle has an under-par edge of only two on Andy Bean and Denis Watson.

title: ALICE COLTRANE'S FIRST CONCERTS HERE IN 7 YEARS
description: JOHN COLTRANE'S music seemed to be in a continual state of flux. The virtuosic saxophonist was the most influential jazz stylist of the 1960's, but he kept searching out new horizons, challenging himself and his limits. His death in 1967, at the age of 40, left his followers wondering what new realms he would have explored had he lived.

title: MUSIC: STRING QUARTET
description: THE Mendelssohn String Quartet roared through its program of Mendelssohn and Schoenberg at the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night with an enthusiasm, a confidence and a sense of adventure which, taken together, describe youth at its best.

title: I.B.M. GETS AN OUTSIDE SALES FORCE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which has been using its own salesmen to sell its emerging factory-automation equipment, announced yesterday that it would begin using a nationwide network of outside distributors as well.

title: 13-YEAR-OLD PLAYS TENNIS LIKE A PRO
description: The idea was first broached to the promoters of the $150,000 Lynda Carter-Maybelline Tennis Classic, now being played at the Bonaventure Racquet Club in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in a local newspaper article. It suggested that 13- year-old Mary Jo Fernandez be invited to play in a field that included Martina Navratilova.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Cascade Natural Gas Corp. , Seattle, said ratings on senior subordinated debentures due in 1993 had been raised to Baa3, from Ba2, by Moody's.

title: ALI'S IMPROVEMENT IS CALLED IMPRESSIVE
description: Muhammad Ali signed autographs, chatted with friends and entertained nurses, visitors and fellow patients with magic tricks yesterday as doctors at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center continued to speak positively of the progress the former champion was making in his struggle with Parkinson's syndrome.

title: Free Concert
description: A free concert of Jewish klezmer music by the Andy Statman Klezmer Orchestra will take place Sunday at 6:45 at the Promenade on Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn. In case of rain, the concert will be at the Kane Street Synagogue, 236 Kane Street, off Court Street. More information: 420-1150.

title: COLT FORTYSIX WINS LITTLE BROWN JUG
description: Colt Fortysix led from start to finish in the first heat and the race-off today to capture the 39th Little Brown Jug, the second race in the triple crown series for 3-year-old pacers.

title: Japan Revises G.N.P. View
description: Japan's economy is expected to grow at the fastest pace in five years during the fiscal year 1984, amid surging exports and higher corporate spending on newer plants and equipment, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Moore in Brooklyn
description: A tribute to the sculptor Henry Moore is planned Sunday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. Tours of the grounds where five Moore sculptures have been temporarily installed will be given at 1:30 and 2:30 P.M. In the auditorium, a short film about Moore will be shown at 1, 2, 3 and 3:30 P.M. Admission is by contribution. Information: 622-4433.

title: CHRISTIAN MILITIA GUARDED EMBASSY
description: The area around the United States Embassy that was bombed today was guarded by Lebanese Christian militiamen because a contingent of 80 United States marines had been withdrawn seven weeks earlier, American officials said.

title: CUT AIR FARES AREN'T THE RULE
description: Although the nation's major airlines are making a big noise in slashing prices on some of their heavily traveled routes, they are quietly raising prices on a number of other runs.

title: French Troops Prepare To Withdraw From Chad
description: French troops have ceased all military operations in Chad and have begun preparing for a withdrawal scheduled to start next week under an agreement with Libya, French military sources said today.

title: Praying for Cubs
description: Among the most ardent fans of the Chicago Cubs this summer have been seven Sisters of the Good Shepherd whose House of the Good Shepherd convent is located less than two blocks from Wrigley Field and has parking for more than 200 cars.

title: Chinese Trade Step
description: China has approved new measures that free national import-export corporations from administrative control by state boards. The action is part of an effort to further smooth international trade, the New China News Agency said today.

title: Saarinen Signs
description: The Rangers announced the signing of 21-year-old Simo Saarinen , the 5-foot-10-inch, 170-pound Finnish defenseman they chose in the 10th round of the 1982 amateur draft. Saarinen played on Finland's bronze-medal- winning squad in the 1982 world junior championships and was an all-star in that tournament last December.

title: Race for the Movies
description: More than 100 bicyclists will be pedaling for cash and for the cameras at the 100-kilometer Manufacturers Hanover challenge on Sunday in Brooklyn's Prospect Park.

title: POP: DIANA ROSS SHOW
description: GLAMOUR, the aura of sanctified narcissism exalted by 1950's movie magazines, has made a big comeback of late thanks to performers such as Diana Ross. The star, who opened an 11- show engagement at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday, distills that elusive mixture of beauty and cultivated charm in its most concentrated form. In her new show, which features several stunning costume changes, music plays second fiddle to images of the star modeling various glittering gowns and jump suits.

title: IN CAPITAL, LEGISLATORS CALL FOR MORE SECURITY
description: Congressional reaction to the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut today ranged from criticism of security measures to calls for stronger efforts to eradicate international terrorism.

title: Florida Bank Takeover Set
description: Federal banking officials today approved a plan allowing the Barnett Bank of Jacksonville to take over the Century National Bank, which had been declared insolvent.

title: MANILA SIGNS I.M.F. LETTER
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that his Government's long negotiations with the International Monetary Fund had been completed successfully, and he predicted that the I.M.F. would sign an agreement to supply badly needed standby credits for the Philippines next month.

title: Decency, at Last, for the Disabled The House and Senate agreement to reform the disastrously mismanaged Social Security disability program should mark the beginning of the end of an ugly policy failure.
description: The program, whose cost ran up to $18 billion, supports people too sick or crippled to work for a living. Alarmed by documented cases of fraud, the Carter Administration set up a sensible plan for reviewing beneficiaries. But the Reagan Administration seized on the review to slash spending. It increased the pace of review and tightened the eligibility rules, a policy that led to indiscriminate, wholesale termination of benefits. The assumption was that those who truly deserved support would regain it in an arduous appeals process.

title: E.PA. WILL RE-INVESTIGATE 13 DISPUTED PESTICIDES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency settled a lawsuit by agreeing today to re-investigate possible threats to health from 13 pesticides it had earlier licensed after closed meetings with the chemicals' makers.

title: No Headline
description: City Investing Liquidation WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

title: ADMINISTRATION URGES AN INCREASE IN BENEFITS
description: Reagan Administration officials today urged the House to approve a cost-of- living increase for Social Security recipients, even though inflation is likely to rise by less than the amount needed to trigger the extra payments.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: a smart, slightly overdone restaurant devoted exclusively to creatures of the sea becomes as popular as a steakhouse. Less than a year old, the Manhattan Ocean Club on West 58th Street is playing to large crowds, despite high prices and some inconsistencies.

title: 'WINDY CITY'
description: ''GOD knows, we were dreamers,'' recalls the hero of ''Windy City'' in voice- over. ''Everybody was gonna be somebody - me, I was gonna be a great writer.'' In fact, Danny (John Shea) does write a book by the film's end, a tome entitled ''All the Sad Young Men,'' chronicling the rueful good times of Danny and his childhood buddies, who call themselves the Rogues. ''You and me, we could've been the kind of guys they write about in books,'' one Rogue tells another midway through the story.

title: JOHNSON FINDS SECOND BEST IS JUST THAT
description: The Mets, a losing club for nearly two months, took the day off yesterday to prepare for the final nine games of the season while Manager Dave Johnson contemplated the glory of finishing second, and found none.

title: Man Who Left Mother Weds
description: Danny James Bass, who left his first wife after learning she was his mother, has married again in an attempt to ''to get his life together,'' his lawyer said today. Mr. Bass' marriage to his mother gained widespread attention when it became public last week at Mrs. Bass' arraignment on criminal incest charges in Dickson County.

title: Dow Rises by 3.53 In Active Trading
description: The stock market, which has been under pressure since Tuesday, rose slightly yesterday in slower but still active trading.

title: ;  Citicorp Affiliate Mortgage Bonds
description: The Citicorp Homeowners Mortgage Acceptance Corporation is offering $340 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: LIMITATIONS OF INQUIRY
description: An independent counsel's report today finding no basis for prosecuting Edwin Meese 3d underscored the limitations of any independent counsel's mandate and the work that will remain for the Senate if Mr. Meese is renominated for Attorney General. Jacob A. Stein, the independent counsel, stressed that his only function was to determine whether Mr. Meese had committed any Federal crime. His report politely rebuffed requests both by Senate Democrats and by Mr. Meese's attorneys that he pass judgment on Mr. Meese's ethics and sense of propriety.

title: Teller Machine Ruling Fought
description: Representatives of credit unions, food stores, bank card holders, savings and loan associations and the Consumers Union urged Congress today to block a judge's ruling they feel will halt the spread of automated teller machines.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:BetterPlayersThinkMore, Especially at Start of Game

title: Failed Bank Reopens
description: The Bank of Verdigre and Trust Company, the second Nebraska bank to close in two weeks, reopened today as a branch of the National Bank of Neligh. When the Verdigre bank was shut down by the state on Wednesday, it became the second commercial Nebraska bank to close this month and the 58th to fail nationwide this year.

title: ;  People
description: * Scott Wallace named executive vice president of D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide.

title: Liberia Dismisses a Minister Who Referred to Dictatorship
description: Gen. Samual K. Doe, the Liberian leader, has dismissed Information Minister G. V. Kromah for persistently referring to the establishment of a one-party dictatorship, the Monrovia Radio said today.

title: OF MUSIC, ART AND APPLES UPRIVER
description: Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik,'' played in the composer's original five movements, instead of the usual four, is a highlight of a busy weekend of activities in the Hudson Valley this weekend. The setting is the Catamount Ski Center at Hillsdale in Columbia County, where the Clarion Music Society opens its annual ''Leaf Peeper'' series tomorrow night at 7:30, although the leaves are only beginning to turn. The concert will be conducted by Newell Jenkins.

title: No Headline
description: Way Is Clear for U.S. To Copy Town Statue

title: PERSONAL SAFETY: WHEN GOVERNMENT KNOWS BEST
description: To the Editor:

title: MATTERS OF HONOR; Hudson Pact New York and New Jersey have settled the feud that has been delaying passage of the Clean Water reauthorization by Congress. The casus belli was a tight cap on New York's sewage effluent proposed by Representative James Howard of New Jersey. Resolution was achieved when Mr. Howard consented to make the cap no tighter than the city could wear without a headache. Why would Mr. Howard want to give the city a headache? New York, to its shame, daily dumps 220 million gallons of raw sewage into the Hudson and East Rivers. But it has two big sewage treatment plants under construction, due to come on line in 1986 and 1987. Perhaps Mr. Howard feared the schedule would slip, as it has twice already. But construction is now six months ahead of schedule. He's agreed that sewage doesn't have to be limited until the date the plants are meant to open.
description: What was the fuss all about? If it weren't for the Hudson, New York City and its New Jersey environs might consider themselves part of the same community, each with a stake in the other's welfare.

title: Alumax Cutback
description: Alumax Inc., an Amax Inc. affiliate, said it plans to reduce aluminum ingot production by about 40,000 short tons at its three primary reduction plants in Maryland, South Carolina and Washington. It said it would consider idling additional capacity if warranted.

title: MATTERS OF HONOR; Air Force Cheats
description: The honor system that has now broken down at the Air Force Academy, as it previously did at West Point and Annapolis, is a most brutal form of discipline. Dispensing with monitors at examinations and locks on the doors, it requires cadets to offer their careers as surety that they'll not stray into dishonesty.

title: 19 ARE WOUNDED IN VENEZUELA AS POLICE FIRE ON STUDENTS
description: At least 16 students and 3 national guardsmen were wounded when guardsmen fired at five buses carrying students to a planned protest in Caracas, a Government statement said.

title: ASSERTING INNOCENCE, CONVICT DIES IN FLORIDA ELECTRIC CHAIR
description: James Dupree Henry, trembling and professing innocence, died in the electric chair today for the murder of an 81- year-old man in a robbery.

title: STEVE MARTIN IN 'ALL OF ME'
description: SOME things simply have to be seen to be believed, and the sensational teamwork of Steve Martin and Lily Tomlin in ''All of Me'' is one of them. If this, the best American comedy since ''Tootsie,'' doesn't have you in stitches, check your vital signs: you may be in as much trouble as Edwina Cutwater, the dying dowager Miss Tomlin plays. Edwina is expiring fast as the movie begins, and she is about to embark on a master plan whereby she will leave her own body and inhabit a much prettier one.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL ON CHARGES AGAINST MEESE
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the independent counsel, Jacob A. Stein, concerning Edwin Meese 3d:

title: ARGENTINE REPORT ASSAILS 'SAVAGE' ARMY
description: A Government panel of inquiry gave President Raul Alfonsin a major report tonight on the military's campaign against subversives in the 1970's, calling it the most savage event in Argentine history.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I heard a burst of shooting and saw the skid marks and then the lights went out.''

title: 100 Feared Drowned in India
description: Nearly 100 passengers were feared drowned near the border between Nepal and India after an overcrowded wooden boat capsized during the weekend in the Rapti River in Nepal, the Indian news agency Press Trust of India reported today. The river had been swollen by monsoons. There was no immediate comment by Nepalese authorities.

title: HOMOSEXUAL STUDY CITES HORMONE LINK
description: A group of homosexual men has been found to have a hormone-response pattern midway between that of heterosexual men and heterosexual women, according to a study published yesterday. The pattern suggests, but does not prove, that a biological factor may play a role in the development of homosexuality in some men.

title: ONCE AGAIN, A BLAST, A CALL AND DEATH
description: Again, the slabs of concrete wall hanging limply, the rawboned young marines in their flak jackets tensely clutching their M-16's too late, the Red Cross workers digging into the rubble.

title: AUCTIONS
description: EMERY MAY HOLDEN NORWEB, who was known as the grande dame of Cleveland society and was the only woman ever to serve as president of the Cleveland Museum of Art, became a coin collector at the age of 8, when her father gave her a rare early American cent. Until her death at 88 in March, Mrs. Norweb pursued coins, acquiring with a connoisseur's eye, specimens from 50 B.C. through the 1980's. Over the years, she also assembled formidable holdings in Pre- Columbian art and period paperweights.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 21, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Help for Anemic Africa The global recession is over for most of the industrial world. Not for Africa. In the vast sweep of poor nations south of the Sahara, anemic levels of output and income continue to shrink. And a drought of historic severity, the worst of this century in parts of eastern Africa, explains only a part of the crisis.
description: A new analysis by the World Bank concludes that these desperate societies need dramatic internal reforms and sharp increases in aid. Without both, there looms the ''specter of disaster.'' The bank's report will be presented to the annual meeting of its 147 member countries next week. But American officials are grumbling that the member that can help the most is already doing enough.

title: AN AUTHORITY IN TYPOGRAPHY
description: J. Ben Lieberman, an authority on printing and typography, died of a heart attack Wednesday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: CITRUS GROWERS JOLTED AS CANKER THREATENS THEIR LIVELIHOOD
description: Bill Hancock is 6 feet tall and weighs 242 pounds. He played semipro football and jumped out of airplanes in the Army. No man has ever frightened him.

title: NO PROGRESS SEEN
description: Two weeks of talks between Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders ended here today without any apparent progress, but further discussions were scheduled for Oct. 15.

title: FIRE IN NEWARK KILLS 3 PEOPLE IN A TENEMENT
description: Three people were killed and nine were injured in an apartment-house fire here that forced some residents to leap out of windows onto mattresses taken to the scene by neighbors, officials said today.

title: G.I.'s Honored in Grenada
description: A bronze monument to the 19 American servicemen killed in the invasion of Grenada last Oct. 25 will be unveiled at St. George's University School of Medicine on the first anniversary of the landing here, Arthur Massolo, public relations director of the school, said today. He said a six-foot bronze scroll carrying reproductions of the signatures of the 19 men was jointly commissioned by the institution and the school's Association of Parents.

title: Exchange Rate Issue
description: The House Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy today failed to approve a resolution calling on the President to consider limited intervention in exchange markets as part of a program to assure a stable exchange rate for the dollar. The resolution called on the President to withdraw the Administration's current policy of nonintervention in exchange markets and to explore the possibilities for constructive limited intervention.

title: MET $6 MILLION IN RED
description: The Metropolitan Opera ended the 1984 fiscal year with a loss of nearly $6 million after contributions, according to a budget report presented to the company's board yesterday.

title: A SAUDI VESSEL IS DAMAGED BY EXPLOSION IN GULF OF SUEZ
description: A Saudi-registered merchant ship was damaged today, apparently by a mine, in the Gulf of Suez just south of the Suez Canal, Egyptian and shipping sources said.

title: HEADING OFF HARD TIMES
description: The adverse effects of this country's huge

title: Good News in the Mail
description: The unholy economic alliance

title: Money Funds Continue Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 335 money market mutual funds jumped for the second consecutive week, reaching their highest level in 18 months, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Elmore Retires All
description: Len Elmore had needed to make his retirement from the Knicks a certainty was a notification that he had been accepted to Harvard Law School. It came recently, and so, after 10 pro seasons, Elmore, a 32- year-old forward and center, has begun to pursue the law career he often talked about.

title: 3 Players Have Much in Common
description: Carmen Cozza's Yale football team will open the season tomorrow against Brown at Providence, R.I., with three quarterbacks named Mike in the starting offensive lineup.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: There's No Business Like Koch Business

title: SOUTH LEBANON MILITIAMEN SAID TO KILL 13 SHITES
description: Militiamen of the South Lebanon Army killed 13 residents of a Shiite Moslem village near the Syrian border today, Israeli officials reported.

title: 'UNTIL SEPTEMBER'
description: IT all begins when Mo Alexander (Karen Allen), a perky American from the Midwest, misses her flight out of Paris. Through a series of coincidences too perfect for close scrutiny, this denim-clad vagabond winds up in the posh apartment of a former schoolmate named Chantal. Chantal, like every other serious Parisian, is out of town for her August vacation. So are the wife and children of Chantal's next-door neighbor, Xavier de la Perouse (Thierry Lhermitte). Xavier has an even fancier apartment and just happens to be the best-looking, best-dressed Frenchman this side of Louis Jourdan.

title: THIS BROWN FOR HIRE
description: Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, has offered his services as a campaigner for Democratic candidates in a dozen states in October. Mr. Brown, it will be recalled, was a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination himself in 1976, in an unsuccessful effort to derail Jimmy Carter, and again briefly in 1980. Most of the states he has selected for 1984 stumping are likely to be major stops on the Democratic primary circuit in 1988, places like Iowa, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Florida and Illinois.

title: Bid by Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation said it is bidding for a contract to build 99,150 lightweight delivery trucks for the Postal Service over an eight-year period starting in 1986, with the General Motors Corporation to serve as a major subcontractor. Grumman, based in Bethpage, L.I., would manufacture aluminum truck bodies for the vehicles, while G.M. would supply steel chassis understructures, including engines and transmissions.

title: HONORING OVER-30 SCHOLARS
description: At the age of 41, Nancy Halloran Hutter decided she wanted to go to college. She got her bachelor's degree, then went on to the Villanova Law School. Today she is a lawyer for the City Council in Philadelphia.

title: Steinbrenner Cleared
description: Marshall Criser , the president of the University of Florida, headed to Mission, Kan., with some other school officials yesterday to appear before the National Collegiate Athletic Association's committee on infractions over all those violations in the Florida football program. But before departing Gainesville, Criser held a news conference dealing with the school's response to the N.C.A.A.'s letter of inquiry, and among the names that came up was that of George Steinbrenner , the Yankee owner.

title: PANEL REFUSES TO BLOCK PARKWAY TO CARTER LIBRARY
description: For more than two years, plans to build an access highway to Jimmy Carter's proposed Presidential library here have been caught up in a bitter dispute that has locked the former President in a feud with a group of neighborhood activists.

title: Impact of Pap Test Measured
description: Pap smear tests taken regularly are so effective they have cut the incidence of cervical cancer two-thirds among women who had at least one screening in 10 years, a Swedish study finds.

title: Begin Has Operation And Is 'Feeling Well'
description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin underwent successful surgery today for removal of his prostate gland.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $7.8 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced an unusually large $7.8 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, to $552.7 billion, but the rise was so widely anticipated that it had only a slight effect on interest rates.

title: PADRES WIN BY 5-4, CLINCH FIRST TITLE
description: The San Diego Padres clinched their first divisional title today after a frustrating 15 years in which they had never finished higher than fourth place in the National League West.

title: Earth to Rawhide
description: 3850The mantle of espionage, not surprisingly, rarely seems to fit

title: MINING 113a: PAVLOV FOR POETS
description: Reporters who have covered the United Mine Workers over the years have grown accustomed to hearing the union viewpoint expressed with the directness of a pickax blow, adorned only by an occasional coalfield aphorism or expletive.

title: Whooping Cough Hits 200 in Washington State
description: Health officials are puzzled by an unexpectedly severe whooping cough epidemic that has hit the Seattle, Wash., area.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: An Honor for the Folk In Basic Blue

title: CORRECTION
description: A report by The Associated Press in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the Columbia-Harvard football game tomorrow incorrectly described ticket availability. Columbia said yesterday that tickets had not sold out and were still for sale at the campus ticket office and that at least 300 would be available at the Baker Field gates starting at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Hong Kong Plan Endorsed
description: The British Cabinet endorsed a draft agreement today that covers the transfer of sovereignty over Hong Kong to China in 1997. Cabinet members recommended that the agreement be initialed in Peking next week.

title: U.S. SAID TO KNOW LITTLE ABOUT GROUP DESPITE INCREASED INTELLIGENCE EFFORTS
description: The United States knows little about the terrorist group that took responsibility today for the car bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: ENVOY ON THE FIRING LINE
description: On Oct. 23, 1983, one day after he arrived to assume his post as the new United States Ambassador to Lebanon, Reginald Bartholomew pulled up at what was left of the Marine garrison in a steel-plated limousine amid the chaos caused by the terrorist bombing. For many of the reporters in Beirut it was the first glimpse they had had of the new envoy, who was surrounded by a phalanx of Lebanese and United States security guards as he surveyed the results of the bombing, in which 241 American servicemen were killed.

title: A WORLD OF DANCE UNDER ONE SOHO ROOF
description: Julie West was lying on the gray carpeting in a hallway of the Pineapple Dance Center, the city's newest and largest dance studio, her hands behind her leotard-clad calves, struggling to stretch her legs.

title: BLAST KILLS DRIVER
description: A suicide car bomber raced through a hail of gunfire today and devastated the United States Embassy here, killing at least 23 people and wounding scores.

title: ASSEMBLING CUNNINGHAM'S 'EVENTS'
description: The other day after a rehearsal, Cathy Kerr, Patricia Lent, Neil Greenberg and Chris Komar - all members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company - started talking about ''Events.'' They recalled ''Events'' in museums, armories, gymnasiums and city plazas. ''Events'' in vast theaters and ''Events'' in spaces no bigger than a living room. And then there was the ''Event'' on an outdoor stage, where the dancers rehearsed during the day in boiling heat, only to find it was so cold at night that their feet went numb.

title: Bill to Allow Cancer Patients To Use Heroin Loses in House
description: The House of Representatives has defeated a bill that would have allowed the use of heroin to treat the pain of dying cancer patients for whom no other drugs proved effective.

title: No Headline
description: Trade Powers Bill Advances WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

title: ACCORD SEEMS NEARON TERMS FOR NORTH KOREA TO AID SOUTH
description: After several turnabouts and unexpected moves, North and South Korea appeared today to have settled their differences on how the North could send relief supplies to flood victims in the South.

title: Blue Note Twin Bill
description: The singer Bobby McFerrin, with a group featuring John Scofield on guitar, is sharing a double bill at the Blue Note (475-8592), 131 West Third Street, with the trumpeter Jon Faddis's quintet, including Ron Carter on bass. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., tonight through Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: Avant-Garde Jazz
description: This weekend, avant-garde jazz with a sense of theatrics comes to Irving Plaza (477-3728), 17 Irving Place, at East 15th Street. Tonight, the pianist Sun Ra will lead his Solar Arkestra big band, with the rock band Barrence Whitfield and the Savages opening at 11 P.M. Tomorrow, the Art Ensemble of Chicago celebrates the beginning of its third decade as a group with two concerts, at 8 and 11:30 P.M. The ensemble includes Joseph Jarman and Roscoe Mitchell on saxophones, clarinets and flutes; Lester Bowie on trumpet, Malachi Favors on bass and Don Moye on percussion. Tickets, $12 each.

title: THE REGION ; ;  Judge Rules Out Overgrown Yard
description: A self-described environmentalist whose neighbors complained because his front yard was overgrown with weeds and wildflowers up to six feet tall was ordered today to remove the foliage or face a $50-a-day fine.

title: Article 218062 -- No Title
description: A 20-year-old man from North Massapequa, L.I., left permanently paralyzed by a pole-vaulting accident three years ago has won a $5 million out-of-court settlement.

title: No Headline
description: Three hundred thirty-four people were arrested yesterday near schools in the city for selling or possessing drugs as the first step in an expanded effort by police and school officials to curb drug abuse by students.

title: ADVERTISING ; ; Casa Lupita Chain To Geer, DuBois
description: Geer, DuBois, the advertising home of Peak Freans cookies, has gotten considerably more to nibble on: the Casa Lupita chain of Mexican family restaurants started by Ponderosa Inc. of Dayton, Ohio.

title: AT CAMP 'HILTON,' VIETNAMESE LEARN WAYS OF U.S.
description: When Diep Hai Ki mentions San Diego, his weathered face lights up. Mr. Diep, 64 years old, a Vietnamese refugee, has never seen San Diego - or, for that matter, any part of the United States.

title: JUSTIN J. McCARTHY
description: Justin J. McCarthy, a lawyer who had served as chairman of the Legislative Bill Drafting Commission, died Monday at his home here. He was 50 years old.

title: FIRST WOMAN SLAIN ON DUTY
description: A Transit Authority police officer who was last seen chasing a robbery suspect yesterday afternoon was found shot to death three hours later in a vacant lot in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,097,000 for the quarter and $2,980,000 for the year and a gain of $22,193,000 for the quarter and year for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses of $72,000 for the quarter and $1,088,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: No Headline
description: Chevron Units Draw Kuwaitis A Chevron spokesman said

title: THE CITY ; ;  Jury Is Still Out In Omega 7 Trial
description: The jury in the Omega 7 terrorist trial deliberated for the fourth day yesterday without reaching a verdict in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Quotable Berra
description: Yogi Berra received a surprise of sorts yesterday.

title: INSURING HOME COMPUTERS
description: With some 10 million personal computers in American homes, and the number continuing to grow, insurance protection specifically written for computers has become an important consideration for many owners.

title: Looking Back On Decker's Fall
description: Maricica Puica would love to give Mary Decker another chance. But it won't happen today. The Rumanian runner, who won the women's 3,000- meter race in which Miss Decker fell at the Los Angeles Olympic Games, is one of the favorites today in the 5th Avenue Mile.

title: A MESSAGE FROM NEW YORK CITY'S BLACK VOTERS
description: Ever since the Rev. Jesse Jackson's startling showing in the New York primary last April, local politicans, both black and white, have been wondering what his popularity - and his voter registration campaign - would mean for their efforts to appeal to New York City's black voters. The Democratic primaries here this month provided one answer to their questions, bitterly disappointing three blacks challenging white incumbents in predominantly black districts.

title: GOV. HUNT, DON'T PLAY POLITICS WITH LIFE
description: Ever since the Rev. Jesse Jackson's startling showing in the New York primary last April, local politicans, both black and white, have been wondering what his popularity - and his voter registration campaign - would mean for their efforts to appeal to New York City's black voters. The Democratic primaries here this month provided one answer to their questions, bitterly disappointing three blacks challenging white incumbents in predominantly black districts.

title: LETTER: ON EXPORTS
description: AMERICAN DRUGS TO SAVE LIVES ABROAD

title: THE TRIAL THAT SHOULD NOT HAVE BEEN
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE WAY WE WERE New York, between 1790 and 1815, was only the city at the south end of Manhattan, but even then it was a giant of a town, the biggest in the growing young nation. There were 96,000 people working to make it the shipping and mercantile center that had been its destiny from its founding. It was also during this period that the New-York Historical Society was founded, in 1804.

title: Stable Buys Back Share in Ill Colt
description: Windfield Farm in Maryland has agreed to buy back a half interest in an ailing colt purchased for $8.5 million at the July Selected Yearling Sale at Keeneland, Charles Taylor, president of Windfield Farm, said in an announcement issued from the track Friday.

title: PIANO: DEGAETANO IN RECITAL
description: According to the biography in the program of his piano recital Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House, Robert DeGaetano has had a curious career. Born in 1952 and a graduate of the Juilliard School, he studied with Alexis Weissenberg and, more exotically, with Sviatoslav Richter.

title: PATENTS ;
description: Producing Anti-Cancer Chemicals Synthetically

title: GENERAL MOTORS AND UNION REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation reached agreement early today on a tentative three-year contract providing wage increases, added pension benefits and job security.

title: REAGAN REPORTED READY TO PRESS GROMYKO FOR CABINET-LEVEL TALKS
description: President Reagan, in an effort to break the deadlock in arms-control negotiations, will propose to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko next week that the United States and the Soviet Union step up their contacts through more Cabinet- level meetings, Administration officials said today.

title: PERCY ORDERS AN INQUIRY INTO EMBASSY SECURITY
description: The Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today ordered an investigation into whether ''all necessary precautions'' had been taken to prevent the bombing Thursday of the United States Embassy in Lebanon.

title: OFFICIALS SAY STATE AND DEFENSE DEPTS. DIDN'T COORDINATE SECURITY
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will investigate the embassy bombing. Walter F. Mondale accused the Administration of allowing security lapses. Page 4.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1984
description: The Economy

title: REWARDING FAITHFUL (AND GOOD) CUSTOMERS
description: About a month ago a select group of Neiman- Marcus customers around the country received a hand-delivered basket filled with caviar, wine and other fancy foods. Tucked inside was a note from Richard Marcus, chairman and chief executive officer of the 21-store company thanking the customers - all of whom had spent at least $3,000 at the stores over the previous year - for their loyalty and their business.

title: Conservatives Reject Percy, Back Libertarian for Senate
description: Rejecting Senator Charles H. Percy as a ''partisan Democrat in Republican's clothing,'' a group of conservatives today endorsed the Libertarian candidate for the Illinois Republican's seat.

title: Senate Seeks Restraints On Election Projections
description: The Senate joined the House today in calling for voluntary restraints on election projections and the polling of voters as they leave voting places.

title: Baptism of Jewish Boy, 7, Is Annulled in Miami
description: The baptism of a 7-year-old Jewish boy involved in a custody battle between his parents has been annulled by the Roman Catholic Church, and a priest said it appeared to be the first such case on record.

title: T. EDWARD KARLSSON
description: -Svea, the country's oldest Swedish-American newspaper, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Iranians Accuse Swede Of Favoring U.S. Claims
description: Two Iranian judges who hit a Swedish fellow judge this month at the tribunal settling American and Iranian financial claims defended their actions today and accused the Swede of favoring American claimants.

title: No Headline
description: Net at Federal Express Down MEMPHIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -

title: ADVANCED TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-The comparative year-ago results were not available because the company went public in December 1983.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL REALIGNED
description: The watchword in high school football this season seems to be realignment as officials throughout the region attempt to achieve parity and competitive play.

title: The Theory and Reality of Parking
description: Few malfunctions of city life so deaden its quality as loss of mobility on its streets. In central New York today, subways repel, buses move like glaciers and auto traffic has reached unprecedented levels. The coils of congestion squeeze the joy and vitality out of the city.

title:
PATENTS;
MAKING COMPUTER CHIPS
description: WASHINGTON

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May and a 5 percent stock dividned paid in August.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BUSH'S STAID JOURNEY ON CAMPAIGN PATH
description: At the start of Vice President Bush's campaign week, reporters covering him found themselves waiting in a sunny Fort Lauderdale restaurant with a vista of palm trees and azure sky. Mr. Bush, playing one of his frequent roles in this campaign, encouraging Republican supporters at fund-raising events, was ensconced in an upstairs reception room.

title: BOMB ATTACK IN LEBANON: CONFUSION OVER CASUALITIES
description: There was confusion today over the number of dead and wounded in the suicide car- bomb attack against the United States Embassy on Thursday, with Lebanese and American officials offering widely varying figures.

title: Coroner Rules Gaynor Death Was Result of '82 Accident
description: The death of the actress Janet Gaynor has been officially ruled a direct result of a 1982 traffic accident in San Francisco, the Riverside County Coroner's office said today.

title: MADISON AVE.'S FOOTBALL WOE
description: When the United States Supreme Court ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 33-year reign over college football broadcasts, it created all the chaos of a broken play on Madison Avenue.

title: BRETT'S SLAM HELPS ROYALS STAY ON TOP
description: George Brett, still hobbled slightly with a pulled hamstring, smashed a grand slam home run in the seventh inning tonight to push the Kansas City Royals to a 7-4 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: THE REGION ; ;  2,000 at Funeral Of Slain Officer
description: More than 2,000 police officers attended the funeral today of an Essex County police officer who was shot to death Monday when he stopped a car on Interstate 280 in East Orange.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Chicago dispatch on Thursday about the campaign of Geraldine A. Ferraro misstated a finding of the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. It found that among the public, those rating Mrs. Ferraro unfavorably had risen to 31 percent from 16.

title: POPE SPEAKS OUT ON POLITICAL ROLE
description: Pope John Paul II today defended the intervention of the Roman Catholic Church in political debates, but said the church should not be directly involved in politics.

title: Brooklyn Museum Adds a Day to Schedule
description: The Brooklyn Museum will be open one more day a week, on Monday, the museum's director, Robert Buck, has announced. The change was made possible by a $600,000 increase in financing from the city.

title: Carnegie Jazz Series
description: ''New Jazz in the Recital Hall,'' an eight-concert series at Carnegie Recital Hall, begins on Oct. 13 with a performance by Reggie Workman, a bassist and composer.

title: SCIENTIFIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Student Gets Backing Of Bush on Homework
description: A student who told Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice- Presidential nominee, that he was too busy with homework to spend much time thinking about the nuclear arms race has received encouraging words from Vice President Bush.

title: UNESCO AIDE ASSAILS RELEASE OF STUDY
description: A Unesco spokesman today described the disclosure of a confidential American report critical of the agency's Director General as ''psychological warfare'' by those who want the United States to quit the world body at the end of this year.

title: SEOUL WARNS EXILED OPPOSITION LEADER
description: The Government said today that it would take ''necessary'' legal action against Kim Dae Jung, the exiled opposition leader, if he followed through on his announced plan to return home from the United States late this year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fuzzy Zoeller , the United States Open champion who withdrew from this week's Panasonic Las Vegas golf tournament because of back spasms, will undergo exploratory surgery Monday, according to Eddie Elias , his attorney. . . . Gordon Johncock suffered a mild concussion yesterday in a crash during practice for Sunday's grand prix race in Brooklyn, Mich., for Indianapolis-style cars. . . . Garry Maddox , the 35-year-old Philadelphia Phillie center fielder who has been on the disabled list since Aug. 19, underwent back surgery and should be fully recovered in six to eight weeks, his doctor said. . . . Robert Monti , a former Pace University football player who was expelled along with a teammate, Michael Robustelli, after they were charged with assaulting a fellow student last September, was found not guilty following a trial in Village Court in Pleasantville, N.Y. Robustelli, the son of the former Giant defensive end and general manager, Andy Robustelli, was acquitted in June.

title: WALKER MAY HAVE GLAUCOMA
description: Wesley Walker, the star receiver of the Jets who is legally blind in his left eye, has learned that he may have glaucoma in his right eye. However, Walker said that he has been assured that it poses no danger to his sight.

title: THROUGH A LENS BRIGHTLY
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Gromyko, has agreed to meet with President Reagan during the election campaign. White House pleasure about this was dampened when Mr. Gromyko announced he would also meet with Walter Mondale.

title: Book and Map Auction
description: An auction of old books and maps, including a map of colonial Maryland and the first description of New York printed in English, raised $1.88 million Thursday and today at Sotheby's. A 1635 map of Maryland went for $62,000 to an unidentified London dealer.

title: Communist Ticket Gets Connecticut Ballot Spot
description: The Communist Party Presidential ticket has gained a spot on a Connecticut election ballot for the first time in 44 years, the Secretary of State's office announced Thursday.

title: CONSERVATOR GUIDELINES TO BE SET
description: New York State's top judges have agreed to establish guidelines aimed at insuring that conservators and guardians are appointed by the courts ''on an impartial basis without favoritism and without even an appearance of impropriety,'' the state's Chief Judge said yesterday.

title: METS GAIN AND STAY ALIVE
description: The Mets stayed mathematically alive last night by beating the Montreal Expos, 6-2, and then Dave Johnson stood in the manager's office staring at his television set. In rich color, the Chicago Cubs were losing their fifth straight game, and now they led the Mets by six and a half with eight to play.

title: Postal Flood With the Cubs closing in on the National League East title, club officials announced recently that a post card lottery would be used to allocate the 35,000 Wrigley Field seats available to the general public should the Cubs make the playoffs and the World Series. Postal officials now wish they had come up with a different method. The postmark deadline was noon Thursday, and as it approached, post offices in the Chicago area were being clogged with entries. ''They're very noticeable going through,'' said
description: Don McMullen, a floor supervisor at the postal distribution center in Springfield. A post office in Decatur that normally sells 50 post cards a day sold 3,000 Monday. There was no final count from the Cubs, but officials said the main Chicago post office had processed about 1.5 million Cub cards.

title: European Joblessness
description: The Common Market's unemployment in August rose to 11 percent of the working population, from 10.9 percent in July and 10.4 percent 12 months before, the trade bloc's statistical office said today. The agency said 12.4 million people - the most for any summer month - were jobless in the nine of the bloc's 10 members included in the survey, up 148,000 from July. Greece is not included in the jobless figures, because of differences in how it measures unemployment.

title: PATENTS ;
description: Rubik's Cube Inventor Devises a New Toy

title: Celebrating for Meese
description: Lawyers who successfully represented Edwin Meese 3d in the

title: San Francisco Ballet Rehires Ousted Official
description: Michael Smuin, dismissed last month as co-director of the San Francisco Ballet, has been rehired by the company's board of trustees.

title: EUROPE VS. U.S.: WHO'S THE BEST?
description: If the French mare All Along runs

title: ARE BOTTLE LAW OPPONENTS PUNISHING NEW YORK CONSUMERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Blizzard Gain
description: Ace Ntsoelengoe scored at 33 minutes 53 seconds tonight to lift Toronto to a 1-0 victory over the San Diego Sockers, sending the Blizzard into the North American Soccer League's championship game for the second straight year.

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $5.1 million for the quarter and year from an investment impairment. c-Net income

title: M.T.A. REFUSES TO GIVE NOTES TO INSPECTOR GENERAL
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority refused yesterday to give the inspector general of the authority access to notes from an M.T.A. inquiry into its new Japanese subway cars.

description: Prvious Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 13.00 13.00 11.00 DISCOUNT RATE *9.00 9.00 9.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 11.00 11.12 9.08 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS *10.27 10.25 8.83 6-MO. TREAS.
