description: To the Editor:

title: Yet Again in Beirut
description: ''How could it happen again?'' asks Robert Dillon, who was Ambassador to Lebanon when America's Embassy was first destroyed by a car bomb last year.

title: New Milestone
description: Aaron Krickstein, the 17-year-old tennis professional from Grosse Pointe, Mich., became the youngest player ever named to an American Davis Cup squad when he, John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors and Peter Fleming were selected to play against Australia in Portland, Ore., Sept. 28, 29 and 30.

title: F.T.C. Dismisses Charge on Echlin
description: A Federal Trade Commission judge dismissed a 1981 complaint charging that Echlin Inc.'s purchase of the Borg-Warner Corporation's automobile replacement parts operations would substantially lessen competition.

title: HOME CARE GAP IN THE MEDICARE SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ANALYSTS SAY G.M. ACCORD WON'T WIDEN INDUSTRY GAP
description: The proposed settlement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers should not put the company at any greater disadvantage in the worldwide automobile market, analysts for Wall Street said yesterday.

title: Ensemble Studio Festival
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater's ''Octoberfest '84'' - a three-week festival of 70 plays - begins Oct. 1.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 35.

title: Ford Fills Key Job in Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company today named Alexander J. Trotman president of its European operations. Mr. Trotman has been president of Ford's Asia-Pacific operations.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS IN THE MOM-AND-POP GROCERY STORE
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAHAM TOUR OF SOVIET ENDS ON AN UPBEAT NOTE
description: The Rev. Billy Graham concluded a tour of the Soviet Union today, saying the 12 days had been among ''the most unforgettable and fascinating of my entire ministry.''

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Bruce Berenyi, for whom a .500 record this season seemed a long shot several weeks ago, aims to get even at 13-13 today. (Television - Sports Channel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. (Radio - WABC, 770; 2:15 P.M.)

title: NEW YORK AREA COSTS ROSE 0.7% LAST MONTH
description: The cost of living in the New York- northeastern New Jersey area increased seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, led by higher prices for housing, food, clothing and medical care, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. It was one of the largest monthly increases this year.

title: Reagan to Campaign On a Trip to Midwest
description: President Reagan plans to make a campaign trip to Ohio and Wisconsin next week, the White House has announced.

title: THE CITY ; ;  Obscenity Spliced IntoFilmatSchool
description: Officials were trying to determine yesterday how a few seconds of pornography flashed onto the screen in the middle of a Laurel and Hardy film being shown at a Brooklyn elementary school.

title: No Headline
description: Kertesz Show Due at MetAndre Kertesz: Of Paris and New York,'' a retrospective of more than 180 photographs, will open Dec. 19 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. The display, to be on view through Jan. 27, is drawn from collections at the Metropolitan, the Art Institute of Chicago and other public and private holdings.

title: TAX BREAKS NEVER DIE
description: In New York City, tax concessions

title: CATHOLICS IN BOSTON DISCUSS POINTS OF VIEW ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: For two bright days this week, Roman Catholics serious about their faith took time from work to kneel at mass in the dimness of the Workers' Chapel on Arch Street.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL CONFEREES REACH A MAJOR COMPROMISE
description: House and Senate negotiators, trying to resolve differences on immigration legislation, today approved a major compromise that would make it easier for farmers to import foreign workers. The action virtually assures that the conferees can agree on a comprehensive immigration bill.

title: FOOD: MUGGING FOR THE CAMERA
description: The days of food advertisements with marbles in the soup to make it boil more appealingly and shaving cream in place of whipped cream are over, thanks to truth-in-advertising regulations that prohibit food fakery in commercials.

title: INFLUENTIAL HARVARD PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Carl J. Friedrich, a professor of government at Harvard University for nearly 50 years and the influential author of books on political thought, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Lexington, Mass., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Mais Oui
description: The French Finance Minister,

title: AT YANKEE STADIUM, A WISTFUL SEPTEMBER SONG
description: The crack of a bat sounded amplified in cavernous Yankee Stadium, sprinkled lightly with fans on a cool September evening. Calvin Adams was off like a shot to catch the ball, looking back now and again to follow its flight, then making a neat grab after it crashed foul in the blue- plastic seats. He held up his prize to the crowd's applause.

title: Guerrillas in Colombia Battle Police at School
description: Left-wing guerrillas fought a gun battle with the police and then held 50 people hostage at a Bogota school today, the police reported. They said 10 of the rebels escaped and five surrendered.

title: Move Over, Moby Dick
description: The Navy is investigating an incident in which the captain of a

title: 1,200 AT THE 4TH GAME OF WORLD CHESS MATCH
description: The Hall of Columns of the House of Trade Unions, which seats 1,200, was comfortably filled tonight for the fourth game of the world championship chess match between Anatoly Karpov and his challenger, Gary Kasparov.

title: CHARLES A. CRAPE
description: Charles A. Crape, former president of the decorative-fabrics division of Burlington Industries, died of leukemia Wednesday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 66 years old.

title: CONCERT: PETER ALLEN
description: In the decade and a half that he has been a solo performer, Peter Allen has metamorphosed from what he calls ''a sensitive singer-songwriter'' into a consummate music hall entertainer. Pixieish and proudly androgynous, Mr. Allen sings, dances and tells racy show business anecdotes with a glee that is contagious. And on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, where he opened the first of seven performances, he blended all of his tricks into a sparkling evening of one- man musical comedy.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 8
A VOLCKER PROTEGE
description: Despite the individual reputation he has attained as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, Edward Gerald Corrigan is best known, both inside and outside the Federal Reserve System, as the protege and close confidant of Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Colleagues of Mr. Corrigan say that to know Mr. Volcker's views and interests is to know Mr. Corrigan's. Ever since the two met at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1975, where Mr. Volcker was then president and Mr. Corrigan a vice president, the two have shared a close professional and personal relationship.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DY;
description: Putting the Arm On the Law

title: ZACCARO FACING A STATE INQUIRY ON REAL ESTATE
description: New York's Department of State, which licenses real-estate brokers, said today that it was conducting a ''routine investigation'' of John A. Zaccaro's real-estate business.

title: Steve Goodman, Composer And Folk Singer, Dies at 36
description: Steve Goodman, the folk singer and composer who wrote the song ''City of New Orleans,'' died of complications from a bone marrow transplant Thursday at the University of Washington Hospitals in Seattle. He was 36 years old and had suffered from leukemia for the last 15 years.

title: FOR MR. JOHNSON, THE ELEMENTS OF STYLE
description: He was a chunky black man in his early 40's. I noticed him because he took notes. Copious notes. In freshman composition, there is not a lot of lecture material worth taking down, but - I will call him Kenneth Johnson - copied assiduously. That was one of his words: assiduously. Others were: corroborate, temerity, altercation, depredation, contumacy, tergiversation, crepitant. He had hundreds of them, perhaps thousands, that he had hoarded for years and was now squandering recklessly in my class.

title: EDWARDS, A. G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Stilling a Voice

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:New York Unit Final Today InNationalPairs

title: His Three Sons
description: Jim Baldinger of Massapequa Park, L.I., who played as an end at Navy in the early 1950's, is a proud football father. He has three sons of exceptional talent who are playing the game on a high level - two professionally and the third in college.

title: BROKERAGES OFFER BALDWIN SETTLEMENT
description: Twelve of the country's largest brokerage firms yesterday announced a $135 million settlement of class action suits that were filed by holders of annuities written by the financially distressed Baldwin- United Corporation.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS END TO 'RUDENESS'
description: Officials of President Reagan's re- election campaign said yesterday that they were urging supporters to refrain from heckling Walter F. Mondale or Geraldine A. Ferraro, lest sympathy be created for the Democratic challengers.

title: Pre-Albany Cycle
description: The Ink Truck. By William Kennedy. 278

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE REGION ; ;  Jersey Road Shut After Fuel Spill
description: Route 17 was closed for more than two hours today after gasoline spilled from two trucks involved in an accident, the police said.

title: Reuters Reporter Freed In Lebanon Unharmed
description: A correspondent for Reuters who disappeared in Lebanon 23 days ago was released unharmed today by his abductors.

title: Reagan Fund Surplus To Be Shared With U.S.
description: President Reagan's campaign committee has a surplus of more than $1.5 million from his unopposed quest for his renomintion as the Republican candidate for President and will refund one- third of that money to the Treasury, a spokesman said today.

title: Japanese Auto Output
description: Japan's auto makers produced 774,928 cars, trucks and buses in August, up 7.1 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. It said the 12- month rise was the highest ever recorded in August.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Birders Migrate Downtown for Tea

title: Ali Leaves Hospital Vowing to take better care of himself and get more sleep,
description: Muhammad Ali was released from the Neurological Institute at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center last night after making demonstrable progress in his struggle with Parkinson's syndrome. ''I'll get all my business done by 10, get to sleep at 10:30 and sleep till 6,'' Ali told a news conference before leaving for the Sudan and an Islamic conference this weekend.

title: BRUNEI IS GREETED AS THE 159TH U.N. MEMBER
description: Brunei Darussalam, a newly independent nation on the South China Sea, became the 159th member of the United Nations today.

title: 'SOLDIER'S STORY' STAR, FOUR YEARS OF WAITING
description: Four years ago, when Howard E. Rollins Jr. heard he had landed the plum part of Coalhouse Walker in ''Ragtime,'' he fell to his knees and began to weep. All the years of trying to make it as an actor had finally paid off, and the flashy role - which won him rave reviews - seemed guaranteed to launch his career to stardom.

title: MONDALE ATTACKS ADMINISTRATION ON BEIRUT BLAST
description: Walter F. Mondale blamed the Reagan Administration today for security lapses at the United States Embassy in Lebanon and said President Reagan ''owes the American people answers about this tragedy.''

title: NEW SUMMARY;
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1984 International The chance presence of bodyguards assigned to the British Ambassador in Beirut appeared to have saved the United States Embassy from total destruction and greater loss of life when it was devastated Thursday by a car bomb. The bodyguards may have killed the suicide bomber before he could reach his goal, a driveway under the embassy where an explosion would have caused the building to collapse. (Page 1, Column 1.) The vulnerability of the embassy in Lebanon to a car-bomb attack was partly the result of a failure to coordinate security arrangements between the State and Defense Departments, according to Reagan Administration officials. (1:2.)

title: Dome-Canada Accord to Halt
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said the new Canadian Government would not renew the agreement involving the Government, Dome and Canadian bankers that is to expire Oct. 1.

title: ARMORED-CAR GUARDS ROBBED ON COFFEE BREAK
description: Armed robbers surprised two armored-car guards during a coffee break this morning, took their guns and the keys to the armored car and escaped with about $127,000, the police said.

title: EVEN CLINCHED TITLE CAN'T RUFFLE COMPOSURE OF PADRES' FANS
description: Out near San Diego's stadium, at a bar draped with team pennants, glasses were hoisted Thursday night when the San Diego Padres won their first National League West title. It was a joyful tribute by some of this sun-crowned city's most die-hard Padre fans.

title: FARMERS WELCOME REAGAN'S LOAN PLAN BUT ASK FOR MORE AID
description: Farmers seem generally receptive to President Reagan's initiative this week to keep more debt-ridden farmers from being forced off the land, although they say it is more of a ''first step'' than a final solution to the nagging financial problems of the agricultural sector.

title: YANKEES WIN, MOVE CLOSER TO 2D PLACE
description: In the only team race left for the Yankees, they moved one game from second place tonight by defeating the Detroit Tigers, the American League East champions, by 5-3. In the even more interesting individual race, Don Mattingly grabbed the league hitting lead from Dave Winfield.

title: REAGAN VOWS INCREASED DRIVE ON NARCOTICS
description: President Reagan, declaring that America had ''come to its senses about drug abuse,'' said today that his Administration would redouble its fight against drug traffickers and try to ''take the customers away from the drugs'' through education.

title: ABORTION'S DISTINCTION AMONG IMMORAL ACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTUMN, AND THE CAPITAL IS HUMMIN'
description: The Nautical Almanac Office of the Naval Observatory here is very precise about it and says so in the terms of a military command: ''At 4:33 P.M. Eastern daylight time on Saturday, autumn will begin.''

title: THE BOMBS BURSTING IN AIR
description: Fred Ferretti is a reporter for The New York Times. FIREWORKS

title: HOW PINKNEY MADE IT
description: LAST ONE HOME By John Ehle. 345 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: THE HUNT FOR NAZIS SHIFTS INTO 'HIGH GEAR'
description: While officials in Washington last month were announcing the deportation of Archbishop Valerian D. Trifa, head of the Rumanian Orthodox Church in America, two Justice Department lawyers were in Lithuania, videotaping testimony. They were looking for evidence of war crimes by a Cicero, Ill., man who was a prison warden there more than 40 years ago.

title: Gelato
description: To the Editor:

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Becket Starring Peter O'Toole, Richard Burton, Donald Wolfit, John Gielgud, Pamela Brown, Martita Hunt; directed by Peter Glenville, 1964 Maljack 150 minutes. $59.95

title: DRIFTING AND DREAMING
description: Joe W. Kittinger , who had a record for coming down, now has a record for staying up. Mr. Kittinger last week completed the longest solo balloon flight ever, 3,353 miles from Caribou, Me., to Savona, Italy. It was also the first Atlantic crossing by a lone balloonist. Mr. Kittinger, a 56- year-old Florida resident who had previously entered the record book with a 16-mile free fall from a balloon at 102,800 feet, was said to be ''elated and euphoric,'' although he suffered a broken ankle during a storm-tossed landing in Italy.

title: No Headline
description: N.J. Transit Will Get 100 Segmented Buses

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 23, 1984Fiction*1 THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. *2 THE WICKED DAY, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) King Arthur, fulfilling a prophecy of Merlin, falls into an incestuous relationship. *3

title: A PIANIST ASSESSES TRAINING
description: NO matter what the adage says about talent skipping a generation, it is resoundingly wrong in the case of Beveridge Webster: the father of the renowned Scarsdale pianist was one of the founders of the Pittsburgh Symphony; his son, the brilliant clarinetist Michael Webster, now heads the Rochester Chamber Music Society. Nor does the artistic line stop there - Mr. Webster's first cousin is Anne Bennett, members of whose own distinguished musical family founded and still run the Bennett Conservatory in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: TOWN SPLIT IN FIGHT OVER A GUN RANGE
description: JUANITA SCISM of Stafford signed a petition the other day opposing a shooting range. She hasn't heard the end of it since. She is a Stafford native, and in a town where hunting is a way of life, she said, such a reaction is no suprise.

title: California Man Learns He May Be an Heir
description: A man who could not afford $50 bail after being arrested Friday for panhandling and public drunkenness was stunned to learn that he might be the heir to millions of dollars.

title: INVESTIGATORS FIND NO CASE AGAINST MEESE
description: After a five-month inquiry, an independent counsel last week reported that he had found no evidence that Edwin Meese 3d, whose nomination to be Attorney General is stalled in the Senate, had broken any Federal laws.

title: OWNERSHIP SHOULD BE REVIEWED
description: The future of a family's house or condominium after the death of one or both of the owners is a matter of major concern to most families. Above all, there is the threat that the property may have to be sold to pay inheritance taxes.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Jazz
description: Ever since the jazz revolutions of the 1960's broke down the last remaining restrictions on harmony and rhythm, musicians have been putting together their own kinds of post-avant-garde jazz. Both the David Holland Quintet, which is playing Tuesday through next Sunday at Sweet Basil, and the George Adams-Don Pullen quartet, at the Village Vanguard the same nights, are dedicated post-modernist groups - and they couldn't sound more different.

title: A Stockholm Sampler
description: Rates are for a double room with private bath, including taxes and service charges. Address/ TelephoneRooms/ RateNotes Grand 8 Blasieholmshamnen 22 10 20352 rooms $90-$110Traditionally the hotel for visiting leaders, Nobelists and other celebrities. Harbor view, opposite royal palace. Best rooms with water view, balcony. Large winter garden, French restaurant and bar with good smorgasbord.

title: SHELTER FOR RUNAWAY GIRLS SPLITS VILLAGE
description: IN Patchogue, residents speak of

title: STATE DETECTIVE REPORTED SLAIN
description: The state police said today that they were searching for an ''armed and dangerous'' man in the murder of a state police detective.

title: 5 Haitians Are Sentenced For Bombings in 1983
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 22 (AP) - Five Haitians have been sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor for terrorist bombings in 1983 that killed five people.

title: Mauritanian Group Says It Killed Libyan in Rome
description: A Mauritanian opposition group today took responsibility for killing a Libyan found beaten to death in a Rome hotel room two days ago. The group said he was killed because he had cut off aid to rebels.

title: LIFE AFTER RADCLIFF
description: SUPERIOR WOMEN

title: Cologne
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERIM VERDICT FOR MR. MEESE
description: In finding that Edwin Meese committed no crime while serving as a trusted White House aide, the court-appointed independent counsel also emphasized what his investigation was not doing. Jacob Stein properly rejected the entreaties of both friends and foes of Mr. Meese and rendered no judgment on his ethics or fitness to serve as Attorney General.

title: LEBANON BLAMES ISRAELIS IN SLAYING OF SHIITES
description: Lebanon accused Israel today of being fully responsible for the slaying of Shiite Moslem villagers in Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon two days ago.

title: FERRARO OBJECTS TO TONE OF OPPOSITION
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro said again yesterday that there appeared to be an organized campaign to blacken her Vice- Presidential candidacy.

title: REDHEADED HELLIONS IN THE CRAPE MYRTLE
description: Beverly Lowry's last novel was ''Daddy's Girl.'' She is completing a new book, ''The Bethany Wars.'' VICTORY OVER JAPAN

title: OLD SYNAGOGUE, NEW WINDOW
description: WHEN worshipers enter the sanctuary of Temple Adas Israel on Atlantic Avenue in Sag Harbor for the High Holy Days services later this week, they will see a colorful new addition to the decorations in the 86- year-old synagogue, home of the island's oldest Jewish congregation.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
 SHADOW PUPPETS BLEND EAST AND WEST
description: TO appreciate the accomplishment of Tamara Fielding, perhaps the only woman Dalang (Indonesian puppet master) in the West or in Indonesia, a viewer of her performance of the Wayang Kulit, the shadow puppet plays of Java, should not only watch the action on the illuminated screen, but walk behind it and watch her at work.

title: Heavy Rains in Cape Verde
description: A violent storm hit the drought-stricken Cape Verde archipelago off West Africa last Sunday and Monday, killing 31 people and causing heavy damage, the Cape Verde Government said today. But the rain restored underground water reserves, improving prospects for agriculture, the Government said.

title: ; LETTERS
description: GELATO

title: Q & A
description: Question:

title: WHEN THE PHONE IS YOUR BEST FRIEND
description: BARBARA LEE, a 43-year-old stockbroker with Shearson Lehman/ American Express,loves living in a house on a lake and operating out of a two-room office behind a real estate agency. She doesn't miss her East Side Manhattan apartment or her 33d- floor Madison Avenue office at all. What she does miss, however, is gossip - both the kind that is vital to keeping on top of business and the kind that represents plain, friendly watercooler kibitzing.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have rewarded the center Tim Kerr , who led the team in scoring last season, his best in the National Hockey League, with a new multiyear contract. . . . Chuck Nevitt , at 7-5 the tallest player in N.B.A. history, has signed a contract and will now try to convince the Los Angeles Lakers he belongs. He failed to convince the Knicks in a tryout last month. . . . Darryl Sutter , the Chicago Black Hawks' left wing, will be lost for at least four weeks, after he underwent arthroscopic surgery. The operation to remove cartilage from his right knee, injured during a Thursday scrimmage, was performed Friday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: INTERSTELLAR PIG

title: Sports of The Times ; 'I'll Take the Cash'
description: THERE was only one thing

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ISLIP FESTIVAL

title: BROOKLYN MAN HELD IN SLAYING OF POLICE OFFICER
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a Transit Authority police officer on Friday.

title: COMPONENTS THAT DO DOUBLE DUTY
description: The proverbial difficulty of telling fish from fowl is compounded by a new class of components that falls between the cracks of established categories, such as video and audio. The last of these columns described a unit designed to unify audio and video components into a functionally integrated single system. Today, our survey of these hybrid devices spotlights receivers combining audio and video capabilities.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: OLD WESTBURY Gardens, the thriving former residence of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Phipps that was built in the early part of the 20th century to recreate an 18th-century English country house, was all glitter and glory for its Silver Anniversary Ball, which marked the 25 years the lavish home and grounds have been open to the public. Almost 500 people were expected last night for the $200-a-person benefit, which will aid the restoration of the estate's upper terrace.

title: FRENCH HIGH COURT SUPPORTS BASQUES' EXTRADITION
description: France's highest appeals court has rejected an appeal by seven Basque separatists seeking to block their extradition to Spain.

title: DEMOCRATS' CONCERNS ABOUT ROLE OF JACKSON APPEAR TO FADE
description: A few months ago the Rev. Jesse Jackson was such a controversial figure in the Democratic Party that there were questions about his value as an active supporter of the Democratic ticket, despite his popularity among blacks and the importance of their support in November.

title: WRITERS UNDER A DOUBLE DISADVANTAGE
VIENNA ORCHESTRA HIGHLIGHTS SERIES AT PARAMOUNT CENTER
description: SEVERAL weeks ago in this column we previewed a few of the many splendid concert series that are making it increasingly unnecessary for Westchester music lovers to brave Manhattan traffic in their quest for top-notch solo or chamber recitals. Here are some more suggestions.

title:
NUMISMATICS ;
DEALERS' ORGANIZATION PLANNING ITS NEXT MOVE
description: Coin and bullion dealers are ready for Round Two in their fight against Big Brother, Washington- style. The fight began last year, when dealers formed the Industry Council for Tangible Assets - ICTA - to counteract what they considered overzealous government regulation. Since then, the new organization has done much to help safeguard the interests of buyers and sellers of coins, bullion and other tangible assets.

title: STANDING TALL IN THE HAMPTONS
description: Building along the inviting but flood-prone shore areas between the village of Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the Atlantic Ocean has always been a risky proposition. That is why zoning ordinances now require that any new construction be at least seven feet above sea level.

title: MERCENARIES IN FATIGUES MEET IN NEVADE GLITTER
description: If the presence of American mercenaries opposing Communists in Central America becomes an international issue, no one would appear to be happier about it than those who are doing the guerrilla training and occasional fighting.

title: POOR LITTLE TYKES
description: Aljean Harmetz is the Hollywood correspondent of The New York Times and the author of ''The Making of the Wizard of Oz,'' recently reprinted in paperback. TWINKLE, TWINKLE, LITTLE STAR

title: CONNECTICUT DOCTORS GIVEN INSURANCE CHOICE
description: Connecticut's 4,000 physicians are being asked to participate in the state's first doctor-owned insurance company in an effort to fight increasing malpractice insurance premiums.

title: A SIDE TRIP TO SIBERIA
description: Five Americans on an Alaskan supply boat found themselves in hot water in the Bering Strait. After making a delivery to a research ship north of the Arctic Circle, the Frieda K apparently veered off its southern course back to Nome and approached another craft to ask directions.

title: REFUGE MAY GET INCREASED FUNDS
description: WHILE attention is focused on Congressional approval of the proposed 142-acre national wildlife refuge on islands in Long Island Sound, an existing refuge in Westbrook stands to benefit from the $2.5 million in Federal money set aside for the larger land package.

title: ; FRENCH BISTRO DISHES TO ENLIVEN THE LAST DAYS OF SUMMER
description: SOME foods never go out of fashion. As the evenings grow cooler, certain French bistro dishes go perfectly with the last vegetables and herbs of the season. A classic such as veal kidneys in a mustard sauce, can be served with buttered noodles and zucchini seasoned with tarragon and chives. A tender piece of calf's liver, its juices deglazed with Madeira wine can be accompanied by mashed potatoes and grilled tomato topped with pesto sauce. With these simple bourgeois dishes, drink a red wine - a light Bordeaux or Beaujolais with the liver, a full red Burgundy with the kidneys.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Welles Has Nuptials

title: Mona Rivera of CBS Will Marry in Spring
description: Mona Rivera, a reporter for CBS, and Robert Snedeker, an international trade executive, plan to marry next spring.

title: ECONOMIC LINKS
description: Car sales and auto company profits have rebounded since the 1982 contracts were signed, largely because of restraints on imports. A set of reports last week dramatized the interrelations of the United States and the world's economies.

title: Women in the Middle East
description: I turned eagerly to Judith Miller's article, ''A Mideast Odyssey'' (Aug. 12). Her sharp perceptions and appreciation of Egypt set her writing apart from other Middle East reporting.

title:
PERSONALLY SPEAKING;
CAN HAPPINESS BE A WARM PUPPY?
description: -eyed puppies, especially those whose piteous whimpers seem to say, ''Please take me home,'' or a wide-eyed, tearful, 4-year-old blond boy begging, ''Oh, please, mommy, I love the little puppy.''

title: MUSIC: ROBERT STALLMAN, FLUTIST
description: What made Robert Stallman's flute recital at Alice Tully Hall Friday night such a satisfying one was more then just the variety of the program; it was the way Mr. Stallman could bend the color and the character of his instrument to fit the music at hand.

title: VERBATIM: SMALL BUT WORLDWISE
description: 'Our country has known peace, but also war; wealth, but also poverty; energetic commerce, but also isolation; development, but also exploitation; self-government, but also foreign rule. All this has not been without benefit to us.

title: ETHIOPIAN CHURCH REASSERTING ITSELF
description: Two weeks ago, when Ethiopia celebrated the 10th anniversary of the revolution that overthrew Emperor Haile Selassie, monuments were erected throughout the capital: billboards of the Communist trinity of Marx, Engels and Lenin, portraits of the Ethiopian leader Mengistu Haile Mariam and giant yellow stars bearing the hammer and sickle.

title: NICARAGUANS SAY THEY WOULD SIGN PROPOSED TREATY
description: Nicaragua has announced that it will accept a draft peace treaty for Central America proposed two weeks ago by the four nations known as the Contadora group.

title: Reservations
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon Drive for Reagan
description: Mayor Frank Ivancie of Portland, long a Democrat, will head Oregon Democrats for Reagan-Bush '84, President Reagan's campaign officials announced Friday. Both the Republican and Democratic national tickets are considered facing a tight contest here. Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh, a Republican, is among those who have called the race a ''tossup.''

title: CUTS FOUND IN U.S. WORK ON PRIVACY ISSUES
description: The Reagan Administration has sharply reduced the number of Federal employees working to protect individuals from improper use of public and private records, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Judith Chapman Wed To Charles E. Proctor
description: Judith Latimer Chapman, the daughter of Harlen M. Chapman Jr. of Orleans, Mass., and the late Margaret Latimer Chapman, was married yesterday to Charles Edward Proctor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Proctor of Scituate, Mass., and Deep Valley, Ariz. The Rev. David G. Robinson Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans.

title: FOR THE BIG EVENING, DRESSES BY SCAASI
description: These women go to big parties five nights a week,'' said Arnold Scaasi, the designer of made-to-order clothes. ''They need big dresses.''

title: LAUGHS AND LESSONS IN TWO NEW CHILDREN'S SHOWS
description: This season, two new series designed for younger audiences may well end up attracting the attention of older viewers as well. Both are aimed at provoking thoughtfulness but each is taking a rather different approach., Bucking the sea of Saturday-morning cartoons is CBS's 'Pryor's Place,' featuring Richard Pryor, the controversial comedian known for his off-the-wall humor. 'WonderWorks' is a public-television of prime-time programming for children.

title: Jane K. Baumgardner Becomes a Bride
description: Jane Kohl Baumgardner, a daughter of Mrs. Marvin Dodge Baumgardner of Greenwich, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mr. Baumgardner, was married yesterday to Walter Granruth 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Granruth Jr. of Baltimore and Stone Harbor, N.J. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: How much longer will political campaign memorabilia be collected? It's a question raised every four years during Presidential campaigns - and one that so far has not been answered. The problem is that the popularity of period material increases with every Presidential election, but the contemporary production of campaign mementoes for today's candidates is on the wane. Eventually, some observors believe, this may cause a decline in popularity of these collectibles.

title: NEW YORK GETS A NUDGE ON THE HUDSON'S SLUDGE
description: ''Flush and forget'' was how New Jersey Senator Frank R. Lautenberg once described New York City's practice of dumping untreated sewage into the Hudson River. He and other New Jersey lawmakers had long contended that the waste carried into the Atlantic was polluting beaches in their state. Last week, however, after New York's two Senators relented and agreed to restrictions on the discharge of the sewage, Mr. Lautenberg changed his description to ''flush and forgive.'' The limits, to take effect in two years, are included in an amendment to the Clean Water Act, which had been held up by Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Their go- ahead helps clear the way for a vote on the bill in the final days of the Congressional session.

title: Rowan Teresa O'Riley To Marry W. S. Kaiser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. O'Riley of Phoenix, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rowan Teresa O'Riley, to William Stuart Kaiser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Kaiser of Cleveland. The wedding is to be Jan. 5.

title:
CAMERA;
FINDING OUT WHAT WENT WRONG
description: Was there a time when a roll of vacation pictures turned out to be blanks? Or all the faces photographed were too dark? Or the landscapes seemed washed out? There are many things that can go wrong in photography. And every photographer from beginner to pro has experienced most of them.

title: Thomas Johnson Is Wed in Bedford To Miss Laughlin
description: Laura Bailey Laughlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bailey Laughlin of Darien, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas West Johnson, a son of Mrs. Wynant D. Vanderpool Jr. of Washington and the late Stuart H. Johnson Jr. The Rev. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. He was assisted by Bishop G. P. Mellick Belshaw of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, the bridegroom's uncle.

title: WHAT TO EXPECT IN COMING SEASON
description: IN the state's theaters, it appears

title: Hospital Names President
description: A vice dean at Columbia University has been chosen president and chief executive officer of Presbyterian Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and will formally assume the position in January, officials have announced. The dean, Thomas Morris, will succeed Dr. Felix Demartini, who plans to retire in September 1985 and will act as an adviser until then. The chairman of the hospital's board, Howard Clark, said Mr. Morris was selected after an 18-month search.

title: CATHOLIC ACTIVISM: REASONS AND RISKS
description: The Roman Catholic Church has been plunged into American politics in a way that is unique in recent history. A sudden flurry of activity by the bishops of the Northeast has come at a time of conflict over the political activism of the Protestant right. It has raised questions about the constitutional barrier between church and state - and also about why the bishops have acted, seemingly on behalf of the President's re- election, within a church that in the past has been reluctant to appear too aggressive for fear of stirring a Protestant backlash of the kind that marred their relations for many years.

title: STATE AGREES TO CHANGES AT L.I. CENTER FOR RETARDED
description: New York State officials have assured a Federal judge that they would fully carry out his order to reduce the population and improve conditions at a large institution for the mentally retarded on Long Island, despite their previous opposition to the order.

title: NEGLECTED BRITISH OPERAS ARE HEARD
description: Strindberg's one-act play ''Miss Julie'' has inspired at least one ballet and three operas in recent times. One of the operas is by the English composer William Alwyn, and it now can be heard in a recording on the Lyrita label (two disks, SRCS.121/2). It is one of several disks featuring the work of English composers that merit attention.

title: Sports of The Times; For Ali, What Price the Thrilla in Manila?
description: WHEN that epic in brutality ended in the Philippine Coliseum nearly nine years ago, Joe Frazier had lost. His manager, Eddie Futch, had surrendered for him after the 14th round. Muhammad Ali had retained his world heavyweight title. About 15 minutes later, Joe Frazier, his left eye closed below the towel over his battered head, trudged into the interview room to answer a few quick questions. But even after Joe Frazier departed, Muhammad Ali did not appear.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
MORE TIME IS NEEDED TO STUDY THE BIDS
description: THE debate over the proposed

title: Music and Hits It was a noteworthy night for
description: Jim Traber , the Baltimore Oriole first baseman called up to the parent club before the game Friday night against the Boston Red Sox. The 22-year-old Traber, a professional singer during the offseason, had split the season between Hagerstown of the Class A Carolina League and Charlotte of the Class AA Southern League, batting .354. But in his major league debut, he was belting out music as well as baseballs, as he sang the national anthem before the game and then started in the Oriole lineup as the designated hitter, going 1 for 4.

title: DEMOCRATS RUN L.I. RACES APART FROM MONDALE
description: SEVERAL Long Island Democratic candidates are beginning to put some distance between themselves and the party's Presidential candidate, Walter F. Mondale, as polls increasingly point to a sweep by President Reagan, particularly in such normally Republican areas as Long Island.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: HOBOKEN FESTIVAL

title: STUDY ASSAILS MOVE TO STRENGTHEN JOINT CHIEFS
description: A new study has asserted that a proposal inCongress to strengthen the Joint Chiefs of Staff would ''leave the United States exposed to provincial Prussian- style military leadership.''

title: GETTING A TASTE OF NORTHERN FOOD
description: EDITH MARKS, a teacher and writer, is the author of ''Job Hunting for the Disabled'' (Barron's).

title: 'CREATIVITY AND MADNESS' ARE LINKED, STUDY SAYS
description: Artists, writers and poets are 35 times more likely to seek treatment for serious mood disorders than the average person, according to a recent study.

title: PREZIOSO HITS HIS TOP 100
description: Moments after his players had carried him off the field, after he had exchanged hugs with former players and with neighborhood folk, Joe Prezioso sat back in a folding chair and savored the occasion of his 100th victory as head football coach at DeWitt Clinton.

title: 'GO FOR IT': MAKING YOUR WAY IN A TRIATHLON
description: EIGHT o'clock Saturday morning, and I am in water over my head with 648 other swimmers, waiting for a gun to start Manufacturers Hanover's Mighty Hamptons Triathlon - a three-part race in Sag Harbor, L.I., involving a 1.5-mile swim, 25-mile bike ride and a 10-mile run.

title: MORE THAN WAGES MOVE A UNION CHIEF
description: DAVID LIVINGSTON of Manhasset likes to refer to the caption on the picture of the turtle that hangs in his office in Manhattan. ''Consider the turtle,'' it says. ''He makes no progress until he sticks his neck out.''

title: SIGNS IRK TRADITIONALISTS
description: -and-white-lettered directions on Long Island parkways may be a sign of the times, but area historians don't like the direction to which they are pointing.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on page 1 of the Real Estate section Sept. 9 incorrectly reported the recipient of the proceeds from the sale of the air rights over the City Center. The proceeds will be divided among the New York City Opera, the New York City Ballet and the 55th Street Dance Theater Foundation, which operates the theater.

title: CLOSE VICTORY FOR GATE DANCER
description: Gate Dancer, the Preakness winner who was outfitted in his familiar earmuffs to ward off the crowd noise that distracts him, made up eight lengths with a late rush to beat Precisionist in a close finish today in the $500,000 Super Derby for 3-year-olds at Louisiana Downs.

title: HONDA CIVIC COUPE IS RATED BEST IN U.S. TEST FOR MILEAGE
description: A Honda model, for the second straight year, captured the best mileage ranking among automobiles sold in the United States, according to the annual ratings released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: 14 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 14 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: BREAK DANCERS FORM CREWS AND BATTLE TO THE BEAT
description: THERE is quite a difference between Jefferson Park in Mamaroneck and the rubble- filled streets of the South Bronx, but one thing they have in common is the driving beat of ''rap music'' booming from huge radios as young men twist and contort acrobatically to the music.

title: CHINA TO GET AID OF GEORGIA TECH
description: The Georgia Institute of Technology will become the first American university to enter into joint ventures to help develop industries in China for the manufacture of advanced-technology products.

title: DEMOCRATS MAY GAIN SEATS BUT NOT CONTROL
description: When President Reagan came to Iowa last week, Senator Roger W. Jepsen was not just clinging to his coattails. The Republican, who is facing a stiff challenge from Representative Tom Harkin, stuck so close to Mr. Reagan that he seemed at times to be trying to climb inside his coat.

title: AN IRREPRESSIBLE '65 MINGUS CONCERT
description: Dedicated to heartfelt emotion in his music and candor on stage and off, the bassist-composer Charles Mingus was not one to mince words - and his directness has been restored to print on the recently reissued ''Music Written for Monterey, 1965: Not Heard...Played in its Entirety, at U.C.L.A.''

title: FOR A SECURE EMBASSY, BEIRUT ISN'T THE PLACE TO BE
description: Pieces of steel shaped like giant jacks were placed across the narrow road leading to the entrance of the French annex of the French Embassy in the hills of East Beirut today.

title: PRIMA DONNA, TRIUMPHANT IN EXILE
description: GALINA

title: Q.& A. WITH CITY'S LEASING CHIEF
description: Richard P. Stone has worked in leasing for several chains, including Restaurant Associates, A. & P. and Heyman Properties, and is an administrator of the S. Klein estate and the president of Stone-Erlanger Inc., a real estate investment company.

title: No Headline
description: Karen Morrison Is Married

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption and a listing of comedians today on page 20 of The Guide, section 2A, for the New York debut of Emo Philips, are outdated because of a postponement. Mr. Philips's run at Caroline's begins Thursday.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PARIS
description: They call it la rentree, the return. In this historic rite of early autumn, Parisians, who take their vacations seriously and en masse in August, come back to resume the richness of life in the French capital. Suddenly the city that was pleasantly quiet and empty in the summer becomes pleasantly busy and full. Schoolchildren are back on the street in their new fall clothes, leather satchels slung over their backs. Politicians, in what is known as la rentree politique, stake out positions for the battles that lie ahead. The universities reopen for la rentree scolaire, and the shops and restaurants that were closed for much of August and the early part of September are back in business. The weather turns cooler as October approaches, but cultural life heats up considerably.

title: BEVERLY GRUBB COLE THE BRIDE OF NED B. COSTELLO
description: Beverly Grubb Cole, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Wells Cole of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Ned Bolton Costello, the son of Mrs. Norman Dello Joio of East Hampton, L.I., and Robert E. Costello of New York. The Rev. Kirk Smith, assisted by the Rev. Robert Griffiths, performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title:
ART;
IS THERE ART AFTER COLLEGE?
description: WAYNE '' TEN YEARS AFTER,'' an exhibition of design and illustration at William Paterson College through Oct. 10, is addressed mainly to that perennial question of American students, ''Is there life after college?''

title: 'PROMISES' PROVES AN UNWISE CHOICE
description: IN its 1968 premiere, ''Promises, Promises'' heralded a new kind of amplified, electronic sound for Broadway. With that, a glossy production and fierce energy, the show had big-league hit status stamped all over it, whether one liked it or not. Indeed, the musical version of the Billy Wilder film, ''The Apartment,'' racked up a longer run than ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''The King and I,'' ''Kiss Me, Kate'' and ''Annie, Get Your Gun.''

title: SHAPE AND COLOR
description: -TO-WEAR COLlections in New York, Paris and Milan, as oversize coats, pants and turtleneck sweaters worn with flat brogues kept appearing on the runways, one particular beauty note stood out: Short hair looked right. But not all short hair; models who had cropped their hair in a severe, mannish way looked wrong. What looked best with the man-tailored clothes were sleek, smooth, tousled or spiked variations. Two new products - hair gels and hair mousses - help to give hair body and texture, making these sculptured shapes possible to achieve.

title: Monika Mazurczyk Weds Jerzy Waclaw Swiatkowski
description: The St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Shrine was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Monika Heidi Mazurczyk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Mazurczyk of Rumson, N.J., to Jerzy Waclaw Swiatkowski, the son of Dr. Irena Swiatkowski of Warsaw and the late Antoni Swiatkowski. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: IF NOT DEBATE, AT LEAST DEBATES
description: The 1984 Campaign, Take 2, Scene 1 will begin with a clack of the take-board on Sunday, Oct. 7. That's the date finally agreed to for the first televised Presidential debate, and it will come not a moment too soon for Walter Mondale.

title: THE YEAR THE WORLD CHANGED
description: Robert C. Tucker, the author of ''Stalin as Revolutionary,'' and ''The Soviet Political Mind,'' is a professor of politics emeritus at Princeton University. THE RUSSIAN REVOLUTIONS OF 1917

title: ALONG RAIL LINES, A BONANZA IN LAND
description: ABOUT 3,800 acres of industrial land along Connecticut's railroad lines is vacant, according to a recent survey conducted by the State Department of Transportation.

title: TREATING VICTIMS OF RAPE
description: ALTHOUGH large hospitals and treatment centers in New Jersey have no problem treating victims of sexual assault or sexual abuse, many others do not know what to do for them, say officials of the state's Department of Health.

title: PRIESTLEY'S FOOTSTEPS
description: Benedict Nightingale is a drama critic and author of ''A Reader's Guide to Fifty Modern British Plays.'' ENGLISH JOURNEY

title: FOR BOTH EAST AND WEST TWO GERMANYS IS BETTER
description: ''Everybody agrees that the two Germanys should have good relations. It should be clear, however, that pan-Germanism is something that must be overcome. There are two German states and two German states must remain.''

title: McCallum's Ankle Broken
description: Napoleon McCallum, Navy's senior tailback and Heisman Trophy candidate, suffered a broken left ankle today in the 21-9 loss to Virginia here. The injury came seven plays before the end of the game when McCallum took a pitchout round right end for a 1-yard gain.

title: STAGE: 'CAFE CON LECHE,' A COMEDY
description: Foreign-language theater in New York has always had one great theme to draw from its own audience: The way they and their Yankee offspring make their way in the New World. An amusing and happy addition to this repertory in Italian, Yiddish, German, Chinese and other tongues is the Spanish-language 'Cafe con Leche,' a new comedy by Gloria Gonzalez presented by Repertorio Espanol, the Spanish company ensconced at the Gramercy Arts Theater on East 27th Street.

title: MUSIC VIEW ; NEVER MIND SALIERI, SUSSMAYR DID IT
description: At this point you might justifiably say, paraphrasing Edmund Wilson's dismissal of Agatha Christie and the whole murder-mystery genre, ''Who cares who killed Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart?'' Well, Peter Shaffer, for one. His play ''Amadeus,'' now transmuted into a Milos Forman film with a screenplay by Mr. Shaffer, shows that he continues to care deeply. Over the years, invoking a dramatist's license, he has taken ever more fanciful liberties with musical history to indict poor Antonio Salieri, the rival composer who in his last years supposedly confessed to poisoning Mozart. (He just possibly may have done so, though no hard evidence exists to support the idea.)

title: NEWARK SEES NO SLOWING OF AIRPORT GAINS
description: NEWARK THE recent agreement between the airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration to reduce delays at Newark International Airport by spreading out flights during peak hours, rather than by curtailing them, was greeted with enthusiasm by the airport's operators.

title: Q&A
description: Co-op Investors and Fees

title: SALE OF TRACT STIRS CONCERN IN BRONXVILLE
description: ONE night in 1905, appendicitis struck Dudley B. Lawrence as he visited his brother, Arthur, in Bronxville, which was then a village without a hospital. An emergency ride on the wooden floor of a New York Central freight car took Mr. Lawrence to treatment in New York City and convinced his father, William V. Lawrence, that a hospital was needed closer to home. The elder Lawrence, a real estate developer who would later found Sarah Lawrence College, put up $100,000 in 1906 to help start Lawrence Hospital.

title: Drama's Niche on the Publishing Shelf
description: The number of plays that turn up between the covers of books is truly impressive, as a visit to any of New York's bookstores devoted primarily to plays and the theater can attest. But although drama books occupy an important niche in book publishing, it is a niche not unlike that occupied by volumes of poetry - a sentimental place reserved for labors of love, rather than for the corporate piggy bank.

title: ART VIEW ; COLLECTING ANCIENT OBJECTS WAS FREUD'S 'OBSESSION'
description: When great human beings die, we die a little with them. By way of consolation we sometimes resort to a variant of fetishism. We take possession of their house. We try to keep it exactly as it had been before. And then the public troops in, hoping to breathe the air of genius.

title: SOME OUTSIDE HELP FOR H.R.A.
description: Mayor Koch did nothing last week to dispel speculation that he is trying to put some political distance between himself and the troubled Human Resources Administration.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Dance
description: Whatever kind of dance one likes best, one can surely find it this week. Attractions range from Dance Theater of Harlem's Creole ''Giselle,'' at City Center, to Merce Cunningham's choreographically unpredictable Events at the Joyce.

title: Nazi Past Is Hinted For Florida Honoree
description: An Austrian Mayor honored by predominantly Jewish Miami Beach was a member of a Nazi ''murder brigade'' and a concentration camp official, according to a group that keeps track of Nazi war criminals.

title: COAL MINERS WARILY PREPARING TO VOTE ON A 40-MONTH CONTRACT
description: ''The ones who say they are going to vote to strike are the ones who haven't been laid off yet.''

title: BLACKS, JEWS AND TENSIONS IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: P ERHAPS

title: LATIN DEBT: POSTPONING THE BURDEN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO FOR the first time since Mexico's financial collapse ushered in the Latin American debt crisis

title: NEBRASKA ROUTS U.C.L.A. BY 42-3
description: Jeff Smith rushed for 123 yards and a touchdown, all in the first half, as Nebraska trounced U.C.L.A., 42-3 today. Smith, who carried 20 times, left with an ankle injury that is not believed to be serious and did not play in the second half.

title: WAS MAYOR'S WIDOW
description: Marie La Guardia, the widow of Fiorello H. La Guardia who for 37 years lent her name to civic groups, philanthropic organizations and political candidates that she believed carried on the tradition of her husband, the 99th Mayor of New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 89 years old.

title: NATIONAL MERIT SEMIFINALISTS
description: THE semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's annual competition represent a half of 1 percent of all high-school seniors in the country. Nationwide, they total some 15,000 students.

title: WHAT DOES MODERN ART OWE TO THE PRIMITIVES?
description: There is a phenomenon and a riddle in the New York art world this fall. The phenomenon is that nearly every major museum, and several smaller ones, are mounting exhibitions of ''primitive'' art - art of tribal peoples from Africa, Oceania and North America - this month or next. The largest and most scholarly of the exhibitions begins this Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art, where the curator William Rubin and co-curator Kirk Varnedoe have produced a show that exhaustively documents the profound effects of tribal art on the development of modern art. Entitled '' 'Primitivism' in the 20th Century: Affinity of the Tribal and the Modern,'' the show will run to Jan 15.

title: Promising Drug Tests Asserted by Company
description: A new drug has proved promising in tests to treat recurrent outbreaks of a herpes virus and to help prevent the development of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, a pharmaceutical concern said Friday.

title: Vicki Van Steenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Vicki Van Steenberg and Christopher Grant Frederic La Farge, were married yesterday by the Rev. Frederick Gillif, a Unitarian minister, who performed the ceremony at the South Ferry Church in Saunderstown, R.I.

title: DEALING WITH THE I.R.S.'S MISTAKES
description: HAS the Internal Revenue Service been dunning you for taxes that you paid years ago? Was the computer-generated notice that showed up in your mailbox virtually incomprehensible? Is your refund check from last year's tax return several months overdue?

title: GROMYKO AND CHINESE MEET FOR TWO DAYS AT U.N.
description: Foreign Ministers Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Wu Xueqian of China today ended two days of talks described as a step toward ''mutual understanding.''

title: CURRY BEATS LA ROCCA
description: A pair of undefeated Americans, Don Curry and Richie Sandoval, retained their World Boxing Association titles on the same card today.

title: SOMETIMES, EXTENDING LIFE ONLY PROLONGS DEATH
description: I N

title: I.M.F. PANEL AGREES TO REDUCTION IN CREDIT LIMIT OF DEBTOR NATIONS
description: Industrial and developing countries have decided on action to curtail international credits available for loans to debt-burdened countries, it was announced here tonight.

title: DAILY BY RAIL TO FLORIDA, BATTLES IN PENNSYLVNIA
description: Auto Train To Run Daily Starting Oct. 15

title: COPING WITH THE LOSS OF AMERICA'S CUP AND SETTING A COURSE TO WIN IT BACK
description: wide depression? No. However, the loss of the America's Cup cast the dismal feelings usually associated with a Dunkirk or a Waterloo over many people.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: As for the Catholic bishops, these are the so-called spiritual leaders who have given the American church empty seminaries, empty convents, empty novitiates, half-empty churches and schools that can barely be called Catholic. The bishops seem to think they can divert attention from their spiritual failings by pontificating on such nonspiritual topics as national defense and the economy.

title:
THEATER;
THEATER REBOUNDS WITH A TOUR
description: '' ONE MO' TIME,'' the sizzling 1920's vaudeville revue that opened this year's summer season at the Sharon Playhouse, broke all box- office records at the 388-seat country theater, according to its directors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm delighted. They do things in a big way in Brunei.'' - Mayor Koch, accepting a $500,000 donation from the Sultan. (40:3.)

title: CONNECTICUT TRIES TO CURB LAWSUITS
description: Connecticut's Attorney General, saying ''the courts in this state are swamped with cases,'' is seeking ways of curbing lawsuits in which the state is involved.

title: WHERES THE SCAFFOLD?
description: Strollers on Madison Avenue near 64th Street who have watched a painstaking restoration of the building at No. 740 are wondering why the scaffolding has been removed and the work has stopped, even though the two lower floors still bear the scars of time and neglect.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL CORRECTION
description: In last week's Westchester Weekly section, the captions accompanying photographs taken at the Tallix Foundry in Peekskill misidentified Nathan Rappaport, a sculptor. He was pictured in the lower photograph, working on the plaster model of a soldier.

title: NEW YORK'S FILM FESTIVAL READY TO LAUNCH
description: Filmgoers know that Christmas is the time for major studio releases - like the forthcoming ''Cotton Club'' and ''Dune'' - and that a few blockbusters (or ghostbusters) can be expected as summer vacation beckons. New York's cinephiles also know that October is the month for the release of foreign, independent or sophisticated American films. Why? Simply because the New York Film Festival remains the showcase - and launching pad - for this kind of cinema.

title: RUNNING CLINIC
description: To encourage runners preparing for the second 10-kilometer MONY Run, Bill Rodgers, the four-time winner of both the Boston and New York City marathons, will conduct a clinic on Tuesday. The run will be held Oct. 7 on the Bronx River Parkway, and about 1,000 participants, from 5 to 75 years old, are expected. The race gets under way at 10 A.M.

title: Caroline Felton Becomes a Bride
description: At All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J., yesterday Caroline Peters Felton, a daughter of Zoe Wells Walker of Bay Head and New York and Samuel Morse Felton of Evanston, Ill., was married to Gregory Patton Moore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Moore of Westfield, N.J. Canon E. Rugby Auer performed the ceremony.

title: A REPUBLIC OF FEAR
description: John Vinocur, chief of The Times's Paris bureau, visited Paraguay last month. By John Vinocur PARAGUAY WORKS like this: A man parks his car, and to keep it from being stolen, he attaches it to a rope tied around his waist. The man is arrested walking through the streets, and charged with public ridiculousness. He has insulted national dignity, which, officially, has been restored and exalted over the last 30 years by El Excelentisimo, the President of the Republic, Don Alfredo Stroessner, General of the Army, First Magistrate of the land. Beaten, robbed, demeaned, the man eventually bribes his way out of jail. He finds his automobile on a used car lot, and informs the dealer. ''That's a break for you,'' the dealer says. ''You know the real mileage.''

title: STRANGE SIGHTS; ANOTHER WORLD
description: There are some strange and wonderful sights at New York's Museum of Modern Art right now: the marvelously masked and costumed people of Irving Penn's photographs. They seem startling because they reflect a culture to which few Amerians have been exposed - New Guinea's say, or Cameroon's.

title: SUCCESS IS LOW-KEY, HIGH-SCORING
description: FOUR years of frustration kept Mississippi Valley State University's football coach, Archie Cooley, unusually tight-lipped last week.

title: PROPOSED POWER PLANT TO USE STATE'S NATURAL GAS
description: Private developers and a state agency have announced plans to build a large power plant here that would use natural gas from local gas fields to produce both electricity and steam.

title: La Chiusa
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON SALARY MEASURE
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN and two legislators have ended a standoff by agreeing to modifications in a bill creating a task force to study wage discrimination in state government service.

title: ; SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS' MESSAGE TO GOVERNMENT COLLABORATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL TACKLES TOPICS 1 AND 2
description: Placing the possible and the unavoidable at the top of its list, Israel's new coalition Government last week dug into the major issues it can agree on - withdrawal from southern Lebanon and bailing out the economy.

title: THE REWARDS OF WATCHING AND WAITING
description: GRAEME GIBSON is a Canadian writer whose latest novel is ''Perpetual Motion'' (St. Martin's Press).

title: No Headline
description: New Gas-Line Rules To Aid State Farmers

title: ITALIAN ISLE FOR ALL SUN
description: When the last high-powered motorboat has roared off to its home port, and when the sails of the streamlined Milanese yachts swell with the wind that will carry them home, Ponza slips happily back into a state of sleepy forgetfulness.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: NEW JERSEY is the most important state for the national environmental movement in the Presidential election campaign, according to the director of the state chapter of a national environmental political action committee.

title:
GARDENING;
CREATING IDEAL LOAM FROM SAND OR CLAY
description: SOMEWHERE in most any garden book will be found a reference to garden loam as the ideal soil in which to grow plants. To most gardeners, however, that ideal growing medium is as elusive as the mythical holy grail. The facts of life are that most of us are blessed with either clay or sand and must make the best of our less-than- ideal situation.

title: Susan Alderton To Be the Bride Of Stephen Crane
description: Announcement has been made by Squadron Leader and Mrs. Ronald H. Alderton of Ramsey, England, of the engagement of their daughter Susan Edith Alderton to Stephen Andrew Crane, the son of Mrs. Andrew J. Crane of New York and the late Mr. Crane. A November wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN PARSIPPANY, THE THEME IS CHESS
description: ALARGE chess piece is depicted in bas relief on the outside wall of the Chessmen Bistro in Parsippany. Inside, the scene is continued with framed caricatures of Bobby Fisher and Boris Spassky on the walls, plus an impressive painting by Kenneth Stern of a giant chess game that takes place every other year in Venice, in which live horses and people are used as chessmen.

title:
ART;
FEMALE ARTISTS DEPICT SHIFTING VIEW OF WOMEN
description: '' THE FEMININE GAZE'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford surveys women as depicted by female artists from 1900 through 1930. There is an element of touche in the title: The catalogue informs us that it is a turn on the expression ''The Masculine Gaze,'' which film theorists have coined to characterize the patriarchal angle from which women have been traditionally depicted in the movies.

title: AMERICA'S BANKS IN CRISIS
description: NOT ONCE BUT twice, in May and again in July, the eighth-largest bank in the United States requires a multi-billion-dollar Government rescue effort to stave off imminent collapse. A few weeks later, at the nation's largest savings institution, another wholesale withdrawal of deposits is stanched only by Government intervention.

title: Drifter Gets 75-Year Term
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a drifter who has been convicted of five murders in Texas and one in Michigan, pleaded guilty Thursday to charges of strangling a teen-age baby sitter. After Mr. Lucas confessed the 1981 murder of Dianna Bryant, 17 years old, he was sentenced to 75 years in prison. Mr. Lucas is charged with at least 19 slayings in Texas, Maryland, Florida, Louisiana and Arkansas.

title: Indian City Extends a Curfew After Hindu-Moslem Clashes
description: A round-the-clock curfew was extended to more parts of the southern Indian city of Hyderabad today after four people were stabbed in nightlong Hindu- Moslem clashes, the police said.

title: SHAPING THE FUTURE OF THE HUNTERS POINT WATERFRONT
description: The word ''partnership'' is much on the lips these days of officials of both the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the city who are associated with the ambitious waterfront redevelopment program for Hunters Point in Queens.

title: Miss Towell Has Nuptials
description: Jennifer Ann Towell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Gilmer Towell of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher V. B. Smith, a son of J. Morse Smith of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Thomas Lynch of Port St. Lucie, Fla. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title:
EXPERIENCE, INSTINCT AND INTIMACY;
DAYS WE WOULD RATHER KNOW
description: By Michael Blumenthal. 118 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $14.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $9.95. BLACK DOG, RED DOG

title: THE LITTLE CAR THAT WENT FOR A SWIM
description: WHEN a car in Connecticut found itself underwater - and on the front pages - I knew I was in trouble. Within hours, the same picture but with a customized caption landed on my desk. In that version, Lee Iacocco was announcing the new, amphibious 'Kathy Kafer Car.' As the chief engineer, I was quoted extensively.

title:
Behind the Reagan-Gromyko Meeting;
A Possible Shift By Moscow
description: Most speculation about the Reagan-Gromyko meeting scheduled for Friday centers on whether it really signals a change in President Reagan's attitude toward dealing with the Soviet Union or was engineered as a campaign ploy. There is of course the other side of the coin: whether Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's willingness to meet with Mr. Reagan indicates a significant shift in the Kremlin's ultra-hard line toward Washington. I believe it indicates either that or the beginning of a change.

title: THE MANY SURPRISES OF STOCKHOLM
description: WILLIAM HOWARD ADAMS teaches at the Graduate School of Architecture, Columbia University. His book, ''A Proust Souvenir,'' will be published next month.

title: BEIRUT BLAST AGAIN FORCES MIDEAST INTO U.S. POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON A N act of violence has again forced the Middle East to the top of the American political agenda after months in which the region was largely ignored, not only by the Administration but by the Democrats as well. Interest in the region, it seemed, rises only in time of war, conflict or acts of terror.

title: IN SHORT
description: A Dakota farm boy turned sailor stumbles into the port of an unnamed guerrilla-torn country in Central America to search for his hometown sweetheart, Sally, who lives in the mountains, teaching peasants to read. The sailor, named McQuade, would be a modern frontier hero except that he is going mad, increasingly unable to distinguish hallucinations of home from his present circumstances. Not surprisingly, shortly after he finds Sally, decked with flowers and poised on a veranda like a prairie bride, he loses her. In this surrealist adventure tale, Mark Smith tries to bring unity and understanding to Central American revolutions, United States intervention, madness and heroism. In his prose style, he wants to evoke the absurdity of war and the exoticism of Latin America, but his characters often seem vague, mere caricatures. Besides McQuade and Sally, they include Fortune, a heart-of-gold mercenary; Gabriella, his street girl; a pair of suspicious merchants with the aliases de Groot and Pendleton (much like Tweedledee and Tweedledum); a daft American ambassador and his daughter, who, humiliated by an unrequited love, wills herself into a coma. Unfortunately, the dialogue is heavy-handed, at times rife with cliches. (When McQuade arrives, Sally says, ''And here you are . . . like a bee in the flower.'' ''Smoke Street'' has an obtrusively male sensibility, and yet the author's feeling about this maleness remains unclear. For example, an Army captain says, ''I can understand killing in passion, it is like making love to your young mistress with whom you are infatuated.''

title: FLAGGING ENTHUSIASM
description: I got depressed last month after hearing that the country was suffering another onset of patriotism.

title: ARGENTINA AND TERROR: TWO TALES
description: For Susana Caride, six months a prisoner in a secret jail run by the Argentine military in the 1970's, one of the most difficult periods came after she was set free.

title: MOUSSE CALL
description: Under the heading ''Mousse Is on the Loose,'' Time magazine reports that the latest fad in the $3 billion American hair-care industry is mousse : ''Not a rich dessert, but a hair-styling foam.''

title: MINDS MEET ON DEFENSE
description: The MX's might be a little slower moving off the assembly lines in the future, but if Congress goes along with a compromise struck last week the Administration will get a Congressional go-ahead to further accelerate military spending in 1985.

title: AMERICAN STUDENTS SCORE AVERAGE OR BELOW IN INTERNATIONAL MATH EXAMS
description: In international tests of mathematical skills, American junior and senior high school students as a group scored average or below, a team of scholars reported yesterday.

title: Frost and Sandburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Citrus Canker Found At 6th Florida Nursery
description: As an infestation of citrus canker was reported today in a sixth Florida nursery, the state's agriculture chief said he would decide by Monday whether to impose a two-week harvesting ban on Florida's citrus industry.

title: A CHRONOLOGY OF BOARD ACTIONS
description: Following is a chronolgy of actions taken by the state's Board of Medical Examiners on foreign medical school students who want to train in New Jersey hospitals and on graduates of those schools who apply for licenses to practice medicine: February 1981 - Began to interview any applicant for licensure who graduated from a foreign medical school, but completed clinical training at an American hospital. Until then, interviews had not been required, but the board said they had become necessary to insure that candidates from foreign medical schools had completed ''four thorough and comprehensive years of medical education.''

title: THEATER REVIEW ; A PEERLESS POIROT GETS HIS MAN
description: DAME AGATHA CHRISTIE turned to playwriting after she was already well-entrenched in her successful career as a mystery writer par excellence. Other writers had been adapting her work for the stage and she felt those plays were dramatically unsuccessful because they followed her plots too closely. So she did her own adaptations from her own novels. She adjusted her murderers, her detectives and her plots.

title: Hugh W. Downe, Jeanne Twiname Are Wed on L.I.
description: At St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church in Southampton, L.I., yesterday Jeanne Copeland Twiname, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Dean Twiname of New York, was married to Hugh Wisner Downe, the son of Susan C. Downe and Edward R. Downe Jr., both of New York. The bride's father performed the ceremony.

title: TEMPLE USPSETS PITT ON FIELD GOAL, 13-12
description: A clutch 50-yard third-down pass, from Lee Saltz to Willie Marshall, set up a 21-yard field goal by Jim Cooper with 26 seconds left to play today that gave Temple a 13-12 upset victory over Pitt.

title: Coach Leads By Example
description: Darrell Coulter, Morgan State's career leader in passing who is now an assistant coach with the team, was in midseason form on defense today during a 44-14 loss to Connecticut.

title: WRITING WITHOUT ROOTS
description: Seth Mydans is a reporter in the Moscow bureau of The New York Times.

title: JOHN HENRY POSTS WIRE-TO-WIRE VICTORY
description: John Henry, the richest race horse ever, gutted out one of the most popular victories of his 82-race career yesterday by leading every step of the way and holding off Win to win the $625,250 Turf Classic at Belmont Park. All Along, the French mare who was last year's horse of the year, finished fourth in her first start since November.

title: A HARVEST OF GLOOM
description: Late September is usually a happy time for Florida citrus growers, with millions of oranges, grapefruits, limes and tangerines nearly ready for harvest. Last week, instead of farm workers preparing to pick the fruit, teams of inspectors swarmed through citrus nurseries in search of a virulent bacteria that threatens to destroy the $2.5 billion industry.

title: Roosevelt to Guarantee $100,000 for Sweep 7
description: Roosevelt Raceway announced today that it would guarantee a minimum payoff of at least $100,000 for its new Sweep Seven betting, which goes into effect Monday night.

title: STARS OVER MONTANA
description: ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of the Chicago bureau of The New York Times.

title: WAREHOUSE CONVERSION KINDLES A BATTLE
description: As neighbors watched the conversion of the old police warehouse at 196 Avenue of the Americas into apartments last spring, they saw work that appeared contrary to the building plan that they knew had been approved. Extra floors were being added. The facade was being changed.

title: DEAL IS STRUCK ON HONG KONG
description: Hong Kong, a financial giant that has long answered to absentee owners, got a further glimpse last week of what its present and future masters are planning. Britain and China announced a draft agreement transforming the British crown colony into a Chinese special administrative region for 50 years after Britain's 99-year lease expires in 1997.

title: THE SHRINKING OF THE STEEL INDUSTRY
description: FOR two decades, Washington

title: LAFAYETTE SUFFERS ITS 2D LOSS IN ROW
description: In Brooklyn Division A action, South Shore sent Lafayette to its second straight loss yesterday with a 22-0 shutout.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Air Bandits
description: The robbery was modern, swift and efficient. The two gunmen flew into the small airport near Overton, Nev., early this month, tied up three witnesses, took a car and drove into town. They ''cleaned out'' a branch of the Valley Bank, the police said, and flew off in their private plane.

title: October Nuptials For Jo Rosenberg
description: Jo Rosenberg, who is on the faculty of the Cornell University Medical College, and Jonathan Hariton, an associate with the New York law firm of Silverman & DiGiovanna, plan to be married Oct. 14 in a civil ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Rosenberg, parents of the future bride, in Albany.

title: About Books
description: THE Swan Hotel in Lambertville not only figures in ''The Skook,'' a new novel by JP (sic) Miller (Warner, New York, $17), but also was the scene of a recent party marking the book's publication. In fact, not only Lambertville, but also much of Hunterdon County and its residents are referred to in the work.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
RECYCLING AWARDS
description: The awards may be new, but at a countywide conference to be held tomorrow evening in White Plains, the emphasis will clearly be on the used and the re-used.

title: FRENCH BISTRO DISHES TO ENLIVEN THE LAST DYS OF SUMMER
description: SOME foods never go out of fashion. As the evenings grow cooler, certain French bistro dishes go perfectly with the last vegetables and herbs of the season. A classic such as veal kidneys in a mustard sauce, can be served with buttered noodles and zucchini seasoned with tarragon and chives. A tender piece of calf's liver, its juices deglazed with Madeira wine can be accompanied by mashed potatoes and grilled tomato topped with pesto sauce. With these simple bourgeois dishes, drink a red wine - a light Bordeaux or Beaujolais with the liver, a full red Burgundy with the kidneys.
