description: GROUP FOR BIRD LOVERS

title: Best Wishes, Howard Cosell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BRAZILIAN WIZARDRY
description: When the World Team Olympiad begins in Seattle at the end of next month there are expected to be 51 teams in the Open Division. Many will be employing sophisticated modern systems based on relay structures and perhaps also the ''strong pass.''

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CURBS DISABILITY ACTIONS
description: The United States Attorney's office for the District of New Jersey has decided not to defend the Government in a small number of ''indefensible'' cases in which the Social Security Administration has denied disability benefits, Federal officials say.

title: PACT ON WEAPONS KEEPS MOST REAGAN PROPOSALS
description: The compromise on the military budget reached by Congressional leaders and the White House preserves most of the Reagan Administration's proposed weapons buildup, according to military specialists in Congress.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur - will be celebrated a little differently this year by one Jewish group in central New Jersey.

title: MITTERRAND AND KOHL HONOR DEAD OF VERDUN
description: The leaders of France and West Germany visited this battle site today to pay silent homage to the millions of their compatriots killed in two world wars.

title: DORMITORY PLANS OPPOSED IN CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN ADETERIORATING neighborhood of boarded-up windows, vacant lots and deserted buildings here is facing an unusual problem: Too many people want to develop it.

title: PICKING OUT THE RIGHT BAG TO PACK
description: ''No one set of luggage will do everything well,'' in the view of R. Michael Meek, whose family has been in the retail luggage business in Denver for more than 110 years. ''It's like with cars,'' said Mr. Meek, president of the A. E. Meek Trunk and Baggage Company. ''A four-door sedan will do everything reasonably well, but it won't do special things. Sometimes a two-door subcompact or a station wagon will do much better.''

title: FRESH START FOR A DARK THEATER
description: John V. Lindsay, the former New York City mayor, extended his theatrical career into playhouse management last week when he took on a job as chairman of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: ; Can You Compare Rose and Cobb?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Eliza Mauran Wed to Nigel Blackwell
description: Eliza Pumpelly Mauran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mauran of Providence, R.I., and Nigel Stirling Blackwell, a son of Mrs. Richard Blackwell of Tubney, near Abingdon, Oxfordshire, England, and the late Mr. Blackwell, were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church in Providence, R.I. The Rev. Thomas E. Ahlburn performed the ceremony.

title: Caroline A. Evans Becomes a Bride In Basking Ridge
description: Caroline Anderson Evans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Horton Evans of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Carlisle Jones, a son of Mary Philbrick Jones of Summit, N.J., and Carlisle Jones of New York and Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Calvin Jackson performed the ceremony at the Basking Ridge (N.J.) Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. William H. Felmeth.

title: A VATICAN STATEMENT CLEAR ON LIFE'S START
description: To the Editor:

title: Shipping a Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Horton, Researcher, Is Wed to James Polos
description: Susan Horton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Roscoe Horton of White Plains, was married there yesterday to James Polos, a son of Mrs. Charles Jerabek of West Islip, L.I., and the late Second Lieut. James Polos, U.S.A. The Rev. Clifford Lawrence performed the Congregational ceremony at the Church in the Highlands.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Broadcast TV
description: The New York City Opera's ''Carmen'' (part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series, Wednesday at 8 P.M. on channels 13 and 49, with simulcast over WNCN-FM) should be a natural for television, mostly because of one person: Victoria Vergara, the sexiest opera singer I have ever seen, as Carmen.

title: PREPAREDNESS, IN PART, HELPS TO CONTAIN STORM'S DAMAGE
description: When Hurricane Diana began stalking the coast here earlier in the month, Rick McLean, town manager in this beachfront community of 2,000, was worried. He knew what a storm with 130-mile- an-hour winds, eight-foot waves and a flood tide can do.

title: BUSY SEASON OF MUSIC IN STATE GETS UNDER WAY
description: PREMIERES, debuts, new programs and a new theater are highlights of what promises to be an exciting 1984-85 season for New Jersey concertgoers.

title: SPLIT ENZ
description: Split Enz Sony 54 minutes. $39.95

title: TETERBORO BRIDLES AT F.A.A. CHARGES
description: TETERBORO PRIVATE pilots and officials of charter airlines based at Teterboro Airport take exception to complaints by executives of scheduled airlines that private aircraft are partly to blame for delays at Newark International and La Guardia Airports.

title: DORIS LESSING SAYS SHE USED PEN NAME TO SHOW NEW WRITERS' DIFFICULTIES
description: In an attempt to dramatize the difficulties faced by unknown writers, the acclaimed novelist Doris Lessing recently wrote two novels under a pseudonym. After a rejection by her longtime British publisher, the books were published in Britain and in the United States with little fanfare and few sales.

title: FEDERAL COURTS OFF LIMITS TO TV
description: The 26 judges who make the rules decided last week that the Federal court system is not ready for television. The ''alleged public benefits,'' said a report to the Judicial Conference of the United States headed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, ''are outweighed by the risks.''

title: Pushing the Meter
description: When the Metric Conversion Act became Federal law in 1975, proponents hoped to put the nation on the metric system by 1985. But after a flurry of early, well-publicized steps toward that voluntary goal, where have all the converts gone?

title: The Past was More Exotic
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TREND BUILDS, THE PROBLEMS INCREASE
description: THE advantages of computer commuting - a bucolic lifestyle, reduced traveling time, and closer family ties - have been widely noted. The drawbacks are only beginning to appear. But social scientists say that ways of handling those drawbacks will be critical.

title: FOREIGN POLICY: WHEN IT PAYS TO 'CUT AND RUN'
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
UNTOWARD DELAY WILL BE SELF-DEFEATING
description: WHEN the right opportunity arrives for the Federal Government to sell Conrail, we should take advantage of it. A combination of favorable conditions for a sale has been developing in recent months. To impose an artificial delay, as some in Congress have suggested, would risk losing the opportunity when it arrives.

title: PENN ATTACK ROUTS DARTMOUTH BY 55-24
description: Penn, which gained a share of the Ivy League title last season by routing Dartmouth on the final weekend, scored an even more one-sided victory over the Big Green today.

title: SULTAN OF A YOUNG NATION GIVES THE CITY A CHECK FOR 100,000 MEALS FOR ELDERLY
description: When the Sultan of Brunei Darussalam handed Mayor Koch an envelope yesterday, the Mayor asked: ''May I open it?''

title: Baker Loses Last Bid For TV in the Senate
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, lost a test vote Friday and conceded defeat in his farewell bid to open the Senate to gavel-to-gavel television and radio coverage.

title: Dolphins Get Johnson
description: The Miami Dolphins, in the market for a running back ever since they lost the injured Andra Franklin for the season, obtained Pete Johnson from the San Diego Chargers yesterday for a second-round choice in next spring's draft. The trade is the second involving the Dolphins and Chargers in the last month.

title: EXAMINING QUALITY OF HISPANIC LIFE
description: THE special concern of the county's Hispanic community will be the subject of a hearing to be held Wednesday at the South West Yonkers Community Center. The hearing, ''Issues Affecting the Quality of Life of Hispanics in New York State,'' is one of a series the Governor's Advisory Committee for Hispanic Affairs has been holding statewide.

title: A NEW MET SEASON AND A FINALE FOR BLISS
description: At the end of the Metropolitan Opera's current fiscal year, on July 31, 1985, Anthony A. Bliss, who will be then be 72 years old, will step down as general manager of the company. His has been a lifelong devotion to opera, - or prelifelong, since his father preceded him at the Met - first as president of the board when Rudolf Bing was general manager, then as general manager himself, in fact and eventually in name, for the last decade.

title: MANY GARDENERS ARE SPECIALISTS IN INTENSITY;
description: There are Gardeners and there are gardeners. Gardeners grow the biggest and the best of everything. They are the first to know about the latest methods and varieties and they are the first to harvest anything.

title: IN SWABIA, MEALTIME IS SP"ATZLE TIME
description: In other places the staple may be potatoes, but in Swabia in the southwest region of West Germany it is sp"atzle - fat, irregularly shaped noodles served with meat, in soup or topped with melted cheese and onions. The distinctive taste and texture of sp"atzle results from a time-consuming process; soft egg dough is sliced into thin strips that are whisked from the cutting board into boiling water. Labor-saving devices abound, but the best sp"atzle, say the people in Swabia, are made by hand.

title: Correction
description: The island and the inn of the same name described in ''Sunsets Gleam on a Maine Retreat'' (Travel, Aug. 19) were misspelled. The correct spelling is Islesboro.

title: The Bombs Bursting in Air
description: When we are children we know absolutely that when we grow up we will be firemen, test pilots, policemen, railroad engineers, tugboat captains, nurses and Presidents. Most times, when we grow up, most of us are none of these. Yet we have had our dreams. Then there is George Plimpton, our perennial child, a fellow with an apparently limitless capacity for playacting, an indefatigable joiner, who manages to sell video games, pitch major league baseball, quarterback major league football, sidestep charging rhinos, conduct orchestras, ignite firecrackers and in general act out his childish fancies, then write about them, sharing them with us.

title: KENNELY'S G.O.P. CHALLENGER HOPES 2d TIME AROUND IS BETTER
description: HARTFORD HERSCHEL A. KLEIN was reflecting last week on what a difference two years can make in an election campaign.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION
description: IT'S FALL: THE HAWKS HEAD SHOUTHZ

title: THE PUERTO RICAN BISHOPS' 1960 'BLUNDER'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HELLO, THIS IS HAL, COMPUTER SALESTHING'
description: EACH of us finds our own way to cope with computers as they sneak into almost every aspect of our lives. Not only are we confronted with them as we venture into the world every day, but now they are reaching out to question us over the telephone lines, in the privacy of our own homes. I never thought that I would be talking with one of these machines, but a recent ''conversation'' I had with an interviewer over the telephone for an insurance survey questions that assumption.

title: HIS ANGRY OLD AGE
description: David Herbert Donald, a professor of history at Harvard University, is writing a biography of Thomas Wolfe. FAULKNER

title: No Headline
description: Shawn O'Neil Is a Bride

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LONG ISLAND SOUND'S BIGGEST PROBLEM: EDUCATION
description: AS fall settles in and we reflect on the summer past, many of us will remember heading for the water to escape the heat and humidity. For many residents of Connecticut and New York, this watery haven in which to cool off as well as to sail, fish, swim, or watch the sunset is Long Island Sound. But last summer also saw beach closings, congested harbors and dirty-looking water.

title: 2 Women Die in Buggy Crash
description: An Amish woman and her daughter who were riding a horse-drawn buggy were killed in a collision with a pickup truck Thursday. The state police identified the women as Melinda Peachey, 51 years old, and Nancy, 23, of Newmanstown, in Lebanon County.

title: SCHOOLS FOR PROFESSIONAL COOKS
description: FOR many years, anyone interested in entering the food service industry had to leave New Jersey to attend either the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., or Johnson and Wales College in Providence, R.I., because these were the only accredited cooking schools in the country.

title: JOHN DOS PASSOS - ODYSSEY OF AN OPTIMIST
description: John Dos Passos was a seeker. He always hated institutions. They were built on fear, he said. He hated bigness because of what it did to the individual, and in this animus he never changed. We talked about this near the end of his life when he was in New York to sponsor his friend Bill Buckley for the Century Club.

title: Ringing Rhetoric
description: It was with enjoyment and satisfaction that I read William Safire's article, ''Ringing Rhetoric: The Return of Political Oratory'' (Aug. 19).

title: BOOK-OF-THE-MONTH EXPANDS
description: Book-of-the-Month Records has been quietly selling classical, jazz and other recordings for a decade, using its vast mail-order network to reach potential buyers. All the records have been licensed productions - recordings made by someone else but pressed anew and repackaged by Book-of-the-Month Records for its clientele. While some of the records, even though recorded by someone else, were exclusive to Book-of-the Month Records, such as the highly acclaimed ''Duke Ellington at Fargo, 1940,'' most were available in stores - or had been at one time - through the original record company.

title: THE PROS AND CONS OF 'COMPUTER COMMUTING'
description: LENOX,Mass.

title: MERIT STUDENTS LISTED
description: -seven New Jersey high school and preparatory school students have qualified as semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's 30th annual merit program.

title: On the Record ; Boston's Archbishop on Abortion Issue
description: From an interview Thursday with Archbishop Bernard F. Law of Boston:

title: Royals Maintain Lead
description: Darryl Motley drove home two runs with a triple and Dan Quisenberry earned his 43d save, helping the Kansas City Royals maintain their lead in the American League West with a 4-2 victory today over the Oakland A's.

title: REUTERS REPORTER RECOUNTS LEBANON ESCAPE
description: A correspondent for Reuters held since Aug. 29 by unidentified gunmen in Lebanon said today that he gained his freedom by escaping from a cell where he had been held.

title: WINFIELD MAKES THE SEASON ANOTHER LEARNING EXPERIENCE
description: SO who does Dave Winfield think he is anyway? Rod Carew? Bill Madlock? Pete Rose? Maybe Roberto Clemente or Stan Musial or Ted Williams. Will he ever be Dave Winfield again?

title: Whitney Got There First
description: To the Editor:

title: PASS BY HENRY LIFTS CLIFTON
description: Mike Henry hit John Hanle with a 39-yard touchdown pass in the fourth quarter to lift Clifton over Paramus, 14-6, in the season opener for both yesterday in Clifton.

title: TAKING TEMPLE TO HOME
description: LAST year, a Larchmont grandfather couldn't get to temple for the High Holy Days. On Rosh ha-Shanah morning he went into the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center for major surgery. ''But I went into the operation feeling very brave, very brave,'' he said later. ''That program truly inspired me.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Recession in Sight?

title: Inquiry Into Death Is Asked
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called for a Federal investigation into police treatment of a black man whose death last month while in police custody touched off rioting in the east Georgia town of Waynesboro. Earl Shinhoster, southeast regional director of the association, cited reports of possible police mistreatment of the man, Larry Gardner, and on Friday called for the Justice Department to ''undertake a full scale Federal civil rights investigation'' into Mr. Gardner's death Aug. 17.

title: U.S. SEEN KEEPING EAST-WEST RESEARCH ROLE
description: Several recent developments, including a softening of Federal opposition, have increased the likelihood of continued American participation in the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, an East-West research institute near Vienna.

title: THREE NEW MOVIES ENRICH THEIR GENRES
description: Part of the pleasure of watching ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' or ''The Seagull'' or ''Death of a Salesman'' or ''Charley's Aunt,'' or just about any good, time-tested play with which one is familiar, is knowing the work well enough to be able to anticipate what's about to happen, and then, if all goes as it should, to be surprised all over again. In each case there are obligatory moments that, in superior productions, seem utterly new, though they also benefit from one's earlier encounters with them.

title: Amy Susan Abromowitz Married to David Baxter
description: Amy Susan Abromowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Lewis Abromowitz of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to David Carl Baxter, a son of Mrs. Frank Alden McChesney of Cranbury, N.J., and Wellfleet, and Milton Carl Baxter of Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. The Rev. William C. Heffner performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco.

title: Abby Jean Pirnie Weds Brian Maas
description: Abby Jean Pirnie, a daughter of Duncan Pirnie of Englewood, N.J., and the late Esther Lewis Pirnie, was married yesterday to Brian Maas, a son of Shirley Maas of Denville, N.J., and Preston Maas of Bloomfield, N.J. Kathleen Prim, a Fairfax County, Va., civil celebrant, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gregg J. Wright in Falls Church, Va.

title: Pasquale Putting Jet Units In Gear
description: Larry Pasquale is the apostle of punt, the conductor of kickoff.

title: A RUSSIAN RECANTS
description: For whatever reasons, Oleg G. Bitov has gone to a lot of trouble to get from Italy to Russia. After he disappeared from the Venice Film Festival a year ago, Mr. Bitov, who was then culture editor of a weekly Soviet publication, turned up in London saying he had skipped to the West to protest the Kremlin's cultural policy and its downing of a Korean airliner.

title: RUTGERS STUNS SYRACUSE, 19-0
description: Rutgers capitalized on four of seven Syracuse turnovers tonight and upset the Orangemen, 19-0, before a crowd of 41,810 at the Carrier Dome.

title: Middlebury
description: To the Editor:

title: PACT IN AUTO AND COAL INDUSTRIES VIEWED AS A BLOW TO INFLATION
description: Economists and labor experts said today that automobile workers and coal miners appeared to have struck the year's most effective blow against high inflation in the tentative contracts they had just reached.

title: ENTISTS FIND L.I. COMPETITION FIERCE
description: '' WHEN my oldest son was born 15 years ago, I wanted him to follow in my footsteps. When I got ready to retire, I wanted him to take over my practice. Today, I would discourage him.''

title: YET ANOTHER DEADLY SYNDROME
description: Dave Barry is a humor columnist for The Miami Herald and the author of the forthcoming self-help book ''Babies and Other Hazards of Sex.'' THE WENDY DILEMMA

title: Data Bank; September 23, 1984
MORGAN GUARANTY CUTS ITS PRIME RATE
description: Morgan Guaranty cut its prime rate on Friday by one-quarter of a percentage point to 12 3/4 percent - the first reduction in the key lending rate since February 1983. Though no other major banks followed Morgan's lead, analysts predicted the big banks would drop their prime rates in the near future. The cut comes at a time when interest rates have declined, when the economy has slowed appreciably and when many Federal Reserve watchers are convinced that the central bank has eased its monetary policy. If the drop becomes an industry-wide move, this should weaken interest rates further, analysts said. The dollar went into a free fall on foreign exchange markets, partly in reaction to the prime rate cut, partly because the Labor Department reported a five-tenths of one percent spurt in consumer prices during August, but also because of a huge intervention effort on the part of the West German central bank to support its sagging mark. The Deutsche Bundesbank reportedly spent $450 million to support the mark, which had fallen as low as 3.177 to the dollar. Once the dollar began to fall, it lost about 4 percent of its value against the mark in 90 minutes, closing in New York at 3.043 marks. The dollar also fell against the British pound and French franc, after having set all-time highs earlier in the week.

title: CHESS TITLE GAME DRAWN IN MOSCOW
description: Anatoly Karpov, the 33-year-old world chess champion, and his challenger, 21-year-old Gary Kasparov, agreed to a draw after 44 moves of the fourth game of their title match in Moscow yesterday.

title: Reagan Team Seeks 50% Of Coast Hispanic Vote
description: Encouraged by polls showing President Reagan leading Walter F. Mondale among Hispanic voters in California, the Reagan campaign is opening nine Hispanic field offices in California.

title: HIS TORMENTS SHAPED HIS POLITICS
description: DOS PASSOS

title: FOR MEXICANS, CONCERN RISES ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Mexico, which prides itself on its image of civil liberty and social calm, has recently seen a series of events that have raised alarm among opposition groups and even some officials of the governing party.

title: 'GENTRIFICATION OF EAST VILLAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: RETHINKING THE HONOR SYSTEM
description: A committee dominated by Air Force officers took control of the honor system at the Air Force Academy last week because of ''overwhelming evidence'' of cheating by cadets and a breakdown in enforcement of the code.

title: U.S. RESOLVE TO KEEP BEIRUT EMBASSY IS AFFIRMED
description: An Assistant Secretary of State, Richard W. Murphy, said here today that the bombing of the United States Embassy on Thursday had failed to shake American resolve to remain in Lebanon.

title: Burundi Is Refusing to Clear Parcels for the U.S. Embassy
description: Customs officials are refusing to clear more than a ton of parcels addressed to the United States Embassy.

title:
TV VIEW;
'PAPER DOLLS' IS A GLOSSY POP FANTASY
description: This evening's two-hour premiere of ''Paper Dolls,'' on ABC at 9 o'clock, does have the distinction of being a television rarity. Most of the film is simply a remake not of some Hollywood classic but of a made-for-TV movie that racked up some impressive ratings a little over two years ago. The subject is New York's modeling industry. One of the chief characters is a tall young lady who bears at least a passing resemblance to Brooke Shields, complete with protective mother. And the entire production is a glossy testimonial to popular fantasies of the chic life in New York, with its posh stores, beautiful people and seductive promises of easy sex and accessible drugs. Add a thumpingly contemporary music track, along the lines of Michael Jackson's ''Billie Jean,'' and you have a fairly accurate idea about where the producer's exploration-exploitation tactics are headed.

title: Debra Slotnick Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer H. Slotnick of New Rochelle, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Debra Slotnick, to Michael Miron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Miron of Geneva, formerly of White Plains.

title: PROPER CARE WILL MAKE YOUR CARPETS AND RUGS LAST LONGER
description: ALL carpets and rugs regardless of whether they are made of natural or synthetic fibers or a combination of two or more different types - will last a lot longer and look a lot better if they are vacuumed frequently and regularly given a thorough cleaning - for instance, by shampooing or steam cleaning. In addition, it is especially important to clean up stains that occur through carelessness or accidents promptly - if you want to make sure these blemishes do not become permanent. The sooner you clean up an accidental spill, the better the chance of getting the stain out completely.

title: 2 REPUBLICANS CITE RECORDS IN STATE SENATE
description: STATE Senator John E. Flynn of Yonkers, who is seeking re-election in November to a 10th term in office, says he plans to campaign in the remaining weeks before Election Day as he always has, by concentrating on appearances before organized groups.

title: Nancy Santos Married To Kenneth Fishman
description: Nancy E. Santos, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Santos of Medford, Mass., was married yesterday to Kenneth J. Fishman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Fishman of Lattingtown, L.I. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky performed the ceremony at the Goddard Chapel of Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title:
ART;
HUMAN PRESENCE IMBUES SCULPTURE
description: JUST now, with major showings of primitive art heading a new season at the Metropolitan and the Museum of Modern Art, the public is more aware than ever of the scope of creativity found in early societies.

title: GIANT PASSING TO TEST TAMPA
description: The Giants have been living by the long pass and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers have built their defense around stopping the long pass. Something may give Sunday afternoon when the teams meet at 4 P.M. at Giants Stadium.

title:
GARDENING;
CREATING IDEAL LOAM FROM SAND OR CLAY
description: SOMEWHERE in most any garden book will be found a reference to garden loam as the ideal soil in which to grow plants. To most gardeners, however, that ideal growing medium is as elusive as the mythical holy grail. The facts of life are that most of us are blessed with either clay or sand and must make the best of our less-than- ideal situation.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: Eugene Kennedy presents an informative article, but the implications in the article and in the fears expressed by several businessmen cited belie what Catholic theology understands the pastoral letter to be, and what the mature moral conscience demands it be.

title: PRIVATE FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE EL ONCE CLATTERED
description: Since the Third Avenue el was dismantled in 1954, a corridor of high-rise apartment buildings has been created along the avenue, replacing what had been a streetscape of five-story tenements and low commercial structures. Now, another tall apartment house is getting started at the 84th Street corner, just two blocks from two other residential towers that are nearing completion at 1430 and 1441 Third Avenue, between 81st and 82d Streets.

title: Alice Young, a Lawyer, Becomes Bride Of Thomas L. Shortall, a Stockbroker
description: Alice Young, the founding partner of the New York office of the international law firm of Graham & James, was married yesterday to Thomas Leonard Shortall, a vice president of Smith Barney & Company in New York. The Rev. Ann Brewster Jones performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Troops in Afghanistan Hold French Journalist
description: A French journalist taken prisoner in Afghanistan by Government troops six days ago is being held at the town of Spinbaldak, near the Pakistani border, the Kabul radio said today.

title: KENNEDY TOPS LEHMAN, 46-6
description: After two seasons of losing hard defensive battles to Lehman, Kennedy High finally devised a winning formula. The key ingredient was offense.

title: POLY PREP ROLLS TO A 42-2 VICTORY
description: Poly Prep, which went undefeated in nine games last year after winning only two in 1982, registered its second victory this season with a 42-2 trouncing of Pingry yesterday on the winners' field in Brooklyn. Last week, Poly defeated Sheepshead Bay of the Public Schools Athletic League, 26-8.

title: 20 Groups Ask 4 Debates By Reagan and Mondale
description: Twenty groups representing labor, consumers and the elderly asked President Reagan and his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, on Friday to agree to four televised debates instead of two.

title: JERSEY FIRE PANEL TO SUGGEST AMUSEMENT-PARK IMPROVEMENTS
description: The head of a state panel investigating the fatal Haunted Castle fire at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park said this week that the panel had approved suggestions for smoke detectors and emergency lighting in buildings at amusement parks.

title: HOW DENTISTS COPE WITH PATIENTS AND THE PSYCHOLOGY OF FEAR
description: I KNOW the look of someone who is afraid. The eyes wander toward the ceiling or floor, but not at me. The hands are clammy and fidgety, the body in constant motion, as if in search of a comfortable position; the sentences incomplete and punctuated by a nervous giggle. I notice the dry lips, the crackling voice, and sometimes a childish raising of the hands to the mouth while turning the head away.

title: A MANAGED ECONOMY CAN TURN UNRULY
description: Surveying the new economic strategies of East Europe's Communist states, a Roman Catholic history professor who is a close adviser to the Solidarity movement in Poland observed, ''One by one, they are confronting their fictions.'' Whether these governments are indeed conceding the existence of critical flaws in state-managed economies is debatable. But many are casting about for ways to stimulate productivity while leaving Communist control unthreatened. Once-taboo words such as ''incentives,'' ''motivation'' and even ''free market'' are regularly used in discussions about spurring productivity.

title: STRANGE SIGHTS; TAXI TANK
description: ''Experimental No. 304'' is not the latest home computer or food additive. It's the newest yellow cab in New York, bearing a special promise.

title: CORRECTION
description: A story on coping with Alzheimer's disease in the Long Island Weekly on Sept. 2 inaccurately identified a geriatrician affiliated with Huntington Hospital. He is Dr. Fredrick T. Sherman.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Avenging a Moose
description: Three states - Maine, Vermont and New York - cooperated in the investigation. Agents of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation trailed the suspect from Vermont to New York State, where he was seized.

title: UCONN LAW SCHOOL BEGINS A NEW ERA
description: ALONG with the new school year,

title: Correction
description: A chart accompanying the article on Texas oil last Sunday listed an incorrect number of employees in the state's oil industry. The figures were in thousands.

title: 'HISTORIC' DEAL ENDS WALKOUTS AT GENERAL MOTORS
description: While 1984 is not 1970, when autos were a main engine of growth and a prolonged auto strike sent the economy into an early stall, economists and politicians of both parties concerned about their prospects in Middle Western industrial belt were breathing a little easier on Friday.

title: Robin Tilghman Wed to Director
description: The marriage of Robin Shiland Tilghman, a television and stage actress, to Byam Kerby Stevens 3d, a theatrical director and acting coach in New York, took place yesterday at the Fairfield, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Austin Tilghman, also of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Jr. of Jericho, L.I. The Rev. Henry Ashe Tilghman, an Episcopal priest and uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: FORCED TO CONQUER
description: John Boardman, the author of ''The Greeks Overseas,'' is writing a book on the Parthenon and its marbles. THE HELLENISTIC WORLD AND THE COMING OF ROME

title: LURING WEEDS INTO A FATAL CHEMICAL TRAP
description: An amino acid that can trick plants into bleeding to death could alter the way farmers control such common weeds as mustard and purslane, according to two scientists at the University of Illinois at Urbana- Champaign. Professors Constantin A. Rebeiz and Herbert J. Hopen said last week that the substance, delta- aminolaevulnic acid, or ALA, occurs naturally in all plants and animals.

title: Record 58-Yard Kick
description: Kevin Mills, a senior at Shore Regional High School in West Long Branch, broke a New Jersey state high school football record yesterday for the longest field goal when he kicked one from 58 yards in Shore's 51-17 victory over Pinelands in Tuckerton.

title: MUSIC: ALICE COLTRANE QUARTET PERFORMS
description: Alice Coltrane's appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday - the first local concert date in seven years by the keyboardist-harpist and widow of John Coltrane - was timed to commemorate her husband's birth. The great jazz saxophonist would have been 58 on Sept. 23, and in tribute to him, Mrs. Coltrane and a splendid quartet that included the saxophonist Sam Rivers, the bassist Reggie Workman, and the drummer Rashied Ali, recreated ''Impressions,'' one of his complex, jubilant free jazz compositions.

title: U.S. AIDES ADMIT BEIRUT SECURITY WAS INADEQUATE
description: Administration officials acknowledged today that security at the United States Embassy near East Beirut was deficient when American diplomats moved there in July, and was still inadequate on Thursday when a car bomb exploded outside the building.

title: YONKERS BIAS SUIT DRAWS TO AN END
description: AFTER more than eight months of testimony and a seven-month recess that saw attempts to reach an out-of-court settlement fail, final arguments were heard last week in the Federal Government's housing and school desegregation case against the city of Yonkers and its Board of Education.

title: Nets, Williams Settle
description: Buck Williams and the Nets have settled their longstanding salary dispute several days before the two parties were to have appeared before an arbitrator. Williams, an all-star power forward, who averaged 15.7 points and 12.3 rebounds a game last season, agreed to an extension of his contract that amends the final two years of the six-year pact he signed when the Nets made him their top draft choice in 1981.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR nearly five years, Doris Friedensohn of Leonia and Barbara Rubin of Manhattan, instructors of women's studies at Jersey City State College, have fervently believed that women's roles in history have been neglected.

title: BIRTHPLACE OF SUFFRAGIST TO GET NEW RECOGNITION
description: The parlor is painted pink, linoleum covers the white pine floors and a television aerial is nailed to the roof. Home to a private family for the last 35 years, the 1817 structure has long stood in oblivion on a back road in Berkshire County.

title: CONSUMER RATES
A MAN KNOWN BY ALL, AND BY NONE
description: TO this day, more than a century since he first appeared on the back roads of Westchester County in New York and Middlesex County in south-central Connecticut, no one knows his real name, where he came from or why he chose the bizarre, lonely life he led.

title: A TV TRIBUTE UPSETS BALANCHINE STEREOTYPES
description: Just when recent tributes to George Balanchine on television suggested there was little to unearth regarding the late choreographer's work in that medium, along comes the Museum of Broadcasting with an extended view of his televised ballets since the 1950's. Many of these programs will come as a surprise, even as a shock, to the new public that discovered Balanchine when it flocked to his New York City Ballet in the 1970's.

title: LINES DRAWN IN SCHOOLS' FISCAL FIGHT
description: DESPITE a combined loss of almost $7.5 million, the school year began as usual for the students in eight Long Island school districts involved in the bankruptcy of two security firms, Lion Capital and RTD Securities.

title: OTHER PROFESSIONS CITE 'GLUT' ON ISLAND
description: LONG ISLAND'S professional glut extends beyond dentists, but many lawyers and doctors feel they are coping better than their dental counterparts.

title: RINGING RHETORIC
description: Among William Safire's visions for the future: ''I see an oratory delivered by the same person who wrote the lines.''

title: Bach's Birthday Brings a Deluge
description: Because Johann Sebastian Bach was so extraordinarily prolific, performers and record companies have been gearing up for the 1985 Bach tricentennial for the last three or four years. As the date draws nearer, the number of new Bach disks hitting the market is bound to increase, but it seems the deluge has already begun: At the moment, each new recording of a Bach work arrives simultaneously with a competing version released simultaneously on another label. Not surprisingly, these pairs of disks often contain performances informed by points of view that - in terms of instruments, performing forces and stylistic philosophies - differ widely.

title: OPEN OPENINGS
description: The open game has become less and less open in recent years. This can be seen most clearly in the case of the Ruy Lopez, especially in defenses to it such as the Breyer, the Smyslov and the modern treatment of the old Chigorin. The complaint of the average player is that this opening, the noblest of the 1 P-K4, P-K4 openings, has become as baroque as the most tortuous of Queen's Gambits or Catalan Openings.

title: MISSILES IN THE SHOP
description: When the Sidewinder air-to-air missile works, it works very well indeed; witness the Israeli Air Force's successes last year in dogfights with Syrian aircraft. But a General Accounting Office investigator told Congress last week that thousands of the United States' Sidewinders, as well as its Sparrow missiles, are sidelined for maintenance or technical improvements.

title: BROWN WILL MERGE ITS PREMEDICAL AND M.D. STUDY PROGRAM
description: Starting next year, Brown University will admit most of its medical school students directly from high school in an innovative program that will merge the university's premedical and M.D. degree programs.

title: MARGARET HEILBRUN WEDS KEVIN CROTTY
description: Margaret Heilbrun, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Heilbrun of New York, was married yesterday to Kevin Michael Crotty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Crotty of Buffalo. The Rev. Gerald J. McMahon, a Roman Catholic priest and uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: EXILE IS CONVICTED AS OMEGA 7 LEADER
description: A Cuban exile was convicted in Manhattan yesterday of carrying out a murder and numerous bombings as the leader of an anti-Castro terrorist group known as Omega 7.

title: THOUGHTS OF ALI: VICTIM OF SPORT HE SAVED
description: MOST of the words spoken and lines written last week were in the past tense - eulogies for a man who still was very much alive. Perhaps, it is the nature of boxing and the toll it exacts that prompts some people to think that boxers die young no matter how old they live to be. But this was not some Johnny-come-lately or has-been, a statistic for the medical profession to use in its continuing debate about the risks inherent in the sport. This story was about Muhammad Ali, a man with a special place in boxing and American history. This story touched some people in a more personal way.

title: TAXES TAKE SPOTLIGHT IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON THE state's tax pendulum appeared poised for a downward swing last week, following a meeting between Governor Kean and the Democratic leaders of the Legislature to discuss ways to reduce the taxes raised two years ago in the middle of the recession.

title: D [ n ]  - D [ o ] (1xr)  . A Formula For Trouble.
description: Forty years ago, on the West Side piers of New York City, if you were broke on a Monday morning there was no problem. You could borrow $20, with $30 to be paid back on payday, which was Friday. If you didn't have $30 on Friday, that was no problem. You could pay $40 on Wednesday. The extra $10, then $20, then $40, was called vigorish. (A detective friend reports that today it's called The Vig.) It kept mounting. Sooner or later, your family bailed you out in a big scene, or you ended up in St. Clare's Hospital.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden, who lost his ninth game in his last outing on a balk despite striking out 16 batters for the second straight game, goes after his 17th victory. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers , at Detroit, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.)

title: Mullaney Legally Blind An injury in last Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons, has left
description: Mark Mullaney , the Minnesota Vikings' defensive end, legally blind. Mullaney suffered a blowout fracture of the orbit, the bony structure in which the eye sets.

title: MONTCLAIR STATE ROUTS KEAN
description: Montclair State, making its fourth appearance in the Pride Bowl, routed Kean yesterday, 43-3, before 5,200 fans at Schools Stadium in Newark.

description: WASHINGTON WITH only two weeks remaining before members of Congress return home to campaign, time is running out for reauthorization of the Superfund hazardous-waste cleanup law this year.

description: House

title: DESIGN IMPROVES RECEIVERS
description: The multifarious field of audio grows in many directions all at once. No sooner does one tendency seem to take hold than a countervailing development is launched, leaving observers puzzled whether all these conflicting happening are the result of vigorous competition or merely of clever tradesters hedging their bets.

title: GELATO$
description: TELTo the Editor: The article on Rome's ice cream was delightful, and I am going to take it with me in December on my 18th trip to this wonderful city. Fortunately, most of the gelaterias stay open in winter, although they cannot quite understand why Americans love ice cream all year round.

title: IOWA IS DEFEATED BY OHIO STATE, 45-26
description: Keith Byars ran, passed and threw for four touchdowns today, leading Ohio State to a 45-26 victory over Iowa in their Big Ten Conference opener.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: No Such Thing As Too Many Swans What is the magic number that suddenly creates an ''overpopulation'' of mute swans as mentioned in the article, ''State Studies Swan Population'' (Aug. 12). Who decides this magic number, and why?

title: SCHNABEL'S STYLE ILLUMINATES SCHUBERT'S SONATAS
description: Good performances of Schubert's piano music, all vividly recorded with the latest engineering techniques, continue to appear on records. But they will perhaps always be measured against a handful of hollow-sounding, blunted issues made many years ago, when records turned faster and sounded much farther away.

title: PORTUGAL FEARS THE IMPACT OF TOURISTS' ILLNESS
description: Portuguese authorities are worried that a reported outbreak of intestinal disorders among Scandinavian visitors to a popular Mediterranean vacation area could seriously affect tourism.

title: NEW JAPANESE SPOT ON OLD SITE
description: IN Hartsdale where Shimizu-ya once stood, Omasa now presides. If customers have not noticed any change, it would hardly be surprising, for the restaurant remains under the friendly and gracious direction of Noriko (Mary) and Masaru (Steve) Yamada. Those curious about the new name might note the union of ''O,'' the last letter of Mrs. Yamada's first name, and ''Masa,'' the first four letters of Mr. Yamada's first name.

title: THE POWER OF PERSONALITY
description: AUDRAN SHE IS A FRENCH ACTRESS who is relatively unknown in the United States, though many may remember her as Cara in ''Brideshead Revisited.'' She will next appear in the miniseries ''Mistral's Daughter,'' which begins tomorrow on CBS- TV. A woman with superb posture, a sharp, direct gaze and chiseled features, she says: ''One must have tremendous willpower and a respect for the body, not just so the results will please someone else, but as a respect for life itself. Beauty is a result of the state of your soul. If you are afraid, you age 20 years. You should learn to see yourself in a good situation.'' AIMEE TO CATCH A GLIMPSE OF her on a Paris street, hidden behind a cloud of black hair and big dark glasses - shorter than one imagines - it would be easy to forget that she is a symbol of seductive womanliness. Easy, that is, until she smiles. Then the seduction truly begins. And when she starts to speak, as any of those who saw her in ''A Man and a Woman'' will remember, the entrapment is complete. ''If I am beautiful,'' she says, ''well, it starts with the look you begin life with. For me, a beautiful woman is Ava Gardner. After 30, even 25, it is what's within you that counts. What I hope is that as I grow older I do not lose my sensuality.'' Of her current relationship with the Parisian designer Emanuel Ungaro, she says, ''What can I say when he told Italian television two years ago that he has waited to meet me for 20 years.

title: HAROLD EICHHORN
description: Harold Eichhorn, the leading alumni figure in track and field affairs for New York University for almost two decades, died here early today.

title: Miss Bernstein to Wed Thomas C. Hunter Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bernstein of Washington and Bethany Beach, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary S. Bernstein to Thomas C. Hunter Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hunter of New Haven. The wedding is planned for Nov. 3.

title: Britain and China Set Date to Initial Pact
description: China and Britain will initial a draft agreement on Wednesday to transfer Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty, a Government spokesman said today.

title: 3 Italian Minehunters Returning to Red Sea
description: Three Italian minehunters were returning to the Red Sea today after taking part in a search for mines in the Suez Canal sector known as the Bitter Lakes, shipping sources in Port Said said.

title: BEST SELLERS Sept. 23, 1984Fiction *116
description: THE FOURTH PROTOCOL, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $17.95.) A London jewel robbery leads to plots and counterplots behind the Iron Curtain.

title: STOCKMAN DENIES FUELING POVERTY
description: Taking issue with several nonpartisan studies, David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, has told Congress that the Reagan Administration is not responsible for an increase in poverty in the country in recent years.

title: PAN AM, STILL HURTING, NOW TACKLES THE UNIONS
description: FOR decades, the round blue emblem of Pan Am has symbolized

ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
LIBERAL ARTS AND THE BIBLE

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS: IT'S ANOTHER YEAR
description: LAST September, the Yonkers School Superintendent, Dr. Joan M. Raymond, came into her office on a Saturday, as she often does, to work without interruptions. ''I had just gotten my cup of coffee when I was told that a boy had died playing football,'' she recalled.

title: 'INJUN' FIGHTERS IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: SITTING IN DARKNESS

title: RINGING RHETORIC
description: I disagree with William Safire's evaluation of Walter Mondale's and Geraldine Ferraro's oratorical ability. Mr. Mondale is a poor speaker, lacking conviction, color and delivery technique. Mrs. Ferraro reads her speeches.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CAREY'S CHALLENGE
description: A CHEERING, flag-waving throng estimated by the police to be 4,000 strong gathered under brilliantly sunny skies in Mount Kisco last Sunday to celebrate the homecoming of Rick Carey, the Olympic swimming champion.

title: A RESTAURANT STARTER KIT
description: IF there were such a thing as a restaurant

title: MUSIC FAIR TO OPEN SITE OF IVES CENTER
description: CHARLES IVES would have loved it! This most proudly individualistic composer was fascinated by every aspect of American music, and wrote all sorts of pieces with fragments of marches, hymn tunes, folk songs and who knows what else swirled together in exhilarating cacophony.

title: WALKER CAPTURES 5TH AVENUE MILE
description: John Walker, racing out of the past with a burst of speed and a bright smile, avoided the potholes he said bothered him midway through the race and scored a popular upset victory in the 5th Avenue Mile yesterday.

title: INVESTING ; SKEPTICISM ABOUT THE MARKET TIMERS
description: MANY on Wall Street have long been skeptical of their brethren who use the market- timing approach. This year, the strategy of trying to anticipate market moves was further discredited when numerous professional timers missed the August stock market rally. And to add insult to injury, a recent issue of the Harvard Business Review included an article entitled ''The Folly of Stock Market Timing.''

title: THE KOREAS TURN CIVIL, IF NOT QUITE NEIGHBORLY
description: North and South Korea make direct contact so infrequently that any meeting becomes an event. Usually, everyone concerned goes home as angry as ever, but last week something different happened. The two Koreas, in sessions at Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone, may actually have agreed on something.

title: EFFORT GROWS TO IMPROVE SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: TWO years ago, when Diane Basior learned that cafeterias in Byram Hills schools were selling chocolate milk and packaged cakes to the students, she was so upset she became chairman of a parents committee formed to make nutritional changes in school lunches. At the time, her sons were only 2 and 3 years old.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;  Cable TV
description: Plays made into movies don't always work. Yet they can hold surprises, even rewards, as happens this week on cable television. Take ''Dracula'' (1979), a sleekly sophisticated version of Broadway, with Frank Langella, Laurence Olivier and Kate Nelligan. (Saturday at 11:30 P.M. on MAX.) Effective, yes, but the old Hollywood version of the first Broadway play back in the 1930's, with Bela Lugosi, has the real bite. It also has that great, cobwebbed opening chapter in the castle - an expansion that's pure movie stuff. The newest ''Dracula'' is effective, but the old version still packs the wallop. Watch for it.

title: No Headline
description: Paget Cozzi a Bride

title: IT'S STILL NOT THE BIG APPLE
description: FOUR out of five business mornings, Player Crosby, 42 years old, drives his jeep down a Berkshire valley road, rolls into Lenox, a colonial New England town of 6,523 people and starts another day of dealing in Mexican pesos. The home-to-office trek takes him a few minutes - the type of quick commute that is luring a growing number of fed-up urban dwellers to uncongested areas.

title: PROER CARE WILL MAKE YOUR CARPETS AND RUGS LAST LONGER
description: ALL carpets and rugs regardless of whether they are made of natural or synthetic fibers or a combination of two or more different types - will last a lot longer and look a lot better if they are vacuumed frequently and regularly given a thorough cleaning - for instance, by shampooing or steam cleaning. In addition, it is especially important to clean up stains that occur through carelessness or accidents promptly - if you want to make sure these blemishes do not become permanent. The sooner you clean up an accidental spill, the better the chance of getting the stain out completely.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES IN NEW STADIUM
description: For the overflow crowd of tailgaters wearing Columbia blue - the old grads who were here not for a seminar but a football game, and the students who once poked fun at the players when they bothered to notice them at all - this was a homecoming day of a different sort. More than an annual reunion, this marked a return of football to Baker Field, where a crumbling, old wooden stadium was now a fond memory, and a modest new one made of concrete had taken its place on the site along the scenic Harlem River.

title: JEREMY IRONS IS LOOKING FOR PASSION IN HIS ROLES
description: Dispassionately, over a cup of good English tea, Jeremy Irons is talking about passion. ''It is the quality I like most in women and in men,'' he says. ''By passion, I don't mean only sexual passion. I mean enormous caring toward something. I love that energy. It seems such a good way to get through life, to be deeply involved with things, whether it be a play or a dog or a woman.''

title: SERENDIPITY COMES TO WESTPORT
description: YEARS ago in New York City a bright, witty, with-it eatery that was part coffee house, part ice-cream parlor appeared on the scene. The establishment, called Serendipity, quickly became the ''in'' place for sophisticated city dwellers to go to for imaginative sandwiches and ice-cream extravaganzas.

title: MAJOR PARTIES WATCHING 7 HOUSE RACES IN STATE
description: Democrats and Republicans have identified seven Congressional races in New York State as critical and potentially close contests in which incumbents are jeopardized or party control of a seat could change.

title:
GARDENING;
CREATING IDEAL LOAM FROMSAND OR CLAY
description: SOMEWHERE in most any garden book will be found a reference to garden loam as the ideal soil in which to grow plants. To most gardeners, however, that ideal growing medium is as elusive as the mythical holy grail. The facts of life are that most of us are blessed with either clay or sand and must make the best of our less-than- ideal situation.

title: THE FUNNY BONE AS ART, SERIOUSLY
description: THE artist Ray Johnson and the pecussionist David Van Tieghem take their respective arts very seriously. So this afternoon when Mr. Johnson performs on a six-foot by 180-foot expanse of concrete on a Glen Cove parking garage rooftop, and Saturday evening when Mr. Van Tieghem ''plays music'' at Brookwood Hall in East Islip by beating upon balloons and assorted pots, pans and metal ashtrays, they will be following their individual creative muses.

title: FLUTIE STARS IN 52-20 TRIUMPH
description: Doug Flutie showed again tonight why size bears no relation to success. The 5-foot-9-inch senior quarterback of Boston College passed for six touchdowns, a school record and two more than he had ever thrown in a game, to lead the Eagles to a 52-20 victory over North Carolina.

description: THE revitalization of Roosevelt, despite a decade of doubts, is gaining ground with a new shopping center and plans for an office building.

title: CAN'T SOMETHING BE DONE ABOUT BASEBALL'S GNAWING INJUSTICES?
description: If we had one baseball league, the best four teams would play for the championship. -- GEORGE STEINBRENNER Aug. 9, 1984

title: 2d Birth Control Center Firebombed in Georgia
description: A planned parenthood counseling center in this affluent suburban community has been firebombed, the second such attack directed against an Atlanta area family planning clinic in a week.

title: CONDOMINIUMS RISE ON A CHALLENGING SITE
description: The three-and-a-half acre lot off Schuyler Avenue in Kearny had tantalized developers for years. It stands on a ridge overlooking the Hackensack Meadowlands and, beyond them, the Lower Manhattan skyline.

description: For any serious student of both architecture and design in this century, a day or two out of a longer stay in Stockholm is enough to become acquainted with some of the major works of Eric Gunnar Asplund, Sweden's leading architect of the 20th century.

title: Lucy West Weds Iner Engebretson
description: Lucy Bradford West, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen K. West of Bernardsville, N.J., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to Iner Mark Engebretson, a son of Lillian Engebretson of Greenwich, Conn., and I. Oliver Engebretson of Wallkill, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred Niese performed the ceremony at St. John's on the Mountain Episcopal Church in Bernardsville.

title: IMPOVEMENTS CITED IN HIRING CITY TEACHERS
description: The hiring of teachers, traditionally a cumbersome process in New York City's schools, went more smoothly this summer than it has in years, according to school officials. This improvement, they say, may foreshadow an easing of the city's serious teacher shortage.

title: TOPICS
description: I'VE achieved a goal I'd been trying to reach for a long time. I went shopping for a raincoat, found one in my size marked down from $100 to $29.95 and didn't buy it. All the seams were intact and there were no missing buttons. Reduced 70 percent, and I didn't buy it.

title: 2 DIE IN CLASH IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Two black miners were killed and at least 135 were hurt in a disturbance at a gold mine, the police said today.

title: ORCHESTRAL SEASON OPENING ACROSS STATE
description: VIRTUALLY every major Connecticut orchestra has its opening concert scheduled in October, but the Hartford Symphony under Arthur Winograd is also giving a free concert this afternoon at 2 in Salmon Brook Corporate Park in Glastonbury.

title: PEPPERS IN EVERYPOT
description: EVER THE PAST FEW YEARS, we have written often about the many changes in American taste - for example, the ''discovery'' of ''new'' salad greens; the multiplicity of ''new'' mustards, vinegars and oils; the overall broadening of interest in American cooking; the unparalleled interest in barbecuing generally and with mesquite wood specifically.

title: STREETCAR AT NEW GOERGE ST.
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE George Street Playhouse's imposing new space on Livingston Avenue includes a stage twice as large and twice as many seats (352, as opposed to 259) as the former facility on the theater's namesake street.

title: THE TOO-MIGHTY DOLLAR TAKES A TOLL OF MANUFACTURING JOBS
description: The battle to stop the decline in manufacturing jobs - the principal casualty of the strong dollar and the ever-rising American trade deficit - went into a new phase last week. President Reagan ordered protection for the domestic steel industry through a system of ''voluntary'' quotas not dissimilar to a four- year-old arrangement that has kept Japan from grabbing more than 21 percent of the domestic auto market.

title: ISRAEL TO ASK U.S. TO BE GO-BETWEENS WITH THE SYRIANS
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir says the new coalition Government intends to ask the United States to serve as a go-between with Syria to work out arrangements for a withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon.

title: RearAdm.BruceBradley,81; Former Navy Medical Officer
description: Rear Adm. Bruce E. Bradley Sr., retired, a former deputy surgeon general of the Navy Medical Corps, died Wednesday at the Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas.

title: YOUTHS GIVEN 26,592 JOBS IN SUMMER PROGRAM
description: Summer Jobs '84, a program to find employment for low-income youths 16 to 21 years old, filled a record 26,592 jobs in New York City last summer, officials said.

description: Robert Manning, editor in chief of Boston Publishing Company, was an Assistant Secretary of State from 1962 to 1964. THE RIGHT HAND OF POWER

description: Not every philanthropist wants to be immortalized on a school of medicine, a museum or a monument.

title: Nervous Retailers Watch Malls Grow
description: BEFORE the Trumbull Shopping Park was built 21 years ago, the land it now occupies was pasture. Charlotte Greenwood, who lives a block away, recalls that neighborhood residents never locked their doors. When plans for the mall were announced, Mrs. Greenwood and her neighbors fought it, fearing it would destroy their tranquil way of life.

title: ITALIAN WINE AT A GOOD PRICE
description: IN step with Manhattan, many county restaurants now offer outstanding Italian wines at reasonable prices. This trend stems primarily from the strength of the dollar and the recent increase in quality of imports - especially white wines - from areas such as Sicily, Tuscany and Emilia-Romagna. Consumer awareness of products other than Chianti and Soave has also allowed restaurateurs to broaden the selection on their lists.

title: Crippled Soviet Sub Is Towed Toward Home
description: A Soviet ballistic-missile submarine was being towed toward home today after drifting in the Sea of Japan for two days, a Defense Agency spokesman said.

title: MANY SEE MERCY IN ENDING EMPTY LIVES
description: Daylight was fading when it happened.

title: Law Student Engaged To Bonnie Sue Ryzoff
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ronald I. Ryzoff of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and West Dover, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Sue Ryzoff, to Scott Wayne Bernstein, a son of Martin B. Bernstein and Eleanor Bernstein, both of Oceanside, L.I.

title:
Behind the Reagan-Gromyko Meeting;
Kremlin Change? Unlikely.
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's planned visit with President Reagan on Friday has raised hopes for an upturn in superpower relations. Perhaps the Kremlin now feels it must come to terms with a President seemingly headed for a second term.

description: BARBARA GUEST'S fascination with the American poet H. D. began when she was a schoolgirl in California. Later, as a young poet, she tried in vain, she said, to imitate the intense images and chiseled lines of H. D.

title: Iraqi Forces and Kurds Said to Renew Fighting
description: Iraqi forces have been fighting Kurdish insurgents in Kurdistan in the last week, ending a nine-month cease-fire and ending hopes for an agreement on Kurdish automony, Kurdish rebel sources said today.

title: GANDHI AIDES STEP BACK IN ANDHRA PRADESH
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi surprised both friends and enemies last week when she allowed her supporters to step aside in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh so that a popular opponent could reclaim his job as chief minister.

title: Suzanne MacLeod Herr Bride of Jay R. Olson 3d
description: Suzanne MacLeod Herr, the daughter of Cowles Whitehouse Herr and the late Joan Dawson Herr of Milford, N.J., was married yesterday to Jay Raymond Olson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olson Jr. of Mount Pleasant, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Milford, N.J.

title: A REAGAN PLEDGE ON PEACE EFFORTS

title: DANCE: THREE WORKS BY CLAUDIA GITELMAN
description: The works that Caludia Gitelman and Dancers presented Friday night in the Marymount Manhattan Theater revealed Miss Gitelman to be a thoughtful choreographer. Yet she took such obvious pains in devising her choreography that her dances looked finicky and they never really came to life.

title: BRIDGEWATER EAST GETS PAST WATCHUNG HILL, 12-8
description: Bridgewater East scored a touchdown in the second quarter and again in the third to hold on for a 12-8 victory over Watchung Hills yesterday in Warren.

title: SNEEZES' END
description: The days are blue and brilliant, the nights so cool that sleepers reach for blankets yet unpacked. Greenmarkets spill white eggplant, yellow tomatoes and purple cauliflower into the shopper's hands, and the sun sets in a lemon sky.

title: IT TAKES TWO TO UNTANGLE IN CHAD
description: Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, regarded by many in the West as the world's leading terrorist, appears to be trying a new strategy: moderation. In a joint communique last week, Libya and France announced they had agreed to a ''total and simultaneous'' withdrawal of their troops from Chad.

title: TEHERAN SAYS U.S. SEARCHED HOME OF AN IRANIAN DIPLOMAT
description: The Iranian press agency said today that United States security agents had searched the house of an Iranian diplomat in Washington soon after the car bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut.

title: Belgian Princess Wed
description: Princess Astrid of Belgium, 21 years old and a niece of King Baudouin, and Archduke Loren of Austria-Este, 28, a grandson of Charles I, the last emperor of Austria, were married today in civil ceremonies in the Gothic chamber of the 18th-century Brussels Town Hall and in religious ceremonies at Notre- Dame des Sablons Roman Catholic Church.

title: BENIGN WINDS GET A HEARING
description: In recent years, distinguished

title: NEW HYDE PARK RUNS TO DEFEAT SOUTH SIDE
description: Two touchdowns by George Kasimatis, a 210-pound junior fullback, helped New Hyde Park defeat South Side yesterday, 21-7. But the Gladiators' dependency on aggressive ground work was not entirely pleasing to the head coach, John Calo.

title: U.S. VOICES SKEPTICISM ON NICARAGUAN MOVE
description: The State Department today criticized the announcement by the Nicaraguan Government that it will sign a peace plan for Central America devised by the so- called Contadora group.

title: COLLEGE CAN BE A STRUGGLE, TO A DEGREE
description: BACHELORS come easy to some people. Dating women get them, partying men give them, gardeners grow them, but me, I've been struggling so long with my bachelor's degree.

title: Princeton Tops Cornell
description: Doug Butler threw for 215 yards and one touchdown and the safety Jim Anderson intercepted two passes, including one he returned 100 yards for a touchdown, to lead Princeton to a 17-9 victory today over Cornell.

title: 'Old Politics,' Says Hart Of Reagan and Mondale
description: Senator Gary Hart said today that both President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale practiced ''old politics at its worst,'' and added that he probably would be ahead in 12 states if he was the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: LAURA VAN THUMEN BRIDE OF M.W. GREENOUGH 3D
description: At St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., yesterday Laura Van Thunen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Francis Van Thunen of Saddle River and Singer Island, Fla., was married to Malcolm Whelen Greenough 3d, the son of Mr. Greenough Jr. of Prides Crossing, Mass., and Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Sarah Greenough of Beverly, Mass. The Rev. Edward F. Kavin performed the ceremony.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Using Homework The Right Way The story about schools setting new policies on homework (Aug. 26) suggests that this aspect of school reform may fall into the same category of most of the other widely touted school reforms: superficial. More school days, more hours, more credits, more homework may be just as effective as trying to improve an ailing baseball team performance by simply adding more innings to the game.

title: 'GENTRIFICATION OF EAST VILLAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tessa Merritt Weds Charles LeBaron
description: Tessa Merritt, a daughter of Adele Biddle Schoettle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Henry T. Merritt of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Wade LeBaron, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Wade LeBaron of New York.

title: LOBSTER RUSTLERS STILL FLOURISH
description: AN estimated 90,000 lobster pots rest at the bottom of Long Island Sound along the Connecticut coast during the peak fishing months of June, July, August and September, according to conservation officials.

title: GIVING BANKS SOCIAL INCENTIVES
description: Banks, not surprisingly, like to go where the money is. Last week, Governor Cuomo offered them a potentially lucrative incentive to go where it is not.

title: Susan Atwater Is Wed To a Graduate Student
description: Susan Kellogg Atwater and Mark Allen Boyd were married yesterday at the Sarah P. Duke Memoral Gardens in Durham, N.C., by the Rev. John Steed, an Episcopal priest. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eastwood Atwater of Blue Bell, Pa.

title: ARMY TIES, 24-24, AGAINST TENNESSEE
description: Nate Sassaman, a defensive back last season who was converted into the quarterback in Army's new wishbone formation, kept the ball for a 1-yard touchdown run with 1 minute 17 seconds remaining and Craig Stopa kicked the extra point to earn a 24-24 tie with Tennessee today.

title: BRASSAI EXPLORED MORE THAN THE SEEDY LIFE OF PARIS
description: It seems beyond dispute that Brassai, who died in July at the age of 84, was one of the major photographers of this century. A Transylvanian transplanted to Paris, he manage in the 1930's to capture aspects of French life that had never before submitted themselves to the camera, and to do so with a directness and vigor that is a hallmark of greatness in the medium. No doubt as a emigre he saw Paris more acutely than most of its natives, but he also was able to penetrate its darker demimonde because of a relentless passion for the forbidden and deep sympathy with the outcast.

title: PLUME POISONS WATER
description: A LITTLE over a year ago, a Suffolk County homeowner discovered that his water ''tasted funny.'' A neighbor's two horses went lame, and a litter of English pointers was born deformed. Another neighbor began to lose her hair, and a nearby resident complained of frequently feeling ill.

title: A HOME FOR CAMBODIA'S CHILDREN
description: Gail Sheehy, author of ''Passages'' and ''Pathfinders,'' is at work on a book about the Cambodian survivor who has joined her family, 14-year-old Mohm Phat. By Gail Sheehy JEFFERSON, N.H., IS A TINY, TRADITIONAL New England hamlet, hugged by the White Mountains and muffled a good part of the year by snow. The lives of its residents revolve mostly around work and church. Yet this insulated little town is the scene of an extraordinary experiment in reconstructing the shattered lives of eight Cambodian children orphaned by war and horror half a world away. To youngsters born in a land of sugar palms and sarongs, nothing could have been more alien than the north country, where since 1980 they have been full, sharing members of a family assembled by a Congregationalist minister, the Rev. Peter L. Pond, and his wife, Shirley. Nor could the youngsters, with their amber skin and singsong language, have been more exotic to crusty Yankees who had seldom seen a black or Hispanic face, much less an Asian one.

title: Jane Berry Is the Bride Of Walter Halle Briggs
description: The marriage of Jane Wendell Berry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Thomas Berry of Darien, Conn., to Walter Halle Briggs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Briggs Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. The Rev. Douglas Ray performed the ceremony.

title: IRAQI WARPLANES RAID AND IRANIAN CHEMICAL PLANT
description: Iraqi jets raided an Iranian petrochemical complex at the head of the Persian Gulf today.

title: A CELLAR TO BUILD ON
description: QUESTION: I have $1,000 to build a wine cellar. Where do I start? Answer: In a trendy housewares shop. Buy a medium-size wine rack, in black iron or natural wood, with room for 40 or 50 bottles. This will cost around $100. Then drop in at a trendy wine shop and buy a case of, oh, Chateau Montrose 1961. This will cost around $900. That's it. You have used up your $1,000. Your cellar is small, but distinguished, and it entitles you to say, whenever you wish: ''Of course, I haven't touched my '61s yet.'' If you already have a wine rack, you might choose a case of the 1975 Chateau Lafite-Rothschild. It will run you just about $1,000. In either instance, you have made no provision for sales tax, which will come to about $80 in New York. But no one ever said being a connoisseur was easy. When it comes to variety, a one-case cellar obviously leaves something to be desired. But it does serve to show how many possibilities there are when it comes to spending $1,000 on wine. Some enthusiasts do not hesitate to spend that much on a single bottle. Others - admittedly not in the connoisseur class - never spend more than $4 a bottle. There are collectors who keep only French wines. Some specialize in Bordeaux; some, even in one or two chateaus in Bordeaux. There are Italian cellars and German cellars and cellars devoted entirely to California cabernets.

title: 2 GIRLS FOUND SLAIN IN DUTCHESS
description: Two 13-year-old girls were found bludgeoned to death Friday in a creek less than a mile from their homes in Fishkill, N.Y., the Dutchess County Sheriff reported yesterday. There were no suspects and the motive for the slayings was unclear.

title: Judge Trims Award in Crash
description: Federal District Judge Peter Beer has cut in half a $10.1 million award to a man and wife resulting from the 1982 crash of a Pan American World Airways jetliner into a neighborhood in suburban Kenner. Judge Beer pared the total to $4.9 million on Thursday, saying evidence in the trial did not support the larger award by a jury to Christopher and Barbara Schultz, whose daughter died in the crash.

title: 'SHWCASE' OF ARTS TO TAKE PLACE SATURDAY AT MONTCLAIR STATE
description: MONTCLAIR IN ITS seven years, the Arts in

title: EXCERPTS FROM STUDY OF MISSING ARGENTINES
description: Following are excerpts from the introduction of a report by the National Commmission on the Disappearance of Persons, as translated by The New York Times from the Spanish, which was presented to President Raul Alfonsin on Thursday. The introduction was written by Ernesto Sabato, an Argentine novelist who headed the 11-member commission. The complete report of 50,000 pages has not been made public.

title: Farrell Blanks Stepinac, 33-0
description: Monsignor Farrell rolled to a 33-0 victory over Stepinac on the strength of two Chris LaGrego touchdowns.

title: Henry Laskau And the Walk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MAURA CORRIGAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Maura Corrigan, associate fashion editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, was married yesterday to Brendan James McCurdy, a manager for Phipps Houses, a nonprofit realty development concern in New York. The Rev. Richard Viladesau performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: BOOTHE RUSHES FOR 206
description: George Boothe, a junior tailback, ran for 206 yards on 31 carries and scored three touchdowns to lead North Edison to a 27-7 victory over Perth Amboy yesterday in Perth Amboy.

title: TOUGH START FOR EDGEMONT COACH
description: It was almost enough to make Terry Smith go back into retirement. The first-year Edgemont coach had to open the season yesterday against Dobbs Ferry, which had a 19-game winning streak, the state's longest. The Eagles made it 20 in a row as they won, 33-6.

title: HIGH ROAD, HARD ROAD
description: The campaigning last week of Ronald Reagan and Walter F. Mondale provided a point-counterpoint on the styles and status of their runs for the Presidency. Wrapped in the panoply of incumbency and brimming with confidence, Mr. Reagan took care, as he has for months, not to mention his opponent by name.

title: ISSUE MARKS ELEANOR ROOSEVELT CENTENNIAL
description: Postmaster General, William F. Bolger, will be the principal speaker at first day of issue ceremonies on Oct. 11 at Val-Kill in Hyde Park, N.Y. The ceremonies will note the release of a 20-cent stamp honoring Eleanor Roosevelt on the 100th anniversary of her birth. Val-Kill was Mrs. Roosevelt's residence during the latter years of her life.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: ARE NEW YORK SCHOOLS PLAYING POLITICAL FOOTBALL?
description: For the past two seasons, Jim Walsh, the head coach at George Washington High School, has feuded bitterly with officials of the New York City Public High School Athletic League over the question of whether Washington's football team belonged in the stronger or weaker of the league's two divisions.

title: Annette T. Thieman Wed To Stephen Edgar Pollack
description: Annette Therese Thieman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Thieman of Minster, Ohio, was married yesterday to Stephen Edgar Pollack, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Pollack of Allen Park, Mich., and Wareham, Mass.

description: The following article is based on reporting by Patrick Ragosta and Anthony De Palma and was written by Mr. Ragosta.

title: ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA TO VISIT CHINA TO 'PROMOTE HARMONY'
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, said in New York last week that he planned to visit China next month to ''promote harmony and understanding.''

title: MALLS ARE NOT FOR ALL
description: WHILE shopping malls have proven successful for many stores, Keyboard Center, which did business primarily in shopping malls during the 1970's, has left the malls one by one as its leases have run out. Changing consumer tastes and increasing mall rents have prompted the moves to free-standing stores, said J. Ronald Oligino, who with his brother, Dennis, owns the piano and organ stores.

title: Ibby Curtis Bride of K. D. Baldridge
description: Isabel Semler Curtis, a daughter of Dr. Charles P. Curtis of Sanibel Island, Fla., formerly of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Anne S. Curtis, was married yesterday to Kempton Dunn Baldridge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dickson B. Baldridge of Fairfield. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ORADELL
description: Floyd Winters leaves early each school morning from the place of his birth - a small frame house on Kinderkermack Road in Oradell. He walks up a small hill behind Borough Hall, and by 7:30 he is eagerly awaiting the first children crossing to the elementary school on Prospect Avenue.

title: MUSIC: EVELYNE BURNNER
description: Whose idea was it that Evelyne Brunner, the Swiss soprano whose European opera credits are so impressive and intriguing, should have made her New York recital debut Thursday at Tully Hall? If her own, then it is doubly surprising that she appeared in a program of music with which she was evidently not yet comfortable.

title: GEORGIA UPSETS CLEMSON
description: Kevin Butler kicked a 60-yard field goal with 11 seconds remaining today to give Georgia a 26-23 upset over Clemson, the nation's No. 2 ranked team.

title: MANY BOXERS FOUND AFFLICTED
description: Specialists in boxing injuries are not surprised that Muhammad Ali has developed symptoms similar to those of Parkinson's disease. Examinations of former boxers and autopsies of those who have died have shown a substantial number with symptoms similar to those of Parkinsonism.

title: DON'T USE MEXICO'S SOLUTION AS A MODEL
description: AT the annual gathering of the International Monetary Fund and

title: Ridgefield 27-20 Winner Andy Bellagamba rushed for
description: two touchdowns, and Ridgefield's defense held Norwalk to

title: BAY SHORE STOPS WEST BABYLON, 14-0
description: Despite heavy graduation losses, Bay Shore, the defending Suffolk County champion, shut down its league rival West Babylon yesterday, 14-0, on the losers' home field in the opener for both teams.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: In contrast to a growing number of American prelates, many European bishops seem content with a more conservative, hawkish posture, e.g. nuclear deterrence is legitimate because of the ''aggressive and dominating character of Marxist-Leninist ideology.''

title: Susan De Laney Weds Henry Morgan
description: Susan Louise De Laney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger De Laney of Lloyd Neck, L.I, and Henry Morgan, a son of Rear Adm. Henry S. Morgan Jr., U.S.N., retired, of Houston, and Mrs. Albert Pratt of Boston and Osterville, Mass., were married yesterday.

title: RINGING RHETORIC
description: I was out of the country during the Democratic Convention, but read some of the speeches referred to by William Safire in his article.

title: METS TOP EXPOS BY 4-2
description: Wally Backman made a misplay in the fifth inning that gave Montreal the lead for a while yesterday, but the Mets' second baseman hit a sacrifice fly in the seventh inning that gave the Mets the lead for good in a 4-2 decision over the Expos at Shea Stadium.

title: POP RECORDS TURN TO HIP-HOP
description: Each year at around this time, the record industry unveils the new season's latest lines in aural fashion.
