Last year, the two main influences on the pop mainstream were Michael Jackson's ''Thriller,'' and an English synthesizer pop that represented a glamorous refinement of the previous year's spare ''techno-pop.'' On three of this fall's major albums - Daryl Hall & John Oates's ''Big Bam Boom'' (RCA AFLI 5309), Barry Gibb's ''Now Voyager'' (MCA 5506), and Chaka Khan's ''I Feel For You'' (Warner Bros. 25162), last season's synthesizer-pop has been dressed up and rhythmically charged with elements of ''hip-hop,'' the New York- originated dance music style that embraces rapping, scratching, break dancing and harsh, electronic sound effects. In fashion industry terms, the mood of these records might be described as one of elaborate severity, in which high technology meets the street.

title: SMALLER AIRLINES MAY BALK AT SCHEDULE REVISIONS
description: Revised schedules designed to minimize peak-hour flight delays are being put into final form by a group of airlines so they can be submitted early this week for approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Maryland Weighs Bass Plan
description: Resources to seek a total ban on the harvesting of striped bass by both sport and commercial anglers marks a significant stage in the continuing effort to aid that highly prized and beleagured species.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID DISPUTED IN POLL
description: A survey among black South African factory workers that was published today shows overwhelming resistance to the notion that United States companies should withdraw investment in this racially divided nation to force change.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Women's Apparel At Up to 50% Off
description: Designers . . . for Less has stores in Scarsdale at the Eastchester line, in Rye Brook and in Stamford, Conn., each carrying discounted women's apparel and accessories bearing well- advertised labels. The usual markdown is 20 to 50 percent, but seasonal sales and promotions can drop the charge to 80 percent off the suggested retail price. Sizes are 4 to 14, with some 16's and fewer 18's. There are also petites and some suits begin at size 2.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
AN AMATEUR MARRIAGE
description: Steve Tesich is the author of ''Summer Crossing,'' a novel, and of ''Breaking Away'' and other screenplays.

title: HOW DEMOCRATIC LEADERS ARE HURTING MONDALE
description: To the Editor:

title: British Examine Bomb Found in Londonderry
description: British Army explosives experts are examining a new type of bomb rigged by guerrillas to blow up 25 vehicles at once, according to a police spokesman.

title: HE WHO LAUGHS LAST
description: GOD KNOWS

title: ELIZABETH B. HAWKINS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday Elizabeth Barrett Hawkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hyde Hawkins of Bronxville, was married to Gaye Hakan Sokmensuer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Adil Sokmensuer of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. John Duffell performed the ceremony.

title: Amy Longsworth Wed in Virginia
description: Amy Porter Longsworth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Longsworth of Williamsburg, Va., was married there yesterday to Douglas R. Horne, a son of Florence T. Horne of Westfield, N.J., and the late Sidney Horne. The Rev. Jeffrey S. Dugan performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Coke-Garrett House, a historic house where the bride's parents live.

title: L.I. SHORE CALLED VULNERABLE TO MAJOR STORMS
description: The South Shore of Long Island is far more vulnerable to major storms now than it was when the last major hurricane hit 46 years ago, according to a report by the Long Island Regional Planning Board.

title: STATE TO REVIEW BLOCKED HYDROELECTRIC PLAN
description: The New York Power Authority said this week that it would re-examine its plan to build a large hydroelectric power plant in the northern Catskills to see if changes could be made to satisfy objections raised by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: FOR CITY'S HOTELS, IT'S SPRUCE UP TIME
description: At the New York Hilton, workmen are building a new porte-cochere for its main entrance, which faces on the Avenue of the Americas between 53rd and 54th Streets. Soon it will have new granite walkways under a mirrored portico, a glass-enclosed fountain and stainless steel doorways. It will, said Michael Spector, the architect who designed the changes, make a glittering contrast to ''the darkness of the old entrance, which no one liked.''

title: PLAYERS' AGENTS LINING UP TO REGISTER
description: AS part of the collective bargaining agreement signed with the owners in December 1982, the National Football League Players Association won the right to register and monitor agents and attorneys who represent players in contract negotiations with their clubs.

title: Newspaper Apologizes To Indians After a Suit
description: The efforts of an Indian community to protect the privacy of its tribal rituals have led a newspaper to publish an apology and agree to other concessions in settling a lawsuit filed by the Indians.

title: MERIT SCHOLARS LISTED FOR COUNTY
description: THE 15,000 semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's yearly competition represent one-half of 1 percent of all high school seniors in the country.

title: R. R. Grow Weds Christine Fisher
description: Christine Frances Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Fisher Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard R. Grow, a son of Mrs. Lawrence Ruby of Grosse Pointe and the late J. Alfred Grow Jr. The Rev. Dr. David Antonson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Fisher home in Grosse Pointe.

title: ODDS AND ENDS IN ART AND LIFE
description: STONY POINT, N.Y. BITS of glass, old shoes, charred wood, tennis balls, banana peels. For Sari Dienes, these odds and ends of daily life are the raw materials of art. However, she will quickly tell you, ''My life and my art are the same.''

title: REAGAN APPEARS TO SUCCEED BY AVOIDING SPECIFIC ISSUES
description: Incumbency has always been one of the strongest forces in Presidential politics. In 1984, advances in the staging of campaign events, President Reagan's skill as a performer and the communicative impact of television seem to have combined to turn incumbency into a political weapon of awesome potency.

title: NEW YORK-MONTREAL SERVICE BY HIGH-SPEED TRAIN BACKED
description: High- speed train service between Montreal and New York City could attract 3.5 million riders a year and make enough money to cover its cost, according to preliminary findings of an economic feasibility study released this week.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AFTER 12 years of effort, the Communist Party in Connecticut will have its Presidential candidate, Gus Hall , listed on the state ballot this November.

title: BROWN BEATS YALE WITH INTERCEPTIONS
description: Keiron Bigby, a sophomore defensive back from Central Islip, L.I., playing in his first varsity game for Brown today, returned two Yale passes that he had intercepted for touchdowns on runs of 91 and 102 yards.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ESTATE BECOMES DESIGNER PROJECT
description: STOCKTON '' LOLLY, baby, I ain't got no time for nothin' but trouble.'' Anne Elstner Matthews was the actress who made the line her signature on the long-running radio serial ''Stella Dallas,'' in which she played the leading role from the show's inception in 1937 until it went off the air in 1955.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: RONKONKOMA I GAVE my son a flying lesson for

title: THE JEOPARDY OF CHILDREN ON THE STAND
description: The charge was the sexual abuse of children, and as in many crimes, the best witnesses were the alleged victims. But could the adults serving as prosecutor, defense attorneys, judge and jurors rely on the children's testimony? Six children took the stand in Minnesota last week to accuse two adults from their neighborhood of sexually violating them, but the children were outnumbered by the adults and overwhelmed by the legal system. The trial left them in tears. The defendants were acquitted. In less than a year, sexual abuse of children has replaced drunken driving as the hidden crime competing most ferociously for public attention. Last week three day-care center workers in the Bronx were indicted on charges of sexually abusing children at their city-sponsored facility. The indictments were based on the testimony of 15 children. And in Washington an expert on child pornography shocked a Congressional subcommittee when she revealed her suspicion that there exists a network of day-care centers around the United States that serve ''child predators.'' Since the first major case broke at the Virginia McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif., last spring, prosecutors across the country have forced the cases of accused child sex offenders to trial rather than dismiss them to save embarrassment to the young victims.

title: Doctors' Group Sues to Halt Freeze on Medicare Payment
description: The American Medical Association filed a suit Friday to block a new freeze on doctors' Medicare fees, officials of the association said.

title: PRESERVING THE OPULENCE
description: A distinctive limestone structure at 50 East 69th Street is now in the hands of a plastic surgeon who is lovingly restoring it.

title: Bride Held in Groom's Death
description: Less than 24 hours after the wedding of a couple described as ''perfectly happy,'' the groom was dead and his bride was in jail, charged with manslaughter.

title: 'PLEASE TAKE MY NAME OFF YOUR REEL'
description: Hal, the Computer Special Communications System Equitable Life Insurance Company 1285 Avenue of the Americas New York, N.Y. 10019

title: Future Events Formal and Informal
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: STATE MEDICL BOARD CURBS STUDENTS FROM CARIBBEAN SCHOOL
description: TRENTON THE state's Board of Medical Examiners has ruled that the Ross University School of Medicine on the Caribbean island of Dominica may no longer send students to hospitals in New Jersey for the hands-on part of their training.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS SPURNING STEEL AID AS HELP TO FARMERS
description: President Reagan said today that he decided last week to aid debt-ridden farmers but declined to impose import quotas on steel to aid that industry because they were a ''quick fix'' that might backfire on agricultural America.

title: TIGERS' PETRY STOPS YANKS ON 4 HITS, 6-0
description: Sparky Anderson, whose Detroit Tigers played their 99th winning game of the season today, 6-0, over the Yankees, has been playing games of another kind with his pitchers recently.

title: FORBIDDEN PRIVATE WARS
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
THE WORKINGS OF THE ARTIST'S MIND
description: TODAY'S art audiences are more curious than ever about the thought process - in the good old days, it used to be called ''inspiration'' - that leads up to the creation of what we are shown in galleries and museums. Whether or not it is art at all seems to depend more and more on where it came from, rather than what it looks like.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Pope and Fans in Canada
description: In the same week, the Olympic Stadium in Montreal was the scene of appearances by Michael Jackson and Pope John Paul II.

title: BOARD PICKS TWO NEW EXECUTIVES TO HEAD DISNEY
description: Two veteran motion picture industry executives were chosen today by the board of Walt Disney Productions to head the troubled company a mouse built.

title: Mary Gray Gilchrist Is Bride of Barry W. Sachtjen
description: Mary Gray Gilchrist, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Stuart Gilchrist Jr. of Alexandria, Va., and Richmond, was married yesterday to Barry William Sachtjen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur M. Sachtjen of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Richard R. Baker 3d performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: LAST OF THE DALAI LAMAS?
description: The Dalai Lama , revered as a religious and national leader by Tibetans despite 25 years in exile, began a 44- day visit to the United States last week with an appeal for a mingling of the cultures of East and West. ''Eastern philosophy and Western science could be a good marriage, without a divorce,'' he said.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: The bishop's letter on war and peace was not only the most Christian discourse I have ever read, but one of the most thoughtful and rational (''America's Activist Bishops: Examining Capitalism,'' by Eugene Kennedy, Aug. 12). The fact that none of them earn their living from nuclear submarines only enhanced their credibility.

title: AMERICA'S ACTIVIST BISHOPS
description: I am not a Catholic, but as far as I'm concerned the Catholic Church covered itself with glory by issuing the pastoral letter on nuclear war. Of course, the new letter on the economy has not yet been written; it seems safe to predict, however, that this letter, too, will rest on the extraordinarily rich, considered, complex Catholic tradition of hard thought about exchange, fairness, social class and power. ALAN HYDE Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: MERIT SEMIFINALISTS NAMED
description: THE semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's annual competition represent a half of 1 percent of all high school seniors in the country. Nationwide, they total some 15,000 students.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1984 Israel intends to ask the U.S. to act as the intermediary with Syria in the new coalition Government's negotiations for a withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said. Mr. Shamir, Prime Minister under the former Likud government, said in an interview that he would raise the possibility of a new American mediating role in discussions in New York next week with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (Page 1, Column 6.) Nicaragua will accept a peace treaty for Central America that was proposed two weeks ago by the the four nations known as the Contadora group, the Government announced. Diplomats and others familiar with the draft said the treaty would require signers to offer amnesty to political dissidents, hold impartial elections under independent auspices and end support for groups fighting to overthrow other governments. (1:4.)

title: ARCHBISHOP EXPLAINS ABORTION STAND
description: Archbishop Bernard F. Law of Boston says he and other Roman Catholic bishops, with their recent statements on abortion, were seeking to seize the moment to elevate the issue to the high level that civil rights for blacks held in the 1960's. He says their intention was not promoting President Reagan's re-election.

title: GOLD FROM TREASURE SHIP LEADS TO COURT DISPUTE
description: Sunken treasure, the booty of 18th-century sea battles, has spawned a new fight, a contest in Federal District Court here over the rights to what some say may amount to millions of dollars worth of gold.

title: Mondale's Son Speaks To Labor Convention
description: Ted Mondale, the son of Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, brought hundreds of cheering union members to their feet Friday as he denounced President Reagan and told them what it would be like if his father were elected.

title:
GARDENING;
CREATING IDEAL LOAM FROM SAND OR CLAY
description: SOMEWHERE in most any garden book will be found a reference to garden loam as the ideal soil in which to grow plants. To most gardeners, however, that ideal growing medium is as elusive as the mythical holy grail. The facts of life are that most of us are blessed with either clay or sand and must make the best of our less-than- ideal situation.

title: A VICTORIAN GEM IS RESTORED
description: ONE HUNDRED years ago, the newspaper advertisement read: ''Winter and summer residences with gardens attached and containing all the modern conveniences, with gas and water from Public Works, gas fixtures, hot air furnaces, ranges, baths, water closets, etc., surrounded by ample gardens, laid out with walks and shrubbery in an agreeable neighborhood combining city conveniences, with all the advantages of country air, a pure embracing atmosphere, free from malaria, and particularly healthy and agreeable at all seasons.''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: New & Noteworthy THE FAMILY ARSENAL, by Paul Theroux. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) Our reviewer, Lawrence Graver, described Paul Theroux's 1976 novel,''The Family Arsenal,'' as a thriller whose ''sensational plot turns on terrorist bombings, art theft, gun running and guilt about Vietnam; the cast of freaky, foul-mouthed conspirators crosses a spectrum from radical squalor to radical chic; and the sense of urban rot edging toward ruin is palpable on every page.'' He also said Mr. Theroux skillfully catches ''the blend of coarseness, provincialism and bigotry that is one distinctive (and usually unexportable) brand of popular British humor.'' NEGRO: An Anthology, Collected and edited by Nancy Cunard. (Ungar, $19.95.) This work, virtually the size of a telephone directory, was privately published by Nancy Cunard in 1934, a time when most whites assumed blacks were inferior. The British shipping heiress set out to prove there was no superior race. Reviewing the commercially published 1970 edition, Julius Lester said in these pages, '' 'Negro' is the most ambitious anthology on blacks ever attempted. It covers practically every aspect of black life: history, literature, education, law, racial injustice, theater, art and music. It examines black life in the United States, the West Indies, South America, Europe and Africa.''

title: C-SPAN WIDENS ITS CAMPAIGN FOCUS
description: As the major networks continue to tag after the candidates and gear up for next month's Presidential debates, C-Span, the cable network that has made its mark with continuous live coverage of the House of Representatives, rushes enthusiatically into Tulsa. Tulsa? The Oklahoma city, more noted for its oil refineries than its politics, is the fifth stop on a 15-city tour that is the backbone of ''Grassroots '84,'' C-Span's current series intended to gauge the political tenor of the nation by quite literally taking to the streets.

title: SEVEN DAYS AS HITLER'S SUCCESSOR
description: DONITZ

title: VERMONT IN AUTUMN'S DAZZLE
description: Summer is already blurring into memory and winter is still just an apprehension of windy street corners. But autumn is more than an interval, a time for getting the sweaters out of mothballs; in much of the Northeast, it is the time of the greatest beauty, when the trees turn to torches of gold and wine and flame.

title: NEW ROCK FROM THE SUBURBS
description: Things are happening in the suburban sprawl of sunny southern California. A new generation of musicians and bands, energized by the first wave of punk rock that hit Los Angeles in the middle and late 1970's, has arisen from such suburban communities as Redondo Beach, Lawndale and Torrance. These musicians were thrilled by the ferocity and commitment of germinal Los Angeles punk. But as suburbanites, many of them have had more extensive musical educations and experience than the sometimes-amateurish first-wave punk rockers.

title: A GLIMPSE OF THE BIRDERS' WORLS
description: RICHARD J. ROBERTS, a longtime birder, is editor of the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times.

title: A MORNING TRAIN IS CLASSROOM, TOO
description: ABOARD THE 6:40 FROM TRENTON '' I.R.A.,'' said the speaker, gripping the gyrating lectern and trying to read his vibrating notes about Individual Retirement Accounts, ''compounds the power.''

title: HelenDutchAnderson,Hos pitalAide, Married to Arthur Osgood Phinney 3d
description: Helen Dutch Anderson, the daughter of Joseph A. Anderson of Bridgehampton, L.I., and the late Frances Brooke Anderson, was married yesterday to Arthur Osgood Phinney 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur O. Phinney Jr. of Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Benjamin Minifie performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THIS 'GISELLE' IS A SOUTHERN FARMGIRL
description: 'I try to sense the great warmth and humidity, smell the hanging moss and even feel the gnats in the air,' says Virginia Johnson the Dance Theater of Harlem's ballerina who later this week will dance the title rolse in a highly novel new staging of the classic 19th-century ballet 'Giselle.'

title: The Worm and the Apple ; BUSTED 'Expired' What to do when a derelict New York parking meter, its ''Expired'' flag showing, refuses to swallow the proper coin, no matter how firmly proferred? Leave the car unattended while hurrying across the street to claim a reserved table in an impatient restaurant? Or search for a piece of paper to slip under the windshield wiper in hopes a note might prevent a ticket?
description: The best thing to do, it turns out, is to call 830-7500, the city's phone number for reporting broken meters. But most drivers don't know about the number because it doesn't appear in any telephone book.

title: MARK FOR ANDERSON
description: A clubhouse visitor was kidding Sparky Anderson that if the Cincinnati Reds had kept him, he would not have been in position to make baseball history today. The Detroit manager laughed, agreed with the premise, then said more seriously:

title: Hope for the Schools The results of this year's college board tests bore good news: the average scores of the nation's college-bound high school seniors improved by four points over last year. It's the fourth year of modest improvement, suggesting a real trend after a dramatic 17-year decline. The right response is not celebration but hope.
description: The Scholastic Aptitude Test measures a student's verbal and mathematical reasoning skills based on knowledge acquired both in and out of school over a number of years. It's the main test used by colleges in screening applicants.

title: Fritz Bamberger Dies at 82; Was German Jewish Scholar
description: Fritz Bamberger, a German Jewish scholar who directed the 140-school system for the education of Jews in pre- World War II Germany and later became editor of Coronet magazine, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived on Manhattan's East Side.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Tuesday misidentified the parent company of Robert Bruce Industries. It is Savoy Industries.

title: Anita Altman, Journalist, Married to Barry Muller
description: Anita Altman, an editor in the Sunday department and a feature writer for The Providence (R.I.) Journal- Bulletin, was married yesterday to Barry W. Muller, chief of the division of air and hazardous materials of the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management in Providence. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, signed the marriage certificate and the ceremony was conducted by the couple at the chapel of the Church Center of the United Nations in New York.

title: Imitated, but Not Flattered
description: President Reagan has managed

title: SOME ELDERLY CHOOSE SUICIDE OVER LONELY, DEPENDENT LIFE
description: Wylie Boyle sent his housekeeper on ahead to the post office that wintry Saturday morning in Paducah, Tex., early this year. Then, as he had every day, the 86-year-old retired insurance salesman went to visit his wife, Avis, at Richards Memorial Hospital.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE SEIZE 600 BLACKS
description: South African police officials said tonight that they had arrested more than 600 black people over the weekend for attending illegal meetings.

title: MR. REAGAN'S BEIRUT
description: BOSTON The explosion in East Beirut illuminates with terrifying clarity

title: Advertising; A Shared TV Screen For Ads
description: IN order to cope with the problem of

title: Margaret H. Marshall, a Law Partner, Is Wed to Anthony Lewis, a Columnist
description: Margaret Hilary Marshall, a partner in the Boston law firm of Csaplar & Bok, was married yesterday to Anthony Lewis, a columnist for The New York Times. James Vorenberg, dean of the Harvard Law School and a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at Land's End, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin H. Plimpton in Osterville, Mass. Dr. Plimpton is the newly elected president of the American University of Beirut.

title: SOUTHWEST JOURNAL ; FLOODING, AGE GAPS AND FRAUD
description: While two- thirds of Texas lay parched and brown under moderate to severe drought, torrential rains left half the South Texas county of Cameron under water last week, forcing some families to evacuate and causing millions of dollars worth of damage.

title: LESS GRAIN FROM A PARCHED CANADA
description: With the prairie provinces in the grip of a severe drought, Canadian grain exports are expected to decline sharply this year.

title: Dr. Ellen Scherl Is Wed To Dr. Fredric Harbus
description: Dr. Ellen Scherl, a gastroenterologist at Beth Israel Hospital, was married yesterday to Dr. Fredric Harbus, a district manager in the office of the chief financial officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York. Rabbi Charles Sheer performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Lila Scherl, in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Hawaii's 2 Congressmen Win Democratic Primary
description: Both of Hawaii's Representatives in Congress and Honolulu's Mayor easily won nomination in their Democratic primary races Saturday.

title: Ann Horwitz Married In Manchester, Conn.
description: Ann Horwitz, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Temple University, and David M. Stone, a Harvard law student, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Horwitz, in Manchester, Conn. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman officiated.

title: ROYALS AND TWINS TIE FOR LEAD IN WEST
description: Rickey Henderson singled, doubled and slammed a two-run homer today, lifting the Oakland A's to a 5-1 victory over Kansas City and dropping the Royals into a first-place tie with Minnesota in the American League West.

title: NEW DISNEY TEAM'S STRATEGY
description: The new leaders of Walt Disney Productions, Michael D. Eisner and Frank G. Wells, said today that they were given a mandate by the company's directors to put the struggling Disney studios on an equal footing with the biggest and best of Hollywood's film companies.

title: Newspaper Backs Reagan
description: The Chicago Sun-Times is urging voters to re-elect President Reagan, crediting him with improving the country's economy, self-image and foreign relations. Mr. Reagan has ''lifted a dispirited nation out of a despairing and defeatist direction headed formerly by the Carter-Mondale team,'' read an editorial published in today's issue of The Sun-Times. The newspaper is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News America.

title: THE DANCE: TWO WORKS BY SKAGGS
description: In the two dances that Sarah

title: STAGE: SAMUEL BECKETT'S 'ALL STRANGE AWAY'
description: In Samuel Beckett's ''All

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:2 Pairs Share New York Title I

title: NEIGHBORS OF EMBASSY SAY THEY'RE IN DANGER
description: Residents of this tiny hilltop village say the opening of a United States Embassy here this summer has placed them in mortal danger.

title: A SURFEIT OF WEST BANK LAW
description: The trial that resumed last week in Jerusalem against 27 Jews accused of acts of terror against the Arab population of the West Bank raises one question: can a country that claims to be a democracy apply different laws to people living side by side?

title: GEORGIA HIRES WEST GERMANS FOR SCIENCE AND MATH
description: Georgia education officials believe they may have found a way to ease the shortage of science and mathematics teachers that plagues high schools in this state and throughout the country: importing West Germans.

title: PERILS AND PAIN OF GROWING UP TOO FAST
description: She wasn't a typical teen-ager: groomed to be a highly competitive tennis player since the age of 4, Diana had spent long hours practicing while other children were playing. Although there were tangible rewards - Diana won a tennis scholarship to one of the nation's premier universities - her achievement had its THE FAMILY cost. Diana was constantly engaged in trying to re-create the childhood she had never had, according to Dr. David Elkind, a child psychologist and professor of child study at Tufts University, who studied her as a junior in college.

title: PAYTON PASSES HARRIS AS BEARS FALL, 38-9
description: Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears passed Franco Harris of the Seattle Seahawks to become the National Football League's second-leading career rusher behind Jimmy Brown today. But the Seahawks dominated practically every other statistic for a 38-9 triumph.

title: Car Is Driven Through Mall
description: The police said Sunday that the damage caused by a car driven through the Brunswick Square Mall here early Saturday could reach $1 million. The driver, John Waskis, 21 years old, of Sayreville, N.J., was being held in the Middlesex County jail in $50,000 bail. The police said he drove a 1980 Buick through the plate-glass doors of the J.C. Penney store, down the length of the mall and through Bamberger's store at the opposite end.

title: Stockholder Is Sought
description: Carl W. Whitmore is being sought along the East Coast because he has stock worth $60,000 in the Days Inn motel chain, which is being sold for $300 million. Mr. Whitmore managed a Days Inn in Savannah, Ga., in the early 1970's and was given several shares of stock instead of a pay increase in 1972. He is the only such stockholder who has not been found. Mr. Whitmore and his wife, who also worked at the inn, left the concern in 1974.

title: METS WIN AS CUBS CLINCH TIE FOR TITLE
description: In the upper reaches of Shea Stadium yesterday, the banners that tally Dwight Gooden's strikeouts rippled in the breeze for the last time this season. The brilliant rookie did not accommodate those who are only satisfied by double digits, but otherwise his last 1984 appearance in New York was a fitting finale.

title: MAMAISON SCORES IN UPSET AT BELMONT
description: Chris McCarron, who rode John Henry to victory in the Turf Classic Saturday, completed a sweep of the weekend stakes at Belmont Park with another California shipper yesterday when he rode Mamaison to an upset victory in the $128,400 Fall Highweight Handicap.

title: The Best Way to Die ''It was a whole lot easier,'' an elderly woman said to Times reporter Andrew Malcolm, the second of whose articles on euthanasia appears today, ''when God made the decision.''
description: She was talking about dying, an old subject that is raising urgent new questions for families, physicians and lawmakers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in the Metropolitan Report Tuesday about kosher cheese for the needy incorrectly identified the site where the cheese was being distributed by the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty. It was the United Jewish Council/Bialystoker Houses on the Lower East Side.

title: Joanna Knowles, Lawyer, Marries
description: Joanna Martinson Knowles, the daughter of Anne Driscoll Martinson of Princeton, N.J., and the late Carl Edward Martinson, was married yesterday to Ralph Allen Jacobs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Jacobs of Haddonfield, N.J. Rabbi Mayer Selekman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.95

title: JUDGE TO PERMIT NEW EVIDENCE ON FATAL JET CRASH
description: A Federal district judge has agreed to reopen the trial record and to allow new evidence in a negligence suit against the Boeing Company and two other defendants resulting from the crash of an Air India Boeing 747.

title: STUDY FINDS ELDERLY WOMEN MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO POVERTY
description: The nation's 16.4 million elderly women still bear the brunt of poverty and neglect in America, according to a study prepared for the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues.

title: O'CONNOR CHALLENGES CUOMO ON ABORTION BUT LAUDS STAND
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York said last night that Governor Cuomo ''is trying to confront and work his way through'' the abortion issue.

title: GISCARD REGAINS SEAT IN PARLIAMENT
description: Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing defeated six other candidates today for a seat in Parliament from his home district of Puy-de-D^ome, in south-central France.

title: JETS TOP BILLS, 28-26
description: The Jets continued to prove today that they can beat mediocre clubs in an age of parity, which means they may be much better than they appeared to be at the season's start.

title: NICOLAS BORNOZIS MARRIED TO MARIE STELLA KONSTANCE
description: The marriage of Marie Stella Konstance, Northeast regional manager of Wharton Econometrics, an economic consulting company in New York, to Nicolas Bornozis, an assistant vice president of Credit Commercial de France in New York, took place yesterday in Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. John J. Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Geri Sniffen Married To Daniel Silverstein
description: Geri Sniffen, the daughter of Peggy Triano and the late Anthony James Triano of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel Alfred Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Silverstein of San Diego. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.

title: COLUMBIA GETS ITS FIRST SORORITY CHAPTER, AND 40 ARE INITIATED
description: Jody Abramowitz, a senior at the Columbia School of International Affairs and Public Policy, pushed aside her textbooks and even skipped the Columbia-Harvard football game over the weekend. Instead she joined 39 women from Columbia University and Barnard College for a weekend of secret rituals and parties.

title: CELEBRATING JOHNSON'S BICENTENNIAL
description: It is almost 200 years since Samuel Johnson died on Dec. 13, 1784. At Yale this past weekend a gathering of Johnsonian scholars and collectors, an extraordinary exhibition of his published writings, and much talk about the changing face of Johnsonian scholarship seemed to clear the collective mind of cant. Johnson's reputation, if possible, is rising.

title: ; OUR CAR MARKET NEEDN'T BE A FREE-FOR-ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE TO EXTRADITE THREE BASQUES TO SPAIN
description: The Government announced today that it would extradite three of seven Basque separatists to Spain.

title: MONDALE WON'T ALTER CAMPAIGN TACTICS
description: With a tone of exasperation, Walter F. Mondale said today that President Reagan was avoiding debate on the issues and conceded that the tactic was working, but declared that he would not change his own campaign style.

title: ;  Links to Remember
description: Whether a golfer gets a more satisfying sense of challenge from slicing a drive into a pretty pond or hooking one into a babbling brook may be a matter of personal taste, but there are those who believe that golf courses can be evaluated by objective standards.

title: NICARAGUANS SAY THEY WON'T DELAY NOV. 4 ELECTIONS
description: Nicaraguan Government leaders said over the weekend that they would not postpone national elections scheduled for Nov. 4 despite pressure from opposition parties and the Reagan Administration.

title: Anderson Hopes to Lead Independents to Mondale
description: John B. Anderson, the independent Presidential candidate in 1980, says he hopes to swing the independent vote to the Democratic Presidential ticket in November.

title: Financiers in the Eye of a Storm
description: There's a spooky calm as the world's finance ministers gather for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The world seems to have weathered the debt storms of the past two years. No country has defaulted. The industrial powers and many of the poorer countries are growing again. But if anyone - or any government - thinks this means clear sailing, let them think again.

title: SPOUSAL AROUSAL
description: WASHINGTON

title: Drop in Union Membership
description: Union membership dropped below 20 million in the 1981-82 recession, a survey of major labor groups showed today. It was the lowest level in more than a decade, the survey said. The Bureau of National Affairs, a private publisher of newsletters and Government regulations, surveyed 216 unions and said membership fell 2.6 million from 1980 to 1982, to 19.8 million.

title: ECONOMISTS DISAGREE ON 4TH QUARTER
description: The pace of the current economic expansion clearly slowed in the third quarter, but after sifting through the latest data a number of analysts are suggesting that the period of deceleration was short-lived. Rather than continuing to moderate between now and year-end - as projected by many governmental and private economists - the rate of economic growth, some analysts now predict, will increase instead.

title: YUGOSLAVS WAITING FOR GOOD TIMES (AND GODOT)
description: In a downtown courtyard here, a three- month ''Waiting for Godot'' festival was in full swing.

title: Spotlight Still on Author Of '81 Continental Memo
description: It was Kathleen Kenefick's July 1981 internal memorandum, written while she was a loan officer with the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, that first warned of the bank's overexposure in its energy loans.

title: ;  See How They Run
description: If you're a runner, whether a casual, short-distance jogger, a serious, long-distance obsessive or something in between, some researchers at Tulane University would like to hear from you.

title: NORTHWEST'S SUITOR SEES 'NO FIRE SALE'
description: Donald P. Kelly, who is leading the investor group trying to take over Northwest Industries, is doing his best to squelch speculation that one or more units of the Chicago-based conglomerate will have to be sold off to pay for the leveraged buyout.

title: Advertising Association Gets Washington Head
description: Bradley H. Roberts, 57 years old and one-time vice chairman and head of the West Coast operation of Needham, Harper & Steers, has been named to run the Washington office of the American Association of Advertising Agencies as an executive vice president in the organization. He replaces Charles F. Adams, retiring before his 57th birthday on Wednesday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: A MANDATE TRANSCENDING ISSUES OF HOUSING THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Swedish G.N.P. Rises
description: Sweden's gross national product in the first half of the year climbed a seasonally adjusted 1.5 percent from the final six months of 1983 and was up 3.5 percent from the 1983 first half, Statistics Sweden said.

title: Dr. Reidar Sognnaes; Identified Hitler Teeth
description: Dr. Reidar Sognnaes, the dentist who identified the remains of Hitler and Martin Bormann, the Nazi Party secretary, from their teeth, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: CULTURAL PARKS DRAWING CRITICISM
description: The international trend toward establishing cultural parks in places where indigenous people are trying to carry on the beliefs and practices of their ancestors may be disrupting their way of life instead, delegates to a conference on cultural parks have been told.

title: WORLD BANK PLAN FOR AFRICAN AID GETS SUPPORT BUT NO PLEDGES YET
description: Developed and developing countries endorsed a World Bank program today that would channel $2 billion more a year into sub-Saharan Africa to improve conditions that the bank says have left the average African worse off economically than at any time since 1970.

title: Mirra Bank Wed To a Psychiatrist
description: Mirra Ellen Bank, the daughter of Julia Bank of Rye, N.Y., and the late Michael L. Bank, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Marc Brockman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel David Brockman of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the Columbia University Faculty House in New York.

title: PUT AN S ON HIS CHEST
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: HASSAN CALLS CRITICISM OF LIBYAN PACT UNFOUNDED
description: King Hassan II of Morocco, one of America's closest allies in the Arab world, says his treaty of union with Libya has been misunderstood in the United States, in part because of an exaggerated view of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, as a threat to world peace.

title: Koch Proposes That the City Sell150HarlemBrownstones
description: One hundred and fifty city-owned Harlem brownstones would be sold and rehabilitated under a plan that has been proposed by Mayor Koch. Sixty- five percent of the buildings would be set aside for Harlem residents, while the rest would be available to all city residents.

title: REAGAN, MEETING GROMYKO, ASKS FOR CLOSER TIES
description: President Reagan shook hands with Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, in New York yesterday and told him he wanted ''nothing less than a realistic, constructive, long-term relationship with the Soviet Union.''

title: OUTDOORS: NO DILETTANTE ANGLER
description: ROSCOE, N.Y.

title: MAN SHOOTS 2 IN SIEGE ON L.I. AND DIES IN BLAZE
description: A gunman in a Long Island house shot two men, one fatally, and held off the police during an all-night siege that ended at dawn yesterday when he died in a fire started by a police tear-gas canister, the Suffolk County police said.

title: 'MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER' STARTS TONIGHT
description: After watching all of ''Mistral's Daughter'' - which tonight at 8 begins an eight- hour run over three consecutive evenings on CBS - I was admittedly taken aback by the mixture of constantly simmering passions and the sporadic pauses to consider soulfully one's roots. Judith Krantz, the author, obviously knows her Alex Haley. But then, in a recent magazine interview, Miss Krantz revealed that her work might best be approached as high comedy. The question of how high is debatable, but the point about comedy can be illuminating. .

title: Just a Coincidence?
description: Sharp-eyed Washingtonians driving up Wisconsin Avenue have

title: IMMIGRATION ARTERIOSCLEROSIS
description: With the Simpson- Mazzoli immigration bill temporarily on hold, it is time for Congress to confront a fundamental dilemma. Strengthening immigration enforcement without building up the rest of the administrative system would be a perverse ''reform.'' By increasing the already large number of aliens who languish in overcrowded prisons for long periods of time, more arrests would simply shift the problem somewhere else.

title: WHAT CAN MAKE A TEEN-AGER CHOOSE DEATH?
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: TORONTO IS HOST TO THE CONTEMPORARY
description: The International Society for Contemporary Music was founded in 1923, and since then - except for a hiatus from 1940 to 1946 - it has presented an annual festival of contemporary music entitled the World Music Days. The I.S.C.M., as it is known by all, has long been centered in Europe, even though there has been a United States branch from the beginning and a Canadian branch since 1971. Now 30 countries have I.S.C.M. national organizations, with more planning to sign up soon.

title: U.S. Tells Former Nazi To Leave Country
description: The Justice Department ordered an Austrian mayor to leave the country after confirming he was a sergeant in a World War II Nazi brigade, a department official said today.

title: The Old Commish
description: On Thursday afternoon, Bowie Kuhn will leave the baseball commissioner's office and head directly for a national series. His flight will carry him beyond the ball parks of America, where in other years he would have sat through rain, sleet, fog and hail, toward his destination of Seoul, South Korea.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many college football players have been three-time all- Americans since Red Grange achieved it in the 1920's?

title: REAGAN IS KEY FOR G.O.P. IN SENATE RACE IN JERSEY
description: When President Reagan campaigned recently in Hammonton, N.J., he put his arm around the shoulder of Mary Mochary and urged the thousands of people in the audience to send her to the United States Senate.

title: St. Francis Prep Routs Iona Prep
description: St. Francis Prep, the defending Catholic Schools Football League champion, opened its season yesterday by overwhelming Iona Prep, 30- 14, at St. John's University. The victory extended the Terriers' unbeaten streak to 17 games, including one tie.

title: NEW LIFE FOR CONTINENTAL AIR
description: When Jim Wright returned to work at Continental Air Lines last year, shortly after the carrier filed for protection from its creditors, his salary was cut to $30,000 from $45,000. His standing in the cockpit went from co-pilot to the lowest rank of flight engineer.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 24, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WORLD CENTER

title: ON LOWER EAST SIDE, A SYNAGOGUE BEGINS A NEW LIFE
description: A silence of 50 years was broken gently - as much by the squealing of young children as by the echoing voices of their elders - as the elegant, long-abandoned sanctuary of the Eldridge Street Synagogue was rededicated yesterday.

title: BOOKS ; JEWISH LIFE
description: THE OUTSIDER. By Howard Fast. 311

title: Pilot Dies in Illinois Crash
description: A homemade ultralight airplane crashed Saturday at a private airstrip west of Chicago, killing the pilot, the police said. The pilot, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, was the only person aboard the single-engine plane.

title: DISPUTE FLARES AMONG FRENCH BANKS
description: A furious dispute has erupted among France's mainly nationalized banks over an agreement between Credit Lyonnais and American Express that would allow non-French holders of American Express cards to draw francs directly from the bank's automatic cash machines.

title: CUBS CLINCH A TIE
description: Gary Matthews drove in five runs with a double and a homer today as the Chicago Cubs clinched a tie for the National League East championship - their first title of any kind in 39 years - with a doubleheader sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: No Headline
description: A Caribbean Festival To Begin Next Month

title: Politics Takes No Holiday
description: Taking no chances in this election year, President Reagan on Friday proclaimed Oct. 8 as Columbus Day and Oct. 9 as Leif Ericsson Day. In doing so, he avoiding any judgment on whether the Italian or the Norwegian was first to reach America.

title: TAX DEBATE: WIDE ISSUES
description: There is more to the discussion about taxes in the Presidential campaign than Walter F. Mondale's promise to raise them and President Reagan's assurances that he would not. What is going on, according to many authorities, is a basic national debate over how to run the country.

title: MONDALE AN ISSUE IN CAROLINA RACE
description: Senator Jesse Helms and Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., exchanged caustic attacks tonight in the third debate of their heated campaign for the United States Senate.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 24, 1984: MONDAY Amer ExpressSCM CorpAmeron IncSterchi BrosCapital Cities Comm

title: DEFENSE ASSISTS COWBOYS
description: The cornerback Everson Walls had two interceptions and the safety Michael Downs had two sacks and blocked an extra-point attempt to highlight a defensive effort by the Dallas Cowboys in their 20-6 victory over the Green Bay Packers today.

title: Futures/Options; Philadelphia's Currency Role
description: PHILADELPHIA WHETHER or not last Friday's intervention by the West German central bank to prop up the mark signaled the end of the dollar's long advance against most major foreign currencies remains to be seen. What was not in doubt was that the intervention caused the dollar to plunge and it gave substance to the newest, fastest growing and most ''invisible'' foreign exchange options market - the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: EVENTS Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Wagner's ''Lohengrin,'' 7. PETER ALLEN, singer-songwriter, Carnegie Hall, 8. DIANA ROSS, pop singer, Radio City Music Hall, 8. ROBERT HERRING, baritone; INGE HULGAARD, soprano, Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street, 8.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 7:30 P.M. The Mets' purpose is twofold: to keep alive their slim chance for first place in the National League East, and to keep the Phillies from catching them.

title: Stockman to Play Mondale
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, will play the role of Walter F. Mondale in rehearsing President Reagan for the forthcoming campaign debates, Newsweek magazine reported today. Four years ago, Mr. Stockman portrayed President Jimmy Carter in the Reagan debate rehearsals. Representative Lynn Martin, Republican of Illinois, will play Geraldine A. Ferraro in rehearsals with Vice President Bush for the Vice Presidential debates.

title: TAX-EXEMPT ISSUES REMAIN HEAVY
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, where the Government has scheduled auctions of new issues due in three, six and 12 months.

title: Ali in Khartoum For Islamic Fete
description: Muhammad Ali, in Sudan to celebrate the 1983 imposition of Islamic law, dismissed fears about his medical problems today and said his health was sound.

title: Alcott Triumphs
description: Amy Alcott shot a one-under-par 72 for the final round to win the $175,000 San Jose Classic by two strokes today at Almaden Country Club.

title: Principal Is Suspended Over Religion Classes
description: An elementary school principal who introduced classes in religion was suspended after he refused to concede that the courses violated the Constitution, a school board spokesman said.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Commercial Credit Co. , Baltimore, is under review for its debt and commercial paper ratings for possible downgrading by Moody's Investors Service.

title: KOCH WILL FIGHT EFFORT TO EXTEND TAX-BREAK PLAN
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would oppose an effort by some City Council members to expand the areas in Manhattan where rental apartment buildings would be eligible for tax breaks under legislation proposed by his administration.

title: Baseball and Ballet
description: Joanne Steinbrenner, wife of the

title: Study Says Big Traders Can Sway Index Option
description: A special study committee appointed by the Chicago Board Options Exchange has concluded that sophisticated stock trading strategies can affect the value of stock indexes at the expiration of index options.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amedco Inc., Chesterfield, Mo., a company in the health care industry, named Wayne A. Scheer to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: Always Prepared
description: Never let it be said that the State Department is not forehanded. Next year will mark the 40th anniversaries of two major conferences between the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union that helped bring World War II to a close on the diplomatic front.

title: EDITORS' NETWORK AIDS REAGAN'S BID
description: The conservative publishers of small-town daily and weekly newspapers are organizing to support the re- election campaign of President Reagan and Vice President Bush.

title: HELLER TALKS OF ILLNESS AND KING DAVID BOOK
description: In December 1981, when Joseph Heller was about two years into the writing of his newly published novel, ''God Knows,'' he was suddenly hit with Guillain-Barre syndrome, an inflammation of the muscle nerves that results in paralysis. ''It came on very fast,'' he said. ''I was in Santa Fe. I'd been jogging and sunbathing all summer. I looked gorgeous. Then, suddenly, my muscles just went.

title: NESTLE, LOOKING FOR SAFETY,CONTINUES BROAD SHIFT TO U.S.
description: Carl L. Angst, executive vice president of Nestle S.A., put the case for change compactly: ''If you are in a world where risks are increasing, where it becomes more and more difficult to invest in developing countries, you turn increasingly to low- risk regions.''

title: 20 Soviet Bombers Fly Close to Japan
description: Japanese fighter planes were scrambled today when Soviet aircraft, including Backfire bombers, appeared off northern Japan, the Defense Agency said.

title: Market Place; Omark Trying New Methods
description: OMARK INDUSTRIES is not a huge company, nor is it in a glamorous industry - its main product is chains for chain saws. But Omark is making a name for itself by putting the latest management ideas into practice.

title: Blacks in Baseball
description: Joe Black, who won 15 games as a rookie with the 1952 Brooklyn Dodgers, will be among a number of former Negro League players who'll appear Wednesday night at Union County College in Cranford, N.J., in an exhibition entitled ''Before You Can Say Jack Robinson: Black Baseball in New Jersey in the Era of the Color Line.''

title: BROWNS OVERTAKE STEELERS
description: Paul McDonald, who became the quarterback this season after Brian Sipe joined the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, passed for 222 yards and two touchdowns in the second half to rally the Cleveland Browns to a 20-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today.

title: Sting Ties Series With 3-1 Victory
description: Karl-Heinz Granitza scored the decisive goal late in the second half today as the Chicago Sting scored a 3-1 victory over the Vancouver Whitecaps and tied their North American Soccer League playoff series at 1-1.

title: Media General Chief Retiring RICHMOND, Sept. 23 (AP)
description: Alan S. Donnahoe will retire

title: ALLEGATIONS OF CHILD ABUSE STUDIED AT WEST PT. CENTER
description: The F.B.I. is investigating allegations of physical and sexual abuse at a day-care center for the children of Army personnel and civilian employees of the United States Military Academy at West Point, military and Federal Bureau of Investigation officials said yesterday.

title: SUBSIDIES WILL BE CUT
description: Israel's coalition Government announced new austerity measures today designed to cut the country's nearly 400 percent inflation rate and narrow the trade gap.

title: Good News On the Lamppost Front
description: When Margot Gayle looked up, she

title: A LESSON IN GOLD-MEDAL ECONOMICS
description: For some athletes, the Olympic Games became a ticket to the whirling, sparkling, all-American, publicity-and-commerce merry-go- round. On this special carousel, the spin may be dizzying, but all the rings are gold, and the challenge is to see how many you can grab before the merry-go-round throws you off.

title: Venezuelan Repayment Pact
description: The Venezuelan Government announced today that it had reached an agreement in principle with foreign banks to restructure $20.75 billion of its $27.5 billion in foreign debt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The triathlon is the sport of the 80's as running was the sport of the 70's.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman of Nike Back as President
description: Nike Inc., the apparel and athletic shoe manufacturer, has announced that Philip H. Knight, its co-founder, chairman and chief executive officer, would reassume the post of president, which he relinquished just over a year ago.

title: RIGGINS HELPS REDSKINS STOP PATRIOTS
description: When John Riggins woke up this morning, his back hurt. That's not especially newsworthy. He injured his sciatic nerve in a Monday night game last year and it has bothered him on and off ever since.

title: 2 Die in Brawling In Turbulent Indian City
description: Two people were killed and several were seriously hurt in separate Hindu-Moslem clashes in the troubled city of Hyderabad, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: CONCENTRATION IS WATCHWORD AT CROQUET CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: It took 10 cases of Champagne and 200 lunches - as well as four balls, one yellow, one blue, one red and one black - to play the final round of the United States National Croquet Championships yesterday in Central Park.

title: Kirkpatrick Says U.S. Cannot Allow Attacks
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, said today that the United States could not allow attacks against its overseas posts.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO FEAR SANDINISTA PUBLICITY COUP
description: The State Department's negative response to Nicaragua's acceptance of a Central American peace plan was based partly on concerns that the Sandinistas' announcement would be a public relations coup, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: HELPING IN A HOME OFF CAMPUS
description: THEY are not parent and child although they belong to different

title: VANS ARE CARRYING MORE COMMUTERS AND CUTTING INTO CITY'S BUS BUSINESS
description: Along Cropsey Avenue in Brooklyn, vans - many with tinted-glass windows and fancy paint jobs - seem as numerous as city buses most mornings. In Queens, near the 169th Street subway stop, dozens of vans line up to wait for customers coming off the trains in the afternoon.

title: WHERE MONDALE AND FERRARO DIFFER
description: As the campaign progresses, differences have emerged between Walter F. Mondale and his running mate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, on some key issues.

title: APOLITICAL SOURCE FOR A POLITICAL GAIN
description: The law requiring appointment of an independent counsel to investigate evidence of possible crimes by top officials has worked very nicely for the Reagan Administration lately, even though the Administration dislikes it quite a bit.

title: WHAT'S IN, WHAT'S NOT: AN AUTUMN HARVEST
description: Some people migrate northward to find fall. But the trend-watchers - experts on the city's seasonal changes - stay here and find it in the clubs and cafes and boutiques and on the streets.

title: By Eva Hoffman;
description: REFUGEE SCHOLARS IN AMERICA:

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: WAR GAMES SAID TO SHOW ALLIED READINESS
description: United States, West German and British troops, who have been conducting annual autumn maneuvers near this Bavarian village, have reached a level of readiness in training and weapons unapproached for a decade, military officials here say.

title: Jerry Volpe, Golf Pro, Dies;He Taught Many Celebrities
description: Jerry Volpe, the golf professional at the Englewood (N.J.) Golf Club from 1946 to 1963, died of a heart attack Saturday.

title: Mondale Aide Cites Bombing
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign chairman said today that the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut was a political issue and would remain one until President Reagan answered the question, ''How could it happen again?'' The chairman of the Democratic Presidential campaign, James A. Johnson, said in appearance on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' that the car-bomb attack Thursday ''outrages the American people.''

title: CITRUS GROWER PRAISED FOR NOT HIDING CANKER
description: For Franklyn Ward, the ordeal began on a bright Thursday morning more than four weeks ago.

title: DMINGO FACING 'LOHENGRIN' AT MET
description: Around this time last year, the music world and the press were abuzz with speculation about the Metropolitan Opera's opening night. Would Domingo sing? Could he? The famed Spanish tenor had put the management on notice that he was not sure he could handle the long, difficult, high- flying role he had taken on in ''Les Troyens.'' (He could, as it turned out.)

title: FEDERAL BANK RESCUE WAY BEYOND THE CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: E. Brooke Lee Is Dead at 91; Political Leader in Maryland
description: E. Brooke Lee, a former speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates and a member of a famous political family, died of pneumonia Friday at his home in Damascus. Md. He was 91 years old.

title: 'HILL STREET' WINS BEST SERIES EMMY
description: As has been its habit in the last few years, NBC's police drama ''Hill Street Blues'' won top prizes in the 36th annual presentation of the Emmy awards last night in Pasadena, Calif.

title: T-Shirt With a Twist
description: Peter Barrett, an official of the

title: The Kilrea Brood
description: Diane, who is 26 years old, is a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, assigned to the drug division in Montreal.

title: New Dean Appointed A
description: Teachers College of Columbia University has announced the appointment of Dr. Judith Berman Brandenburg as dean.

title: DENIS WATSON'S 68 GOOD FOR $162,000
description: Denis Watson of South Africa birdied the last hole to complete a wind- blown round of 68 and score a one-shot victory today in the richest tournament on the PGA Tour, the $1,122,500 Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational.

title: The Worm and the Apple ; Busted
description: Drug Lesson

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF A STATE TROOPER IS DISCOVERED DEAD
description: A man suspected of killing a state police detective was found yesterday hanging from a tree, apparently a suicide victim, in woods near Princeton, N.J., the authorities said.

title: Karen Wollman, Designer, Bride of Kenneth A. Siegel
description: At the Brotherhood Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday Karen Wollman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wollman of New York, was married to Kenneth Alan Siegel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Siegel of Wantagh, L.I. Rabbi Irving J. Block performed the ceremony.

title: DEMOCRATIC AIDE ASKS A REAGAN CHECK ON ORIGIN OF HECKLING
description: The national chairman of the Democratic Presidential campaign today urged President Reagan to seek to determine who was involved in heckling Walter F. Mondale and Geraldine A. Ferraro at recent campaign appearances.

title: Dollar Sale Explained
description: Contary to widespread belief, the dramatic sales of dollars by the West German central bank last Friday was not part of a grand European plan to drive down the price of the United States currency, according to German bankers attending the annual meetings here of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Dutch Industry Output
description: The Netherlands' seasonally adjusted industrial production fell 2 percent in July from June, but rose 4.2 percent from July 1983, the Central Bureau of Statistics reported on Friday. Manufacturing output, a narrower measure that excludes the natural gas sector, decreased nine-tenths of 1 percent from June but was up 4 percent from a year earlier.

title: ANALYSTS SURPRISED BY A RISE IN YIELDS
description: The specter of a heavier-than-normal supply of Treasury notes and bonds in coming weeks plus concern over the implications of Friday's sharp drop in the value of the dollar helped cause a quick rise in interest rates late last week.

title: THE STRIKE: UNIONS ADJUSTING TACTICS
description: The United Automobile Workers and the United Mine Workers, unions with histories of using the strike as a blunt instrument, demonstrated last week that the instrument can also be used with surgical precision. In doing so, they have suggested fresh possiblities for labor's ultimate weapon, which has lost much of its power in recent years.

title: SOME EX-VOLUNTEERS UNEASY OVER CENTRAL AMERICAN ROLE
description: It is not just the flow of United States military aid to Central America that is increasing. Over the next three years, the number of Peace Corps volunteers headed for Honduras, Guatemala, Costa Rica and Belize will more than double, to some 1,200 workers.

title: Shoemaker Given 7-Day Suspension
description: Bill Shoemaker, who rode Precisionist and lost a close decision to Gate Dancer in the Super Derby on Saturday, was suspended today for seven days by Louisiana Downs stewards for whipping Gate Dancer in the stretch.

title: THE MOSLEM VEIL IN THE CITY: A MATTER OF TRADITION
description: ''Women in New York look at me like I lost my head when I put on my veil,'' said the wife of an Iranian engineering student whose blue polyester veil exposed only a small circle of face. ''But I feel sorry for

title: A MANDATE TRANSCENDING ISSUES OF HOUSING THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1984 International The U.S. Embassy move in Beirut was explained by President Reagan at a meeting with reporters in New York. He acknowledged that American personnel had been moved into the new embassy building near East Beirut last summer before all security measures had been completed. But he said that this had been done ''because it represented more safety than the one we were in.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Lebanese faced mortal danger when the United States Embassy was moved to the Christian suburb of Aukar near East Beirut from West Beirut, neighbors of the embassy said. The attitude of local residents reflects the deep security quandary that the United States faces with all of its diplomatic establishments in Lebanon. (A8:1.)

title: U.S. FURLS THE FLAG AT SCHOOL FOR LATIN MILITARY
description: The American flag was folded for what appeared to be the last time here this week as the School of the Americas, the main United States military training base for Latin America, formally closed its doors after 38 years in operation.

title: RULES ON INSURANCE FOR VAN OPERATORS
description: Van operators certified by the State Transportation Department are required to have more insurance than private motorists.

title: Intelligence Shake-Up
description: Theoretically, the Senate and

title: Ritual Slaughter of a Sheep Provokes Protest in London
description: An Iranian diplomat is being reported to the British Government over an incident in which a sheep was ritually slaughtered in a London street, the police said today.

title: BRADFORD CHAMBERS, DIRECTOR OF COUNCIL ON BOOKS, IS DEAD
description: Bradford Chambers, director of the Council on Interracial Books for Children, an organization devoted to promoting bias-free textbooks and children's literature, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Saturday. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Bellport, L.I.

title: LAW REVIEW IS CAUGHT IN CORPORATE CROSSFIRE
description: To Martin Lipton and Joseph Flom, there is nothing new about being on opposite sides of a corporate takeover fight. But it is not every day that they find the august Harvard Law Review coming between them.

title: REAGAN CONCEDES EMBASSY SECURITY WAS NOT COMPLETE
description: President Reagan acknowledged yesterday that American personnel were moved into the new United States Embassy building near East Beirut this summer before all security measures were completed. But he said this had been done because the new location ''represented more safety than the one we were in.''

title: Cardinal, in New York, Calls Filipinos Misled
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, said in a homily from the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday that the Philippines and its people ''continue to be enmeshed in an economic and political crisis of calamitous proportions'' and predicted ''tragic consequences should our leaders continue to mistrust and mislead them.''

title: U. of New Mexico Offers Presidency to Professor
description: The regents of the University of New Mexico have offered the post of president of the university to Thomas Farer, a Rutgers law professor. Mr. Farer indicated he will accept the post pending final negotiations and formal approval at the regents' meeting Oct. 9.

title: 3 NAVY SHIPS ARRIVE OFF LEBANON AS A U.S. ENVOY VISITS DAMASCUS
description: Three American warships including the landing ship Shreveport arrived off the Lebanese coast today, an American Embassy spokesman said.

title: Brief Encounter
description: At that rare morning hour when the

title: British Airlines in Route War
description: A struggle over the shape of the British airline industry is expected to be resolved soon when the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher decides whether to transfer some of British Airways' routes to other British airlines before selling control of the state-owned company to the private sector.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1984

title: Bus Crash in India Kills 34
description: A bus skidded off a winding highway and plunged into a gorge in the Himalayan foothills today, killing 34 Hindu pilgrims and injuring 11, the United News of India reported. The news agency quoted authorities as saying the group was returning from a mountaintop temple at Badrinath when the crash occurred 185 miles northeast of New Delhi in the state of Uttar Pradesh.

title: CANDIDATES FOR ASSEMBLY SEAT FACE A PRIMARY VOTE-AGAIN
description: When they added up the voting machine totals, Jim Brennan led Louise Finney by four votes in the Democratic primary in the 51st Assembly District in Brooklyn.

title: Career Ends for McCallum, Navy Star
description: For the second straight week, a leading ballcarrier and candidate for the 1984 Heisman Trophy was injured so badly that he will miss the remainder of this season. In the case of Napoleon McCallum of Navy, who suffered a broken left ankle Saturday, that also means the end of his varsity career. He is a senior who expects to be ated and to receive his commission next spring.

title: Filipinos Flee As Volcano Erupts
description: Some 50,000 people fled their homes today after the Mount Mayon volcano in the central Philippines erupted, disaster relief officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Myth in Modern Life Is Subject of Conference

title: EMILY KATZ IS MARRIED TO Dr. EDUARDO ANHALT
description: Emily Ann Katz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice B. Katz of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Eduardo Anhalt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique Anhalt of Mexico City and New York. Rabbi Samuel Lerer performed the ceremony at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Washington Watch; Rift Continues On Steel Quota
description: LAST week's Presidential decision to protect the steel industry finally got Dan Rostenkowski off the hook. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee has been blocking steel quota legislation that most of his Democratic colleagues supported.

title: Rath Packing Reports Offer
description: Rath Packing Company's board has received and approved an offer to buy the company from a group headed by the Financial Resources Corporation of New Jersey, Rath said Friday.

title: PRICE TAG FOR GETTING THE LEAD OUT OF GASOLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: ORDERS FOR TOOLS HOLDING UP
description: Machine tool orders surged 46.5 percent in August from their sharply depressed year-ago level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said yesterday.

title: BOOK LINKS NIXON TO '72 WATERGATE BREAK-IN
description: A new book drawing on secret memorandums purportedly written by Howard R. Hughes says that President Nixon inspired the Watergate break-in to cover his links with the billionaire.

title: Doctor's License Is Revoked For Diagnosis of Evil Spirits
description: A physician has been stripped of her license for diagnosing patients as possessed by ''demons and evil spirits'' and treating them with excessive amounts of controlled drugs.

title: Chernenko Is Honored With 3d Order of Lenin
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, has been awarded his third Order of Lenin, evidently in connection with his 73d birthday on Monday.

title: Mondale Campaign Names Urban Counselor
description: Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee, has appointed Representative Parren Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, as his national campaign counselor on urban affairs and economic issues.

title: NEW SPIRIT FLOURISHING AT ARMY
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.

title: SWISS VOTERS AGAIN REJECT BAN ON NUCLEAR POWER
description: Swiss voters turned down for the second time today proposals that would have eliminated the country's atomic energy power plants by the year 2000.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM AND 'EVENTS'
description: Merce Cunningham occasionally likes to take separate pieces of his fixed choreography and link these fragments together. As any Cunningham fan knows by now, the resulting performance is called an ''Event.'' Mr. Cunningham and his excellent dance company launched a 10-day series of ''Events'' at the Joyce Theater over the weekend.

title: 12-METERS MEETING IN FRIENDLY WATERS
description: The arena in yachting that once belonged to the America's Cup in Newport, R.I., has moved abroad this year to the luxurious surroundings of the Costa Smeralda Yacht Club in northeast Sardinia.

title: LAROUCHE MULLS OPTION YEAR
description: Pierre Larouche, always tricky on the ice, was equally confusing off it last night when he said he will play out the option year of his contract.

title: 3 DIE IN SOUTH LEBANON CLASH
description: Three people linked to a Palestinian guerrilla group were killed and two others wounded today in a clash with Israeli troops in southern Lebanon.

title: IN STATE APPLE ORCHARDS, TIME IS RIPE FOR HARVEST
description: Warren Smith stood in an orchard here watching a crew of pickers climbing ladders to reach the tops of trees laden with McIntosh apples as the annual state apple harvest began this week.

title: Kenyan Winner
description: Sam Sitonic of Kenya won the Bronx Half Marathon yesterday on the streets surrounding Yankee Stadium.

title: Pacific Isle's Separatists Plan Own Government
description: Melanesian nationalists in New Caledonia say they have decided to break off autonomy talks with France and to elect their own provisional government.

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV DRAW IN CHESS
description: The fifth world championship chess game between Anatoly Karpov and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, ended in a draw this evening. Karpov leads in the match, 1-0.

title: A Sleeping Deaver
description: Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff at the White House, affirmed in a recent television interview that President Reagan sometimes seemed to doze off at boring Cabinet meetings. That caused some consternation at the White House, although it is not known whether Mr. Reagan ever reprimanded Mr. Deaver privately.

title: Bye-bye Basil?
description: Many Washingtonians, as residents of a war-and-peace capital, are constantly mulling profound issues of state. But they also take time out to consider matters of taste.

title: RIVERS'S HISTORY OF JEWS USES MATZOH BACKDROP
description: At an opening-night celebration at the Jewish Museum last evening, an unusual pictorial history of the Jewish people was given its first public showing. The three-part history is painted directly over three images of matzohs - the unleavened bread eaten by Jews at Passover - which form the painted background of each 10-by-14-foot canvas.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Continental Telecom Inc. , a telecommunications company based in Atlanta, had its ratings on outstanding debentures and industrial revenue bonds raised to A-, from BBB, and convertible subordinated debentures to BBBx, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's.

title: BENETTON: FASHION'S MAVERICK
description: When it opens a new boutique, Benetton is usually satisfied with a modest appearance - a bright green facade, say, and wooden clothing shelves propped against the walls. The overall effect is, to say the least, unprepossessing, as befits the fashion equivalent of fast food.

title: INTERNORTH'S GAS FOR TEXAS EASTERN
description: Internorth Inc.'s Northern Natural Gas Company said it had signed a 15-year contract to sell natural gas to the Texas Eastern Corporation's Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation.

title: GOLDEN OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CREDIT MARKETS ; Treasury Security Prices Off
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as prices of Treasury securities declined during the afternoon and closed at about the lowest levels of the day.

title: HIS ADOPTED SON IS HELD
description: A writer who won the 1982 Editors' Book Award for his first novel, about the life of Times Square hustlers, was beaten to death in his Queens apartment by a drifter conspiring with the author's adopted son, to whom the novel was dedicated, the police said yesterday.

title: NAUTILUS ENVIROMEDICAL SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WHERE'S THE BEEF? THE MAIL? THE ARMY? THE TRAIN?
description: Can United States savings bonds and enlistments in the Army be sold the same way as toothpaste and beer?

title: FLAWS SEEN AT WEST BEIRUT EMBASSY
description: Protective steel antirocket netting was still not in place this afternoon atop the United States Embassy building in West Beirut.

title: 9.9% Southland Financial Stake
description: Craig Hall, a Dallas real estate investor, and two of his companies, DSA Financial and Court Players, have bought 1,650,000 common shares, or 9.9 percent of the shares outstanding, of the Southland Financial Corporation for $48.3 million. Mr. Hall told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he and Court Players were ''considering'' buying more shares of Southland, which is based in Irving, Tex.

title: DUTY-FREE STORE UPSETS SMALL UPSTATE BORDER TOWN
description: Jim Wiley set his boning knife down and wiped his large hands on a blood- stained butcher's apron. Like many of his fellow storekeepers, he has been fuming for weeks over the arrival in town of a duty-free store.

title: DELOREAN CASE FIGURE GIVEN PRISON SENTENCE OF 10 YEARS
description: William Morgan Hetrick, an admitted drug smuggler who was indicted with the automobile maker John Z. DeLorean in a cocaine-conspiracy case, was sentenced today to 10 years in Federal prison after prosecutors said he had ''cooperated handsomely'' with the Government.

title: Friar Says Vatican 'Caricatures' Marxism
description: A Brazilian Roman Catholic theologian, in an article published today, likened the Vatican's criticism of liberation theology to ''shooting at the crowd to kill the assassin.''

title: Rare Squirrels Return After 50-Year Absence DOVER, Del., Sept. 24 (AP) - After more than a 50-year absence, Delmarva fox squirrels are back in Delaware, wired with radio transmitters in the hope that they will not disappear again.
description: Seven large, silvery squirrels, three males and four females, were trapped two weeks ago on private property and at the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge near Cambridge, Md.

title: Prices in Denmark Up
description: Danish consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month from July and 6.6 percent from 12 months before, the Government said today. In another report, it said that Denmark's trade deficit in August narrowed to 400 million kroner, or about $36.8 million, from 703 million kroner in July.

title: BENOIT SPORTSWOMAN OF YEAR
description: At 5:30 A.M. yesterday, Joan Benoit started her morning run of eight, nine miles in Freeport, Me. Less than five hours later, hardly looking out of breath, the winner of the first women's Olympic marathon received an award at the Plaza Hotel here from Geraldine A. Ferraro, who has not been running so well.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 8
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 29, 1984.

title: NEW ANALYSIS HINTS ANCIENT EXPLORERS MAPPED ANTARCTIC
description: FOR years a few imaginative authors have argued, based on 16th century maps, that the ice-covered continent of Antarctica was discovered and mapped by an ancient civilization, perhaps one from another planet.
