The latter proposition was dismissed by most geographers and historians as preposterous.

title: COMPUTER SCIENTISTS STYMIED IN THEIR QUEST TO MATCH HUMAN VISION
description: EXPERTS pursuing one of man's most audacious dreams - to create machines that think - have stumbled while taking what seemed to be an elementary first step. They have failed to master vision.

title: WHITE-COLLAR UNION IS SET TO STRIKE TOMORROW AT YALE
description: Members of Yale University's clerical and technical workers union, without a contract after nearly a year of negotiations, have voted to walk out Wednesday if an agreement is not reached by then.

title: FOR WHOM PRESCHOOL EDUCATION IS UNATTAINABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Petitions Oppose S.I. Navy Base
description: An antinuclear group, Mobilization for Survival, presented petitions to city officials yesterday from 30,000 people who oppose the Navy's plan to base ships in New York Harbor. The group says the vessels will be armed with nuclear missiles.

title: Low Profiles
description: Pssst! Who's on the Democratic national ticket?

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 5
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss includes $72,000 loss from restaurant closings in January and a $23,000 loss on the sale of a restaurant in August.

title: A CHANGING CAST AMONG MOVIE STUDIO CHIEFS
description: The heads that wear the tinsel crowns are uneasy.

title: Ex-Policemen Sentenced In Philadelphia Case
description: Seven former policemen, including a onetime deputy commissioner, today were sentenced to up to 18 years in prison for participating in a $350,000 extortion conspiracy to protect illegal gambling.

title: Waldenbooks Chooses Grey
description: account to Grey Advertising,

title: METS BEAT PHILLIES, CLINCHING 2D PLACE
description: When it was over, it was over, and the Mets had no regrets. They were eliminated last night from any stray chance at first place, but they clinched second, and they had the second-best record in the club's 23-year history and the best since the World Series winners of 1969.

title: Savoring a Windfall
description: A moment of triumph can come in

title: Harvester Closing Memphis Factory
description: The International Harvester Company said it would close its Memphis factory as part of a ''consolidation of its North American agricultural equipment operations.''

title: ATTENDANCE IS UP FOR 'A CHORUS LINE'
description: When ''A Chorus Line'' became the longest-running play in Broadway history last Sept. 29 - with a performance uniting 332 past and present cast members and a midnight gala in Shubert Alley - it was an evening of celebration and artistry.

title: CUBS' FAN VS. THE COMMISSIONER
description: Others have suffered longer with the Chicago Cubs in the years since that usually tattered team was in its last World Series, in 1945, but Marty Hennigan remembered exactly when his personal agony began. He was 5 years old in 1957 when his father took him to his first Cubs game at Wrigley Field around this time of year.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Alors, Watteau
description: Art critics of varying competence showed up at the National Gallery on Sunday for the last day of an exhibit of works by Antoine Watteau, the 18th-century French rococo artist. The gallery said that since the exhibition opened June 17, more than twice as many people viewed Watteau's paintings (378,519) as did his drawings (154,214).

title: 2 Bank Companies In Ohio Set Merger
description: Two Cleveland-based bank holding companies, the Society Corporation and the Centran Corporation, yesterday announced an agreement in principle to merge in a transaction valued at about $220 million. The merger would create the second-largest bank holding company in Ohio, after the National City Corporation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''History demonstrates beyond controversy that just as the arms competition has its root in political suspicions and anxieties, so it can be channeled in more stabilizing directions and eventually be eliminated if those political suspicions and anxieties are addressed as well.'' - President Reagan. (A10:5.)

title: S.E.C. INAUGURATES COMPUTER FILING SYSTEM
description: At 11:13 this morning, John S. R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, inserted an eight-inch floppy disk into a computer terminal, sending 85 pages of corporate data speeding into the agency's public reference files and initiating the commission's long-awaited electronic filing and retrieval system.

title: BUSH REASSURES MINERS ON ACID RAIN
description: Vice President Bush descended into a coal mine in this economically hard-pressed region of southern Illinois today, reassuring mine workers that the Reagan Administration did not intend to place restrictions on the emissions of sulfur dioxide from factories and power plants that burn coal.

title: Six Flags in Baltimore
description: The Six Flags Corporation, a subsidiary of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, operates family entertainment parks out in the countryside in five states. Now it is moving into an urban location, opening Six Flags Power Plant in a building near downtown Baltimore. It plans to spend $1 million to promote it and has selected a local agency, Richardson, Myers & Donofrio, to handle it.

title: RAM BACK MAKES THE RIGHT CHOICE
description: At first, Mike Guman of the Los

title: CONTINENTAL BANK WARNS ON SUITS
description: Lawyers for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said today that current and threatened lawsuits by borrowers over a rescue plan for the troubled Chicago bank could delay the $4.5 billion plan.

title: A BAN ON U.S. DRUG EXPORTS WORTH LIFTING
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE KRAIGHER, PILOT IN TWO WARS
description: George Kraigher, who learned to fly in 1914 and served in both World Wars, died Sept. 17 at his home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 93 years old.

title: JAZZ: JIMMY ROWLES
description: EVEN though they play different instruments, the pianist Jimmy Rowles and his daughter Stacy, an accomplished trumpeter, display a familial similarity of musical temperament. The father and daughter were two of five jazz musicians who performed together on Saturday at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Letter Carrier Is Warned About Role in Politics
description: An Indiana letter carrier has been charged with violating the Hatch Act by running for election as the Democratic candidate for a commissioner's seat in Cass County, Mich. The law, enacted in 1939, forbids Federal employees from engaging in partisan political activity.

title: FAST APPROVAL OF MINERS PACT IS SEEN AS VOTE PROCESS BEGINS
description: The United Mine Workers today began an accelerated contract ratification process that union leaders expect will end Thursday, in the first strike-free labor settlement with major coal producers in 20 years.

description: The Rangers aren't sure yet where Reijo Ruotsalainen will end up this season, on defense or at forward, but the quick-skating Finn will remain at left wing for the duration of training camp.

description: Ammirati & Puris, which picked up the $9 million Pulsar Time account in July, is back in the winner's circle again with the United Parcel Service.

title: O.E.C.D. Jobless Rate
description: Overall unemployment in 24 Western industrial countries next year will hold steady at this year's 8.5 percent rate as a result of climbing employment in the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. But the O.E.C.D. said that a record 20 million Europeans, or 11.25 percent of the working population, were likely to be unemployed next year, up sharply from 18 million, or 11 percent, this year.

description: Unions representing a third of Disneyland's employees voted to reject the company's latest contract offer today and authorized a strike against the amusement park, a union spokesman said.

title: Aamco Resignation
description: Calet, Hirsch & Spector has resigned its assignment from Aamco Transmissions because of ''creative differences.'' In this case, especially, those are the most imporant kind, since the agency has been doing only the creative for the last seven years. Aamco got its media buying and placing elsewhere.

description: Democratic officials of the United States Conference of Mayors today made public a survey contending that the poor are not benefiting from the economic recovery.

description: Three convicted killers and two other ''dangerous'' inmates used hacksaw blades to cut their way out of the state prison today, apparently taking advantage of openings left by a renovation project.

title: ZOO RETURNS RARE MONKEY TO THE WILD
description: HOPING to set a precedent, researchers from the National Zoo in Washington have returned 14 captive- bred golden lion tamarins to their native forest home outside Rio de Janeiro. It was the first time that an attempt had been made to return this small monkey species, Leontopithecus r. rosalia, to its native habitat.

title: The Race for Arms, and Votes Ronald Reagan assumed the Presidency as the sworn opponent of the arms control deals negotiated by his predecessors. He said, correctly, that they had not reduced nuclear arms, only channeled them in certain directions. He also argued, wrongly, that this left the United States in imminent danger of a fatal vulnerability. So he set out not only to correct a perceived imbalance but to run an arms race that would force the Russians to beg for relief.
description: Now, campaigning for re-election, Mr. Reagan contends that he has ''repaired'' America's strength and is ready to negotiate a halt. Reductions, he says, depend not on him but on Moscow's readiness to start talking anew.

title: YANKS DROP TWO TO ORIOLES, 8-1 and 7-6
description: The Yankees, one of baseball's hottest teams since mid-July, have hit a cold spell that could ruin what the team had hoped would be an upbeat finish to a disappointing season.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Allied Bancshares Appoints President
description: D. Kent Anderson has been named president of Allied Bancshares Inc., the Houston-based bank holding company announced yesterday.

title: U.S. EMBARKS ON $100 MILLION STUDY OF AGENT ORANGE
description: After years of bureaucratic bickering, Federal health agencies are finally embarking on a full-scale, collaborative investigation of the health effects of exposure to Agent Orange. The studies, which will go on for at least a decade, may prove to be one of the largest medical research projects ever undertaken by the Government.

title: NBC TOPS NETWORKS IN EMMYS
description: NBC led the three major networks in the 36th annual Emmy awards Sunday night in Pasadena, Calif. NBC led in the number of major awards with 11. CBS followed with 10 and ABC was next with 5. Counting the technical awards given last week, NBC received 20, CBS 18 and ABC 16.

title: Bonneville Delays Seen
description: The Bonneville Power Administration tentatively recommended today a further delay for two Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear power plants, increasing the risk that the projects - currently mothballed - may ultimately be killed.

title: Lanier Retires
description: Bob Lanier made it official yesterday. As expected, after 14 National Basketball Association seasons with the Detroit Pistons and the Milwaukee Bucks, 959 regular-season games, 19,248 points and 8 knee operations, the 6-foot-10-inch center announced his retirement at a Milwaukee news conference.

title: STATE POLICE WIN SUIT OVER BIAS AT ACADEMNY
description: A Federal judge today rejected a charge that the New York State Police Academy discriminated against minority recruits in its 1981 class, in which black and Hispanic candidates dropped out at much higher rates than whites.

title: Queen Elizabeth Starts Her Visit to Canada
description: Greeted by a 21-gun salute and sunny skies, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip arrived today for a Canadian visit that will include celebrations marking 200 years of settlement in New Brunswick and Ontario.

title: Masters Settles Kerr-McGee Suits
description: The Masters Energy Corporation said it had settled suits filed against it by the Kerr-McGee Corporation.

title: FIRST SINCE 1945
description: The Chicago Cubs, with Rick Sutcliffe pitching a two-hitter for his 14th straight victory, captured their first championship in 39 years tonight when they won the National League East title by beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief in SportsMonday yesterday incorrectly identified the winner in the women's division of the Bronx Half Marathon Sunday. She was Lisa Chapman of the North Jersey Masters running club.

title: Hundreds in Two States Held in Nuclear Protests By The Associated Press
description: Hundreds of antinuclear protesters yesterday blocked roads at weapons laboratories in California and Massachusetts, resulting in more than 150 arrests.

title: Change in Viewpoints
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., who was assigned to make immediate crises disappear when, working in City Hall, he was known as ''deputy mayor for trouble,'' is spending his postpolitical years taking the long view. Already head of the city's Commission on the Year 2000, he was named advisory board chairman of New York University's urban research center yesterday.

title: F.D.A. MOVES TO PREVENT SITUATION THAT ALLOWED INFANT-DEATH DRUG
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it was instituting procedures to prevent circumstances like those that led to the marketing of a Vitamin E solution that has been linked to 38 deaths of infants.

title: Clean Up the Guardian System New York's system for choosing court-appointed guardians smells awful, but it's not yet clear whether the stench sufficiently offends the judges who run the system. They'll have a chance to clean it up next month, when their administrative board meets to consider remedies.
description: Guardians collect lucrative fees for managing estates of children, incapacitated adults and people who've died. Flagrant favoritism for judges' relatives and political friends isn't new, but recent publicity raises hopes for ending historic indifference.

description: THE Soviet Union, the other Warsaw Pact countries and Cuba have significantly stepped up their scholarship aid for students from Latin American and Caribbean countries, a study by the General Accounting Office shows. American foreign affairs and military authorities view such signs of long-range Soviet involvement in the United States sphere of influence with serious concern.

description: Members of minority groups and poor people suffer disproportionately from environmental pollution, according to a report issued today by the Urban Environment Conference.

title: Cap Ruling Asked Federal Judge
description: Robert L. Carter reserved decision yesterday on the request by Leon Wood, one of the Philadelphia 76ers' two first-round draft choices, for a preliminary injunction that would prevent the N.B.A. from enforcing the college draft and the league's salary cap. title: The Editorial Notebook; George Bush's Daily Dilemma
description: Traveling with Vice President Bush is like traveling with a circus tiger in a cage. His mission is not to make national news; that's for the President. His campaign is meant to get on television in far-flung media markets and to flatter small-town reporters with press conferences in this Elks Hall and that Holiday Inn. But there's an obstacle - the planeful of national reporters following his campaign.

title: DEMOCRATS ACCUSE THE PRESIDENT OF MAKING LIGHT OF THE BOMBING
description: Democratic leaders accused President Reagan today of making light of the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Lebanon, and Congressional committees pressed ahead with plans to investigate why security at the embassy had been breached.

The veteran center, who Sunday night scored three goals in the Rangers' 7-1 exhibition victory over the Islanders, said after the game that he had notified Ranger managment that he would no longer negotiate on a new contract.

description: Steve Trout, the left-handed pitcher who broke the Chicago Cubs' longest losing streak of the year, five games, when he beat the St. Louis Cardinals Sunday, feels that by ending the downward spin the team finally put to rest the specter of the Cubs' late collapse in 1969.

title: Aarthur Is Changed to Aava

After examining the animal, zoo officials revised their earlier judgment that the aardvark was a male. It is difficult to determine the sex of infant aardvarks because the appearance of newborn males and females is very similar, zookeepers said.

The utility said the agreement, which increases its bank borrowing facilities to $445 million from $230 million, will provide it with financial flexibility while it completes the Nine Mile Point nuclear power plant No. 2.

title: ROYALS WIN TWO, LEAD BY HALF-GAME
description: Darryl Motley drove in six runs with a double and a grand-slam home run in support of the rookie pitcher Danny Jackson tonight, powering the Kansas City Royals to a 12-4 victory and a sweep of a doubleheader over the California Angels.

title: MOSCOW GOSSIP: EMBASSY JOGGING AND NEWS OF CRIME
description: This has been an autumn of political mysteries in Moscow. How sick is Konstantin U. Chernenko? Why is Andrei A. Gromyko meeting with President Reagan? Why was Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov dismissed as Chief of Staff?

title: F.T.C. Inquiry On St. Regis Bid
description: The Champion International Corporation said it had been served with subpoenas by the Federal Trade Commission seeking additional information relating to its proposed takeover of the St. Regis Corporation.

title: THE FEDERAL EXPRESS STORY
description: SHARES of the Federal Express Corporation tumbled 6 5/8 points last week, to 37 3/4, after the company disclosed that operating expenses of Zapmail, its new electronic document transmission service, had cut sharply into the latest quarterly earnings. But the stock strengthened yesterday after several analysts issued favorable comments about the company, which in recent years has turned overnight delivery of small packages into a bonanza.

title: THE G.O.P. PLATFORM-GROUNDS FOR WORRY
description: Party platforms are traditionally meant neither to be read nor to be believed. The Reagan Republican platform of 1984 is different.

title: JUDGE REJECTS CBS MOTION TO END WESTMORELAND SUIT
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to dismiss the $120 million libel suit that Gen. William C. Westmoreland filed against CBS concerning a television documentary about the Vietnam War.

title: ULSTER INMATES RESTART STRIKE
description: Four Protestant inmates resumed a hunger strike in a Northern Ireland prison today to protest being locked up with Roman Catholic prisoners, officials said.

title: TONY FRANCIOSA FINDS OTHERS' LOST LOVES
description: IN ''Highway to Heaven,'' the

title: COUNCILMAN ALTERS STAND ON EXTENDING HOUSING TAXBREAKS
description: The head of a City Council committee reversed himself yesterday and said that he would reconsider changes he made last week in a Koch administration plan to restrict tax benefits for rental housing.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wife of Australia's Premier Tells of the Family's Ordeal
description: The wife of Prime Minister Bob Hawke said tonight that her daughter and son- in-law were heroin addicts and that concern over them had led her husband to burst into tears at a news conference.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $280,316. c-After income from discontinued operations of $217,893.

title: Healers by Faith Get Prison in Son's Death
description: A husband and wife whose faith-healing religious sect taught them to shun medical care were sentenced to five years in prison today for allowing their infant son to die at home of untreated pneumonia.

title: 13 REFINERS AGREE STATIONS MAY SELL ANY BRAND OF GAS
description: The nation's major oil companies have agreed to allow more than 50,000 service station operators to sell any brand of gasoline they choose, even though their neon signs and franchise agreements identify them with a single brand. The result, industry experts say, will be more competition and lower prices.

title: Tandem Ventures
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had formed ventures with units of Scandinavian Airlines System Group and with Bedford Associates Inc. to develop an airline reservations system called Spar and to market 22 other software packages with airline- related applications. One of the two S.A.S. units is owned with Enator A.B. Tandem said Spar would be installed in December 1985.

title: Market Declines in Slower Trading
description: The general stock market staged a broad decline yesterday in much slower trading although the Dow Jones industrial average finished with a small gain following its selloff on Friday.

title: MORE MUNICIPALITIES JOINING DRIVE TO CUT SOUTH AFRICA LINKS
description: Ten years ago it was college students who most visibly protested South Africa's official system of racial separation by putting pressure on trustees to sell stock in companies that did business in South Africa. Now American cities and states are, more and more, restricting investments in South Africa.

title: MICHENER THANKS TO SWARTHMORE: $2 MILLION
description: In the spring of 1925 a ''small-town boy with promising high-school grades'' won a $2,000 scholarship to attend Swarthmore College.

title: PUBLISHED RUSSIAN LITERATURE
description: Carl Proffer, a Michigan professor who translated, edited and published dozens of books of Russian literature, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 46 years old.

title: Gray Sold Part Of His Holding Harry J. Gray, chairman and
description: chief executive officer of

title: SUSPECT'S FATHER FACES A NEW ORDER
description: Since his 17- year-old son was arrested on murder charges, Bernard Port has repeatedly refused to testify against him. So has Odette Port, his wife and the youth's stepmother. Twelve days ago they went to jail for it.

title: AN ISRAELI PULLOUT: THE OBSTACLES IN THE WAY
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said last week that Israeli troops would be withdrawn from southern Lebanon ''in a matter of several months.'' But officials here say they face many obstacles before such a pullout can be carried out.

title: Andretti Wins
description: Mario Andretti held off Tom Sneva with the aid of a caution flag four laps from the finish yesterday and won the rain-interrupted Detroit News Grand Prix Indianapolis-car race at Brooklyn, Mich. Johnny Rutherford , who had earned the pole position and was leading when the race was halted Sunday after 33 laps, hit the concrete wall in the fourth turn of Michigan International Speedway's two-mile banked track. He was not injured, but the 200-mile race was completed running single-file under the yellow flag.

title: Floods Kill 200 in Nepal
description: Floods and landslides have killed at least 200 people and blocked a major supply road in Nepal for nine days, the official Nepalese press agency said today. The road, which was reopened today, runs south through Nepal to Bihar in eastern India and is used to bring fuel and basic commodities to the landlocked Himalayan kingdom. Its closing caused acute shortages and forced fuel rationing.

title: DONOVAN CALLS INQUIRY IN BRONX A 'WITCH HUNT'
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan testified for more than four hours before a Bronx grand jury yesterday and later described the panel's investigation as a ''witch hunt.''

title: When Cities Rig the Market The Supreme Court holds that local governments are subject to the antitrust laws unless specifically exempted by a state. Congress therefore wants to protect local taxpayers from damage claims but not so much that it lets cities undermine business competition. A sensible compromise seems at hand, permitting the courts to issue injunctions against a city's anti-competitive policy. But the cities ask too much when they aim to prohibit any action against them by the Federal Trade Commission.
description: Local governments have all too often used regulations and franchise restrictions to serve special interests, from refuse collectors to taxi fleets. But the foolish or venal actions of local officials should not leave their taxpayers vulnerable to the treble damage awards that are used to punish other antitrust violators.

title: GREEN AND STEIN, IN FIRST DEBATE, TRADE CHARGES OVER THEIR QUALIFICATIONS
description: Representative Bill Green and Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan yesterday challenged each other's qualifications in their first debate in what is expected to be one of the toughest, most expensive House races in the country.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 2
India Is Reported Getting 40 MIG-29's From Soviet
description: India will receive an initial order of about 40 new supersonic MIG-29 jet fighters from the Soviet Union, with the first scheduled to arrive before the end off the year, the International Defense Review reported today.

title: Saatchi Gets Almay
description: Saatchi & Saatchi/Compton Worldwide, which works for International Playtex in seven markets abroad, has had its New York office tapped to take over the toiletries and cosmetics business of Almay Cosmetics.

title: MUSIC: 'LOHENGRIN,' WITH DOMINGO
description: THE major question facing the house last night when the Metropolitan Opera opened its centennial-plus-one season lay in the voice of Placido Domingo, who had never sung a German role here but was taking on the title part in ''Lohengrin.'' There never was much doubt that the handsome Spanish tenor would make a dazzling knight in shining raiment (this August Everding production dispenses with the armor), but whether Mr. Domingo would be overtaxed by a role generally the property of Wagnerian heldentenors could not be confidently predicted.

title: REAGAN, AT U.N., ASKS SOVIET FOR LONG-TERM 'FRAMEWORK' TO PRESS FOR ARMS CONTROL
description: President Reagan's highly conciliatory remarks to the General Assembly today marked the culmination of a yearlong effort by the Administration to convince the Soviet Union, the American public and Washington's allies that he is sincere in seeking a new era in Soviet-American relations, despite his previous harsh anti-Soviet remarks.

title: Allnet Contract
description: Allnet Communication Services Inc. said it had signed a one-year agreement with five telecommunication companies of Ameritech for selective billing services. The companies - Illinois Bell, Indiana Bell, Michigan Bell, Ohio Bell and Wisconsin Bell - will bill Allnet customers who use the company's long-distance network.

title: A LONG, LONG WAY FROM OKLAHOMA
description: Draped over the arm of a chair in LaDonna Harris's sunlit office on Massachusetts Avenue is a khaki-colored Army blanket, a gift bestowed upon her by the Winnebago Indians in a recent ceremony making her an ''Honorary Pow Wow Princess.''

title: REALTY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Great Cadillac Debate
description: The Cadillac is gone from the Hard

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOWARD A. KIEVAL
description: Howard A. Kieval, director of the American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology for the New York Region and a former executive director of Big Brothers Inc., died of a heart attack Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TV SHOW LETS VIEWERS SOLVE CRIME
description: Television ostensibly values novelty but sometimes seems confused about what to do with a novel show. A case in point is ''Scene of the Crime,'' an offbeat new mystery show that will be broadcast Sunday at 10 P.M. on NBC, and is intended to be the start of a series.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Charged In Their Mothers' Deaths
description: Two teen-age boys were charged today with murdering their mothers and one youth's sister after the authorities found the bodies hidden in a mobile home, the police said.

title: People
description: * Eugene O'Sullivan , director of client services of Young & Rubicam New York, was named executive vice president of Y.&R. USA.

title: Hambrecht Link
description: Hambrecht & Quist and Woodman, Kirkpatrick & Gilbreath, investment banking firms based here, announced an agreement in principle to merge Woodman, Kirkpatrick & Gilbreath into Hambrecht & Quist. Final details are being worked out. Both companies provide investment banking services to high- technology and emerging growth companies.

title: WHAT YOU SEE IS WHAT YOU GET
description: There has been plenty of talk this Presidential year about images and perceptions and backstage campaign maneuvers - as if such things were going to be decisive in November. In the opinions of campaign professionals, who are paid to attend to it, this ''inside story'' is the key to understanding the election. But there is also an ''outside story'' - a record of public words and actions and the ideas they reflect. And in this election, as in almost every other, the outside story has been most important.

title: EX-HEAD OF F.A.A. IS CHARGED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged J. Lynn Helms, the former head of the Federal Aviation Administration, and a business partner with diverting $1.2 million from an issue of tax-exempt municipal bonds to their personal use.

title: West German Coalition Urges A Ban on Chemical Weapons
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition called for a global, verifiable ban on chemical weapons today.

title: Cranston and Hart Say Mondale Can Win
description: Two unsuccessful candidates for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination said today that they believed that the man who defeated them, Walter F. Mondale, had a chance to defeat President Reagan.

title: FOR RESORT WEAR, NEW SHORT SEPARATES
description: Whether skirt lengths continue their descent toward the ankles or remain steady just below the knee, women will not have to hide their legs in warm weather. Hardly a designer has shown a resort collection on or off Seventh Avenue without introducing at least one - and it's usually more than one - pair of shorts.

title: West German Spy Suspect
description: West German counterin telligence agents have detained an employee of a leading manufacturer of NATO's latest multirole combat plane on suspicion of spying, an official spokesman said today. He declined to give any details about the suspect or his job at Messerschmitt-B"olkow- Blohm, which plays a leading role in production of the Atlantic alliance's new multirole plane, the Tornado.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Utility Agency Makes Offering in California
description: The Southern California Public Power Authority is offering $235 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 11 percent for bonds due in 2021, according to tentative prices announced yesterday by underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. For shorter maturities, bonds were tentatively offered with yields ranging from 8.75 percent in 1990 to 10.60 percent in 1999 and 10 7/8 percent in 2004.

title: 'MINELIKE OBJECT' OFF EGYPT IS LINKED TO RUSSIANS
description: A mysterious cylindrical ''minelike object'' found in the Gulf of Suez almost two weeks ago is probably a tube-launched mine of Soviet manufacture, according to Egyptian military sources and others close to the investigation.

title: LTV Layoffs
description: The LTV Corporation said it would idle certain semifinishing steel facilities at its Aliquippa, Pa., works, effective Sept. 30, idling 360 workers.

title: ; YOUNG PEOPLE LURING PEERS TO THE POLLS
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN OPERA OPENS ITS SECOND CENTURY WITH A FANFARE
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its new season and second century last night with a curious confrontation of styles - in the audience and around the house all the pomp and glamour of opening night, on stage the solemnity of Wagner's ''Lohengrin.''

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Law Enacted to Spur Generic Drug Market
description: President Reagan signed legislation today intended to get cheaper but chemically identical versions of prescription drugs on the market more quickly.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The figures for the latest quarter reflect a loss of $107,278 from the discontinued communications division. San Juan Racing realized an extraordinary gain from the sale of land in Puerto Rico, which, after provision for income taxes, was $273,934, or 6 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $767,580, or 18 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: NORTHERN DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BEIRUT PAPER REPORTS ANTI-U.S. THREAT
description: As American security officials continued to sift through debris at the the bombed United States Embassy building near East Beirut, a local newspaper reported a new threat today against American installations here.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BETWEEN GREEN AND STEIN
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Bill Green, a Republican seeking election to a fourth term as United States Representative from the 15th District on the East Side, and his opponent, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, a Democrat.

title: OF MORAL LEGITIMACY AND DEMOCRATIC GOVERNANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1984 International President Reagan urged Moscow to join Washington to bring about ''a better working relationship'' and proposed the establishment of a new American-Soviet negotiating ''framework'' to chart a course of arms control talks for the next 20 years. Mr. Reagan addressed the 39th session of the United Nations General Assembly. (Page A1, Columns 4-6.) Democrats accused the President of making light of the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Lebanon. The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said it was ''ridiculous'' for Mr. Reagan to liken the incomplete security measures at the embassy to the typical delays in a kitchen remodeling. (A1:1-2.)

title: Gastineau Flaunting It HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 24 - Mark Gastineau, who in recent
description: years has shown off a full-length mink coat, brought his latest possession to the Jets' training complex today: a Rolls-Royce convertible. He said that the price was $156,000, and that he had bought the car,

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactively restated to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in fiscal 1984.

title: KNIGHT'S LESSONS HELP NET ROOKIE
description: There were the usual high- fives, hugging and celebrating that accompany a championship. Jeff Turner remembers Pat Ewing shouting, ''We are the best in the world.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has elected David B. Greenwood president of American Express Export Credit Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,092,000 for the quarter and $3,660,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: GREEK OPPOSITION WARNS AGAINST ANTI-U.S. POLICY
description: The newly elected opposition leader, Constantine Mitsotakis, has accused Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of ''playing with fire'' by making what he called anti-American and anti-Western gestures while continuing as a member of the Western alliance.

title: Percy, Pressed by Foe, Releases Data on Taxes
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, under pressure from his Democratic challenger, Paul Simon, to make public his tax returns, released financial data Monday showing that he and his wife paid 73 percent of their income in Federal taxes last year.

title: COMPANIES AND LOCAL BOARDS SUED BY JERSEY TEACHERS OVER ASBESTOS
description: The New Jersey Education Association today sued 157 school boards and 125 unidentified asbestos manufacturers and contractors for the costs of medical checkups for school employees exposed to asbestos hazards.

title: A SEASONED ECUMENIST
description: The Rev. Arie R. Brouwer, nominated Monday to become the next general secretary of the National Council of Churches, is a seasoned ecumenist who wins acclaim from other church leaders for his piety and devotion to social justice. Many within the 31 Protestant, Anglican and Eastern Orthodox groups that belong to the nation's largest ecumenical organization hope that those qualities will allow Mr. Brouwer to usher the council out of its recent travails and into a period of renewed vitality.

title: Ford Recalls 2,500
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had recalled 2,500 workers who were laid off at its auto assembly line at the Claycomo plant on Sept. 18 because of a shortage of quality parts.

title: 3 Who Fled Prison Captured
description: The authorities today captured three of five Kansas State Penitentiary inmates who had escaped from the Lansing facility the day before and were searching for another in Leavenworth County. The men were captured after the police sealed off part of the northeast section of the city, where they had been seen. The five inmates apparently used pieces of hacksaw blades to cut through a mesh gate, then slid down three floors to reach a blower duct where they sawed through a bar.

title: HOUSE VOTES BROADCAST AID
description: The House agreed today to insure that public broadcasting receive at least $159.5 million in spending authority in 1987, the same amount earmarked for 1986.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York State Plans Commercial Paper Sale
description: New York State this November expects to begin regular sales of tax-exempt commercial paper, a kind of short-term security that sells with a much lower interest rate than long- term bonds.

title: JORDAN RESUMING TIES WITH EGYPT IT BROKE IN 1979
description: Jordan announced today that it was restoring diplomatic relations with Egypt.

title: TWP PRONGS IN A WINNABLE ASSAULT ON DRUGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Housing Bonds The Massachusetts Housing
description: Finance Agency is offering $80

title: Hope for Marietta It may not have the most intimidating players, but the way
description: Phil Roach, the athletic director at Marietta College in Columbus, Ohio, sees it, the school's Division III football team has put enormous pressure on 1984 opponents by its 30-game losing streak.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bowie Kuhn was honored at a black tie dinner last night, three days before he will step down and be replaced by Peter V. Ueberroth . Among the 800 guests were Willie Mays, Gerald Foird, Sonny Werblin, Pete Rozelle and David Stern. . . . Alan Merrick , a star with the old Minnesota Kicks, was named coach of the Minnesota Strikers of the North American Soccer League, replacing David Chadwick , whose contract was not renewed. . . . Marvis Frazier , in his first fight since a first-round loss to Larry Holmes 10 months ago, stopped Dave Starkey of Troy, Ohio, in the first round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout last night at Pennsauken, N.J. Frazier (11-1), knocked down Starkey (11-5) four times before Referee Ted Pick stopped the bout 10 seconds before the bell. . . . Lev Yashin, the Soviet goalkeeper who played in three final-round tournaments of soccer's World Cup from 1958 to 1966, had a leg amputated to save his life, Soviet soccer officials reported. They said the 55-year-old Yashin, who suffered a heart attack two years ago, was stricken with thrombosis while attending a gathering of players in Budapest and was flown back to Moscow for the emergency operation.

title: UNIONS STRIKE AT DISNEYLAND OVER PAY FREEZE PLAN
description: About 1,800 workers struck Disneyland today after rejecting a wage freeze, and they set up picket lines outside the amusement park, which calls itself ''The Happiest Place on Earth.''

title: FREE TRADE ENDORSED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan called on nations today to support a new round of trade liberalization to ''strengthen the global trading system and assure its benefits spread to people everywhere.''

title: CARTWRIGHT INJURES FOOT, MAY MISS KNICK OPENER
description: Bill Cartwright, the Knicks' starting center, learned yesterday that he had a stress fracture of the left foot and would be sidelined four to six weeks. He may not be ready when the Knicks open the season Oct. 27 against the Detroit Pistons in Madison Square Garden.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cray Research Inc. a scientific computer company based in Minneapolis, said it had sold equipment valued at about $16 million to the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

title: PUBLIC FIDUCIARIES AS ESTATE CONSERVATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Definition
description: They were just two people in a

title: 2 Bombs Go Off In Office Building
description: Two bombs exploded here early today in an office building where South Africa has its consulate.

title: ARGENTINE ACCORD ON AUSTERITY PLAN ACCEPTED AT I.M.F.
description: Argentina and the International Monetary Fund have come to terms on a program of austerity for that country that could make available billions of dollars in fresh credits from both the I.M.F. and commercial banks.

title: U.A.W. Leaders Meet To Hear About Pact
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers began gathering here today to review a tentative contract with the General Motors Corporation that the union president, Owen F. Bieber, has predicted workers would ratify.

title: Ex-KissingerMaid Charged on Goods
description: A former maid of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Kissinger has been charged with the possession of nearly $200,000 in property, including art objects and a sable coat, stolen from the Manhattan apartment of the former Secretary of State and his wife, authorities said today.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $2.5 million provision in the first quarter as a reserve for restructuring debt related to the 1981 divestiture of Glas-Craft. c-Net income

title: Czechs Drown in Bid to Flee
description: Yugoslav authorities have recovered the bodies of two Czechoslovaks who drowned in the Mur River when their family of five tried to swim to Austria, border officials said today.

title: Boesky Raises Midlands Stake
description: A group controlled by the New York investor Ivan F. Boesky told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in Midlands Energy Company common stock to 612,800 shares, or 7.1 percent of the total outstanding. The Boesky group said it made net purchases of 137,500 shares between Aug. 1 and Sept. 17.

title: Brennan Ahead In Primary Rerun
description: James F. Brennan won an apparent victory yesterday in a rerun of the Democratic primary election in the 51st Assembly District in Brooklyn. With one of 68 election districts still to report, he led Louise Finney by 3,297 votes to 3,206.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $572,000 for the quarter and $853,000 for the year.

title: On the Record ; Mondale on Foreign Policy
description: From a speech yesterday at George Washington University, as distributed by The Associated Press:

title: RARE AND WELL-DONE COOKBOOKS ON SALE
description: ''YOU come to a point when you realize you can't own something forever,'' said Elizabeth Crahan, a hint of sadness in her voice. The California librarian was speaking of the treasure trove of more than 1,000 rare and antique cookbooks and gastronomic tomes she had collected with her late husband, Dr. Marcus Crahan. The collection will be auctioned at Sotheby's New York sale rooms on Oct. 9 and 10.

title: ROYALS WIN IN 12, 6-5
description: Steve Balboni hit a two-out single over the head of the California left fielder, Juan Beniquez, in the 12th inning to give Kansas City a 6-5 victory last night over the Angels and increase the Royals' lead to a game and a half in the American League West.

title: Ex-Head of Kaiser Joins British Columbia Bank
description: Edward F. Kaiser Jr., former chairman of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Bank of British Columbia, Canada's ninth-largest commercial bank.

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ben's Boys Gathering Again
description: Ben's Boys will gather for one of their periodic reunions this weekend as their successors as Syracuse football players try against Nebraska at the Carrier Dome.

title: NORTH CENTRAL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARD FROM SUSPECT IN $7 MILLION THEFT
description: The F.B.I. said today that it believed that the suspect in the theft of $7 million from a Wells Fargo depot last year had written a postcard received by a local newspaper.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it plans to build an $80 million, 105,000-square- foot technology unit at its semiconductor manufacturing plant in Nepean, Ontario. Work is to begin immediately and be completed by 1987. The company said its goal is to create the technology to produce semiconductors, or microchips, to an accuracy of one micron or less.

title: STRIKE SET FOR TODAY NEW HAVEN, Sept. 25 - Negotiations between Yale University and a union representing clerical and technical workers broke off late tonight and a strike of 1,800 union members was set to begin at 5 A.M. Wednesday.
description: The union, Local 34 of the Federation of University Employees, has been without a contract for nearly a year. Another union, Local 35, which represents 1,800 service and maintenance workers, has said it will not cross Local 34's picket lines.

title: Norbert Guterman, 84, Writer And Dos Passos Translator
description: Norbert Guterman, a Polish-born translator and writer who lived in New York for more than 50 years, died on Sept. 20 in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he retired last May. He was 84 years old.

title: I.B.M. MOVES INTO SOFTWARE MARKET In its first major thrust into the business software market, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced 31 programs for its Personal Computer that create electronic spreadsheets, draw graphs and create reports.
description: The programs, which were developed internally by I.B.M., are similar to the Lotus Development Corporation's popular 1-2-3 program, and Ashton-Tate's line of dBase data management software. Analysts said that both companies could be hurt by the introduction, but found I.B.M.'s own aggressive entry into the software market - where the company has never been a major presence - more significant than the products themselves.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: FRENCH TROOPS START THE WITHDRAWAL FROM CHAD
description: The French forces who came to Chad 13 months ago began withdrawing from the Central African country today under a pullout agreement with Libya.

title: Destination
description: A private bus, decorated with Wild

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $81,000 for the quarter and $207,000 for the 9 months.

title: CANKER JUST LATEST BLOW TO FLORIDA'S ORANGES
description: Putting a glass of orange juice on America's breakfast tables has become a multibillion-dollar business, dominated by a handful of giant processors such as Minute Maid and Tropicana. So large and voracious are their appetites for oranges that the processors consider it vital to assure themselves of a steady flow of fruit at relatively steady prices.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the crossword puzzle yesterday, the omission of a black square before 29 Across affected the answers for 10 Down and 28 and 29 Across, Also, a wrong definition was given for 44 Across. It should have been ''closet accessory.'' The correct puzzle answer appears today on page C19.

title: Suspect in Slaying JumpsBeforeTrain
description: A 35-year-old Philadelphia man who was wanted for the murder of his wife killed himself yesterday by jumping in front of a Metro-North train as it approached the Spuyten Duyvil station in the Bronx, the police said.

title: THIS CAN'T BE YOGURT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
POLICIES TO ACHIEVE 'TRADITIONAL VALUES'
description: Both parties have taken their stands on hard work, the family, religion and other ''traditional values.'' President Reagan has proclaimed them. Geraldine A. Ferraro says she personifies them. But neither party has proposed much in the way of policies that would actually achieve them. The appeal to values is largely an exercise in political symbolism. Yet there is much that Washington could do to set standards for society if it chose.

title: STOCKS WEAKER AMID RATE WORRIES
description: The overall stock market declined moderately yesterday in more active trading although the three leading market indicators ended with small gains.

title: Continental Group
description: Continental Group, the Kiewit-Murdock Investment Corporation and Universal Leaf Tobacco Company said they had signed a definitive agreement under which Universal Leaf would acquire all of the stock of two Continental subsidiaries, the Lawyers Title Insurance Corporation and the Continental Land Title Company, for $115 million.

title: C.H.B. FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $361,000 for the quarter and $1,533,000 for the year.

title: OPERA: DOMINGO IN WAGNER'S 'LOHENGRIN' AT THE MET
description: THE major question facing the house Monday night when the Metropolitan Opera opened its centennial-plus-one season lay in the voice of Placido Domingo, who had never sung a German role here but was taking on the title part in ''Lohengrin.'' There never was much doubt that the handsome Spanish tenor would make a dazzling knight in shining raiment (this August Everding production dispenses with the armor), but whether Mr. Domingo would be overtaxed by a role generally the property of Wagnerian heldentenors could not be confidently predicted.

title: Market Place; Portfolio Plan's Use of the Dow
description: ''HOW is the market doing?'' When many investors ask that question, they usually are referring to the Dow Jones industrial average. But the Dow, though it is the best known of all market indicators, has its critics. Some people complain that its 30 blue-chip component stocks do not present as true a picture of the overall market as, say, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index with its much broader base.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
APPEALS PANEL REFUSES TO BAR CONDOMINIUMS
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that the owners of a group of subsidized apartment buildings in New York City built for moderate-income families did not need Board of Estimate approval to convert them to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: SEXUAL LURE FOR ROACHES SYNTHESIZED
description: Chemists at Yale University have produced a synthetic cockroach aphrodisiac, and a company is negotiating with the university to test and market it.

title: PRESIDENT DISCOUNTS SOVIET REACTION
description: President Reagan said today that he did not consider the Soviet Union's initial negative reaction to his United Nations address to be a rejection of his call for improved relations.

title: City Home Publishing Announces Executives
description: That which was in the wind in the spring has now been set in concrete and announced.

title: Verbatim Expects Loss in Quarter
description: The Verbatim Corporation said it expects a loss in the first quarter ending this Friday ranging between $10 million, or 43 cents a share, and $12 million, or 53 cents a share. The company, which develops and markets flexible magnetic storage disks, had 1983 first-quarter net income of $5.4 million, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $40.4 million.

title: Honda Prices Up
description: The American Honda Motor Company said it had raised 1985 car prices by 3.5 percent, or an average of $295 an automobile. Prices will range from $5,399 for a five-passenger Civic Hatchback, to $12,945 for the Accord four-door sedan. The Civic CRX HF, the Environmental Protection Agency's 49-state fuel economy leader, is priced at $6,479.

title: THE CLIMATE FOR MIDEAST TERRORISM
description: As the din of yet another Beirut suicide bombing reverberates in the United States, the international muggers we know as terrorists are savoring the attention they receive for the carnage. Obviously, the United States must do what is necessary to combat such enemies, but we must not lose sight of the deeper causes of such tactical violence.

title: 'Everyone Plays'
description: Two years ago Burt Haimes had a few dozen soccer balls and a few hundred kids, but no fields. Now he has the soccer balls and - unexpectedly - the playing fields, but has lost track of the kids.

title: Hazardous Wastes
description: Further progress in dealing with hazardous wastes will falter unless Congress finishes two important bills. The Superfund, a levy on the chemical industry to pay for cleaning up abandoned toxic dumps, is about to run out of money.

title: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty CHICAGO, Sept. 25 - Walter
description: W. Brinkman, former president of the Chicago Board of

title: Anti-Castro Leader Faces Charges in Miami
description: Eduardo Arocena, leader of the anti-Castro terrorist group Omega 7, was one of five men charged today with the manufacture and possession of machine guns, silencers and other illegal weapons.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VOCATIONAL SCHOOLS ARE SAID TO ABUSE AID
description: Auditors for Congress say that lax admission standards by some trade schools are costing the Government millions of dollars in wasted student aid.

title: Business as Usual in Detroit By any ordinary measure, the auto workers' tentative contract with General Motors is a model of successful collective bargaining. Disputes over automation, job security and compensation were compromised early and fairly.
description: But this was no ordinary negotiation. Auto makers and their workers have been getting costly import protection on the premise that they needed time to retool and save jobs. Yet nothing in the three-year contract will increase jobs. Indeed, it insures that import restraints will serve to raise wages and profits. It's clearer than ever that the way to give consumers the best car at the best price is to reopen the market to all.

title: HONG KONG ACCORD INITIALED IN CHINA
description: China and Britain today initialed a draft agreement that will return Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, signalling the end to a British rule over the colony which began more than 140 years ago.

title: Clarence Reisen Dies at 62; Official of Lumber Company
description: Clarence Reisen, vice president of Reisen Lumber Industries in Union, N.J., and past president of the United Jewish Federation of MetroWest, died of a heart attack yesterday at Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in South Orange.

title: CITY STUDIES LITTLE DIOXIN FROM GARBAGE-FUELED PLANTS
description: New York City officials yesterday released two studies saying that dioxin emissions from eight proposed garbage-to-energy plants in the city would be small. The reports said the plants should be built quickly because the city was running out of room for its trash.

title: 1,000 Publishers to Go To Jerusalem Book Fair
description: More than 1,000 publishers from 36 countries will take part in the 12th Jerusalem International Book Fair, running May 5 to 10 in Israel.

title: ABC SETTLES LIBEL SUIT OVER 20/20
description: ABC-TV has agreed to settle a libel suit filed three years ago by the head of the Justice Department's Federal Witness Protection Program. The trial was scheduled to begin Monday in Fairfax County Circuit Court.

title: GENETIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Freedom of creative work cannot be a privilege for a few.

title: CANADIAN, ADDRESSING U.N., PLEDGES BETTER TIES TO U.S. AND SOVIET
description: Canada's Foreign Secretary said today that his country ''intends to get along better with its neighbors,'' the United States and the Soviet Union, but implied that an initial contact with Andrei A. Gromyko had seemed unavailing.

title: DR. SANFORD SCHWARTZ
description: Dr. Sanford Schwartz, for many years a member of the political affairs division of the Secretariat of the United Nations, died Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: New York Magazine Gets New Publisher
description: Carolyn Wall has been promoted to publisher of New York magazine replacing Marty Singerman, president of the News Group Magazines, its parent.

title: PRESIDENT OF I.B.M., 49, NAMED ITS NEXT CHIEF
description: John F. Akers, a charismatic executive who rose rapidly through the sales ranks of the world's largest computer company, yesterday was named the next chief executive of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
SEPT. 11-20 AUTO SALES ROSE 18%
description: Despite the six-day strike at some General Motors Corporation plants, new-car sales in mid-September rose 18 percent on a daily selling rate basis over the same selling period last year, the nation's six major manufacturers reported today.

title: Gooden Ends Record Year Dwight Gooden's dazzling
description: rookie season ended last night

title: JUDGE FINDS VOTER DRIVE OF STATE AGENCIES ILLEGAL
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that Governor Cuomo had violated the State Constitution by ordering state agencies to help register voters.

title: Amnesty Group Issues Harsh Report on China
description: Amnesty International said today that China is holding thousands of political prisoners in jails and labor ''re- education'' camps and has executed thousands of other Chinese in a 13- month-old anticrime campaign.

title: Transactions
description: Purchased contract of Jamie Quirk, catcher-infielder, from Denver of American Association. Assigned Kevin Rhomberg, outfielder, to Maine of International League. TEXAS (AL) - Signed Doug Rader, manager, to two-year contract extension through 1987.

title: KEY ENVIRONMENT BILLS FEARED LOST IN SHUFFLE
description: Some of the best-laid legislative plans of environmentalists may go awry in the Congressional rush to adjournment now under way. What is worse, in the view of legislators and activists who had hoped the 98th Congress would strengthen environmental laws, it may be a long time before there is another realistic shot at passage.

title: SUDANESE TO JOIN ROCKEFELLER BROTHERS FUND
description: The Rockefeller Brothers Fund has taken the unusual step of naming a former Sudanese diplomat and scholar to help develop the foundation's reshaped philanthropic program.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Including $125,748, or 8 cents a share, from the payment for termination of a lease. The results for the previous year are for 53 weeks.

title: West German Protesters Try to Block War Games
description: Demonstrators trying to disrupt NATO military maneuvers blockaded United States Army exercise grounds today and disrupted a service in a cathedral by unfurling a banner saying ''With God Against Rockets.''

title: Strike Set in Bangladesh
description: Thousands of people poured onto the streets of Dhaka today for demonstrations in advance of a national strike called by opposition political leaders for Thursday. The strike is aimed at putting pressure on President H. M. Ershad to end martial law and set up an interim government.

title: Five Bills for the Eleventh Hour As the days dwindle down, Congress always leaves unfinished business, and that's never so painful as in an election year. It means legislation must start all over again next year. There's no chance, for instance, that Congress can finish a big bill to rewrite Federal banking regulation. The Simpson- Mazzoli immigration reform bill, which died in the 97th Congress, may yet cross the finish line in time and do honor to the 98th. If not, it too will have to begin again.
description: But there's precious little time left, with Congress planning to leave Oct. 4, just eight or nine legislative days from now. There are at least five pieces of legislation that, practically speaking, can be finished and richly deserve to be:

title: Judge Doesn't Ban Minute of Silence
description: A Superior Court judge today refused a request to halt the 20-year- old practice of beginning school days here with a minute of silent reflection, and ordered the case to go to trial.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY SUSPENDED AS CONDUCT IS WEIGHED
description: Attorney General William French Smith has suspended the United States Attorney in Cleveland on suspicion of disclosing information about a pending grand jury indictment to a person who tipped off the target of the investigation, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: Rates Close Little Changed
description: Interest rates closed little changed yesterday as securities dealers said many institutional investors were on the sidelines.

title: NICARAGUA LINKS SEARCH FOR JETS TO A PEACE TREATY
description: A Sandinista official said today that Nicaragua might be willing to stop seeking jet fighters for its air force if the Central American draft peace treaty it has said it will accept were to take effect.

title: ROBERT G. LINK
description: Robert G. Link, an economist and retired senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died of a heart attack Sept. 13 at his home in Manhattan.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
No Call for Alcohol
description: Outside the Saudi Arabian chancellery in Foggy Bottom Monday night, guests flourishing invitations to a reception in honor of Saudi National Day formed a 15- minute waiting-line on the sidewalk, shuffling patiently toward a security bottleneck inside. New Hampshire Avenue was choked with limousines, many bringing dignitaries from the conference of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

title: RECALLING THE OLD MET AND A NEW 'GISELLE'
description: 1.*Cultural Scarfs e design showing two bejeweled women in a box at the opera; this one costs $98.

title: Addenda
description: * Psychology Today magazine increasing its advertising rates 8.5 percent with the January issue.

title: MAYOR ENTERS SCHOOL DISPUTE
description: The growing dispute over the fate of a Manhattan high school's football team got another player yesterday - Mayor Koch.

title: O.K., RED DELICIOUS, MOVE OVER
description: Jonathan Kolatch is a writer who grows apples and pears in Dutchess County.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ; Dollar Edges Higher In Skittish Trading
description: The dollar fluctuated in a relatively narrow range yesterday, closing higher although traders showed unusual nervousness over the possibility of central bank intervention. While the skittishness kept a lid on the dollar's rise, there did not appear to have been substantial intervention.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: With the exception of Grandma Braden, who said the girl should put some meat on her bones, everyone always said that Maggie Braden, cheerleader and beauty queen, was the prettiest girl in town.

title: CLUBMART OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-The company began operations on Dec. 1, 1983 and therefore did not report comparable year-ago results.

title: STEPS TO END NUCLEAR ARMS RACE URGED BY NORDIC LEADERS IN U.N.
description: Two Nordic leaders, in declarations to the General Assembly, warned today against stepping up the nuclear arms race and urged the superpowers to take firm action to bring it to a halt.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: KNEE injuries are among the most frequent, and severe, suffered by athletes. Among football players alone, some 45,000 knee operations are performed annually, and injuries to countless famous athletes - among them, Joe Namath, Julius Erving, Billie Jean King, O. J. Simpson, Bobby Orr and Gale Sayers - have placed the knee foremost among orthopedic concerns.

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;

title: LAPSES IDENTIFIED IN BEIRUT SECURITY
description: A State Department team sent to Beirut to investigate the bombing last week of the United States Embassy identified some lapses in security but concluded in general that adequate steps were under way to defend the building before the bombing, department officials said today.

title: Rockefeller Resources
description: Several million television viewers

title: Swiss Block Trial of Rich
description: Federal officials said yesterday that the Swiss Government's refusal to extradite Marc Rich, a commodity trader charged last year with evading $48 million of Federal taxes, was disappointing.

title: Court Sets Texas Execution
description: State District Judge William Black today ordered that Thomas Andy Barefoot be executed by lethal injection before sunrise Oct. 30 for killing a police officer in 1978.

title: Morgan Stanley Widening Scope
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, best known as an investment banker for blue-chip corporations, is reaching out to include some lower-rated companies as clients.

title: RUSSIANS COLD TO REAGAN'S U.N. SPEECH
description: The Soviet Union signaled today that it was not ready to shift from its hard-line stance toward the Reagan Administration.

title: Exasperation
description: In the tunnel just before DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn a D train came to an abrupt halt.

title: MINORCO MINERALS & REOURCES CORP LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $87,658,000 for the latest year and an extraordinary loss of $32,655,000 for the previous year.

title: Kerkorian to Raise MGM Grand Stake
description: Kirk Kerkorian, a financier and film executive, said today that he would make an $84 million cash tender offer to increase his 50.5 percent stake in MGM Grand Hotels Inc. to 72.6 percent.

title: I.B.M. ACTS TO ACQUIRE ROLM CORP.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire a leading manufacturer of telecommunications equipment, the Rolm Corporation, in a move that seemed to heighten the competition between the world's largest computer company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH I have spent many years in the kitchen, I am still fascinated by the seemingly miraculous effects of oven baking or stove-top frying. There is, for example, the pastry known as mille-feuille, or thousand- leaf, that puffs up to a multilayered wonder in the oven heat. Souffles rise to dazzling heights. Then there is a frying batter that swells several sizes once dropped into hot fat.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $9,600 for the quarter and year.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AN INTERNATIONAL FLAIR ENHANCES THE KOSHER REPERTORY
description: MENTION kosher food and many people will conjure up visions of heavy Eastern European dishes, a few treats served on special holidays or bland meals endured for the sake of family peace and grandmother's palpitating heart. Few associate ''kosher'' with the notion of cuisine or of gourmet cooking, in the sense of inventive menus and subtle flavors that satisfy cosmopolitan tastes.

title: 6 Groves Are Certified For Harvesting Citrus
description: Six citrus growers received harvesting permits today, a day after a statewide ban on harvesting was imposed because of the threat of citrus canker.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including insurance proceeds of $708,000.

title: Dedication
description: They finally have their library back

title: TWO KORTKO GOALS HELP ISLANDERS WIN
description: Roger Kortko has been in camp with the Islanders for three consecutive seasons and has yet to make the team. Maybe his day will come, but he tries not to dwell on that.

title: TIMES SQ. PROJECT: IMPACT ON THE AREA
description: The recent sale of two major office buildings in Times Square demonstrated the confidence that investors have in the long-term value of commercial properties in the neighborhood. But the short-term impact of the huge Times Square Redevelopment Project remains unclear.

title: Bus Carrying Homeless Crashes in Idaho
description: A chartered bus carrying homeless men from several cities in the East and Middle West to the Rajneesh religious commune in Oregon collided head on with a car today, killing the driver of the automobile and injuring 31 bus passengers, the authorities said.

title: SINDONA IS EXTRADITED TO FACE ITALIAN CHARGES
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who is serving a 25-year sentence in the United States for fraud, was extradited to Italy today to face new charges here.

title: SMART & FINAL IRIS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a gain of $15.8 million from the sale of 29 supermarkets.

title: CHANGE IN PRISON BUILDING URGED
description: The state should consider asking companies to build and own a 1,000-bed maximum- security prison in the Bronx, the head of the state prison system said today.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. The Mets go against Jerry Koosman, a mainstay of their championship teams. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles , at Baltimore. Second place may have slipped virtually out of reach, but the Yankees still have some business to settle: Will the American League batting champion be Don Mattingly or Dave Winfield? title: South African Trade
description: South Africa's foreign trade surplus in the first eight months of the year was more than halved from the period a year ago, the Government said today.

title: Law on Child Smut Is Sought
description: A Senate panel was urged today to push for legislation allowing children who are used in pornography to sue their exploiters for damages.

title: MIDWEST CROWDS CHEER FOR FERRARO
description: Standing before a rusted, open-hearth furnace that was once used in a steel mill but now adorns the downtown area as a nostalgic sculpture, Geraldine A. Ferraro told townspeople here today that they had ''a right to expect a steel policy that boils down to more than, 'Let it rust.' ''

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bergen Brunswig To Buy Synergex
description: The Bergen Brunswig Corporationsaid it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Synergex Corporation of Fresno, Calif., for $18 a share in cash, or about $79 million.

title: Bills Will Protest Officiating
description: Coach Kay Stephenson of the Buffalo Bills said today that he would protest to the National Football League about the officiating in his team's 28-26 loss to the Jets here Sunday.

title: AGENCY'S HAPPY WAKE: IT'S R.I.P. FOR C.A.B.
description: When more than 1,000 current and former officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board gathered last Friday for a party toasting the abolition of the once-powerful, 46-year-old Federal regulatory agency, there were few people happier to raise a glass than C. Dan McKinnon, the chairman. It was another sign that he was achieving what Ronald Reagan had brought him to town to do: shut down the agency.

title: Debt Ratings
description: Ames Department Stores had an A1 rating assigned on $40 million of convertible subordinated debentures by Moody's Investors Service. . First Security Corp. had its ratings on floating-rate notes lowered from A1 to A2; on convertible subordinated debt from A2 to A3; and its rating on commercial paper from Prime 1 to Prime 2 by Moody's.

title: Poll Finds Reagan Leads Among West Virginians
description: Despite a 2-to-1 Democratic edge in voter registration and numerous union endorsements, Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee, would lose West Virginia by a sizable margin if the Presidential election was held now, a poll released today indicates.

title: SEMINARS SUSPECTED IN HECKLING OF DEMOCRATS
description: Officials of President Reagan's re-election campaign said today that they suspected political seminars conducted by a former White House aide might have stimulated the heckling of Mr. Reagan's Democratic opponents on college campuses.

description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of assets of $468,000. c-Includes loss on the sale of assets of $368,000.

description: After a horrendous start to the series, the Yankees recovered from Monday night's doubleheader loss and defeated the Orioles tonight, 6-5, at Memorial Stadium.

title: DURABLES ORDERS OFF BY 0.9%
description: Orders to United States factories for machinery and other ''big ticket'' durable goods dipped nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, the third setback in the last five months, the Government said today.

description: Following is the prepared text of remarks today by President Reagan to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank joint annual meeting, as made public by the White House:

Mondale today ridiculed President Reagan's address to the United Nations Monday as ''deathbed conversions'' and suggested that Mr. Reagan was pretending to change the course of his Presidency to win re-election.
