title: JACKSON TRYING TO CONTROL HIS TEMPER
description: Bobby Jackson, who sees himself as a leader of the Jet secondary, concedes he has a major flaw, ''I guess my downfall has been my temper.''

title: NEW CHAPEL AT WEST POINT HELPS JEWISH CADETS KEEP FAITH OF THEIR FOREFATHERS
description: The West Point Jewish Chapel has yet to be dedicated. Its gallery walls are empty and the tour booklet for the granite building is still being written.

title: HOUSE VOTES ANTICRIME MEASURE AND SENATE EASES ABORTION RULES
description: The House today approved the Reagan Administration's anticrime package and the Senate voted to widen permitted uses of Medicaid funds for abortion as the 98th Congress rushed toward adjournment.

title: Grenada Action Used In TV Ad for Reagan
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee unveiled a new television commercial today showing two former United States students in Grenada who said their lives were in danger before the invasion.

title:
;
FULLY BACK KIM'S RETURN TO SEOUL
description: The announced intention of Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, to end his American exile by returning home before the end of 1984 ''to struggle for the return of democracy'' puts President Chun Doo Hwan on the spot and places the Reagan Administration in a dilemma by focusing attention anew on abuses by the authoritarian regime that it would prefer to ignore.

title: Polo and a Sultan
description: The Sultan of Brunei Darussalam, an oil-rich nation on the South China Sea that became the 159th member of the United Nations last week, was in New York for the occasion, staying in a heavily guarded suite in the Hotel Pierre.

title: Conner Enjoying Fans' Adulation
description: Bart Conner, at 26 the ''old man'' of the United States gymnastics team, admits that even he has been overwhelmed at the response to the medal-winning performances of American gymnasts in the Olympic Games.

title: ETHICS PANEL VOTES DROP ITS INQUIRY ON HATFIELD
description: Saying it had uncovered ''no credible information,'' the Senate Ethics Committee voted unanimously today to end its review of whether Senator Mark O. Hatfield's dealings with a Greek businessman involved a conflict of interest.

title: SECOND CHARITY TO GET REJECTED CUOMO FEE
description: Governor Cuomo, whose offer of $1,500 he earned for his speech on religion and politics at the University of Notre Dame was rejected by one Catholic home for unwed mothers because of his stand on abortion, will give the money to a similar charity.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.S. BUILDING IN WEST BEIRUT SAID TO BE EXPOSED TO ATTACK
description: For the last two months United States Embassy officials, who believed they were relatively safe in the East Beirut area, have left an alley open that provides direct access to the front door of the embassy building in West Beirut.

title: CONFEREES REACH AN ACCORD ON THE NEXT MILITARY BUDGET
description: House and Senate conferees reached a compromise today on a military program for the next fiscal year that preserved the scope, if not every detail, of the Reagan Administration's weapons buildup.

title: RED BARBER AT 76
description: Close the eyes, and it is 1947. Al Gionfriddo is chasing DiMaggio's smash to the fence. Cookie Lavagetto is spoiling Bill Bevens's no-hitter with a game-winning hit in the ninth. Jackie Robinson is playing in his first World Series. The Brooklyn Dodgers are tearing up the peapatch.

title: Crime Insurance
description: The Federal Crime Insurance Program enables residents and store owners in high-crime areas to get insurance against robbery and burglary, something difficult to do privately.

title: FOR TAMING THE FLAME
description: ANYONE who has scorched a custard, inadvertently boiled coffee or dried out a piece of meat during braising will appreciate the simple device pictured here, a heat diffuser. Whether you cook over gas or electric heat, it is often difficult to turn the range to a setting low enough so food can cook extremely slowly - or just be kept warm - without burning.

title: AMDAHL ANNOUNCES 2 SUPERCOMPUTER MODELS
description: The Amdahl Corporation plans to introduce two advanced supercomputers, made by Japan's Fujitsu Ltd., at a news conference Wednesday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DECIDES NOT TO YIELD FOUR WHO FACE CHARGES IN BRITAIN
description: South Africa has withdrawn a commitment to return four of its nationals to Britain to face arms smuggling charges.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; President Resigns At Hasbro Bradley
description: Hasbro Bradley Inc. said yesterday that James J. Shea Jr. had resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective Oct. 1. Hasbro Bradley, based in Pawtucket, R.I., is one of the nation's largest toy makers.

title: ONE VOTE ALMOST CAST
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL GIVES PEACE A CHANCE
description: Since the days of George Washington, diplomats, scholars and politicians have spoken in ethereal terms of establishing a Government office to promote peace.

title: 5TH CHESS GAME: 2 CAUTIOUS PLAYERS
description: The draw in the fifth game of the world championship chess match in Moscow between Anatoly Karpov and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, was the result of two cautious players feeling each other out and making sure they made no foolish mistakes.

title: WHAT ALICE TAUGHT THEM: DISCIPLES OF CHEZ PANISSE
description: IF Henri Soule can be credited with igniting the explosion of fine French food in New York in the 1950's and 60's, then Alice Waters, the owner and sometime chef of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., deserves similar recognition for revolutionizing American cooking in the 1970's and 80's.

title: McCann Gets More Of Sony's Business
description: McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which already serves Sony as agency for its Trinitron television sets, has now been named agency for its consumer audio business, estimated at $3 million in billings.

title: FCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
MEHTA'S PEOPLE, THE PARSIS: A PROUD SECT IN PERIL
description: When Zubin Mehta returned here in triumph recently at the head of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, he came not only as Bombay's exuberantly welcomed favorite son but also as the pride of the Parsis - the followers of Zoroaster, descendants of the Magi, builders of modern, industrial India.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A NICE woman who was interested in meeting some nice men signed up at the People Resources Center, a dating service in Manhattan. She wrote a check for a sizable sum, answered the questions on a form that became her offical ''bio,'' then poured out her hopes and dreams on a videotape. The figure on the tape looked less like a 38-year-old banking executive than a nitwit, she thought. She resolved to do something about that habit of licking her lips.

title: MAMOULIAN'S COLOR CLASSIC RESTORED
description: When Rouben Mamoulian began working almost 50 years ago on what was to become the first full-color Technicolor feature - a screen adaptation of Thackeray's ''Vanity Fair'' - the director's main challenge in tackling the new technique was to ''use color to intensify dramatic values.'' On Saturday, the New York Film Festival will pay tribute to his effort by screening a newly restored print of ''Becky Sharp.''

title: Senate Panel Supports Minimum Aid to Israel
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today agreed to guarantee Israel a minimum level of economic aid for the next five years, a commitment considered highly unusual in United States foreign aid programs.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Local Mycologists

description: b-Net income

title: SENATE NEGOTIATORS IN AGREEMENT ON STRONGER CIGARETTE WARNINGS
description: Negotiators from the Senate, public health groups and the tobacco industry reached agreement today on a bill that would require that cigarette packages and advertising carry an alternating series of health warnings that are substantially stronger than the present one.

title: ATLANTIC OIL LEASE SALE CANCELED
description: The Interior Department today canceled a sale of offshore oil leases on the Georges Bank off New England after the only bids submitted came from an activist environmental group that opposed the sale.

title: Topics ; Waiting for Victory
description: Another Bomb

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lawhon Furniture
description: The John F. Lawhon Furniture Company said it had agreed to acquire all of the stock of 11 Frankart Furniture retail outlets in New York and New Jersey in exchange for one million shares of newly issued Lawhon restricted common stock.

title: GET OUT OF THE KITCHEN
description: Explaining why security construction was still unfinished when

title: Commendation
description: Columbia University's cavernous

title: American Conservation Corps
description: Moved by the spirited example of the Civilian Conservation Corps, the House last year approved a six-year $1.8 billion American Conservation Corps. The Senate version, providing only $200 million over three years, is nonetheless impaled by a late effort to insure that only disadvantaged youth are included. That jeopardizes establishment of any program at all, and imperils hope for thousands of youngsters who need the experience of working.

title: FANON-COURIER USA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: INDIAN TROOPS LEAVE SIKH SHRINE
description: The army withdrew all but one of its token contingent of soldiers from the Sikh's Golden Temple in Amritsar early today, the United News of India reported. The last soldier was expected to leave later today.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Including a tax credit of $439,000. c-Including a tax credit of $317,000.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $409,000 for the quarter and $3,272,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2,265,000.

title: BIG FOSSIL FIND IS MADE IN WYOMING
description: Two paleontologists announced today that they recently discovered in central Wyoming the largest and best preserved group of 50-million-year-old fossils ever found.

title: WALTER PIDGEON, ACTOR, DIES AT 87
description: Walter Pidgeon, the courtly actor who distinguished his 47-year career with portrayals of men who prove both sturdy and wise, died yesterday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 years old and had suffered a series of strokes.

title: Equitable Promotes A Vice President
description: Brian F. Wruble has been named executive vice president at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the insurance company said.

title: Advertising; Changes Coming At BBDO
description: BRUCE CRAWFORD, president of BBDO International, the world's seventh-largest ad agency, and its chief executive since 1977, will be turning both titles over to Allen G. Rosenshine next April 1. The change-over comes in what is expected to be the company's first year in the $2 billion-in-billings class.

title: DONNA SUMMER SEEN ON TWO POP MUSIC VIDEOS
description: TWO of the most personal and impressive recent pop music videos are ''She Works Hard for the Money'' and ''There Goes My Baby'' by Donna Summer. They were made by different directors, but they are similar in their realistic settings, narrative structures and rejection of the arty special effects and fantasy elements that run rampant in some of the other music videos.

title: City Opens Slide Registry For Artists
description: The ''Artist Slide Registry,'' a collection of slides of the work of more than 1,000 artists, was opened on Monday by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: Ellis Island Fund Post Filled
description: A former dean at New York University has been named president and chief operating officer of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, Lee Iacocca, the foundation chairman, announced yesterday. The Chrysler executive said William F. May, formerly dean of the N.Y.U. Graduate School of Business Administration, replaced Llewellyn Jenkins, who retired on June 22.

title: Bowie Comes to Terms
description: The Portland Trail Blazers and their No. 1 draft choice, Sam Bowie of Kentucky, agreed yesterday to terms on a lucrative six-year contract. Financial details were not disclosed, but team officials said the contract would make Bowie one of the highest- paid rookies in the history of the National Basketball Association.

title: PLAN TO DESEGREGATE TENNESSEE COLLEGE APPROVED
description: A Federal district judge today approved a settlement to end segregation at the historically black Tennessee State University by setting a goal of a 50-50 ratio of black to white students by 1993.

title: TV Evangelist Denies Charges by Mondale
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, the television evangelist, denied today that he ever said Jews were damned to hell and charged that Walter F. Mondale had taken out of context his statement that Roman Catholicism was ''a false religion.''

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
JUSTICE DEPT. AND THE I.R.S. REBUKED BY A FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Rebuking the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service, a Federal judge today dismissed charges against seven people and a bank in what was once described as the largest tax fraud case in United States history.

title: Houk Is Retiring As Boston Manager
description: Saying it was time for a younger fellow to take over, Ralph Houk, the dean of major league baseball managers, announced his retirement today after four years with the Boston Red Sox, five years before that with the Detroit Tigers and 11 before that with the Yankees.

title: BUSH WON'T TAKE STEP TO RELEASE TAX DATA
description: Vice President Bush has no intention of revoking a blind trust so that he may release his income tax returns for the years since he took office, a spokesman said today.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STAUB'S PINCH HOMER IN 9TH BEATS PHILS
description: Rusty Staub last night became the second player in baseball history - the other is Ty Cobb - to have hit a home run as a teen-ager and another after the age of 40. Staub achieved the feat in giving the Mets a 6-4 victory over the Phils.

title: WHY MOTORISTS WON'T BUCKLE UP
description: The driver's-education instructor asks a simple question: ''How many of you think it's important to buckle your seat belt every time you get in your car?'' Only a few teen-agers shyly thrust up their hands, so the teacher fires off some sobering statistics. Every 10 minutes, someone dies in a car accident. Everyone can expect to be in an accident at least once in his lifetime. Safety belts double the chances of surviving a crash.

title: Filipinos Clearing Roads To Aid Volcano Victims
description: Engineers bulldozed mud, boulders and other volcanic debris from provincial roads today, allowing relief goods to reach thousands of refugees isolated by mud flows from the eruption of Mount Mayon.

title: Scientologists to Fight Decision by Tax Court
description: Officials of the Church of Scientology said today that they would appeal a United States Tax Court ruling denying tax-exempt status to the church's California affiliate and would fight to reform or dismantle the Internal Revenue Service if they lost.

title: THE DEFINITION AT ABORTION ISSUE'S CORE
description: To the Editor:

title: GRACIOUS ROOKIE IN DEVILS' FUTURE
description: The bus was loaded, jacket and tie required, as young New Jersey Devils players were transported to a rookie game recently in Voorhees, N.J.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
People
description: * Paul Miller has joined Sieber & McIntyre, Chicago, as senior vice president, director of marketing for both the educational and symposiums international divisions.

title: JUDGE TENTATIVELY APPROVES PACT ON AGENT ORANGE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday tentatively approved a settlement under which seven manufacturers of Agent Orange had agreed to create a $180 million fund for Vietnam War veterans and their families who contended that the herbicide had harmed them.

title: Dr.EdwardJ.Hornick, A Clinical Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Edward J. Hornick Jr., chief of clinical psychiatry at the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island, died of cancer Monday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1984 International An accord on credit for Argentina has been reached by the Buenos Aires Government and the International Monetary Fund. Under the plan, Argentines would live austerely and the Government would be entitled to billions of dollars of new credits from both the I.M.F. and commercial banks. (Page A1, Column 6.) Jordan and Egypt are resuming ties, King Hussein's Government announced. Jordan, 1 of 17 Arab countries that severed diplomatic relations with Egypt after President Anwar el-Sadat signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, is the first of those countries to resume ties. (A1:2.)

title: Some Stations Accept Ads for Contraceptive
description: In its campaign to get its new client's contraceptive product onto network television, Keye/Donna/ Pearlstein of Los Angeles first got a commercial on radio, then earlier this month on cable television and next month it will begin to appear on at least 15 television stations, nine of which are network affiliates.

title: Festival of Orchestras Set
description: A performance by the Montreal Symphony on Oct. 27 at 8 P.M. will open the International Festival of Orchestras at Carnegie Hall.

title: VACANT LOTS BLOSSOM IN CITY PROGRAM
description: For years, Tom and Julia Deadwiley looked on helplessly as a two-family house next to their Brooklyn home deteriorated, first into a burned shell, then into a vacant lot filled with trash.

title: WRITERS IN SOVIET GIVEN PARTY LINE
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko laid down the party line to writers today, asserting the continued dominance of Socialist Realism, which he defined as a dedication to the ideals of Communism.

title: Afghan Airliner Lands After Rebel Fire Hits It
description: An Afghan airliner carrying 308 passengers was hit by rebel fire Friday and forced to make an emergency landing at the Kabul airport, the Kabul radio and a Western diplomat reported today. No casualties were reported.

title: Gromyko and Shamir Meet at Soviet Mission
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, conferred with his Israeli counterpart, Yitzhak Shamir, for an hour and a half last night at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, according to a spokesman for the Israelis, who said it was the first such meeting in three years.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Cub Fan Loses Lawsuit CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) - A judge today threw out a lawsuit challenging Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's authority to change the World
description: Series schedule and take a potential home date from the Chicago Cubs,

title: Air Florida Deal Backed
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge, despite criticism from numerous airlines and creditors, today approved a $53 million acquisition deal in which grounded Air Florida would begin flying again as part of Midway Airlines.

title: Bridge: 'Play of Beauty' Is AchievedOn an Idyllic Tropical Island
description: For those who want a Caribbean vacation with maximum isolation, a possibility is Petit St. Vincent, an island in the Grenadines between St. Vincent and Grenada.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ''THE GOOD WAR'': An Oral History of World War Two. By Studs Terkel. 589 pages. Pantheon Books. $19.95. WHEN America moved from the Great Depression of the 30's to World War II, it was rather like going from a depressive to a manic stage. Suddenly everyone was employed, excited, filled with purpose. For some, World War II was the Great Elation, a feeling of confidence and camaraderie that has been compared to the time of the Crusades.

title: Steel Union Will Seek High-Tech Membership
description: The United Steelworkers of America, confronted with a 50 percent membership loss from plant closings and layoffs, decided today to try to organize workers in high-technology industries.

title: STAGE: 'QUILTERS,' A MUSICAL, OPENS A NEW SEASON
description: ''QUILTERS,'' the first Broadway production of the new season, is billed as a ''musical,'' but it might better serve as a diorama at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. Adapted from a slender book of oral history by Patricia Cooper and Norma Bradley Allen, this show means to celebrate those hearty pioneer women who turned a domestic craft into a spirited native form of autobiographical art. The women who created ''Quilters,'' Molly Newman and Barbara Damashek, clearly know a lot about quilting and the unsung heroines who practiced it. If the entertainment at the Jack Lawrence Theater is any indication, their knowledge of theater is somewhat less acute.

title: Marathon Match
description: Vicki Nelson of Wooster, Ohio, returned to the tennis court yesterday, apparently recovered from her record marathon victory Monday night. Miss Nelson, who is seeded No. 2 in the $50,000 Virginia Slims Ginny of Richmond tournament, had played a 6-hour-31-minute match in eliminating Jean Hepner, 6-4, 7-6.

title: A U.S. Rights Official Begins Uganda Visit
description: A Reagan Administration human rights official has arrived in Uganda, a month after another senior United States official said there had been widespread atrocities against civilians in this East African country.

title: Athletes Testify
description: Several former and current athletes as well as coaches were in Washington yesterday to deliver a message in testimony before Congress: that a good way to keep children from experimenting with drugs and alcohol is make sure that sports stars do not glamorize them through advertising or abuse. Among the witnesses at a hearing before a Senate Labor and Human Resources subcommittee were Roosevelt Grier, Calvin Hill, Tom McMillen and Coach Bobby Bowden of Florida State.

title: 'Greenmail' Bill Opposed
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told Congress today that the Administration opposed a House bill intended to outlaw certain defense tactics in corporate takeover battles.

title: Bloomingdale's Chicago Store CHICAGO, Sept. 25 - Bloomingdale's will open its first
description: downtown store outside of New

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday this week incorrectly reported the time for an appearance by Joe Black at Union County College tonight. It is 8 o'clock.

title: IMMIGRANTS BILL CONFERENCE DEADLOCKS ON ALIEN'S RIGHTS
description: House and Senate negotiators drafting a comprehensive immigration bill broke up tonight without reaching agreement on the last outstanding issue, involving the civil rights of legal aliens.

title: Greece and Libya Sign An Economic Accord
description: Greece and Libya signed a $1 billion economic cooperation agreement Monday, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Government announced.

title: WEINTRAUB BUYS INTEREST IN NEDERLANDER THEATERS
description: Jerry Weintraub, the film producer and personal manager, has purchased an interest in six Broadway theaters owned by the Nederlander Organization, it was announced Tuesday.

title: LONDON EXPECTS HONG KONG ACCORD TO WIN EASY APPROVAL IN PARLIAMENT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government expects little trouble in gaining final approval for the Hong Kong treaty that was initialed today by Britain and China in Peking.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILHARMONIC OPENS SEASON WITH MEHTA
description: THE New York Philharmonic seemed to be going out of its way last night to make the opening night of its 143d season a routine affair and almost succeeded. Zubin Mehta, the music director, who has never shown much sense of occasion, led a potpourri program that consisted largely of works that the orchestra had taken on its recent Far Eastern tour, with Beethoven's Violin Concerto added to provide some needed heft. Adding to the evening's feeling of familiarity, the soloist in the Beethoven was an old friend of Mr. Mehta and the Philharmonic, Pinchas Zukerman, who has performed with the orchestra more than 45 times since his first appearance in 1969.

title: THE CITY ; CityU.ActstoEnd Africa Holdings
description: The City University has begun to take steps to divest itself of investments in financial institutions and companies that do business in South Africa as a result of a resolution adopted Monday by its trustees.

title: Union Carbide Forecast
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it expects third-quarter earnings to be about the same as last year's $80.6 million, or $1.15 a share. It said its weak spots are largely steel-related products and petrochemicals, areas in which the company has been reducing its commitment.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE GANG ON 42D ST. One of Manhattan's mainstreams is 42d Street, a thoroughfare that slices impartially through sleaziness, high art and culture in its path from the Hudson to the East Rivers. One of the cultural highlights of 42d Street is the Whitney Museum of American Art branch in the Philip Morris building at Park Avenue, opposite Grand Central Terminal. It is not sheer coincidence, therefore, that the new exhibition opening there today memorializes the famous street on which it fronts.

title: STAGE: YALE REP SEASON OPENS WITH 'TARTUFFE'
description: In Walton Jones's production of ''Tartuffe'' at the Yale Repertory Theater, a row of large mahogany-like doors is positioned against a trompe l'oeil background. The doors are used for quick entrances, exits and punchlines. They slide across the stage on tracks, swing open and slam on cue and are filled with concealed crannies for depositing plot-advancing objects.

title: Education Official Accused of Theft
description: Nassau County's highest-ranking education official was arrested today on an indictment accusing him of double billing for travel, lodging and meal expenses he incurred in his official duties.

title: Manson Is Set Ablaze By Inmate in California
description: Charles Manson, sentenced as a mass killer, was drenched with paint thinner and set on fire today by a fellow inmate who said Mr. Manson threatened him because of the inmate's membership in the Hare Krishna religious sect, the authorities said.

title: C-rations for Congress
description: Senate-House conferees trying to

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WINE TALK
description: Among members of the French Communist Party, red Bordeaux is the favored wine, with Champagne a close second. According to a recent poll by Sofres, the Societe Fran,caise d'Enqu^etes et de Sondages, a major French polling organization, 49 percent of all members of the party queried said red Bordeaux was their favorite, while 44 percent voted for Champagne.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STORYTELLING AND SONG MARK MEMORIAL FOR TRUMAN CAPOTE
description: On a Broadway stage yesterday adorned with two large photographs of Truman Capote, the novelist William Styron described the late author as ''a full-fledged master of the language before he was old enough to vote.''

title: Careers; Counseling Dismissed Managers
description: BUSINESS is booming for outplacement companies, the organizations that help people who have lost their jobs hunt for new ones. The boom reflects, in part, a dramatic change in the job market that should concern every college graduate.

title: JOE PISCOPO APPEARS IN A SPECIAL ON HBO
description: JOE PISCOPO is a fairly harmless looking fellow from New Jersey with a talent for being unexpectedly bizarre. He gained a national following on the second phase of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' - the phase following the one that made stars of Chevy Chase, John Belushi, Gilda Radner and Dan Aykroyd. Now, courtesy of pay-cable's Home Box Office, he has his own television special, a showcase offering a broad sampling of his sometimes peculiar, frequently hilarious talents. ''The Joe Piscopo Special'' can be seen tonight on HBO at 11:30.

title: The Civil Rights Act of 1984
description: Congress keeps saying it wants to restore the teeth that the Supreme Court yanked out of the civil rights laws in the Grove City College case. Now's the time to see if it can do any more than jaw.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains from reversal of DISC deferred income taxes resulting from enactment of the Tax Reform Act of 1984 of $821,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Scali, McCabe Resigns 2 Heublein Accounts
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves reports that it has resigned its two Heublein assignments, Harvey's Bristol Cream and Don Q Rum. According to Marvin Sloves, agency chairman: ''We regret having to resign any client, but there are times when it is the best thing for the client and the agency.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A RELIGIOUS REQUIREMENT IMPOSED BY CUOMO IN '83
description: To the Editor:

title: Denny's Offer Cut
description: Denny's Inc., a major nationwide restaurant chain, yesterday announced a lowering of terms in its agreement to be acquired by a private investor group, which apparently could not line up all the financing to support the original deal.

title: OPEC Panel Opposes a Rise
description: An OPEC committee recommended today that the organization keep its present oil price and production limits. A special session of the full Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is not needed, the panel's chairman said.

title: 'WORLD OF ICE' CELEBRATION
description: EVERY penny of the $3.5 million it cost to produce the 1984 edition of ''Walt Disney's World on Ice'' seems to have been spent on swirling flash, glitter and fireworks. This lavish family entertainment, at Madison Square Garden through Oct. 7, celebrates the 50th anniversary of Donald Duck with an extravagance that more than matches Broadway hits such as ''42d Street'' and ''La Cage aux Folles.'' At a $10.50 top price, it is a bargain for the connoisseur of ultimate glitz.

title: Polish Church Approves Plan to Aid Farms
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops approved a plan today for a church-sponsored fund to aid private farmers, church sources reported. They said the Government could give final approval Saturday when Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, meets Jozef Cardinal Glemp.

title: CLARK, J.L. MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ramon Segarra, Ex-DancerWith City Ballet and Teacher
description: Ramon Segarra, a former member of the New York City Ballet and a teacher for many dance companies in America and abroad, died of cancer Sept. 23 at the University of Miami Hospital in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 43 years old.

title: HOLDERS MUST BEAR COSTS IN BELL TRIALS WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) - The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its former operating companies cannot bill their customers to cover judgments and court costs in Federal antitrust suits, the Federal Communications Commission said today.
description: The agency's ruling came in the course of developing proper ''accounting principles'' for assigning liability for a $276.8 million judgment against the Bell System won by Litton Industries in 1981.

title: Quake Hits San Francisco
description: A sharp earthquake jolted this area today, apparently an aftershock of a large temblor in April. No serious damage or injuries were reported. The United States Geological Survey said the quake occurred 12 miles east of San Jose at 1:46 P.M. It measured 4.5 on the Richter scale of earthquake intensity.

title: STAGE: 'TAKE ME ALONG'
description: WHILE America in the Eisenhower era produced the Beat Generation, rock-and-roll and rebels without a cause, the mood of many Broadway musicals was steeped in turn-of-the-century nostalgia.

title: TECTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fed Loses Bid to Curb Bank Units
description: A court has struck down an attempt by the Federal Reserve Board to narrow a loophole in Federal law that has allowed a growing number of commercial and industrial concerns to enter the banking business by the back door.

title: A Rite for Hans Sondheimer
description: The New York City Opera will hold a memorial service for Hans Sondheimer Monday at 1 P.M. in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Mr. Sondheimer, who died Sept. 1, was the company's lighting director, technical designer and production coordinator from 1944 to 1980. Participating in the service will be Beverly Sills, the company's general director; Julius Rudel, the former general director; Ming Cho Lee, the set designer, and singers from the company.

title: LOW-COST POWER: A REALLOCATION IS DEFERRED
description: For months, Governor Cuomo appealed to the Legislature to adopt a plan to redistribute hundreds of millions of dollars worth of inexpensive hydroelectric power from upstate.

title: THE FREIGHT TRAIN CALLED ADJOURNMENT
description: The politics of adjournment in an election year often leads Congress to make mincemeat of rules and traditions, and this year is no exception.

title: Manson Loses Much Hair
description: Charles Manson lost most of his long hair and beard when he was set afire by another convicted killer, prison officials said today. Mr. Manson, serving a life term in nine ritual murders, was reported in serious but stable condition with second- and third-degree burns over 18 percent of his body.

title: CHINESE-BRITISH ACCORD STATES THAT LIFE IN HONG KONG WILL BE BASICALLY UNCHANGED
description: China and Britain today initialed and made public the text of a draft agreement on Hong Kong that states that life in the crown colony will go on basically unchanged after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: Playing It Safe
description: The surprise player of the United States Croquet Association's national championships, held last week in Central Park, was Bill Cahill of Seattle.

title: RAYCOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Royals Shut Out; Twins Beaten
description: Brian Downing and Doug DeCinces each knocked in a run, and Ron Romanick pitched a seven-hitter tonight to lead the California Angels to a 2-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Preston Brown, the wide receiver and kick returner who was picked up by the Browns when he was waived by the Jets in camp this summer, has been dropped by Cleveland. . . . Grete Waitz, the Norwegian runner who won the New York City Marathon for the fifth time last year, will be trying for a sixth in the 1984 race, on Oct. 28, the organizers announced.

title: THE COST CRACKDOWN AT NEWSWEEK
description: A stern restructuring is under way at Newsweek as the magazine searches for leaner operations and higher profits.

title: WORLD ECONOMIC ORDER IS THEME AT THE U.N.
description: The Foreign Ministers of France and West Germany voiced concern today about the world economic situation and offered proposals to alleviate it.

title: Clifford Believes Race Could Be Like 1948
description: Clark Clifford, a former White House aide and campaign adviser to President Truman, suggested today that increasing public concern with issues and mistakes by President Reagan give Walter F. Mondale a chance to repeat Mr. Truman's come-from-behind victory over Thomas E. Dewey in 1948.

title: COHALAN BUDGET FOR '85 INCLUDES 7.6% TAX RISE
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, released his proposed 1985 budget today and said the county would be able to maintain current services despite a $52 million shortage in property taxes due from the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: AIR CANADA CUTS
description: Air Canada announced a fall ''seat sale,'' with cuts off as much as 65 percent from published tourist fares.

title: NO MEETINGS SEEN ON ALIENS MEASURE
description: Congressional efforts to draft a comprehensive immigration bill broke down today over the question of job protection for legal aliens, and lawmakers from both parties said they saw no way to resolve the impasse.

title: Court Blocks Removal Of Casino Union Chief
description: An appeals court today blocked an order by the state's Casino Control Commission that the president of a casino workers' union leave his job by Friday because of allegations that he is tied to organized crime.

title: FUTON MATTRESSES: WHAT AND WHERE
description: THE futon mattress, a version of the sleep mat traditionally used in Far Eastern countries, is becoming a popular alternative for many Americans.

title: TAIWAN BIDS HONG KONG FIGHT COMMUNISM
description: Prime Minister Yu Kuo-hwa of the Chinese Nationalist Government urged Hong Kong's Chinese residents today to resist the prospect of Chinese Communist rule and promised to help those wishing to move to Taiwan.

title: CHINA CALLS ON NUCLEAR POWERS TO PLEDGE ON FIRST USE OF WEAPONS
description: China called today for a pledge by all nuclear powers not to be the first to use such weapons, followed by their prohibition and then their destruction.

title: Lily Studies Sale
description: Lily-Tulip Inc., which has been active in recent days in over-the- counter trading, reported that it had retained Kidder, Peabody & Company to explore the company's financial alternatives, including its possible sale. On Monday, the company's stock rose 37.5 cents, to $12, on a volume of 162,900 shares; on Tuesday it was up $1.875, to $13.875, on a turnover of 614,900 shares, and yesterday it added 12.5 cents, to close at $14, on trading of 557,440 shares. Lily-Tulip makes and markets disposable paper, plastic and foam cups, plates and bowls.

title: WHAT THE U.S. CUSTOM HOUSE SHOULD HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: WASTE-DEEP SPENDING
description: Congress should take to heart the axiom ''waste not, want not.'' President Reagan's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control has shown Congress how to ''waste not,'' and Congress, to its discredit, has shown that it ''wants not'' such advice.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for the 50 percent stock dividends paid Oct. 24, 1983 and Sept. 10, 1984.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ONE of the biggest expenses a homeowner is likely to face in routine maintenance is the cost of replacing a shingle roof. One way of extending the life of a roof is a new coating especially designed to protecting asphalt shingles, which are by far the most widely used in residential construction.

title: HOLMES-SMITH BOUT MOVED UP TO NOV. 9
description: Before anyone could scream ''turkey,'' Larry Holmes decided to observe Thanksgiving at home this year and so James (Bonecrusher) Smith will not be added to a list that includes Randy (Tex) Cobb and Marvis Frazier.

title: Youth Is Killed By Power Lines
description: A teen-ager was electrocuted and a 12-year-old friend was critically burned after they came in contact with power lines on top of a N.J. Transit tower, authorities said today.

title: A Neighborhood Dispute
description: Four men slump over the sturdy

title: Marsteller Officer Joins Nadler as President
description: Ricardo Calvillo, for the last two years executive vice president and general manager of Marsteller, New York, will be joining Nadler & Larimer as president.

title: HERS
description: IT had been a long and difficult night in the

title: Down but Not Starving
description: In the past, delegates to the annual

title: Slight Crime Drop NotedbyTeachers
description: Crimes against teachers in schools dropped slightly during the last school year compared with the year before, the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday.

title: U.S. STUDY NEARLY 3 OUT OF 10 GET BENEFITS
description: In 1983 nearly three of every 10 Americans lived in a household receiving direct benefits, mostly from the Federal Government, according to a new Census Bureau statistical series published for the first time today.

title: ALARUMS IN GEORGETOWN
description: For many years the residents of Georgetown, striving to retain the sedateness that marked its cobbled streets in the 18th and 19th centuries, were at odds with many of its business people, even though the most conscientious of them sought ways to earn a profit without marring the community's historic appearance.

title: Libya Says Pullout Has Started in Chad
description: Libya's official press agency confirmed today that the simultaneous French and Libyan troop withdrawal from Chad had begun.

title: COURT BACKS REFUSAL BY U.S. TO AID CHICAGO SCHOOL PLAN
description: An appeals court ruled today that the Federal Government did not have to provide upwards of $100 million to help the Chicago school system pay for a program to offset the effects of desegregation.

title: Herbert Epstein Dies; Newport Civic Leader
description: Herbert William Epstein, a civic leader in Newport, R.I., died of cancer Sept. 8 at the New England Medical Center in Boston. He was 59 years old and lived in Newport.

title: Rosh ha-Shanah Services For the Deaf
description: The sound of the shofar will be communicated to the deaf at Rosh ha- Shanah services today.

title: Justice in the Dark The judges who set administrative policy for the Federal judiciary find that the public benefits of televising trials are merely ''alleged'' and ''outweighed by the risks to the administration of justice.'' And with that swift conclusion, the Judicial Conference of the United States, headed by Chief Justice Warren Burger, dismissed a serious proposal from two dozen news organizations - including The Times - for a change in the rules.
description: A ban on courtroom photography no longer belongs in any code of judicial ethics, if it ever did. Half a century ago, in the wake of the raucously reported Lindbergh kidnapping trial, the American Bar Association added such a rule to its canons. The idea was carried forward in the A.B.A.'s 1972 code revision and adopted by the Judicial Conference without much examination. Since then the A.B.A. itself has repudiated the undiscriminating rule against cameras.

title: A FORMAL GARDEN, MADE IN AMERICA
description: acre formal garden she designed in the classical style in the Taconic foothills in upstate New York, she might be describing the construction of an elaborate house. ''The local people who built it were fine craftsmen working from a medieval point of view,'' Mrs. Poehler, a landscape architect, said of the privately owned garden, rarely open to the public. ''There are four different kinds of stone - granite, bluestone, shale and red dog, a kind of rosy slag - in the design.''

title: West German Trade
description: West Germany's trade surplus grew to 3.80 billion marks, or about $970 million, in August, from 2.99 billion marks in July and 2.54 billion marks in August 1983, the federal statistics office said today.

title: Slowdowns at Renault
description: Workers protesting mandatory Christmas holidays and a decline in their purchasing power staged slowdowns and partial strikes today at five of the Renault auto plants in northern France.

title: 23 Rescued as Boat Sinks Off the Coast of Maine
description: A 64-foot schooner carrying 23 people capsized and sank in a storm today, tossing vacationers and crew members into the cold waters of Penobscot Bay, where they were quickly rescued.

title: Reporters' Night Out
description: Reporters covering Walter F. Mondale had a rare night off in New York City last night. The reason was that the Democratic Presidential candidate had scheduled no public events as he prepared for his meeting this afternoon with Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister.

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including income of $57,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Sewer Bonds Sold By San Francisco
description: A $90 million issue of San Francisco sewer revenue bonds was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.30 percent for bonds due in 2009 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 9 3/4 percent for bonds due in 1998.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HONG KONG SEE THE FUTURE: WILL IT WORK?
description: The Governor of Hong Kong came back from Peking today bringing the people of this British colony their first detailed glimpse of their future under Chinese rule after 1997.

title: DOZENS HAD ROLES IN SECURITY MEASURES FOR BEIRUT
description: Dozens of officials and more than 20 State Department offices were involved in the planning and construction of security measures at the United States Embassy in Beirut, according to department aides.

title: Gallup Poll Says Reagan Has Increased His Lead
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush have increased their lead over their Democratic rivals to 18 percentage points, according to the most recent Gallup Poll.

title: GIANTS' CARSON FEELING BETTER
description: Harry Carson had bad news today for the Los Angeles Rams, whom the Giants play Sunday in Anaheim, Calif.: He is feeling better.

title: Companies
description: I.B.M. announced that it would acquire Rolm, one of Silicon Valley's leading makers of telephone switching equipment, for $1.25 billion in securities. The acquisition, I.B.M.'s largest ever and its first since 1962, would place the computer giant in direct competition with A.T.& T. and several Japanese companies in the market for complex telephone equipment. (Page A1.)

title: CONTINENTAL BANK SEES RECOVERY
description: William S. Ogden, chairman and chief executive of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, predicted today that the beleaguered bank would be ''in the neighborhood of breaking even'' in the third quarter.

title: GOLDMARK SAYS HE WILL LEAVE PORT AUTHORITY
description: Peter C. Goldmark Jr., who guided the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to a broader mandate of regional economic development, said yesterday that he would step down as its executive director at the end of the year.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LIFTS BAN ON MAVERICK WHITE CLERIC
description: The South African authorities today lifted a seven-year-old ban on a white cleric who severed the ties that bound him to his Afrikaner forebears by worshiping with black people and espousing their political cause.

title: Bridge:Robert
description: One of the fastest thinkers who ever sat at a card table died in New York last week at the age of 75. The player, Robert Appleyard, was a feared competitor in the 40's and 50's, with many titles to his credit.

title: 2d Large Bank Cuts Its Prime
description: The Wells Fargo Bank, the 11th-largest bank in the country, yesterday became the nation's second major lending institution to reduce its prime rate.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BIOPHILIA. By Edward O. Wilson. 157

title: Sybron to Revamp Its Dental Units
description: The Sybron Corporation said it will take a $25 million, or $2.50-a-share, charge against third-quarter results to restructure its dental business.

title: Series Problems
description: No one in baseball knows where the World Series will open and which league will have the home-field advantage if it should go seven games. Nor will anyone know until the National League's championship series, between Chicago and San Diego, is completed.

title: Penn Square Officer Acquitted on Most Counts
description: A United States District Court jury today acquitted a former Penn Square Bank loan officer, William G. Patterson, of 23 charges that he violated Federal bank laws. But the jury was instructed to continue deliberations on two other charges on which it had been unable to agree.

title: THE RIGHTEOUS FANATICS

title: Excommunication Idea Spurned by a Bishop
description: Bishop Harold Dimmerling of Rapid City says he is not interested in seeing a petition that seeks to have Representative Thomas A. Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: MANHATTAN PORTRAITS It would be difficult to turn a camera on almost any part of southern Manhattan and come up with a picture that is other than eye-catching. Lower Manhattan is always changing, yet it always hums with activity, more so recently - when it seems never to shut down - than in past years when keyed to office hours.

title: U.S. AND ISRAELIS WELCOME JORDAN MOVE TOWARD EGYPT
description: The United States and Israel yesterday both welcomed Jordan's decision to restore diplomatic relations with Egypt.

description: president and chief operating

title: CONFERENCE TO EXPLORE 18-CENTURY HANDWORK

title: IN ANCHORAGE, COONEY TUNES UP WITH CHARM
description: As the tape was unwrapped from his hands following his first workout here Monday, Gerry Cooney reflected on one of his first impressions of the state, 4,800 miles from his Long Island home.

title: OPERA: EUGENE ONEGIN AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: ''EUGENE ONEGIN'' is not one of the most popular works in the standard repertory, but that hardly speaks well for popular taste. It is an opera that appeals deeply to its audience, if it appeals at all, and deserves the best, most sensitive effort that an artistically responsible company can bring to it. The Metropolitan Opera's production, which had its first performance of the season last night, once had its merits but now is so seriously faded, visually, that only singing actors of enormous talent and intelligence could be expected to make much out of it.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ARGENTINE-I.M.F. TEXT

title: Yankees Defeat Orioles
description: When Manager Yogi Berra informed John Montefusco in the dugout that he wouldn't be starting the eighth inning tonight, the 34-year-old Yankee pitcher, who had broken a blister on his right thumb, pleaded to be left in.

title: Jazz, Stockton Agree The Utah Jazz have reached agreement on a multiyear contract with
description: John Stockton , the Gonzaga University guard who was their first pick in the National Basketball Association collegiate draft and the 16th player chosen over all. No specifics on the agreement were announced, but Stockton is being seen as a backup to the Jazz playmaker Rickey Green .

title: LEADERS OF AUTO UNION LOCALS ENDORSE GENERAL MOTORS PACT
description: The tentative contract between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation was approved today by about 300 local leaders of the union.

title: Midway to Delay White Plains Plan
description: A spokesman for Midway Airlines said that the carrier would not start service from White Plains airport until Oct. 15 in order to meet with the Westchester County Executive, Andrew O'Rourke, and work out any differences over use of Air Florida slots at the airport.

title: COLLECTORS CHERISH THE ORDINARY AUTO
description: HERE he is, Jak Phillips with his red beard and the beanie with the Mickey Mouse charms, talking and happy as he polishes the blue paint of his tiny 1949 Crosley station wagon, the car he has always wanted. ''My wife found it in an ad,'' he says. ''I went out to look and I remembered it from the circus. When I was a kid, this little Crosley would drive into the center ring and all these midgets would get out. It's the car I've always wanted, but I just never knew what it was.''

title: Midtown Jazz Series To Begin on Oct. 17
description: A concert with the trumpet player Dick Sudhalter and the pianist Dick Wellstood will kick off the Midtown Jazz at Midday series Oct. 17 at 2 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 53d Street.

title: DRUSE LEADER ASSAILS U.S. POLICY
description: Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, was quoted in an interview published today as saying the United States should change its Middle East policies ''or nothing will protect its embassy'' from new bombing attacks.

title: PARTY CHIEF PICKS LOSER IN PRIMARY
description: The Bronx Democratic organization has nominated for a countywide Civil Court judgeship a Democrat who was defeated for a district Civil Court nomination in the Democratic primary two weeks ago.

title: Nicaraguan Trick or Treaty?
description: The not-so-secret, not-so-cold war between the United States and Nicaragua has acquired a mysterious new diplomatic dimension. But with the motives of both sides well concealed, it's hard to chart the direction of the conflict.

title: JURY CONSIDERS EXTORTION CHARGES IN BOSTON
description: A Federal jury began its deliberations today in the extortion trial of Theodore V. Anzalone, the chief fund-raiser for former Mayor Kevin H. White, after the Government contended Mr. Anzalone had conspired to extort money from a contractor in Mr. White's office.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a loss of $1,905,000 on the disposal of a plant. The results include Derotchild Knitwear Inc. from Oct. 1, 1983 and Fabric Tree Inc. from April 1, 1984.

title: SOME SCHOOLS ARE JAMMED AS OTHERS BEG FOR STUDENTS
description: Public School 189 in Washington Heights is very, very crowded.

title: Bank Rates Dip Again
description: Average annual yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued to drop in the week ended yesterday, accelerating a decline that began the week before, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: SHELLY MANNE, JAZZ COMPOSER, IS DEAD AT 64
description: Shelly Manne, a jazz drummer and composer, died today at a hospital after collapsing at his home here. He was 64 years old .

title: ; THE MX IS COUNTERPRODUCTIVE TO OUR SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Deficit Adds $33.5 Billion
description: The Federal budget deficit soared to a near-record $33.5 billion in August, putting the total for the year well above the shortfall forecast by the Reagan Administration, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: SAUDIS' TIES LOOSEN; LITTLE U.S. CAN DO
description: The effects of declining oil revenues are suddenly beginning to hit home in the Arabian Peninsula, undermining Saudi confidence and eroding relations between Riyadh and Washington. This cooling of what was once one of our best friendships in the Arab world is particularly unfortunate - and there is little that Washington can do about it.

title: AMERICA'S HARD LINE ON AID TO POOR NATIONS
description: In talking with delegates to the joint meeting here of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, twin pillars of the global economic system, the Reagan Administration has been selling neo-classical supply-side economics, just as it does at home. No amount of aid will help poor countries, the Administration argues, unless they provide incentives and commercial opportunities to private enterprise.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Natural Resources Co. , a natural gas exploration company based in Detroit, said its ANR Pipeline Co. had signed a 15-year agreement with Mobil Corp.'s Mobil Oil Exploration and Producing Southeast Inc. to buy all of the natural gas produced from Mobil's Mary Ann field off the Alabama coast. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SOVIET TO FIGHT ANY CHANGES IN UNESCO
description: The Soviet Union today criticized demands by the United States and other Western countries for changes by Unesco and said it would oppose their efforts to curb the organization's politically disputed activities.

title: Town Is Planning 2d 'TV Turnoff'
description: The Farmington Library Council, which sponsored a ''TV Turnoff'' last January, decided this month to proceed with a second effort next January.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL VOWS NEW RAIDS
description: A Nicaraguan rebel leader said today that his forces planned to intensify attacks against military installations and Cuban advisers in Nicaragua.

title: LAST FAREWELL FOR AN OFFICER SLAIN ON DUTY
description: The blue uniforms of more than 3,500 police officers formed a somber corridor for six blocks along Amsterdam Avenue yesterday. They stood five deep, heads bowed and gloved hands raised in salute. Under a steady drizzle, with the wind carrying the wailing of bagpipes playing ''Amazing Grace,'' they said goodbye to Irma Lozada.

title: Horizon Bancorp
description: Horizon Bancorp said it had applied to the Comptroller of the Currency to establish consumer banks in Palm Beach, Fla., Philadelphia and in Christina, Del. Horizon, the fourth-largest bank holding company in New Jersey, recently applied for a trust company charter in Boca Raton, Fla., and said it would apply for a consumer bank in lower Manhattan.

title: Mary Hyde Is Wed to Viscount Eccles
description: Viscount Eccles of Dean Farm, near Andover in Hampshire, England, and Mary Crapo Hyde of Four Oaks Farm in North Branch, N.J., were married yesterday in London. Canon Trevor Beeson, Anglican chaplain to the House of Commons, performed the ceremony in the Crypt Chapel of the Palace of Westminster.

description: ''Well, I know it must have been good,'' said Eva Marton in a flower- filled apartment the afternoon following her opening night performance in ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera. ''My husband told me he had always been too modest to shout for his own wife, but he says that yesterday he shouted.''

description: Thanks to a new state law that allows New York State wines to be sold at farmers' markets, all the items necessary to sustain life are now available at 9 of the city's 23 Greenmarkets.

description: The Helen of Troy Corporation, the Texas-based company that makes and markets Vidal Sassoon hair care products, announced yesterday that its three top officers had been elected to new positions.

description: The citrus industry today nervously watched the track of a tropical storm that took a bead on the southern Florida coast and threatened to hamper the fight against citrus canker.

title: PATTERNS FROM ENGLAND
description: ONCE in a while it's nice to go into a showroom and find the tried and true rather than the new and unexpected. Arthur Sanderson & Sons, an English concern that was established in 1860 and has just opened its first American showroom, has a wide variety of fabrics and wallpapers - from sweet British pastels to the fresh and bold handblocked and screen-printed designs of the master William Morris.

description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

description: The Smart and Final Iris Company said it had agreed to be taken over by Casino USA Inc. for $74.7 million. Casino already owns 17.5 percent of Smart and Final's stock.

title: HEALTH PANEL WARNS PATIENTS ARE AT RISK FROM BLOOD PLASMA
description: Health experts warned today that as many as ten thousand patients a year might be contracting hepatitis and other infectious diseases from transfusions of a major blood product that these experts said was not needed by 90 percent of the patients who received it.

description: Ashland Oil's long-term debt is being reviewed by Moody's Investors Service for possible downgrading.

description: Clerical and technical workers went on strike against Yale University today, setting up picket lines outside dozens of administrative and classroom buildings.

description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., saying, ''We have enough controversy,'' today prevented consideration of legislation that would have banned the sale of armor-piercing bullets.

description: A Republican candidate for Congress in Westchester County, responding at a candidate forum last weekend to a question about Federal financing of abortions, said members of minority groups ''enjoy having children'' partly because ''it gets them another check.''

description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on Sept. 4.

title: WHAT THE U.S. CUSTOM HOUSE SHOULD HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Remedy for Pain: A Deaf Ear Heroin, says the House of Representatives, may not be used to relieve the intractable pain of dying cancer patients. By a vote of 355 to 55, the House has buried a bill to allow physicians in hospitals and hospices to prescribe the drug as a last resort.
description: The bill's opponents cited the opinion of the American Medical Association, which argues that other drugs could serve as well. They ignored the contrary views of other health-care groups like the American Nurses Association, whose members have the hour-to-hour responsibility of keeping chronic pain at bay, and the Canadian Medical Association, which prefers to give individual physicians maximum discretion in relieving pain.

title: SEOUL READY FOR AID FROM NORTH
description: The South Korean Red Cross said today that it would provide ''safe-conduct memorandums'' to North Korea for the delivery of flood relief aid from the north to the south this weekend.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from London published on Sept. 13 included a quotation in which Dr. David Owen, leader of the Social Democratic Party, gave an incorrect year for formation of Sir Anthony Eden's Conservative Government. He became Prime Minister on April 6, 1955.

title: Joint Declaration
description: Following are excerpts from the agreement on Hong Kong that was initialed today by Britain and China, as made public by the British Foreign Office: The Government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the Government of the People's Republic of China have reviewed with satisfaction the friendly relations existing between the two Governments and peoples in recent years and agreed that a proper negotiated settlement of the question of Hong Kong, which is left over from the past, is conducive to the maintenance of the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong and to the further strengthening and development of the relations between the two countries on a new basis. To this end, they have, after talks between the delegations of the two Governments, agreed to declare as follows:

title: GERMANS BATTLE WAR GAMES
description: At least 96 people were arrested today as hundreds of demonstrators tried to break into munitions depots, damage military equipment and blockade bases to protest NATO military maneuvers, the authorities said.

title: DEFENSE DEPT. CONTENDS IT HAS ROOTED OUT FRAUD
description: The Defense Department asserted today that it had saved $5.9 billion, obtained 1,300 convictions and suspended 1,110 companies from doing business with the Government in a three-year campaign against fraud and waste.

title: NO JOY IN REGGIEVILLE
description: Until now, Reggie Jackson's home runs always seemed to supply martial music accompanying the success of his teams. In other years, the Yankees and the Oakland A's were winning the World Series; even the California Angels won the American League's Western Division title two years ago, after he had joined them the previous winter. With every long, soaring homer, it was as if he turned on a long-playing tape of his biggest hits.

title: FERRARO ASSAILS REAGAN ON KENNEDY NAME USE
description: With Senator Edward M. Kennedy by her side, Geraldine A. Ferraro reclaimed the memory of John F. Kennedy for the Democrats today and charged that President Reagan ''portrays himself as a friend of the very things he undermines.''

description: Norman Levy, vice chairman of 20th Century- Fox Film Corporation, announced today that he was resigning.

description: Above the elevator on the first floor of the tall, stately building at the end of Washington Street here is a clock, and above that clock is a faded sign that reads, ''Welcome to Our City Hall.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, a diversified company, has appointed Coy S. Baugh vice president-treasurer, and Herbert F. Kropp vice president-corporate audit.

title: ABC'S '20/20' EXAMINES A RAPIST
description: ONE of every 10 American women will be raped, Geraldo Rivera reports tonight on ''20/20,'' and nearly half the women will know their attackers. He also says that ''in the macho world of law and order, rape is still the crime least understood.'' The program will be seen on ABC at 10 P.M.

description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., which on Tuesday purchased Days Inns of America Inc. from the estate of Cecil B. Day for about $615 million, said yesterday that Henry R. Silverman had been elected chairman and chief executive of its new unit.

title: Kuhn Takes Hat Off to Mays
description: Sitting in the audience was Mays, who was ordered by Kuhn four years ago to relinquish any baseball duties as long as he was working for an Atlantic City gambling casino. Mays, in fact, was sitting with his boss, William S. Weinberger, president of the Bally Hotel and Casino, who had bought a table for the $250-a-plate dinner.

title: Australian's Grandson Is Born Addicted
description: Prime Minister Robert J. Hawke's youngest daughter and her husband sought help for their heroin use after doctors said their son was born addicted to the drug, hospital officials said Tuesday.

title: COMPOSURE HELPS IN DIRECTING ATTACK
description: Doug Strang has never seen a defense played quite the same way Texas plays it. The Longhorns, who will face Strang and his Penn State teammates Saturday at Giants Stadium, blitz often and trust their cornerbacks to employ man-to- man coverage against the wide receivers. Most other Penn State opponents have used a zone defense.

description: ''THE RED SHOES'' returned to the Cinema Village theater recently, and at the showing I attended moviegoers started sighing. That was no surprise. ''The Red Shoes'' has prompted sighs ever since its premiere in 1948.

title: PHONE SERVICE KNOCKED OUT
description: A 69-year old water main burst on the Upper East Side yesterday, knocking out telephone service for about 7,000 customers, a New York Telephone Company spokesman said.

description: MILAN, Italy

title: Piracy Said to Stir Concern Of Seamen and Shipowners
description: Piracy at sea has reached alarming levels, prompting seamen and shipowners to seek protection from the United Nations, according to Lloyd's Nautical Year Book.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report Monday with an article about the rededication of the Eldridge Street Synagogue in Manhattan misidentified a boy watching a woman sign the register at the synagogue. He was Noah Abram Teitelbaum.

title: Weather or Not
description: Rain fell in sheets and fierce winds

title: PLANTS TO PROTECT FROM FROST
description: THIS is the time of year when gardeners start thinking about cover-ups. As soon as nights become cool they have a tendency to coddle plants so they do not get an evening chill. For many tender plants this attitude is fine. But for others covering up is probably the worst thing that can be done. The differences are important.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday on the heckling of Democratic candidates incorrectly reported the remarks of a Reagan campaign official. Maureen Halikis, youth coordinator in California, said members of Americans for Freedom had participated in a demonstration against Walter F. Mondale at the University of Southern California on Sept. 19, but that they had not started the heckling of Mr. Mondale.

title: ABORTION FOES PRESSING DRIVE AGAINST FERRARO
description: As Geraldine A. Ferraro addressed a rain-spattered campaign rally here today, Ruth Packard pressed toward the front of the crowd and raised a hand-lettered sign high above her head. It showed a drawing of the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate and read, ''I voted 14 times to kill the unborn.''

title: EX-WQXR OFFICIAL CHARGED IN THEFTS
description: The former controller of radio station WQXR was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing $145,000 from the station.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE'S 'GISELLE'
description: FOR all the qualms one might have about taking the classics out of their intended context, the Dance Theater of Harlem's startling transposition of ''Giselle'' to Louisiana's bayou country must be chalked up as a triumph of ingenuity.

title: PEROT PURCHASES A COPY OF MAGNA CARTA
description: A 687-year-old copy of Magna Carta has been sold to the Dallas billionaire H. Ross Perot by relatives of the Earl of Cardigan, who led the Charge of the Light Brigade.

title: EAST OUTRIDES WEST IN JOCKEY CHALLENGE
description: Herb McCauley and Angel Cordero Jr. rode favorites to victory to lead a team of East Coast riders to a decisive victory over a team of California jockeys in the third annual East-West Jockey Challenge tonight at the Meadowlands race track.
