title: MONDALE MOVES TO SHORE UP BASE
description: As thousands of exuberant steelworkers shouted ''We Want Fritz,'' Walter F. Mondale today accused President Reagan of ''neglect and total indifference'' to trade unionists and charged that Mr. Reagan's plan to help the troubled steel industry was an election- year maneuver.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS OPENED AS SHULTZ RECEIVES GROMYKO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held what he called ''comprehensive and broad'' talks yesterday with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in New York to set the stage for the Soviet official's meeting Friday with President Reagan at the White House.

title: Last Islanders Return
description: The Islanders who were members of the Canadian team that recently won the Canada Cup, returned home and began skating today at Cantiague Park - with one notable exception.

title: CHESS MATCH: SIXTH GAME IS ADJOURNED
description: The sixth game of the world chess championship was adjourned today after the 42d move.

title: LAW ON CHILD ABUSE IS PASSED BY HOUSE AND GOES TO SENATE
description: The House today approved a compromise bill on child abuse that includes provisions intended to assure that severely handicapped babies receive appropriate medical care.

title: Reagan Sheds a Tear
description: President Reagan, it seems, is

title: Finn Explains Drug Test HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 26 (AP) - Martti Vainio of Finland,
description: who was stripped of the silver medal he had won in the 10,000-meter run

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ON THE HUSTINGS AS MONDALE FIGHTS BACK
description: As Walter F. Mondale left Houston late Monday night, his aides quietly began the final work on a five-minute nationwide television commercial for all three major networks Thursday night. It is to be broadcast at 10:55 o'clock, Eastern daylight time.

title: MITSUBISHI DRIVE BY CHIAT/DAY
description: THE Mitsubishi Electric corporate print advertising campaign

title: CONGRESS COMMITTEES MOVE ON WEAPON AND CURB ON TROOPS
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today moved to kill the Army's problem-plagued Sergeant York air defense weapon while the House Appropriations Committee reduced funds for President Reagan's proposed research on space-based antimissile weapons.

title: Amsterdam Trial Opens In Heineken Kidnapping
description: Three men accused of kidnapping Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman, and extorting an $11 million ransom went on trial here today.

title: ITT to Expand Defense Group
description: The ITT Corporation said it plans to spend more than $575 million over the next five years to expand its Defense Space Group facilities and technical capabilities.

title: Indian Orissi Dance
description: The art of Indian Orissi dance, which for centuries was performed only during religious ceremonies, will be demonstrated by Sanjukta Panigrahi on Oct. 10 and 11 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue.

title: STUDY SHOWS EFFECTS OF CIGARETTE SMOKE ON THE NONSMOKER
description: A nonsmoker in a family in which more than two packs of cigarettes are smoked each day actually inhales smoke the equivalent to that of one or two cigarettes, a Japanese study shows.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $185,000 from the sale of assets.

title: JOYOUS GALA FOR DANCE TROUPE
description: TO some of the people packed into the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria in yesterday's early hours, discoing on its tiny dance floor or eating smoked salmon and turkey, the gala fund- raising benefit for the Dance Theater of Harlem was simply a fine party.

title: Former Spy Chief Is Awarded $930,000 in Defamation Suit
description: Max C. Hugel, an adviser to President Reagan's re-election campaign who formerly directed clandestine activities for the Central Intelligence Agency, has been awarded $931,000 in a defamation suit against two former Wall Street stockbrokers.

title: MUSINGS ON A FALL CATALOGUE
description: -order catalogue, newly arrived, calls to mind the doting mother whose spoiled son is borne aloft everywhere by four porters. ''Thank heaven he'll never have to walk again,'' she tells herself.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Total Public Debt, Aug. 31 $1,560,649 Interest on Public Debt, Aug. 12,714 Interest, Fiscal Year through Aug. 141,494 Actual Deficit, Fiscal 1983 195,354 Projected Deficit, Fiscal 1984 174,303 Projected Deficit, Fiscal 1985 166,866 Receipts, Fiscal Year through Aug. 598,439 Receipts, Period Last Year 537,006 Outlays, Fiscal Year through Aug. 790,566 Outlays, Period Last Year 734,306 Deficit, Fiscal Year through Aug. 192,127 Deficit, Period Last Year 197,300 Gold at end of Aug. 11,098

title: MAN HELD IN SLAYING OF 2 GIRLS UPSTATE
description: A 22- year-old man was charged today with clubbing to death two teen-age girls last week on the edge of this sleepy village of 1,555 people in southern Dutchess County.

title: Letter: On Imports ; Sweater Deals That Won't Wash
description: To the Editor:

title: MET OPERA: A TALE OF THREE TENORS
description: IT was supposed to have been

title: Italian Aide Reissues Warrant Linking Arafat To Terrorists
description: A Venice magistrate has reissued an arrest warrant for Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organizaion, over allegations that the P.L.O. supplied weapons to Italian terrorists.

title: Subway Changes Are Announced
description: Subway trains on the N line will not run on the Manhattan Bridge for two weeks, and RR Chambers Street and QB service will be suspended while crews rehabilitate the bridge, the Transit Authority said.

title: Stress Hormone Tested As Heart Risk Measure
description: Measuring blood levels of a single hormone gives doctors an accurate assessment of the risk of death faced by people with severe congestive heart failure, a University of Minnesota Medical School study concludes.

title: Transactions
description: Announced that Danny Ozark will not return as manager in 1985. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Signed Bill Hanzlik, forward, to multiyear contract.

title: Cock-a-Doodle-Don't
description: We can all sleep a little easier

title: A PHOTOGRAPHER OF IMMIGRANTS IS REMEMBERED
description: Lewis Hine, the influential documentary photographer known for his images of Ellis Island immigrants and of children and adults laboring in American industry, was honored posthumously yesterday on the 110th anniversary of his birth with fanfare and an exhibition of 40 of his works in the lobby of the Empire State Building.

title: BUSH TO RELEASE DATA ON TAXES FOR THREE YEARS
description: Vice President Bush said here tonight that he would release the ''essential information'' of the three years of income tax returns filed on his behalf since he assumed office.

title: INDIA TV BOOM, 'STAR TREK' RERUNS AND POLITICS
description: For weeks, patients in a certain New Delhi hospital would leave their rooms every Sunday morning at 10:30 and flock to the building's one television set to hear the magic words: ''Space. The final frontier. These are the voyages of the Starship Enterprise.''

title: TERRORIST GROUP BLAMED FOR CONSULATE BOMBING
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that a relatively little known but increasingly active terrorist group was responsible for a bomb blast early yesterday that damaged the South African Consulate on Park Avenue.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees' final series of the season begins with a game against Jack Morris.

title: Continental's Tie To Kiewit Backed
description: Continental Group Inc. stockholders approved the $2.75 billion merger of the conglomerate with the Kiewit- Murdock Investment Corporation. S. Bruce Smart Jr., Continental Group chairman and chief executive, said the merger now needs the approval of the Georgia and New York State insurance commissioners.

title: SYRIA DENOUNCES MOVE BY JORDAN
description: The Government- controlled press in Syria said today that Jordan's decision to renew ties with Egypt was dangerous and linked the action to a possible resumption of the American-sponsored peace process in the Middle East.

title: INTELLIGENCE CUTS BY PREDECESSORS HAD A ROLE IN BLAST, REAGAN SAYS
description: President Reagan suggested today that ''the near destruction of our intelligence capability'' in the years preceding his Administration had resulted in the lack of warning of the explosion last week at the United States Embassy in Lebanon.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN COMMENTS ON BOMBING
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan today challenged President Reagan's comment that the bombing of the United States Embassy in Lebanon was, in part, a result of a ''near destruction'' of American intelligence capability ''before we came here.''

title: Radio Problem Is Cited In an Attack on Officer
description: The Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association blamed faulty radio communication yesterday for the plight of an officer who was assaulted on Tuesday evening by a suspected fare-beater in a Greenwich Village subway station.

title: METS VS. YANKEES: WHO'S NO. 1 IN CITY?
description: Back when the baseball season was young, the talk around town was that the dismal Yankee start and the fast Met spurt would help the Mets capture New York's heart.

title: Ex-U.S. Attorney Wins Damages in Libel Case
description: A former United States Attorney has been awarded $800,000 in damages in a libel suit against The Philadelphia Inquirer, eight years after the cause of the suit appeared in the newspaper.

title: REPORT IN JERSEY FINDS PARK FIRE WAS AVOIDABLE
description: The fire that killed eight teen-agers at the Great Adventure amusement park last May could have been avoided if local officials had enforced fire safety rules, according to a report issued today by the New Jersey Fire Safety Commission.

title: EAST SIDE COUNCILMAN IS CLEARED BY A PANEL
description: A City Council committee has cleared Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos of allegations that he improperly used his private law practice in handling cases involving matters before the Council.

title: I.B.M. TO PURCHASE COMPANY ON COAST FOR $1.25 BILLION
description: In a forceful expansion into telecommunications, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it would acquire one of Silicon Valley's leading makers of telephone switching equipment for $1.25 billion in securities.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE ACCORDS
description: Following are highlights of the agreement on Hong Kong:

title: Slowing Up Indy Cars Indy cars may be a shade slower next year as a result of new rules on design specifications, but probably not for long. That is the word from
description: Kirk Russell, and he should know. Russell is the technical director of Championship Auto Racing Teams, which sanctions all Indy-car races except the Indianapolis 500, whose own sanctioning authority, the United States Auto Club, has also adopted new rules, including a mandatory ''flat-bottomed'' design that should hold down speeds.

title: E.E.C. Steel Output Off
description: Crude steel production in the European Economic Community declined in July and August from June, the Common Market's statistical agency said.

title: Divers Seeking Detective's Body
description: A search of ''every inch of shoreline'' around New York City has begun for the body of a New York state detective who may have been killed by a man who subsequently hanged himself, officials said today.

title: MILITARY COURT IN ARGENTINA DEFENDS OFFICERS
description: The Armed Forces Supreme Council has said in an interim report that there was ''nothing objectionable'' about the orders given by Argentine military officials during a 1970's antisubversion campaign in which 9,000 people disappeared.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
TV'S PUPPET GOVERNMENT LAMPOONS FRENCH POLITICS
description: Every night here, just before the evening news, television viewers can see a puppet show that displays the major political leaders of this country, from the left of the spectrum to the right, in caricature.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The latest quarter contained 13 billing weeks compared with 14 weeks in the year-earlier period.

title: WHEN INSANITY LEADS TO A CRIMINAL ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 split paid July 1984.

title: CONGRESS VOTES STIFFER WARNINGS OF TOBACCO RISK
description: Congress today approved a bill that requires cigarette manufacturers to tell smokers more forcefully that they are endangering their health.

title: Ozark Steps Down He's 60 years old, he has had his share of baseball glory, and, he recalled, when he reported to spring training this year he knew this would be his last season. But that was before
description: Danny Ozark was promoted from third-base coach to manager of the San Francisco Giants, and since he replaced Frank Robinson in August there had been speculation that he might like to continue in the job next year. Now he has put an end to such talk.

title: E.P.A. SEEKS NO MONEY FOR SCHOOL ASBESTOS PLAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will not seek money to help schools clean up asbestos, a high-ranking agency official said today.

title: DECISION ON EXECUTION ORDER A KEY ISSUE IN CAROLINA RACE
description: Whether a 51-year-old woman will be put to death next month for murder has become a central issue in the highly charged Senate race between Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. and Jesse Helms, the Republican incumbent.

title: RETIRED REACTOR TO BE DISMANTLED
description: Here at the cradle of the nuclear power industry, where the first commercial plant opened in 1957, technology is fast facing another first: the dismantlement and burial of a reactor.

title: ARGENTINA AND BANKS BEGIN TALKS
description: Argentina's President, Raul Alfonsin, began negotiating today with leading international banks to stretch out his country's foreign debt and to obtain new credits.

title: No Headline
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1984 International A 3-hour Shultz-Gromyko meeting in New York was characterized by a senior State Department official as ''a good start.'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz held what he said were ''comprehensive and broad'' discussions with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to set the stage for the Soviet official's meeting with President Reagan at the White House tomorrow. (Page A1, Column 6.) A draft accord on Hong Kong was initiated by Britain and China. The agreement states that life in the crown colony will go on basically unchanged for 50 years after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. (A12:1-5.)

title: John Facenda Is Dead at 72;Narrator of N.F.L. Highlights
description: John Facenda, a longtime broadcaster whose voice was known to millions as the narrator of National Football League highlight films, died of cancer today at age 72.

title: Bendix Aerospace Seeks King Radio
description: The Allied Corporation said its Bendix Aerospace unit had agreed to acquire the King Radio Corporation for $40.50 a share, for a total of about $110 million.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Fed Policy Easing Seen as Rates Fall
description: A four-day decline in the closely watched rate for overnight interbank loans in the Federal funds market, to less than 11 percent, is giving rise to a growing belief that the Federal Reserve has eased monetary policy more than was expected.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Multi-Family Mortgages Back Midwest Offering
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday announced an unusual financing in which multi-family mortgages were used to back an issue of collateralized mortgage obligations issued by the Woodlawn Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association of Minneapolis.

title: Beatrice Lifts Earnings 16%
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that earnings in its fiscal second quarter, ended Aug. 31, rose 16 percent from a year earlier, while sales climbed 38 percent. Esmark Inc. was acquired on Aug. 7, and the Beatrice report includes two months of Esmark results.

title:
FUTURES/OPTIONS ;
Supply Report Sparks Heating Oil Price Rise
description: Heating oil futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in response to an industry report that disclosed an unexpected decline in the nation's supply of distillates.

title: EASING PHONE'S COMPUTER BILLS
description: -distance telephone

title: FRENCH COURT REJECTS BASQUE APPEAL
description: France's highest judicial authority on administrative decisions today rejected an appeal of an extradition order signed Sunday by Prime Minister Laurent Fabius, clearing the way for three Basque separatists to be turned over to Spain.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 27, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt, Bristol-Myers Split
description: After six years together Kenyon & Eckhardt and its client Bristol-Myers are calling it quits because of those frequently cited irreconcilable differences. The announcement came yesterday.

title: MET FINALE IS WINNING ONE
description: The Mets bade farewell to New York yesterday with a crescendo: They won their sixth straight game by beating the Philadelphia Phillies, they achieved their best record at Shea Stadium in 15 years and they ended their best home season at the gate in 11 years.

title: STATE U. KEEPS BAN ON GRANTS
description: The trustees of the State University of New York, by a vote of 8 to 2, rejected a proposal today that they lift their ban on athletic scholarships at the university's 29 campuses.

title: AT ROLM, AN INDEPENDENT STYLE
description: Up in Santa Clara, the big question around the swimming pools, on the tennis courts and in the Jacuzzis at the Rolm Corporation's headquarters today was whether Rolm's dream-come- true working conditions could long endure under the rule of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: LIQUIDATION SET BY CITY INVESTING
description: The City Investing Company's board voted yesterday to liquidate the company. In the first step, it agreed, as expected, to sell three major operations for $1.25 billion to an investor group led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

title: The Basic Speech The heart of each Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidate's message emerges in a
description: ''basic speech'' that varies little

title: QUARTERBACK TALE: ONE PLAYS, ONE SITS
description: The careers of Ken O'Brien and Tony Eason have had remarkable parallels: Both are quarterbacks from the Sacramento area, both were attracted to California-Davis, both chose the same agent, and both were taken on the first round of the 1983 draft.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Director of L. B. Foster Becomes Its Chairman
description: The L. B. Foster Company of Pittsburgh has a new chairman. Milton Porter, 73 and son-in-law of the founder, has retired after 40 years with the company and turned over the chairmanship to Edward C. Mabbs.

title: A NEW CHALLENGE FOR SEOUL LEADER
description: With the exiled opposition leader Kim Dae Jung planning to come home soon, President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is being put to a new test of his grip on power.

title: Zungul Named M.V.P.
description: His team, the Golden Bay Earthquakes, had an 8-16 record, the worst in the North American Soccer League this summer. But that didn't seem to impede Steve Zungul.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said it and the Grumman Corporation's Grumman Aerospace Corporation would bid for one of the prime contractor roles in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space station program. The joint venture will be centered at General Dynamics' Convair division in San Diego. Grumman will contribute work on laboratory outfitting and thermal systems.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE weather may not have felt

title: BRADY, W.H. CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
On the Record ; Reagan on Embassy Security
description: From the White House transcript of the question and answer on embassy security Wednesday at Bowling Green State University in Ohio:

title: High Life Agency Search
description: One competitor for the $55 million Miller High Life account does not think the Miller Brewing Company will make a decision until January. Miller's new marketing people are not even looking at the speculative campaigns until later this fall, he said.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Can Co. of Greenwich, Conn., said it had sold about 16,000 acres of timberland in Alabama to Gulf States Paper Corp. and others for $12.4 million in cash, resulting in a third-quarter gain of about 24 cents a share.

title: E.P.A. TELLS ASBESTOS STAND
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would spend $50 million already appropriated by Congress to help schools clean up asbestos but ''feels it is simply too early to know what funds will be needed in the future.''

title: RESTAURANTS
description: French fare on 14th Street. Tucked in among the slightly seedy facades of 14th Street near Eighth Avenue, the shiny red enameled entrance to Quatorze casts a welcoming glow. This delightful two-month-old restaurant, whose name means 14 in French, has all the accouterments of a proper bistro, not the least of which is its straightforward, carefully prepared food.

title: ANOTHER PROBLEM IS CITED IN TRANSIT POLICE RADIOS
description: A transit police officer trying to arrest six armed-robbery suspects was forced to use a pay telephone and call the 911 emergency number for help yesterday morning after his police radio was unable to transmit his requests, transit police officials said.

title: Alaska's Senators Muddy the Water An unworthy campaign by Alaska's two Republican Senators threatens to deprive all states of cleaner waters.
description: After months of debate, an important bill renewing the Clean Water Act has been made acceptable to all sides and is ready to be passed by Congress. The only obstacle is the insistence of Senators Frank Murkowski and Ted Stevens that two polluting pulp mills in their state get a third extension of a waiver sanctioning their use of inferior pollution-control equipment.

title: No Headline
description: St. Paul Cos. Plans To Sell Some Units

title: Diner's Journal; A 'BARNYARD' RESTAURANT THAT SPECIALIZES IN PORK
description: THE term ''pig out'' has taken on near literal dimensions with the recent opening of Pig Heaven (1540 Second Avenue, near 80th Street), the whimsical creation of the restaurateurs David Keh and Ed Schoenfeld. The setting is strictly barnyard: a bale of hay in the middle of the dining room and straw scattered around the floor, pink- tinted barnboard walls bordered by a frieze of pink piglets, crayon-yellow plastic tablecloths, and even coffee mugs with pink nostrils painted on the bottom so you can oink-oink and giggle over dessert. Gimmicky, yes. But Pig Heaven is one of those exuberant places we all need once in a while. And some of the food is good.

title: No Headline
description: Berkshire Ballet DebutThe Berkshire Ballet makes its New York debut this weekend at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 110th Street.

title: RIOTS RESUME IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Angry blacks rioted across South Africa today in growing protest against the Government's racial policies.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Salvagers Resume Retrieval Of Sunken Radioactive Cargo
description: Salvage teams resumed their efforts today to retrieve the radioactive cargo from a sunken French freighter as the weather improved after a week of gales, officials said.

title: Sikh Golden Temple Returned to High Priests
description: President Zail Singh returned control of the Golden Temple, the holiest Sikh shrine, to the sect's high priests today after nearly four months of army occupation, the United News of India reported.

title: China-E.E.C. Trade Accord
description: China and the European Economic Community have initialed a new five- year trade and economic cooperation agreement, underlining large increases in their commercial and technological exchanges.

title: Allen Retires as Coach He's the only coach in professional football to have won more than 100 games without posting a losing season. But, at the age of 66,
description: George Allen has decided it's time to leave the field. Allen, who came out of retirement two years ago to help inaugurate the United States Football League as coach of the Chicago Blitz, announced yesterday that he was retiring as coach of the Arizona Wranglers, the team that succeeded the Blitz in a franchise switch before the 1984 season.

title: CLOSING DOWN THE PENTAGON FOLLIES
description: In a news conference the other day, Representative Barbara Boxer of California put some new defense follies on the record. General Dynamics, it appears, has charged the Pentagon - that is, the American taxpayer, you and me - $7,417 for an alignment pin that the humbler among us buy for 3 cents at the corner hardware store. McDonnell-Douglas charged $2,043 for a six-sided nut that costs 13 cents at the store. Pratt & Whitney charged $1,118 for a 22 cent plastic cover for stool legs. Hughes Aircraft charged $2,543 for a $3.64 circuit breaker. And in each case the Defense Department meekly handed our money over to the corporate highwaymen.

title: THE TWO GERMANYS (1)
description: Nothing crosses cold-war barriers more effectively than music. That's why a group of rock-loving youngsters recently stopped Philipp Jenniger on an East Berlin street to thank him for an agreement permitting Western recordings to be legally imported and sold in East Germany.

title: CASH: A TALENT SPICED BY A 'RAW PERSONALITY'
description: In the lobby of the Marriott Hotel this morning, Neale Fraser straightened the collar of Pat Cash's white flannel suit with the gentle touch of a father readying an unkempt son for a grammar school photo.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
description: b-Net income including a gain of $75,000, or 2 cents a share, relating to the sale of a production facility in Oregon.

title: No Headline
description: Sindona Held In Murder ROME, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -

title: Double Elections Ruled Separate by U.S. Panel
description: The son of the late Representative Carl D. Perkins can collect up to twice the normal limit on political contributions because he is running both to fill the last two months of his father's term and for a regular seat in Congress from Kentucky, the Federal Election Commission ruled today.

title: LAXALT AND COAST EDITOR IN LIBEL FIGHT
description: Senator Paul Laxalt has filed a $250 million libel suit against McClatchy Newspapers, leading the Sacramento publisher C. K. McClatchy to charge today that the Senator was trying to intimidate the news media.

title: State Advice Held Faulty
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan's staff should not have told local governments and school districts in 1983 that they could use the services of a particular investment consulting company, a special counsel to the Comptroller said today.

title: BRITAIN CALLS FOR NEW SYSTEM TO MONITOR UNESCO CHARGES
description: Britain called on Unesco today to establish a new ''monitoring system'' to insure that the world agency carries out all the policy initiatives agreed upon by member countries at a meeting under way here.

title: 5 Die in Bangladesh During Political Strife
description: At least five people were killed and hundreds were hurt throughout Bangladesh today during a national strike called by political groups opposed to the military Government, politicians and hospital officials said.

title: Computer Concern's Net Up
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation yesterday reported strong sales and earnings for its fiscal first quarter. Some analysts, however, are raising warning flags for the semiconductor industry in the coming months.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL AGAIN IN SYRIA ON MIDEAST TOUR
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy was reported today to have returned to Damascus for a second visit in his tour of the Middle East.

title: 'BODY ROCK,' A LOUD SPLICE OF LIFE
description: ''BODY ROCK,'' which opens today at Loew's State and other theaters, looks not like a theatrical film but like a series of music videos that have been spliced together to make a feature-length presentation.

title: SOHIO TO BUY SOME GULF ASSETS
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said today that it would buy the Gulf Corporation's marketing and refining operations in the Southeast, where it now does little business. The sale presumably clears the way for final approval of the Chevron Corporation's $13.3 billion acquisition of Gulf, which would be the biggest merger on record.

title: MONDALE CHARGES REAGAN IS EVADING BLAME IN BOMBING
description: Walter F. Mondale accused President Reagan today of an ''inexcusable'' attempt to shift the blame for last week's bombing of the American Embassy near East Beirut. Earlier, the White House sought to soften Mr. Reagan's implication that the fault lay with the ''near destruction of our intelligence capability'' before his Administration took office.

title: APPEASING DANIEL WEBSTER'S GHOST
description: Is the Capitol haunted? Is there any merit to many tales that still linger, including reported sightings of President Grant shaking hands with Gen. Robert E. Lee in Statuary Hall?

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
description: b-After a tax credit of $3.9 million, or 4 cents a share.

title: Death of a Transit Cop Arresting and handcuffing a suspect alone is as dangerous as any task in police work, and that's the position Transit Officer Irma Lozada found herself in last Friday. A suspect allegedly wrested her gun from her and killed her, making her the city's first female police officer to die in the line of duty. The incident lends new urgency to questions about the management and autonomy of the Transit Police.
description: Officer Lozada and her partner, Nat Giambalvo, chased a chain-snatching suspect out of an elevated subway station into a wooded area. When they split up to continue the chase, Officer Lozada took the radio they shared. Officer Giambalvo searched the woods and nearby streets, then returned to the subway stop. Using another officer's radio, he tried to raise his partner, but got no answer.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
34 HURT AS MANILA POLICE CRUSH A RALLY
description: At least 34 people were hospitalized, including 12 with gunshot wounds, after police officers armed with guns, clubs and tear gas broke up an anti-Government demonstration here today. Many others were injured but did not require hospital care.

title: No Headline
description: Emery Going To Thompson Emery Worldwide, which

title: A Turkish Martial-Law Court Sentences 22 Leftists to Die
description: The killers of four American servicemen were among 22 leftists sentenced to death today by a Turkish court, a press agency reported.

title: HEAD OF UNION PLANTERS QUITS AMID 'DIFFERENCES'
description: The board of the Union Planters Corporation, in a move that it said represented ''differences of opinion'' about the future direction of the company, announced yesterday that William M. Matthews Jr. had resigned as its chairman and president and as chairman of the Union Planters National Bank, its principal subsidiary.

title: ANGELS ELIMINATED
description: Jamie Quirk, in his first time at bat for Cleveland, hit a bases-empty home run off Ron Davis with two out in the ninth inning to give the Indians a 4-3 victory over Minnesota tonight. The loss dropped the Twins two games behind first-place Kansas City in the American League West.

title: Slew o' Gold's Frog Is Marlboro Focus
description: Why did the vice president for racing at Belmont Park toss a stuffed Kermit the Frog doll to the trainer of the best horse in the country yesterday morning? He was sounding the theme of tomorrow's $400,000 Marlboro Cup, a race in which frogs are getting as much attention as the horses.

title: CANADA HAILS ELIZABETH II, JUST AS IT DID GEORGE III
description: Pictures of the British royal family adorn the parlors in this city of 80,000, books on the same subject are commonly displayed on coffee tables and a surprising number of trees seem to have been planted by one monarch or another.

title: MATTINGLY KEEPS 'LEAD'
description: As the Detroit Tigers were finishing their victory lap around the American League East and the Kansas City Royals and Minnesota Twins were stumbling toward the wire in the West, the decimal level of the last meaningful race in these parts continued at four figures last night.

title: More Cars From Japan
description: Japan's exports of motor vehicles in August rose 14.2 percent from a year earlier, to 469,153 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. Exports to the United States climbed 21.8 percent, to 195,753 units.

title: Ex-White House Aide Satirizes Ferraro in Song
description: A former White House aide, Morton C. Blackwell, said today that a song he sang about Geraldine A. Ferraro's ''renting spaces to the mob'' was meant ''obviously as satire.''

title: PATTERN PROCESSING TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-There were no revenues reported.

title: THE REGION ; ;  3 Hurt as Bomb Explodes in Jersey
description: A mother was burned and her two sons were critically injured today when a pipe bomb exploded while she was cleaning the apartment of a neighbor, the police said.

title: ART: A GOLUB RETROSPECTIVE AT NEW MUSEUM
description: AT the age of 62, Leon Golub has become a star. While artists rise and fall overnight, while the radical chic dote over graffiti artists and art dealers scour the ranks of teen-agers for new talent, Golub is widely experienced as an artist to believe in. His career evolved slowly, according to its own patient but insistent rhythm. The pictorial investigations of political terror that have placed him at the center of the present debate about politics and art are the culmination not only of sustained political concern, but also of a lifelong journey into the human heart.

title: Fox Picks Movie, TV Executive
description: Lawrence Gordon today was appointed president and chief operating officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation's newly named Entertainment Group. The company's television and movie divisions will report to Mr. Gordon, who has headed Fox's movie production since July.

title: No Headline
description: A Continental Rescue View WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -

title: CITY'S SALE OF HOUSES INCREASING
description: Bright and early last Friday, Gordon Powell and a small team of assistants took themselves to Ralph Avenue at the eastern edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn to look long and hard, inside and out, at an empty building.

title: UNITED NATIONS REFORM AWAITING POLITICAL WILL
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS PREPARE TO STOP DICKERSON
description: For their game against the Giants Sunday, the Los Angeles Rams can put their offensive plan on the back of a postage stamp if they wish. Two words - Eric Dickerson - will do.

title: ABORTION IS NOT A PROPER FEDERAL CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH'S BLIND TRUST: GUARDING AGAINST CONFLICTS OF INTEREST
description: The decision by Vice President Bush yesterday to release tax information from his trust has drawn attention to the use of trusts by Government officials. Relatively few officials have trusts, but those who do are usually the most powerful members of an Administration, whose financial arrangements are likely to attract public attention.

title: OPERA-HAPPY CITY GETS 9 IN 3 DAYS
description: NEW YORK is the only city in America, and one of the few in the world, with two major opera companies. Yet for reasons of scheduling, tonight, tomorrow and Sunday mark the first weekend in nearly a year that the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera are offering simultaneous performances.

title: MORGENTHAU ASSAILS JUDGE ON SHELVED CASES
description: The Manhattan District Attorney accused a Criminal Court judge yesterday of ''clearing his calendar at any and all costs,'' and filed a petition in State Supreme Court demanding that the judge restore 27 cases.

title: Japanese Output Grows
description: Production by Japanese factories and mines rose 11 percent in August from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. Output grew mainly for transportation equipment, metal products and oil- coal products.

title: Utility Stocks Surge Ahead
description: Have utility stocks flashed a go-ahead signal for the rest of the market? These issues sometimes act as an advance indicator for gains in the overall market, although the guideline is by no means infallible.

title: PRIMITIVE SPIRITS INVADE THE MODERN
description: THE unprepared visitor who walks into the Museum of Modern Art any time between now and Jan. 5 may be startled to find that a large part of the museum has been taken away from modern art. In its place, we find primarily a community of vagabond spirits that originated quite some time ago in Africa, Oceania and the Americas. The spirits in question inhabit the standing figures, the reliquary figures, the fetishes, the headdresses and, above all, the masks that fill room after room.

title:
;
'PUFF' THE MAGIC GUNSHIP
description: Nicknames have mysterious origins - they appear one day and are accepted. ''Puff'' is a case in point.

title: DOUBTING ECONOMISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Perilous Passers: The Ones to Fear
description: Which quarterback do some of the National Football League's best defensive players fear most in a critical game situation, when victory or defeat will emerge from one final possession of the ball?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AM Cable TV Industries, Quakertown, Pa., has named Tom Saldi president and chief operating officer, succeeding Maqbool Qurashi, who remains chairman and chief executive.

description: Game's the thing in football play due in December. IT'S a sad commentary, but alas true: there

title: Dow Climbs 4.64, to 1,216.76;  Gain Is Tied To Rate Cuts
description: Stock prices advanced yesterday in active trading, buoyed by the news that many large banks had finally matched the cut in the prime lending rate announced last Friday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: HOW GOOD IS KEY U.S. INDEX?
description: At exactly 8:30 Friday morning, the Government will publish what might seem to be its most important economic statistic: the figure designed to predict the course of the $3.6 trillion-a-year American economy.

title: New Penn Square Indictment
description: The former energy-loan officer at Penn Square Bank was named in a new Federal indictment today, just hours after an Oklahoma City jury acquitted him of earlier charges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Rise in Pay-Phone Rate Brings Rise in Vandalism

title: A SPRIGHTLY WHODUNIT IN 'MURDER, SHE WROTE'
description: LIGHT mystery stories, the traditional sort of whodunits, were once a television staple, but they somehow fell out of favor in recent years. CBS will try to change that situation with ''Murder, She Wrote,'' a series getting under way on Channel 2 Sunday evening at 8 with a special two-hour premiere.

title: TWO WAYS TO ENHANCE NEW YORK CITY DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhetoric in the Farm Belt
description: Speaking to farmers in the heart

title: SUZANNE VEGA MELODIES DRAW ON FOLK TRADITION
description: THE freshest and clearest new voice on the New York folk music scene these days belongs to a 25-year-old singer, composer and guitarist named Suzanne Vega. Miss Vega, who is appearing tomorrow at Folk City, 130 West Third Street, has the pristine enunciation and ringing, acoustic guitar style that make her an heir to the folk-pop tradition of Joan Baez, Judy Collins and Joni Mitchell. But the introverted, diamond-hard imagery of her song lyrics, many of which describe New York's street life with a photographic objectivity, and her trancelike melodies that favor the whole-tone scale, also reflect new- wave and Eastern influences.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF SPEECH BY GROMYKO TO THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Following are key sections of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's address to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday, as translated by the United Nations and recorded by The New York Times:

title: ART: EXPLORING 6 YEARS OF POP AND MINIMALISM
description: African, Oceanic, and Northwest Coast Indian - that are enlivening Manhattan's museums and galleries this season, it may not be amiss to include ''Blam! The Explosion of Pop, Minimalism and Performance 1958- 1964,'' at the Whitney Museum through Dec. 2.

title: Floods Kill 150 in Nepal
description: A heavy downpour brought floods and mudslides, killing more than 150 people a week ago in south and southeastern Nepal, the Nepalese news agency, R.S.S., reported today. Most of the deaths were in the Sindhuli district of southeastern Nepal, the news agency said, but it did not give specific figures.

title: 4TH MAJOR CHANGE MADE BY CROCKER
description: In what may mark an end to a period of sweeping change in its top- level management, the Crocker National Corporation announced yesterday that Jeffrey L. Morby, an executive vice president at the Bank of Boston, had been named vice chairman of the holding company and its principal subsidiary, the Crocker National Bank. The appointment is effective next month.

title: No Headline
description: Sweeping organizational changes were announced yesterday by AT& T Information Systems, the company formed to market computers, phone switching systems and other advanced office equipment for the deregulated American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:2 Champions Offer Services As Prize in a Charity Event

title: HOTEL INVESTORS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including gains on the sale of property of $212,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $456,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year. c-Including a gain of $1,338,000, or 52 cents a share, for the quarter and year on the sale of property.

title: Ticket to Ride
description: Pat Valenzuela alone couldn't get a team of California-based riders to win the T.W.A. East-West Jockey Challenge at the Meadowlands on Wednesday night.

title: CAROLINA SLAYER FAILS IN HER BID FOR A REPRIEVE
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. said today that he would not block the execution of Margie Velma Barfield, a 51-year-old woman convicted of killing her fiance with arsenic.

title: Egypt Oil Prices Stable
description: Egypt will leave its crude oil export prices unchanged in October, holding to levels that have been in effect since April, an oil ministry official said today. The price for the top grade remained at $28 a barrel. Egypt produces nearly 900,000 barrels a day, according to the latest official figures.

title: Noise Rule Exemption Is at Issue for Miami
description: An attempt to delay new Federal airline noise restrictions for airlines serving Miami is being pursued amid opposition from nearly two dozen airlines.

title: CARTWRIGHT INJURY A PROBLEM
description: In a synopsis of his team last season, Hubie Brown, the Knicks head coach, said that, for all of his multistructured defenses, the system would collapse if Bernard King or Bill Cartwright were lost to the team.

title: HELPING WOMEN AS THEY AGE
description: Like the refrain of a popular song, the proclamation made by Gloria Steinem on the occasion of her recent birthday - ''This is what 50 looks like'' - was taken up by women ranging in age from 30 to 80 at a conference this week.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $55,000 for the quarter and $3,313,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $2,270,000 for the quarter and $3,052,000 for the year.

title: Debating the Debates
description: Until the Presidential campaign debates take place next month, political controversy on the subject is necessarily confined to who outmaneuvered whom in the debate negotiations.

title: Rejoining the Colts
description: Donnell Thompson is the talented Indianapolis Colt defensive end who was suspended from the team and then suffered shoulder and back injuries while playing golf during the suspension. Now he has resumed practicing with the club and will be eligible to be removed from the nonfootball-injury list after the Colts' game against Washington on Oct. 7.

title: 3 Basques Hospitalized On Arrival in Spain
description: Three Basque separatists extradited from France on charges of killing nine people arrived here early today and were hospitalized because of the effects of a hunger strike.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BACH, UPTOWN AND DOWN

description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING ; ;  Olympia's Choice
description: William S. Doyle, executive vice president of Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle, will head an agency team on a trip to Frankfurt to see A.E.G., a maker of office equipment. The company's American arm, Olympia, has just chosen the agency to handle its $2 million account. Olympia USA is in Somerville, N.J. The previous agency was Brouillard Communications, part of the JWT Group.

title: PUBLISHING: KLAUS MANN UPDATED
description: AFTER the family of Thomas Mann went into exile from Nazi Germany in 1933, Klaus Mann, the son, wrote an autobiography titled ''The Turning Post.'' It was published in 1942, shortly before the young man joined the United States Army.

title: No Headline
description: Datapoint Link Is Widened The Datapoint Corporation,

title: Church in Dispute Gets Over Half of Taxes Back
description: The Crystal Cathedral, the site of televised Christian services by the Rev. Robert Schuller, got back more than half the $473,185 in property taxes it paid under protest a year ago, church officials say.

title: No Headline
description: A Baron's Collection On Display at Sotheby's

title: MUSIC: SOUND OF CARIBBEAN
description: REGGAE and Rastafarian beliefs have made Brother Valentino an anomaly among calypso singers. At Sounds of Brazil Wednesday, Valentino's appearance - standing nearly stock- still on stage, with his hair in long dreadlocks - and his earnest songs were a long way from the wry, cocky presentation of most calypso artists.

title: CAIRO AIDE CONFERS WITH REAGAN
description: The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Esmat Abdel Meguid, bearing a message from President Hosni Mubarak, told President Reagan today that Egypt saw some hope for reviving the long-stalled Middle East peace process.

title: CASE OF 6 SERBS SIGNALS A CRACKDOWN
description: A pending trial of six dissidents is being viewed here as signaling a harder crackdown on domestic political opposition while Yugoslavia tries to maintain a reputation for liberalism abroad.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2,129,000. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,004,000.

title: FULLER, H.B. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $132,000 for the 9 months, a loss of $435,000 for the 9 months on the disposal of certain operations and a loss of $729,000 for the 9 months on assets in Lebanon. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $99,000 for the quarter and $36,000 for the 9 months.

title: CUOMO CITES PLEDGE
description: While waiting to clear last- minute legal hurdles, New York State is preparing to close the 1,000-bed state prison here on Monday.

title: OPERA: 'EUGENE ONEGIN' BEGINS RUN AT THE MET
description: Eugene Onegin'' is not one of the most popular works in the standard repertory, but that hardly speaks well for popular taste. It is an opera that appeals deeply to its audience, if it appeals at all, and deserves the best, most sensitive effort that an artistically responsible company can bring to it. The Metropolitan Opera's production, which had its first performance of the season Wednesday night, once had its merits but now is so seriously faded, visually, that only singing actors of enormous talent and intelligence could be expected to make much out of it.

title: AKRON PUT ON PROBATION
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today that it had placed the men's basketball program at the University of Akron on two years' probation because of a series of rules violations.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Market Place column in Business Day Monday incorrectly reported the employer of Jeffrey Atkin, a securities analyst. It is Cable, Howse & Ragen of Seattle.

title: CHERNENKO MAKES OVERTURE TO WEST
description: The Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, said today that the Soviet Union was prepared to be an ''honest and well-wishing partner'' in cooperation with the West if Western nations were ready to respond.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1984
description: The Economy

title: Cubs Honor Banks The Chicago Cubs reactivated 53- year-old
description: Ernie Banks, naming him an honorary member of the National League's Eastern Division champions. Banks, the Hall of Fame infielder who was nicknamed Mr. Cub during a 19-year career in which he belted a team-record 512 home runs, will suit up in his familiar No. 14 uniform during the National League's championship series, against the San Diego Padres beginning Tuesday at Wrigley Field.

title: An Effort to Understand Cecil B. De Mille
description: One of the most alluring and dangerous subjects for documentary biography is the Hollywood producer, director or actor. Unlike many other subjects, these people leave behind a body of work that is ideally suited for the purposes of the biographer: film itself.

title: UPSTATE, SCULPTURE AND SHEEP
description: From spinning wool to the latest in modern interior design to art designed to be viewed from a moving train, a varied range of activities awaits visitors to the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: FILM FESTIVAL OPENS WITH U.S. ACCENT
description: A CONTEMPORARY American story launches this year's New York Film Festival, which begins tonight at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall and runs through Oct. 14. The opening movie, ''Country,'' stars Jessica Lange and Sam Shepard as Iowa farmers who are battling a hostile government bureaucracy willing to foreclose their farm loans in exchange for a favorable bottom line - even if that means destroying the farmers' lives. Directed by Richard Pearce, the film (review on page C20) lends an uncharacteristically home-grown flavor to the premiere of a festival that has long been more associated with foreign films than American.

title: REP. BOGGS, 68, FACING HER TOUGHEST CAREER CHALLENGE IN LOUISIANA PRIMARY
description: Representative Lindy Boggs, at the age of 68, is facing the toughest challenge of her political career in an open primary election Saturday, but the head-to- head fighting that Louisiana voters customarily expect is conspicuously absent.

title: PINKERTON'S COMMISSIONER
description: For six years, the New York City Police Department was the round- the-clock, relentlessly high-tension preoccupation of Robert J. McGuire. As commissioner, he oversaw thousands of employees, tried to manage a succession of life-and- death crises, and did what he could to satisfy often antagonistic community groups.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75 ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: C.I.A. Denies a Murder Effort
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said Wednesday that it had never plotted to kill Ronald Rewald, an investment counselor in Honolulu who asserts that his failed company was a C.I.A. front.

title: No Headline
description: Jazz and Poetry Festival at Shuttle Lab

title: STRIKING WORKERS' PICKET LINE CUTS VISITORS TO DISNEYLAND
description: The Monorail whooshed quietly along and Snow White, in a tremulous soprano, sang of ''wishing for the one I love'' at Disneyland. There were fewer visitors by far, but those who came did not seem to mind that the world's most famous amusement park, where the sacred mission is escape from reality, had pickets outside.

title: IN CHICAGO, CUB FANS ARE IN HEAVEN AFTER YEARS OF WATCHING AND HOPING
description: Thousands of rabid fans braved the cold early this morning to welcome home the conquering heroes of the National League's Eastern Division, the Chicago Cubs.

title: WILLIAM G. WILKERSON
description: The Rev. Dr. William G. Wilkerson, a Baptist minister, physician and former State Assemblyman, died of a heart attack last Friday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 68 years old and lived in Orange.

title: Ratings
description: Citizen's Utility Co . of Stamford, Conn., had ratings on first mortgage and collateral trust bonds raised to Aaa, from Aa1, by Moody's. The rating for commercial paper remains at Prime 1. National Fuel Gas Co. had ratings on $230 million of securities raised to A-, from BBBx; preferred stock to A-, from BBB, and the commercical paper to A1, from A2, by Standard & Poor's.

title: Wisconsin Finds Wide Use Of Marijuana in Its Prisons
description: Twenty-five percent of the 640 state prisoners tested last summer were found to have marijuana in their systems, results showed.

title: I.M.F. CHIEF SEES THIRD-WORLD GAIN
description: Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that third-world countries would experience growth this year of 3 1/2 percent, or more than twice their rate of growth in the previous two years.

title: MUSIC: MEAT PUPPETS AT RITZ
description: -core rock band, Suicidal Tendencies, and a former hard-core band, the Meat Puppets, on Wednesday.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $615,000 for the quarter and $354,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $481,000 and a tax credit of $14,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $788,000 and a tax credit of $950,000.

title: SOUTH KOREAN LEADER WARNS STUDENTS ON DISORDER
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea has warned that student disorders on university campuses will be dealt with sternly if they threaten to create what he called social instability.

title: Note and Bond Rates Fall Money Supply Off 3.4 Billion
description: Interest rates fell yesterday, with the sharpest drops occurring in the note and bond market where investor buying activity was much greater than earlier in the week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They (the Americans) are once again proclaiming a policy of 'peace through strength.'

title: No Headline
description: 'Kutztown Connection' Presents Benefit Series

title: DANBURY CELEBRATES A FAVORED SON, CHARLES IVES
description: One of history's most eclectic and intriguing composers was born 110 years ago in Danbury, Conn. This weekend in the same place, the Charles Ives Center will give birth to a two-day festival that aspires to reflect the kaleidoscopic diversity and energy of his music.

title: NO TALKS PLANNED IN YALE WALKOUT
description: Striking white-collar workers today picketed Yale University for the second day, with neither side making a move to resume negotiations.

title: CARDINAL PRESSES FIGHT ON ABORTION
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago yesterday said that abortion was a matter of public morality and that politicians ''cannot conscientiously ignore the issue or fail to take steps to restrict it.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in the Finance/New Issues column in Business Day Wednesday incorrectly reported the rating assigned by Moody's Investors Service to $40 million of convertible subordinated debentures of Ames Department Stores. It was Ba1.

title: INMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Including gains of $161,776 for the quarter and $366,034 for the 6 months on the sale of assets. c-After a loss of $32,632 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of assets.

title: ART: WILL INSLEY'S VISIONS OF A LABYRINTHINE CITY
description: LAST year at the Guggenheim Museum it was the miniature settlements of Charles Simonds that were made from tiny bricks of unfired clay. They evoked by turns the ''apartments'' and kivas left by the Chaco Indians, the remnants of Assyrian walls and the Sardinian towers known as nuraghi, as well as the lingams of Hindu mythology. Replete with mystery and eroticism, these ruined emplacements addressed themslves to the past and to the collective human unconscious.

title: Prosecutor Withdraws In Child Sex Abuse Case
description: The prosecutor who filed charges of sexual abuse of children against 24 people has withdrawn from the second trial in the case, saying the defense had made her an issue.

title: SETTLEMENT SEEMS NEAR IN MARC RICH TAX CASE
description: Negotiations to settle the largest corporate criminal tax-evasion case in the nation's history are nearing completion under terms that would bring the Government $100 million to $150 million, according to Federal officials and others familiar with the case.

title: 2 Hispanic Firefighters Bar Possible Promotion
description: Two Hispanic firefighters have refused possible promotions because they scored lower on a test than several white collegues.

title: HAROLD E. WETHEY
description: Harold E. Wethey, an art historian, died at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Saturday. He was 82 years old.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS REAGAN WON'T FIND FAULT IN BLAST
description: President Reagan has no interest in second- guessing officials in Beirut for decisions that preceded the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Lebanon, the White House said today.

title: EAST MEETS WEST IN DANCING OF JUNKO KIKUCHI
description: THE curtains, the backdrop, the floor, all are gray. And from the audience's right, Junko Kikuchi, one of Japan's leading modern dancers, bounds onstage without warning.

title: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ed Reinhardt, the Colorado tight end who became comatose soon after being tackled in a game against Oregon two weeks ago, underwent a second operation late Tuesday, to reduce brain swelling. He remains in a coma, and Tom Lawry, a spokesman for Sacred Heart General Hospital, said the swelling represented a ''setback in his recovery.'' . . . Michigan State's head basketball coach, Jud Heathcote, who guided the Spartans to the national collegiate championship five years ago, suffered a heart attack yesterday and was taken to a Lansing hospital, where his condition was later described as stable.

title: LIBERTARIAN ASKING LESS GOVERNMENT
description: If David Bergland finds himself in the White House in January, a lot of Federal employees will have to start searching for other jobs. The fundamental proposition of the party he represents, as Mr. Bergland defined it on a recent visit to New York City, is that Government has no business doing most of what it now does.

title: Talkin' Marathon
description: Terry Cashman, who wrote and recorded ''Talkin' Baseball,'' the nostalgic song saluting New York baseball in the 1950's, when Willie Mays, Mickey Mantle and Duke Snider were the star center fielders of the city, has come up with another melodic celebration of a New York sporting phenomenon.
