description: An Offending Preposition

title: Kingman Gets to Play By The Associated Press The three-game suspension imposed by the American League on
description: Dave Kingman, the designated hitter of the Oakland A's, was lifted yesterday, allowing him to play against the Kansas City Royals in a season-ending series starting tonight. The series will be critical in determing whether Kansas City wins the Western Division race, and Bobby

title: Pittsburgh Teachers End a 3-Day Strike By United Press International
description: Teachers in a Pittsburgh area school district returned to work yesterday, ending a three-day strike, but more than 40,000 students across the country remained out of classrooms because of labor disputes.

title: Canadian Output Rises
description: Canada's industrial production in July rose 4 percent from June, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. It noted gains for paper mills, car makers, some mines and steel mills, among others.

title: BIG BANKS TRIM PRIME TO 12-3/4%
description: The nation's leading banks reduced their prime lending rate yesterday a quarter of a percentage point, to 12 3/4 percent, following a similar move last week by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: A CHRONICLER OF FASHION, AT 88, REFLECTS ON CHANGE
description: At the opening of an exhibition of Louise Dahl-Wolfe's photographs this week at the Staley-Wise Gallery, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe sat surrounded by hundreds of admirers, surrounded, too, by some of her most famous photographs: the langourous nude on a sand dune, Suzy Parker in a Balenciaga suit and her luminescent portrait of Colette.

title: Italy's IRI Sets Pact With I.B.M.
description: IRI, Italy's state industrial holding company, said that it had agreements with the International Business Machines Corporation to provide the computer giant with semiconductor chips, computer software and other products.

title: Man-Made Mountain on the Border There's a molehill growing on Capitol Hill. It's called ''alienage,'' and it's growing so fast that unless somebody does something today, it will crush the bipartisan Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill. If so, the country will lose the chance of a generation to end the lawlessness on its borders, leaving the public, in as much suspicion as sadness, to ask why.
description: The reform effort stretches back to Peter Rodino's initiatives in the House a decade ago. Present law says to illegal aliens: No sir, we don't let people like you into this country. But present practice says: That's just talk. If you can sneak past the Border Patrol, before long some employer will be glad to hire you.

title: CATSKILL RESORTS: BIGGER AND SEEKING YOUNGER MARKET
description: The comedian Mal Z. Lawrence works Las Vegas, Atlantic City, Dallas and the Poconos. But for 29 years, the large, traditionally Jewish Catskill resorts have been his bread and butter, or perhaps, it is better to say, his bagel and schmear.

title: BOMBING AT UNION CARBIDE LINKED TO CONSULATE BLAST
description: Investigators searched through rubble at a Union Carbide Corporation building here today for clues to the explosion that sheared off two walls of windows Wednesday night. The explosion came less than 24 hours after a bomb wrecked part of the South African Consulate in Manhattan.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIANS UNEASY OVER ISLAMIC RADICALS
description: Islamic radicalism, an unsettling force in the Middle East, could also threaten the stability of the rapidly developing nations of Southeast Asia, according to some political leaders in this region.

title: SENATE TO TAKE UP ANTI-BIAS MEASURE BEFORE DEPARTING
description: Although backers said they hoped to revive the immigration bill, opponents said it was dead. Page A16.

title: TDA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,135 for the latest year and $11,209 for the year-earlier period.

title: ;  Golin/Harris Takeover
description: Golin/Harris Communications, a Chicago public relations firm with expected 1984 revenues of $5 million, is on the verge of being acquired by Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, the agency announced yesterday. The public relations company will continue to operate under its current name with its current management, within Carl Byoir & Associates, an F.C.& B. subsidiary.

title: House Arrest Is Over For 2 Haitian Politicians
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 27 (AP) - President Jean-Claude Duvalier has ordered the release of an opposition leader and a human rights advocate who were put under house arrest more than two months ago, the police said Wednesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1984 International Ellsworth Bunker, a high-ranking United States diplomat for three decades, died Thursday evening in Vermont. Mr. Bunker, a skilled and patient negotiator who had been a businessman for 30 years before becoming a diplomat, served as Ambassador to South Vietnam during the six years in which the United States became most deeply embroiled in the Vietnam War. (A1:1-3.).

title: GROMYKO, AT U.N., SAYS SOVIET WANTS 'DEEDS' FROM U.S.
description: Key sections of speech, page A12.

title: INDOMITABLE TACTICIAN
description: When talk turns to Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko, words like survivor, professional, indestructible, veteran, indomitable seem to roll off the tongue almost of their own volition. The legends are respectfully told and retold: the American Presidents he has met, stretching back to Franklin D. Roosevelt; how he sat at Stalin's elbow at Yalta and Potsdam; the tributes he drew from adversaries as seasoned as W. Averell Harriman and Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Rozier's Pact Settled
description: Mike Rozier, the Heisman Trophy- winning running back, has finally reached a tentative agreement to buy out the last two years of his contract with the Pittsburgh Maulers, according to his agent, but the buyout won't be signed until he has concluded a deal to join the Houston Oilers. And that apparently won't happen right away. The agent, Art Wilkinson, said Rozier could join the Oilers immediately, but Ladd Herzeg, the Oilers' general manager, who broke off talks when Rozier failed to win his release several weeks ago, said he would not resume negotiations until after the season.

title: ANALYST SAID TO HAVE QUIT C.I.A. IN DISPUTE
description: The senior Latin America analyst at the Central Intelligence Agency resigned in May after William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, insisted that he revise a report on Mexico so it would support Reagan Administration policy, intelligence officials asserted today.

title: Mitel Contracts
description: The Mitel Corporation said its United States subsidiary, Mitel Inc., had signed agreements with seven distributors in the United States valued at a minimum of $100 million (United States) over the next 12 months. The company said contracts had been signed with Alltel Supply, Centel Supply, the Graybar Electric Company, North Supply, Rotelcom Supply, Sterling Supply and Texocom to distribute Mitel superswitch PBX, or private branch exchange, equipment and related products.

title: Dining Out Guide: Northern Italian
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BRUNO, 240 East 58th Street (688-4190) - vv(Feb. 2, 1979) Dark, mirrored panels and rough white plaster walls with colorful botanical prints impart a country atmosphere. Appetizers include an excellent minestrone. Among the pastas, linguine all'Amatriciana is rich in tomato, prosciutto and onion.

title: SEES HOPE IN REAGAN TALK TODAY
description: Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, met yesterday in New York with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and said later that there was ''an opportunity for significant progress'' when the Soviet official sees President Reagan today in Washington.

title: Intergroup
description: National Intergroup Inc., the Pittsburgh-based iron, steel and aluminum products company, announced that it had formed a wholly owned information services subsidiary named Genix. The new unit will offer software sales, computer consulting and remote computer services.

title: Infant's Death Resolved
description: A 15-month-old girl reported missing from her family's van on a trip had leaned against a defective door latch and fallen onto a highway, where she was run over, the authorities said. ''We were looking for the truth and we found it and the parents are absolved,'' Sheriff George Hubbard of Kit County said Wednesday in announcing the results of an investigation by the Colorado Bureau of Investigation into the death of Charmayne Elizabath Young, daughter of Wayne and Charlene Young of Tacoma, Wash.

title: Elizabeth Dole Suspends Push for Rights Measure
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, says she has had to suspend her fight for passage of a Federal equal rights amendment because President Reagan is adamantly against it.

title: INDIAN LINKS POVERTY TO WORLD SPENDING ON ARMS
description: The Foreign Minister of India said today that reducing global military spending would enable the world's industrialized countries to ''augment the presently decreasing levels'' of economic assistance to developing countries.

title: General Host Sale
description: The General Host Corporation said it had signed an agreement to sell its Van de Kamp frozen foods division to the Pillsbury Company for an amount substantially in excess of its investment in the business. The company did not elaborate on the amount of its investment.

title: Ideology in the Park
description: Lafayette Park, the flower and fountain sanctuary facing the White

title: MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE TORN AGAIN BY CONFLICT
description: The chancellor of the City University of New York is investigating charges by the former financial aid director at Medgar Evers College that she was demoted because she would not give aid to ineligible students.

title: SCREEN: 'COUNTRY,' WITH JESSICA LANGE
description: '' COUNTRY,'' which opens the 22d New York Film Festival tonight at Lincoln Center, is a good, decent, 1930's Depression movie set in the mid-1980's, about the problems of farmers as they attempt to cope with the vagaries of Federal farm policies, which are no more easy to predict than the extremes of weather in the Middle West.

title: No Headline
description: Drama ExhibitionCostumes, photographs, playbills and other memorabilia are featured in ''The Academy of Dramatic Arts: Centennial Exhibition,'' on view through Oct. 28 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street. Weekend hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow, and 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Free. Information: 534-1672.

title: Texas Pupil, 10, Shot As He Raises the Flag
description: A gunman wounded a fifth-grade pupil who was raising the American flag at his school, then fired at a student who was late for classes at a nearby junior high school, the authorities said today.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
CONGRESSIONAL OPINIONS DIFFER ON CHANCES FOR BILL ON IMMIGRATION
description: The sponsors of a comprehensive immigration bill said today that they still hoped to rescue the legislation, but some opponents said it was dead.

title: THE NEW REAGAN
description: PARIS The big question after President

title: Times Mirror Sees A Flat 3d Quarter
description: The Times Mirror Company's stock fell $1.625 a share, to $37.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today after announcing that third- quarter earnings are likely to be flat compared with a year earlier. The newspaper and publishing company also said that it does not expect significant improvement in operating earnings for the second half.

title: Wallace Taken to Hospital
description: Gov. George C. Wallace was taken to a hospital in Birmingham today after awaking with a fever, an aide said. Billy Joe Camp, the Governor's press secretary, said the 65-year-old Mr. Wallace had a fever of about 102 degrees.

title: BAMBERGER NAMED BREWERS' MANAGER
description: In an early move in what is shaping up as another end-of-season round of musical dugouts involving managers and former managers, Rene Lachemann was dismissed as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday and George Bamberger was named to succeed him at the end of the season.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Sept. 28, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TENANTS LEARN TO ACT LIKE LANDLORDS
description: Her cup of coffee had gone cold long ago, and Willie Mae Wilson stared intently at a long list of figures. Finally, she looked up and announced, ''We are going to have to raise the rent.''

title: El Paso Rate Cut
description: Burlington Northern Inc.'s El Paso Natural Gas Company subsidiary said it had received Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approval to reduce its rates by about $100 million a year, effective Oct. 1.

title: Romance of Shipboards
description: The aura of trans-Atlantic travel from 1918 to 1940 will be recreated in an exhibition on view through Oct. 14 at Pequot Library, 720 Pequot Avenue, Southport, Conn.

title: U.S., CITING TERRORISM, ADDS TO CURBS ON EXPORTS TO IRAN
description: The State Department, citing a continuing pattern of Iranian support for terrorism, said today that new restrictions were being imposed on the export to Iran of aircraft, spare parts for aircraft and high-powered outboard motors.

title: A LAWYER IN NEW YORK
description: Herman Seid, a New York lawyer who specialized in corporate, patent and international commercial law in a career that spanned nearly 60 years, died last Sunday in Italy, He was 81 years old and lived in Sanibel, Fla., in Manhattan, and in Essex, Conn.

title: KARPOV BEATS KASPAROV AND TAKES A 2-0 LEAD
description: Aggressive, determined play led to a victory for the world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, in the sixth game of his title defense match with his countryman, Gary Kasparov, in Moscow yesterday.

title: AUCTIONS
description: HUNDREDS of fittings and furnishings from the luxury liner United States, the fastest ever built and one of the most handsome as well, will be on view this weekend at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street. Everything from shell- embellished teaspoons to a pair of ship's telegraphs are included in the display, which will precede the auction of the vessel's contents Oct. 8 through 14. The sale will take place at a warehouse in the shadow of the still awesome vessel - a towering, black- hulled ship with raked red smokestacks - which is docked in Norfolk, Va.

title: Bottom Line
description: Two performance artists will appear tonight at 9 and midnight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880) at Mercer Street. David van Tieghem, who plays an assortment of percussion instruments, is headlining; Eric Bogosian, a monologuist, will open the show. Tickets are $8.

title: All-Stars Named Although the Cosmos did not qualify for the playoffs, they placed four players on the North American Soccer League all-star team announced yesterday. The goalkeeper
description: Hubert Birkenmeier, the defenders Johan Neeskens and Andranik Eskandarian and the midfielder Vladislav Bogicevic represented the Cosmos, with Bogicevic being the league's overall top vote-getter. Others named were the defender Bruce Wilson of Toronto; the Golden Bay forward Steve Zungul; the defender Kevin Crow of San Diego, the midfielders Frans Thijssen of Vancouver and Ray Hudson of Minnesota and the forwards Peter Ward of Vancouver and Karl- Heinz Granitza of Chicago.

title: Midwifery in the House
description: Members of the House of Representatives learn early that they can turn to their colleagues for almost any kind of advice.

title: Senatorial Debate Faces Competition for Ratings
description: Phil Gramm and Lloyd Doggett hold the first of two debates Friday in their race for the Senate, but many Texans might decide not to watch it.

title: THEATER: THE PRICE OF SUCCESS
description: SURELY there are few 20th century morality tales more familiar than the one about the poor immigrant who strikes it rich in America at the price of losing his soul. Ernest Joselovitz's ''Jesse's Land'' is another variation on the theme, in its Jewish-American incarnation: the play is set in 1941, the heyday of Budd Schulberg's Sammy Glick. Yet Mr. Joselovitz has something of his own to say. As a piece of dramaturgy, ''Jesse's Land'' is creaky, even primitive, but attention must be paid to the playwright's novel approach to his subject and his characters.

title: Money Fund Assets Soar
description: The assets of the nation's 335 money market mutual funds recorded their largest weekly climb in almost two years, soaring $2.38 billion, to $184.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $355,000.

title: Pursuing the Smoke-Free Dream Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's impossible dream - a smoke-free society by the year 2000 - seems a bit more possible now. This week, after a two-year wrangle, Congress finally approved a bill requiring cigarette manufacturers to spell out the threats lurking in that little box or soft pack. The old warning was overly familiar and nonspecific, and consequently often overlooked. It will be hard to miss the new ones.
description: There are four of them, to be rotated, and they're strongly worded. One label, for instance, lists the diseases that can be caused by smoking: lung cancer, heart disease and emphysema.

title: SEARLE FAMILY SEEKING TO DIVERSIFY
description: The Searle family, which owns 34 percent of G. D. Searle & Company, put the big Middle Western drug company on the auction block yesterday by asking management to help it diversify its holdings.

title: GRINDING THE GEARS AND WAITING FOR GROMYKO
description: On Sunday night, when the United States Information Agency flashed to missions abroad the advance text of President Reagan's speech to the United Nations, one sentence was held back. Missing was the line in which Mr. Reagan said, when he delivered the speech on Monday, that in possible talks with the Soviet Union on outer space weapons, the United States ''would consider what measures of restraint both sides might take while negotiations proceed.''

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $17,000 for the quarter and $1,257,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The latest periods' income includes a gain from the sale of investments of $31,000 for the quarter and $2,908,000 for the 9 months. The year-earlier periods' income includes a gain from the sale of investments of $337,000 for the quarter and $626,000 for the 9 months.

title: Steel Curb Sought
description: The Chaparral Steel Company, a joint venture of Texas Industries and Co- Steel International Ltd. of Toronto, said it had filed a request with the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, calling for voluntary agreements to reduce imports of steel from Poland and Norway. The company said it also intends to initiate several new countervailing-duty and antidumping petitions against other nations.

title: No Headline
description: Italian FilmsThe Center for Italian Studies at Columbia University, 1161 Amsterdam Avenue, opens a series titled ''Film Classics From Italy,'' this evening at 7 with Fabio Carpi's ''Basileus Quartet'' (1983). The series continues with Lina Wertmuller's ''Swept Away,'' on Friday, Oct. 5, and concludes on Friday, Nov. 2, with Ettore Scola's ''Special Day'' (1977).

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Cubs' Alumni Society
description: It cost Cy Block $40 the last time he

title: REAGAN BEGINNING TO GET TOP BILLING IN CHRISTIAN BOOKSTORES FOR POLICIES
description: The most prominent single display in The Olive Branch, one of thousands of Christian bookstores in the United States, is a rack of books on President Reagan.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: New Hampshire Utility Sets $425 Million Offer

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Sept. 19 about Meldrick Taylor, the Olympic boxer, misidentified Lloyd Remick. He is Taylor's attorney.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,713,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $7,805,000 for the quarter and $7,652,000 for the 9 months. d-After income from discontinued operations of $3,431,000 and a gain on the sale of a theme park of $1,914,000.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,000 for the quarter and income of $32,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: THERE'S NOTHING ANACHRONISTIC ABOUTHONESTY
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVOY HAD KEY SAIGON ROLE
description: Ellsworth Bunker, a high-ranking United States diplomat for three decades, died last night at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital in Vermont. He was 90 years old and lived in Dummerston, Vt.

title: KLEINERTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Including tax credits of $341,000 for the quarter and $829,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $206,000 for the quarter and $256,000 for the 9

title: Atlanta Zoo Cancels Benefit After Getting Feeble Support
description: Directors of the Atlanta Zoological Society have canceled a benefit for the troubled Atlanta Zoo because only 55 of 6,000 prominent Atlantans invited agreed to attend.

title: COAL PACT WINS MINERS' SUPPORT BY A BIG MARGIN
description: The United Mine Workers tonight announced that coal miners across Appalachia and the Middle West had voted overwhelmingly in favor of ratifying a new contract,

title: Equimark Capital Plan
description: An investor group led by the chairman of the Equimark Corporation yesterday offered to invest $25 million in the Pittsburgh bank holding company as part of a $50 million capital infusion plan.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE AT CITY CENTER
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem performed Glen Tetley's ''Voluntaries'' for the first time Wednesday night at the City Center and danced with a passion that suggested the ballet might have been created for its own dancers. Actually, it was choreographed for the Stuttgart Ballet a decade ago.

title: THE REGION ; ;  An End Is Seen To 'Brain Drain'
description: The state's labor force and population have grown since the mid-1970's, apparently indicating an end to the ''brain drain'' of New York's highly skilled workers, several experts said yesterday.

title: 2 WORKERS HURT AS FLOOR FALLS IN AT BUILDING SITE
description: Two workers renovating a building on the Lower East Side were seriously injured yesterday morning when the floor gave way beneath them and they fell eight feet to the basement below.

title: A Frightening Rate Scenario
description: In these final weeks before the November election, the Reagan Administration is striving to

title: Ailing Wright Air
description: Wright Air Lines Inc. said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law. It said it would continue scheduled flight operations. The company, which reported substantial losses as a result of unanticipated expenses incurred by its recent merger with Aeromech, a West Virginia-based regional carrier, said the action was necessary because of the refusal of a key creditor to approve a program to restructure its overall debt.

title: METS FACE DECISION ON STAUB
description: Rusty Staub is guardedly optimistic. Frank Cashen, the general manager, is guarded. Dave Johnson, the manager, is optimistic. The rest of the Mets, to a man, are insistent: Staub must be brought back to pinch- hit next year at the age of 41 if the Mets are to win.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SECOND MARRIAGE. By Frederick Barthelme. 217 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95. WHEN I read ''Moon Deluxe,'' Frederick Barthelme's recent collection of stories, I found it hard to accept the desolation of te lives he described. It seemed to me that he was exaggerating for effect, making things out to be worse than they are, which is a habit common to writers. But some people disagreed with me. ''You've never lived in California,'' they said.

title: HIGH-FLYING CHARGERS STAYING CLOSER TO GROUND
description: For the last six seasons, the San Diego Chargers have been the best passing team in the National Football League. And why not, with Dan Fouts throwing to all those marvelous receivers, such as John Jefferson, Charlie Joiner, Kellen Winslow and Wes Chandler?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Snow White and the IRT

title: Diplomat Shot in Uganda
description: Gunmen shot and wounded a Soviet diplomat in the arms and ribs while he was in his car outside his house in a suburb of Kampala last Friday, diplomatic sources said today.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ray Fontenot tries to bring his record up to a season-ending .500, at 9-9. But he's facing Dan Petry, an 18-game winner for the American League's Eastern Division champions. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.)

title: NICARAGUAN APPEALS TO U.S. ON PACT
description: The Nicaraguan leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, called on the United States today to accept the draft peace treaty proposed by the four-nation Contadora group this month.

title: ARCO NAMES OFFICIALS IN DOMESTIC REALIGNING
description: Reflecting the growing importance of its holdings in Alaska, the Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it was realigning its domestic oil and gas operations into two groups, and it named executives to head them.

title: AUTO ACCORD: G.M. SIGNALS
description: An underlying theme of the tentative agreement between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation, a number of authorities say, is that the United States auto industry must shrink its labor force to become competitive with foreign manufacturers. Another theme, some experts say, is that both sides wish to expand the worker-participation program that G.M., like some companies in other industries, has established.

title: Control Data Denies Rumors
description: The Control Data Corporation said there was no truth to takeover rumors that pushed its stock up $1.875, to $30.25, in active trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: SEARCH though you may, you will find no Fort Neal, La., on any roster of United States military installations.

title: MEDIFLEX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NETS BIDDING FOR CENTER
description: In an effort to add depth to their front line, the Nets yesterday acquired the rights to George Johnson from the Atlanta Hawks for future considerations.

title: U.S. GENERAL ASKS GERMANS TO PUNISH PROTESTERS
description: The United States Army urged West Germany today to move strongly against ''anarchists and criminals'' trying to disrupt NATO fall manuevers.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'DIFFERENCES,' STARRING RYAN O'NEAL
description: A COY little girl's plan to ''divorce'' her parents is the pretext for ''Irreconcilable Differences,'' which opens today at Movieland and other theaters, though the film itself is mostly about the adults and the process by which they go show-biz. The Brodskys - Albert Brodsky (Ryan O'Neal) and Lucy Van Patten Brodsky (Shelley Long) - are seen in flashback as down-to-earth young idealists when they first meet. But that doesn't last, especially after Albert, a film buff, gets a chance to direct a movie of his own. Soon he is a rich, famous Hollywood director.

title: Wells Fargo Considers a Sale
description: Wells Fargo & Company said that it was considering the sale of the residential mortgage operations of its Wells Fargo Mortgage Company subsidiary.

title: 'THE WILD LIFE' OPENS
description: ''THE WILD LIFE,'' which opens today at the Eastside Cinema and other theaters, is something like a sequel to ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High.'' The characters are different, but the perspective on teen-age Americana, West Coast-style, is very much the same.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MICHIGAN SCHOOL CROWD RALLIES FOR BUSH
description: A raucous crowd of about 3,000 people, most of them students, jammed a Michigan high school gymnasium today to give Vice President Bush one of his most organized and vibrant receptions of the past two weeks.

title: Kaufman & Broad Shares Bought
description: J.B. Haralson, a Houston investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased 1 million common shares of Kaufman & Broad Inc., or 8.3 percent of the shares outstanding, for $15.9 milllion.

title: CITY PASTIME: TREASURE HUNT FOR REFUNDS
description: For some determined consumers the hunt for empty bottles and cans to return for refunds knows no season. They can be found roaming the city on most days, though some are pickier than others.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: 76ers Sign Wood
description: Leon Wood, the Philadelphia 76ers' rookie holdout who had sued in an effort to overturn the National Basketball Association's team salary caps, signed a multiyear contract with the 76ers and immediately reported to training camp. No terms were disclosed, but Harold Katz, the team owner, said that neither the Sixers' salary cap nor Wood's suit had been an issue in the negotiations.

title: WRESTLING'S WORLD OF THRILLS, CHILLS AND PRATFALLS
description: Hulkamania sweeps across the land. In blase Manhattan, where the likes of Jackie O. and Mr. T have been observed walking the streets unhindered, Hulk Hogan cannot go 10 feet.

title: ATV SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MET SAID TO DECIDE ON BRUCE CRAWFORD AS GENERAL MANAGER
description: Bruce Crawford, who was elected president of the Metropolitan Opera in May, will give up that title and become the company's general manager, according to high-ranking Met officials.

title: ANIMAL TESTS THAT ARE NOT YET NEEDLESS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 2 SERIES, 'PARTNERS IN CRIME' AND 'COVER UP'
description: Among the new series on the Saturday night schedule are NBC's ''Partners in Crime'' at 9 o'clock and CBS's ''Cover Up'' at 10. Both were given their debuts last week but, for doubtless cogent reasons, the tapes were not made available for previews. What follows are impressions gleaned while watching the on-air broadcasts of the premieres.

title: Indian Music Series
description: The Alternative Museum will continue its series of music from North India tomorrow at 8 P.M. with a vocal program by Pandit Jasraj and Zakir Hussain.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 23

Morgan in Teamster Bid Morgan Stanley & Company has formally requested that it be allowed to manage stocks for the $5 billion Central States Pension Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, while also acting as the fund's adviser. Morgan replaced the Equitable Life Assurance Society as the fund's outside adviser earlier this year.
description: In a letter to the Labor Department this week, Morgan Stanley said it now wants to take charge of the fund's stocks from seven outside managers in order to increase efficiency, and lower commissions and management fees by more than $4.3 million a year.

title: New School Head Named By Chicago Board
description: The Chicago Board of Education, after more than two months of legal maneuvering, voted unanimously today to appoint Manford Byrd Jr. to replace Ruth B. Love as superintendent of the nation's third-largest school system.

title: THRIFT UNIT REPLACING AUDITORS
description: The Financial Corporation of America, apparently trying to severe ties with its troubled past, said yesterday that it was replacing Arthur Andersen & Company as its auditor.

title: RECOVERING UNCLAIMED PROPERTY
description: ''DEAR Beneficiary,'' the letter reads, ''we have conclusively established that you are rightfully entitled to a sum of money you may never have seen or known about. Your name appears on the comptroller's list of abandoned property. The state owes you money.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Security Pacific Loss Reserve
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest bank holding company, today said it would increase its loan-loss reserves by 27 percent, to about $500 million, because of ''continuing uncertainty'' about the ability of Latin American countries to pay their debts.

title: YANKS FALL IN 12
description: Dave Winfield edged ahead of Don Mattingly in the American League batting lead last night and early this morning, but the 4 hours and 3 minutes of tedium at Yankee Stadium was highlighted by what Sparky Anderson had always figured was inevitable finally happening.

title: Elizabeth Nichols Wed To Mark Steven Welch
description: Elizabeth Bradford Nichols, the daughter of Mrs. Philip Owen of Littlehampton, Sussex, England, and Lewis Nichols of Vershire, Vt., was married yesterday to Mark Steven Welch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Welch, also of Littlehampton. The ceremony was performed at the Worthing, Sussex, Registry Office by the Registrar.

title: Genrad Outlook
description: Genrad Inc. said it expects its third-quarter earnings per share to be significantly below the 26 cents a share it earned in the same quarter of 1983.

title: PAIR OF DOCUMENTARIES ARE SCREENED
description: Deceptive is the word for documentaries. At their best, they can give the impression of being artless, effortless visual recordings that almost accidentally illuminate their subject. In truth, they are - or should be - full of deliberate, sophisticated choices by which the film maker defines his material.

title: NAMES CAN BE HANDICAPS
description: A recent advertisement for a British horse-breeding

title: BECKER MILK CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE JOB, NOT GENDER, IS FOCUS IN OFFICER'S DEATH
description: Since Transit Police Officer Irma Lozada was shot to death in a vacant lot in Brooklyn last Friday, police officers have been questioning her death, searching for a message, a lesson, a warning.

title: REHNQUIST'S ILL-CONCEIVED PLAN TO CURB APPEALS
description: To the Editor:

title: A WHALING MORATORIUM OPPOSED BY I.W.C.'S OWN SCIENTISTS

description: DO NOT BITE!!!!!

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Justice White Declines to Free Couple in Jail for Contempt
description: A Supreme Court Justice today refused to free a Houston couple who were jailed Sept. 12 for not testifying before a grand jury investigating charges that their son killed a postal carrier.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Debut for Violinist
description: Mischa Lefkowitz, the violinist who won the 1983 International American Music Competition, will make his New York recital debut at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow at 8 P.M. His program will include music of Copland, Bartok, Brahms, Rochberg and Sarasate. Tickets are $8 (students and the elderly half price; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Reservations can be made by calling the Merkin Hall box office (362-8719) or Chargit (944-9300).

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $170,991 for the quarter and year. c-After a loss of $853,297 from discontinued operations.

title: Holland at Sweet Basil
description: The Dave Holland Quintet, led by the bassist and composer, is performing tonight and tomorrow night at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street. Steve Coleman is on alto saxophone, Kenny Wheeler on trumpet, Julian Priester on trombone and Marvin (Smitty) Smith on drums. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is an $8 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Baby-Sitter, 13, Charged With Murdering Infant
description: A 13-year-old girl was held without bond today on a charge of murdering an infant for whom she was baby-sitting, and the authorities said she could face the death penalty if convicted.

title: Senate Panel Is Asked to See If U.S. Reports Were Tailored
description: The Senate minority leader, Robert C. Byrd, asked the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today to investigate whether the Reagan Administration had tried to tailor intelligence reports to support policy.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
description: b-Includes a reduction of the tax provision of $425,000 for income taxes applicable to the company's Domestic International Sales Corp. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $424,000. The year-earlier results include income from the sale of land of $4,762,000.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIAL QUESTIONS VOTER REGISTRATION PLANS IN 3 STATES
description: A Federal official has ordered three Democratic Governors to explain by Monday whether they are violating Federal rules by using state agencies to encourage voter registration.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1984

title: Smith Announces Drive Against Election Fraud
description: Attorney General William French Smith on Thursday announced a training program, an educational campaign and other steps to detect voting fraud in the November elections.

title: ATTIA RASAMNY
description: Attia Rasamny, president of the Islamic Cultural Society in the metropolitan area from 1976 to 1978 and president of the Arab-American Women's Friendship Society here from 1979 to 1980, died of cancer Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 65 years old and lived in Redding, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: Jays Rehire Cox
description: Bobby Cox, who brought the Toronto Blue Jays from the cellar to second place in three years, will have a chance to continue the climb.

title: PATENTS;
description: Method of Sorting Linens for Hospitals

title: GROUP SEEKS GLOBAL SCIENTIFIC PROJECT
description: Scientists from around the world took the first step today toward what may be one of the biggest cooperative scientific efforts ever.

title: JOHN W. STROH, 91, EX-HEAD OF THE FAMILY BEER COMPANY
description: John W. Stroh, chairman emeritus of the Stroh Brewery Company, the nation's third-largest beer maker and the brewer of Detroit's working-class favorite, died today at Bon Secours Hospital in Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 91 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: MAGNA CUM ENNUI
description: News Item: H. Ross Perot of Dallas has paid $1.5 million to buy one of 17 known copies of Magna Carta from its English owner. The document, a 1297 copy of the original signed by King John at Runnymede in 1215, contains 2,500 Latin words written on animal skin with vegetable dye.

title: ; EXECUTION VOTED FOR MURDERER, 19
description: A Superior Court jury that Thursday convicted a Neptune man of the murder of an Asbury Park woman decided today that he should die for the slaying.

title: Polish Bishops Seek Action on 1980 Accords
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops today urged the Communist authorities to follow up the amnesty for political prisoners by carrying out the 1980 agreements that allowed for creation of Solidarity.

title: Nets' Dawkins Is Optimistic
description: Darryl Dawkins descended from Lovetron and predicted more good things for the Nets, who opened their National Basketball Association training camp today.

title: NASA Contract
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced that it was teaming with Honeywell Inc., the International Business Machines Corporation and the RCA Corporation to compete for a major segment of a NASA contract for the definition and preliminary design of the manned space station.

title: Petro-Lewis Posts a Loss The Petro-Lewis Corporation, citing several major
description: write-offs, yesterday reported a

title: 2 Killed in Blast Cleanup
description: Two workers cleaning up after a refinery explosion were killed and a third was injured Thursday when they were buried by debris at the Union Oil Company, where 17 workers were killed in the blast July 23. The victims, Kenny Pointer, 33 years old, and Gerald A. Klimczyk, 26, were removing catalytic material from a tank when the material collapsed on them.

title: MCENROE AND CONNORS PUT U.S. UP, 2-0
description: John McEnroe labored against Pat Cash today, and then Jimmy Connors stormed by John Fitzgerald, and their straight-set victories gave the United States a sturdy 2-0 lead over Australia in the semifinal round of Davis Cup play.

title: Holders Approve BancOhio Merger CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) - The merger of the BancOhio Corporation into the National City Corporation was approved today by shareholders at separate meetings, creating the largest bank holding company in Ohio, with assets of $12 billion.
description: Shareholders of BancOhio, based in Columbus, will receive either $37 in cash or a package of 0.50 share of National City common stock and 0.55 share of a new National City convertible preferred stock. National City is based in Cleveland. The total value of the deal is about $300 million.

title: Andujar Wins 20th Game CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) - Joaquin Andujar became the first -
description: three-run 10th inning gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-1 victory over the

title: U.S. DELEGATE SAYS SHE ISN'T OPTIMISTIC ON UNESCO DISPUTE
description: The American delegate to Unesco warned today that she was not optimistic that the United States would remain in the organization after this year, but she vowed to keep working for changes in the world body that would allow continued membership.

title: Japan Payments Deficit
description: Japan's unadjusted balance of payments deficit rose to a near record $3.44 billion in August, ballooning almost thirteen- fold over a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The record for a monthly deficit was $3.58 billion in April 1980.

title: Not Guilty Plea Made By Mayor of San Diego
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, the financier J. David Dominelli and two other people pleaded not guilty today to charges that they conspired to funnel funds illegally into Mr. Hedgecock's 1983 election campaign.

title: S I HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Net loss

title: DODGING AT THE GREEN
description: A few days ago, I was riding up

title: Dr. Linda Keller Brown Dies; Expert on Education Abroad
description: Dr. Linda Keller Brown, a specialist in developing American studies abroad and an adviser to the American Council on Education, died of cancer Sept. 20 at her home in Washington. She was 40 years old.

title: PICTURE OF COMET TAKEN BY AMATEUR
description: Tsutomu Seki of Japan, a veteran comet-hunter, appeared to be the first amateur astronomer to have photographed Halley's comet as it races through the solar system toward the sun.

title: Marist Coach Out
description: Mike Perry, head basketball coach at Marist College, has resigned amid charges of violations regarding ''extra benefits'' and ''unethical conduct,'' according to the Poughkeepsie school's president, Dennis J. Murray.

title: Hard to Figure
description: To a lot of fans in New York, George Bamberger must be a hard man to figure.

title: Rangers Defeat Devils
description: The Rangers rallied from a two- goal deficit and defeated the Devils, 3-2, tonight in a National Hockey League preseason game before 10,220 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Transactions
description: Announced that the club does not plan to offer 1985 contracts to Al Bumbry and Benny Ayala, outfielders; Ken Singleton, designated hitter, and Tom Underwood, pitcher, all of whom may become free agents. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Manager Bobby Cox to one-year contract; retained Al Widmar, pitching coach; Billy Smith, first-base coach; Jimmy Williams, third- base coach; John Sullivan, bullpen coach, and Cito Gaston, batting instructor. BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Signed Jawann Oldham, center, to two-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Signed Leon Wood, guard, to a multiyear contract. PORTLAND (NBA) - Agreed to a two- year contract extension with Kenny Carr, forward; agreed to give the Los Angeles Lakers a third-round draft choice next year if the guard Eddie Jordan, a Laker last season, is still with Portland, with whom he is trying out, on Dec. 15. UTAH (NBA) - Signed one-year-contracts with Billy Paultz, Kenny Natt and Jay Triano, free agents, and John Stockton of Gonzaga, Marcus Gaither of Fairleigh- Dickinson, Dave Pope of Norfork State and Jim Rowinski of Purdue, rookies. WASHINGTON (NBA) - Signed Tom Piotrowski, free agent center. FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Placed Mitch Krenk, tight end, on injured reserve; activated Pat Dunsmore, tight end. MIAMI (AFC) - Activated A.J. Duhe, linebacker; Steve Clark, offensive lineman, and Fulton Walker, defensive back and kick returner. All had been injured. ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Placed Cedric Mack, wide receiver-cornerback, on injured reserve; activated Bill Whitaker, linebacker, and Quentin Walker, wide receiver. SEATTLE (AFC) - Activated Randall Morris, running back; placed Paul Johns, wide receiver, on injured reserve.

title: HORSERADISH: AN ORNERY ROOT
description: William J. Keller, a ruddy, muscular man who grows 50 acres of horseradish near this farm town a dozen miles east of St. Louis, asks himself why he continues to grow this problematic root.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 1
FROZEN PUFF PASTRY WORTHY OF CAREME
description: My napoleons used to list. My vol- au-vent looked like cornucopias. Literally thousands of layers of puff pastry passed through my kitchen before I became proficent enough, and patient enough, to make the napoleons and vol-au-vent stand up straight.

title: CHAD SEES NO LIBYAN PULLOUT
description: Libyan troops have not begun withdrawing from Chad, as called for in an agreement with France, Chad's Information Minister says.

title: COMMISSIONER CRITICIZES OFFICIALS FOR DISMISSAL OF A WHISTLE BLOWER
description: The City Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that he would punish a Buildings Department official and recommended action against two other employees for their roles in the improper dismissal of a boiler inspector.

title: HOLLYWOOD, IN TUMULT, BOOMS
description: For all the recent turmoil at the top, some of Hollywood's studios are flourishing at the box office.

title: HONDURAS BARS TRAINING OF SALVADORANS AT BASE
description: Honduras has suspended the training of Salvadoran troops by United States military instructors at a key base in Honduran territory, a high-level Honduran official said today.

title: ; Yale Student Rally Supports Strikers
description: Several hundred Yale University students rallied today in support of striking clerical and technical workers.

title: BOND PRICES MOSTLY LOWER
description: Bond prices fell as much as a point yesterday, largely as a result of speculative selling by traders who sought to lock in profits earned when prices moved higher earlier in the week, analysts said.

title: Hills Brothers
description: Hills Brothers Coffee Inc. has announced that it purchased the name and manufacturing facilities of the Chase & Sanborn Coffee Company.

title: POLE ASKS CUT IN TENSION
description: Poland's Foreign Minister called today for an improvement in Soviet-American relations, warning that ''the policy of confrontation can only lead to a catastrophe.''

title: Vector Graphics
description: Vector Graphics Inc. said it is seeking a possible merger or acquisition to help reorganize operations and improve product offerings. The company said that because of continuing losses and liquidity problems, its auditors had issued a qualified opinion on financial statements for the year ended June 30. Vector today reported a fiscal year 1984 loss of $7.63 million, compared with a 1983 loss of $2.96 million.

title: Bridge:M
description: One of the oldest New York tournaments, the Metropolitan, has been in the doldrums in recent years, partly from lack of a suitable home. It has been revived by the Greater New York Bridge Association at a new location, the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street, where play begins today with the following schedule: Today - Newcomers pairs, 1 P.M.; flighted pairs 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; newcomers pairs, 7 P.M. Tomorrow - Newcomers pairs, 12:30 P.M.; Swiss teams, 12:30 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.; newcomers Swiss teams, 6:30 P.M. In the heat of battle not only the newcomers but also many of the experts would fail to spot the play required for success on the diagramed deal, which was reported in an Ontario magazine, The Kibitzer.

title: CARTER RECEIVES APOLOGETIC CALL FROM PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan telephoned former President Jimmy Carter this morning to say he had not intended to suggest that Mr. Carter's Administration was responsible for the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Lebanon, the White House announced today.

title: EUROPEANS BEGIN TALKS WITH LATINS
description: European and Latin American officials called today for political and economic measures to bring peace to Central America as the first formal meeting between West European and Central American nations began here.

title: Rabies Victim, 12, Is Dead
description: A 12-year-old boy suffering from the first known human case of rabies in Pennsylvania in 32 years died Thursday. The boy, Ernest C. Cochran Jr., of Williamsport, who had been in the intensive care unit at Geisinger Medical Center, died of respiratory failure at 8:20 A.M., said Marsha Gori, a hospital spokesman.

title: SPELLMAN BOOK DELETES HOMOSEXUAL ASSERTIONS
description: A biography of Francis Cardinal Spellman, which in its early stages had asserted that the late Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York was a homosexual whose sex life ''was a source of profound embarrassment and shame to many priests,'' will be published Oct. 31 without that assertion. Four pages of similar assertions, which were in the bound galleys that had been distributed to reviewers last July, also will not appear in the book.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL TO INVESTIGATE ACTIONS OF CASEWORKER IF CHILD DIES
description: The city's Human Resources Administration has established an independent committee to investigate social workers when children they are responsible for are killed or seriously injured, officials said yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS IN TIGHT CONTESTS KEEP DISTANCE FROM TICKET
description: As the cold cuts were being prepared for an informal political supper, Representative Bob Edgar made a strong pitch to 50 people in a living room for help in his campaign and that of Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, a fellow Democrat.

title: Red Sox Looking
description: Lou Gorman, the vice president of baseball operations for the Boston Red Sox, said yesterday that Earl Weaver ''would have to be considered a candidate'' for the vacancy created when Manager Ralph Houk announced this week that he would not return to Boston next season.

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $166,359 for the quarter and $2,657,716 for the year. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $6,549,320 for the quarter and $8,194,394 for the year.

title: RENAULT OFFICER NAMED A.M.C. CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The American Motors Corporation announced today that Jose J. Dedeurwaerder, a former executive of its principal shareholder, Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, had been named chief executive officer, succeeding W. Paul Tippett.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX UP BY 0.5%
description: ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

title: Trade Deficit Narrows As Oil Imports Decline WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) - The nation's foreign trade deficit for August totaled $9.9 billion, down 30 percent from the record $14.1 billion imbalance set in the previous month, the Government reported today. The improvement was partly the result of a reduced demand for oil.
description: The total deficit for the year, however - $83.7 billion - has already topped the record imbalance of $69.4 billion registered last year. Government and private analysts have predicted that the red ink would reach $130 billion this year.

title: Landmark Case Figure Is Convicted of Abuse
description: A man whose murder conviction was overturned 20 years ago by a landmark Supreme Court decision was found guilty today of sexually abusing his second wife's daughter.

title: Books of The Times; Arms and Reagan
description: DEADLY GAMBITS. By Strobe Talbott.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At the end of an intense discussion like this, it's not the sort of thing where you agree, 'All right, we'll do x, y and z.' '' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (1:6.)

title: NEW CONTRACT FOR COAL MINERS SIGNED AMID AN AURA OF OPTIMISM
description: In the office once occupied by the coal union's hero, John L. Lewis, the leaders of the United Mine Workers and the coal operators signed a new contract today and spoke optimistically of the return of discipline and stability to an industry long accustomed to labor militance and economic upheaval.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $503,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $678,000 for the quarter and $1,569,000 for the year. d-After income from discontinued operations of $19r,000 and a loss of $535,000 from equity in extraordinary item of affiliate. The 1983 figures were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Zellerbach Cuts
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said it will close permanently its Los Angeles paper mill and converting operations before the end of the year. The mill. which produces about 7 percent of the company's tissue and sanitary paper production, has been unprofitable for nearly three years, the company said. About 240 employees will be affected by the closing, the company said.

title: 4 Indicted in Hazing Deat
description: A grand jury indicted four Texas A&M University students today on misdemeanor criminal charges in the death of a Corps of Cadets member who died after being rousted from bed and forced to perform ''motivational exercises.''

title: TIDE OF FOREIGN WORKERS IS FLOWING OUT OF LIBYA
description: Abdu el-Daim Mohammed Mahmoud, a 72-year-old Egyptian, is a bellhop. For 10 years, he has supported his family back in Cairo by sweeping floors, carrying suitcases, emptying ashtrays and sharing a small, dank room with three other workers at the delapidated hotel in Tripoli that employs him.

title: Capital Event for Queens
description: Five figures in the cartoon on the invitation grin and hold a banner: ''National Friends of Queens County.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Around the Nation column Sept. 20 about the appointment of William Randolph Hearst 3d as publisher of The San Francisco Examiner incorrectly described the status of Outside magazine, which he helped establish. It is still being published.

title: The Market
description: John T. Dolan, chairman of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, has raised millions to help elect conservative Republicans and defeat liberal Democrats. The 33-year-old Mr. Dolan, who likes to be called Terry, plans to leave the organization after the November election and, to some extent, he will begin raising money for himself.

title: Steel Imports Up Over 1983 WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) - United States steel imports decreased 5.3 percent, to 2,516,000 short tons, in August from 2,657,000 tons in July, but were up from 1,617,000 tons in August 1983, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today in citing Commerce Department figures.
description: It said steel imports from January through August were 17,629,000 tons, up 72.3 percent from 10,228,000 tons in the comparable period last year.

title: A Fixture Retires
description: Three days before the Empire State

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: AFRICAN ADORNMENT The new exhibition at the African- American Institute's main floor galleries, 833 First Avenue, at 47th Street, opposite the United Nations (949-5666), offers an eyeful of handsome adornments - 150 headdresses, costumes and other items made by more than 50 African ethnic groups. It is an unusual show that seeks to bring out the beauty, not the anthropology, of the objects.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The results for the latest year had a $78.8 million writeoff of unusual or nonrecurring items.

title: Cabby Gets a Timely Tip
description: ''That's some big pumpkin - go

title: Comsat-Mitsubishi
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan are joining to offer small, high-frequency satellite reception equipment to United States customers, the companies announced today. Washington-based Comsat said the new ''teaming agreement'' had been prompted by the desire of both companies to bid on what is expected to be a $1.2 billion contract over the next 10 years at the Federal Express Corporation for satellite reception dishes.

title: Iacocca Urges Focus On Economic Issues
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, has criticized the two major Presidential candidates as failing to address important economic issues in the campaign.

title: Jackson Says ReaganHas 'Character Deficit'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, attempting to build support for key civil rights legislation, attacked what he called President Reagan's ''character deficit'' today, warning that the ''hoofbeat'' psychology of defeat must not prevail in the November elections.

title: SOVIET DECISION-MAKING: SYMPTOM OF A PARALYSIS
description: To the Editor:

title: PATENTS;
description: Apparatus for Handling Kidneys for Storage

title: BUSINESS OF JAZZ IS CONSIDERED
description: Attache cases outnumbered instruments 10 to 1 as the Jazz Times Convention sounded its first notes yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. ''This is the only meeting anywhere of the national and international jazz community,'' said Ira Sabin, publisher of the magazine Jazz Times and the convention's organizer. ''What we're trying to do is to bring together everyone who makes a living in the jazz industry.''

title: Bomb Kills 3 Guards In a Basque Town
description: Three civil guards were killed in a bomb attack today as protest against France's extradition of Basque separatists to Spain continued.

title: TIME CHANGES PENN STATE AND TEXAS
description: The only time Penn State and Texas have met in football was in the Cotton Bowl, Jan. 1, 1972, when Franco Harris and Lydell Mitchell played their final game as the spectacular running back tandem for the Nittany Lions. In the 30-6 victory over the favored Longhorns, it was the Penn State defense that caught the eye that day by shutting down the mighty Texas wishbone.

title: Columbia's Ghost Is a Smash, Too
description: One day last February a wary ghost, peering through a red circle with a diagonal line through it, appeared for the first time on one of the oversized billboards that light up Hollywood's great white way, Sunset Boulevard.

title: Bordi Left Out On the way to the Cubs' division championship,
description: Rich Bordi, a right- handed reliever, did his part, compiling a record of five victories, two losses and four saves. He may have thought that would assure him a place on the roster of 25 men who will play for the league pennant against the San Diego Padres, but he was wrong. Yesterday, Manager Jim Frey announced that he had decided to limit the roster to nine pitchers and that Bordi would not be one.

title: 'STRANGER THAN PARADISE,' A TRIO ON THE ROAD
description: Jim Jarmusch's ''Stranger Than Paradise'' looks as if it had been left on the windowsill too long. Shot in 16- millimeter black-and-white, and now blown up to 35 millimeter, its images appear to have been aged by the sun and by general neglect until they've faded into a uniform shade of gray. When, occasionally, there's a splotch of comparatively pure black or white, the effect is disorienting until you recognize what Mr. Jarmusch is up to - that is, discovering the ludicrously sublime in the supremely tacky. The film, a prize-winner at this year's Cannes festival, is something quite special.

title: CANADIAN LEADER SEE NO U.S. SHIFT ON ACID RAIN
description: Brian Mulroney, Canada's new Prime Minister, said today that he made no progress this week in persuading President Reagan to move swiftly to curb acid rain.

title: ACCORD BRINGS HOPE FOR CABLE TELEVISION BILL
description: A last- minute compromise on cable television legislation has been worked out by the National League of Cities, the United States Conference of Mayors and the National Cable Television Association.

title: NEW YORK NEEDS THE DEATH PENALTY
description: On Friday evening, Sept. 21, I was having dinner with Kenneth Conboy, New York City's criminal justice coordinator. Around 8 P.M., I Edward I. Koch is Mayor of New York. received a telephone call from the Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward. Ben said: ''Ed, a female Transit Authority police officer has just been found murdered in a wooded lot in Brooklyn. The report we have is that she was chasing a chain snatcher. That is all we know. I am going out there now.'' I left Gracie Mansion with Ken. With the car's lights and sirens going, we got to the scene in Brooklyn in about 15 minutes.

title: Watteaus on Display
description: Two works by the 18th-century French artist Jean-Antoine Watteau, ''The Embarkation for Cythera'' and ''Gersaint's Shop Sign,'' will be on display through Oct. 14 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street.

title: The Freebie
description: More than 60 of the 72 reporters accompanying the Walter F. Mondale campaign into New York City this week were treated to dinner and the theater Wednesday night at the expense of the campaign organization. Robert Neuman, a former Democratic National Committee official who supervised the activity, said the evening out was offered to help the reporters fill their spare time while Mr. Mondale had no public events scheduled because of his meeting with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: To Argentina's Credit, Both Kinds
description: In the space of one week, Argentina has taken two important steps toward healing the damage it inflicted upon itself during the most disastrous decade in its history. The democratic mandate that President Raul Alfonsin won last year came burdened with two legacies: the enduring effects of lawless state terrorism, and near-bankruptcy.

title: CRENSHAW REACHES SEMIFINALS IN GOLF
description: Ben Crenshaw became the only American to advance to the semifinals of the $183,000 Suntory World Match Play Golf Championship today with a 3 and 2 victory over Toru Nakamura of Japan.

title: Bruce Edwin Stewart Weds Lisa C. Gilligan
description: Lisa Catherine Gilligan, a daughter of Thomas Gilligan of Clarks Summit, Pa., and Mrs. Harold T. Hunter of Port Washington, Pa., was married yesterday to Bruce Edwin Stewart, the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Stewart of Port Washington. The Rev. Francis Gallagher performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: ; 12 Guards Deny Beating Inmates
description: Twelve Trenton State Prison guards pleaded not guilty today to charges that they beat 15 inmates or allowed the beatings to occur.

title: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $396,000 for the quarter and a gain of $551,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: 11 BODIES ARE FOUND AFTER MANILA PROTEST DENOUNCING MARCOS
description: Opposition leaders said today that it appeared that as many as 11 participants in an anti- Government demonstration Thursday had been killed after the rally was broken up by the police.

title: Tough Talk About Family Violence Understandable skepticism greeted the Reagan Administration's creation last year of a new Task Force on Family Violence. The panel had no nationally known authorities. It was meagerly funded. And it carried the aegis of an Administration that had discontinued aid to several domestic-violence programs. But now the panel has proved the skeptics wrong. Its new report represents a tough and thoughtful approach to a distressing fact of modern life.
description: American households are the scene of eight million violent incidents every year. Husbands beat wives, parents abuse young children and adults abuse their elderly parents.

title: Passing Yardage Is Still Sky-High
description: For all the early talk that the rushing game might enjoy a resurgence in the National Football League this season, at the expense of passing, a check of current figures suggests nothing of the kind. If anything, N.F.L. teams are passing for more yardage than ever, and, if form holds through the rest of the season, a most striking record will be set: More quarterbacks than ever before will have finished with 4,000 or more passing yards.

title: Afghan Plane Kills 32 In Raid, Pakistan Says
description: Pakistan said today that an Afghan warplane raided a Pakistani border town used by anti-Communist Afghan rebels and killed 32 people.

title: DAVY CROCKETT NEARS 30
description: Nineteen fifty-five was a good year to be four years old. I had much to be thankful for: some things I knew nothing about (it was the year polio vaccine was perfected), some things I could only appreciate in retrospect (the following year would see the end of my leisured existence, as I was dragged off to kindergarten), and one thing I knew a great deal about, the Davy Crockett fad.

title: Hospital Corp. Sets Expansion The Hospital Corporation of
description: America signed an

title: TROPICAL STORM MOVES BACK INLAND AS FORECASTERS WATCH FOR BUILDUP
description: Tropical Storm Isidore, fed by warm waters from both the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean, moved off Florida's west coast today and traveled northeast back across the state, leaving one dead and a trail of beach- eating high tides in its wake.

title: THE POINT OF THE MEETING
description: The throngs of reporters and television crews at the White House today attested to the worldwide interest in President Reagan's meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko. But two audiences were described as uppermost on Mr. Reagan's mind: the Russians and the Americans.

title: Reagan Must Assume Blame, Ford Asserts
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford said today that President Reagan ''has to assume the responsibility for any problems that arise'' in military or diplomatic affairs, including the Sept. 20 bombing at the United States Embassy in Lebanon.

title: AT R.P.I., THE STUDENTS AGAIN HONOR THE TRADITION OF FRENZIED WAITING
description: They came. They sat. They waited.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., a distributor and manufacturer of hospital supplies, said the Food and Drug Administration gave the corporation's optics division approval to market its YAG- 100 laser to treat cataract patients.

title: Longshoremen's Bill Signed
description: President Reagan has signed legislation to restrict coverage, limit benefits and provide safeguards against fraud and abuse in compensation for longshoremen and harbor workers.

title: EXPOS TROUNCE METS, 7-0
description: Dave Johnson let Bobby Valentine run the Mets tonight as a guest manager because Johnson was ''emotionally drained'' in the closing hours of the season. And the Mets promptly showed Valentine why managers get emotionally drained.

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Braves' Watson Retires The Atlanta Braves first baseman
description: Bob Watson says his 19-year big league playing career will come to a close at the end of this season.

title: Sting Moves to Finals
description: The Chicago Sting moved into the final round of the North American Soccer League playoffs by defeating the Vancouver Whitecaps, 4-3, tonight in the third game of the semifinal series.

title: MAN INDICTED IN IRT ASSAULT
description: A 19-year-old man was indicted yesterday on charges of assaulting a New York City transit police officer in the Christopher Street station of the IRT line.

title: Key Rates
description: * split rate, 12.50-12.75** Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TOWN PLANS MERRY WAKE FOR COFFIN-MAKING PAST
description: Motorists taking State Route 9 through this little Alabama town usually slow down and stare when they get to the red light. A seven-foot-long pine coffin, wrapped in cloth and lined in satin, is propped up on the corner.

title: Legal Footrace
description: About 400 lawyers are expected to

title: PATERSON REJECTS RACE FOR MAYOR OPPOSING KOCH
description: Basil A. Paterson said yesterday that he would not be a candidate for Mayor in 1985.

title: ARMY DATA ON GUN CALLED MISLEADING
description: The Pentagon's inspector general said today that Defense Department officials had used oversimplified and misleading test results in deciding to produce the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun.

title: U.S. STEEL SELLS COALS UNITS TO ARCH
description: DANIEL F. CUFF

title: Commune's New Policy Stirs Fears in Oregon
description: Homeless people brought to this city-commune since Sunday by followers of an Indian guru will not get free trips home if they decide to leave, town leaders say.

title: ; 2 Plead Not Guilty In Extortion Case
description: A former Atlantic City official and the nephew of a reputed organized-crime figure pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to extortion charges involving dealings in Atlantic City.

title: GROMYKO RECEIVED BY THE PRESIDENT FOR OVER 3 HOURS
description: President Reagan and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko held what was called a ''forceful and direct'' discussion today of the sharp differences between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Off 2.8% WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) - The prices farmers received for their raw products fell 2.8 percent in September from August, the Agriculture Department said today.
description: Prices were 2.2 percent above the September 1983 level, the department's Crop Reporting Board said. Price declines for potatoes, hogs, beef cattle, oranges, corn and soybeans were partly offset by increases for tobacco, apples, peaches, milk and broilers.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1984 International The President and Andrei Gromyko held what was described as a ''forceful and direct'' discussion of the sharp differences between the United States and the Soviet Union. Secretary of State George P. Shultz will continue the talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister today at the State Department. (Page 1, Column 6.) Human rights gains in Haiti have not lived up to the dramatic improvements promised a year ago by President Jean-Claude Duvalier. Despite widely publicized orders to end arbitrary arrest, torture and other abuses, the editor and publisher of a newspaper was arrested and beaten, two other critics of the Government were placed under house arrest and another went into hiding. (1:2.)

title: INDOOR POLLUTION: U.S. NOTES HEALTH HAZARD
description: For millions of American workers, the health threat from air pollution may come more from within their own offices and homes than from the smokestacks of industry, Government investigators say.

title: TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income includes a nonrecurring gain of $800,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Our Towns column in Metropolitan Report on Thursday misidentified the Mayor of Hoboken, N.J. He is Steve Cappiello.

title: Nofziger Offers Forecast Of Second Reagan Term
description: A second term for President Reagan would be a carbon copy of the first, with no major Cabinet shakeup, says Lyn Nofziger, a Presidential political adviser.

title: American Aide Meets With Gemayel Again
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs held a second round of talks today with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon, Reagan Administration officials here said.

title: False Move Against Rental Housing The rental politics of New York continues to chip away at the housing market, to the detriment of the entire city economy. It may satisfy the populist urges of Mayor Koch and the City Council to withhold a temporary subsidy from the builders of Manhattan rental apartments for the relatively well-to-do, but the only effect will be to chase to the suburbs some residents who could have been well served at no cost to the public.
description: With the Mayor's support, the Council proposes to cancel the 10-year 421-A tax subsidies for all housing in most of Manhattan. The reason is the embarrassing discovery that this program had resulted in a subsidy to multimillion-dollar residences in Trump Tower - a lapse that could have been overcome by eliminating condominiums and co-ops from the program. By also barring aid to rental units, the city is choking off valuable construction that over time repays the subsidy many times.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
AN ODE TO THE POTOMAC...
description: In some ways this city is defined as much by its rivers as its politicians. It is as hard to imagine Washington without politicians as it is to imagine it without the Potomac and the Anacostia wending their serpentine ways through the heart of the capital.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.)

title: CHINA LAGS ON BUYING U.S. GRAIN
description: China appears likely to default for a second year running on its commitment to buy at least six million tons of American grain under a 1980 agreement, according to Western diplomats here.

title: OVERBURDENED MONITORS OF CHILDREN'S SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: JURORS IN BOSTON CLEAR WHITE'S AIDE
description: Theodore V. Anzalone, chief fund-raiser for Kevin H. White when he was Mayor, was found not guilty of extortion today by a Federal jury after three days of deliberation.

title: Shultz Mourns Bunker
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today mourned the death of Ellsworth Bunker, saying he was responsible for ''remarkable achievements that have few parallels in American history.'' Mr. Bunker, who served as a diplomat under seven Presidents and was Ambassador to South Vietnam at the height of United States involvement there, died Thursday night.

title: Accord Reported in Suit Against Miami Police
description: The parents of a 20-year-old black man who was fatally shot by a city policeman, leading to a riot, have reached a tentative settlement in a $6 million civil suit against the city, lawyers said today.

title: T I M E -DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $10,196,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: PATENTS;
description: Pocket-Size Receiver For Stock Quotations

title: SANDINISTA PRIESTS TOLD THEY COULD BE DEFROKED
description: A senior Nicaraguan bishop warned today that if four priests now serving in the Sandinista Government refused to give up their secular posts soon they would be stripped of their right to function as priests and perhaps excommunicated.

title: Sweden Leads, 2-0
description: Henrik Sundstrom scored a five-set upset of Ivan Lendl to give Sweden an unexpected 2-0 lead today over Czechoslovakia in the best-of-five semifinals of the Davis Cup tournament.

title: Orioles Clean House The Baltimore Orioles have already begun paring players from their disappointing 1984 team, announcing yesterday that they did not plan to retain these four familiar names:
description: Ken Singleton, the team's long-established designated hitter; Al Bumbry and Benny Ayala, outfielders, and Tom Underwood, pitcher. General Manager Hank Peters, making clear that the club would be looking for more youth next season, said the Orioles had elected not to renew the option years on the contracts of Ayala, Singleton and Underwood. As for Bumbry, he has an expiring contract, ''and we have decided that we are not prepared at this time to offer him a 1985 contract,'' Peters said.

title: AMID DEBATES, SHOREHAM PLANT SITS IN SILENCE
description: While the fate of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station is vigorously argued in courtrooms, hearing rooms and board rooms, here in the eye of the storm the situation is calm.

title: KNICKS DENY OFFER FOR PAXSON
description: The Knicks' confusion at guard, which began virtually at the moment Ray Williams became a free agent, deepened yesterday with reports - and then immediate denials - that New York was on the verge of tendering an offer sheet to Jim Paxson, the Portland Trail Blazers' high-scoring free-agent backcourt man.

title: Figure in an Adoption Case Is Charged With Molestation
description: A homosexual who won a court battle to adopt a boy was ordered today to stand trial on charges of sexually molesting a young runaway he took into his foster home.

title: Long Recovery Ends for Crable
description: The Jets added some significant muscle yesterday when they activated Bob Crable, the middle linebacker whose long recovery from arthroscopic surgery on his right knee has kept him from playing this season.

title: REAGAN AND O'CONNOR ASSAILED BY PLANNED PARENTHOOD OFFICIAL
description: The head of Planned Parenthood of New York City said yesterday that the ''heated rhetoric'' against abortion by President Reagan and Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York had ''incited'' harassment of women seeking abortions and violence against clinics that offer them.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Sept. 19 with an article about Erich Honecker, the East German leader, was incorrectly dated. The photograph of Mr. Honecker meeting with environmental leaders was taken Sept. 5.

title: Chicago School Aid Frozen
description: A Federal district judge today continued his order freezing up to $80 million in Federal funds earmarked for the Chicago Board of Education. Without the action by Judge Milton Shadur the funds would have returned to the Federal Government on Sunday, the end of the Federal fiscal year.

title: RISING LAKES ARE DROWNING OREGONIANS' DREAMS
description: People tended to look away from the natural disaster as it advanced on the flourishing ranch life around here. Certainly they hid it from strangers.

title: Letter: On Cuomo's Speech
description: Begging the Abortion Question

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS TO DROP CRIME BILL IN SPENDING FIGHT
