description: President Reagan told the Senate Republican leadership today that he would forgo enactment of a crime-fighting package that he wanted in order to obtain a catchall spending measure without any riders.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Pickens, 2 Plans Raise Mesa Stake
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the president and board chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Corporation and two of the company's stock option plans of which Mr. Pickens is the sole trustee, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had raised their stake in Mesa common stock to 4.73 million shares, or 6.9 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: 168,000 Gerber Jars Of Baby Food Recalled
description: Gerber is recalling about 168,000 3.5- ounce jars of its strained chicken and chicken broth baby food after glass fragments turned up in four samples of the product, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Dow Drops 10.05 Points; Economic Report Cited
description: ALEXANDER R. HAMMER

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income. The year-ago results have been restated.

title: Argentina Pays $100 Million Argentina yesterday paid foreign banks $100 million in interest on public sector debt, a committee of banks said. That leaves Argentina's interest paid up through late April.
description: The statement said that as previously arranged, Argentina would repay an additional $100 million to the banks Monday. The funds were advanced as part of the financial package arranged at the end of March for the payment of interest arrears on Argentine public sector debt to foreign banks.

title: POP: BARBARA RANKIN SINGS
description: Barbara Rankin embodies a very traditional image of the supper club chanteuse. With her ripe, sultry soprano, stability of pitch and an appealingly direct delivery well-suited to simple pop ballads, she suggests a composite of several early-1960's nightclub performers.

title:
PATENTS;
HELPING CATS FIGHT A DISEASE
description: AWAY to immunize cats against toxoplasmosis, an animal disease that can be transmitted to man, was patented this week for the Kansas University Endowment Association in Lawrence, Kan. Patent 4,473,548 was granted Dr. Jacob K. Frenkel and Donald D. Smith, researchers for the Kansas University Medical Center.

title: Bananas
description: Yes, we have some bananas, even from Nicaragua. And Representative Douglas Applegate, an Ohio Democrat, says this situation is hypocritical.

title: U.S. Embassy in Peru Sprayed With Gunfire
description: Gunmen dressed like policemen sprayed the United States Embassy in downtown Lima with automatic weapons fire today, shattering windows but causing no injuries, the authorities said.

title: ; MCI Long-Distance Fee Rise
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced today that it would raise its long-distance calling rates by up to 5 percent next month.

title: MissdeRochefort Is Wed to Writer
description: Ghislaine Anne de Rochefort, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean de Rochefort of New York and Chester Depot, Vt., was married yesterday to Nicholas Charles Frederick Shrady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Shrady of Easton, Conn. Archbishop Giovanni Cheli, the Holy See's permanent observer at the United Nations, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan.

title: SOUTH AFRICA HINTS IT'S MEDIATING BETWEEN MOZAMBIQUE AND REBELS
description: South Africa has indicated that it is acting as a mediator between Mozambique's avowedly Marxist Government and the rebellious army seeking to unseat it, which is said to be seeking a cease-fire.

title: Consumers Power
description: A judge today approved a Michigan Public Service Commission staff plan to consider emergency rate relief that would bring financial stability to the Consumers Power Company. Robert Hollenshead, an administrative law judge for the commission, ruled that he would allow consideration of a $205 million annual rate increase to keep Consumers solvent in the wake of the shutdown of the company's Midland nuclear power project.

title: Shamrock Reports Stake in Orion WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) - Shamrock Holdings Inc., the personal holding company of the Disney family, told the Securities and Exchange Commission it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in the common stock of the Orion Capital Corporation for investment purposes.
description: Shamrock said it had paid about $12.8 million for its 557,200 common shares, which were bought in a single block in a third market trade on Sept. 20. The stock of Orion Capital, an insurance holding company, closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $23.50, down 87.5 cents.

title: PATENTS;
description: Carriage-Chair Used For Descending Stairs

title: 7TH CHESS GAME ADJOURNED
description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, and Gary Kasparov adjourned the seventh game in their title match today with Kasparov holding what many chess experts saw as a virtually hopeless position.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 39.

title: ; LANDMARKS PANEL WITH WRONG PRIORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH JUDGE RULES COAL STRIKE ILLEGAL
description: A High Court judge ruled today that a six-month strike by British coal miners was illegal because the miners' union had not held a national ballot of its members.

title: Setback at Seabrook A ruling by the New Hampshire Supreme Court late yesterday appeared to complicate efforts of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire to avoid a default on Sunday.
description: The company is on the brink of default because of legal challenges to its efforts to issue up to $425 million in debentures and warrants to finance the construction of the Seabrook reactor. The company had sought a ruling from the court to allow the sale to go forward despite the possibility of additional challenges, but its petition was denied.

title: ...BEFORE IT NEEDS AND ELEGY
description: For all its beauty and appeal, the Potomac is a river with a serious problem.

title: Eight Plead Not Guilty
description: Eight men have pleaded not guilty to charges of stealing confidential information from the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell and using it to make $1.5 million in stock- trading profits. Among those who pleaded not guilty on Thursday was Alan Robert Ihne, 35 years old, who was manager of office services at Sullivan & Cromwell until he was suspended last Nov. 9. The others are James Stivaletti, Eugene Chiaramonte, Michael Musella, John Musella, Anthony Brunetti, Thomas DiSpigno and Albert DeAngelis.

title: EGYPTIAN PRAISES AN ISRAELI STAND
description: The Foreign Minister of Egypt commended Israel today for promising to withdraw from southern Lebanon. But he said it should also withdraw from the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and the Golan Heights.

title: GERMANS ARREST 188 ON U.S. ARMY BASE
description: The West German police said they arrested 188 people who entered a United States Army training area today in a protest against military maneuvers.

title: Your Money; Appointing A Conservator
description: A CONSERVATOR is appointed by a court to manage the affairs of an adult who has not been declared judicially incompetent, but who is considered unable to manage his or her finances or property. The office has drawn attention recently because the publicized financial activities of John A. Zaccaro, husband of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, focused on his role as a conservator. In addition, last week the top judges of New York State decided to establish formal guidelines for a conservatorship.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN HAITI: A PROMISE UNFULFILLED
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - Over the last year, President Jean-Claude Duvalier has promised some dramatic improvements in human rights.

title: Irish Navy Said to Seize 'Huge' Arms Shipment
description: Two Irish navy cutters intercepted a huge shipment of weapons in a pre- dawn operation off Ireland's west coast early Saturday, a senior government official reported.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC AND ZUKERMAN
description: The New York Philharmonic and its music director, Zubin Mehta, began their new season of subscription concerts yesterday afternoon with an odd but interesting hodgepodge of music. Ulysses Kay's ''Chariots'' made its first trip to New York; Elgar's Violin Concerto, a charming and expansive piece, had one of its infrequent hearings here; and sitting between them on the program was the Schumann Fourth Symphony.

title: THE NEXT TASK IS AT HAND
description: FRESH from producing a $150 million profit for the Summer Olympics by doing the Games his way, Peter Ueberroth becomes the new commissioner of baseball tomorrow. He plans to do that job his way, too.

title: Chicken in Stands
description: After years as sometimes the only worthwhile attraction at Padre home baseball games, The San Diego Chicken will be taking a back seat to the team when the National League Championship series goes to the West Coast next Thursday. Or maybe a front seat.

title: Carder Byrd Mills Weds Miss Bruce
description: Eliza Dancy Bruce, the daughter of Mrs. Jock Leslie-Melville of Nairobi, Kenya, and New York, and Frank Battle Dancy Bruce of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Carder Byrd Mills, the son of Mrs. Samuel Lester Mills and the late Mr. Mills of Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Earl Johnson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Cockeysville, Md., home of Mr. and Mrs. William Boucher 3d, friends of the couple.

title: IN FIGHTING TRIM
description: When Bruce Mays projects ''Can I take him'' onto his fellow men, writing ''That's the language men speak,'' one wonders how he will feel when aging inevitably lengthens the odds. Will he then narrow his dog-pack way to his age and weight class, or become the old codger glaring in truculent impotence, muttering ''I coulda bin a contender''?

title: Julie Meintzer Weds Thomas Gebhard
description: Julie Adams Meintzer, a daughter of Mrs. David Wells Collins of Roxbury, Conn., and the late William Charles Meintzer Jr., was married yesterday to Thomas Eric Gebhard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ten Eyke Gebhard of Barrington, R.I., and Westport Harbor, Mass. The Rev. Bruce M. Shipman performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Roxbury.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. The season finale for the Yankees and an end to the seasonlong batting race betwen Dave Winfield and Don Mattingly.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; NEW HORIZONS IN SOUTH AMERICA
description: Some of travel's most rewarding experiences and biggest challenges lie in South America. It is a continent of extremes: modern cities and exceptionally well-preserved, ancient ruins; gleaming ocean beaches and some of the highest cities in the world; urban sophistication and remote jungles and mountains where the people speak obscure local languages; desperately poor and politically volatile slums in the shadow of ostentatious luxury apartments and mansions.

title: N.R.C. ORDERS CON ED TO STEP UP EMPLOYEE SAFETY AT INDIAN POINT
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's procedures at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant are inadequate to protect workers from radiation, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has charged.

title: Iraq Says It Attacked Iranian Chemical Plant
description: Iraq today attacked a petrochemical complex under construction at Bandar Khomeini in southwest Iran for the second time in eight days, an Iraqi military spokesman and diplomats here said.

title: FAR ROCKAWAY SETS BACK BAYSIDE, 22-6
description: Either the Bayside Commodores or the Far Rockaway Seahorses had to leave yesterday's game in the bruising Brooklyn A division with a blemished record. The host Seahorses, after losing seven players to the hospital last week, went home with the 2-1 record, losing by 22-6.

title: WHEN THE SOUL ENTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ECLECTIC ART OF BALLET HISPANICO
description: ''Fifteen Million Americans Speak Spanish. Their Dance Speaks For Itself'' proclaims a poster of the Ballet Hispanico of New York, the small company headed by Tina Ramirez, which opens a one- week engagement on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM O'NEILL TO STRAVINSKY
description: Hughie Starring Jason Robards. Directed on stage by Jose Quintero; directed for television by Terry Hughes, 1981 RKO Home Video 65 minutes.

He believed that the soul entered the fetus at the moment of quickening, when the fetus began to move inside the mother. He therefore believed that abortion was perfectly licit before that moment arrived. This, of course, would validate nearly all the abortions that are taking place today. There is no better evidence that Catholic theological views are scarcely a monolith, even on the abortion question. MURRAY N. ROTHBARD Las Vegas, Sept. 18, 1984

title: RETICENT ROCK GUITARISTS ARE EDGING INTO THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Andy Summers of the Police, Robert Fripp of King Crimson, and Robert Quine, at present with Lou Reed's band, are three of contemporary rock's most accomplished and influential guitarists. But it takes some digging into their recorded works to find examples of full- fledged guitar solos. Although they are distinctive stylists, their musical attitudes are similar in at least one respect: They play to make their bands sound good, not to boost their own egos. Even their new albums of instrumental music are more concerned with nuances of atmosphere than with pyrotechnic self-expression.

title: A YOUNG DANE WINS NEW HONORS
description: The latest exploit of Curt Hansen, a 19-year-old international master from Denmark, has been to win the world junior championship. He scored 10 1/2-2 1/2 to win the annual tournament for players under 20 years old, held in Kiljava, Finland, this year.

title: CNCERT PREVIEWS BY TOP ARTISTS OFFERED
description: ONE of the reasons that schools or local chamber music societies with modest budgets can afford to present world-renowned artists is that almost every soloist or ensemble needs a couple of tryout performances before arriving at Carnegie or any other major New York City hall. It is the classical equivalent to the shows that play a week in New Haven or Boston before opening on Broadway. In any event, the alert Westchester music lover can take advantage of this, usually at great saving of time and money. You can buy tickets for the Mozartean Players in recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Oct. 4, for example, or hear the same artists perform exactly the same program at a free preview at 8 P.M. Oct. 3 in the Music Building at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR State Should Contribute More to Schools
description: In a vehement attack on our public schools (''Money Is Not the Solution to Problems in Our Schools,'' Sept. 2), Ernest Barra began by describing public education as ''in total disarray'' and concluded ''The answer is dedication. . .''

title: U.S. ECONOMY NEEDS EXPANDED TRADING
description: FOR the American economy, 24-hour stock - and debt-security - trading would result in higher equity values, lower interest rates, a stronger dollar and a continuation of the economic recovery without inflation. In the face of all that, naysaying arguments about the technical impracticality of round-the-clock trading or the sanctity of the specialist- auction system should just fade away.

title: FILM: MEG TILLY IN 'IMPULSE'
description: There's a lot of ''Twilight Zone'' to the premise of ''Impulse,'' a small- town science fiction thriller that opened yesterday at the Criterion. Imagine a Middle Western town in which everyone, without warning, begins acting on his every whim. While the children play vicious practical jokes, old men on Sutcliffe's Main Street play games like kick-the-can; in the bank, people steal money simply because they see it lying around. Everyone, quite without inhibition, says anything that comes to mind.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA STUNS GEORGIA
description: South Carolina upset previously unbeaten Georgia, 17-10, tonight when a reserve quarterback, Mike Hold, completed a 62-yard pass with Ira Hillary to set up his 1-yard sneak for the game-winning touchdown.

title: PRNCETON TEAM WORKING ON LASER DEVICE TO CUT AIRCRAFT COLLISIONS
description: PRINCETON AERONAUTICAL engineers at Princeton University have developed a laser-beam system that is expected to reduce the number of aircraft collisions.

title: SHOREHAM UPDATE: GETTING READY
description: THE Shoreham Nuclear Power Station is 10 weeks and one permit away from beginning low-level operations, according to John D. Leonard Jr., the Long Island Lighting Company's vice president for nuclear operations.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE THINGS THAT GO TOOT! IN THE NIGHT
description: EVERY generation produces its own band of forward- thinking individuals, shakers and shapers whose revolutionary notions transform, for good or ill, the fabric of society.

title: An American Journalist Is Freed by Colombia
description: An American journalist was released from jail here Friday night after a 78-day detention on charges of marijuana possession.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: RESERVIST LOSES SUIT AGAINST U.S. OVER RAPE
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that a former Army reservist cannot sue the Government for damages after her rape by two enlisted men on a military base.

title: VERBATIM: A VIEW FROM BEIRUTVerbatim: A View From Beirut 'In principle, we have denounced the bombing. But the United States naturally has to realize that nothing will protect its embassy if it persists with its current policy, no matter what precautions it will take.' Walid Jumblat,
description: the Druse leader and leftist Lebanese Cabinet Minister, commenting on the terrorist attack on the American Embassy in Beirut.

title: Miss Horner, Scott Fossel Are Married
description: Petria Maitland Horner, a daughter of Mrs. G. Philip Lynch of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Martin McG. Horner of Singer Island, Fla., and Orient, L.I., was married yesterday to Scott George Fossel, a son of Mrs. Leslie T. Fossel of Francestown, N.H., and the late Mr. Fossel.

title: CRASH TEST RESULTS PUBLISHED FOR 38 NEW CARS AND TRUCKS
description: The Transportation Department has released the results of crash tests on 38 new cars and trucks.

title: MEETING OF MUSICAL EXTREMES
description: Despite several years of intimations that such a thing was about to happen, the album titled ''Boulez Conducts Zappa'' (Angel DS- 38170) will still come as a shock to two camps of people. One will be the hardline modernists for whom Pierre Boulez, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic and widely regarded as one of the great composers of this century, represents about as stern and serious a role model as possible. The other will be the drug- addled teen-age Zappa freaks who crowd into Frank Zappa's rock concerts.

title: THE HITLER DIARIES: A FIASCO ON TRIAL
description: The prosecutor's slide show took the darkened courtroom on a vicarious tour of the defendant's handsome duplex apartment in one of Hamburg's most exclusive neighborhoods.

title: KARAJAN LEADS BERLIN PHILHARMONIC AFTER TALKS ON DISPUTE
description: Herbert von Karajan conducted the Berlin Philharmonic's first concert of the season tonight, hours after he and musicians' representatives held preliminary talks aimed at settling a long dispute.

title: 16 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 16 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: JERSEY SEEKS TO SAVE PROPOSAL TO UPGRADE ATLANTIC CITY TRAIN
description: Delays in finding matching state funds to upgrade a rail line linking this city and Philadelphia could jeopardize a Federal grant, but officials said this week that they had a new plan for the project.

title: UNCOMMON VILLAGE GREENS
description: THOMAS A. GAINES, an architectural historian, lives in Hampton, Conn.

title: In Fighting Trim
description: Bruce Mays's article ''In Fighting Trim'' (About Men, Sept. 2) perpetuates the myth of aggressiveness, competitiveness and arrogance. I, too, grew up in the world Mr. Mays speaks about.

title: KEMP TRIES TO FILL THE GAP FOR RAMS
description: The fickle fingers of fate continue to dog the Los Angeles Ram quarterbacks. Pat Haden, who was always too short and often too injured, twice broke fingers, once on a seam in the Astroturf at Seattle. Last season, just as the team was headed for the playoffs, Vince Ferragamo hit someone's shoulder pads and suffered a deep cut between the third and fourth fingers of his passing hand. Two weeks ago, the fifth metacarpal bone in the same hand was fractured when a linebacker crashed into him.

title: HARROD'S BARGAIN HUNTERS
description: Harrods, the elegant London department store, has always been on the ''must see'' list for tourists. But nowadays, Americans are flocking there for a different reason.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPNION;
THE EXODUS TO THE SUNBELT: A VIEW OF ISLANDERS WHO LEFT...
description: FIVE years ago my family moved away from Long Island as part of the modern-day exodus to the Promised Land: the Sunbelt. Their move was accompanied by pronouncements that they simply wished to live 2,500 miles away from the Long Island Expressway, high taxes, skyrocketing utility rates and what they perceived as a generally deteriorating quality of life. They settled in Arizona, which lies smack in the middle of that Sunbelt paradise.

title: Cathy Brown Wed to an Accountant
description: Cathy J. Brown, a daughter of Maj. Gen. Donald D. Brown, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Brown of Scott Air Force Base, Ill., was married yesterday to Alvin K. Peinhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Peinhardt of Hanceville, Ala. Col. William F. Mattimore, a Roman Catholic chaplain, performed the ceremony at the Bolling Air Force Base Chapel in Washington.

title: YOUNG LONG ISLANDERS: THE NEW BREED OF COMMUTER
description: AMONG those rushing toward the gate of Penn Station's Track 17 during the evening rush hour can be found a new breed of commuter - not city emigres who have sought suburban greenery in which to raise children, but young, native Long Islanders who brave the daily trip for the sake of their urban jobs.

title: ELIZABETH DEFEATS PLAINFIELD
description: Robert Nicholas, a second-string senior tailback, ran for 116 yards on 27 carries and scored the winning touchdown on a 1-yard run in the first quarter when Elizabeth upended Plainfield, 6-0, yesterday in Elizabeth.

title: 3 Killed, 1 Hurt as Car Hits Barrier at Toll Plaza on L.I.
description: A young Long Island man and two teen-agers were killed and a 14-year-old girl was injured when their car struck a toll plaza safety barrier on the Wantagh State Parkway, the state police said today.

title: RANGEL MIGHT ACCEPT DRAFT IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Representative Charles Rangel said yesterday that he would consider running for Mayor in 1985 if no other acceptable candidates emerged and his constituents pressed him to enter the race.

title: No Headline
description: Maureen Bannon Is Wed

title: THE TWO GERMANYS (2)
description: One of the strangest aspects of the division of Germany and Europe into Communist East and democratic West is that East Germany - one of the most repressive of the Soviet satellites - is blanketed by West German television.

title: MCENROE CLAN'S MAN IN MIDDLE
description: On one end of the family there is his older brother, John, the tennis champion. On the other end is his younger brother, Patrick, the junior tennis champion. And in the middle is Mark McEnroe, a fairly decent tennis player, but, as he puts it, ''terrible, in my family.''

title: EXETER TAKES ITS 3D STRAIGHT
description: Things are looking up for the Phillips Exeter football team and Ed Frey is happy about that. Yesterday the New Hampshire school won its third straight game of the young season when it downed Choate, 34-21.

title: THE HOUSE OF 12 GABLES
description: The Gable has long held a powerful fascination in American architecture. From ornate 19th-century Gothic revivals to a child's primitive drawing of a house, the strong profile of this simple triangular form has become a classic, even comforting, symbol of home.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE CUT FLOWERS
description: ALL too frequently, it seems, cut flowers do not last as long as one might expect. While this is especially disappointing with flowers purchased from a florist, it is also discouraging when it happens with flowers from one's own garden.

title: BRITAINS'S DO-OR-DIE STRIKE
description: Godfrey Hodgson, who lives in Oxford, England, writes regularly for The Financial Times. His book ''Lloyds of London'' will be published next month. THEY CALL HIM ''MAC THE Knife,'' ''the Butcher,'' ''MacWrecker.'' The angry nicknames seem grotesquely inappropriate for the quiet, small, 72-year-old Scottish-born American who lets himself into an elevator in the basement of Hobart House, a nondescript London office building, a little before 8 every morning.

title: M. C. MacKenty Wed To Elizabeth Doering
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Doering, a daughter of Mrs. Rogers Montgomery Doering of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Doering, to Michael Carson MacKenty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edmund MacKenty of Scarsdale, took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Bernard R. Brunsting performed the ceremony at the Greenville Community Reformed Church in Scarsdale.

title: THREE VIEWS OF SCHUMANN
description: Robert Schumann took the usual process of artistic development and turned it upside down. He did write a scattering of important pieces in the last part of his troubled life, but when we think of his music, it is the immense fertility of the earlier years that come to mind, not the uneven qualities of what came after. Schumann was a composer, in other words, who bloomed early and faded later on.

title: Boggs Beats Challenger In Louisiana Voting
description: Representative Lindy Boggs, running the toughest race of her career in a newly configured district with a black majority, won re-election today to a seventh term in the House.

title: Mitzi Lyn Solomon Is Bride
description: Mitzi Lyn Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Solomon of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Scott Mitrani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Mitrani, also of Plainview.

title: ARCHITECTS SEEK TO HELP HOMELESS
description: Architects from around the country met here this month to try to define a role for their profession in dealing with the problems of housing the homeless.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Neglected Lessons

title:
LONG ISLAND OPNION;
...AND A FEW REFLECTIONS FROM ONE WHO NEVER LEFT
description: THE caravans are moving. They engulf my little white house in puffs of dust as they turn the corner, and the dust makes my eyes moisten. In the beginning I would stand and wave and think about the wagon trains of long ago heading west. Now I prefer to be away as they pass.

title: COMPUTERS MAY MAKE JOBS MORE SATISFYING
description: Contrary to what many fear, the most profitable companies of the computerized future will not have a preponderance of mindless, boring jobs, and they will not substitute computers for people in their dealings with customers, a growing number of experts contend.

title: PROGRAM AIDS TEACHERS
description: MICHAEL CONTE, a teacher at a New Haven public school, has a new approach for teaching mathematics this fall. He is incorporating math problems involving Connecticut's industrial and geologic history.

title: Primary Resident
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Black Bass and the Hudson River
description: -water bass

title: FERRARO SHARPENS CRITICISM OF REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: Conceding that it was a comparison she found odious, Geraldine A. Ferraro said today that the Democratic ticket on which she is running for Vice President was not an extension of the Carter Administration.

title: 'THE HOLY INNOCENTS,' SPANISH PEASANT FAMILY
description: On a feudal farm in northern Spain, stereotypical images of noble, earthy peasants are made unexpectedly touching in Mario Camus's ''Holy Innocents,'' which focuses on the travails of one peasant family. As gatekeepers to the large country estate of a marchioness and her family in the 1960's, these workers are privy to all the aristocracy's cruelty and callousness.

title: U.S. Court Orders New Trial In Case of Toxic Shock Death
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned a ruling that cleared a tampon company in a wrongful death case brought by a man who contends his wife died of toxic shock syndrome.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1984 Andrei Gromyko concluded his talks in Washington with an agreement with the Reagan Administration ''on a process of follow up exchanges between the two sides,'' a senior State Department official said. The Soviet Foreign Minister's final session with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, was ''a constructive useful meeting,'' the official said. (Page 1, Column 4.) A week of anti-NATO protests in West Germany ended with an anti-nuclear arms demonstrations by tens of thousands of people in Fulda, in the region where the North Atlantic Treaty organization held maneuvers. (3:4.)

title: Too Few Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY SAYS SOIL EROSION COULD CAUSE FAMINE
description: Erosion of agricultural topsoil is a ''quiet crisis'' that could lead to famines in some parts of the world, according to a new study by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: JOHNSON RUNS FOR 166 YARDS
description: Herb Johnson ran for 166 yards on 16 carries and scored three touchdowns to lead Snyder of Jersey City to a 41-6 victory over Barringer yesterday in Schools Stadium, Newark.

title: TUITION FEES VARY
description: TUITION fees proposed for next year at the state's public higher-education institutions range from no increase at the Connecticut State University system to a 15 percent increase at the five state technical colleges.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Hospital Thrift Shop Undergoes Expansion The New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center Thrift Shop, opened a year ago in a single room, has just reopened with a September Gift Arcade after expanding into four rooms of the former nursing school residence. Proceeds from the cash-and-carry sale of donated merchandise and good-condition women's and children's clothing go to the League for Service, the auxiliary of the hospital. The volunteers have added Friday to the former Tuesday and Thursday schedule.

title: BOTTI HELPS SACHEM BEAT WARD MELVILLE
description: Michael Botti, the Sachem running back, knows how to make a triumphant return.

title: ATHENEUM TO SHOW OFF NEW GALLERIES TODAY
description: HARTFORD WITH fifes and drums and the Capital Brass Band, with games and favors and a free open house topped by a 2 P.M. ceremony attended by the Governor, the Wadsworth Atheneum is dedicating 20 new American galleries today, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title:
ART ;
PUTTING SCULPTURE IN A GARDEN
description: WILLIAM E. COURDUFF has been designing gardens for 35 years, and his plans have often included sites for works of art among the plantings or adjacent to pools or patios. He finds, however, that few of his clients respond to this suggestion because, as he says, ''sculpture is not readily available, especially sculpture suitable for outdoor use.''

title: WEST GERMANS HOLD A BIG ARMS PROTEST
description: A week of protests designed to disrupt North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuvers ended today with an antin uclear arms demonstration by tens of thousands of people here.

title: 2 PCB STUDIES SHOW NO LINKS TO BIRTH WEIGHT
description: Two studies by the State Health Department have found no evidence that the direct exposure of pregnant women to PCB's results in lower birth weights.

title: 'HEARTSOUNDS' TAKES AN UNBLINKING LOOK AT DOCTORS
description: Doctors and nurses are the very stuff of television uplift. From ''Dr. Kildare'' and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.'' to ''Nurse'' and ''St. Elsewhere,'' the medical profession has furnished scriptwriters with a seemingly endless flow of selfless dedication in the face of awesome life-and-death crises. Even television comedies such as ''M*A*S*H'' or the current ''E/R'' have carefully mixed their laugh tracks with basic respect and admiration.

title: Miss Steiner, a TV Producer, to Wed Dr. Howard Klar, Psychiatrist, in May
description: Robert L. Steiner of Washington and Mrs. Frank M. Fox of Cincinnati and Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Therese Fleischmann Steiner, to Dr. Howard Klar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Klar of Brooklyn. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Race for Greater Auto Profits
description: IN 1980, the automotive industry seemed to be on the road to irreversible ruin. The General Motors Corporation, the largest of the automakers, registered the first loss in its modern history -- a staggering $763 million. G.M., the Ford Motor Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation together sold a respectable 6.6 million cars that year but racked up a loss of nearly $4 billion.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: RING: A Biography of Ring Lardner, by Jonathan Yardley. (Atheneum, $13.95.) Ring Lardner wrote on baseball for Chicago newspapers, had a syndicated column, published short stories - some of them now regarded as classics - in The Saturday Evening Post, wrote radio criticism for The New Yorker and was happily married. But this great American humorist drank to excess and died in 1933 when he was only 48. When ''Ring'' came out in 1977, V. S. Pritchett wrote in The Book Review, ''The clown was a sad man, and Jonathan Yardley shows us why with insight and sympathy.'' His biography ''is welcome,'' Mr. Pritchett added, ''for it tells a good deal about Lardner which had mystified us.'' TWO SERIOUS LADIES, by Jane Bowles. (Dutton, $7.95.) In 1967, John Ashbery commented in these pages that ''Jane Bowles is a writer's writer's writer. Few surface reputations are as glamorous as the underground one she has enjoyed since her novel 'Two Serious Ladies' was published in 1943.'' That story concerned the decline into debauchery of two staid women - a wealthy spinster seeking salvation and a married woman who takes a trip to Panama with her husband. ''Mrs. Bowles's seemingly casual colloquial prose is a constant miracle,'' said Mr. Ashbery.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Policing Nassau's Third Precinct The article ''Assignment: Nassau's Busiest Precinct'' (Aug. 26), contained high praise for Inspector Tracy Smith, and we could not agree more.

title: THE SCANDAL OF THE NOBEL PRIZE
description: EVEN Prince Paris got it wrong. His prize-giving of the golden apple led to his own death and the ruin of Troy. All human awards are fallible. Time and again, immortality goes to the blackballed, to the salon des refuses in which the Impressionist masters exhibited their officially rejected and ridiculed paintings. At the height of his genius, Schoenberg was turned down for a Guggenheim. The gentle soul who refused Einstein academic employment in Switzerland died peacefully not so very long ago.

title: SUPREME COURT IS TO CONSIDER KEY ISSUES OF CHURCH AND STATE IN NEW TERM
description: The Supreme Court opens its new term Monday in the glare of an election-year spotlight and with volatile questions of church and state high on its agenda.

title: DEBATE ENVELOPES CONDOMINIUM PLAN
description: or 202, or 194, or 180 - on the site of an old golf course at the northern tip of New Castle has brought the opposition of hundreds of residents, repeated requests for revisions by the town's Planning Board and outrage from neighboring Mount Kisco.

title: NEW I-95 VENDOR FOR CONNECTICUT
description: The State Department of Transportation has selected McDonald's to replace Howard Johnson's as the operator of all 10 state-leased restaurants along the Connecticut Turnpike, effective Feb. 24.

title: MichaelByronIsWed To Gale A. Folgherait
description: Gale Ann Folgherait, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis S. Folgherait of Weatogue, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Stewart Byron, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald William Byron of Toronto. The Rev. Lyman Potter performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ in Simsbury, Conn.

title: MARQUES JOHNSON TRADED TO CLIPPERS
description: The Milwaukee Bucks traded the veterans Marques Johnson, Junior Bridgeman and Harvey Catchings today to the Los Angeles Clippers for the forward Terry Cummings and the guards Craig Hodges and Rickey Pierce.

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCING: CHANGES CHANGED
description: TRENTON SOME of the proposed changes in the state's public-financing law for gubernatorial elections have run into a roadblock, chiefly because of objections by several potential Democratic candidates for Governor next year.

title: THREE ARMED MEN ROB 14 IN A RESTAURANT ON L.I.
description: Three armed men took $1,500 in cash and more than $1,000 worth of jewelry from employees and patrons of a restaurant in Valley Stream, L.I., at 1 A.M. yesterday, according to Nassau County police officials.

title: OFFICIALS SEE NO LEASING OF STRAIN ON CITY'S JAILS
description: The inmate population of New York City's jails, which hold people awaiting trial and those sentenced to terms of up to a year, has been growing steadily, and officials say they expect the growth to continue indefinitely.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
ON DEFINING THE END OF CHILDHOOD
description: RAISING the national drinking age to 21 is not an isolated political act. It is part of a larger process in which our society is engaged, a process that amounts to a radical redefinition of the nature of youth and a radically new response to the question, When does a youth become an adult?

title: U.S. HOT LINE ON FRAUD SHOWS HANDSOME RETURN
description: A two-star Army general knew a hot investment opportunity when he saw it. Anticipating a housing shortage when his troop strength was increased, he bought an interest in a hotel near the base he commanded.

title: Holly Stachelberg Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bronner Stachelberg of Palm Beach, Fla., and Weekapaug, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Holly Ann Stachelberg, to Michael Harley Montgomery, the son of Andrew Thompson Montgomery of Sausalito, Calif., and Mrs. Adolphus Busch Orthwein of St. Louis. Miss Stachelberg graduated from the Palm Beach Academy, Pine Manor College and Florida Atlantic University. Her fiance, a graduate of the Choate School, attended Ohio Wesleyan University.

title: Donna Marie Morrell Weds Richard Pinney
description: Donna Marie Morrell of New York, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Morrell of East Norwich, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Heil Pinney of Tulsa, Okla., a son of Mrs. James Granville Pinney of Salt Lake City and the late Mr. Pinney. Justice John W. Burke of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite in New York.

title: Mabel Churchill Wed in Vermont
description: Mabel Harlakenden Churchill, a daughter of Creighton Churchill and Camilla Churchill of South Pomfret, Vt., was married yesterday to Charles Richard Niebling, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Frederick Niebling of Exeter, N.H. The Rev. Donald E. Boyer performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CAN A TEACHER CHANGE A LIFE?
description: BEING faced with an impossible task seemed to happen every day when I was assigned to teach reading to special-education classes. Nonreaders and poor readers, in particular, were in abundance. A few students had been started along their way to learning earlier in the year through the use of simple reading books, sentence combining, basic word practice, puzzles and reading-skill builder series that included lessons on comprehension, phonics and word attack skills, along with any other less- known technique I could include.

title: SUNG BY CELEBRATED SOPRANOS
description: Leo Delibes is known today chiefly for his ballet music (''Sylvia,'' ''Coppelia''), but of his 17 operas and operettas only ''Lakme'' is remembered. The title role was composed for a Brooklyn soprano, Marie Van Zandt, who sang the part at the Paris premiere at the Opera-Comique on April 14, 1883.

title: GREATNESS IN DANCING IS NOT EASY TO CATEGORIZE
description: The latest book on male dancers is ''Men Dancing'' by Alexander Bland and John Percival (Macmillan, $35) and it is the fourth on the subject in coffee-table format since 1977. The first in an obvious trend was ''Danseur, the Male in Ballet,'' by Richard Philp and Mary Whitney (Rutledge-Macmillan), followed by Walter Terry's ''Great Male Dancers of the Ballet'' (Doubleday-Anchor) and ''L'Homme et la Danse,'' in French by the Swiss critic, Jean-Pierre Pastori (Office du Livre, Fribourg).

description: The Salvadoran military possesses stocks of napalm incendiary weapons, the United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today.

title: PANEL TO COMBAT SUICIDE BY YOUTHS
description: New York State has formed a Council on Youth Suicide Prevention, Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello announced this week.

title: MarySusen,anEditor, Marries S. A. Kersten
description: Mary Clare Susen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Susen of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen A. Kersten, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerhard Kersten of Walden, N.Y., and Siasconset, Mass. The Rev. Augustine Jones performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Fires Rage in Tanzania
description: A fire blackened 40 square miles of pastureland in Ngorongoro Crater, according to reports reaching here, and the ruling Uhuru Party newspaper said another fire on Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest mountain, had been contained after it destroyed large sections of forest. Both sites are tourist attractions and both are in drought- stricken areas.

title: Miss McDowell Wed To Bruce F. Magown
description: Kathryn Peirce McDowell, a daughter of Dr. Edward Irvine McDowell Jr., and Phyllis Murray McDowell, both of North Haven and Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce Forrest Magown, a son of Mrs. Robert M. Magown of Warwick, R. I., and the late Mr. Magown. The Rev. Allan O'Neil performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in North Haven.

title: A GOAT CHEESE FINDS ITS HOME
description: THE cheese that is turning heads these days is ch evre. Ch evre means goat and the category refers to cheese made from goat's milk.

description: The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, took a 3-0 lead in his title defense match in Moscow yesterday after his countryman, Gary Kasparov, resigned the seventh game.

title: RECORD KICK A NATURAL
description: Kevin Mills didn't know how long it was, but he knew his first-quarter field-goal attempt against Pinelands last Saturday was through the uprights. He didn't find out until halftime that it was a 58-yarder, a New Jersey high school record.

description: Norwich University struck for four first-quarter touchdowns in roaring to a 49-6 victory in the 50th renewal of its rivalry with the Coast Guard Academy.

description: After nearly 16 years as the commissioner of baseball, Bowie Kuhn stepped down last week, relinquished his office to Peter Ueberroth, flew to South Korea to watch postseason baseball in the Orient and said that the thing he would remember most was ''the beauty of the game.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 FIDDLIN' AROUND
description: If you have a talent - especially an unusual one - why not flaunt it? That is what local members of the New York State Old Tyme Fiddlers' Association will do today when they convene at the Museums of Stony Brook for the Island's first Fiddlers' Convention. Starting at 10 A.M. with informal jamming and beginning in earnest at noon, the fiddlers and other musicians, dancers and assorted practitioners of traditional music will go through their paces in front of the barn on the museum grounds.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SCENIC RIDGE residents have had second thoughts about seceding from the village of Croton-on-Hudson and joining the town of Cortlandt. The village did not want them to leave, and the town of Cortlandt has decided not to take them in.

title: A DAY'S CAMPAIGNING
description: ANY seasoned politician knows that Monday mornings are not the best times for campaigning. And when it is a rainy, muggy Monday morning, like the one last week, and it is 6:45 A.M. at a train station where delays are being announced every five minutes - well, it might fluster even the most experienced politician.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
FOR HORST, ARTIFICE WAS EVERYTHING
description: The lives of the fashion photographers seem to point a moral. If you want to rise to the top of your profession, start out in life wanting to be something else - a painter, an architect, a charming dilettante.

NEW NETWORKS OF IMMIGRANT ENTERPRENEURS;
ALL IN THE FAMILY APPROACH
description: ON the surface, there is no pattern to John Lam's mix of businesses. The 32-year-old Mr. Lam, who came here from Hong Kong 15 years ago, is a garment contractor who makes clothes for such quality houses as Leslie Fay, Pierre Cardin and Evan Picone. He is a real estate speculator who owns four Chinatown buildings. He trades in silk. And he is talking about opening a bank.

title: Getting Information On Caesarean Births
description: I am writing to express my good thoughts on the article ''L.I. Caesarean Rate Stirs Debate'' (Aug. 26). Although I am not a mother or planning to be one in the near future, I thought the article was interesting and most informative. I think it's important that more research of this kind be done on hospitals in our area, particularly on emergency room facilities - i.e., average waiting time, level of professional treatment, etc. BARBARA T. STENZEL Northport

title: EUROPEANS BACK CONTADORA DRIVE
description: European foreign ministers meeting here for the first time with their counterparts from Central America, appear to have sidestepped a United States effort to isolate Nicaragua from European political and economic assistance.

title: THE MORGAN HONORS A RENAISSANCE MAN
description: William Morris (1834-96) did so many things in his life, and did them with such an all-pervading energy and enthusiasm, that some of them just had to turn out well. An idealistic socialist, he wanted to bring about a new era of equality and social justice. In this context, no audience was too small for him to travel a long way to address it, nor any task too menial for him to take it on gladly. If there were flyers to hand out, he did it. If there was an opening for a lecture on the new thing in textiles, he would go and give it, even if - as happened in 1884 - it was at the International Health Exhibition and he was in company with lecturers on ''Alcoholic Drinks'' and ''The Physiology of Digestion.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
AFTER A WAR: THE SOFTBALL FIELD HELPS SORT LIFE OUT
description: WHEN one is well beyond middle age and that short uncertain road beckons, one looks back to other times. One such time was 1946.

title: DANCE: 'SWING A DOG'
description: For a few moments, Timothy Buckley had his dancers hold their hands as if they were dogs' paws. But, fortunately, no one was cruel to animals in ''How to Swing a Dog,'' the new two- act work that he presented Thursday night in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. If anything, Mr. Buckley tried to show how kindhearted he was, for in one scene he required the cast to play with toy animals, including a big snake.

title: THIS TIME THE ORANGES MAY NOT BOUNCE BACK SO FAST
description: Oranges are as much associated with Florida as sunshine, palm trees, Mickey Mouse and the mobile home trailer park. Ever since Spanish explorers planted the first orange trees more than 400 years ago, the fruit has been the foremost export industry in an economy that seems to import everything else, and especially tourists and retirees.

title: Cionna Buckley Wed To Jerome Rosenthal
description: Cionna Mary Buckley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Buckley of Beverly, Mass., was married yesterday to Jerome Alfred Rosenthal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Rosenthal of San Francisco. The Rev. John Griffin, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Summons for Torre The Floyd boys and other Atlanta fans may have to shift the focus of their support next season. The Braves just may be getting a new chief. There has been increasing speculation that
description: Joe Torre will be replaced as manager, and the Braves' owner, Ted Turner, did nothing to dampen such talk when he popped into the clubhouse before the Braves' loss to San Diego Friday night and told Torre: ''Come see me Monday morning at 11 in my office.'' Turner declined to comment on Torre's future, but Torre said he was relieved. ''At least I know when,'' he said.

title: THE REGION ; Police AcademyCleared of Bias
description: A few racial jokes in New York State Police Academy classrooms and a policy of not allowing black recruits to dine together don't add up to unfair discrimination, a Federal judge ruled in Albany last week. In so deciding, District Judge James T. Foley rejected a charge that because of racial harassment some black and Hispanic candidates failed to complete the 1981 class.

description: JERUSALEM

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LONG, pointed wings and a tapering tail are characteristics of the falcons; short, broad wings distinguish the sharp- tailed hawks from the northern harriers that glide low over the marshes on long, rounded wings; biggest of all, the red-tailed hawks soar on four-foot wings and fanned-out tails as they fly in effortless arcs above the dunes.

title: Moscow Is Said to Add Missiles in East Europe
description: A West German politician said today that the Soviet Union shifted SS-22 nuclear missiles to East Germany and Czechoslovakia during the last three weeks.

I., and New Milford, Conn. Rabbi Marcus Kramer performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Indians Accuse Paper Of Violating Agreement
description: An Indian community has asked a Federal district judge to set aside the settlement of its lawsuit against The New Mexican, accusing the newspaper of violating the settlement and of seeking to ridicule the Indians in print.

description: Notre Dame escaped with a 16-14 victory over Missouri today when Brad Burditt's 39-yard field-goal attempt fell short with 2 seconds to play.
