title: PRINCETON CORRIDOR: BOOM OR THREAT?
description: THE 26 miles of U.S. 1 between New Brunswick and Trenton can be looked at in at least two ways: as ''Boom Town U.S.A.'' or as a disaster about to happen. John P. Sheridan Jr., Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation, takes the boom-town view; conservationists have called the strip ''a sort of Los Angeles East.''

title: KATHLEEN M MORAN BECOMES THE BRIDE OF MICHAEL F. Walsh, A LENDING OFFICER
description: Kathleen Marie Moran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Moran of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Francis Walsh, a son of Mrs. John Bernard Walsh of Rumson and the late Mr. Walsh. The Rev. Daniel Ryan McBride, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Patrick Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom's great- uncle, assisted.

title: COURT EXTENDS LIABILITY OF SCHOOLS FOR CRIMES
description: In 1978, a 19-year-old college student was attacked in daylight on the campus of San Francisco City College by a man who jumped from behind thick, untrimmed foliage and attempted to rape her. He was never captured.

title: SECURITY HEADS U.A.W.'S NEW AGENDA
description: Owen F. Bieber, the president of the United Auto Workers, outlined the approach at a strategy meeting of local union officials in late spring: ''Let's say we forget about job security and simply go for the money package. Well, we'd be suckers, because we'd have played into G.M.'s hands.''

title: Mark L. Baird Married To Wendy K. Schmidt
description: Wendy K. Schmidt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Schmidt of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark L. Baird, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Baird of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Richard L. Rush performed the ceremony at the First Church Congregational.

title: UNUSUAL TREES CAN PERK UP A TIRED LANDSCAPE
description: Are gardeners getting into a rut? Are they planting the same things over and over again not caring what the plants look like as long as they are pretty and grow? Or are gardeners becoming wiser and wanting something better?

title: CUOMO, TOO, IS A GREAT COMMUNICATOR
description: Governor Cuomo is at a peak of political popularity not often achieved by public officials. Just last week the Marist Institute for Public Opinion reported that 66 percent of New Yorkers felt Mr. Cuomo was doing a good or excellent job. The strength of these ratings cut across geographic, ethnic, religious and even political lines.

title: TRADITION TO A MILITARY BEAT
description: THE puffs of white smoke were not from a wood-burning stove or a fireplace, but the collective breath of 400 ''rooks,'' the term used to describe the freshman class of cadets at Norwich University. In the gray dawn one day last week, when the temperature hovered at a wintry 30 degrees, the rooks embarked on the annual Dog River Marathon, a three-quarter-mile march along the river near campus. The difficult part, though, would come on the return trip, when the cadets were required to take the water route and wade all the way home.

title: Gerard Byrne Weds Abigail Debevoise
description: Abigail Huntington Debevoise, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Dickinson R. Debevoise of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Gerard Francis Byrne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Byrne 3d, also of Short Hills. The ceremony was performed in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Millburn, N.J., by the Rev. Joseph D. Herring, former rector of the church, assisted by Msgr.

title: Miss Kneisel and E. T. Krumeich Jr., Both Lawyers, Wed in Massachusetts
description: Elizabeth Ann Kneisel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Kneisel of Boston, was married yesterday to Edward Thaddeus Krumeich Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Krumeich of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. James Wiesner performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Mass.

title: DANCE: BERKSHIRE BALLET
description: There's a good ballet company in the Berkshires. That was evident on Wednesday night when the Berkshire Ballet of Pittsfield, Mass., made its New York debut in the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: 3-FLOOR CONVERSION
description: After watching overbooked casino hotels nearby turn away guests, the developers of a 221-unit condominium in Atlantic City have converted the first three floors of their partially sold building into a hotel.

title: Serena Granbery Becomes a Bride
description: Serena Weld Granbery, a daughter of John Granbery of Salisbury, Conn. and Joya Weld Granbery of Cotuit, Mass., was married yesterday to Charles Webster Carleton Jr., the son of Mr. Carleton of New Canaan, Conn., and Ardis V. Carleton of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Bevan Jr. at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Execution On forCarolina Woman
description: Several years ago, Margie Velma Barfield put rat poison into the beer and iced tea she served to her fiance shortly before they went to a Rex Humbard religious revival. He died four days later.

title: ADS AS WAY TO MEET PEOPLE
description: If you enjoy the outdoors, particularly the water, and are a loving and caring woman, who likes quiet evenings, a good book and conversation, I would like to hear from you. I'm in my mid-40's, fairly attractive, with a good sense of humor, and enjoy the simple pleasures of life.

title: Louise Bachelder Wed to Executive
description: Louise Stewart Bachelder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Bachelder 3d of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to George Lewis Alcock Jr., a son of Mrs. Alcock of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Alcock. The Rev. Daphne W. P. Hawkes performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: DON'T UNDERESTIMATE THE ASIANS AGAIN
description: LESS than two decades ago, the phrase ''Made in Japan'' was synonomous with ''cheap'' and ''shoddy.'' But, as we know, Japan and other East Asia exports have penetrated, and even come to dominate, the markets for certain manufactured goods sold in the United States and Europe.

title: LOOKING FOR LOVE AFTER MARRIAGE
description: SECOND MARRIAGE

title: DATABANK
FINAL RAILS LAID ON KEY LINE TO OPEN UP SIBERIAN RICHES
description: After 10 years of work, the last segment of track was laid today on a 2,000-mile Soviet rail project that may ultimately cost an estimated $10 billion and open up vast new Siberian resources.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM O'NEILL TO STRAVINSKY
description: Stephen Beck: Illuminated Music Electron Video (41 Tunnel Road, Berkeley, Calif. 94705) 49 minutes. $39.95

title: WHEN THE SUPERTITLES FIGHT THE PRODUCTION
description: The Lord, omnipotent and ambidextrous, gives with one hand and takes away with the other. Consider the mixed blessing that some of us prefer to call supertitles. (The term, after all, refers to translations projected above the stage, not under it). Recently, many operagoers have had reason to give thanks for the innovation that first sprouted at the Canadian Opera under the trademark of Surtitles but that is known elsewhere by a wild variety of names, including subtitles (the New York City Opera) and OpTrans. The latter designation, which is the Pittsburgh Opera's entry this month into an increasingly crowded field, is short for opera translation.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DADDY'S GIRL

title: Bill Kennedy's Sudden Fame
description: One small amplification regarding the struggling years of William Kennedy (''The Sudden Fame of William Kennedy,'' Aug. 26). It is certainly true, as Margaret Croyden writes, that he was an ''overlooked part-time instructor'' at the State University of New York at Albany for eight years - absurdly overlooked by an administration that was indifferent to his talent; bafflingly overlooked by factions of an arts and sciences faculty that was deaf to strong sentiment from others for his full-time appointment, when he needed the financial security he now enjoys.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
IT'S A GOOD IDEA: TOO BADIT WON'T WORK
description: THOMAS HENRY HUXLEY once

title: GARDEN CITY VICTOR
description: Two key interceptions by Garden City cornerbacks helped the Trojans preserve a slender lead and go on to beat Calhoun, 14-10. Garden City, now 2-0 in Conference II, scored first with just 20 seconds remaining in the half on a 1-yard run by Paul Tully, a halfback. Ken Egan, a fullback, scored the second Trojan touchdown on a 35- yard run in the third. Steve Testa kicked both extra points.

title: Dr. Bedell Weds In Poughkeepsie
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., yesterday, Dr. Susanna Elizabeth Bedell and Dr. Robert Finley McFarlane were married by the Rev. Richard G. Shepherd.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: UPBEAT ASSESSMENT BY MONDALE OFFICIAL
description: At a time when Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign has been drawing mostly gloomy reviews, James A. Johnson, the campaign's national chairman, has begun providing Democratic leaders with his own assessments of Mr. Mondale's political progress. The Johnson report is strikingly more upbeat than many of the reviews turned in by reporters and politicians.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A DOG'S LOVE IS ALWAYS NEAR
description: OUR springer spaniel, Phoebe, has been a loyal and much adored member of our family for years. She has spent countless winter afternoons cozying up to the fire and, on more than one occasion, has awoken my husband and me with the sound of her contented snoring. She is a wonderful dog and has asked little of life but this - a comfortable home and people to love her. I'm sure she has envisioned spending her twilight years cuddled in her favorite corner dreaming of steak bones and dog yummies.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Congress StalledOn Immigration,Other Disputes
description: With most members of Congress eager to adjourn and get back to their campaigning, possibly irreconcilable differences over the civil rights of aliens last week threatened to shunt the long-pending immigration bill off onto a legislative siding.

title: MAN IS ACCUSED OF ABUSING 5 CHILD HOSTAGES
description: A 31-year-old man held seven children hostage in a house in Atlantic City a half-hour Friday and sexually assaulted five of them, according to the police.

title: HOLY CROSS DEFEATS HARVARD
description: Holy Cross, held to a tie by Harvard last year when a perfect season seemed in reach, struck back today.

title: THE WORLD ; Spain Gets HelpOn Basques
description: The violent Basque separatist movement is one of the biggest problems that Spain's young democracy has had to face. Last week, Madrid was encouraged by a major shift in France's policy of allowing Spanish Basque terrorists to take refuge in the French Basque provinces.

title: NEW NETWORKS OF IMMIGRANT ENTERPRENEURS
description: A new cadre of immigrant-entrepreneurs has clearly surfaced in New York. Korean vegetable stands dot residential neighborhoods. Indians and Pakistanis run a growing percentage of business-district newsstands. Chinese has become a common language in the garment district, while Israeli accents abound in electronics, auto parts and clothing stores.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MEXICO CITY
description: RICHARD J. MEISLIN is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The Times. Fall is one of the best times of the year to visit Mexico City, the most populous capital city in the Americas and, depending on who's counting heads, in the world. An extraordinarily wet rainy season is coming to a close, leaving the city a bit greener than usual. The peso, which began a continuous, gradual devaluation late last year, is edging toward 200 to the dollar.

title: Nancy Petrick Is Wed To Kent Elliott Novit
description: Nancy Elizabeth Petrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Michael Petrick of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to Kent Elliott Novit, the son of Sidney Novit of Highland Park, Ill., and Nancy Elliott Novit of Chicago. The Rev. George H. Pike performed the ecumenical ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Cranford, assisted by the Rev. William O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
About Men;
Caring for the Older Dog
description: Max Apple

title: Jane A. Williams Wed in Montclair
description: Jane Amerman Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Williams of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Russell Redmond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Redmond of West Orange, N.J., and Bondville, Vt. The Rev. Ernest L. Fogg performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in Montclair.

title: PROSPECTS ; Linerboard Rebellion
description: Because the highly competitive food and beverage industries are finding it more and more difficult to pass along increased costs to consumers, they have staged a widespread revolt against recent price rises by makers of linerboard and other packaging materials.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The New York Philharmonic, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, and the violinist and violist Pinchas Zukerman, will join forces for a ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast on Wednesday night at 8 on channels 13 and 49.

title: The Testing Of Duarte
description: Having personally met with President Duarte regarding the murder of four churchwomen in El Salvador, two of whom were Maryknoll sisters, I feel Lydia Chavez (''The Testing of Jose Napoleon Duarte,'' Sept. 2) has soberly presented the continuing difficulty of pursuing legal justice in El Salvador. ''The real test will come with Mr. Duarte's promised investigation of the human- rights abuses that accounted for an estimated 40,000 deaths in the last five years. . . . Only one politically sensitive case has been successfully prosecuted.''

title: PITT BOWS, 28-10, TO DROP TO 0-4
description: Willie Drewrey caught a 31-yard scoring pass and then returned a punt 74 yards for the decisive touchdown as West Virginia routed Pitt, 28-10, today. Pitt suffered its fourth consecutive loss this season and fifth over two seasons.

title: HERO IN AIR INCIDENT HONORED
description: A Cornell University law professor was honored this week by the Federal Aviation Administration for helping subdue a deranged man who stormed an airliner cockpit and sent the plane plummeting toward the ground.

title: BENEDICT ARNOLD TO BE TRIED AT LAST
description: FOR more than 35 years, William B. Stanley of Norwich has maintained that Benedict Arnold was not a traitor, but was a hero who helped the colonies win their freedom in the Revolutionary War.

title: Man Found Shot Dead AtHomeinManhattan
description: A Manhattan man was found shot to death yesterday in the entrance hall of his apartment on East 80th Street, the police said.

title: AT OSSINING HIGH, A TIME TO IMPROVISE
description: '' ON Aug. 22 I sat here at my desk and was feeling very good that everything was in place for the school year,'' said Robert Huntz, principal of the Ossining High School. ''Everything was planned, and we were ready to open school. I had just mailed out schedule cards to all the students and it was on that day that our Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds came in and said, 'I think we may have a problem.' ''

title: TIES THAT WON'T CHANGE THEIR STRIPES
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS;
description: The beachfront estate in Glen Cove, L.I., built by William Hester, whose family owned The Brooklyn Eagle at the height of its popularity and Loeser's department store in downtown Brooklyn, is being turned into a residential community.

title: A NEW THEATER GROUP MAKES ITS DEBUT
description: THE opening performance this month of ''Bad Habits'' by Terrence McNally at the former Grasmere School in Fairfield was also the debut of Fairfield's first professional theater - The Boston Post Road Stage Company.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Three years before his death last spring, Ansel Adams selected and printed 25 of his favorite images for museum collection. The large, imposing prints in this ''museum collection'' compose the best possible introduction to - and summing of - the master's work, and from Oct. 3 through Nov. 4 they will be on view at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street.

title: BIG CHANCE FOR PAT CUMMINGS
description: As Pat Cummings donned his Knick uniform for the first time today at Hofstra University, he said: ''Ideally, I'm a power forward, not a center.''

title: CITY PUBLIC SCHOOLS EASE INTO SEASON
description: On the first true autumn weekend, as leaves fell stubbornly and a brisk breeze swept across the spacious parade grounds at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, the city's public schools opened their cross-country season yesterday with the annual group run. No scores were kept, no winners were crowned, but the coaches of the 81 participating schools left with a better estimation of what fortunes the season may bring.

title: COUNTY SCHOOLS HONORED BY WASHINGTON
description: two high schools and one middle school - are displaying colorful banners proclaiming excellence in education. The award was given to 202 public junior/middle and high schools and 60 private schools nationwide that the Department of Education has singled out for recognition.

title: SCHOOL CHIEF VOWS TO FIGHT SUSPENSION
description: NEWARK ATTORNEYS for Dr. Columbus Salley, the suspended Executive Superintendent of Schools here, have vowed to fight his suspension, even it means taking the case to the highest judicial levels.

title: Andrea Ker Is Engaged to Paul Hutter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Ker Jr., of New Canaan, Conn., and Brewster, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Hodges Ker to Paul Anthony Hutter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hutter Jr., of Philadelphia. An Oct. 27 wedding is planned.

title: STEP-UP IN CHLORINE UPSETS WATER USERS
description: SOME people have bought purifiers. Some have stopped drinking the water altogether. Others have decided just to hold their noses.

title: CELEBRATING THE COLONIAL
description: Wallace Nutting's collection of 17th- and 18th-century American furnishings is bound to be reevaluated beginning today when it goes on view again at Hartford's Wadsworth Atheneum after an absence of nearly 20 years. The collection of the Massachusetts clergyman, who gave up the ministry in 1905 when he was 44 years old, and became a photographer, antiques collector, furniture producer and writer, focused attention 60 years ago on the colonial period at a time when Americans were eager to know more about their heritage.

title:
CRAFTS;
A CENTER FOR THE TEXTILE ARTS IN CROTON
description: JUST inside the door of The Niddy Noddy on Route 9 in Croton-on-Hudson a pot simmers on the stove, its steam smelling of wet wool from the yarn being dyed. In the front room of the wood-frame building, shelves are neatly stacked with spools of brightly colored yarns, while hand-dyed skeins of every texture and hue spill out of oversized baskets in the corners. An assortment of beads and buttons of wood, shell and ceramics fill the drawers of an old oak chest, and stacks of hand-knit sweaters are loosely piled on nearby shelves. In yet another room upstairs, fabric works ranging from African mud paintings to batik and cashmere wait to be discovered.

title: Agent Orange Deadline
description: Vietnam War veterans who believe their health problems or those of their families were caused by exposure to Agent Orange have until Oct. 26 to file claims with the New York State Division of Veterans Affairs.

title: Fan Par Excellence
description: Golf is his game, but it's baseball that's on Ray Floyd's mind these days. That's because the Chicago Cubs are headed for the playoffs and Floyd is the ultimate Cub fan.

title: THROUGH THE VALLEY OF CHATEAUS
description: OLIVIER BERNIER's most recent book is ''Louis the Beloved, the Life of Louis XV'' (Doubleday).

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Sobering Up
description: They came in casual clothes, carrying spare clothing in overnight bags. They lined up, 150 strong, waiting to go to jail in Nashville.

title: Dr.Ann W.Lucas Becomes a Bride I
description: Dr. Ann Wayne Lucas, a veterinarian, and Dr. William James Mesnard, a physician, were married yesterday in Malvern, Pa., at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in the Great Valley. The Rev. Frank Harron performed the ceremony.

title: CASINO ASSOCIATION GETS NEW OFFICERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY LITTLE more than a center for information and sporadic lobbying since it was organized in 1978, and facing dissolution a year ago, the Atlantic City Casino Hotel Association apparently is becoming a force for action in this resort, which has been beset by transportation and financial problems.

title: Personalities Overpower Parties, Anderson Says
description: The ideals of the Democrats and Republicans have been overshadowed by the personalities of politicians, says John B. Anderson, who was an independent Presidential candidate in 1980.

title: U.S. IN CUP FINAL
description: Without the loss of a set, John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors and Peter Fleming have deprived Australia of another Davis Cup.

title: ROYALS SAY CLUB HELD ON
description: If they gave a Comeback Franchise of the Year award in major league baseball, the Kansas City Royals would win it hands down.

title: THE LOVERS OF NEW PLACE
description: THE LADIES

title: Lois Cunningham Is Bride in Michigan
description: Lois Anne Cunningham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Cunningham Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday to John Howe Billings, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Tremaine Billings Jr. of Nashville. The Rev. Almus M. Thorpe Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cranbrook in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: THE MERGERMAKERS' SPIRALING FEES
description: WHEN Carnation directors agreed to a $3 billion bid from Nestle earlier this month, the arbitragers who had gambled on a possible takeover had plenty to cheer about. So did loyal Carnation shareholders.

title: Sorbetto
description: To the Editor:

title: Debris Falls From 747 South of Seattle
description: Chunks of debris up to eight feet long fell from a Boeing 747 jumbo jet shortly after takeoff this afternoon on a flight from Seattle to Seoul, Korea.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO HANDLE CUT FLOWERS
description: ALL too frequently, it seems, cut flowers do not last as long as one might expect. While this is especially disappointing with flowers purchased from a florist, it is also discouraging when it happens with flowers from one's own garden.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HELP FROM THE COMICSZ
description: BETTY BOOP was there. So was Beetle Bailey. Dagwood and Blondie were there, too, with their dog Daisy.

title: FRANKLIN ROUTS HILLSBOROUGH
description: Darin Roberts, a senior quarterback, completed 13 of 19 passes for 297 yards and three touchdowns when Franklin breezed past Hillsborough, 41-7, yesterday in Franklin.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A TOUR OF WETHERSFIELD HOMES
description: NEXT Saturday and Sunday, members of the Wethersfield Historical Society will celebrate the 350th anniversary of that town with a tour of homes built from the late 17th century through the 20th century.

title: BED-BREAKFAST'S LITTLE WORLD GETS BIGGER
description: Five years ago, the bed and breakfast concept, beloved by American travelers to Britain, underwent a sea change as it landed on American shores. The big news then was the development of numerous local reservation service organizations - called R.S.O.'s. The big news today is the growth of national reservation agencies, improved communication among owners, agencies and travelers and the development of both accommodations and reservation agencies that cater to special groups or offer unusual amenities and services.

title: THE MERITS AND DEMERITS OF THE GRAND JURY SYSTEM
description: It was, by all accounts, a most unusual court hearing. A grade-school French teacher went to State Supreme Court in Manhattan recently to ask that he be relieved of the oath of secrecy required by grand jurors.

title: KINDERCARTEN CLASS HAS MAN IN CHARGE
description: ''I DON'T like to focus on the fact that I'm a male,'' said William Hicks. ''I'm a good teacher. That's the important point.''

title: Victoria Eidell Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Victoria Eidell, a vice president in the corporate finance department of Wertheim & Company in New York, to William Cogswell Johnston, a vice president of Dillon, Read & Company in New York, took place yesterday at the Queen of the Snows Roman Catholic Church in Lake Tahoe, Calif. The Rev. Egon Javor performed the ceremony.

title: Medicaid Fee Freeze to Start
description: A Federal district judge has ruled against the American Medical Association in its attempts to postpone the start Monday of a 15-month freeze on fees for Medicare patients.

title: TIES THAT WON'T CHANGE THEIR STRIPES
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADLINERS ; The Family Seat If ever there was a local election in Europe that could interest Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, it occurred in France last week. Campaigning on the slogan ''Experience Counts,'' former President
description: Valery Giscard d'Estaing , who was turned out of office by the Socialist victory in 1981, swamped six opponents to win himself a seat in Parliament.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR Seat Belts Are A Good Idea
description: I applaud Mary Carolyn Morgan's article (''No Wisecracks Please: Just Buckle Up,'' Sept. 2).

title: Miss Rosakranse Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rosakranse of Accord, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Elizabeth to Daniel Lee Hauspurg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hauspurg of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in October.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LAKME'BY DELIBES IS PRESENTED
description: ''Lakme,'' the Leo Delibes work that the New York City Opera revived last night, has some perfectly ridiculous moments, and those are the good parts. It is at this point in history a piece of interest chiefly to collectors of operatic memorabilia. The work has a certain quaint charm, like an antique clock that runs some of the time but is not something to depend on. Veteran operagoers in New York retain affection for ''Lakme'' because it served so long and so well as a vehicle for the idolized Lily Pons, whose bare midriff and silvery coloratura in the Bell Song are still held in fond memory.

title: COLUMNIST BITES NEWSPAPER
description: THE INK TRUCK

title: U.S. ENVOY LEAVES MIDEAST AFTER WEEKLONG TOUR
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy left Lebanon en route to the United States today, ending a weeklong tour of Middle East capitals.

title: DANCE: LILO WAY AND HER COMPANY
description: As a dancer, Lillo Way brings to mind a Gibson Girl in all her beauty, brimming with sublimated sensuality. The surprise, then, was the impish humor that surfaced in her choreography, as seen at her dance company's opening Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The program included two premieres and two earlier works that make much of accompanying songs with a turn-of- the century irony.

title: TRAWLER'S SEIZURE CALLED MAJOR SETBACK FOR I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald said today that many lives may have been saved by the predawn capture of a trawler he said was carrying arms from the United States to Irish ''subversives.''

title: IN 2d DISTRICT, DIVERSITY OF VOTERS IS CHALLENGE TO CANDIDATES
description: IN the sprawling Second Congressional District in

title: A SUPERSALESMAN AT I.B.M.'S HELM
description: International Business Machines named a new chief executive. He is John F. Akers, one of the company's top salesmen. Mr. Akers, 49 years old and currently I.B.M.'s president, replaces John R. Opel, 59, who will remain as chairman. Colleagues described Mr. Akers as warm and eloquent in selling but a fighter in garnering market share. Mr. Akers's toughness may come in handy. I.B.M. is already dueling with the Japanese in the big-computer market, and experts predict a confrontation between I.B.M. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. To meet the A.T.& T. challenge, I.B.M. announced it would buy the Rolm Corporation, offering $1.25 billion in securities to acquire the leading maker of telecommunications equipment. I.B.M. already owns about 23 percent of Rolm, and analysts said the giant computer company would likely move quickly to exploit Rolm's knowledge of data transmission and telephone switching. One possible obstacle to a healthy business combination, experts say, is that I.B.M.'s straightlaced corporate culture might clash with Rolm's easy style.

title: SOME DOCTORS HELD INSENSITIVE ON RAPE
description: SOME doctors, said Joan McKenna, director of Women Against Rape in Collingswood, a rape-crisis center, are ''very gentle and kind'' in handling rape victims.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a profile in last Sunday's Business section of George B. Munroe, chairman of Phelps Dodge, incorrectly reported Asarco's ownership status. Asarco is an independent copper company.

title: Miss Allen Is the Bride Of David H. Coughlan
description: Louise Boulton Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Arthur Allen of Noroton, Conn., and Sandwich, N.H., was married yesterday to David Hopkins Coughlan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Charles Coughlan Jr. of Needham, Mass. The Rev. David Watson Boulton, the bride's uncle, and the Rev. Water Hamilton Taylor officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

title: ATYPICAL MONEY-RAISER DELIVERS FOR THE G.O.P.
description: When President Reagan or the Republicans need to raise money these days, they turn to Joe M. Rodgers.

title: MANAGUA TAKES A TRICK WITH THE CONTADORA CARD
description: The United States, which has sought to portray its Central America policy as essentially peaceful, was jolted when Nicaragua announced last weekend that it was willing to sign a proposed regional peace treaty. The offer suddenly made the Sandinista Government seem the one anxious to take risks for peace, while the Americans were seen as equivocating by refusing to join in the draft treaty. It appeared to be a propaganda victory for Nicaragua and it caught the United States by surprise.

title: U.S. INQUIRY FINDS GANGSTERS HOLD GRIP ON KENNEDY CARGO
description: Organized crime has a ''stranglehold'' on a large part of the cargo business at Kennedy International Airport, extorting millions of dollars every year from shipping and trucking companies, according to the head of a Federal investigative unit.

title: COMMUTERS GAINING NEW JOBS
description: COMMUTERS are gobbling up a growing share of the new jobs created in New York City, and Long Island's economy is one of the chief beneficiaries.

title: U.S. PUBLIC POLICY ON ABORTION: THE FIRST 100 YEARS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO USE A STEPLADDER SAFELY
description: MOST people take stepladders pretty much for granted since they are so widely used for everything from changing a light bulb in an overhead fixture to papering or painting the ceiling and walls. Yet there are many things the do-it-yourselfer can do to make a stepladder safer and easier to use, and to minimize the amount of climbing up and down because of dropped or forgotten tools and the like.

title: ADAMS AND SWENSON LEAD PLEASANTVILLE'S ROMP
description: James Adams, ''Mr. Inside'' for Pleasantville High School, ran for four touchdowns, and Mark Swenson, the Panthers' ''Mr. Outside,'' scored twice to lead Pleasantville to a 41-14 victory over Bronxville yesterday. It was Pleasantville's second straight victory.

title: 70, He Crosses U.S. on Kite
description: Cheers from well-wishers greeted 70-year-old Jack Halbeisen Friday as he ended a 7,800-mile flight on a motorized kite.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; 'Good' A-Bomb
description: The ''tentative conclusion'' put forth by a disciple of the late Marshall McLuhan was startling, even for a sect accustomed to unconventional thinking and controversy. Dr. Derrick de Kerckhove, a co-director of the McLuhan Program in Culture and Technology at the University of Toronto, suggested in February that the atomic bomb might be a good thing.

title: Rachel Jane Horowitz Married to Louie Nikolaidis
description: Rachel Jane Horowitz and Louie Dimitrios Nikolaidis, both students at Rutgers University Law School in Newark, were married last night at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irvin M. Horowitz, in Montclair, N.J. Judge Reginald Stanton of the New Jersey Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title:
NEW NETWORKS OF IMMIGRANT ENTERPRENEURS;
GOOD ADVICE AND EASY CREDIT
description: IN 1968, Shual Levy, then 21 years

title: Aimee B. DuMont Bride of Jeffrey Herbert Peppel
description: Aimee Belden DuMont, a daughter of Allen B. DuMont Jr. of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Allison D. Teaze of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Herbert Peppel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Peppel of Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Andrew McElwee performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Caldwell.

title: LOOKING FOR LOVE AFTER MARRIAGE
description: -DEVIL

title: Homage To Mozart
description: In his ''Paying Homage to Mozart'' (Sept. 2), Peter Shaffer combines his deep understanding of the composer's genius with his delightfully contagious enthusiasm. More is the pity that he feels the need to make comparisons and assign ranks (Watteau, Beethoven, Wagner). As Kierkegaard wrote in his own essay on Mozart, ''struggle for the highest or lowest place is just as childish as a struggle for the first place at confirmation before the altar.''

title: DIVERGING POLITICS OF SEXES SEEN IN POLL
description: The gender gap, though not a decisive factor in a so far lopsided Presidential campaign, is critically important in key Senate races where men prefer Republican candidates and women like Democrats better.

title: 'NEW OLD' L. I. FAIR TO BEGIN A 4-DAY RUN
description: WHAT color is ''drab?'' That's what Edward Smits wants to know. For there are times in every historian's life when too much knowledge leads to confusion, and Mr. Smits is currently experiencing just such a time.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Sept. 30, 1984Fiction*1 THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $3.95.) Three generations of a German Jewish family in New York. *2 THURSTON HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) Three generations of a San Francisco family. *3

title: TASTING THE BOUNTY OF THE VALLEY
description: In the gentle valley of the Loire, every other town and village seems to be named for either a chateau, a wine, a cheese or a pastry. That speaks well for gastronomy. And like the soothing, quiet landscape that is crisscrossed by lazy, winding rivers, flat golden wheat fields and a vineyard or orchard here and there, the food is neither startling nor stupendous but perfectly matches the tamed land.

title: GOLDEN DAYS FOR SCALLOPING, THOUGH NOT A GOLDEN YEAR
description: THESE are the golden days of the scalloping season - late September and early October. The sun is still warming but not scorching. The vacationers and other amateurs who take to the water in the first few weeks of scalloping to earn extra money have gone, leaving the East End bays to the pros, the commercial fishermen like Peter Wenczel of Southold. These are the days that reaffirm his decision some 10 years ago to make his living on the water.

title: NBC'S HEAD SAYS TV VIEWERS SPURN QUALITY SHOWS
description: Grant Tinker, the chairman of NBC, got up from his desk in his office on the sixth floor of the RCA building in Rockefeller Center. Behind him hung a huge framed blowup of the dictionary definitions of the word ''tinker.'' He sat on a couch and stretched his legs; across the room from him, three television sets were tuned to the three networks' evening-news broadcasts.

title: NAZIS BROUGHT TO JUSTICE
description: THE NUREMBERG TRIAL

title: JERSEY AIDES CLASH ON WAIVING TEACHING RULE FOR PRINCETON
description: Princeton University's small education program does not comply with new state regulations, and New Jersey's two top education officials have clashed over the Ivy League school's request for an exemption.

title: SOUTHERN CAL LOSES TO L.S.U. BY 23-3
description: Dalton Hilliard rushed for 82 yards and a pair of 2-yard touchdowns for a 14-3 halftime lead today as Louisiana State (3-0-1) beat previously unbeaten Southern Cal, 23-3.

title: AMERICAN JEWS REDISCOVER ORTHODOXY
description: NEXT SATURDAY, ON YOM KIPPUR, the Day of Atonement, half a million American Orthodox Jews - more than at any time since World War II - are expected to attend services at synagogues to spend all day in prayer and fasting. Among them will be Zalman Chaim Bernstein, 58 years old, chairman of the New York investment firm of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company (assets under management, $3.7 billion). But like many others in today's Orthodoxy, Mr. Bernstein was not always so devout; he legally adopted his Hebrew name less than a year ago. But now this bluff, hearty financier, who wears an exuberantly multicolored skullcap in the cover photograph on the annual report of his company, proudly advertises his Orthodox homecoming to the whole world of investment management.

title: BERGEN MAN HAS SCOTS SAVORING PIZZA
description: WHEN Eric O. Brown starts his day in the wee hours, it is usually with a checklist much like that used by any other customer-conscious restaurateur.

title: Film View; STAGE AND SCREEN GO THEIR SEPARATE WAYS
description: Hollywood - meaning movies in general - and the American theater have parted company. That may seem like a strange if not lunatic thing to say hard on the heels of the successful openings of the Milos Forman-Peter Shaffer screen adaptation of Mr. Shaffer's ''Amadeus,'' the Norman Jewison- Charles Fuller screen adaptation of Mr. Fuller's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Soldier's Play,'' retitled ''A Soldier's Story,'' and Francesco Rosi's surprisingly cinematic ''Bizet's Carmen,'' which is nothing less than a full-scale screen opera.

title: G.M. Is Canada Strike Target
description: The United Automobile Workers will strike General Motors of Canada Ltd. on Oct. 17 unless negotiators write a new contract for some 36,000 employees working under contract extensions, the union said Friday.

title: Fair Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: AND NOW, NATIONAL STAMP COLLECTING MONTH
description: October is National Stamp Collecting Month. Dedication services for a 20- cent United States commemorative stamp will be held tomorrow at Shaker Heights, Ohio, High School, the first of many events around the country. The new stamp recognizes the importance of family unity and is the first U.S. postage stamp based on a design by a student.

title: Hope Is What Makes the Giants
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: M
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Santry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Santry Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Claude Robert Cochin de Billy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillipe H. Cochin de Billy of Paris. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Sienna Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Film buffs have some vintage pearls on cable this week. Bravo is showing Abel Gance's 1927 silent-screen classic ''Napoleon'' - with all four hours subtitled - in its reassembled form with music added, on Monday at 8 P.M., with a rebroadcast at 1 A.M. With the fiery-eyed Albert Dieudonne as Bonaparte, the picture is an extraordinary blend of human drama and spectacle in pioneer technical imagery that is often riveting.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: BACK TO YESTERDAY WITH A LONG-SUFFERING CUB FAN

title: THE STRENGTHS OF NAVRATILOVA AND ANNETTE NIEMTZOW
description: IT is only fitting that it was a serve-and-volley player who performed one of the most courageous acts by a female tennis player. Just as she was never comfortable sitting back on the baseline, Martina Navratilova was not content to rest on her laurels. She disregarded the traditional notions of a woman's body and, at much cost, attacked her opposition by initiating a training program that has raised the level of her game dramatically, so that she now owns the undisputed No. 1 ranking in women's tennis and is heading toward the title as the greatest female player of all time.

title: Victoria
description: To the Editor:

title: COONEY STOPS RIVAL IN FOURTH
description: Gerry Cooney, absent from the ring for 27 months, resumed his quest for the world heavyweight title today and unveiled a campaign to become known as ''America's fighter'' as he stopped Philip Brown in the fourth round.

title: 'I'm for Peace.' 'So Are We.'
description: The Reagan-Gromyko conversation that began with professions of peace at the United Nations last week appears to have culminated in an ''intense'' and ''aggressive'' exchange at the White House. Those are the adjectives Secretary of State George Shultz used in his report, and it's not hard to fill in the nouns to which they apply.

title: Ban on Citrus Sales Is Lifted in Florida
description: A ban on sales of citrus within Florida, imposed because of a plant disease, has been temporarily lifted to ease a glut of fruit in stores, Federal agriculture officials said today.

title: Baldwin Tops Berner In Nassau County Conference I yesterday, Baldwin defeated Berner, 30-17, by scoring three of
description: four touchdowns on defense.

title: Lorraine J. Smith Becomes a Bride
description: Lorraine Jarvis Smith, a daughter of James S. Smith of New York and Narragansett, R.I. and the late Ruth Ann Jarvis Otto, was married yesterday to Joseph White Gerard Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Brooks of Baltimore. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan.

title: THE NATION ; Mine WorkersSettle Quietly
description: For two decades, it had been as much a part of life down in the mines as the constant threat of cave-ins and layoffs; whenever their contract with the coal companies ran out, members of the United Mine Workers took off their hard hats and headed for the picket lines.

title: FIRETRAP
description: Penny Janeway is an editor and freelance writer who lives in Cambridge, Mass. COCOANUT GROVE

title: Article 236688 -- No Title
description: A bequest valued at up to $8.3 million has been left to Columbia University by the widow of Robert A. W. Carleton, an alumnus and civil engineer, whose company constructed many of New York City's subway and railroad tunnels.

title: THE WORLD ; Argentina GetsI.M.F. BackingFor Austerity
description: After almost a year of arduous negotiations, Argentina and the International Monetary Fund got together last week on an austerity program that is expected to bring relief to the developing world's third largest debtor. The banking world breathed a little easier but there were still big troubles ahead.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS HONE THEIR TACTICS AND ATTITUDES
description: Summer is stirring in South Africa now, a season, this year, of omens and unrest.

title: STRUGGLES IN A WELFARE HOTEL RECOUNTED
description: The hotel halls and the stairwells are filthy. There are rats and roaches in the rooms. People are mugged in the elevators. Preparing food for the family means cooking each item and then eating it before cooking the next item, because the only cooking facilities are hot plates and there is no refrigeration.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'GALLERY TOURS' AT SHORT HILLS
description: SHORT HILLS THE antiques business, like many others, has seasonal highs and lows. After a summer of relatively little activity, autumn brings a resurgence of interest and a wealth of antiques shows.

description: ASUBSTANTIAL number of men who may not have grown up with the feminist movement are now feeling - and enjoying - its fallout.

title: LONGSHOREMEN'S BILL SIGNED
description: President Reagan has signed legislation to restrict coverage, limit benefits and provide safeguards against fraud and abuse in compensation for longshoremen and harbor workers. In signing the measure Friday, Mr. Reagan said the bill struck a balance between providing fair, necessary benefits and giving employers and the Labor Department the means to control costs.

title: MORE OFFICES
description: In 1974, when the first building was going up in Princeton University's Forrestal Center, a 1,700- acre development park on Route 1 near Plainsboro, it was expected that the 21st century would arrive before the region could support more than 7 million square feet of commercial space.

title: ONLY THE INTERPLAY MATTERS IN 'DEJA VU'
description: WHETHER it is the fading of a friendship or the imminent end of the world - by an ''invasion of imperalist ants'' - there is nothing more monumental than the beginning of a courtship and the possibility of romantic love.

title: PRECIOUS OBJECTS
description: THE dented spaghetti pot with the slightly rounded bottom is known in this household as ''Richard's pot.'' There are also a couple of ''Richard's cookbooks'' on the shelf.

title: LETTERS
description: Freud as Collector

title: SYRIA RECEIVES NO LAURELS OR REST IN BEIRUT
description: Dizzying spins of the Middle East roulette wheel have cast doubt on the chances for Syrian President Hafez al-Assad to attain his goal of being the dominant Arab power broker in the region.

title: The Hatfield Case, Not Closed
description: The Senate Ethics Committee is dropping its inquiry into Senator Mark Hatfield's dealings with a Greek businessman who sought influence to help him promote a $12 billion oil pipeline across Africa. The only explanation given was that staff interviews had discovered ''no credible evidence'' to continue investigating and that a fuller report was in preparation. The Senator, though pleased with the committee action, said he would welcome that report.

title: RESTAURANT STRIKE EXPANDS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: In the month since picket lines began to appear around some of the best-known restaurants here, a strike by members of the Hotel, Restaurant and Bartenders Union has forced one restaurant to close and 27 others to curtail service.

description: Inhibiting Factor?

title: AMERICA'S ANIT-ARMAGEDDON SATELLITES
description: To the Editor:

title: PERUVIAN BISHOPS CONFER WITH POPE
description: A delegation of Peruvian bishops has been meeting with Pope John Paul II and other Vatican officials this week in an effort to resolve differences over the teachings known as the theology of liberation.

title: NORTH HEMPSTED SEEKS COUNTRY CLUB AS PUBLIC LINKS
description: THERE'S a ''demonstrated need,'' according to John Kiernan, the North Hempstead Town Supervisor, for open space in the town, and it is that need that has impelled him to look closely at the possibility of acquiring the Links - formerly a posh private country club - as a town golf course.

title: MUSEUM TO DISPLAY MACHINES
description: ONE raises sheep. Another sells automobiles. A third builds stage scenery for Broadway shows. But they, and dozens of other Connecticut residents from a variety of backgrounds, share a common interest. They collect, restore and return to operation antique machinery, from corn huskers to cider mills.

title: Tall Ships
description: To the Editor:

title: DOGGED ROCKWELL BETS ON REAGAN
description: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL's first B-1 bomber rolled impressively out of its southern California plant earlier this month, ending a politically turbulent 15-year gestation period. The company's Discovery space shuttle orbited the earth for six eventful days recently on its highly touted maiden voyage. Rockwell's backlog of weapons contracts has climbed to $10.4 billion, thanks to the Reagan Administration's hefty defense budgets. And Rockwell, with $1.3 billion in cash along with one of the strongest balance sheets in American industry, is in the process of posting its ninth consecutive yearly earnings increase.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPIINION;
'EQUAL ACCESS' TO SCHOOLS: WHO BENEFITS?
description: ON the surface, the law providing ''equal access'' to public schools, which was recently signed by President Reagan, seems harmless and even has the attribute of being a reaffirmation of our country's commitment to free speech and free assembly.

title: DOONEBURY LEAVES SALAD DAYS BEHIND FOR GROWN-UP WORLD
description: Michael Doonesbury works for a large Manhattan advertising agency.

title: THE ART OF SPENDING
description: Lottery winners, when asked how they plan to spend their millions, invariably astonish me with answers that reveal a revulsion for the lap of luxury. One recent winner could think of nothing more vilely rich to do than buy a new Buick. Others say they will be content with a weekend at the seashore or seats at a baseball game.

title: COLUMBIA BOWS TO LAFAYETTE
description: Dean Rivera, Lafayette's junior quarterback, scored on a 1-yard plunge midway through the fourth quarter yesterday to erase Columbia's only lead and lift the Leopards to 23-14 victory at Wien Stadium.

title: THE NATION ; Going GenericAt the Pump
description: There was a time when some people swore by Texaco, while others wouldn't go anywhere for their gas but the Chevron station across the street. But, thanks to the dislocations in the oil industry in the last decade and lower prices at stations that sell Brand X, consumer loyalty has begun to go the way of the unfailingly washed windshield.

title: SIKH PRIESTS GIVEN CONTROL OF SHRINE
description: The Government formally handed over control of the Golden Temple, the holiest shrine in the Sikh religion, to a committee of five Sikh priests today.

title: THE WORLD ; Violence SpreadsIn Manila
description: With the official report on the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. expected any day, demonstrators in Manila last week ran into stiff police countermeasures. At least 34 people were hospitalized, including a dozen with gunshot wounds, after 500 police officers dispersed 3,000 marchers headed toward the palace of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

description: MONTCLAIR IN ITS first season, Unity Concerts presented a number of

title: JOHANNESEN'S 40 YEARS OF CONCERTS
description: Forty years ago last April, a young pianist named Grant Johannesen came to town, played an unhackneyed recital program, and won general praise for his sound technique, thoughtful interpretations and unusual musical intelligence.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT was one of those glorious Sundays, and my wife and I, recently returned from trudging

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Egypt and JordanTogether Again
description: Egypt and Jordan ended a four- year estrangement last week, raising hopes for progress on moderate solutions to Middle East problems. In an Islamic New Year's telephone call to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, King Hussein of Jordan announced he was restoring diplomatic relations. The move could help Egypt to regain influence as an Arab leader, and open the way for Jordan to edge toward discussions with Israel about the West Bank.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Comedian Unity
description: The nation's professional stand-up comedians, who thrive on individualism, were asked in January to band together to improve their job benefits and working conditions.

title: CONCERTS FIND NEW AUDIENCE
description: THE cellist closed her eyes, and built to a crescendo with passionate intensity. Some members of the audience closed their eyes, too, as if to shut out all but the music's beauty.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
FROM A POCKETFUL OF CHESTNUTS, NEW LIFE
description: THE tulip tree was dead. Its long furled leaves, pointing skyward like the fingernails of an elegant woman, would never green and open. They merely clung to the twigs held by the branches that sprouted from the shaft of the trunk - all of them ossified last fall when lightning hit.

title: JERSEY AREAS GET H.U.D. AID
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has awarded $6.4 million in community development block grants to two New Jersey counties and three townships that became eligible for the program for the first time this year.

title: HIGH PARTS PRICES ARE DEFENDED
description: Ken Blakely, head of a company that produces a coffeemaker for airplanes that costs $3,046, is upset by recent allegations that the Pentagon is paying too much for that and other items.

title: U.S. WOULD LET STATES' OFFICIALS MONITOR RIGHTS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to delegate some of the responsibility for enforcing Federal civil rights laws to officials of selected states.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM O'NEILL TO STRAVINKSY
description: A Soldier's Tale An animated film by R. O. Blechman; music by Igor Stravinsky (''L'Histoire du Soldat'') performed by the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra. Narrator: Andre Gregory; executive producer: Chloe Aaron MGM/UA 56 minutes.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE CHEROKEE
description: At one time, long ago, all living things were in the sky, according to Cherokee myth keepers. But as the sky rock became too crowded, first the water beetle and then the grandfather buzzard were sent to earth to find a place where people and animals could live. As the great buzzard became weary, his wings dipped into the muddy surface of the world, carving out valleys and ridges. Thus were born the Great Smoky Mountains.

title: SOME SYSTEMS IMPROVED SINCE VERMONT RAIL CRASH
description: Amtrak and the Central Vermont Railway have improved their systems for weather reporting and communications since an Amtrak passenger train derailed in northern Vermont last July on tracks undermined by rain.

title: 'DOONESBURY' SPAWNS A 'PARTISAN REVUE'
description: Where does satire end and nihilism begin in the media-wise America of the 80's? It is a question that troubles Garry Trudeau, the 36-year-old cartoonist who won a Pulitzer Prize, in 1974, for his topical comic strip, ''Doonesbury.'' Since 1970, the controversial strip has chronicled the follies of four Presidential adminstrations, along with the metamorphosis of 60's hippies into today's yuppies. Mr. Trudeau's latest venture is ''Rap Master Ronnie,'' a cabaret revue of satirical songs which he's written with the composer Elizabeth Swados. Last year, the pair collaborated on the Broadway musical version of ''Doonesbury.''

title: STAE, SEEKING NEW D.R.G. WAIVER, SEES HOSPITAL SAVINGS
description: -setting system will save the Federal Government $126 million in Medicare payments over the next three years, according to projections released last week by the state's Department of Health.

title: SUDANESE PRESIDENT LIFTS EMERGENCY DECREE
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry lifted the national state of emergency today that he imposed amid growing unrest over economic problems and corruption five months ago.

title: ART UNDER LATE CAPITALISM
description: HAS MODERNISM FAILED?

title: Laura C. Weyher To Be the Bride Of G. B. Hall Jr.
description: Mrs. Alan Kenneth Gage of New York and Harry Frederick Weyher of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Carter Weyher to Gordon Bennett Hall 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for Dec. 8.

title: CRUSTED MEMORIES OF ALSACE
description: THERE ARE SOME food memories that lodge themselves in the mind like a grappling hook. They can range from a platter of deep- fried perch served at a small restaurant on the shores of Lake Leman to a Stygian-black truffle baked in puff pastry and served with a Madeira wine sauce at the Auberge de l'Ill in Alsace to the lobsters and corn on the cob at a simple clambake on a beach near my home in Long Island.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ; Luring RoachesInto a Fatal Trap
description: Cockroaches, as everyone knows, thrive on adversity. They have evaded countless and creative schemes to wipe them out, infesting six continents and probably most New York City apartments at one time or another.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TWO recent studies of New Jersey's largest employers show that, although manufacturing industries still provide most jobs in the state, high-technology and service companies continue to make gains. Economists and business leaders see a social implication in the trend as cities lose manufacturing jobs while suburbs and rural regions gain high-technology and service companies.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LET'S GET ON WITH HOUSING
description: STATE Senator John H. Dorsey, Republican of Mountain Lakes, is understandably crestfallen (Opinion Page, Aug. 19) at having represented a half- dozen Morris County municipalities in their efforts to uphold the use of zoning to exclude low- and moderate- income households from their midst, only to have that long-standing tradition firmly put down by the State Supreme Court as unconstitutional.

description: THE cheese that is turning heads these days is ch evre. Ch evre means goat and the category refers to cheese made from goat's milk.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;
PEPERS AND ARIAS, OLD TIMES AND NEW
description: ONE evening, while visiting a chic new espresso cafe in Massapequa, I watched the waiter serve someone a plate of ''peppers and eggs.'' When the patron smiled approvingly after the first bite, I felt triumphant as I thought back to an event in my childhood, 30 years ago, in that very neighborhood.

description: ''Twelve years ago,'' Anzac Wallace was saying, ''I would rather have punched you than talk to you.''

title: MARYLAND TRIES TO SAVE STRIPED BASS
description: A Maryland official called a press conference here this month and abruptly proclaimed a moratorium on fishing for striped bass in Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries. As recently as the mid- 1970's, these waters were the source of 90 percent of the East Coast's stripers.

title: YALE STUDENTS GET CAUGHT IN THE STRIKE
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN 1,800 clerical and technical workers struck Yale University on Wednesday, 10,300 students faced a few unusual choices.

description: Victoria Joanne Perry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Perry of Ormond Beach, Fla., and Cape Rosier, Me., was married yesterday to Lawrence Henry Summers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Summers of Merion Station, Pa. The ceremony was performed at the Harvard Club in Boston, with the Rev. Arlan Baillie, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh officiating.

Cook of Mystic, Conn., and Diane S. Cook of Albany. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

description: Nancy Anne Shlora, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bernard Shlora of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Louis Donnelly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Donnelly of Morris Plains, N.J. The Rev. William Warren performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

description: Texas' two candidates for the United States Senate seat being vacated by John Tower battled each other in a televised debate last night. Both claimed victory, but there was some question about how many viewers watched the candidates rather than the television season's first episode of ''Dallas.''

title: 'YOU KNOW, I COULD WRITE THE MOST WONDERFUL BOOK'
description: Barbara Goldsmith, a social historian, is at work on a novel. T happened twice in one week. At a cocktail party on Monday, a woman I'd never seen before said, ''So you're the writer. You know, I could write the most wonderful book, if only I could find the time.'' Then on Wednesday an acquaintance called, ostensibly to invite me to a political fund-raiser. ''Would you be interested in helping me with my book?'' she inquired. ''How?'' ''By writing it. I've had such a fascinating life, but I'm having a little trouble pinning it down.'' I had visions of myself in a New Yorker cartoon, wielding a butterfly net, chasing after episodes in her life and slapping them down on a yellow wide-lined pad. ''Sorry,'' I said, ''but I have trouble collaborating, even with myself.'' This is my standard reply to this query, which comes up with disconcerting regularity. The answer is meant to sound amiable, it usually works, and it masks my rage.

Officials said it would improve the mechanical reliability, passenger comfort and scheduled performance of the trains used on the Hudson and Harlem Lines.

title: BILL KENNEDY'S SUDDEN FAME
description: William Kennedy is the new American Dream, the hope of thousands of people in ''artistic anonymity.'' And he is more beautiful, because he is spirited rather than bitter. How he keeps from thumbing his nose at the lot of them, especially the State University of New York at Albany, is the mark of a real great man.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Jenifer Lewis, the actress-singer whose one-woman show, ''How I Spent My Summer Vacation,'' returns to Don't Tell Mama (343 West 46th Street) on Wednesday, is a performer with such a vivid and varied talent that stardom would seem to be inevitable sooner or later. Miss Lewis had a small part in the Broadway musical ''Eubie!'' More recently she sang in Bette Midler's backup group, the Harlettes, and her new act, written and directed by David Holdgrewrie, contains a lot of Midleresque topical jokes.

title: Tiger Supremacy Is Fragile
description: WHEN Sparky Anderson became manager of the Detroit Tigers in the middle of the 1979 season, he boldly - some thought foolishly - assured everyone that he would produce a pennant in five years. Now that the Tigers have won half a pennant - a division championship - the truth can be told.

title: PRETORIA'S JUGGERNAUT
description: John de St. Jorre, author of ''A House Divided: South Africa's Uncertain Future,'' is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. SOUTH AFRICA AT WAR

title: MONDALE'S HEALTH TERMED EXCELLENT BY PHYSICIAN
description: Walter F. Mondale is in excellent health, though like millions of other Americans he must take medication daily to control his high blood pressure, according to the Democratic Presidential nominee's personal physician. In Mr. Mondale's case, the medication consists of a combination of three drugs.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLLY;
EMPTY SEATS THAT GO BACK IN TIME
description: AS A CHILD, I went to Adath Israel in Trenton. I went for 30 years. I will tell you who sat where, a kind of emotional geography of that synagogue.

title: HEADLINERS ; Price of Freedom The rights of man have a price, and
description: H. Ross Perot has paid it. Mr. Perot, a Texan who went from very rich to super rich a few months ago when he sold the family computer business to General Motors for $2.5 billion, announced last week that he had bought a 687-year-old copy of Magna Carta for $1.5 million. Updated by King Edward I in 1297, the animal skin document is believed to be the most complete version of the affirmation of English civil rights that King John was forced to sign at Runnymede in 1215. Mr. Perot bought it from the Brudenell family of Corbey, England, which is said to have owned it since the day it was signed.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: Start with America's long love affair with sweets, mix in the current mania for chocolate chip cookies and add the growing popularity of giving combined gifts of flowers and candy and you get another boom year for the confectionary industry.

title: GEORGE K. BIENKOWSKI
description: George K. Bienkowski, a professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering at Princeton University, died Friday of injuries suffered in a bicycling accident.

title: RUTGERS ROLLS OVER CINCINNATI BY 43-15
description: Rutgers won two of its first three games this season with solid defense. Today, the defense was good, the running better and Tom Angstadt's field- goal kicking the best in the school's long history.

description: William Clark is the president of the London- based International Institute for Environment and Development. THE CROWDED EARTH

title: THEATER'S GENDER GAP IS A CHASM
description: No one doubts that many feminist battles have been fought and won over the past decade or two. There's never been a time in American life when men and women have tried so hard - and, with increasing frequency, succeeded so well - at dealing with one another on equal, enlightened terms. But enter a theater where a hit play by almost any male American dramatist is on the boards, and you may well come away with quite a different impression.

title: E.P.A., BOWING TO COURT, SETS TOXICITY TEST
description: A testing schedule for several potentially dangerous chemicals has been set by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency under the pressure of a court ruling in Manhattan.

title: Jeffrey Hall Is Married To Wendy B. Jennings
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Wendy Brewster Jennings, a daughter of Mrs. Burton J. Lee 3d of Armonk, N.Y., and John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., was married to Jeffrey Prince Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Joseph Hall of St. Louis. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: MONDALE SAYS REAGAN FAILED IN TALK
description: Campaigning with Jimmy Carter by his side today, Walter F. Mondale charged that President Reagan's meeting with Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, apparently ended in failure. He challenged Mr. Reagan to prove him wrong.

title: CHINA CUTS A HONG KONG DEAL WITH ASSURANCES ON ALL SIDES
description: The surest guarantee of Hong Kong's capitalist future after it submits to Chinese rule in 1997 may be not the joint declaration that Britain and China initialed last week but the international fanfare that surrounded it.

Hazzard of Katonah, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Roger Stewart Halik, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Halik of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Bruce White, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the garden at the Hazzard home.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS GET TOUGH WITH TRUANTS
description: STUDENTS playing hooky have more of a chance of getting caught and punished these days, as Connecticut school districts adopt tougher policies to reduce absenteeism and class cutting.

title: METROPOLITAN AREA RUSHES TO ADD PRISON CELLS
description: Racing to catch up with a burgeoning inmate population that shows few signs of abating, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have embarked on vast prison construction programs with a combined cost of nearly $1 billion.

title: STATE COMPUTERIZES ITS FLOOD WATCH
description: TWICE in the last three years, the Federal Government has declared a state of emergency in Connecticut because of flooding. In 1982, spring rains caused an estimated $100 million damage, and this year the damage was more than $40 million.

title: ARMY SETS BACK DUKE, 13-9,WITH GOOD DEFENSE
description: Army's new wishbone offense worked well enough today for a 13-9 victory over Duke that made the Cadets undefeated in the first three games of the season for the first time since 1966.

title:
DINING OUT;
PSST, BUT ISN'T THAT JOLTIN' JOE?
description: JOE DiMAGGIO eats here and Frank Sinatra is said to drop in now and then, and some evenings much of the local population seems to dine here. What attracts these loyal patrons to Belleville's unprepossessing Belmont Tavern are the simple Southern Italian fare and bustling conviviality of this neighborhood spot.

title: PUBLIC SERVANTS Promotion Cost The Senate hearings ten years ago on Nelson Rockefeller's nomination as the first appointed Vice President
description: were a historic letdown. He didn't have, or didn't admit to having, as much money as people thought. Mr. Rockefeller documented his piece of the family fortune at $179 million.

title: A SINGULAR JAPANESE RESTAURANT
description: -SE in New Hyde Park, which opened at the beginning of August, seems to have been cut from the same mold as virtually every other Japanese restaurant on the Island (if not in the entire United States), but certain aspects of the menu, the preparation and the presentation of the food set it apart.

title: HOFSTRA REBOUNDS FOR 14-13 VICTORY
description: Tom McLaughlin, a transfer from U.C.L.A., threw a 4-yard touchdown pass to Emil Wohlgemuth with 35 seconds remaining in the game to give undefeated Hofstra a 14-13 victory over Catholic University yesterday in Washington. Phil Kuzniar kicked the extra point for the victory.

title: PERU REBELS RAID 2 NEW OFFICES
description: Armed commandos of a new guerrilla organization occupied the offices of The Associated Press and United Press International here today, and at gunpoint forced both news agencies to send a revolutionary communique. No one was reported hurt in the incidents.

title: MONTAUK PARKING DEBATED
description: NEARLY 200 residents have petitioned the East Hampton Town Board to extend the boundaries of a parking ban on Old Montauk Highway. Though the main target of the ban is Gurney's Inn, the town's biggest and most well-known resort, the underlying issue appears to be the increasing encroachment of businesses and developments into what many residents have long considered an isolated vacation community.

title: FERRARO THE CAMPAIGNER
description: Jane Perlez is a reporter for The New York Times. By Jane Perlez THE BACKDROP WAS AN AMERICAN flag and the place an empty hangar in Toledo, Ohio. Her campaign airplane had broken down, so Geraldine A. Ferraro, with some time to kill, held an impromptu news conference to defend herself against the onslaught of the Archbishop of New York, John J. O'Connor, who on three successive days had criticized her for her position on abortion.

title: Haughton Memorial To Broadway Express
description: Broadway Express, driven by Mickey McNichol, scored a 1 1/2-length victory over Praised Dignity, the 9-to-10 favorite, to win the $611,800 Peter Haughton Memorial Pace for 2-year- olds tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: GEORGIA HISTORY, TAKING ALONG A COMPUTER
description: Exposition To Dramatize Savannah's Past In a restored brick train shed that once resounded to the hiss, chug and clangor of the locomotives and rail cars of the Central of Georgia Line, another sort of transportation is being prepared - a journey into the past.

title: AIR FORCE, MX IN DOUBT, SPEEDS A SMALLER MISSILE
description: With the MX nuclear missile in political jeopardy, the Air Force is hastening the development of a smaller intercontinental missile, according to Defense Department officials.

title: LIKE IT OR NOT, TWO SIDES SHARE A NEED FOR TALKS
description: WASHINGTON FOR a President who began his term with the warning that the Soviet Union will ''lie, cheat and steal'' to achieve its objectives, last week's shift in tone looked stunning. Even nonaligned diplomats were encouraged to hear Ronald Reagan appeal at the United Nations for ''a better working relationship'' with the Soviet Union and to declare that both sides should work ''to shorten the distance'' between them, especially on nuclear arms control.

title: COMIC INTERLUDE
description: Ask any follower of the game to name the most cosmopolitan annual tournament played anywhere, and he is almost certain to get the wrong answer. Tournaments in Europe and North America attract little participation from other continents. And the World Team Olympiad, scheduled in Seattle in November, is quadrennial not annual.

title: DIPLOMATS CAUTIOUSLY HOPEFUL ON GROMYKO'S TRIP
description: Tass announced today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had left Washington for home, and Western diplomats said they were encouraged by the Soviet reports of his meetings with the Reagan Administration.

title: Grenada Says Airport Will Open Next Month
description: Grenada's international airport will be officially opened to civilian aircraft next month, the Government announced this week.

title: Linda E. Johnson Plans to Be Wed To S. Andre Rice
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Johnson of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda E. Johnson, to S. Andre Rice, son of Ethel Mae Rice of New York. The wedding is planned for Nov. 2.

title: CEMENTING TIES THAT PAY OFF
description: LAST year Suesh and Bhawnesh Kapor, two brothers who came here from New Delhi in the mid-1970's, got a license from the Metropolitan Transit Authority to operate 143 subway newsstands. The Subway News Dealers Association, a group of 96 individual owners who had also bid for the contract, promptly filed suit, charging the M.T.A. with violating fair bidding practices.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Part of the secret of making decisions is to know which decisions not to make.'' - Governor Cuomo. (31:1.)

title: S.I. Child-Care Worker Faces Charges of Rape and Sodomy
description: A child-care worker at a New York Foundling Hospital group home on Staten Island was charged yesterday with raping one girl and sodomizing another at the hospital's group home in the Rosebank section.

title: MYTHS FOR THE MASTER RACE
description: CHILDREN'S LITERATURE IN HITLER'S GERMANY

title: COAST MAYOR SEEMS SET TO RUN AGAIN FOR 2 OFFICES
description: It would be hard to beat the kind of year Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles has had. He received wide recognition as a possible candidate for Vice President of the United States, he was widely credited as the man who brought the eminently successful Olympic Games to his city, and he saw his name go on a new $123 million international airport terminal.

title: MUSIC: VARIED PROGRAM OF MICROTONAL WORKS
description: If Thursday's concert of microtonal music at Christ and St. Stephen's Church never told us what precisely its subject matter was, it made clear what it wasn't. Its six composers, from varied backgrounds and periods, provided a united front against a common enemy - the impure, yet highly practical, system of tuning known as equal temperament, the aural compromise allowing free movement from key to key that has dominated music for the last two centuries.

title: IN SHORT
description: ''The civilized,'' Isak Dinesen wrote, ''must take lessons in silence from the wild before they are accepted by it.'' While she was referring specifically to hunting in her adopted Kenya, the remark hints at a deeper truth about African life. Survival comes from adapting to it rather than superimposing order on it. In ''The Grass Rain,'' which is set in emerging Kenya, Eduardo Garrigues portrays both approaches. In this accomplished first novel he examines how so-called civilized people, Western and African alike, have disrupted the rhythms of Kenyan life - its countryside, wildlife and social order. Mr. Garrigues has written a fictional counterpart to Dinesen's ''Out of Africa,'' a paean to Kenya's red-earthed beauty, a lyrical cry against its corruption. Into this he has woven a taut suspense story that trades on the narrative paradox of the hunter and the hunted. Set in 1977, the story opens when an American ecologist, Bob Fender, arrives in Nairobi and discovers that his friend John Murphy has been killed in a violent accident. What he fails to suspect is that Murphy, a C.I.A. agent bent on infiltrating the nation's opposition party, was murdered. Mistaken as Murphy's replacement - a misunderstanding perpetuated by the American Embassy - Fender proceeds to the National Park where he begins his research on its grasslands. In a series of unpleasant coincidences, Fender realized he's being used to lure culprits suspected of trafficking in contraband ivory and machine guns, the very means by which the opposition party hopes to topple the Government.

title: Milbry Polk Bride of Dr. P. A. Bauman
description: Milbry Catherine Polk, a daughter of Joan Cooledge Nemser of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. William Roe Polk of Vence, France, and Dallas, was married yesterday to Dr. Phillip Allen Bauman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bauman of South Salem, N.Y. The ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was performed by the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, its Dean.

The controversy over President Reagan's apparently impromptu remarks, during a campaign swing in Ohio, about the roots of intelligence and security failures in the Middle East and his subsequent explanatory telephone call to former President Carter, Democratic strategists said, could be signs that Mr. Reagan is not altogether invincible.

description: Normally, economists view a rise in business inventories as an optimistic sign for retail sales. But this may not be the case if the August inventory figures, due out Wednesday, show the big bulge that many expect.

title: THE REGION ; Paterson DecidesTo Keep His HatOn His Head

The former Deputy Mayor and New York Secretary of State said that for ''family and personal reasons,'' he had made the ''firm and irrevocable decision'' not to run for Mayor next year.

title: FINESSE MAKES THE CARTRIDGE
description: According to liberal points of view, there are many ways to get to heaven, even for audio engineers. Of course, every engineer insists that his way is the best. The designers of phono cartridges, for example, adhere to several creeds, each different from the other. One swears by moving-coil cartridges, another by the moving-magnet principle, while still others favor moving-iron types. As if to prove their case, partisans of each persuasion have lately come up with excellent models, leaving us to conclude that these products owe their quality not so much to their design principle as to the finesse with which the design is executed.

title: 'A HILL ON DARK SIDE OF THE MOON'
description: In view of the fact that it supposedly depicts two very serious 19th- century intellectuals, ''A Hill on the Dark Side of the Moon'' is surprisingly sappy. She (Gunilla Nyroos) is the brilliant mathematician Sonya Kovalevsky, a prize-winning scientist and the world's first woman university professor in her field. He (Thommy Berggren) is Maxim Kovalevsky, a fellow Russian exile who coincidentally shares the same last name, a radical scientist with a firm belief in feminism.

title: WEDGEWOOD SHOW OFFERS A TASTE OF HISTORY, VARIETY
description: AT the Hammond Museum in North Salem, ''All About Wedgwood'' lives up to its name, with 700 examples of just about every line produced by this famous pottery since its inception in 1759. Functional or ornamental, often both, the objects include vessels and dishes of all kinds as well as plaques, cameos, intaglios and small sculptures. This is the whole kit and caboodle of gracious living as it was practiced in England, first by the upper and merchant classes, and later by their emulators.

Now we have A TIME TO REAP (St. Martin's, $12.95), and it is a sequel to ''The Fields of Eden.'' It again gives us Emil Whippletree. Last time around he was the sheriff of a small Minnesota town. Now he is retired, but he has been asked by his successor to help out in a murder case. St. Cloud is not a community that has had much experience with murder.

''Diary for My Children'' will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 7 and tomorrow at 9:30.
