description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY OF HOMELESS CITES SPECIAL NEEDS
description: A profile of homeless people in New York City shelters has found a largely nonwhite population of middle-aged men and women who have settled into the shelters for nearly a year with little prospect of leaving.

title: SALES TAX RISE BUOYS SUFFOLK
description: A QUARTER of a penny increase in the county sales tax marks the beginning of the end to the seemingly endless crisis over the Southwest Sewer District, according to Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan.

title: FIRST HEARING FOR AN EARLY DEBUSSY PIANO TRIO
description: Claude Debussy went to Russia in 1880 as the personal pianist of Nadejda von Meck, the wealthy widow who was Tchaikovsky's patron. While there he composed a piano trio. Its composition never was a secret, and it is listed in standard reference works. The trouble is that nobody had ever heard the work; the manuscript had disappeared. But a few years ago the first movement surfaced in Paris, was auctioned and now is in the possession of the Morgan Library in New York.

title: THE NATION ; Panel DropsHatfield Case
description: Lacking evidence that Senator Mark O. Hatfield had misused his office in his dealings with a Greek businessman, the Senate ethics committee last week voted unanimously to end its informal investigation.

title: Barbara Forbes Is a Bride
description: Barbara Ellen Forbes, a daughter of Mrs. James Caryl Forbes of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Forbes, was married yesterday to Gary Thomas Phillips, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Phillips of Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Rev. George Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, assisted by the Rev. William Reynolds, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride's father was United States manager of the Bermuda Department of Tourism. The bridegroom's father, who is retired, was an automobile frame specialist for P. Scozzava Motors in Niagara Falls.

title: MAILBAG Missing Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Face Dickerson's Inside Moves
description: There is Lawrence Taylor, of course. But there are two other Giants, Andy Headen and Terry Kinard, who have special worth. These three - the two outside linebackers and the free safety - were praised last week by Jack Faulkner, who scouts future opponents for the Los Angeles Rams, the Giants' opponent today in Anaheim, Calif.

title: SCIENTIST'S POETRY BLENDS WITH ART
description: and has been since he left his formal post as president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center more than a year ago. But retirement doesn't mean a life of leisure for the noted biologist-writer, who admits to ''being 70 in my stocking feet.''

title: BEDSIDE MANNER STILL COUNTS
description: A NEW program at Yale University's School of Medicine has doctors taking a second look at their bedside manner.

title: HAARLEM: FOR ART, TULIPS AND MORE
description: Haarlem, capital of the province of North Holland, is just 13 miles west of Amsterdam. For travelers who care about architecture, art, music and food, such easy access is cozily convenient. Nevertheless, for some inexplicable reason, Haarlem - for which New York's Harlem is named - is too often visited superficially or overlooked entirely. It can easily be seen as a half-day trip from Amsterdam. Because Haarlem has several excellent restaurants and hotels, however, as well as many quaint byways to explore, it deserves at least an overnight stay.

title: CEZANNE AT PRINCETON MUSEUM
description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH the late Henry Pearlman of New York City started his art collection more than 25 years ago, he was able nonetheless to acquire an extraordinary number of prizes.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: -related organizations around the state are conducting special programs for the public throughout October, which has been designated Wellness Month by Governor O'Neill.

title: THE REGION ; A Dioxin RiskIs Played Down
description: Burning garbage in city incinerators would have only a negligible effect on New Yorkers' health, Mayor Koch argued last week. He released studies predicting that dioxin escaping from the first of eight proposed trash-burning plants would mean, at worst, an increase of fewer than six cancer deaths per million people who spent their lifetimes (70 years) breathing the air at the point of maximum exposure.

title: MORE RACHELS TRACED IN JEWISH HISTORY
description: '' IT was the primeval nature of the memory that was so touching; she was certain that all men had this Name within them, because all men were the Lord's creation. Indeed, she fancied that the Name that lived within her was what was alive, was what brought warmth and emotion to cold flesh and inert bone.''

title: ON THE ROAD, BUSH BECOMES THE MAN WHO WASN'T THERE
description: In just about every city George Bush visited during a four-day leisurely tour of the Middle West and Pennsylvania last week, there was an organized ritual with the local press that is fast becoming a hallmark of the Vice President's campaign repertory.

title:
DINING OUT;
A GALLIC STATEMENT IN NYACK
description: SINCE our review two years ago, Raoul's kitchen has had some ups and downs, and recent visits reveal that it has not quite yet recovered its equilibrium. One could, as we did, have a meal of accomplished dishes meriting a wholehearted two-star rating or a dinner adding up to a charitable Fair.

title: ABUNDANT CORNFIELDS BECKON AS PROSPECT OF DEEPER DEBT LOOMS
description: Raymond Tarvin stood by his kitchen window here and gazed out over the vast fields of corn stalks turning brown as far as the horizon in all directions. ''It's looking pretty fair,'' he said, ''pretty fair.''

title: WINFIELD WIDENS HIS LEAD
description: Making a determined effort to gain a distinction never expected of him, Dave Winfield took a 2-point lead over Don Mattingly yesterday in their race for the American League batting championship.

title: MOST OF DISPERSED HOUSING PROJECTS IN 87 CITIES ARE SAID TO BE SUCCESSES
description: Four years ago, James and Geri Morris and a dozen of their neighbors stood in the path of a bulldozer in what they considered a final effort to save their neighborhood. Mr. Morris stood there long enough to be arrested. The Chicago Housing Authority development they were protesting went up anyway.

title: PEKING MAKES FRANK FILM FOR CHINA ON HONG KONG
description: A new documentary color film that will open here next month starts with a look at Hong Kong's British past and ends with a glimpse of its future - a red flag fluttering against the backdrop of the colony's skyscrapers to the rousing strains of a patriotic song, ''Heart of the Chinese Nation.''

title: PREDICTING THE QUALITY OF THEIR LIVES
description: SELECTIVE NONTREATMENT OF HANDICAPPED NEWBORNS

title: Miss Blumenthal Weds Composer
description: At the Greens Farms Congregational Church in Westport, Conn., yesterday Victoria Blumenthal, the daughter of Mrs. Eli Eisner of Westport and the late Dan S. Blumenthal of New York was married to John Marshall Forster, a son of Mrs. William Hall Forster of Mystic, Conn., and the late Mr. Forster. The Rev. William Bryant performed the ceremony.

title: INVESTING ; KILLING THE PURVEYORS OF BAD NEWS
description: CORPORATIONS are about ready to begin the quarterly ritual of issuing earnings reports. But in the past few weeks, scores of companies have already let Wall Street know that their third-quarter earnings will be below those of last year's. And countless others have said that, while their earnings will be up, they will come nowhere near the levels that optimistic analysts had been predicting.

title: ONE-OUNCE PERSONS?
description: * To the Editor:

title: POLICIES RE SUGGESTED FOR BABY DOE CASES
description: AN infant was born at Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford this year with trisomy 18, a chromosomal condition in which the brain is not fully developed that kills most infants in three months.

title: THE WORLD ; Apartheid FalloutIn South Africa
description: Relations with Britain that are admittedly ''worse than delicate,'' persistent black boycotts of schools, tension and clashes between the police and demonstrators in the black township of Soweto and elsewhere. South Africa last week continued to harvest bitter fruit from a constitutional revision that gives people of mixed race or Indian ancestry limited representation in Parliament but denies the overwhelming black majority a share of power.

title: ART MEANT FOR BODIES,, NOT
description: WALLS

title: NATURE WATCH;
description: OVENBIRD

title: The Mission of Lawrence Taylor
description: It is regretful that N.F.L. owners have allowed themselves to be bulldozed by linebackers like Lawrence Taylor (''Search and Destroy: The Mission of Linebacker Lawrence Taylor,'' Aug. 26) into renegotiating contracts. As good as Taylor is, you may destroy team morale when you vow to a player to renegotiate and pay him an excessive amount of money.

title: YORK GUN PROGRAM IS PLACED ON HOLD
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today said he would not ask Congress for any more money to buy the Army's problem- plagued Sergeant York antiaircraft gun, pending the outcome of further tests.

title: WHAT IS THE CHURCH?
description: John M. Todd, a visiting professor in the Faculty of Theology, King's College, London University, is the author of ''Luther.'' THE CHRISTIAN TRADITION

title: Ann Terrien Has Nuptials
description: Ann Skakel Terrien, a daughter of George Terrien of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Georgeann Skakel Terrien, was married yesterday to Dr. Gregory Mark Closkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Closkey of Drexel Hill, Pa. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan and the Rev. Eugene Nolan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Butler Chapel at the Marymount Convent in Tarrytown, N.Y.
